The U.S. and China Reach a Trade Accord
American and Chinese negotiators reached an agreement to open China's economy to foreign competitors and make the world's most populous nation a full partner in international commerce. China would reduce various tariffs and lift many barriers to American banks, insurance and telephone companies. A1
 
The administration and business groups are working on a campaign to win Congressional approval of China's entry into the World Trade Organization. A1 

The issue of China in the W.T.O lays bare deep divisions among Republican presidential candidates on the nature of relations between the United States and China. A16
 
Reviewing a Bosnia Massacre
Secretary General Kofi Annan laid out in a self-critical report the tragic story of how the United Nations allowed the Bosnian Muslim "safe area" of Srebrenica to be overrun in July 1995 by Bosnian Serbs, who then systematically killed thousands of its men and boys. A3
 
Violence After Afghan Sanctions
Mobs in several Afghan cities have stepped up attacks and protests against the United Nations after international sanctions were imposed because of a refusal to turn over a Saudi-born Islamic militant to the United States, United Nations officials said. A6
 
Clinton's Nudge to Turkey
President Clinton praised Turkey's democratic progress in a speech to its Grand National Assembly, even as he nudged the country to strengthen its adherence to human rights. A6
 
Ulster Peace Effort Renewed
George J. Mitchell's mission to rescue the Northern Ireland peace settlement regained momentum as leaders of various parties voiced positive attitudes and a desire for accommodation. A14
 
Optimism on Nazi Slave Talks

World Briefing A6
 
NATIONAL A21-25
 
Cockpit Tape May Prompt F.B.I. to Take Over Inquiry
Government officials said the National Transportation Safety Board was considering asking the F.B.I. to take over the case of EgyptAir Flight 990, after a review of the cockpit voice recorder. The officials said they were focusing on a cryptic utterance, possibly a prayer. They said there were many questions about exactly what was said and what it meant, but they were concerned that the statement might be the last words of a pilot determined to destroy himself and the airplane. The crew's conversations, other than uneventful ones with air traffic controllers, were in Arabic, and senior officials of the safety board said that even with the aid of additional interpreters, they did not understand what was being said on the tape. A1

Congressional Republicans agreed to eliminate or change a series of pro-business amendments in the year's last spending bills, even though the measures had been sponsored by their own senators, effectively sweeping away the next-to-last barrier to a final budget deal. A24

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Close Little Changed Ahead of Fed Panel Meeting

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks closed little changed yesterday as investors waited for today's Federal Open Market Committee meeting that will decide the direction of interest rates.
"People were reluctant to take a stand one way or another for fear of being surprised by the Fed meeting when they just have a few hours to wait," said Michael Holland, chairman of Holland & Company in New York, which manages $50 million. 
 The market was hindered by Microsoft, which fell after a report in Barron's said the software company could be worth almost one-third less if antitrust enforcers broke it up.
"All the stuff going on with Microsoft is giving the market pause" because the company is so large, Mr. Holland said. "It can stop the upward movement of the market."
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 8.57 points, to 10,760.75. The Nasdaq composite index declined 1.61 points, to 3,219.54. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.67 points, to 1,394.39. All three market measures moved between small gains and losses during the session. Eight stocks rose for every seven that fell on the New York Stock Exchange. Some 793 million shares traded on the Big Board, about average for the last three months.
The Ameritrade Holding Corporation rose 4 7/16, to 26 7/16, and TD Waterhouse Group rallied 2 3/8, to 19. The discount brokers said they would form an online investment bank with the Charles Schwab Corporation in an effort to sell more shares of initial public offerings directly to retail investors. Schwab rose 2 1/4, to 43 1/4.
Microsoft dropped 2 1/8, to 87 1/16, its eighth decline in nine days. David Readerman, an analyst at Thomas Weisel Partners in San Francisco, told Barron's the value of the company's three major operations -- its Windows-related business, development and applications, and the Internet -- adds up to about $355 billion, 31 percent below its current market value.
Microsoft shares have fallen 5 percent since Nov. 5, when the judge found that Microsoft used its monopoly to squash competitors. The finding opened the way for sanctions that could include breaking up the company.
Global Crossing Ltd. rose 4 1/4, to 42 7/8, after saying it would form a $1.2 billion venture with Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. to offer Internet-related services in Hong Kong and later in mainland China.
Oak Industries soared 19, to 68 3/4, after Corning Inc. agreed to buy the telecommunications equipment maker for $2 billion in stock and debt. Corning, the maker of fiber optic cable, will exchange $75 of its common stock for each Oak share. The offer represented a 51 percent premium to Oak's closing price of 49 3/4 on Friday. Corning fell 3 1/4 to 87 1/8.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasuries Are Flat
 By Dow Jones
Treasuries were little changed in quiet trading yesterday, as most market participants stayed on the sidelines ahead of today's meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury rose 4/32, to 101 13/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.02 percent from 6.03 percent on Friday.
Trading activity was said to be on the cautious side yesterday. Both investors and dealers are wary of building new positions in bonds because it is still unclear whether the policy-making committee will raise interest rates. The decision will be announced around 2:15 p.m.
"Very few people are willing to take any risk" by creating new positions ahead of the committee meeting, said Yasunori Sugi, a trader at Fuji Bank Ltd. in New York.

HEADLINE: THE TRADE DEAL: THE OVERVIEW;
U.S. REACHES AN ACCORD TO OPEN CHINA ECONOMY AS WORLDWIDE MARKET

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM with DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 15

 BODY:
American and Chinese negotiators reached a landmark agreement today that would open the economy of China, the world's most populous nation, to foreign competitors and would also make it a full partner in the world's trading system.
After six days of arduous negotiations, the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, and China's trade minister, Shi Guangsheng, signed the papers at 3:50 p.m., shook hands and raised a Champagne toast to an agreement that capped 13 years of on-and-off negotiations on China's entry into the World Trade Organization. 
 Under the deal, Beijing would reduce tariffs on various industrial and agricultural products. It would also lift many of the barriers that have hamstrung American banks and insurance and telephone companies that want to expand their operations and investments in China.
In exchange, the United States agreed to support China's bid for membership in the global trade group, the 135-member organization that sets the rules for international commerce.
China still must complete agreements with the European Union, Canada and some developing countries, including Brazil, before its application can be taken up by the group's member states.
"Let me just say that this is a profound and historic moment in U.S.-China relations," said a clearly exultant Ms. Barshefsky, adding that the agreement would not only aid the economies of both countries, but also serve as an anchor in their tumultuous political relationship.
The last six days of day-and-night negotiations were conducted in a "win-win spirit," Mr. Shi said, "and finally we reached an agreement that serves the interests of both China and the United States."
For all the rejoicing, the agreement faces tough resistance in the United States, where it is opposed by labor unions and some critics of China. Congress will not vote on the deal itself, but must vote to put an end to its annual review of Chinese trade and to establish normal -- and permanent -- trade relations with Beijing.
For China, membership in the trade group would mean a long-sought acceptance into the "club" of world powers. The W.T.O.'s elaborate rules would help protect China from unfair trade policies abroad, but would also impose a body of international rules on China's own fitful progress toward a market economy.
The accord goes to the heart of China's transition to an open, market economy. It would put Beijing, for the first time, under the jurisdiction of the rules set by the World Trade Organization, which are enforced by a trade court.
Full membership would be a victory for President Jiang Zemin, who sees achieving economic modernization as his legacy even as he tries to ensure continuation of Communist rule. At the same time, membership would cheer the more liberal, reform-oriented factions led by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, since it locks China onto a path that could force China's state-owned industries to become efficient.
The step is a politically risky one for China, coming at a time when those state-run companies are already shedding millions of workers.
For President Clinton, today's agreement provides a badly needed centerpiece to his fraying policy of engagement with China, offering the prospect of tangible gains to many companies and to consumers. It is also a stunning recovery from what his own top aides describe as a huge mistake: his decision to walk away from the surprisingly sweeping deal, largely identical to today's, offered in April by Mr. Zhu.
After the signing today, Ms. Barshefsky and Gene Sperling, the White House chief of economic policy -- who opposed the April deal and attended the talks as a symbol of Mr. Clinton's renewed commitment -- were driven to the secluded leadership compound for a brief meeting with Mr. Jiang, who twice in the past month conducted telephone talks with Mr. Clinton.
Speaking in Turkey today, Mr. Clinton said: "I think this is a good agreement for China, for America and for the world."
But Mr. Clinton's struggle to make this accord a central foreign policy achievement is far from over.
Congress will essentially review the accord when it prepares to vote on the biggest single American concession: granting permanent trading rights to China rather than reviewing those rights annually, a Capitol Hill ritual that has turned into an annual debate about human rights and arms proliferation.
Mr. Clinton has spoken often of "integrating China into the world economy" and gradually getting the country to embrace "the rule of law," starting with commercial law. But without closing a World Trade Organization agreement, his aides said, he would have little progress to point to.
The agreement may also help to repair the damage done to Chinese-American relations by charges of Chinese spying in the United States, the American bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade in May and China's continuing suspicion that the United States is attempting to "contain" Chinese military and economic power.
"Successful completion of W.T.O. will go a long way to smooth out some of the extreme oscillation that we have seen in Sino-American relations in recent years," said Joseph Fewsmith, a China expert at Boston University. "I think it gives us a chance to build some substance into a relationship that has been badly damaged."
Today's agreement is a huge step toward membership for China, but it very likely comes too late, experts said, for China to be admitted before Nov. 30, when a new round of global trade talks begins in Seattle.
But today's accord means that China can take a larger role in setting the agenda there. And past trade rounds have lasted for years.
From the beginning, the American goal was not just to press China for large reductions in tariffs on imported farm products and industrial goods like automobiles. In measures that may ultimately have a far more profound impact, China had to commit itself to allowing foreign companies to take majority investments in many industrial and service sectors.
The final six days, and usually nights, of negotiations went through several rough spots. Several times Ms. Barshefsky and Mr. Sperling suggested they were packing up to leave, threats Ms. Barshefsky said in an interview today were "largely tactical, to force the Chinese to make some progress."
"Clearly," she said, "they were not going to let us leave."
In an interview from Hong Kong today, Ms. Barshefsky said that the key Chinese player in the talks appeared to be Prime Minister Zhu, who twice stepped in to break an impasse and ultimately directed his negotiators to make several key concessions -- allowing American companies to take a 50 percent stake in China's booming telecommunications companies, for example. But all his decisions, analysts here said, were almost certainly cleared by the top party leadership.
The outlines of an agreement had been worked out last April, when Mr. Zhu visited Washington. But President Clinton backed away from any agreement at the time, fearing Congressional opposition. Most of today's pact follows the April understandings, and in resolving areas of continued dispute, Ms. Barshefsky asserted -- in a statement sure to be scrutinized by skeptics in Congress -- "I think we achieved an overall strengthening of this agreement."
The agreement involves a general reduction in China's import tariffs from the current average of 22.1 percent down to 17 percent, with tariffs on major American farm products cut sharply to 15 percent or less.
Tariffs on automobile imports, which now range up to 100 percent to protect China's inefficient producers, would be reduced over a six-year period to 25 percent, with the quickest reduction in the initial years. That is one year longer than China offered in April.
But equally important, American officials said, foreign auto companies and banks would for the first time be able to offer consumer loans for cars, a critical concession in a country where few can lay out the money for such a large purchase.
Thus, Chinese consumers may soon be buying General Motors cars, for example, with the "G.M.A.C." loans so familiar to Americans.
Two of the most contentious issues in recent days, Ms. Barshefsky said, involved the American demands for ways to respond to surges of imports into the United States and for use of a method to identify when the Chinese might be illegally selling products below cost, or "dumping."
China wanted such measures to phase out quickly, but in the end agreed to surge protections for a 12-year period, and the anti-dumping regime for 15 years. Without those concessions, Ms. Barshefsky told her Chinese counterparts, Congress could easily balk at the accord.
For the first time, China also agreed to allow foreign companies to distribute their own goods, rather than forcing them to distribute food or industrial components through Chinese companies. They would also be able to repair and support their products directly.
In terms of textiles, one of the most politically sensitive topics in the United States, it was the Americans calling for restrictions on free trade. The Chinese wanted to scale back the American demand to continue existing textile import quotas for another 10 years. In the end, the United States agreed to end quotas after five years, but with special anti-surge safeguards for another four years after that.
The anti-dumping and textile provisions are charged issues for Vice President Al Gore. He hopes to keep the support of organized labor in his presidential bid, but such groups oppose the trade accord.
Foreign investment in China's telecommunications sector had become a sore point inside China, where some saw it as an issue of national security. The Americans fought for 51 percent ownership rights -- which Mr. Zhu had offered in April -- but finally agreed that foreign firms could take up to 50 percent ownership of companies in this booming sector, beginning two years after China enters the trade organization.
"It became clear that this was an incredibly emotional issue for the Chinese," Mr. Sperling said in an interview.
Important provisions would open Chinese retail banking to foreign firms over several years, and also improve market access for insurance companies, and legal and accounting firms. But the American negotiators got far less in China's infant and high-risk financial securities market, where they would be limited to minority stakes in activities like underwriting stock issues.
For China -- which is still unraveling the legacy of Mao Zedong's cloistered, command economy -- entry into the World Trade Organization will carry profound implications.
Many economists here compare entry to Deng Xiaoping's landmark opening of the economy to market forces and foreign influence in the late 1970's.
"The opening of China to the outside world began with Mao Zedong's meeting with Richard Nixon in 1972," said Hu Angang, a leading economist here at the Chinese Academy of Sciences. "The second major stage was marked by Deng Xiaoping's visit to the United States in 1979."
"Joining W.T.O. will represent a whole new stage in China's opening to the world," he said. "It will signify a shift from partial to comprehensive opening and reform," he said, "and a shift from an opening based on domestic rules to an opening based on internationally defined rules."
China's embrace of more open markets reflects the desire of President Jiang and other top leaders to push ahead with a radical overhaul of the domestic economy, opening it to global competition and bringing in more foreign capital and technology.
President Jiang and his fellow Communist Party leaders see economic transformation as vital if China is to become a great power in the century ahead. They also know that if they do not provide steadily rising incomes to their people, the party's rule is in trouble.
So the renewed opening is perhaps unavoidable, but it is a risky step for the leaders, who can expect to see some cherished state enterprises crushed even as others are energized. In the short run, at least, already impoverished farmers may be harmed by cheap imports and more urban workers might lose their jobs.
The impact of today's agreement on the power of Mr. Zhu, who is nominally number three in the party hierarchy, is unclear. Over the last six months or so, his influence appeared to slip, as the country took a more conservative and nationalistic turn, and Mr. Jiang took a stronger role in economic matters. By many accounts, Mr. Zhu lost his former control over policy on the World Trade Organization and the reform of state enterprises.
But Ms. Barshefsky said today that in a phone call between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang last month, "Jiang said that Zhu Rongji is in charge of these negotiations."
"And," she said, "it looked very much as if he had taken ownership of it."
Today's agreement put Mr. Zhu and his ideas back in the limelight, but Chinese television reports this evening featured President Jiang, and both Chinese and foreign analysts continue to speculate about power shifts in the secretive Communist hierarchy.
On paper, the changes China has promised are breathtaking in scope. But even the most optimistic American officials concede that threatened ministries and provinces are likely to find ways to delay implementation of many provisions. This suspicion is likely to feed controversy in the United States about the pact.
Still, both Democrats and Republicans say the agreement will almost certainly be approved in Congress sometime early next year, after a spirited debate.

(Stephen Shaver/Agence France-Presse)(pg. A17)
 
Chart: "AT A GLANCE: Key Points of the Agreement"
 
TELECOMMUNICATIONS -- Foreign telephone companies may own 49 percent of Chinese telephone service providers, increasing to 50 percent in two years. The United States had wanted 51 percent.
 
INTERNET -- Foreigners may invest in Chinese Internet businesses.
 
DISTRIBUTION -- Foreigners may establish their own product distribution systems and sell directly to Chinese consumers.
 
SERVICES -- Foreigners may establish their own repair and maintenance service businesses in China.
 
ENTERTAINMENT -- China will double the number of foreign film imports to 20 annually.
 
BANKING/FINANCIAL SERVICES -- Foreign banks may offer services to Chinese customers in two years. China will allow foreigners to own 33 percent of other financial service providers, and later 49 percent.
 
VEHICLE SALES -- China will reduce taxes on imports and permit foreign carmakers to sell and finance sales to Chinese customers.
 
TARIFFS -- China will reduce average tariffs from 22.1 percent to 17.
 
FARM PRODUCTS -- China will eliminate subsidies of exports.
 
TEXTILES -- The United States will abandon quotas on Chinese textile imports in 2005.
 
ANTI-DUMPING -- The United States will retain safeguards for 12 years to prevent a surge in inexpensive Chinese imports. (pg. A17)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

China to Open Its Economy Under Landmark Trade Deal
United States and Chinese negotiators agreed to open China's economy to foreign competitors and make the world's most populous nation a full partner in international commerce.
Under the deal, Beijing would reduce tariffs on industrial and agricultural products and lift many of the barriers in the way of American companies. In exchange, the United States agreed to support China for membership in the World Trade Organization. Page A1.
 
Mike Moore, the head of the World Trade Organization, cautioned that several steps remained before China could become a full-fledged member. C11. 

Shares of Chinese and China-related companies surged as investors concluded that the trade agreement would help Chinese companies more than hurt them. C12.
 
Uprising Widens Over A.T.M. Fees
After two California cities banned banks from charging non-customers for using their automated teller machines, many other cities are said to be considering similar bans. And the banking industry is fighting to squelch the uprising before it gathers more steam. A1.
 
Toys 'R' Us Profit Increases 55%
Toys "R" Us posted a 55 percent jump in third-quarter earnings on strong sales of video games, Pokemon cards and other products, easily beating Wall Street expectations. The company benefited from popular products like the Sega Dreamcast computer system and from the introduction of Pokemon game leagues in all of its stores. Shares of Toys "R" Us rose $1.4375, to $17.9375. C2.
 
Stocks Flat Ahead of Fed Decision
Stocks closed little changed as investors waited for today's Federal Reserve decision on interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 8.57 points, to 10,760.75. The Nasdaq composite index declined 1.61 points, to 3,219.54. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.67 points, to 1,394.39. C16.
 
Coke Bottler Reassures Investors
Coca-Cola Enterprises, Coca-Cola's largest bottler, told investors and money managers in a rare conference call that its decision to raise retail prices earlier this year should improve the company's cash flow and profitability despite a drop in volume. C8.
 
Gates Says He Backs Consumers
At the Comdex technology conference, William H. Gates tried to portray Microsoft as a company that wants to give consumers choices in how they use computers and get on line. But most attendees were skeptical. C2.
 
Vice President Al Gore told hundreds of Microsoft employees that competition is fundamentally a good thing. A22.
 
Rite Aid Names a New Chairman
Rite Aid said that it had named Leonard Green its chairman in hopes he could revive the company, which also said that KPMG International had resigned as its auditor. Rite Aid is restating results of the last three years. C15.
 
Gucci Group to Buy Sanofi Beaute
In the latest step in the growing consolidation of the European fashion and luxury-goods industries, Gucci Group said that it would buy Sanofi Beaute for about $700 million in cash to gain control of Yves Saint Laurent. The deal represents the first major step by Gucci's chief executive, Domenico De Sole, to fulfill his ambition of creating a luxury group of many brands that is large enough to challenge the industry leader, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton. C6.
 
Borders Names a Chief Executive
Borders went outside the book industry for a chief executive, appointing Greg Josefowicz, a food and drugstore executive. C14.

HEADLINE: Chinese Stocks Surge 9% On the Hong Kong Market

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Shares of Chinese and China-related companies surged here today as investors concluded that a landmark trade agreement between the United States and China -- and the competition it promises -- would help Chinese companies more than it would hurt them.
The Hong Kong Stock Exchange's "red chip" index, which tracks the performance of Hong Kong-based, Chinese-controlled companies, soared 9.8 percent after the news broke that American and Chinese negotiators had achieved a deal in Beijing after six days of talks. The H share index, which tracks companies based in mainland China, jumped 9.69 percent. 
 Hong Kong's broader Hang Seng index rose 2.64 percent, to close at 14,564.79 -- its highest close in more than two years. Shares also rose strongly on the stock exchanges in Shanghai and Shenzhen, though not as spectacularly as China-related stocks in the Hong Kong market.
 The Hong Kong market was stronger in morning trading on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng up seven-tenths of a percent at noon.
Analysts said that the trade agreement, which removes a major barrier to China's entry into the World Trade Organization, would strengthen Chinese companies, simply by exposing them to competition. Although few details of the agreement have been disclosed, officials said it would open China's telecommunications, banking and insurance industries to American companies.
"If China joins the trading world, its companies are going to be forced to change," said Andy Xie, an economist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter here.
Such optimism is far from conventional wisdom in mainland China. Indeed, a main reason this trade agreement took so long to reach was that some Chinese government officials feared that the country's state-owned corporations -- many of them bloated relics of a command economy -- would be thrashed by more nimble rivals from the United States or Europe.
Those fears have not gone away. But Mr. Xie said they were outweighed by the prospect that foreign companies could help Chinese companies as partners or investors. One of the oft-mentioned candidates for such a partnership, China Telecom (Hong Kong) Ltd., recorded an 8.5 percent increase in its shares.
China Telecom is a prime example of a company that could be transformed by China's entry into the World Trade Organization. As the dominant player in China's burgeoning mobile phone business, it would be an instant candidate for an alliance with a European or American cellular carrier, when outsiders are allowed to own stakes in Chinese telecommunications providers.
As if to dramatize that point, one of Hong Kong's leading telecommunications providers, Hutchinson Whampoa Ltd., announced a $1.2 billion joint venture today with Global Crossing Ltd., the operator of a worldwide fiber optic network. The new venture, to be called China Crossing, will build a high-speed fiber optic voice and data network, initially in Hong Kong but later aiming at the mainland China market.
Some analysts contend that Chinese fears of foreign competition are overblown. American companies have stumbled in China in businesses as diverse as insurance and beer, and not always because of trade barriers.
"The obstacles to making money in China are not just those that have to be removed as part of W.T.O. accession," said Richard Margolis, a regional strategist at Merrill Lynch here. He cited issues like pricing and marketing.
Not all the Chinese companies that benefited from today's announcement are on the frontier of technology or communications. Two old-style shipping companies, Cosco Pacific and China Shipping Development, recorded 12 percent and 13.69 percent increases in their shares, respectively, because of hopes that the trade pact would expand the amount of cargo flowing between the United States and China.
Mr. Xie said the agreement also raised the odds that several big Chinese state-owned companies would be able to issue shares in the Hong Kong market the next year. Beijing hopes to raise more than $20 million by offering shares in companies like China National Petroleum and the Bank of China.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: DEAL ON U.N. DUES BREAKS AN IMPASSE AND DRAWS CRITICS

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
A fragile deal between the White House and House Republicans to end a fight over abortion and United Nations dues drew scathing criticism today from abortion rights advocates and cutting reviews from Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley.
Both sides today claimed victory after breaking an impasse that will free nearly $1 billion that the United States owes the United Nations, an issue that threatened to undermine America's global reputation and a year-end budget agreement. 
 The deal still has a few crucial loose ends, like the timing of the repayment of the back dues and a dispute over debt relief to the world's most impoverished nations.
But its central element would put into law a ban on United States money going to international organizations that promote abortion rights. Until the agreement is completed, the long-term impact of the measure remains uncertain.
For now, the compromise appears to pave the way to end a long-running dispute that has threatened to strip the United States of its vote in the United Nations General Assembly unless it pays before Dec. 31. The seat and vote in the Security Council are not affected.
The criticism from Mr. Bradley and Mr. Gore underscore Mr. Gore's desire to avoid giving his Democratic rival any opening to exploit. As Mr. Gore's presidential campaign heats up, he has been more willing to take positions that diverge from President Clinton's.
Speaking to employees at Microsoft in Seattle today, Mr. Gore would not directly answer whether he supported the deal brokered by a White House House deputy chief of staff, Steve Ricchetti. "I do not favor bargaining away any critical policy aspect of a women's right to choose," Mr. Gore said.
A senior Gore adviser said the vice president had expressed "strong reservations" about the deal, and while heaping most of the blame on Republicans said Mr. Gore "opposed what the White House ended up doing."
While Mr. Gore has tried to distance himself from Mr. Clinton on the issue of the president's personal conduct, this policy is probably the one on which he has set his own position most distinctly.
Under a compromise struck late Sunday, a ban on United States financing to international organizations that promote abortion rights would be written into law, but only for one year, a triumph for House conservatives led by Representative Christopher H. Smith, Republican of New Jersey, who for three years has insisted on conditioning the payment of the United Nations dues on these terms.
Under the agreement, the bill includes $385 million that a State Department agency, the Agency for International Development, awards to women's health groups abroad. The two sides agreed that if Mr. Clinton invoked a waiver so the money would go to those groups, $12.5 million, just over 3 percent of the total, would be removed and given to a separate children's health fund, also administered by the Agency for International Development.
If the deal is completed, Mr. Clinton is expected to invoke such a waiver.
Mr. Smith and his colleagues had initially sought to restrict the full $385 million, then later tried to set the amount diverted at $100 million.
If Mr. Clinton invokes a waiver, the agreement caps at $15 million the total amount of money that the United States would give to organizations that perform abortions or lobby for changes in abortion laws overseas.. Administration officials said it was unlikely the cap would be met and health services would be only minimally affected. But abortion-rights supporters said the provision would have a chilling effect on family-planning activities overseas, from sponsoring conferences to publishing safe-sex pamphlets.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who has aggressively lobbied Mr. Clinton to repay Washington's debt and has volunteered to be the lightning rod for criticism from abortion rights groups, defended the compromise.
"The agreement that I hope will come out will not interfere with family planning around the world and that it will have minimal effect," Dr. Albright told reporters traveling with Mr. Clinton in Turkey.
Abortion rights advocates denounced the deal as a sellout of principle to appease a small band of Republicans, which will endanger the lives of women in developing countries who rely on international family planning groups.
"Women's lives have once again been sacrificed for political expediency," said Gloria Feldt, president of Planned Parenthood Federation of America, which uses less than 1 percent of its funds for abortion services.
Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, Democrat of New York, who telephoned the White House chief of staff, John Podesta, to demand a meeting on Tuesday, said, "Administration negotiators paid an unjustifiable, high-cost ransom to a small number of extreme-right, anti-choice lawmakers."
The Agency for International Development says that family planning programs, which it oversees, have helped prevent unintended pregnancies in more than 70 countries, and have increased the use of contraceptives in those countries to 40 percent from 10 percent 34 years ago.
Some Democrats expressed pessimism about reaching a final deal.
"The more I get into the details, the more difficult it is to resolve," said Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the senior Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee. "We've got too much talking on camera, including by the secretary of state."
The issue exploded on the campaign trail today as a potentially divisive issue between the two Democratic presidential candidates.
A spokeswoman for Mr. Bradley, Kristen Ludecke, said the former New Jersey senator opposed the tentative deal and cited his remarks on Sunday.
"I would not support it if I was there," Mr. Bradley said on CNN's "Late Edition." "A woman's right to choose is absolutely essential, and I think family planning for the rest of the world, if we wanted to provide it, should be permissible."
House conservatives expressed cautious optimism that they had won their biggest victory on the issue since Mr. Clinton rescinded a 1984 executive order by President Ronald Reagan that denied grants to international organizations for any purpose if they promoted abortion rights.
The United States has barred direct financing for abortions since 1973, but Mr. Reagan advanced that policy by adopting what has become known as "Mexico City" because he announced the executive order during a United Nations conference there.
"It's as close as we've been to reinstating the language of Mexico City since Bill Clinton became president," said Michele Davis, a spokeswoman for Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader.
Mindy Tucker, a spokeswoman for Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican presidential front-runner, said Mr. Bush "would support reinstating the executive order banning the use of taxpayer money to promote abortions in foreign countries."
The agreement is tied to a separate bill that would authorize the State Department to repay the $926 million debt to the United Nations over three years. The first installment from that bill combined with money from a second spending bill, that covers the costs of the Commerce, State and Justice departments, would be enough to prevent Washington from losing its General Assembly vote, administration officials said.
"U.S. foreign policy is on a little firmer ground with this news," said Linda S. Jamison, executive director of the Emergency Coalition for U.S. Financial Support of the United Nations.
Two of Mr. Clinton's key Senate allies, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, and Joseph R. Biden, the senior Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee, also voiced support for the deal.
"Somebody has to give, and there is give here on both sides," said Mr. Daschle. "It's a pretty good deal."
In defending the deal, administration officials said they could shield international groups from financial cuts by defining which organizations are affected and how lobbying for abortions rights is defined.
Moreover, they said the deal expires after a year, when all sides agreed the fight would be joined again.

HEADLINE: THE TRADE DEAL: THE CHINESE;
Joy, Worry and Indifference in Streets of Beijing

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Many Chinese were pinching themselves this afternoon, filled with disbelief that after more than a decade of false starts, China had actually taken the plunge into the international economy, signing a landmark trade agreement with the United States.
On a chilly gray afternoon in Beijing, many people were ebullient when they first heard the news. For most people, it raised the prospect of new opportunities to make money as well as new chances to consume. The agreement drops many current restrictions on trade and investment and reduces import taxes. 
 "It's signed?" said Li Dayong, 29, who works for an American pharmaceutical firm. "That's great! I'm thrilled! We've been wanting this for so many years."
Some took a macro view, welcoming the treaty as a sign of bigger things: China's new economic muscle, an immutable commitment to further economic reform and a renewal of relations with the United States that had been ravaged by the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade in May.
But Beijingers also seemed keenly aware that there will be individual winners and losers along China's new path. Most are paying careful attention to the micro view, calculating what the trade agreement -- which is widely expected to lead to World Trade Organization membership -- means for them.
"This is great news: I had planned to change my Daewoo for a better car soon and now I'll buy an imported American one," said Xu Yiang, a stock investor, referring to the car he now owns.
Mr. Xu said he also plans to change his investment strategy, buying telecommunications stocks that he deems likely to attract foreign investment.
But Luan Wenqiang, a worker at the Beijing Light Truck Company, predicted that the agreement would drive him out of his already tenuous job. "Our factory is already in bad shape," he said. "Most workers are on leave and are called back only when there is work to do. This will open China to better and cheaper U.S. trucks. I don't believe we will survive."
Under the agreement, duties on imported vehicles will drop dramatically, from the current rate of 80 to 100 percent.
For the hundreds of millions of Chinese who farm the land or work as low-wage laborers in small cities and towns, today's triumphant treaty was a big bang in another universe -- although many will probably feel its effects.
Half a dozen migrant workers interviewed in Beijing said they had never heard of the trade organization, which has had only fleeting recent mention in the press despite the frantic negotiations here.
"It has nothing to do with my life," said a middle-aged man, a worker in a small machine factory, strapping a huge box of cabbage to the back of an ancient bicycle.
The new treaty will certainly bring both new investment and intense competition to China and the outcome will vary from industry to industry. But many corporate leaders seemed to relish the challenge of being able to compete in the world arena.
"I'm extremely happy to hear about this," said Duan Yongji, the Chairman of China's giant Stone Group, a technology company. "Everyone knows that entry will make the country more open and that will bring more competitive pressure.
"But we shouldn't need a greenhouse to protect us. And we also hope that entry will open more opportunities for collaboration and cooperation between Chinese and foreign companies."
Mr. Duan added that, at a personal level, he was relieved to hear the government renew its vows, so to speak, to principles like economic overhaul and engagement with the West. The Chinese government has often appeared lukewarm on such concepts.
In Beijing's business districts, many owners of small businesses likewise focused more on the opportunities of today's deal than its risks.
Many foreign companies have opened offices here in the last five years -- though their activities were extremely circumscribed by Chinese law -- gambling that this huge economy would one day open. Today people dared to imagine the payoff.
Li Dayong, an American drug company employee, said that until today his company has not been able to import many of its medicines to China. "Now I think it should become easier to bring foreign medical products in," he said.
Dai Liming, 35, well dressed in a sweater vest and suit, saw only possibilities when he heard the news. Mr. Dai, who works as a representative for a domestic trading company, predicted that "the deal will bring my company new opportunities for foreign trade."
But others offered more sober assessments, noting that many of China's service industries -- from insurance to the Internet to personal banking -- are young and ill prepared to compete on the world stage.
"We are already facing fierce competition from foreign companies in some areas and if further concessions are made in the insurance sector we'll be facing a grimmer future," said Lu Youquan, manager of Antai Life Insurance Company in Shanghai.

HEADLINE: City's Teachers Perform Poorly On State Exams

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Not only does New York City have a disproportionate number of uncertified teachers, but those who do pass the state certification exams tend to score much lower than their counterparts in the suburbs and upstate, according to state data that is to be placed into evidence today in a landmark school-financing case.
The data shows that 31 percent of teachers in the city's public schools failed the main certification exam -- the liberal arts and sciences test -- at least once, compared with only 4.7 percent of teachers elsewhere in the state. About 47 percent of city teachers who took the state certification test for math failed at least once, compared with about 21 percent of teachers elsewhere. And 26.9 percent of city teachers who took the state test that measures elementary teaching skills failed, compared with 3 percent elsewhere. 
 The plaintiffs in the case say the statistics show that prospective teachers who excel on the certification exams gravitate toward the more selective suburban systems, where they can command salaries much higher than city schools offer. The starting salary for New York City teachers is $30,807 -- roughly 25 percent less than starting salaries in affluent suburban counties like Westchester and Suffolk.
The plaintiffs cautioned yesterday that the data did not reflect the scores of all 75,000 teachers in the New York City school system, because the state has tracked the scores of city teachers only since 1989. But they said the data provided a comprehensive look at the qualifications of city teachers, and maintained that the city's failure to attract better teachers was the result of its low pay scales and poor working conditions.
"This shows what everyone has known intuitively for a long time," said Joseph Wayland, the plaintiffs' chief lawyer, "which is that New York City is simply not attracting the most qualified teachers. It shows that New York City doesn't have enough money, so it is forced to buy an inferior teacher product."
The civil lawsuit, which is being heard by Justice Leland DeGrasse of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, is the most serious challenge yet to the state's system of financing public schools.
The plaintiffs, a coalition of advocacy groups called the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, contend that city schools need significantly more state aid to provide the "sound, basic education" required by the State Constitution.
Under the current formula, the city gets 35.5 percent of the state's education aid even though it enrolls 38 percent of the state's public school children, according to the lawsuit; increasing the city's share of aid to 38 percent would provide $318 million more annually.
In particular, the plaintiffs contend that the state does not provide New York City with enough money to meet rigorous new curriculum standards.
But lawyers for the state have said the new standards represent "exceptionally high aspirations" and students are required to receive only a "minimally adequate" education under the State Constitution. The Legislature already provides more than enough aid for city students to meet that goal, the lawyers say.
Darren Dopp, a spokesman for the state attorney general's office, said he had no comment on the test score data because state lawyers had not seen it.
Prospective teachers usually take their certification tests toward the end of college, or, if they are becoming teachers later in life, in the months before they apply for a job. If they fail, they may still be hired, but they are expected to take the tests again during their first year.
If they have not passed the tests after four years, the state usually removes them from the system, although New York City has gotten waivers in recent years to allow uncertified teachers to stay in the system longer.
Board of Education officials did not dispute the data. They said they were developing recruitment strategies that they hoped would lure more talented teachers to the struggling system.
But Lewis H. Spence, the deputy schools chancellor for operations, said the city would never attract enough qualified teachers unless it significantly increased starting salaries, which are negotiated by the teachers' union and City Hall, not the Board of Education.
"The data confirms our worst fears," said Mr. Spence, who added that New York City does not require teacher applicants to submit their certification test scores. "When you are the least competitive urban school system in the country in terms of teacher salary, you suffer terribly in terms of the average level of preparation and qualification."
Officials at the United Federation of Teachers complained that the data did not provide an accurate picture because it focused on scores from only the last 10 years. But Randi Weingarten, the union president, agreed that the data showed that the city pays teachers far too little.
"Our teachers are dedicated and hard-working," Ms. Weingarten said in a statement. "But it is true that as the salary gap has grown between our system and suburban areas, more and more teachers who have joined the school system in the last 10 years have come in without full qualifications or academic preparation."
About 12 percent, or 10,000, of the city's teachers are uncertified. Because senior teachers can often choose which schools they teach in, many of the uncertified teachers work in the schools with the poorest children and the lowest student performance. The data to be submitted as testimony today shows that even many of the certified teachers in those schools just barely passed their certification exams.
The data, which was analyzed by Hamilton Lankford, an economics professor at the State University of New York in Albany, also shows that city teachers in schools with large numbers of white students generally scored much higher on the certification tests than those in schools whose student bodies were overwhelmingly black and Hispanic.
Several national studies have suggested that having certified teachers is a better guarantee of high student achievement than several other factors, including small class size.
But Arthur Levine, the president of Teachers College at Columbia University, said it was not clear whether the teachers with the highest scores on certification exams were better than those with mediocre scores.
"What the research shows," he said, "is that uncertified teachers do less well in the classroom than certified teachers."
The new data comes at a time when the state is setting higher standards for teachers and education schools.
State officials say that tougher teaching standards are necessary if students are to meet challenging new educational standards, including more difficult reading and math tests and a requirement that high school students pass Regents exams in five subject areas.
Beginning in the current school year, at least 80 percent of the students who graduate from New York State teaching programs must pass the state licensing exam for teachers or that teaching school can be put on probation for three years and then shut down.
At least two dozen of New York's 113 teacher education programs are in danger of losing their accreditation, including several at the City University of New York.
According to the data compiled for the school-financing lawsuit, 45 percent of New York City teachers earned their college degrees from CUNY. The new standards are expected to have a major effect in the next five years, as about half of the city's teaching force becomes eligible for retirement.
"We are going to have to replace them with teachers hired at a time when we are at the worst competitive disadvantage of any major school system in country," Mr. Spence said.
"There is no question that we need better teacher pay if we want not just a decent, but an outstanding public education system."
