HEADLINE: After Med School, the A B C's of Insurance

SERIES: LIFE, DEATH AND MANAGED CARE: 'Something Has to Give' -- Third of four articles.

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
The investigators came late last January, on a Thursday. They were deliberately cryptic. All they would tell St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center was that they were looking into a possible violation of the federal "anti-dumping" law, which prohibits hospitals from refusing to at least examine and stabilize patients who cannot pay. It was serious business. Only a handful of cases were investigated each year. Not until the investigators left did the hospital learn what it was all about.
The previous July, a French woman in her 40's had come to the emergency room with abdominal pain. Pelvic cancer was suspected, and she was admitted to the obstetrics and gynecology floor, where the diagnosis was confirmed. A private doctor, along with the house staff, attended to her. The doctor concluded that she needed surgery within several weeks followed by chemotherapy. The woman had no insurance. The senior physician discharged her, and left a note on the woman's chart saying she had instructed her to obtain health insurance or go to a public hospital. 
 Investigators determined that when the woman left the hospital, on Manhattan's West Side, she had barely been able to walk. That same day, she went to Bellevue Hospital Center, a city facility, where surgeons operated immediately. Officials there felt the woman had been treated unlawfully by St. Luke's-Roosevelt and complained to the State Health Department.
The agency's investigators spent five days at St. Luke's and issued a harsh report criticizing the care of the French woman but also identifying much else they didn't like -- tardy treatment of patients in the E.R., poor record-keeping, uninsured patients being told they would have to pay at least $400 and then leaving the E.R. without being examined. The hospital was ordered to put new policies into effect or be cut off Medicare, an action that, in effect, would close it down.
Hospital administrators felt their decision on the uninsured woman had been a judgment call -- that she was not in imminent danger and had time to make arrangements to enter another hospital -- although they acknowledged that doctors should have helped her transfer. And the documentation was sloppy. The hospital believed the woman had been given more care than her chart indicated.
In March, new procedures took effect in the E.R. Dr. Edward Lathan heard about them at the weekly department meeting. The supervisors didn't dive right into the issue: First there was a presentation about assessing a patient's airway to determine the difficulty of inserting a breathing tube. Slides were shown of potential patients. Hillary Clinton's face flicked on the screen. "Easy for the anatomy, difficult because of the hype," one intern volunteered. Prince Charles ("May have receding mandible and therefore difficult"). Linus ("His head is too big for his body").
Then an administrator related the case of the French woman. He told the residents that under no circumstances was anyone to be turned away again for lack of money.
A third-year resident spoke up: "This is similar to what we do every day in the E.R. Someone comes in and needs a root canal and has no insurance. I say, 'You can go to our dental clinic, but you'll get a bill. I suggest you go to a city hospital,' and I give them some names."
"And you're not going to say that anymore," he was told. "I have been informed that our clinics will see any and all referrals from the E.R." (Actually, this might have been more than the regulators were insisting on, but the hospital wanted to do too much rather than too little.)
As Dr. Lathan began his shift that day, changes were already manifest. At the check-in counter, there had been phones and a list of managed-care companies' phone numbers so patients could call for authorization. The insurers wanted these phones, and of course the hospital did, too, for they made reimbursement easier. The Health Department, however, saw them as an impediment to care. The lists were stripped away. The phones were dismantled. No longer was there to be any discussion of money before a patient was examined. At a time when everything about medicine seemed to come down to money, the word was to be taboo on the doctors' tongues.
The investigators also were unhappy that, life-threatening emergencies aside, the hospital had no guidelines for how quickly patients were to be examined. They singled out a number of troubling cases, including that of a patient who had what he described as "the worst headache of my life" and waited eight hours to be treated for what turned out to be a brain hemorrhage.
Accordingly, new time dimensions were adopted. "Urgent" patients, less dire than emergencies, were to be seen within an hour, "nonurgent" patients within four. Emergency or urgent patients who got fed up waiting and left would be "called and requested to return." If they had no phone, the hospital was to send a telegram.
As part of its remedial plan, the hospital created a video explaining the anti-dumping law and promised to show it to the entire staff. The interns saw it during regular conferences. But no mention was made of the case of the French woman or the state investigation. Dr. Jennifer James and Dr. Bryan Holland, in the medicine and pediatrics departments, gave the video no particular attention. To them it seemed like just one more standard bit of preaching.
 
Food, Glorious Food
The Gin Mill bar on 83rd Street and Amsterdam Avenue was a hive of activity, especially in the rackety back area where the interns congregated. It was Residents' Happy Hour, courtesy of Pfizer. Pretty much every Wednesday, one of the drug houses sponsored a Happy Hour, when the interns could drink and attack a buffet table.
A young, primly dressed Pfizer representative stamped Dr. James's hand, her ticket to free drinks, and gave her a brochure on Norvasc, a hypertension drug. She deposited it in her pocket. She was here to socialize. She scooted to the bar, then dissolved into the merry assemblage of murmuring interns pouring wine and beer down their gullets. There was infinite gossip to absorb -- could you believe that resident who was hitting on two interns? There were pictures to study -- one intern had just married in Japan and had brought his album.
They lined up for food.
There was no understanding interns without understanding their obsession with food. Since they never had time to eat, they thought about it constantly. One of two things generally happened during internship: You gained weight because all you ate was junk food, or you lost weight because you skipped so many meals.
Thus it was a well-known fact that the best way to fill a room with residents was to bait the room with food. Planning a lecture on bladder catheterization? Order pizza and make sure there are plenty of seats.
One particular species willing to provide consumables was the pharmaceutical salesman. Eager to impress on the doctors the illimitable virtues of their drugs, they materialized almost daily during lunchtime. In the late morning, just when a shudder of hunger possessed the interns, the magic words would reverberate over the public address system: "Lunch for the house staff will be served in conference room B at noon." The meaning was clear. A drug rep was here. Free food!
In fact, the interns dictated the menu. Fridays, for instance, they normally insisted on Chinese.
The interns felt they were crossing no ethical lines. They had essentially no say in which drugs were put on the hospital's approved list anyway. "I come to see the other interns and to eat," Dr. James said.
The drug reps were not the only visitors. One day, John Hancock came peddling insurance and mutual funds to an audience commonly boasting negative net worths. Still, the room was full. The company had brought Indian food.
 
'A Little Gastric Upset'
At the monthly meeting for the medicine residents, it was the same nagging issues. The residents were admonished about the need to discharge patients in a timely manner. The all-important length of stay (L.O.S.) averages had been creeping up, particularly among Medicare patients. In 1992, the hospital's L.O.S. was 14 days, and it was now a little over 6, but that was still above the national average. Keep someone too long and the hospital ate the bill.
Recently, in an unsubtle way of shaming the laggards, St. Luke's had resumed sending L.O.S. report cards to the "attendings," as the senior staff doctors were known. The residents got their own promptings: "Anyone who discharges someone today gets a second free sandwich."
But it was hard to make the residents care too deeply about medicine's new economics, about managed care's "Mother, may I?" protocols. Their income remained at the same low level no matter how many patients they treated or how fast they treated them. They were still infused with medical-school idealism. To a certain extent, they felt encased in a magic membrane that shielded them from reality, being taught by doctors who were unsure how -- and often less than entirely willing -- to teach for the new medical world.
Dr. Michael Lesch, the chairman of the department of medicine, struggled in his own mind about how much he was willing to adapt. He labored hard at getting his department's L.O.S. in line. (As he put it, "This is no longer a hotel.") But when he got deep into a discussion of managed care, he would get riled and say, "I teach them medicine. Managed care is not medicine."
He would say, "I'm struggling personally to define those elements of the growth cycle of the residents that I can't compromise, so when they get out of here I'm proud of them."
On close inspection, there was something of a generation gap among the attending physicians. Some younger ones did not quite share the older doctors' virulent feelings about the new age. Even so, the interns heard almost nothing but grumbling from attendings, even young ones, about the changed ways, and often Dr. James said to herself, "Enough already." One day an attending cornered her in the hallway and began moaning about how he was making so much less money and how horrible his life had become. "What am I supposed to do," Dr. James thought, "not become a doctor?"
Still, from their own rush of experiences, the interns had begun to adopt their own biases toward managed care. In tallying up the risk factors of a new patient, Dr. James and her friends joked that if the person was covered by a certain managed-care company, they would consider that a risk factor like smoking or obesity.
All manner of mixed signals were constantly filtering down to the impressionable interns. One morning, after an intern informed her attending doctor that her patient was ready to leave, the attending said he wanted her to stay another day. He wanted to take a picture of the woman's exotic, looping toenails but had forgotten his camera. The intern was astonished that someone was being kept in the hospital for a snapshot of her toenails. To Dr. James, this one set of toenails seemed to reverberate with the growing disharmony of the times. On one rotation, Dr. James reported to a third-year resident, who repeatedly told her, "This is a teaching hospital. If you're just curious, order the test." Dr. James would roll her eyes, and think, "Whatever."
With staffing tight, the attending doctors were stretched as thin as the residents, and it was an issue trying to get them to teach enough hours. Private attendings rarely taught anymore, as they once voluntarily did. And many staff attendings would spend an hour on rounds and then be swallowed up by an increasing weight of responsibilities -- private patients, paperwork, research. They would write a progress note only when a patient was admitted. Dr. Lesch importuned them to write daily notes, as the interns did; the hospital could bill for them. Eyes lifted. Medicaid would pay $7 a note. Eyes lowered. Dr. Lesch wondered how some attendings even knew the patients. How could they teach the interns how to interact with patients when they didn't interact with them?
He recognized that what the interns saw and heard was frequently contradictory. But he did not have the answers. "They have to find their own values," he said. "They have to find how far they will go before they compromise. I hope I at least give them a little gastric upset."
 
Internship: The Bottom Line
One of his clinic patients paid in cash -- $67.50. Seeing actual money change hands, Dr. Holland felt good. "I'm bringing in money for the hospital," he quipped.
Given their low pay and handyman job description, the interns assumed they were big moneymakers for St. Luke's. And compared with attending doctors, they were a bargain, enough so that more were being graduated than society could absorb.
Nodding to concerns about a doctor glut, New York was in the midst of a federal experiment in which the government was paying the state's teaching hospitals to reduce their residents by a fourth. Yet more than half of the enlisted hospitals had withdrawn, unable to make the economics work. After scaling back its interns, St. Luke's was going to raise the number next year. Even so, the hospital was having an increasingly hard time breaking even on its residents.
The algorithm computed by the financial staff went like this: it cost about $184,165 a year to train an intern. There was the modest salary of $39,270, the proportionate expense of an attending doctor, malpractice premiums and various other expenses like the high technology and the inevitable excess of tests and longer patient stays.
Some 80 percent of the cost was covered by Medicaid and Medicare and the rest by private insurers, through a special state tax. In this stubborn new environment, though, they were reducing the level of payment.
As it was, St. Luke's calculated that it actually lost about $1,500 per intern. It tried to economize. The rule of thumb used to be that residents ordered every test known to man times two. While attendings no longer allowed as many tests, studies suggested that residents still ordered about 20 percent more than doctors at nonteaching hospitals.
With further funding cuts looming, there was not much more the interns could be asked to do other than swab the floors.
 
'Another Medical Triumph'
One afternoon, Dr. James joined the others for Intern Report, in which an intern presented one of her cases. Dr. Gregory Steinberg, associate director of medicine, moderated.
The intern recited the bare facts: a 39-year-old man whose chief complaint was he felt sick for five days and was getting worse. He had no significant medical history. He had a throbbing headache, chest pain, shortness of breath and abdominal pain. He smoked crack and marijuana and occasionally slept on the street, where he was exposed to pigeons and rats.
"What do pigeons do for you?" Dr. Steinberg said. "What do rats do?"
"Plague," someone suggested.
"There's not too much plague in New York," Dr. Steinberg pointed out.
What sort of people were exposed to rat urine?
One intern said, "Swimmers."
"Swimmers?" Dr. Steinberg said. "Where do you do your swimming?"
The correct answer was sanitation workers and those who work in sewers.
The man was administered antibiotics, though his diagnosis remained unclear. Tests were done. Day by day, he began feeling better.
"What are we treating?" Dr. Steinberg asked. "At God knows what cost per day? We're treating us. We're feeling better because he's feeling better."
Insurers were howling to get patients discharged swiftly, but the house staff wanted to learn. When oddities arose, curious tangents not always clinically relevant, the interns investigated at their leisure, sometimes forgetting about the patient, never thinking about dollars and cents.
By Day 12, this patient was feeling much better and was discharged. The assumption was that he had leptospirosis, an infection that rats can transmit.
"So we did nothing for him but gave him antibiotics, and he probably would have gotten better without them," Dr. Steinberg said. "Another medical triumph. We did nothing. The patient got better."
 
Children, Checks and Balances
He had been drinking. The police found him passed out on the subway and brought him in. His blood alcohol level was twice the legal limit for an adult. He was 12.
Dr. Holland visited him in his room. He was seeking precipitating events. It was a fragile moment. "Kids start with one thing and then move on to drugs and who knows what," he said. "You want to stop it right away."
The boy insisted he was just experimenting. He was getting good grades in school. Dr. Holland learned from the parents that they were having marital discord. That might be part of it. The boy squirmed and smiled weakly as Dr. Holland spoke indignantly of the evils of alcohol. Truth was, social work was part of being a doctor, too.
Outside the room, Dr. Holland was quiet. "I think he'll be O.K.," he said. "He's clearly smart and well-mannered. He said he was never doing this again. I think he'll be too scared to."
Later, after a shift in the clinic, Dr. Holland and the other doctors clattered into a small back office for a soda. With the inevitability of gravity, the conversation turned to the problems of medicine.
The attending on duty, a young woman from India, mentioned how she recently did a blood screening for a child and the insurer wouldn't pay for it.
" 'Not indicated,' they said," she complained with deep sourness. "And it was absolutely needed. It's really bad out there."
Dr. Holland gave a wry smile: "Down with the insurance companies."
The attending went on, "It's good that something came along, because we needed checks and balances. There was a lot of waste in the system. But they've gone too far."
Her own son had been hospitalized for pneumonia while visiting India and her insurer had refused to cover it. "I fought for a year and two months to be paid," she said. "I nagged them every week. Then I threatened to report them to the attorney general. I got a check in two weeks."
"I'm learning," Dr. Holland said. "Threaten, threaten."
"It's amazing what they get away with," the attending said. "Most people don't have the knowledge to fight. I'm in the business."
There was an exaggerated silence. After a while, the attending said: "The administration calls here all the time and they want numbers. They want patients every 20 minutes. They're constantly looking for numbers. Some socially deprived children need 45 minutes or an hour. I'm supposed to teach the interns, and I'm supposed to turn out numbers. They're contradictory issues. Something has to give."
She continued: "They're always pulling the interns out of the clinic to cover something on the floor. When these interns go out into practice, they almost feel like admitting everybody because all they know is in-patient care. They haven't developed clinical judgment. Someone has pneumonia. Admit him. But wait, this kid doesn't have respiratory distress. I'll send him home and follow up tomorrow. Clinical judgment."
Dr. Holland said: "I've noticed different types of attendings. Some have no clinical judgment. They order every test because they're insecure. Others know right away what to do."
"You have to develop a feel for who you listen to and who you don't," the attending said. "When you're finished here, you'll know what each attending doesn't know. Not what they know, but what they don't know."
 
Conundrums of Intensive Care
The big-bellied man would never wake up. His was a life now unsalvageably distant. His diseased heart had sent him into cardiac arrest. He had lost his pulse entirely. By the time doctors had resuscitated him, he appeared to be brain dead.
If so, the doctors could shut off the ventilator and that would be that, just another of those quotidian horrors of internship. Tests detected no brain waves. He was removed from the ventilator. Under the hospital's protocol, he had to fail to take a breath for two and a half minutes. A few seconds shy of the deadline, he took a single gasp.
That gasp was enough that now only his son, who lived in Puerto Rico, could end what pretense of life machinery continued to give his father.
When Dr. James called him, she explained that, barring unexpected divine intervention, there was no chance his father would recover. She explained that the motionless man lying in intensive care was little more than flesh attached to machines. The son said: "What does it hurt? Let's keep him alive." At a cost of $3,000 a day.
She shivered in anger: "I thought the son was being selfish and stupid. It sounded like he didn't want to think that he was turning off the ventilator and killing his father. But what about how it was inhuman to keep his father alive? How we would have to keep doing tests on him. Maybe add a feeding tube. Maybe end up cracking his ribs if he coded -- for someone who was no longer a person."
Three weeks later, the father did "code" -- his heart stopped -- and this time, the doctors could not revive him.
The intensive care unit was the grimmest destination in the hospital. Here Dr. James often saw the final stumbling gasps of someone's life, and it was never pretty. It was here that she experienced the frustration of having to do too much, to treat patients in the throes of incurable, lingering disease, whose lungs were run by respirators, whose stomachs were fed by tubes, who were more like lab experiments than human beings.
Dr. James kept hearing that time and money were so precious, and yet so much of both was expended on patients locked in an unstoppable dance with death. "Why do another X-ray, another blood culture?" she said. "It's not making them better. If anything, it's making them worse."
The unit had a hazy feel. Often the only sounds were the hum and buzz of machines and the occasional television -- talk shows, soaps. And oh so many misbegotten stories.
She looked in on a patient on a ventilator, unable to speak. She was 89, with respiratory pneumonia. Dr. James had serviced her for two weeks, without exchanging a word. "It's weird," she said.
The managed care doctor had stopped by and urged that her course of antibiotics be finished so she could return to her nursing home. "But the nursing home doesn't take 'vents,' " Dr. James said. "I don't know if I can wean her off it yet."
And for what life? The woman had dementia. She had not spoken in a long time. She had no family, only a legal guardian. Guardians are usually reluctant to halt care because of fear of repercussions. The attending looked in: "I have the feeling that if that woman were awake, she would say, 'Please stop. Don't do this to me.' "
A pulmonary fellow in the unit said: "Doctors are uncomfortable talking to people about health care proxies when they're well, and we pay the price. When I have a practice, I'll have it right on the chart as the first thing to discuss."
She was silent a moment. Then she added, "But it's not easy. Like I don't have one. It's hard to know, who do I entrust my life to?"
So many of these patients posed ethical conundrums for the interns, setting their own brains to squabbling. Do this. Don't do this. Sometimes Dr. James felt bitter. Why should she have to work so hard in here, often for no gain? There were consequences for the soul. The family of one comatose woman had festooned her room with pictures of her dog and cat, and that made Dr. James think of her as truly alive. But she would never open an eye again.
Sometimes they would joke about someone: "Oh, the guy's shot. Let's just let him die." It muted the sorrow, but it also got at what they felt.
So many cases were hopeless that the interns were taken aback when they encountered an I.C.U. patient back on the wards, nearly well again. Dr. James had a man with sickle-cell anemia who reached the brink of death only to reject it. Soon he was released. She thought of him as Lazarus.
Over the loudspeaker now came word of a drug company lunch, and the interns' spirits abruptly lifted. Escape from this sorrowful shift. By the time Dr. James wrapped up her paperwork and got there, however, the turnout was so huge that all the plates had been claimed. Disappointed, she backtracked to the cafeteria with a fellow intern and had to pay for ravioli.
In an uninflected tone, her friend told her about a dreadful case. The interns were urged always to ask about D.N.R. (do not resuscitate) orders, but everything was complicated. The friend said she had just lost a patient, a 53-year-old woman with emphysema. She was intubated and then, as she improved, extubated. She got worse again and refused another intubation. She had signed a D.N.R. order. Helpless to do anything for a woman she felt could entirely recover, the intern watched her die.
"Oh, I just got the funniest news from Ohio," Dr. James said. "Someone I know who's doing her internship in Dayton just had her first death -- this after eight months of internship."
"You're kidding," her friend said.
"I mean, I had one the first month," Dr. James said. "I'm sure glad I'm not doing my residency in Ohio. What would I learn?"
It was sunny out. Dr. James said, "I hope I get done by 4:30 so I can soak in some rays."
"Rays?" her friend said. "How about shopping?"
 
Postmortem Blues
There was a pep talk on autopsies. For years, it had been getting harder to obtain permission for them and the number of autopsies had dwindled steadily. Enhanced technology had greatly improved doctors' ability to diagnose illness and families felt there was nothing more to discover. Relatives were more loath to expose loved ones, particularly the growing ranks of the very old, to what they saw as an indignity when no medical care yet practiced could do them further good. Religious reasons entered in. Still, autopsies did turn up surprises and were important teaching aides. Federal rules were that teaching hospitals perform autopsies for at least 15 percent of deaths, but since few hospitals could meet the threshold, it was rarely enforced. St. Luke's had an 11 percent average.
Interns were understandably squeamish even broaching the issue with inconsolable next of kin. So the medicine department had devised a macabre contest of sorts, with a prize to the intern who rounded up the most autopsies. In past years, interns got medical textbooks or Barnes & Noble gift certificates for each autopsy they achieved. These were apparently inadequate stimuli, so this year the incentive was sweetened, to a grand prize of $1,500.
Many of the interns found this particularly ghoulish. Some actually felt newly disinclined to pursue autopsies. In any event, there was a catch. The prize only took effect if the department recorded at least 100 autopsies for the year, and it was woefully shy of the target.
Dr. James had zero autopsies. Personally, she felt them inappropriate, absent some mystery about the death. She had one fleetingly. But the hospital was unable to get it done before the family insisted on burial. Overnight, she went from +1 back to 0.
 
Salving Loneliness, Saving a Life
Dr. Lathan felt gloomy. "When you're counting the hours and waiting for the shift to end, you know it's not good," he said over lunch. His best friend, an intern at another hospital, told him that one of the surgery interns there had hanged himself in his room. There were money issues. Love issues. Protracted depression.
Dr. Lathan was not so much depressed as aggravated by his ascetic life. He didn't even date; he had no time for a relationship. "You're spending like 80 percent of your life in this place, working six days straight," he said. "It's like being in a prison camp. I find myself less tolerant. Now it's a case of if it's not about my education, I don't want to do it, and I resent it. I don't want to be used as a slave just because of lack of manpower.
"The excitement and thrill is not there. It's a shame, too, because medicine really is a joy. It's a shame that they have a system that actually makes you hate medicine."
Into the E.R. the patients still came. The man said he felt a weakness in his side. He said he could not walk steadily: "I walk like a zombie. I walk like a robot." He had to go to the bathroom. Dr. Lathan watched him walk. He walked like a person. What he was was depressed. Dr. Lathan discharged him and suggested a therapist. "He was wasting my time," Dr. Lathan said. "I don't like people who waste my time."
He saw an 85-year-old woman complaining of diarrhea, vomiting, chills. Her home-care aide told Dr. Lathan, "I think her biggest problem is loneliness. She says when she's home she feels sad. When she got here, she said she felt alive."
He nodded. He understood.
Dr. Lathan was summoned to another room. A woman, 41, desolate for reasons known best to her, had just swallowed 28 tablets of Doxepin, a depressant, declaring her intention to conclude her life. "She just wanted to kill herself in front of the triage nurse," a nurse said.
Dr. Lathan and several residents channeled their energy into reversing her actions. He put in a breathing tube. She was connected to an E.K.G. machine. "Hello, hello," Dr. Lathan said.
They began pumping her stomach. While Dr. Lathan worked on her, the chief resident dispassionately lectured him: How much fluid to add. Why this. Why that. The woman was a life hanging by a thread, but also a vehicle for teaching.
The contents of her stomach emptied into a pink plastic bin. "It's how you take gasoline out of a tank, water out of a swimming pool," someone said.
The floor was a mess of discarded packaging from the cavalcade of medical supplies. Soon, the woman was ready for a chest X-ray, and then she would go to intensive care. The chief resident said, "All right, we're cool."
There was nothing more to say. Dr. Lathan had a pilot with abdominal pain who was supposed to be flying to Spain. The shift had hours to go. Something special had happened. A woman would live who had tried not to.
 
Managed Care 101
Late in the internship year, in a rare attempt at formally addressing the mechanics of managed care with the house staff, the hospital arranged for a pair of seminars. They were described in leaflets sent to all the residents as "important seminars that can assist you in practicing medicine in this ever-expanding era of managed care."
The sessions were staged in a large conference room at Roosevelt and beamed by closed-circuit television to St. Luke's. They attached an accept-it-it's-not-going-away sensibility to the topic. Reprints of studies and charts were stacked up on a table for attendees to take with them. There was not much need.
Only a handful of people showed up.
 
Life, Death and Managed Care
 
In their early months at St. Luke's-Rosevelt Hospital Center, the interns struggled to find their balance in a world of diminished resources and warp speed. Dr. Bryan Holland, in pediatrics, learned the true meaning of scut work and how to tell a stomachache from a desire to skip school. In the E.R., Dr. Edward Lathan dealt with everything from a broken fingernail to heart failure and, for the first time, saw one of his patients die. Working to beyond exhaustion, Dr. Jennifer James, in medicine, worried about making mistakes and got a lesson in the meaning of responsibility. Today: an investigation at the hospital . . . the heartbreaking conundrums of intensive care . . . and the joys of free food.

HEADLINE: State Sues G.E. Over Pollution In the Hudson

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer sued General Electric today, the first time the state has ever taken the company to court over PCB contamination of the Hudson River, in an action that he says he hopes will open the door to many similar suits.
The suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Albany, does not address the environmental and health effects of G.E.'s three decades of dumping PCB's into the river, issues that are the subject of an ongoing inquiry by the United States Environmental Protection Agency. The agency is expected to decide next year whether to order widespread dredging of the river. 
 Instead, Mr. Spitzer's complaint takes the novel approach of pursuing monetary damages, blaming PCB's for the state's trouble in maintaining a shipping canal that links the Hudson to Lake Champlain. And he invited local governments and private interests along the nearly 200-mile length of the river to join in his suit or file their own, on similar grounds.
"The legal theory, once we establish this legal theory, will open G.E. up to damages that are vast, that will apply up and down the Hudson River, and that will be monumental in scale," he said. "All the communities up and down the river have been impaired because of the PCB's in the Hudson -- the value of property, the ability to get commerce through, jobs that have been lost."
Mr. Spitzer intentionally steered clear of sticky questions about damage to human health and ecosystems, adhering, he said, to grounds where he was confident he could win, and win quickly.
Environmentalists applauded the suit, predicting that it would put added pressure on G.E. to reach a settlement with the environmental agency for large-scale dredging of the river. The company strenuously opposes dredging, which could cost it more than $1 billion.
A company spokesman, Mark L. Behan, dismissed the suit as "politics, purely and simply politics," adding that General Electric would contest it "with vigor."
Gov. George E. Pataki's administration also took issue with the action, warning that it could interfere with other state actions against G.E. over pollution in the Hudson, which has been declared a toxic cleanup site under the federal Superfund program.
Environmentalists dismissed that concern, some saying that the governor, a Republican, simply did not like being overshadowed on environmental matters by the new attorney general, a Democrat.
John P. Cahill, Mr. Pataki's commissioner of environmental conservation, predicted that his agency and the E.P.A. would be dragged into Mr. Spitzer's suit. That, he said, would draw resources away from both the federal agency's investigation and a claim for economic damages against General Electric under the federal Superfund law that the state and federal governments have been exploring jointly.
He also argued that the suit could hinder future claims under state law, since all such claims, he said, should be filed at once.
Officials of the environmental agency declined to comment on the suit, or on Mr. Cahill's prediction that it would slow down their work.
But environmentalists were elated that after decades of struggle, the state had finally sued General Electric. "We're delighted to see an aggressive approach being taken, finally," said Cara Lee, environmental director of Scenic Hudson, a conservation group. "This suit will probably bring forward additional information that will, if anything, make for a better E.P.A. decision and better state claims in the future."
The environmental agency is scheduled to make a preliminary decision late next year whether to order dredging of PCB "hot spots" up and down the river, but a final decision is not expected until 2001.
Some environmental groups fear that by then, there could be a Republican administration in Washington that would be less likely to take such action, a prospect that they say makes the attorney general's suit all the more important.
The suit continues Mr. Spitzer's string of audacious actions against major corporations in his first year in office. He has threatened to make New York the first state to sue gun makers in an attempt to make them put safety devices on handguns and limit how and where guns are sold. And he has sued power plants in the Midwest and South over air pollution that crosses state lines; it is the first such suit by any state.
Today's suit deals with the 35-mile-long Champlain Canal, from the southern tip of Lake Champlain to the Hudson at Waterford. It intersects the Hudson just downstream from the General Electric plants, at Hudson Falls and Fort Edward, that dumped PCB's into the river from the 1940's to 1970's, when the federal government banned them.
In some stretches, the canal runs alongside the river. In others, it enters the river; that is, what is called the canal is actually just the deepest part of the river. And that provides the basis for the attorney general's very narrowly drawn suit.
The State Constitution requires that the state maintain the canal for commercial traffic, and state law requires that it be at least 12 feet deep. But where the canal lies in the river, it has been allowed to silt up -- it is as shallow as 7 feet in places, Mr. Spitzer's aides said -- because of PCB's in the sediment.
If the state were to dredge the canal, it would have to abide by strict federal standards for handling and disposing of PCB's, making the work far more expensive. Mr. Spitzer said that is why the state has not dredged the channel in 15 years.
His suit seeks to force the company to pay that additional cost to dredge the shipping channel in the part of the river that doubles as the canal, a sum that he said would be at least $10 million and possibly far more. And he noted he was leaving open the possibility of seeking damages for lost economic activity along the canal, which would probably be many times the cost of dredging.
"The dollar figure is not as important as the precedent-setting nature of the action," Mr. Spitzer said. "This case will also establish a case for others faced with increased dredging and disposal costs. This includes municipalities in the region and downstream. It also includes private facilities such as marinas and waterfront businesses and others who can demonstrate economic harm. These damages will be vast."
Mr. Behan, the General Electric spokesman, said that the state had never even requested permission from the federal government to dredge the channel, proving that it was not a pressing need.
Cynthia Munk, a spokeswoman for the State Thruway Authority, which is controlled by the governor and operates the canal, said, "We believe that there is no need to do dredging for navigational purposes prior to E.P.A.'s assessment."
But she conceded that at times, getting a ship through takes special measures like removing some of its load or using dams to raise the water level temporarily.
Commercial traffic on the river has declined, from 13,615 vessels in 1980 to 2,517 last year, though some of that drop is due to the decline of manufacturing upstate.
Legal experts said Mr. Spitzer's suit appears to be a strong one. "There's a long history of the state suing under public nuisance laws when there is interference with a transportation corridor," said Karl S. Coplan, a law professor at Pace University who specializes in environmental law.
Polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, were long used as insulators in electrical equipment. General Electric estimates that its two plants on the Hudson, 50 miles north of here, dumped more than a million pounds of PCB's into the river, but its critics contend it was far more. Mr. Spitzer said the true figure was more than 100 million pounds.
Though the federal environmental agency has declared that PCB's cause cancer in animals, and probably in humans as well, there is debate among scientists as to what, if any, risk there is to humans from low-level exposure.
General Electric contends that its dumping was legal, because no law explicitly prohibited it. But environmentalists argue that the extent of the dumping made it illegal because it violated state clean-water laws, a position supported by Mr. Spitzer.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 18, 1999, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about a lawsuit filed against General Electric over PCB contamination of the Hudson River included an erroneous estimate from the State Attorney General, Eliot L. Spitzer, for the amount of the chemical dumped into the river over three decades. Mr. Spitzer, who filed the suit, said yesterday that the actual figure was 1.3 million pounds -- the amount acknowledged by G.E. -- and not a quantity exceeding 100 million pounds.

PUB-DATE: November 17, 1999

SECTION: Section H; Page 7; Column 1; Giving 

LENGTH: 2001 words

HEADLINE: Message: I Care (More Than They Do)

BYLINE: By SARA MILES; Sara Miles, a California writer, is working on a book about the politics of Silicon Valley.

 BODY:
THE night is warm, with a sliver of moon rising over the California hills, and Vice President Al Gore gazes at the people gathered outside in the dark. "Kids are going hungry," Mr. Gore tells them, softly, "and we know that's not the way it's supposed to be." He pauses. "The question for America," says Mr. Gore, his voice almost cracking, "is how much do we care?"
Largely because of the proclamations of Mr. Gore's chief rival for the presidency, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, "compassion" has become a buzzword on the campaign trail. Whether it is Mr. Bush's contention that he represents "compassionate conservatism," Senator John McCain's anecdote about "relying on compassion" in the Vietnam War or the insistence by former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey that "America is great because people care about each other," Republicans and Democrats are busy trying to convince voters that they speak, in the vice president's phrase, "not just from the head, but from the heart." 
 Voters who prefer a more traditional style of oratory characterized by high seriousness and patriotic masculinity may lament the vogue of sensitivity. But the use of emotion as a political tool is hardly new.
In 1913, in his first Inaugural Address, President Woodrow Wilson pleaded for attention to the "groans and moans" of the poor, saying "there has been something crude and heartless and unfeeling in our haste to succeed and be great." President Richard M. Nixon, stern in his anti-Communist rhetoric and bellicose about America's power, could choke up evoking "the dreams of a child more important than any politician's promise." And President Clinton, even as he eschewed bleeding-heart social policies, kept demonstrating how deeply he felt America's pain, wielding hugs and moist eyes in public displays of empathy.
James A. Thurber, who directs the Center for Congressional and Presidential Studies at American University in Washington, finds the current rhetoric unconvincing. "Compassion is just a brand right now," Mr. Thurber charged. "It's a slogan, not something with real meaning."
Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York agrees, and says that the moral imperative to care is disappearing from politics.
"It used to be popular to be compassionate in the 60's," said Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat. "That does not sell politically nowadays. You should help others. Why? Because it's so terrible kids are poor? No, because it costs more to have kids be unproductive. It's all about pragmatism. You can't call on the population to help anymore just because it's the right thing to do."
BUT assume for a moment that the candidates' expressions of caring are sincere. Even so, compassion is never simply a sentiment. For the millions of Americans who support community service organizations, or who follow religious teachings, compassionate feelings are inextricably linked with an imperative to act.
Most Americans value compassion in action. Yet if you quantify compassion by the size of philanthropic donations, most are less than exemplary givers, and politicians are no exception.
Mr. Bradley and his wife, Ernestine, with a combined taxable income of $2,416,917 last year, gave just $38,041 to charity, about 1.5 percent of their earnings.
Mr. Gore, and his wife, Tipper, who earned $224,376 in 1998, gave away $15,197, approximately 7 percent of their income. The Gores, however, may have been prompted to act more generously by the disclosure that, in 1997, they gave away just $353 of an income of $197,729, less than two-tenths of 1 percent.
Mr. Bush and his wife, Laura, gave away 6.5 percent of their income in 1997, when they earned $258,375. In 1998, after the sale of the Texas Rangers, their estimated taxable income jumped to $18,405,524. But they donated $334,425 to churches and charities, less than 2 percent and somewhat shy of the "outpouring of compassion" Mr. Bush urged on his fellow citizens.
As Mose Allison, that sly philosopher of blues piano, used to croon, "Everybody's crying mercy, but they don't know the meaning of the word."
It takes more than a calculator, though, to figure out the political meanings of mercy. When the presidential candidates talk about compassion, they are expressing their political and moral values, talking in code to particular voters and dropping clues about the policies they might implement.
The first clue concerns the people a candidate wants voters to care about.
For whom, exactly, does a candidate recommend compassion? All the people of the world? Or just Americans? For all the poor, or just the "deserving" poor, a slippery category that fluctuates according to each candidate's moral judgments?
Does the candidate urge compassion for the sick or for the victims of terrorist attacks and natural disasters? For women, or babies, or fetuses? The elderly? And what about children? Few politicians can pass up a chance to ooze concern for photogenic kindergartners, but how many express compassion for surly 17-year-olds?
Even when the answers are similar, the language in which they are expressed reveals nuanced differences among the men who would be president. The three leading contenders all evoke the plight of poor children with feeling. But in doing so Mr. Bush, who coined the phrase "compassionate conservatism," signals loyalty to his Republican roots. In speeches about helping children, he praises religion and warns against big government. He is careful to emphasize, along with his love for "innocent victims," the values of "self-control and character and goal-setting" when helping them.
Mr. Bradley, whose calls to "eliminate child poverty as we know it" fall squarely in the liberal Democratic tradition of the New Deal and the War on Poverty, gives priority to increased government spending on health care, child care and education. His language equates federal assistance with morality: "As the most prosperous nation on earth," Mr. Bradley declares, "America must do better when it comes to protecting our children."
Mr. Gore splits the difference, echoing Mr. Bush's language of faith and charity while seconding Mr. Bradley's belief in federal intervention. Mr. Gore distinguishes himself with rhetoric that subtly appeals to union voters, calling for aid not to "poor children" alone, but to "working families."
Such careful deconstructing of compassion makes sense to political analysts. "Bush's compassionate conservatism is all about a rational plan to move toward the middle ideologically," said Mr. Thurber of American University. "He's trying to signal that he's not an uncaring right-winger, but at the same time that he's really conservative, and is going to devolve power locally. This works because most people are compassionate, but they don't like government: Bush is trying to walk that fine line."
The vice president's rhetoric, Mr. Thurber said, partly signals Mr. Gore's desire to "hold on to labor and the left," but also suggests a broader effort to humanize his image. "Primarily, Gore's concerned about the fact that he's perceived to be dull, bumbling, a policy wonk," Mr. Thurber said. "He needs to do something to change that."
Mr. Thurber sees Mr. Bradley's expressions of compassion as "less calculating" than those of his rivals, because he relies on rhetoric unpopular with voters. "He's not poll-driven," Mr. Thurber said. "Bradley's going against the trend by saying the federal government should solve problems with money."
THOUGH not known for a warm and fuzzy personal style, Mr. McCain, Republican of Arizona, insists that caring for others is an essential part of his message. The way in which he frames his concern reinforces his appeal to voters who see him as the honest outsider. Mr. McCain's proposals for increasing federal money for public schools in poor areas, for example, rely on removing subsidies for ethanol, oil, gas and sugar "instead of taking money away from the public schools, as other candidates would do," said Dan Schnur, a McCain campaign spokesman.
Mr. McCain is straightforward about the political choices implied by his approach. "Our emphasis is always on support for working families and the disenfranchised," Mr. Schnur said, "at the expense of special interests and the well-connected."
Mr. McCain is gentler in his populism than the Reform Party firebrand Patrick J. Buchanan, whose tirades against "elites" can sound more like incitement to class warfare than appeals for compassion, a subject Mr. Buchanan barely mentions. He makes his priorities clear by emphasizing "responsibility" over caring, in a pitch aimed at angry right-wing voters.
For his part, Mr. Bush has tried to appeal to moderate voters with gestures intended to demonstrate his compassion for ethnic minorities and the disadvantaged, accusing House Republicans of trying to "balance the budget on the backs of the poor."
But he also has not hesitated to push the wall separating church from state by promoting "charitable choice," which lets states enlist faith-based organizations to provide basic welfare services, a position that signals his loyalty to a conservative Christian base.
Most of Mr. Bush's other specific ideas for engaging "armies of compassion" fall squarely within a Republican tradition: $8 billion in tax incentives to encourage individual and corporate giving; support for private and church charities; and rejection of "the failed compassion of towering, distant bureaucracies," by which he means the kinds of government programs hailed by liberals.
It is a stance made possible, Mr. Bush's supporters say, by the failures of liberal approaches to compassion. "Conservatives are getting into the business of reaching out to poor people for the first time," said Clint Bolick, who directs the Institute for Justice, a libertarian public interest law firm in Washington. "The idea is not to fight the welfare-state programs of liberals with less generous similar programs, but to return freedom to people. Bush really understands this at a core level, and it serves the objective of softening conservatives' well-earned reputation for being ungenerous."
Mr. Bradley's proposal for spending nearly $10 billion a year on government programs to fight child poverty is aimed squarely at the liberal Democratic voters who turn out for primaries. Any candidate who condemns "white skin privilege" is not playing to the right wing of his party. "I personally am delighted to hear Bradley's rhetoric," Mr. Cuomo said dryly, "because I gave that same speech for 20 years, and that's why I lost."
Mr. Bradley's decision to campaign on expanding social services to the poor through large-scale government initiatives seems a deliberate effort to overturn Mr. Clinton's centrist approach to the disadvantaged. "Thanks to triangulation, obfuscation and tiptoeing across the political morass, nobody else is talking about how poor people are working and still not getting ahead," Mr. Cuomo said. "The poor are not voters, and politics responds only to votes."
Mr. Gore, whose political fortunes have depended on the triumph of Mr. Clinton's centrism, and the phenomenal economic growth that marked Mr. Clinton's tenure in the White House, is much less capable of challenging the compassion of his boss. Instead, the vice president speaks of his plans to lift children out of poverty as "completing welfare reform." The details of his proposal combine conservative language, "promoting responsible parenthood," with classic liberal Democratic measures such as raising the minimum wage, expanding child-care opportunities and making health care more affordable.
The urge to feel and behave with compassion may be universal. The attention candidates have paid to compassion this year certainly shows that Americans place a high value on caring. But compassion in practice is as particular as any other emotion: the question of whom we care for and how, just as whom we denigrate and how we punish, is political at its heart.

HEADLINE: New Rules Lift the Lid on Nonprofit Pay

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BIG compensation packages for top executives in the business world have become commonplace in the booming economy. But now, as the Internal Revenue Service completes new rules for charities and foundations, experts say it will become increasingly profitable to work for a nonprofit institution.
The new rules will both codify old tax cases and give tax collectors more flexibility to crack down on excessive compensation. But because the I.R.S. regulations follow a line of cases that have permitted compensation based on comparable salaries, stock options and other benefits doled out by the private sector, the new rules for some of the largest nonprofit institutions can be boiled down to a four-word formula: the sky's the limit. 
 The new regulations were drafted last year under a 1996 law urged by Independent Sector, a coalition of philanthropic and nonprofit organizations that was concerned about the scandals surrounding the compensation packages of William V. Aramony of the United Way and Peter Diamandopoulos of Adelphi University. The government has said that tax-exempt institutions may now rely on the proposed regulations, which are expected to become final in 2000. But already, salaries and other benefits for executives are increasing at a higher rate at many nonprofit institutions than at profit-making businesses.
In 1998, compensation for top executives of major nonprofit institutions grew at nearly double the rate shown in 1997, according to The Chronicle of Philanthropy's latest survey, and slightly outpaced raises given to business executives. The survey found that the median total compensation for chief executive officers at 246 nonprofit institutions was $207,990, with more than 13 receiving annual compensation of at least $500,000 and another 89 receiving more than $200,000.
The top earners were seven heads of hospitals, four university presidents, and Joseph Volpe, the general manager at New York's Metropolitan Opera Association, and Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. Among the highest paid executives were Dr. John W. Rowe, the president of Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York and Dr. Paul A. Marks of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, both of whom received more than $1 million.
The survey featured a wide range of top earners at nonprofit institutions, from those in the executive suites to those who render services "on the front line."
Walter H. Annenberg, the retired publishing executive, received total compensation of $500,000 last year from his foundation for overseeing the investment of its $3 billion portfolio. Leonard Slatkin received $829,000 for conducting the National Symphony Orchestra; John Robinson earned $750,000 for coaching the football team at the University of Southern California; and Dr. Wayne Isom received $1.7 million as chairman of the department of cardiothoracic surgery at Cornell University.
Executive recruiters say the large pay packages reflect the realities of the marketplace. Many executives at the top of nonprofit institutions can command huge compensation packages in industries like the Internet, Wall Street or hospitals, where multimillionaires are minted overnight.
"The biggest divider these days that separates the corporate world from the nonprofits is stock options," said James Abruzzo, the managing director of the nonprofit practice at A. T. Kearney, an executive search firm. "The nonprofits just can't compete with the dot-coms. As a result, there will be a whole generation of young business school people, who in the past were very motivated to do something meaningful, who have been lured away by the potential of big payouts and who then may retire in their 30's and can turn to doing nonprofit work."
Mr. Abruzzo said that deferred compensation and performance bonuses, once unheard of in the nonprofit sector, are now routine for many large institutions.
Surveys show that the median increase in executive compensation at nonprofit institutions was 5.7 percent in 1998, while at profit-making institutions it was 4.6 percent. But Mr. Abruzzo said that compensation packages for nonprofit institutions are actually rising at closer to 15 percent a year, and that the traditional salary cap of $200,000 for most foundations has been largely discarded to compete with the business world.
But some critics say that looking at profit-making businesses to determine salaries at nonprofit institutions is inappropriate, because they serve such different purposes.
"This is not a coherent system because it violates the core attributes that distinguish for-profits and not-for-profits," said Peter Frumkin, an assistant professor at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University and an expert on philanthropies. "For-profits live for distributing earnings to shareholders. Nonprofits serve a different purpose altogether."
THE new regulations give considerable flexibility to the government in determining how to deal with executives and institutions where compensation is found to be excessive. Under the old rules, the I.R.S. had few tools to curb excessive compensation, and basically had to choose between doing nothing or taking the extreme step of revoking an organization's tax-exempt status.
Because only such a disproportionately Draconian remedy was available, the agency had to walk away from some cases rather than pursue them, said Marc Owens, the director of the Exempt Organizations section at the I.R.S.
The new rules, called "intermediate sanctions," give the I.R.S. more options. The agency can impose an excise tax on the taxpayer who receives excessive compensation or on the nonprofit manager who approves it. It can impose a penalty equal to 200 percent of the excess if the nonprofit institution fails to correct the problem promptly. It can also order the executive to return any excessive benefits to the nonprofit institution.
Mr. Owens said that the agency recently issued the first eight notices to nonprofit institutions, asserting that they and their executives owed $80 million to the government for excessive compensation. He said that although the rules provided for some flexibility, and allowed foundations and charities to examine ranges of compensation, there were still limits.
"Simply because you look at comparable salaries in the for-profit world doesn't mean that you can pick and choose to use the officers of Microsoft Corporation," he said. "It has to be a comparable situation and a comparable organization."
While many experts have applauded the new approach, some have also said that the federal government is ill-equipped to set any compensation rules for nonprofit institutions. The best approach, they say, is one that relies on self-control by the tax-exempt institutions themselves, combined with clear disclosures that enable donors and others to see whether executive pay is too high.
"It is quite unseemly how much some of these executives are getting," said John G. Simon, a professor at Yale Law School and an authority on regulations governing nonprofit institutions. "Having said that, this is an area that the law cannot in most circumstances do much about."
In that respect, Professor Simon said, it reminded him of one of Samuel Johnson's couplets: "How small of all that human hearts endure/that part which laws or kings can cause or cure."

HEADLINE: The Gospel According to Tony: Help First, Preach Later

BYLINE: By WINIFRED GALLAGHER; Winifred Gallagher's latest book is "Working on God" (Random House).

 BODY:
DRIVING around the slums of Camden and Philadelphia with the Rev. Tony Campolo is like traveling with a hybrid of Mr. Toad and St. Francis of Assisi.
Since Monicagate, this minister, lecturer and author, who is well known among evangelicals -- fervent, traditional, "born-again" Protestants -- is more widely recognized as one of President Clinton's spiritual advisers. But he exults in his resemblance to Homer Simpson. And he delights in antics like paying the bridge toll for a stranger in the car behind his. 
 Like a Zen master, this Baptist preacher wants people to question the status quo -- especially notions like the "permanent underclass." Five or six days a week, he's on the road, mustering support for his far-flung "congregation" of impoverished youth in the United States and Latin America.
What we have here, then, is a merry man with a serious mission -- and something of a maverick in the evangelical world. While the stereotypical evangelist insists on sermonizing as the price of a hot meal and a warm coat, Mr. Campolo's philosophy is to help first, talk later -- but only if the person is interested.
"To be a Christian is by definition to be countercultural," he says. "In an America suffering from 'affluenza,' countercultural means responding to the poor -- the only criterion for judgment that Jesus gives."
Jim Wallis, the director of Sojourners and Call for Renewal, Washington-based religious antipoverty organizations, says, "Although the idea that the Gospel is meant to be good news for the poor is so central in the Bible, it's often painfully absent in contemporary evangelism. Tony is an evangelist who truly cares about social justice."
Spending a day with Mr. Campolo highlights some distinctive features of religious charities, and of his own up-close-and-personal approach to the poor. Our first stop in Camden is a brick church that is the headquarters of UrbanPromise. This is one of the programs sponsored by Mr. Campolo's umbrella organization, the Evangelical Association for the Promotion of Education, or EAPE, which he founded in St. David's, Pa., in 1972. UrbanPromise provides educational and developmental support to 1,000 young people daily.
In his decade as director, says the Rev. Bruce Main, "I've seen a generation of boys disappear. Of the 12 in my first group, 10 dropped out." Despite such heartaches, the ministry has grown. The church that was once abandoned during the city's "white flight" now also houses a gym, community center, teenage employment and leadership programs and two Christian schools.
Describing the ministry as "joyful," Mr. Main said, "The fun is the creativity of searching for real-life answers with the kids."
Mr. Campolo stops to hug Monique, whose problems found an answer in UrbanPromise's "home school" for teenage dropouts. A truant who found her way to this alternative school, Monique, 18, has just started college. She attributes this achievement to a combination of hard work and caring teachers -- "Here, if you don't come to school, someone misses you" -- and "getting saved."
In Camden, the religious values that UrbanPromise promotes, from self-control to faith, aren't just virtues, but survival strategies. Discussing premarital chastity, for example, Monique says: "So many girls think if they have a guy's baby, like some toy, he'll stay around. But he won't."
To Mr. Campolo, Monique and Mr. Main personify the two special advantages of religious charities. "We can communicate spiritual motivations for addressing problems, from dropping out to drug abuse to violence," he says. "That makes us more effective, because poor people are spiritual, if only in thinking in terms of lucky and unlucky."
THE other great strength of religious organizations, says Mr. Campolo, is volunteerism. Three-quarters of EAPE's staff, including Mr. Campolo, are unpaid. As EAPE's chief recruiter and fund-raiser, Mr. Campolo is on the road, addressing church, community and corporate groups. These events attract 95 percent of EAPE's financial resources, typically in individual donations of $25 a month.
"For 20 years, Tony has gotten incredible numbers of people to ask, 'What can I do?' and has challenged both religious liberals and conservatives to walk it like they talk it," said Mike Yaconelli, the director of Youth Specialties, an organization of 100,000 youth workers, based in San Diego.
On a circuitous route from Camden to Philadelphia, Mr. Campolo describes EAPE's programs for the poor in Latin America. Once, he explains, missionaries were preachers. Today, however, local people evangelize, while missionaries often address economic obstacles to human dignity. In the Dominican Republic, for example, one modest project for replanting a rain forest has grown into Floresta, a company with 300 employees.
In Haiti, which has an 85 percent illiteracy rate, EAPE's Beyond Borders project operates 85 schools for adults and children called restaviks -- indentured servants who are, in effect, slaves.
Sometimes, loving thy neighbor requires a more creative response than giving money or time. To illustrate, Mr. Campolo pulls up in front of Schimpf's Garage, just under a sign that reads: Thou Shalt Not Park Here. Lou Schimpf, the white owner, says he decided not to move his shop from Camden after hearing Mr. Campolo preach. "My wife and I prayed on it, and we decided we had to stay," he says.
But that wasn't all he did. Mr. Schimpf gave UrbanPromise an adjacent building that now houses Printworks. Begun with $10 worth of silk-screening supplies, the enterprise produces T-shirts and greeting cards. "We thought it would provide 12 steady jobs, but there's a lot of turnover," Mr. Campolo says, adding, however, that it's all for the best. "The kids learn the processes, then get higher salaries in private industry."
Soon we're rocketing through West Philadelphia to the association's Cornerstone Christian Academy. The school, which comprises kindergarten through eighth grade, is attended by 300 black children, all in uniform. As at UrbanPromise, Cornerstone's most overtly "religious" quality is an emphasis on human worth and decency.
"What's different here is that they teach that being a Christian means living the right way," says Trevor, an eighth grader.
Trevor's goal is "to get into a good high school -- one with computers and football." To Mr. Campolo, such an aspiration is the academy's greatest contribution: "We help the children visualize a future," he says. "It's hard for a kid from the housing project to imagine being a businessman or doctor -- even going to college."
Mr. Campolo has come to Cornerstone to meet with a group of volunteers. Most are white and middle-class, college-age Americans and Europeans who assist the salaried African-American head teachers, living among the poor whom they serve.
The volunteers are about to visit the students' homes. These visits exemplify Mr. Campolo's belief that America doesn't need new social programs, it needs better ways to connect people to existing ones. When a volunteer meets a student's family on its own turf "then it all comes out," he says. "Someone needs a job, has drug trouble." Through interfaith agencies, the volunteer can later put the family in touch with people who can help. What distinguishes one of his programs from a secular equivalent becomes clear when Mr. Campolo advises volunteers about discussing their students' progress. "Explain to the family that you want to do the best job you can for their child -- not just academically, but spiritually. Before leaving, pray with the family for the child."
At the end of a long day, we drive down a stretch of urban America that might be on a different planet from most of the booming nation. "Look at those drug dealers, just waiting!" Mr. Campolo says. "Isn't this block horrendous?" He offers a one-word explanation for why his program's volunteers are drawn to work in such places: fun.
"You can go to the stock market and make lots of money," he says. "In the end, is that so much fun? I don't know why it's fun to work in a slum, but it is."
