SECTION: Section H; Page 1; Column 1; Giving 

LENGTH: 2467 words

HEADLINE: Marching Smartly to Their Own Drummer

BYLINE: By JULIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
IN an age of sophisticated fund-raising, when megabuck donors are giving charities sums equal to the gross domestic product of a small country, and your college is reminding you oh-so-tactfully that planned giving can reduce your estate taxes, the nation's largest charity is still collecting dimes and quarters the old-fashioned way. At least that's how most Americans perceive the Salvation Army -- as a band of quaint do-gooders in Victorian uniforms urging passers-by to drop coins in the Christmas kettles while an off-key brass band belts carols.
But every year since 1991, the Salvation Army has roosted at the top of the Philanthropy 400, The Chronicle of Philanthropy's list of the nation's biggest charities ranked in terms of private support. Last year, the Salvation Army pulled in $1.2 billion, largely from folks like you and me, up 5 percent from the year earlier and twice the amount of the second-place finisher, the Y.M.C.A. 
 How does such a quill-pen organization raise so much money in the computer age? Not just from those kettles; they produce only about $79 million of the take. Paul Schervish, a sociology professor at Boston College, explained the Army's effectiveness this way: "It is viewed as having low fund-raising costs; its people are courteous and trustworthy; there's a religious dimension that helps donors understand that people are dedicated; and the military structure suggests workers serve but don't coddle the people they help."
To be sure, the traits that make the Army a mighty host in the fund-raising world are based on its being a church-operated army of Christian soldiers. But these qualities can be imitated by nonprofit organizations with no religious orientation. What makes the Army so successful is a combination of three essentials to organizational development: It has a clearly defined and easily understood mission; it holds itself accountable for carrying out its mission and for seeing that money goes to the purposes for which it was raised; and it possesses superior marketing skills.
Most donors don't realize that the Salvation Army is an evangelical Protestant denomination with two to three million members, or Salvationists, worldwide. "It's not just a social service agency, but a church," Peter Dobkin Hall, a senior research scholar at Yale Divinity School, pointed out. "What the Army is most like is a Protestant religious order. Salvationists are intensely spiritual, but they don't lay it on others."
The spirituality is expressed in action, however, not in ritual. Sara Melendez, the president of Independent Sector, a coalition of 700 nonprofit organizations, noted: "They are unique as a charity because there is no division between faith and work. It's all of a piece."
Ed Herzberg, a social service worker at an Army drop-in center for the homeless on East 52nd Street in Manhattan, explained: "In his preface to 'Major Barbara,' George Bernard Shaw says the Army would be a great organization if it got rid of that religious aspect. But if we didn't have the faith, we couldn't do such great work. You need something a little more to deal with the people who need us."
Peter Drucker, the management guru and creator of the Drucker Foundation for Nonprofit Management, repeatedly cites the Army for being the nation's best-managed charity, in part because its mission -- "to meet human needs in his name without discrimination" -- is so clear that it could be silk-screened on a T-shirt.
Followers are reminded of that mission constantly. It hangs on the bulletin board of the East 52nd Street center, for example, where red brick walls, linoleum floors and scuffed furniture create the look of an underfinanced high school.
"The Salvation Army wants commitment -- not to the Army or to a cause, but to the betterment of people," said Captain Allan Hausner, who runs the center, as he tended the cashier's table at the center's rummage sale.
The Army was founded in London in 1865 by William Booth, a Methodist minister and former pawnbroker who felt called to bring the good news of salvation to the slum-dwelling vagrants, prostitutes, alcoholics and thieves who were largely ignored by mainstream churches. From the start, General Booth knew his priorities: soup, soap and salvation -- in that order. He frequently warned adherents that it was futile, not to say unchristian, to preach to someone who was cold and hungry.
"Anybody who walks in the door gets helped; we don't ask if they've been saved," said Julius Stein, a retired police sergeant from New York and now a community service volunteer at the 52nd Street center.
And Sherrill Goswell, a home nursing aide who has helped serve holiday dinners at an Army shelter in Fort Worth, said: "There was no sense that they were trying to convert. They'd say a prayer before meals -- that was it."
The Army carries out its mission through a military command structure that promotes accountability. The clergy is the officer class and numbers 5,339 in the United States. There are 120,000 "soldiers," who have publicly declared their beliefs in Salvation Army principles and agree to abstain from alcohol and tobacco; about 40,000 paid employees; and 1.6 million volunteers.
Officers begin training with two years as cadets in one of four Salvation Army colleges. Cadets are commissioned -- that is, ordained -- as lieutenants and dispatched to take over local churches known as Corps, or to start new ones.
A lieutenant becomes a captain after five years of probation and, 15 years after that, a major. (Shaw would no doubt be dismayed to learn that his Major Barbara, described as a "girl," would actually be close to 40.) When officers marry, they must wed fellow officers or resign their commissions; husbands and wives minister to the same Corps. Divorce results in husband and wife losing their commissions.
Corps report to divisions usually commanded by a colonel; divisions report to one of four territories. Territorial commanders report to national headquarters, which is run by a commissioner who reports to international headquarters in London. The rank of general is reserved for the head of the international organization.
It is a tenet of the business world that you manage what you measure, so that you can figure out whether you are meeting your goals. Army services "are measurable by design, because we do hold ourselves accountable for outcomes," said Lt. Colonel William LaMarr, the commander of the Greater New York division.
Officers are expected to formulate annual goals, providing services that fill gaps in community programs, rather than competing with them. If officers project that their programs will grow annually by a given percent, they are held responsible for seeing that the programs do. Local advisory boards of prominent citizens monitor the goals and the programs.
Colonel LaMarr said the Salvation Army is perceived as trustworthy because it's easy for the public to grasp the concrete. For example, at the back of each year's annual report is a complete listing of operation centers (9,163 at last count), people assisted (32,050,573) and services provided, including meals served (25,517,776) and lodgings supplied (7,251,267). The Army is not involved in advocacy: it is too hard to measure, and be accountable for, swaying hearts and minds.
The returns are more certain from running a youth center, for example, like the one in Hempstead, N.Y., where a gangly 8-year-old first played organized basketball and grew up to be Julius Erving, basketball's famous "Dr. J."
Accountability at the Salvation Army is also financial, to ensure that money raised is used appropriately. There are annual internal audits of the corps by the divisions, divisions by the territories and territories by national headquarters. Public accounting firms audit division, territorial and national accounts. Government social service agencies that finance Army services also monitor what's happening to their money.
Though officers frequently refer to their work as a "calling," the Army thinks of itself as, well, an army, with nothing soft at the center. Witness its 1990 showdown with the Department of Labor, which had come after the Salvation Army for not paying the minimum wage to workers in its adult rehabilitation centers. The Army runs 157 of these alcohol and drug abuse treatment centers throughout the United States. Addicts serious about kicking their habits are given a place to live, meals, counseling and therapy free. Rehabilitation, however, means attending Army services and sorting and packing clothes and other donated goods bound for Army thrift shops, whose income supports the program.
The Salvation Army brought suit asking the courts to enjoin the Labor Department from enforcing the minimum wage laws on the ground that the addicts were beneficiaries of a service, not employees. The suit was dismissed, but the Labor Department did nothing further, perhaps influenced by a realization that the Army might rethink the economics of the centers if it had to pay the minimum wage.
The combination of religious mission and military accountability reinforces a public perception of the Salvation Army as a frugal charity with donations going to support the work. The Army reports that of the $1.8 billion it spent last year, 84 percent went to program services, 4 percent to fund-raising and 12 percent to overhead. According to the National Charities Information Bureau, a philanthropy watchdog organization in New York, a ratio of 70 percent or more of expenses going to the mission is a sign of a well-managed charity.
Overhead is low, indeed. Commissioner John Busby, the head of the United States organization, earns $77,754 a year, which includes the value of his Army-provided housing and two cars, in addition to his pension. Contrast that with the nation's second-biggest charity, the Y.M.C.A., which, according to The Chronicle of Philanthropy, pays its leader, David Mercer, $290,000 in salary and $49,686 in benefits and expense reimbursements. The Army furnishes all officers with a parsonage, a car and a small salary that includes grants for each child until the age of 18. Lt. Col. Tom Jones, the Army's national development director, joked that, "We always have a place to live, a car to drive and almost enough to live on."
FUND-RAISERS understand that people give to what they know, and most of us think we know the Salvation Army. Army trucks pick up old sofas; Army volunteers run shelters for dazed disaster victims; Army rehabilitation centers assist alcoholics and drug addicts. In January, when the Barna Research Group, a California market research firm, conducted a nationwide poll of 1,002 adults, it discovered that 99 percent of them recognized the Salvation Army name and , 91 percent of those held a favorable impression.
General Booth, who was ahead of his time in understanding the power of a brand to attract attention, put his followers in uniform. (This year, one such follower, Patryce CoRae King, attracted attention in civvies as Miss Missouri in the Miss America pageant.) Booth was also responsible for another Army icon, the brass band that announced his open-air meetings. Many of the best orchestras in the United States, including the Chicago Symphony and the New York Philharmonic, have been seeded with Army brass players.
"The training is excellent," said Philip Smith, a Salvationist soldier who is the Philharmonic's principal trumpet player. "Kids play more difficult music than they would in a high school band, and they learn to play more lyrically, because they're frequently accompanying hymn singing."
But the best-known symbol of all was an American invention, the kettle that a San Francisco Salvationist set up in 1891 to give the poor Christmas Day dinners. Though they produce less than 5 percent of the Army's income, "the value of the kettles is branding," said Patricia Foster, the New York director of development. "It's important for us to be visible and on the street corner."
The reality, however, is that the Army is less visible today than in the past. Mr. Stein noted that passers-by are hard put simply to find the 52nd Street Center. But, he added, "People in need can spot the Army by its red shield." Indeed, street people, he said, refer to the Army familiarly as "Sallie."
The Army receives 28 percent of its income, the largest amount, from direct mail solicitations and people who send in checks. (Among other sources, the thrift shops are second at 23 percent; government support and gifts-in-kind each bring in 16 percent.)
Among individual donors are people like Joan Kroc, the widow of Ray Kroc, the founder of McDonald's, who gave $80 million to build a recreation center in San Diego, and Ross Perot, who helped victims of Hurricane Andrew and the floods in the Midwest. Jerry Jones, the owner of the Dallas Cowboys, whose star running back, Emmitt Smith, learned to play football at a Salvation Army youth program in Pensacola, Fla., has dedicated the Cowboys' Thanksgiving halftime show to the kickoff of the annual kettle campaign in Dallas.
And for all its image as a low-tech fund-raiser, the Army was among the first to exploit the possibilities in planned giving tools like gift annuities and remainder trusts. That was 25 years ago. Now, many of these donations are, um, maturing, as fund-raisers delicately say. Colonel Jones estimates that the Army's Southern Territory, which includes Florida, is the biggest of the four in planned giving, having written $122 million in contracts last year. (With the holiday season starting, New Yorkers will hear Mason Adams's distinctive croak on public service radio spots promoting the advantages of the Army's charitable gift annuities.)
Still, the average donor is more likely to be an elderly widow who lived through the Depression or whose husband fought in World War II, where the Army was very visible, and who lives below her means. For many years, the New York division received most of its money from Queens, because many police and firefighters lived there and they saw the Army on the front lines of poverty. Now the money comes from Manhattan, Westchester and Nassau Counties, home to many an Army donor whose circumstances improved and hotbeds of subscribers to the Metropolitan Opera, New York magazine and The New Yorker, whose mailing lists the Army rents.
Whether by accident or design, the Army has tapped into two hazily articulated but often deeply held beliefs, said Diane Winston, who wrote "Red-Hot and Righteous: The Urban Religion of the Salvation Army" (Harvard University Press). "Americans think religion is a good thing," Ms. Winston said, "and helping people is a very good thing."

HEADLINE: New Rallying Cry on Campus: Stockholder Power!

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y.

 BODY:
LIKE a grandchild who has traced the branches of his family tree, Josh Glasstetter is intimately familiar with the history of campus activism at Cornell University, where he is a junior.
He can tell you that students with guns took over Willard Straight Hall in the late 1960's to protest racism; that others floated military contracts like paper airplanes out the windows of Carpenter Hall in the waning days of the Vietnam War, and that still others built shantytowns in the mid-80's to draw attention to apartheid in South Africa. 
 Mr. Glasstetter, 20, sees himself as an heir to that grand tradition, but the weapons of his fight are these: strategic information culled from Edgar, the Web site of the Securities and Exchange Commission; figures buried deep in the annual reports of Fortune 500 companies; and, most critical of all, the proxy questions placed before the shareholders of those companies.
Mr. Glasstetter, whose white-blond hair and 6-foot-7-inch frame make him look more like a refugee from Southern California than the blue-collar suburb of Cleveland where he grew up, is a founder of Students for Socially Responsible Investing at Cornell. The quest of his fledgling group, and dozens of others sprouting on campuses across the country only in the last two years, is nothing less than this: to press universities to examine their endowments for corporate investments that conflict ethically with their missions, and, whenever possible, to use their substantial stakes in those big companies as leverage to lobby for change.
"It's different from the 60's," Mr. Glasstetter said over dinner in a natural foods restaurant near the wooded border of the Cornell campus. "By using the massive influence universities have -- not only in their investing, but in their purchasing and contracting -- we can set standards that corporations will have to uphold if they want to take advantage of universities' money."
He added, "I have friends who want to get into investment banking, just to work from within the system to change it."
Their mission, though new and formidable, is not lonely. This month, Mr. Glasstetter and about 400 other students representing more than 100 colleges and universities descended on the Yale campus for the founding conference of the Student Alliance to Reform Corporations. The alliance is pressing the same themes as the Cornell group, but hopes to marshal the collective strength of tens of billions of dollars invested by scores of university endowments.
Among the common principles of the conference participants is that universities, when contemplating investments, consider a company's record on labor rights, product safety, animal rights, the environment and minorities.
Stephen Viederman, the president of the Jessie Smith Noyes Foundation, a nonprofit organization focused on preserving the environment, among other issues, said the wide draw of the Yale conference should be seen as a loud rebuttal to anyone who believes campus activism has been smothered by the nation's prosperity. "What is most important about all this is that students are trying to teach universities something, that investments have consequences," Mr. Viederman said. "That is something universities themselves don't teach in economics classes or business schools."
The wider movement has its roots not only in civil rights protests, but also in the antiapartheid effort, which urged universities to divest themselves of holdings in companies that did business in South Africa. But where Mr. Glasstetter's ancestors had slogans like "Make Love, Not War" and "Divest Now!," his group has struggled to find a rallying cry.
The Cornell group minted buttons last year that read "What? My tuition is going where?" But soon after the buttons appeared on backpacks, the students learned that tuition was spent on operating expenses, and not invested. The buttons had to be scrapped.
Finding a chant, an essential element of any protest, has proven no easier. For now, the students have settled on, "Hey, Hey! Ho, Ho! Bad Investments Have Got to Go!" But they are eagerly seeking alternatives.
In one sense, Mr. Glasstetter and the 14 or so other die-hard members of his group at Cornell have taken a page from the antiapartheid movement and urged that Cornell sell its stock in an "incorrigible" company: the cigarette manufacturer Philip Morris, of which Cornell, by its most recent tally, held 157,000 shares, worth $5.4 million on Sept. 30. (Cornell, citing the advice of its outside portfolio managers, has so far refused.)
BUT in marked contrast to the antiapartheid movement, the students' preferred strategy is more nuanced: they have followed the lead of a handful of foundations and socially conscious mutual funds that have sought to retain high-profile investments, rather than relinquish them, in an effort to prod progress.
The victories of the broader movement have been relatively few. A nearly two-year quest to persuade Yale to divest itself of tobacco holdings was ultimately unsuccessful, with Yale saying that it believed it could do more good working from within the tobacco companies than by walking away from them. Yale, which has invested about $9 million of its $7.2 billion endowment in tobacco stocks, has, for example, written letters to tobacco companies, urging that tobacco not be sold to minors, said Lawrence Haas, a Yale spokesman.
The Cornell group has made more substantial gains in the last school year. Last spring, for example, four students won an audience with the university's chief financial officer, and, later, the chairman of the trustee investment relations committee, to make this pitch: that the university swing its 308,000 shares in Home Depot, worth $18.8 million at the time, behind a shareholder initiative urging the home improvement chain to consider a ban on products manufactured from virgin timber cut from the world's oldest forests.
The trustees agreed.
"They did an outstanding job of explaining why the company should support this and what benefits it would have to us, as a university and a stockholder," said Frederick Rogers, the senior vice president and chief financial officer of Cornell, describing the students.
Though the environmentalists and others who supported the initiative ultimately lost their proxy fight at the company's annual meeting last May, Home Depot announced in August that it would refrain from using wood harvested from "environmentally sensitive areas."
For the students at Cornell, the Home Depot experience has already paid a rich dividend: the student assembly, the university's student government, has formed a standing committee that will make regular presentations about shareholder initiatives it believes the university should endorse.
But the students face a high hurdle: Mr. Rogers said that increasing the value of Cornell's endowment was the university's first priority, and that it was content to relinquish to outside money managers the responsibility of selecting stocks. Thus, Philip Morris, on the managers' advice, has remained in the university's portfolio.
Mr. Glasstetter said he would defer to other members of his group to serve on the new committee. But he will continue to lobby the university to make its investment preferences clear. That could mean a sequel to a rally the group held last year, called "Dress Up as the Company You Hate the Most." Mr. Glasstetter transformed himself into a box of cigarettes.
For Mr. Glasstetter, whose father owned a couple of gas stations outside Cleveland in the 1970's and 80's, his transformation into an activist cements a radical change in his life. As an adolescent, he had aggressively invested several thousand dollars given him by his family in blue-chip stocks, only to become disillusioned and divest himself on the eve of going to college.
"I totally bought into this idealistic vision of American big business and the thought that it was doing only great things for the entire world," he said. "That's a very one-sided, blind vision of what's going on."

LENGTH: 923 words

HEADLINE: Desktop Discount Shopping, The Newest Perquisite

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
First came corporate day care centers. Then it was concierge services that pick up employees' dry cleaning or deliver groceries for a fee. Now comes the virtual discount mall, offering workers everything from books to car insurance at up to 10 percent off, right on their office computer screens.
In the latest attempt to please workers without giving them big raises, some of the nation's largest companies are trying to make shopping of all kinds both cheaper and easier for their employees. It is part of an explosion of soft benefits, which, unlike the hard perquisites of health insurance and retirement plans, cost employers almost nothing. 
 With unemployment at a 29-year low and people working longer hours, executives see the programs as a way to lift workers' morale. They also assume that employees who do their shopping in cyberspace will spend less time ducking out of the office to run errands. At the least, Susan R. Froid, a senior human resource manager at Microsoft, said, employees "don't have to spend all their free time figuring out what they're going to do -- it's an easy decision to make."
That was the pull for Lisa Rose, who works on hiring and training for Sylvan Learning Systems, an education company in Baltimore. When she heard about the offers, she logged onto Sylvan's Web site and bought medical insurance for her 6-month-old Labrador, Ewing, who is named after the New York Knicks center whom her husband idolizes. The cost, $16 a month, is deducted from her paycheck.
She also bought roadside insurance that covers towing, locksmith service and travel planning for $4.16 a month, not even bothering to compare the insurer's prices with AAA's. "It was so easy for me to sign up, and I don't have to pay another bill every month," she said.
The trend has picked up in recent weeks, with such corporate giants as AlliedSignal, Hallmark Cards, Nordstrom and Northwest Airlines connecting their internal Web sites to virtual malls where merchants sell everything from Hickory Farms sausage to MCI Worldcom long-distance service. The pioneers for such plans include Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, Blue Cross/ Blue Shield, Boeing and Microsoft.
"It's so difficult to attract employees, and the retention side is getting more difficult," said Joe Demarte, the vice president for human resources at Nordstrom, the department store chain, which employs 40,000 people. The discounts are the latest addition to a benefit package that includes adoption advice and discounts on legal services.
The virtual malls are an Internet-age remake of the old corporate discount card that gave employees free tickets to a nearby amusement park or a few dollars off at the local florist. The World Wide Web, however, allows workers in satellite offices to take advantage of the discounts. It also enables employers to negotiate deals for a much wider array of products, including expensive items like insurance and mortgages.
The Internet discounts are part of a wider move toward offering more soft benefits to placate time-burdened workers. In 1994, for example, only 8 percent of companies made car insurance available to workers through company-sponsored plans. Next year, the portion should rise to 35 percent, according to Hewitt Associates, a management consulting firm in Illinois.
The virtual malls are typically operated by Internet start-ups, which charge employers nothing for the service and build password-protected links from the corporate intranet sites to, say, toysrus.com. In exchange for what amounts to advertising on the Web site and in company brochures describing the program, merchants then offer the 5 percent to 10 percent discounts and pay a few percentage points of each sale to the Internet companies.
The trend is even creating a new niche of e-commerce. Employeesavings.com received a $5 million investment earlier this year from Benchmark Capital, which previously financed eBay and Webvan. By early 2000, employeesavings says its plans will cover two million people. And Rewards Plus, which sells only financial products, expects its annual sales to more than double to $9 million this year, as it increases its work force by 25 percent each quarter.
The programs are not without their downsides. Not all employees have Internet access, and those who do not -- some Nordstrom sales clerks or Northwest flight attendants, for example -- are often the ones who need the discounts the most because they make less money. (Companies say, however, that some of the discounts are available over the phone or at local stores.)
Web shopping is also a potential threat to productivity, giving workers a company-approved reason to procrastinate. Already, the peak time for Web traffic and many consumer e-commerce sites is the middle of the workday, when people have access to high-speed corporate Internet connections.
But human resource managers said they were not worried. "This isn't something where you're going to go out and play for hours," Mr. Demarte said. "It probably isn't any different from what they already do" by making personal phone calls.
And it may be cheaper. Robert A. Arrison, 41, a computer systems administrator at Aramark Inc., the Philadelphia food service company, was shopping for homeowners' and auto insurance a year ago. He checked the rates of Allstate Insurance, which had sold him a previous policy, and Allmerica Financial, which participated in his company's discount plan. By going with Allmerica, he said, he saved almost $200 a year.

HEADLINE: WINE TALK;
For an American Holiday, Anything Goes

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
ACCORDING to the earliest accounts of the first Thanksgiving, the meal included birds, corn, peas, roast venison and beer. Beer? Apparently there was not yet a decent wine shop in all of Massachusetts.
There are probably quite a few people who still drink beer with their Thanksgiving dinner, and given some of the delicious beers on the market now, it could make for a delightful partnership. But beer is filling, and with the amount of food most of us are expected to ingest on Thanksgiving, wine is a wiser and more festive choice. 
 The traditional Thanksgiving repast is neither a delicate meal nor a sophisticated one; it does not blend subtle, fleeting tastes and aromas. So it is not a time to bring out great white Burgundies, for instance. A big Champagne, like Krug or Bollinger, will hold its own quite well with turkey. But most people are saving their Champagne for the New Year's Eve of all New Year's Eves.
Besides, Thanksgiving is an American event whose centerpiece, the turkey, goes back, oh, 40 million years or so. I guess that makes it as indigenous as an American creature can be. In my chauvinistic view, the bird -- and the rest of us -- deserve American wines.
Choosing domestic wines offers an unexpected bonus. White Burgundy may be out, but California chardonnay, which for my money is too overwhelming for most fowl, is the perfect match for turkey. There are some restrained, elegant chardonnays around, though for the most part California chardonnay is a big-bodied, robust white wine full of up-front flavor and aroma. In other words, just right for the less than subtle taste of a roast turkey filled with a pungent dressing.
For a rich, powerful chardonnay, I'd suggest Chalone Vineyards 1997, a big, buttery, complex wine from the Gavilan Mountains south of San Francisco. It will hold its own in any company, including game. Or if you are planning a venison dinner and you prefer a white wine, this could be the one for you. (About $30.)
A bit less strident, perhaps, but still assertive is Fess Parker's American Tradition Reserve Chardonnay 1997, from the Santa Ynez Valley north of Santa Barbara. The wine has plenty of extract, a nice touch of oak, and a remarkably long finish. (About $20).
For something completely different, there's Tablas Creek Blanc 1997, a muscular blend of three Rhone Valley grapes: marsanne, viognier and roussanne. Tablas Creek is a relatively new winery near Paso Robles, in San Luis Obispo County, started in 1990 by the Perrin family of Chateau de Beaucastel in Chateauneuf-du-Pape. While not a replica of a blockbuster Hermitage white, this white is both elegant and intense. (About $27.)
Most traditionalists will want a red wine with their Thanksgiving dinner, and if they are also patriots, they will probably call for zinfandel, the grape America has adopted as its own. Ridge Vineyards in Santa Clara makes a variety of zinfandels from grapes purchased all over California, the unifying factor being what one wine guide calls the "classic restraint" of the winemaker, Paul Draper. I take that to mean that the wines are rich and intense but less rough and rustic than so many other zinfandels. Ridge's 1996 Sonoma Station Zinfandel has zinfandel fruitiness and classic Ridge structure. (About $20.)
Amador County, far to the east of the Napa Valley, produces some of the best zinfandel grapes. Ravenswood, in Sonoma County, another winery that made its name with zinfandel, uses Amador grapes for one of its most enticing bottlings, Ravenswood Amador County. The scent of blackberries fills the room once the bottle is opened; on the palate, the flavors linger on and on. (About $15.)
For most families, the best choice is a wine priced low enough so that opening another bottle or three or four is not going to precipitate a post-dinner economic crisis. ("That uncle of yours can sure put it away!") For many savvy wine drinkers, the choice is Marietta Cellars Old Vine Red, a blend that lets the winemaker, Chris Bilbro in Sonoma County, use whatever he thinks will produce the kind of wine he wants to make. Zinfandel, carignane, syrah and cabernet may find their way into this delicious, full-bodied wine. Different vintages may be used, which is why the wine is identified only by lot number. Currently for sale, if you can find this very popular wine, is Lot No. 23. (About $12.)
By this point, there are probably quite a few people muttering, "Where's the merlot?" For me, most merlot is too soft and unstructured, without enough tannin, for a main course like turkey -- unless it is bolstered with 30 percent cabernet sauvignon. Here is one that sort of breaks the rules: Canoe Ridge from Washington State has merlot's softer taste, but it has good body. (About $19.)
Not too many years ago, it would have been difficult to create a completely American wine selection for an important meal. No longer. A Schramsberg Blanc de Blancs as an aperitif will match any French Champagne in its price range. (About $25.)
Then, end the day not with Cognac or grappa but with a great American drink, Laird's 12-year-old apple brandy. (About $50). Thanksgiving became an official holiday in 1863; the Lairds began making apple brandy in 1780. Did somebody say something about tradition?

HEADLINE: Georgia Trying Anxiously to Stay Out of Chechen War

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: TBILISI, Georgia, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Capped in snow, the Shatili Mountains are fabled for their rugged beauty. These days they are also one of the Caucasus' more anxious borders.
To the north is Chechnya, a brutal battleground for the Russian military. On the southern side of the mountain divide is Georgia, a former Soviet republic. 
 The Georgians would like nothing better than to stay out of the fighting in the rebellious Russian province to the north. But they have had to contend with a hard-nosed Russian military, which recently sought permission to open a new front against Chechnya from Georgian territory.
"It is very important for us to have good-neighborly relations with Russia, but good relations do not mean saying no to our principles," the Georgian president, Eduard Shevardnadze, said in an interview. "I am categorically opposed to having Russian and Georgian border troops jointly defend the border with Chechnya. And I am even more opposed to the idea of the Russian side using Russian bases in Georgia against Chechnya in a military campaign."
When world leaders meet this week in Istanbul to discuss security issues, the increasingly tense situation in the Caucasus will be among their top concerns. Diplomats have been working behind the scenes on conventional arms limits, energy pipelines and the burning conflict in Chechnya to make the summit meeting a success -- or, at least, not a disappointing embarrassment.
Like Baltic nations during Soviet times, the Caucasus is shaping up as an arena for East-West competition, and possibly even a bit of Russian intrigue. The tone may have been set last week when Marshal Igor Sergeyev, Russia's defense minister, declared that Russia and the United States were locked in a bitter struggle for dominance of the Caucasus, Caspian and Central Asian regions.
Certainly, Georgia's leaders are worried that Russia is determined not only to subdue Chechnya but also to try to reverse Russia's waning influence in the neighboring region.
It is not surprising that Georgia would be particularly sensitive to the political winds blowing from Moscow. Mr. Shevardnadze, a former Soviet foreign minister, has repeatedly insisted that the future of his country lies with the West. He has even said Georgia intends to apply for NATO membership in 2005, which would be the last year of Mr. Shevardnadze's next term as president, assuming he is re-elected next spring.
But Georgia is also a poor nation, burdened with secessionist movements of its own and a long legacy of economic and military dependence on its Russian neighbor.
Russia still maintains four military bases here, including the Vaziani air base just 30 minutes from Tbilisi, Georgia's capital. Mr. Shevardnadze's policy has been to develop Georgia's links with the West while gradually easing the Russian troops out.
Russia recently removed the last of its 15,000 border troops. Georgian officials have sought to use the coming Istanbul meeting to negotiate the closing of key Russian bases as well as to bring about a sharp reduction in the number of Russian forces here. The understandings are part of an updated accord limiting conventional arms, which diplomats hope to sign in Istanbul.
At the same time, Georgia's relations with Russia have worsened as a result of the Chechen war. And Georgia's officials have become concerned that the Russians are in no hurry to leave.
Last month, for instance, Russia sought to send several hundred border troops back to Georgia to help the Georgians patrol their 50-mile-long border with Chechnya, the only stretch of the Chechen border that is not under Russia's jurisdiction. It is currently guarded by 160 lightly armed Georgian border troops.
As many as 4,000 refugees, mostly women and children, have crossed into Georgia in the last two months to flee the fighting in Chechnya. That is a trickle compared with the 200,000 refugees who have fled to Ingushetia, another Russian republic bordering on Chechnya.
But Russia believes that the mountain passes to Georgia may become an exit route for Shamil Basayev, the Chechen warlord sought by the Russians, or some of his fighters if Russian troops continue their march into Chechnya and seize Grozny, the capital. Russian officials have also charged that arms have been smuggled across the border, an allegation Georgians deny.
Russia has also broached the idea of using some of its bases in Georgia in the military campaign against Chechnya, the Georgians say. Marshal Sergeyev planned to come to Tbilisi to discuss the plan, but his trip was canceled after Georgia rejected the idea, Georgian officials here said.
The Georgian government fears that the Russian aim was to use its border troops and bases to encircle Chechnya and open up a new front in the war.
"Had we gone along with those options, we could have been drawn into a big conflict in the Caucasus," Mr. Shevardnadze said.
Georgia's rebuff, however, did not go down well in Moscow. Soon afterward, the Russian prime minister, Vladimir V. Putin, declared that citizens from Georgia and the neighboring former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan would have to obtain visas to travel to Russia, ostensibly to guard against arms trafficking and infiltration by terrorists.
Then Russian military officials unleashed a barrage of allegations suggesting that the Georgians were in league with the Chechen fighters. In fact, there is no love lost between the Christian Orthodox Georgian authorities and the militantly Islamic Mr. Basayev, who fought on the side of Muslim secessionists in Georgia.
Despite the angry words, experts here doubt that Russia has a grand strategy to reassert itself in the Caucasus. But as President Boris N. Yeltsin's physical and political health has declined, rival agendas have emerged in Moscow, with the Russian military taking a particularly hard line.
An immediate test of Russian intentions will come this week at the Istanbul meeting, held by the Organization for Economic and Security Cooperation in Europe, where world leaders hope to sign an updated version of the 1990 agreement limiting conventional forces in Europe.
As part of that accord, the Georgians want the Russians to accept the principle that their forces in Georgia should not exceed those of the modest Georgian military. That would force the Russians to cut their armored combat vehicles in Georgia, for instance, by more than half.
Georgian officials want the Russians to agree to quit the Vaziani air base, near their capital, and the Gudauta base, in the Georgian Abkhazian region.
The Vaziani base is a visible reminder of Moscow's once-dominant role here. Gudauta is situated in the breakaway Abkhazian sector, where Georgia has long suspected the Russians of aiding the separatists.
At least some Georgian officials, however, are dubious that Russia is prepared to meet their demands and to reduce, quickly, its military presence in Georgia.
"Russia's broad strategy is to keep their numbers in the Caucasus and even increase these numbers," said Archil M. Gegeshidze, the national security adviser to Mr. Shevardnadze. "Agreeing with our proposals and starting a process of reduction is something that is against their long-term strategy."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Growth in Japan Is Expected To Lift World Rate in 2000

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The world economy is growing at an unexpectedly fast pace because of surprisingly strong expansion in Japan and South Korea, a more modest upturn in Europe and economic resilience in the United States, an organization of the world's richest nations said here today in a semiannual appraisal.
The group, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which helps coordinate policy among the affluent nations, said it expected the global growth rate to reach 3.5 percent next year. Its assessment in May had forecast growth in 2000 of 2.9 percent. 
 "The outlook for world and O.E.C.D.-wide output growth has improved substantially over the past few months," the organization said.
Its report suggested that Japan's economic recovery in particular had been more vigorous than anticipated. The organization's earlier assessment projected that Japan would continue to struggle next year against recession, its worst since the end of World War II.
"These changes reflect mainly unexpected near-term momentum in the United States economy, a stronger and more rapid resumption of growth in Japan and, particularly, South Korea, as well as a slightly better outlook for the European Union," the report said.
Europe, it said, is showing signs of expansion and in 2000 and 2001 is expected to grow 2.8 percent in the 11-nation euro currency zone. In its last report, the O.E.C.D. predicted euro zone growth next year of 2.6 percent.
The report also suggested that European countries would make progress against high unemployment.
It forecast 3.1 percent growth for the United States next year, after predicting last spring that the American economy faced a natural slowdown and 2 percent growth after eight years of expansion.
And it said that Japan, the world's second-largest economy, had emerged from recession faster than expected, but that in the long term it faced risks from the continued appreciation of the yen.
The Japanese currency's strength this year has already hurt profit at many big-name corporations that derive much of their business from exports, like Sony, Toyota and Hitachi. The yen's rise partly reflects the increased prospect of higher interest rates in Japan because of the heavy borrowing that the government must undertake to stimulate growth through spending.
Last week, the Japanese government announced a new package of economic stimulants worth about $171 billion, almost twice the amount that had been expected a few weeks earlier.
The 29-member O.E.C.D., founded in 1960, was originally made up of nations in Europe and North America. It expanded to include Japan, Australia, New Zealand and Finland. More recently, Mexico, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and South Korea have joined.

SECTION: Section A; Page 25; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Lean Budget, Bloated Government

BYLINE: By Jonathan Rauch; Jonathan Rauch is author of the forthcoming "Government's End: Why Washington Stopped Working."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The closing convulsions of the budget negotiations have marked the return of a condition rarely seen in Washington these days: calm. No partisan train wreck. No government shutdown. In a sort of tacit exchange, conservatives demanded no major reductions in the scope or size of government, and liberals did not demand costly new expansions.
Instead, the White House and Congressional Republicans have haggled behind closed doors over a few contested priorities. President Clinton wanted more new teachers; Congress wanted to curtail abortions abroad. 
 Symbolically, such things matter, but in the context of a $1.8 trillion federal budget, they are flyspecks. Mr. Clinton and the Republicans now act like a husband and wife who loathe each other but have become too tired to fight.
But there is news in the budget compromise. This year seals the failure of a 20-year effort by several Presidents and Republican Congresses to assert control over government programs.
Ever since Barry Goldwater rose to prominence in the late 1950's, conservatives have wanted to make government smaller -- not just to reduce its overall spending, but to eliminate what they regarded as wasteful or illegitimate programs.
David Stockman, President Ronald Reagan's first budget director, tried and failed. In eight years, Mr. Reagan eliminated only four major programs: general revenue sharing with local governments, urban-development action grants, the synthetic-fuels program and the Clinch River breeder reactor in Tennessee.
In 1995, Newt Gingrich tried again. As speaker of the House, he managed to chop out a couple of hundred items, almost all of them too small to notice.
For his trouble, Mr. Gingrich, like Mr. Stockman, earned the enmity of the thousands of groups that make their living by preserving programs that benefit them. Those groups and the Democrats portrayed Mr. Gingrich and his party as mad slashers. This image, plus the government shutdown, cost the Republicans dearly in the next two elections.
Since then, conservatives have subsided into a torpor. In 1997, they ended about two dozen small programs, like the Delaware River Basin Commission and the Railroad Retirement Board's management improvement fund.
In 1998, they killed about 10 programs. The sums involved were trivial: a total of $134 million in 1997, even less the year after.
Stephen Moore, the director of fiscal policy studies at the Cato Institute, notes that the 70 or so biggest programs that Republican revolutionaries once swore to eliminate -- like the Appalachian Regional Commission and the National Writing Project -- are not only still there, but they have had their average spending grow by 3 percent since the Republicans took over Congress.
If domestic programs were not cut, how did Congress balance the budget? By cutting defense (a well that is now nearly empty), raising taxes and riding the economic boom.
In this year's budget fight, the conservatives gave up altogether on eliminating programs. To achieve a spending reduction of less than $4 billion, or just a fifth of 1 percent of the total budget, they went with an across-the-board spending reduction. In effect, they couldn't find any significant programs that they could do without.
The conservatives' failure gives liberals no cause for celebration. In effect, the attempted reforms of the 1980's and 1990's have ended in a conundrum: the government should balance the budget, but it must do so while preserving more or less every program it has ever adopted. That means conservatives cannot get rid of old programs, but it also means that liberals can only rarely create innovative new ones.
Two decades ago, the country began wrestling with both high deficits and an intractable array of government programs. Now, finally, fiscal reform has triumphed, at the precise moment that governmental reform has collapsed.

HEADLINE: U.S. Output Rose Sharply In October

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Industrial production climbed at its fastest rate in seven months during October as utilities and factories rebounded from a dip in September, the Federal Reserve said today.
Production by the nation's mines, factories and utilities rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, much stronger than expected, after falling a revised one-tenth of 1 percent in September, when Hurricane Floyd wreaked havoc on the East Coast. 
 The report of rising manufacturing vigor came before Federal Reserve policy makers met today to consider whether to raise interest rates for a third time this year. They decided to do so, raising short-term rates a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent.
"This is another healthy sign that productivity is rising," Sung Won Sohn, an economist at Wells Fargo Bank in Minneapolis, said of the report. "We're seeing manufacturing humming with employment gains slowing -- that is productivity."
The October increase in industrial production was the biggest since a matching rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent in March, more than twice the gain of three-tenths of 1 percent forecast by analysts.
"In the recovery after the storm, output rebounded at electrical utilities and in a number of manufacturing industries," the Fed said.
Automakers raised their production rate to 13.2 million new cars and trucks a year from 12.9 million in September, signaling their expectations of brisk consumer demand ahead.
Elliott Platt, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York, said that the October production gain was more than simply a bounceback from Hurricane Floyd. He pointed to export demand and possible stockpiling by businesses against Year 2000 problems.
Asian economies have been reviving after a lengthy slump throughout 1998, providing a stronger market for United States-made products.
Businesses ran at 80.7 percent of capacity in October, up from 80.4 percent in September, for the strongest operating rate since last December when they were also at 80.7 percent of capacity.
But Ken Mayland, an economist with KeyCorp in Cleveland, said there was no cause for concern since capacity utilization rates are now lower than they were two years ago and there was industrial slack in overseas economies.
"This means that U.S. industrial production can sustain a rapid pace of growth for more than a year before there would be any possibility of bottlenecks and price pressures," Mr. Mayland said.
The Fed said that manufacturers increased their production in October by six-tenths of 1 percent after a slim rise of one-tenth of 1 percent in September. It was the most vigorous increase in manufacturing activity in a year, since a rise in October 1998 of seven-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Newcomer Gets Attention In Newark

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
JUST a few years ago, Cory Booker seemed to face a stark choice: he could aim to own the world or save it.
An all-American high school football player from Bergen County, Stanford graduate and Rhodes scholar, Mr. Booker was not wanting for lucrative opportunities when he left Yale Law School. Instead he moved to a lousy building here on Martin Luther King Boulevard, which, if you believe Chris Rock, makes it the worst street in the city. 
 He had arrived with a suburban liberal vision of creating one more nonprofit do-gooder group on downtrodden Newark. But then his neighbors saw him take on a slum lord on the block.
"Boy, are you here to be a lawyer or to help the community?" an activist named Virginia Jones asked him. "If you're here to help the community, then you're going to be our candidate for councilman."
It's been 18 months since Mr. Booker, 30, unseated the veteran Central Ward councilman, George Branch, and, in the estimation of many, lodged the sturdiest wrench in this city's machine politics in a long time. He's high on the handicappers' short list of mayoral contenders in 2002.
This weekend, he will help lead a two-day march to draw attention to the plight of the children, who have among the highest rates of infant mortality, teenage pregnancy and failure to finish high school in the nation. This is not exactly the message promoted by the political establishment, which is celebrating Newark's first period of sustained momentum since the 1967 riots.
Officials first denied the march a permit, citing the difficulty of providing security, and Mayor Sharpe James complained to reporters that the march "seems to be a protest against existing service." A new permit application is pending.
"In many ways, Booker's returning to a more elemental issue in black politics, which is the poor who were not able to ride the crest of urban revitalization," said Clement Price, an expert on Newark at Rutgers University.
Despite a privileged childhood, Mr. Booker knew exclusion. He grew up in the comfortable town of Harrington Park, the son of two I.B.M. employees, but his parents had such trouble buying a house that they sued for discrimination. Mr. Booker and his brother were the only blacks in their public school for much of their childhood, and Mr. Booker still remembers the parents of his white prom date refusing to let her out of the house.
He was drawn to cities, volunteering in impoverished East Palo Alto, Calif., while at Stanford and in New Haven while at Yale. Why, he asked, did a black child born in New Haven in the 1990's have less chance of success than Mr. Booker's father, who grew up poor in a segregated town in the hills of North Carolina two generations ago?
Mr. Booker does not overlook the accomplishments in downtown Newark: a new, grand performing arts center; a new minor league baseball stadium; the anticipated arrival of the Nets; a hot real estate market; and a drop in crime. Mr. James calls Newark Renaissance City.
"How do you measure a renaissance?" Mr. Booker asked. "If you measure it in health indices, it's not a renaissance. If you measure it by unemployment, there's been no appreciable difference. If you measure it by median income, there's been no real change."
NOR has the renaissance hit local government. The much-derided school system is under state control, and 1990's municipal corruption scandals resulted in convictions of three City Council members, a former police director and Mayor James's former chief of staff.
Mr. Booker said he came here from Yale because "I had New Jersey in my blood," but clearly some of the old guard sniff ambition. "The guy is paranoid about Cory," one local party official said of Mr. James, who did not return telephone calls.
But Mr. Booker has their attention. Last summer, he organized a vigil at a large housing development in his ward to draw attention to the feverish drug trade. For 10 days, he and his supporters fasted and slept in tents on the grounds of the development, holding health and employment workshops by day. The event succeeded in replacing the drug dealers with a 24-hour police van and a security fence.
The mayor was absent from the newsconference at the start of the vigil, but he was there at the end, with praise and a hug for Mr. Booker, and a hint he could hear his footsteps. "Just as there was a Ken Gibson and a Sharpe James," the mayor said then, referring to the mayor he defeated in 1986, "there will be a Cory Booker and others."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
The Delta Shuttle sets the formal opening of its renovated Marine Air Terminal tomorrow.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
SOME of the improvements have been in place almost a week, but tomorrow the Delta Shuttle will formally open its newly renovated Marine Air Terminal at La Guardia Airport in New York -- a terminal used almost exclusively by business travelers flying between New York and Boston and Washington. (The U S Airways Shuttle departs from that airline's main terminal at La Guardia.)
Among the improvements resulting from Delta's yearlong, $7.5 million overhaul are an upgraded business center with free fax and photocopy services, and several computer stations. A new Bloomberg News station in the waiting area has two computers and a larger screen with a continuous display of financial results, as well as the latest stock prices. 
 In the gate area, automated ticketing kiosks with touch-screen technology allow passengers to receive boarding passes in less than a minute. The redesigned passenger waiting area now has more electrical outlets and telephones with data ports for computers. Baggage carts with cover flaps -- and weather screens on the outside baggage conveyor belt -- will provide better protection for passengers' checked luggage.
Promising "many enhancements" in the near future, William Crumbley, the managing director of the Delta Shuttle, said that the overwhelming majority of its passengers traveled to or from New York. Since its acquisition from Pan Am in 1991, the Delta Shuttle has carried more than 15 million passengers.
 
Pan Am Expands Service
The current incarnation of Pan American Airways is only a shadow of its former self, but today it is scheduled to begin round-trip service six days a week between its headquarters in Portsmouth, N.H., and Gary/Chicago Airport in northern Indiana, and similar service between Gary/Chicago and Sanford/Orlando Airport in central Florida.
Acquired after bankruptcy proceedings in June 1998 by four New England investors, Pan Am operated as a charter airline until last month when it began Portsmouth-Orlando flights six days a week.
 
More Leg Room on Delta
Beginning Dec. 2, Delta Air Lines will begin flying the Boeing 767-300ER aircraft between Kennedy International Airport in New York and Sky Harbor Airport in Phoenix. Delta said its business-class seats had more than double the space of first-class seats of other carriers flying nonstop between New York and Phoenix.
 
LanChile-Alaska Air Accord
LanChile said yesterday that it had entered into a code-sharing agreement with Alaska Airlines. Passengers on both airlines are eligible to participate in the other's frequent-flier programs. Also, through Jan. 31, 2000, LanChile frequent-flier members can earn 1,865 miles when they stay at participating Hyatt Hotels and Resorts in Chicago, Dallas, Los Angeles, Miami, New York, San Francisco, Buenos Aires and Santiago, Chile. After January, each stay at a Hyatt will earn 385 miles. And when LanChile joins the One World alliance, a move tentatively scheduled for next March, its frequent-flier miles can be redeemed on other alliance airlines, including AMR's American Airlines, British Airways and Air Canada.
 
Ever-Bigger Ships
Bigness may not be everything, as the economist E. F. Schumacher argued in his 1973 book "Small Is Beautiful," but you couldn't prove that from the cruise industry's ever-bigger ships. On Nov. 8, Carnival's Cunard Lines announced that it had completed plans for what will be the longest passenger ship ever built (1,100 feet), to be introduced in 2003.
Two days later, on Nov. 10, the Port of Miami-Dade officially opened what it described as the world's biggest cruise passenger terminal (250,000 square feet). And a day after that, this season's biggest cruise ship, Royal Caribbean's 142,000-ton Voyager of the Seas, capable of carrying 3,100 passengers, arrived in Miami in preparation for its year-round seven-night cruises to the Caribbean beginning on Nov. 21.
There are, of course, a number of cruise lines with small ships sailing interesting itineraries. But the reason for the huge ships is that they are intended not just to take passengers on a cruise but on a floating vacation, the better to compete with land-based resorts.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Rates May Rise, but This Bull Is Hanging On

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
INTEREST rates may rise, the Federal Reserve may fret, but there's just no keeping a good bull market down.
Voicing concerns that the economy is too darn hot and employment is way too tight, the Fed yesterday raised short-term interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point. Stock investors generally dislike interest rate increases because, in the broadest sense, they raise the cost of operating a business. Rising rates also make bonds more attractive than stocks as investments. 
 So it was not too surprising that the Fed's rate increase rattled stocks after it was announced. A quick blip upward could not be sustained, and the Dow Jones industrials fell about 140 points on the news.
Minutes later, stock traders got their bearings and roared with approval over the move. The white-hot Nasdaq composite index gained 73.51 points on the day, a 2.28 percent increase. The Dow Jones industrial average raced ahead 171.58 points, or 1.59 percent. At the end of the trading day, the Dow stood at 10,932.33, just 3.8 percent below its high reached last August.
The investor euphoria after the Fed's action seemed to be based on two assumptions. Most compelling was the view that the Fed's move was the last rate increase for the foreseeable future. The next meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee takes place on Dec. 21, an unlikely occasion for anyone except Ebenezer Scrooge to raise rates. The meeting after that, in early February, is expected to feature economic statistics distorted by Year 2000 anomalies. As a result, many economists have concluded that the Fed will not move again on rates until next spring regardless of what the economic numbers show.
Stock investors also liked yesterday's decision by the Fed to shift into neutral on any future moves. Before the meeting, the Fed had assumed a stance that favored tightening.
The increase yesterday in the federal funds rate, the Fed's third increase since June, raises the overnight rate charged by banks when they lend excess funds to one another.
The Fed also raised the rate at which banks can borrow from the central bank, called the discount rate, to 5 percent, a quarter-point move. Some banks responded by raising the prime rate, a benchmark for what they charge some of their best customers, with others likely to follow.
But even as stock investors celebrated, bond investors took up their worry beads. Bond prices fell, pushing up the yield on the 30-year United States Treasury bond to 6.06 percent yesterday, from 6.024 percent on Monday. Bond investors chose to read the Fed's statement that accompanied the rate rises as a warning that further rate increases will follow if the economy does not start to cool.
"We have to see growth slow down to ensure that this is in fact going to be the last tightening move," said Stephen D. Slifer, chief United Sates economist at Lehman Brothers. Mr. Slifer pointed out that recent hints of a slowdown, flattening retail sales and a decline in the housing sector had to be echoed in other data for the Fed to relax on rates. "If this turns out to be another fakeout and growth continues to be 4 to 5 percent," Mr. Slifer said, "the Fed will be back."
In its comments, the Fed gave clues to what economic data it will be watching most closely in coming weeks to help it decide where to go on interest rates. A prime cause for alarm is the low unemployment rate, the central bank said. With unemployment falling to a 29-year low of 4.1 percent last month, many fear that the United States is running out of employable workers. Such low unemployment cannot continue indefinitely without leading to higher labor costs and rising inflation.
What is more, overall economic growth is running well ahead of the rate the Fed would prefer to see. The initial estimate on gross domestic product growth in the third quarter is an increase of 4.8 percent; economists say this figure may be revised up to 5.5 percent. Either number is far above the Fed's target growth rate of 3 percent or even 3.5 percent.
Although the Fed's statement made no mention of elevated stock prices and the ensuing wealth effect from investors who feel more free to spend, Alan Greenspan, the Fed Chairman, has telegraphed to investors that rising stock prices have become a factor in his decisions on rates. In a speech before the Business Council on Oct. 28, Mr. Greenspan alluded to the wealth effect when he remarked upon the "expanding net worth of households relative to income." If the nation's households are seeing their net worths rising faster than their incomes, much of this is driven by stocks.
As a result, the strong rally seen in stocks yesterday may have the unintended consequence of increasing the likelihood of future moves to raise rates. This is also a risk because a rising stock market translates very closely to increased retail sales and other signs of economic strength.
According to International Strategy and Investment, an investment advisory firm, the stock market and Christmas sales are inextricably linked. Last year, for example, the market was up 17 percent in the fourth quarter from the third quarter, and retail sales grew at a strong 11 percent rate from the previous quarter. Conversely, in 1997, the stock market rose 3 percent in the fourth quarter, and retail sales moved up at exactly the same rate.
Mr. Slifer agreed that the stock market acts as a great force on the economy. "If the stock boys keep revving it up here and stock prices go up again," he said, "then budding signs of a slowdown will disappear and G.D.P. growth will continue." Another rate increase would probably follow.
The Fed's focus on the domestic economy in its statement, and the absence of any mention of the international economic situation, are also revealing. The message, said William Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs, is that the Fed is far from finished with raising rates. "I think it's telling you that they're going to keep tightening as long as the economy is too strong," Mr. Dudley said. "If the economy keeps going along at this pace, the Fed is going to have to do more."
Mr. Dudley added that the Fed said its action yesterday "should markedly diminish the risk of inflation going forward." But investors who see a sign of no further rate increases should recall that the same statement was made the last time the Fed raised rates, in August.
Even though the stock market seemed to welcome yesterday's action by the Fed as its final move for a while, numbers still to come could quickly change the picture. Today's announcement of the Consumer Price Index for October is expected to show an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent from October 1998. If the number checks in much higher than that, all bets are off, traders say.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Rally on Fed's Action; Dow Jumps 171.58 Points

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks jumped yesterday in a rally fueled by relief as investors bet that the Federal Reserve, after increasing short-term rates for the third time this year, would be done with raising rates in the near future.
The Dow Jones industrial average shot up 171.58 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,932.33. 
 The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index continued to climb, soaring 73.51 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,293.05, setting its 11th closing high in 13 trading sessions. The Nasdaq market shut down for about 20 minutes, because of system problems, crippling trading before the close.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also set a closing high, its first in four months. It rose 25.64 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,420.03, surpassing the high of 1,418.78 set July 16.
The Fed raised two short-term interest rates to ensure that inflation remained dormant; the central bank also signaled that the increase might be the last for a while.
The federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks was raised to 5.50 percent, from 5.25 percent, which returned it to the level it was before the Fed started a series of three rate cuts last year. The Fed also increased the discount rate on direct loans to banks to 5 percent, from 4.75 percent.
Analysts had been almost evenly divided on whether the Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank's policy arm, would -- or should -- raise rates for the third time this year to calm inflationary pressures.
"Now we have symmetry: We had three tightenings; we had three easings," said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst for Jefferies & Company. "It's behind us, we can move on and start to focus on earnings-growth potential and I think that's a positive for the marketplace."
The committee's next meeting is set for Dec. 21. But Wall Street is betting that the Fed will stand pat for fear of causing more uneasiness ahead of possible widespread computer problems when the calendar flips from 1999 to 2000. The first meeting in the new year is not scheduled until Feb. 1.
Stock of financial-service companies were big gainers, with American Express up 2 1/4 a share, to 159 1/2; Merrill Lynch rising 5 1/16, to 87 3/4, and J. P. Morgan & Company, gaining 4 1/8, to 142 1/2.
The United States trade agreement with China, meanwhile, helped stimulate buying of the stocks of Asian, European and Latin American Internet access providers and media companies.
The China.com Corporation, a Hong Kong-based supplier of Internet services throughout the Asia-Pacific region, soared 27 1/4 a share, to 127 3/4, and the EuroWeb International Corporation, a Central European Internet access provider, saw its shares rise 6 7/32 at 8 9/32.
America Online gained 9 5/8, to 159 1/2, after it introduced a Brazilian online access service, its first in Latin America. A rival of America Online, StarMedia Network Inc., an Internet media network aimed at Spanish and Portuguese speakers, rose 5 1/16, to 37 1/2.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Decline
 By Bloomberg News
Prices for Treasury bonds suffered their biggest decline in more than a month after the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates for a third time this year and warned that inflation risks remain.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 16/32, to 100 29/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.06 percent, from 6.02 percent on Monday.
"If Fed officials think the economy is still strong, they could continue to make policy adjustments" that might hurt bonds, said Roger Bayston, who oversees $10 billion in fixed-income investments at Franklin Templeton Group in San Mateo, Calif. He is staying away from Treasuries, instead looking to buy mortgage- backed, asset-backed and corporate debt for their higher yields.

HEADLINE: THE TRADE DEAL: THE AMERICAN WORKER;
Union Leaders, Sensing Betrayal, Will Try to Block Agreement in Congress

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Union leaders pledged yesterday to try to block Congressional approval of the Clinton administration deal for China to join the World Trade Organization, predicting that they could stop the accord the way they had blocked other administration trade initiatives.
Several labor leaders said they felt betrayed that President Clinton, after having promised to "put a human face on the global economy," would reach a trade-liberalization pact with a country that has suppressed unions and imprisoned labor leaders. 
 The president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., John J. Sweeney, cited a case in which several Chinese labor leaders were jailed after having led a demonstration by workers who were demanding back wages.
The director of the international department of the federation, Barbara Shailor, said: "In China, the labor-rights situation is particularly egregious. It's not only that they can't have unions, but attempts to form unions will put them in prison and, sometimes, put them before an execution squad."
Labor leaders predicted that they could block approval by mustering a majority in the House that would include most Democrats, labor-friendly Republican moderates and conservative Republicans angry about what they called China's human rights violations.
"This will be a very serious fight for us," the chief lobbyist of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Peggy Taylor, said. "This will certainly be as serious as any trade fight we've been in. The consequences of this deal are huge."
One of the biggest concerns is that by letting China join the trade organization, the United States would give up its ability to punish China unilaterally over trade violations, because the 135-nation group would adjudicate trade disputes.
Labor leaders said the accord made it all the more important that ministers at the trade group's meeting in Seattle in two weeks agreed to allow trade penalities against countries that violated fundamental labor rights by, for example, not allowing unions or by tolerating child labor.
Several union officials said they feared that the trade group would never approve such penalties after a giant country like China with extensive labor-rights violations joined.
"We're going to fight this big time," Mark Levinson, director of policy at the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, said. "It's an outrage that a country with China's record on labor rights is allowed into the W.T.O. without any attempt to improve its record. Once a country as big as China is in the W.T.O., that may forever doom the W.T.O. as a forum where progress can be made on labor rights."
In condemning the agreement, Mr. Sweeney used unusually harsh language toward an administration that he usually treats as an ally. Calling the accord "a grave mistake," he said, "It is disgustingly hypocritical of the Clinton White House to invoke the need to 'put a human face on the global economy' while prostrating itself in pursuit of a trade deal with a rogue nation that decorates itself with human rights abuses as if they were medals of honor."
Several union officials said the deal would probably soften support for Vice President Al Gore, whom the A.F.L.-C.I.O. endorsed for presidency last month. In November 1997, the labor movement dealt Mr. Clinton one of his worst legislative blows when it persuaded the House not to pass a "fast track" bill to extend his authority to negotiate trade accords.
"I see this as a much bigger fight than fast track," Mr. Levinson said.
Several labor leaders said they thought that Mr. Sweeney would fight the agreement especially hard, because other labor leaders have criticized him for not being tough enough on trade. "If we're going to stop this, it's going to be in the House," the teamsters' political director, Michael Mathis, said.
The president's economics adviser, Gene Sperling, said Washington had won concessions on several labor demands, among them protections against a surge in imports. Mr. Sperling said that China would not agree to some labor demands and that if the administration had insisted on them, the agreement would have been scuttled.
"Pulling China into a rule-based global trading system," he said, "and getting much more involvement by the United States and other democracies in their economy will in the long run do more for labor and human rights than making demands that China wouldn't go along with and would have blown up the agreement."

HEADLINE: Text of Decision by MonetaryCommittee

 BODY:
Following is the text of the statement by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision yesterday to raise short-term interest rates: 
 The Federal Open Market Committee today voted to raise its target for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points, to 5.5 percent. In a related action, the board of governors approved a 25 basis point increase in the discount rate, to 5 percent.
Although cost pressures appear generally contained, risks to sustainable growth persist. Despite tentative evidence of a slowing in certain interest-sensitive sectors of the economy and of accelerating productivity, the expansion of activity continues in excess of the economy's growth potential.
As a consequence, the pool of available workers willing to take jobs has been drawn down further in recent months, a trend that must eventually be contained if inflationary imbalances are to remain in check and economic expansion continue.
Today's increase in the federal funds rate, together with the policy actions in June and August and the firming of conditions more generally in U.S. financial markets over the course of the year, should markedly diminish the risk of inflation going forward. As a consequence, the directive the Federal Open Market Committee adopted is symmetrical with regard to the outlook for policy over the near term.
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, Cleveland, Richmond and Kansas City. The discount rate is the rate charged depository institutions when they borrow short-term adjustment credit from their district Federal Reserve Banks.
