HEADLINE: THE TRADE DEAL: THE DRAMA;
At the Last Hour, Down to the Last Trick, and It Worked

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Late last Friday evening in Beijing, an angry and frustrated Charlene Barshefsky declared to the Chinese on other side of the negotiating table, "You are wasting my time." Then she pulled out the oldest pressure tactic in a negotiator's bag of tricks: She demanded to see the country's prime minister, Zhu Rongji, and declared that the next morning she would head for airport.
It worked. At 3:10 a.m. on Saturday, Ms. Barshefsky's team was awakened by a call inviting her to Zhongnanhai, the walled lakeside complex next to the Forbidden City where China's top leaders live and work. 
 A few hours later they were escorted in to see the 71-year old Mr. Zhu, the champion of Chinese economic reform who American intelligence agencies had concluded was quickly losing power after a failed meeting on trade in April with President Clinton in Washington. He volunteered that China's leaders had met until 2 a.m. to decide how high a price they were willing to pay for entree into the World Trade Organization.
"Now," said Mr. Zhu, according to Ms. Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, and other American participants in the week of high-tension negotiations, "I am going to tell you what we can do, and what we can't do."
Forty-eight hours later -- after two more threats by Ms. Barshefsky to leave town and another critical intervention by Mr. Zhu -- the world's most populous nation and its most powerful nation closed a deal that leaders of both countries needed, for very different reasons.
What was at stake for Mr. Zhu and for President Jiang Zemin was the future of their own effort to complete one of the most astounding economic reform programs in history while preserving the Communist Party's absolute political control. Only by allowing in foreign competition, Mr. Zhu has long argued, will China's giant, inefficient industries be whipped into shape and prepared to compete around the world.
For Mr. Clinton, a deal would mean he could leave office claiming to have taken the biggest single step toward integrating China with the West -- admitting it to the club of capitalist economies, and winning its agreement to live under the rule of international law.
Ms. Barshefsky knew what she had to deliver. "It's the legacy thing," she told friends at a birthday party for her husband in Washington a few days before she left for Beijing. For the president, she said, "there's nothing bigger."
The winding road the two countries took to Monday's groundbreaking agreement was strewn with obstacles. There were cultural miscues, furious arguments within the White House, a divided leadership in Beijing a bombed Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, and constant political calculations about how the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and dispirited Chinese steelworkers might react.
In the end, Mr. Clinton paid a price: China backed away from its April offer to allow American telecommunications companies and insurance firms to take a 51 percent stake in Chinese companies, allowing only a noncontrolling stake of 50 percent.
The give-and-take had all the ingredients of any modern trade negotiations between great powers: secret phone calls between presidents, the constant tension between global strategy and domestic politics and an endgame that turned into a weeklong game of chicken.
"It's amazing it worked," said Gene Sperling, Mr. Clinton's national economic adviser, who was against a deal in April, and for it once his boss made it clear that the April rejection was a huge mistake. But the hard work may be just beginning.
Once China makes it into the World Trade Organization -- months of work are still ahead -- Mr. Sperling and others expect a long, hard slog as China's domestic interests try to undo on the ground what negotiators just signed on the table.
Perhaps the strangest aspect of these talks is that China was a founding member of the very organization it just spent 13 years negotiating to re-enter.
Though a civil war was under way in China, the Nationalist government was among the first to ratify the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in 1948. After the Nationalists fled the mainland for Taiwan the next year, and Mao created the People's Republic of China, it was unclear which China inherited the seat. Taiwan held it for a year, then withdrew.
By the mid-1980's, as Deng Xiaoping began China's rapid march to a market economy, China's leadership realized that it needed to re-enter the club. It was a matter of national prestige. But it was also a hard-headed issue of economic advantage. As long as China remained outside the treaty, countries were free to place high tariffs on Chinese-made goods -- or to to block their entry unilaterally.
The talks began in July 1986, and a deal seemed within reach three years later -- until the student protests in Tiananmen Square were crushed. Then everything froze.
There were a few signs of life after Mr. Clinton's election, but he was focused on the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, then the Senate battle to ratify a new accord that created the World Trade Organization, the earlier agreement's successor, as a truly powerful enforcer of world trading rules.
Meanwhile, China's enthusiasm for opening its economy waxed and waned.
It was not until Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang began exchanging state visits two years ago that the talks became serious. And then the magnitude of what China would have to do -- open its telecommunications market, allow the distribution of American movies, dramatically lower protections for its car industry, let American insurance companies sell policies around the country -- seemed more than the Chinese leadership could bear.
By April, though, Mr. Zhu was ready to deal. He came to Washington determined to seize the moment and cut a deal. He carried with him some breathtaking proposals: American firms could take up to 51 percent of Chinese telecommunications companies and insurance firms -- two strategic industries for China. Detroit's automakers could have full access to China within five years, with low tariffs. American negotiators were astounded.
The problem was that Bill Clinton was not ready.
Washington was awash in charges that China had stolen nuclear secrets. Mr. Clinton was still recovering from the allegations -- never proven -- that the Chinese government secretly contributed to Democratic campaigns. Moreover, Mr. Zhu's offer was missing an agreement that the United States could continue to act unilaterally if China sold steel or other products below cost to gain a share of the American market. It was a huge issue for the American labor movement.
The day Mr. Zhu was arriving, Mr. Clinton gave a speech warning that America should fear an economically weak China, not a militarily strong one. Many took that as a sign that he was ready for a trade deal. But his advisers were deeply divided.
Ms. Barshefsky; the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright all favored the deal. Mr. Sperling, the chief of staff, John Podesta, and political aides who focus on domestic issues were against it. And so was the biggest heavyweight in the administration, the treasury secretary at that time, Robert E. Rubin. "We judged it couldn't pass in Congress," he said. "And that would be a bigger embarrassment for the Chinese."
When Mr. Zhu arrived, Mr. Clinton invited him for a nighttime talk in the White House family quarters. It was a meeting full of miscues. Mr. Clinton said he could make a deal -- but it would be politically hard for him, and could be politically difficult for Mr. Zhu.
It would be better, he said, to announce "major progress." The prime minister was confused, but did not insist. And so the visit stumbled on, with Mr. Clinton "only half focusing on it," said one participant.
Then the White House published a 14-page list of Mr. Zhu's "concessions" -- which many of China's industrial and political leaders had not seen. They were outraged at what was being given away. So were American executives, but for different reasons. At a meeting at the White House the next week, they cheered Ms. Barshefsky -- and screamed at Mr. Sperling. Mr. Clinton had an explosion of his own over the breakdown. "I've rarely seen him as angry as he was after Zhu left town," said one.
Mr. Clinton called Mr. Zhu, who by that time was in New York, and asked him to restart talks. But Mr. Zhu said he could not do so until he got back to Beijing. And as soon as he returned, he was under attack there.
Weeks later, the C.I.A. delivered an analysis to the White House declaring that Mr. Zhu had been politically undercut by the failed trip, and that his political enemies were using the list of trade concessions to bury his economic reform program. Mr. Berger later told a colleague that the April meeting was "one of the biggest foreign policy mistakes of the second term."
It might have been fixable, but the NATO bomb that blew up the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade in early May also blew up the talks. The wave of nationalism that followed left China's leaders in no position to make concessions.
In late August Mr. Clinton wrote Mr. Jiang a letter, hand delivered by Senator Diane Feinstein, the California Democrat. He asked to get the talks started again at an Asian summit meeting in New Zealand. But the meeting was a dud. "The president kept saying, 'All our negotiators are here, let's get going,' " recalled one White House official. "And Jiang would nod, say something noncommittal, and nothing would happen."
Mr. Clinton kept pushing. On Oct. 16, he called Mr. Jiang and said he would soon send a "bottom line" offer and would follow it up -- if Mr. Jiang wanted -- with a visit by Ms. Barshefsky.
"Jiang's response was not very revealing," said one silent participant allowed to listen in on the call. "But we thought that there was a serious division in the Chinese leadership, and the only way to resolve it was to force the issue."
But there was a downside. In April, China was the supplicant, looking for the deal. Now Mr. Clinton looked like he wanted it more than Beijing did. "It's never good to look too eager," warned Ms. Barshefsky.
On Nov. 8, Mr. Clinton called again, wondering if Mr. Jiang had read the American offer. He had, Mr. Jiang responded, sounding interested but noncommittal. Ms. Barshefsky, he said, should come to Beijing. But Mr. Clinton ended with a caution: "I don't want to send Charlene to fail."
Once the talks began, Ms. Barshefsky and Mr. Sperling realized the Chinese side was treading water. "They clearly didn't have instructions from the top," Mr. Sperling said. The deal they offered was far less than what Mr. Clinton turned down in April. After three days Mr. Sperling, taking a prearranged cue from Ms. Barshefsky, blew his top. Soon after that, Ms. Barshefsky did her take-me-to-your-leader routine.
Mr. Zhu offered the Americans the right to buy up to 49 percent of telecommunications firms, and extend protections against surges in Chinese imports for 10 years after the agreement takes effect. But he said there were political limits to what he could do.
"Control of information was clearly their sensitive point," Mr. Sperling said. "The whole idea of letting foreigners take 51 percent control of the telecommunications network -- Zhu made it clear he couldn't do it."
He sent the negotiators back to the table. But by Sunday night, lower-level Chinese officials were clearly fighting a rear-guard action, raising anew issues that the Americans thought were long settled. On Sunday night, Ms. Barshefsky called Mr. Clinton to report that the talks were "in a downward cycle" and that she planned to leave on Monday morning unless there was a sudden break.
Mr. Clinton, she recalls, said, "If you can't break the cycle, come home." But clearly he was disappointed.
The next morning, back in the negotiating rooms in the Ministry of Foreign Trade, things looked worse. Then Mr. Sperling and Ms. Barshefsky were told that Mr. Zhu -- who does not make a habit of visiting drab Chinese ministry buildings -- wanted to see them upstairs. There, he talked about the political pressures on China. Ms. Barshefsky leaned over and wrote on Mr. Sperling's legal pad, "This is like a Seinfeld episode."
But after a few minutes, Mr. Zhu made the concessions necessary for the Americans to claim they got a respectable deal: foreigners could take up to 50 percent of telecommunications firms, and the United States could continue invoking its anti-dumping laws against Chinese imports for up to 15 years. A few other items sweetened the pot.
Relieved, the two Americans decided to take the deal. But first, they needed a private place where they could place a call to President Clinton. There was only one: the women's bathroom. "It wouldn't have been so bad," said Ms. Barshefsky. "Except that Gene wanders around a lot when he's talking on a cell phone."

Chart/Photos: "China and the W.T.O"
China has struggled to reach a trade agreement with the United States, a prerequisite to joining the trade group, which would increase China's global economic power.
 
STARTING THE PROCESS
 
JULY 1986 -- China applies to rejoin GATT (General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade), which it quit in 1949 when Communists took over the government.
 
JUNE 1989 -- Talks are suspended following crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square, but restart in September.
 
DECEMBER 1994 -- China fails to gain entry into the new World Trade Organization, successor to GATT.
 
MARCH 1995 -- The United States agrees to press jointly with the Chinese for China to enter the W.T.O.
 
DECEMBER 1995 -- The Clinton administration temporarily drops support for Chinese inclusion after imprisonment of the dissident Wei Jingsheng.
 
AUGUST 1997 -- After several months of negotiations, American officials conclude they will not reach agreement to admit China to the W.T.O. in time for President Jiang Zemin's October state visit.
 
AN AGREEMENT SEEMS CLOSE
 
APRIL 6, 1999 -- Chinese and American trade representatives conclude accords on contentious issues involving agriculture, but leave telecommunications, banking and other questions unresolved.
 
APRIL 8 -- President Clinton and visiting Prime Minister Zhu Rongji fall short of concluding the trade deal, with Clinton rejecting as inadequate what the Chinese considered major concessions. But they commit to completion by the end of the year.
 
APRIL 13 -- Clinton telephones Zhu to restart negotiations.
 
A BOMBING, AND A CHILL
 
MAY 7 -- NATO bombs the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, prompting the China to suspend some ties with the United States and halt W.T.O. talks.
 
MAY 26 -- Congress releases a report accusing China of extensive military espionage.
 
JULY 26 -- Economic talks resume in Beijing, but the W.T.O. issue remains frozen.
 
JULY 27 -- The House votes to renew normal trade relations with China for another year.
 
JULY 30 -- The United States pays China $4.5 million in compensation for the embassy bombing.
 
FINAL STEPS TO A DEAL
 
SEPT. 11 -- Clinton and Jiang declare an end to their estrangement, and meetings to discuss W.T.O. membership begin again.
 
SEPT. 27 -- Negotiators meet again in Washington but make no progress.
 
OCT. 24 -- Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers meets with Zhu in China, with little result.
 
NOV. 4 -- Military relations between China and the United States resume.
 
NOV. 6 -- Clinton and Jiang speak by phone, arranging a meeting between the Chinese and American teams.
 
NOV. 8 -- Charlene -- Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, and Gene Sperling, a top Clinton aide, go to Beijing for final talks.
 
NOV. 13 -- A surprise meeting with Zhu gives new life to the negotiations, which had all but broken down.
 
NOV. 15 -- W.T.O. agreement is announced, and is signed by Barshefsky and her Chinese counterpart in the negotiations, Shi Guangsheng.

HEADLINE: Doing Good or Doing Well: It's Starting to Get Blurry

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
THERE is a new phrase in the charity lexicon, one that began as an oxymoron and quickly evolved into an accurate description: nonprofit business. A growing number of charities are creating profit-making subsidiaries, some to make money from the intellectual property they own, and others to separate customers who can afford to pay for services from those who receive those services free, or at a nominal charge.
The poster boy for this phenomenon is Minnesota Public Radio, which last year sold a mail-order business begun with small loans from its directors, putting $90 million into its endowment. The sale made it the financially strongest public broadcasting charity in the nation. 
 Then there is Family Service of America, whose social workers help troubled families without charge or for modest fees. Xerox Corporation hired this nonprofit to provide the same services to employees whose families needed counseling.
There is a flow the other way, too. The Fidelity and Vanguard mutual fund companies, for example, have created public charities that accept tax-deductible donations, with the donors later advising on the charities to which the money should be passed.
As these examples show, it is getting hard to distinguish organizations that are out to do good from those that want to do well. And it is going to get harder, according to scholars, executives of nonprofit groups and tax lawyers who say that fundamental economic and political forces are blurring the lines between charitable and commercial activities, in some cases to the point where they cannot be differentiated.
"You have to work very hard to keep straight in the public's mind what is charitable and what is commercial," said Peter Goldmark, the president of the Alliance for Children and Families, the successor to Family Service of America. That's why his group's for-profit division uses a different name: FEI (for Family Enterprise Inc.) Behavioral Health.
MONEY is the reason for this blurring. Despite all the talk about a golden era of philanthropy, increased donations accounted for just 8 percent of the nonprofit sector's growth from 1982 to 1992, the latest year for which detailed analysis is available, said Lester Salamon, a political science professor at the Johns Hopkins University and an expert on nonprofit finance. Fees accounted for 52 percent of the growth, while government contracts and grants accounted for the remaining 40 percent, Professor Salamon said in a report financed by the Nathan Cummings Foundation in New York.
The growing reliance on fees paid by clients stems in large part from national political changes, experts on the nonprofit sector said. James J. McGovern, a tax lawyer with KPMG Peat Marwick, said that in the last 20 years, sources of financing for nonprofit organizations have switched. "In 1975, four-fifths of support came from contributions and one-fifth from program service revenue," said Mr. McGovern, who until 1996 was the Internal Revenue Service assistant commissioner overseeing tax-exempt organizations. "Now it's the reverse. What drove this was the Reagan administration's decision to significantly defund, or not fund, the third sector of the economy."
Nonprofit hospitals are an example of the revenue shift. Medicaid, Medicare and private insurance -- always the mainstay -- dwarf charitable gifts, which have shrunk to 5 percent of nonprofit hospital revenues, down from 11 percent in 1982.
Professor Salamon is one of many nonprofit experts who believe that charities change as their lifeblood of donations is transfused with fees. "Commercial values drive out charitable values and, increasingly, charities are having to rely on commercial activities to grow," he said.
The evolution of the nonprofit business, or the commercial nonprofit, as it has also been described, began during the late 1970's. Charities that historically solicited donations to pay for services that they distributed free, like summer recreation programs, began charging fees to clients. Museums and other institutions, which had charged token admission fees and opened many events to the public, raised prices and clamped down on who paid.
A variety of Washington researchers lauded these moves, theorizing that if recipients of charitable services paid part of the cost, they would make wiser use of those services.
By contrast, Burton A. Weisbrod, a Northwestern University economist who has studied nonprofits, argues that such commercialization is retarding the growth in donations and may lead to their decline.
Gifts to charities, including religious organizations, have held steady at about 2 percent of individual incomes for decades, despite significant increases in the standard of living and wealth, Professor Weisbrod said. Charities, he said, are too quick to jump at alliances with businesses that appear to offer money in exchange for the use of their names.
But there is no free lunch, he said, noting that such deals are often accompanied by "a loss of confidence by the public in charities, with donations declining only to be replaced increasingly by this commercial, ancillary activity in a sort of downward death spiral."
Death may seem a strange word for a sector of the economy with total revenues of about $750 billion this year. But Professor Weisbrod said the corrosive, long-term effect of commercialization is that "charities are losing the claim to have some kind of special status as they just become front men or agents for these profit-seeking firms."
On the other hand, many charities that plead for donations have assets that could supplement or replace donations, said Will Haddeland, a vice president of Minnesota Public Radio.
Minnesota Public Radio grew wealthy because Garrison Keillor, the host of "The Prairie Home Companion," wanted to give away a Powdermilk Biscuits poster to promote his program at a cost of about $3 a poster. The board balked, said Mr. Haddeland, who was a director at the time, but then agreed after someone suggested enclosing a coupon offering T-shirts and other items for sale with the biscuit logo. "To our amazement, we had a 25 percent response rate and we realized there's a business here," Mr. Haddeland said.
The sale of the catalog business to Dayton-Hudson for $120 million was criticized because $6.6 million in fees were paid to executives of the nonprofit broadcasting operation. "You have to pay people competitively," he said, adding that some of the catalog profits were set aside to pay for trials of other business ventures.
Mark Weinberg, a lawyer in Rockville, Md., who represents nonprofit organizations, said creating a sister for-profit also makes it clear that charitable assets are not being used for unfair advantage. Mr. Weinberg said that when a surplus broadcast studio, for example, is leased to businesses, the charity can say, "We do that through our taxable entities and we pay taxes on those profits just like every other business."
Of course not all nonprofit groups engage in commercial activities. And many of those that do impose rules to protect their images and limit their liabilities.
But the lure of easy money is a siren call and has drawn many charities into relationships that have been sharply criticized for going too far.
Professor Weisbrod pointed to the University of Wisconsin, which accepted money and equipment from Nike under a contract that would have prohibited "disparaging" the company. Complaints about restrictions on intellectual inquiry killed that clause, but Professor Weisbrod said the dispute is a reminder that "you can't become dependent on a revenue source without developing some allegiance to the source."

HEADLINE: 3 Women in the Men's Club Wield Money and Influence

BYLINE: By KAREN STABINER; Karen Stabiner is writing a book about single-sex education.

 BODY:
WITH a rueful laugh, Ann Rubenstein Tisch recalled what people back home in Kansas City, Mo., used to say about rich people: If you want to know what God thinks of money, just look at the people He gave it to.
"I was determined," she said, "not to be one of them." 
 That was before she went on a blind date with Andrew Tisch, a scion of the family that owns the Loews Corporation, which has revenues of $20 billion. Now married seven years and the mother of two daughters, Mrs. Tisch responded to a reporter's stated intention to pay for breakfast at the Regency Hotel on Park Avenue with a blush and an apology: "They'll never understand," she murmured, gesturing at the dining room staff. "We own the hotel."
To skew Shakespeare: Some people are born wealthy, some attain wealth, and some, like Mrs. Tisch, have wealth thrust upon them. The question is how to handle it, without becoming one of those people her relatives joked about. It is an increasingly common quandary, if not on so grand a scale. Initial public offerings from technology companies and the coming transfer to baby boomers of an estimated $12 trillion in inherited money mean that many more people will have what Sarah Pillsbury, a philanthropist and film producer, bluntly described as "more money than we need."
More women are involved in philanthropy, too, because they have made their own fortunes or because they demand a voice in how charitable dollars are spent. "For baby boomers and those younger, there's much more likely to be a partnership between men and women, though, in most cases, still, it was not the woman who created the wealth," said Dr. Gary Tobin, the president of the Institute for Jewish and Community Research, in San Francisco, who conducted a five-year study of Jewish philanthropic families.
Such is the case with Mrs. Tisch, along with Melinda Gates, who almost six years ago married William H. Gates 3rd. Patty Stonesifer, Mr. Gates's longtime colleague, now helps manage the couple's foundation. Ms. Pillsbury, an heir to the Pillsbury baking fortune, took control of her inheritance immediately after college. These women, all in their 40's, demanded membership in what was predominantly a men's club; their presence is already affecting the nature of philanthropy and its beneficiaries.
 
Ann Rubenstein Tisch
Mrs. Tisch, the daughter of an upper-middle-class couple committed to community service, came to wealth with the right instincts. As a television journalist with an interest in education, she found stories that moved her, including one that she carried in her "mental Filofax" for years, about a Milwaukee day care center that enabled teenage mothers to complete high school. One girl had burst into tears when asked where she thought she would be in 10 years.
"That girl was doomed and she knew it," Mrs. Tisch said. "The answer was to keep young women from being in that situation."
But she lacked the resources to effect that kind of change -- until she married. Mr. Tisch was involved in "the usual suspects," she said, the United Jewish Appeal, art institutions, zoos, Cornell, his alma mater. Together, they formed the Ann and Andrew Tisch Foundation, incorporating her priorities as well, like the National Association of Breast Cancer Organizations and the Young Women's Leadership School of East Harlem, a single-sex public school opened in 1996.
This year she formed the Young Women's Leadership Foundation to facilitate contributions to the school. She also hired a guidance counselor, on the foundation's payroll, to help 11th graders apply for college.
Mrs. Tisch would not disclose the cost of establishing the Harlem school (nor the size of her family foundation's endowment). But ticking off the meetings she attended, she insisted: "It's about sweat equity as much as anything else, about time as well as money. It would be easy to write checks, but that doesn't make these schools public institutions, and it doesn't make them replicable. We didn't want this to be about an affluent family treating a few girls to a quality education."
 
Patty Stonesifer
The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, at $17 billion the largest philanthropic organization in the United States, intends to do just that, although its program is co-educational and the numbers are huge by comparison: the new Gates Millennium Scholars Program will spend $50 million in each of the next 20 years to send minority students to college, part of the $855 million the foundation spends each year.
At their level, sweat equity mostly involves the energy needed to sign checks. The programs alter social reality by their existence.
Patty Stonesifer is the co-chairman of the Gates Foundation and the only former Microsoft employee there. Economically, she has journeyed even farther than Mrs. Tisch: a technology multimillionaire and philanthropist herself, Ms. Stonesifer was born the sixth of nine children to an Indianapolis car salesman and a part-time physical therapist.
"Scrambling to find two quarters to put in the church basket on Sunday was just the way we lived," she said. Now she is point person for the richest man in the world. There is nowhere to hide: one morning, she was waiting to meet a grant applicant at Tully's, a Seattle espresso bar, when a stranger pressed a proposal into her hand. She receives 1,000 proposals a month, she said.
Ms. Stonesifer oversaw Mr. Gates's initial foray into philanthropy, the donation of hardware and software to libraries nationwide. Critics charged that Mr. Gates was merely colonizing distant territories and training a new generation of Microsoft dependents.
Mark Dowie, whose history of philanthropic organizations will be published next year by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Press, was a skeptic. "I don't think he had a clue what he was doing with the early philanthropy," Mr. Dowie said.
Ms. Stonesifer, a defender of the library project, said, "Time will judge him more kindly." Grant recipients, she said, were thrilled.
The second wave of Gates philanthropy focuses on global health and education, a shift that Ms. Stonesifer attributes in great part to Melinda Gates. Ms. Stonesifer turns the interests of the Gates into strategy. She wrote the list of six possible educational projects that evolved into the Millennium Scholars Program. She and the foundation co-chairman, William Gates Jr., will hire staff members to administer the growing list of education and health projects.
Ms. Stonesifer, like Mr. Gates 3rd, looks to the entrepreneurial Microsoft model for inspiration. The Gates Foundation, she said, wants to bring in consultants and staff members from the field in which the foundation intends to spend money, so that they won't "lose touch" with the people they support. This differs little from running a business, she said, adding, "I am sober about the responsibility, because a billion dollars can transform many institutions that are doing wonderful work."
By contrast, spending the cash is an emotional rush. For years Ms. Stonesifer seemed comfortable in a space just south of forthcoming; in interviews she was crisp. As it came time to announce the scholarship program (and, coincidentally, to pack her older child off to college), she was "overwhelmed." She cried in public. She did so again in a recent interview as she recited imagined dialogues between hopeful parents and their children. Being able to change fate, it seems, takes a little getting used to.
 
Sarah Pillsbury
Ms. Pillsbury was not ambushed by wealth. The question for this child of affluent Minnesota Republicans was how best to use her resources. "I come from a very philanthropic community in Minnesota," she explained recently. "It's not enough to do well; you have to do good. You really can't hold your head up in public if you aren't contributing to society in some way or other."
Ms. Pillsbury came of age in the mid-1970's, just as the counterculture was figuring out what to do in adulthood. Insulated from society's ills, she said encountering the real world was a "shocker" that "helped to develop the moral outrage that fuels my interests."
But the philanthropic community, which heavily supported existing institutions, offered few models for the progressive political giving she had in mind. So 23 years ago, she and three friends founded the Liberty Hill Foundation in Los Angeles, dedicated to grass-roots community work.
Liberty Hill is a nonprofit public charity, so it has no endowment. Each year, it must raise what it gives away. The budget for the 2000 fiscal year is $2.8 million, said Tori Osborn, the director, $2 million of which will be disbursed.
The foundation remains an anomaly, one of about a dozen nationally that give away not just money, but also control over how most of it is spent. "People close to the ground are the ones who are in a better position to make decisions," Ms. Pillsbury said. "But there's a mistrust of poor people: if they were smart, they'd be rich, as though poor people chose to be poor."
The foundation has awarded grants through a community review board to diverse local organizations, like a police monitoring group and a living-wage campaign. Several have become independent organizations.
Mr. Dowie, the historian, saw a link between Ms. Pillsbury's work and the latest wave of giving. "Younger philanthropists are trying to create value with their money, not financial value, but value in society," he said. "They don't mind taking risks. They don't mind offending power." Or, as Mrs. Tisch said: "It's less noblesse, and more oblige."
 
Children of Wealth Inherit More Than Money
THE offspring of Ann Tisch, Patty Stonesifer and Sarah Pillsbury will inherit wealth. Their parents are determined that they also inherit some idea of how, productively, to part with it.
Mrs. Tisch devised a program to encourage her young daughters' instinctive generosity. One-third of their "piggy bank money" is to save, one-third to spend and one-third to give away. She has also made sure that the children glimpse life as it is not lived on upper Park Avenue, taking them to meet Eddie, a homeless man whom Mrs. Tisch reported on when she worked for NBC-TV.
Ms. Stonesifer's son and daughter were slightly older when technology made their mother wealthy, but she had long since begun their education in giving. "My son and daughter worked together at a food bank from the time my daughter was 11 or 12," she said.
Her children now realize that they have "exceptional resources," she said, and can target their spending. Her son, a college freshman, hopes to develop environmental programs for children. Her daughter, 15, worked last summer in Fiji with a housing group.
Among these families, the Pillsbury children -- a 15-year-old girl and an 11-year-old boy -- have had the least formal philanthropic education, in part because they knew early on about their mother's work with the Liberty Hill Foundation. Ms. Pillsbury sent them to public elementary school, to educate them "in the world," she said.
Rather than enforce philanthropy, she presented her children with situations that would elicit a response. This fall, they will join the foundation's youth-oriented van tours of poor neighborhoods in Los Angeles. Liberty Hill's intent is to move money from the city's affluent west side to its needier south and east sides; the youngsters on the tour, including Ms. Pillsbury's own, are tomorrow's potential donors. KAREN STABINER

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (73%); 

STATE: MISSOURI, USA (73%); CALIFORNIA, USA (53%); 

CITY: KANSAS CITY, MO, USA (73%);

HEADLINE: THE POP LIFE;
Don't Worry? Yeah, Right

BYLINE: By Neil Strauss 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE

 BODY:
This week's No. 1 pop album, "Breathe," by the country singer Faith Hill, extols the virtues of true love, faith in God, the smile of a stranger and the eyes of a child. Though there may be little that is recognizably country on this album of slick pop-rock ballads with a CD booklet that looks like a Victoria's Secret catalog, it does have one thing in common with the earliest commercial country successes more than 70 years ago: It is the sound of pop's rear guard marching, waving the flag of traditional values in a society complaining about their disappearance.
But on Tuesday afternoon, pop's rear guard received a lecture from the front line. Pressing a panic button, the Country Music Association convened what it called a town meeting -- its first in 10 years -- of record label presidents, songwriters and some 500 others in the business. Executives from Manhattan and Los Angeles flew in to discuss two changes that have punctured the vacuum that is the Nashville music business: the Internet and consolidation. 
 One of the most significant developments in the record business in the 90's has been the emergence of a third region to rival the dominance of New York and Los Angeles. The South Coast, as it is called (despite a frequent lack of proximity to the ocean), rose when Garth Brooks started an unprecedented country music boom in the early 90's. That rise solidified when Master P and his No Limit label in Louisiana helped turn the South into rap's creative center.
But with this new national prominence, Southern music empires have lost their immunity to outside business influences. In a shrinking record industry, what affects New York and Los Angeles causes bigger waves in Nashville.
The town hall meeting was divided into two halves. First, for two hours, the gathering was told not to fear the coming of the Internet. That message came from Hillary Rosen, the formerly fearful chief executive of the Recording Industry Association of America; Marc Geiger, the ever-enthusiastic chief executive of the Internet site Artist Direct Network; Phil Ramone, the producer and founder of N2K Entertainment; and others.
Then another panel of experts told the audience not to fear the consolidation that has constricted the record, concert, radio and publishing businesses in recent years. But in telling their colleagues not to be scared, panelists ended up inciting more fear. Though Ms. Rosen asserted that Internet music piracy was under control, she was speaking to a songwriting town, for which issues of performance rights, licensing fees and the breakdown of royalty payments on the Internet have not yet been worked out satisfactorily.
Crash Craddock, the president of 37212, the first Internet company to open on Music Row here, was the first audience member to protest, complaining that traditional radio stations didn't have to pay licensing fees to play music. But his Internet radio stations, even though they have no sources of revenue like advertising, will be required to pay fees to the recording association for transmitting music.
The consolidation segment of the meeting was even more ominous, with executives fooling no one by saying that layoffs were good because they allowed the newly unemployed to become independent entrepreneurs. "I'm on a binge to try and buy radio stations," said Larry Wilson, the chief executive of Citadel Communications, which already owns more than 160 stations. He went on to explain that it was wonderful that a company can own "six or seven stations in one market."
This was probably not very reassuring to record executives who complain that country-music stations have become too limited and closed-minded in making additions to their play lists. It was interesting, however, to observe that broadcasters feel the same way about Nashville; radio executives complained that they were desperately in need of new country superstars, but that Nashville kept churning out copycat singers who all sounded the same.
By the day's end record executives and radio programmers had proven themselves to be two mirrors facing each other, sending the same reflection back and forth ad infinitum. What country may really need is someone to point one of the mirrors in another direction.
And this is where the Internet comes in. "Based on what they were saying, radio is going to have less and less superstars because radio is playing less and less new artists," Mr. Craddock said. "That concerns me. But they also said that as the trees grew bigger, there'd be a lot of nuts to pick up. And I feel like a squirrel with my cheeks full of nuts. Because the Internet will be a place for people to hear the music that's not on the radio."
And this is where the new Faith Hill record comes in. "I've seen walls that could never be broken," she sings, "come tumbling down."

HEADLINE: Making Manhattan An Island of Calm

BYLINE: By ALASTAIR GORDON 

 BODY:
ONE Sunday morning back in the 1980's, long before the art galleries invaded Chelsea, two architects were riding their bikes down the old West Side Highway. As the men, G. Phillip Smith and Douglas Thompson, turned off at 23rd Street, pedaling east, they noticed a vacant lot on the northwest corner of 10th Avenue. "We came screeching to a halt when we saw the 'For Sale' sign," Mr. Smith said. "It was love at first sight."
The corner lot was the perfect size for their purposes. Once the site of two brownstones, it measured 54 by 40 feet. They also liked the rough-edged, mixed-use nature of the neighborhood, which had a gas station on one corner, the old elevated train tracks to the west and the Empire Diner and London Terrace apartment complex across 10th Avenue. 
 "We have this thing about vacant lots," Mr. Thompson said. "It's the blank piece of paper, the empty canvas. We always had a dream to claim a corner of space and build ourselves a decompression chamber."
They didn't want to renovate an old building. They wanted to start from scratch and create their own structure from the ground up. That's why they started to ride their bikes around the city every weekend searching for an empty lot. The architects phoned the real estate broker first thing the next day and learned that the property had already been sold, for $50,000, but they asked the agent to keep them posted.
"We let her know that we really wanted the property," Mr. Thompson said. After three years of waiting, their patience paid off. The property came back on the market, for more than $200,000, four times the previous price. This time, armed with a drawer full of credit cards (which they quickly maxed out) and a short-term construction loan, the architects were able to buy it.
Working in a gradual, reflective way in contrast to New York's frantic pace of life, the two men began to evolve a concept for their space. In their spare time, they sketched ideas out on napkins and tablecloths, planning a building that would serve several purposes: living space, a design studio for Smith & Thompson Architects, and -- to help pay its own way -- commercial tenants. All would be mixed into an intriguing village of spaces, courtyards and terraces that could also provide an oasis from the urban environment.
How often does the chance come along to own a piece of Manhattan? Not often, unless you're Donald Trump. Most people are used to renovating an older building, fitting into the envelope of someone else's design. But New York offers a surprising number of options for those who are resourceful and adventurous, willing to challenge conventions. Vacant lots in odd configurations or out in peripheral, frontier neighborhoods wait to be developed. Mr. Smith and Mr. Thompson, through a combination of imagination, methodical planning and a kind of do-it-yourself Zen persistence, would spend the next 10 years shaping their dream into a reality. "Remember," Mr. Smith said, "none of this had anything to do with real estate speculation. We weren't interested in maximizing the site for future profit. We wanted to make a beautiful place."
The dream had been percolating in their imaginations ever since they first met as architecture students at Columbia University during the turbulent 1960's. After completing their studies, both men, with the help of fellowships, went on design pilgrimages around the world, studying ancient and modern architecture. Mr. Smith worked for the Indian architect Balkrishna Doshi, whose buildings would have a profound influence on his later work.
"Doshi's office in Ahmadabad was in a built-up urban neighborhood," he recalled, "but it had a courtyard, and you went in from this noisy street into a quiet and magic environment." Later, he would work with the Japanese architect Fumihiko Maki, who left a deep impression on Mr. Smith by successfully combining transparency and openness on a gritty street corner in Tokyo with his 1989 Tepia Conference Center.
For their oasis in Chelsea, Mr. Smith and Mr. Thompson would synthesize traditions of 20th-century modernism with ideas they had accumulated in their travels.
"At one point we thought about just living like gypsies on the site," Mr. Thompson said, "parking a trailer on it and building a swimming pool. Then we could drive away whenever we felt restless."
Gradually a more realistic idea evolved, one that acknowledged, even honored, the geometric reality of the city.
"Most people think of Manhattan as a closed, finite kind of space with the grid as the dominant force," Mr. Smith said. They decided to try to maintain the urban grid while inserting a fluid sequence of spaces within the enclosed area.
They knew from the start that there had to be a courtyard.
"The Noguchi museum in Long Island City was a constant touchstone," Mr. Smith said. "It is one of our favorite places in the city." They also knew that they wanted to establish a presence on the corner of 23rd and 10th, with at least two stories, respecting the lines of the street and giving the structure an inner transparency.
Another important influence on their thinking was an old house in Cairo that they had seen in a book about traditional Egyptian architecture. "It was extremely rich in plan and elevation, with so many different levels of interest," Mr. Thompson said. There were many similarities to what they ended up designing: an L-shaped building organized around an open courtyard for both public and private functions, with balconies and multilevel terraces.
From the beginning, they looked for an economy of means and flexibility. By designing everything themselves, they were able to eliminate architectural fees, and they also acted as their own general contractors. To save costly labor, all phases of construction were carefully orchestrated. After the foundation work ended, a framework of steel I-beams was bolted and welded into place like a jungle gym, a job that took only two days because steel sections had been stacked on the delivery trucks in the order of assembly.
More money was saved by using cold-rolled steel as it came directly off the mill, in precut sheets of 10 by 20 feet. The size of the plates established a modular 10-foot-square unit that the architects used throughout the project. (This also worked nicely with the dimensions of the lot.) The architects searched through stacks of steel the way decorators look at fabric swatches. "Every steel mill has a unique finish," Mr. Thompson said. "Most come out fairly black." A set that came from a mill in Pennsylvania had a consistent powdery red finish, a kind of cordovan color, that caught their eye.
After the exterior steel walls were in place, they were coated with a parafin-based sealer to prevent rusting and to protect against graffiti. Conventional timber framing was used for the rest of the structure and then covered in some places with gray stucco or white resin-coated fiberglass, which contrasts with dark steel. Cubic elements stacked like blocks were designed in such a way that different spaces could be combined and recombined over time and could easily be adapted to changing functions. The building, which is approximately 4,800 square feet, ended up costing about $140 a square foot.
The courtyard and two gallery spaces on the lower floors were finished first, in 1997. Several restaurants expressed interest in renting the space, for higher revenues, but Mr. Smith and Mr. Thompson wanted sympathetic neighbors in their little village. The J. Cacciola Galleries moved from SoHo into the ground-floor space, with 2,400 square feet, including a subterranean level. Jim Kempner Fine Arts also left SoHo and moved to the second floor (1,400 square feet).
"The building is helping us all to be together," Mr. Smith said. "It's really like a small community."
AS you approach from the west, the building appears to be hovering like a lantern in the late October twilight. It seems too thin at first -- rice-paper thin -- too insubstantial for this city, more like a temporary structure erected for a street fair. Where are the defensive barriers? The thick walls and narrow entry points that normally signal the line between public and private space? They are almost nonexistent.
Getting closer, you begin to see that the effect is a skillfully composed illusion. The perimeter walls are not paper after all, but armor-plated with steel. Step through the portal into the courtyard, and something changes. Even though the outer membrane is only a quarter-inch thick, street noises are muffled, and it is surprisingly peaceful, even meditative. The city is still out there, rude and clamorous, but it suddenly seems distant. Everything fits neatly into a framework of solid and void, except a parabolic opening that has been cut to accommodate the branch of a tree that stretches into the courtyard. The floor of the courtyard is covered with gravel. Pavers, made from recycled plastic decking, have been placed like stepping stones in a Japanese garden.
"You just don't see many buildings like this in New York," said Dru Arstark, the director of Jim Kempner Fine Arts. "Everyone loves it. We have so many new clients. Many of them just walk in off the street. The building draws people in."
She continued: "My heart melted when I first saw the opening in the wall for the tree. What kind of architects would do that? I loved their sensitivity to the environment."
For such a relatively small structure, there is a great deal going on. Each space leads into the next with a surprising clarity of purpose. One is constantly aware of the sky and the drama of the street. Lines of sight are intentionally arranged to create a shifting play between privacy and exposure, transparency and opacity. Multiple views and openings divide and transform the action on the outside of the building into a series of mini-theatrical events: advertisements on the side of a bus, pedestrians passing, the yellow flash of a speeding cab are glimpsed briefly through slitlike openings.
Conventional borders were further dissolved in the way the architects arranged their combination work-and-living area on the third floor. A system of "Murphy desks" fold up into the wall so that the space can be open for entertaining or living on the weekends. Then there is a small sleeping loft, perched precariously above the design studio.
The architects led the way up a folded steel-plate staircase to one of two roof terraces. Looking out over the busy intersection of 23rd Street and 10th Avenue, Mr. Smith pointed out how the building continues to grow as a work in progress. New spaces set back like rooms of a pueblo village will soon rise in tiers toward the bare wall of an adjacent building. The roof terrace will become a "sky room," with walls but no roof and a private sanctuary for sleeping. "This process is completely open-ended," Mr. Smith said. "The building continues to unfold."
Amid the hectic city streets, this building is a study in slowness. This gradual, almost organic approach is not just for small buildings, they believe, but can just as easily be applied to much larger projects. (The team recently completed an award-winning design for the phased expansion of the Jacques Marchais Center of Tibetan Art on Staten Island.)
There is something inherently quiet about the place and the men who designed it. In explaining their philosophy about living and working in one place, Mr. Smith paraphrased a Zen Buddhist saying he once heard in Japan: "The real master in the art of living makes little distinction between his art and his leisure," he said. "He simply pursues his vision of excellence in whatever he does, leaving others to decide whether he is working or playing. To him he is always doing both."

SECTION: Section A; Page 25; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 700 words

HEADLINE: In America;
Cuomo's Quest

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
It was thought to be dangerous terrain, and the advice of some high-powered political advisers was blunt. Don't go there.
Poverty was a merciless quagmire for a politician. Even Bill Clinton had said that the era of big government was over. Politicians exhibiting an unnatural interest in the poor could expect to be viewed as weirdos or, far worse, liberals. 
 "When I took over the department, I talked to one of the sharp political guys in town," said Andrew Cuomo, the secretary of Housing and Urban Development. "He said, 'Look, never say poverty. It's political suicide for you. The impression is going to be that you're an old-time liberal. You're the son of Mario. You're the politics of yesterday.' "
Mr. Cuomo filed the advice. He set about remaking HUD, which for awhile had been targeted for demolition by the Republicans. President Clinton seemed to like the work he was doing. HUD's budget grew.
Then Mr. Cuomo started traveling the country, visiting places that were -- despite the booming economy, despite the creation of millions of new jobs -- still poor. He went to the tough neighborhoods like Harlem and South Central Los Angeles, but also to places far removed from the consciousness of most Americans -- scenes of economic devastation like Guadalupe, Ariz., and Kasigluk, Alaska, and chronically depressed areas like Appalachia and the Mississippi Delta.
Administrations generally expect drum rolls and sustained applause from their cabinet secretaries, at least in public. But Mr. Cuomo would come back to Washington and write reports with titles like "Now is the Time: Places Left Behind in the New Economy." He would show slides of people living in squalor on Indian reservations and give speeches in which he would declare that now -- when the economy is surging and the budget surplus is huge -- is the time to invest in those parts of the country that are hurting.
"If not now," said Mr. Cuomo, "when?"
As recently as six or seven months ago that kind of behavior was considered politically problematic. Some White House aides made it clear they were not happy with the HUD secretary's insistence that the economy had not cured all ills.
But a funny thing happened to Mr. Cuomo.
Nothing.
He didn't get struck by lightning. The President didn't suggest that he zip it. And the media coverage he got was positive.
To be sure, the secretary went out of his way, often, to tout the administration's economic successes -- the balanced budget, creation of 18 million jobs, the lowest unemployment rate in decades, decreases in poverty among blacks and Hispanics, etc.
But he would also say, as he did in a speech to the National Press Club in April, "I can tell you that the poverty rate, the despair, is just as bad in some places as it has ever been." And he characterized the conditions on some of the Indian reservations as "a scar on this nation's soul."
Mr. Cuomo, it turns out, was onto something. Within a few months America's most perceptive political observer, Bill Clinton, was making his own tour of the nation's poorest venues, and reaping rave reviews throughout. On July 5, in Hazard, Ky., with the national press corps looking on, Mr. Clinton stood in the searing heat and told a crowd:
"Even though this is a blessed time for America, not all Americans have been blessed by it. This is a time to bring more jobs and investment and hope to the areas of our country that have not fully participated in this economic recovery."
Poverty was back on the political/ policy map.
In their campaigns to succeed Mr. Clinton, Al Gore and Bill Bradley are arguing all over the country about who would do best by the poor, and even the Republicans are lip-synching the lyrics of compassion.
Will any of this translate into real help for real people? Perhaps. If the economy holds.
"It's a different story when the people are worried or anxious about their own circumstances," said Mr. Cuomo. "Then they turn inward. But if they're O.K. with their mortgage, and they're O.K. with the tuition, then they can start to look at things beyond their own circumstances. Another way of saying it is, all things being equal, the better angels will win."

HEADLINE: Caught Between Eras: China's Factory Workers

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The middle-aged workers outside the aging Beijing No. 2 textile factory said today that they already knew their days of employment were numbered -- that they knew it even before China signed a landmark agreement this week to open its doors wider to global competition.
Their biggest worry, they said, is not the impact of China's probable admission to the World Trade Organization. They agree that it is essential for China's future, and they know that it should eventually expand the country's exports of textiles, like the cotton cloth their factory makes. 
 What worries them now, said the two workers, who stopped for a discreet conversation, is how well the government will support them after they get the inevitable notice from their factory, which sheds more workers every month. Will they get a livable allowance? What if they need expensive surgery? Will they have any help finding new jobs in a fast-changing economy?
"I hope they won't just throw us out into the society," said one of the workers, Mr. Wu. Now in his late 40's, he said he doubted that he could ever find another job, because his health had been damaged by 28 years of loud noise and cotton dust in the plant.
Mr. Wu and a fellow worker, Mr. Tang, in his early 50's, spoke candidly about their fears -- and their surprisingly bitter feelings toward their factory managers -- on condition that their full names be concealed.
Workers like these two toiled for a pittance for decades, with the lifetime promise of a Communist state's "iron rice bowl." Now, caught between two economic eras, they feel betrayed.
Mr. Tang pulled his last pay slip from his pocket and pounded on a table, his voice quivering. "Look at this!" he said. "Eighty dollars a month, after 35 years of work!"
"We haven't had a pay raise in seven years, but during that time the wallets of the managers have grown fatter and fatter," Mr. Tang said. "In this country the workers have the lowest status."
Such fears and angers, shared by millions across the country, add up to one of China's greatest challenges. And it will be even greater if China fulfills the market-opening commitments it made on Monday to the United States in return for American endorsement of its application to join the World Trade Organization.
That challenge is the creation of a better safety net for the tens of millions of workers who are being displaced in this wrenching transition.
Even more daunting than the problem of urban workers, and receiving far less official attention, is the task of creating new jobs and lives for millions of inefficient farmers who are expected to lose out to global trade and may join the country's vast floating population of migrants who compete for bottom-rung jobs in the cities.
"China's social security system is far from ready for the structural change in employment that would be brought about by W.T.O. accession," concluded a recent report by the China International Capital Corporation, an investment bank in Beijing that is a joint venture of the Chinese government and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
The country has only begun to create Western-style unemployment, welfare, pension and health insurance systems -- all vital to smoothing the transition from the old government-run economy to a modern market one.
"It's inevitable that older state enterprises and economic sectors here are going to lose out," said Hu Angang, an economist at the Chinese Academy of Sciences. "I think it's crucial that government aid should not go to the losing enterprises to prop them up.
"Instead, the aid should go directly to the laid-off workers. That's the key to a successful transition."
The government has been acutely aware of the problem in the last two years as laid-off workers and retirees in dozens of cities have held protests when promised subsistence allowances were not paid.
In the past, state enterprises had lifelong obligations to their workers, including living allowances and medical care for those laid off. But in the 1990's many ailing or moribund enterprises have simply had no money to give out.
To stave off spreading unrest, last year the government mandated the creation of thousands of "re-employment centers" in every city and required local governments to share the costs of living stipends with laid-off workers' former companies.
Workers enrolled at the centers are supposed to get training and job referrals, and in the meantime are supposed to receive monthly subsistence payments of about $20 to $35, depending on the location.
But the coverage is spotty, and many failing companies still pay little or nothing to their former employees, leaving them to fend for themselves. And under current policy, the re-employment centers are supposed to be phased out at the end of 2001.
The No. 2 textile mill on the east side of Beijing, where Mr. Wu and Mr. Tang work, employed about 7,000 workers in the early 1990's. Since then it has laid off 3,000, with more sent packing every month. The nearby No. 3 textile factory, which employed 6,000, shut down entirely in June.
Workers from those plants have no re-employment center, the men said, and have had to search for new jobs on their own. They are receiving monthly stipends of $28. A few former co-workers have found jobs mopping floors at new shopping centers, the men said, while some sell items in street markets.
For laid-off workers and for those who, like Mr. Wu and Mr. Tang, still have jobs because of their seniority, one of the greatest worries is health care.
Even when they use the company clinic and hospital, workers are expected to pay for many services and drugs, to be reimbursed later for most of the cost. But because their company is so short of money, the two men said, workers are kept waiting a year before they are repaid.
Class divisions in the company's medical system are another source of bitterness. "Workers have to go to one clinic while the managers go to another one, on the third floor of the hospital," Mr. Tang said. "The workers can't even get herbal medicines for a common cold, but the managers get whatever they need.
"The managers get a free health checkup every two years, but the workers don't get any checkups."
The two men have heard that the textile industry should boom some time after China enters the World Trade Organization, since the United States would be required over five years to end the quotas that limit American imports from China.
But they know that this brighter future may be beyond their own grasp.
"Only when a textile factory can get better machinery, and better-educated and more skilled workers, can it compete," Mr. Wu said. "So the immediate effect of converging with the world economy is that even more workers will be laid off."
Still, and perhaps remarkably, both men seemed to offer sincere and unqualified support for Chinese membership in the trade group.
"Without more global competition, China will be hopeless," said Mr. Tang, who knows at first hand about bad management and shabby equipment. "China can get rich only by competing with capitalist societies.
"We know that this factory will no longer exist in the next few years. We all hope it will be transformed into a new factory in a capitalist system."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Fall Again on Renewed Inflation Fears

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell for the second consecutive session yesterday after the Labor Department reported that the rise in consumer prices in October met expectations. And for market participants, it left the door open for another increase in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve should inflation accelerate.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1, to 99 29/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, rose to 6.13 percent from 6.06 percent on Tuesday. 
 The economic statistics released yesterday were somewhat anticlimactic, some market participants said, because the data came on the heels of the Fed's decision on Tuesday to raise the federal funds rate for the third time since June.
The Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of a percent in October, the smallest rise in the last four months, which kept the year-over-year increase to 2.6 percent, economists said. While the rate of increase did not accelerate, it is still higher than the 1.6 percent pace last year.
Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, noted that the 2.1 percent year-over-year increase in the core rate was a touch higher than the 2 percent rise in September, which in turn was up from the 1.9 percent August reading, all of which suggests that the core rate of consumer price inflation may have already hit its low point.
"Housing starts in October rose a barely perceptible one-tenth of a percent and seem to have plateaued since April," he said. "But there is virtually no evidence to date that would indicate housing activity has begun a cyclical decline, and it's instructive to note that slowdowns in aggregate economic decline are invariably preceded by cyclical falloffs in housing."
Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said the data confirmed that the housing sector had peaked from earlier highs. "Nevertheless, single-family starts remained strong, pointing to continued strong spending on housing items," she added.
Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities, said: "The housing sector is clearly not dead yet. The recent dip in mortgage rates has rekindled housing activity."
Which brings analysts back to the interest rate increase by the Federal Open Market Committee. "The Fed's tightening move was accompanied by both a shift to a neutral bias and a market expectation that the F.O.M.C. will keep policy on hold for quite some time," Mr. Fine said. "But the prudent bond market assumption is that the next Fed move will be another tightening unless economic data suggest otherwise."
Mr. Fine added, "The realization that the Fed is acutely aware of, and ready to act against, potential inflationary consequences of excessive economic growth has brought the recent bond market rally to a screeching halt, and together with an overbought situation and looming corporate supply has produced today's negative tone."
Many corporate deals are coming to market for investors seeking to add yield offered by nongovernment debt because they think gains in Treasury securities are limited. Among them are the Lockheed Martin Corporation, which is planning to price $2.5 billion of debt today.
The sale, managed through Goldman, Sachs & Company and J. P. Morgan Securities, will be in three parts: $750 million of six-year notes that are expected to offer a yield 190 to 195 basis points over a comparable Treasury; $750 million of 10-year notes, with yields about 215 to 220 basis points over a comparable Treasury, and $1 billion of 30-year bonds yielding about 225 basis points over a comparable Treasury. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Drug Groups and U.N. Offices Join to Develop Malaria Cures

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Major drug companies have joined international agencies in an unusual approach to keep research in antimalarial drugs from ending because of the drugs' poor commercial potential.
Each year 300 million to 500 million people become ill from malaria, and a million die, mostly in Africa. The problem is getting worse because some established treatments are becoming less effective.
 Although the market is vast, "people who need these drugs can't afford to pay," said Richard B. Sykes, chairman of Glaxo Wellcome, which plans to join the World Health Organization and the World Bank in a program called the Medicines for Malaria Venture. The nonprofit project, with a $30 million yearly budget, plans to develop and register a new antimalaria drug every five years.
 The sum budgeted is only a third of the estimated average $500 million cost of discovering and marketing a new drug, but industry and public officials fear that without a new approach, no new antimalaria drugs will come to market. 
 The joint venture "has been created because the increased costs of developing and registering pharmaceutical products, coupled with the prospects of inadequate commercial returns, have resulted in the withdrawal of the majority of research-based pharmaceutical companies," said the W.H.O. director general, Gro Harlem Brundtland.
 The organization aims to halve the incidence of worldwide malaria by 2010, when the first drugs developed in the new venture should become available.
 Robert Ridley, acting head of the program, said the idea to set up an independent group grew out of discussions by industry officials on how to keep drug companies interested in an unprofitable business area. In the joint venture, the companies will work with academic researchers.
 Officials estimate that the cooperation will still require a cash outlay of $150 million for each drug developed, in addition to such in-kind contributions as access to companies' chemical libraries.
 Then, Mr. Ridley said, the industry would have to help make sure that any newly discovered drugs were made widely available. "You're not going to get a $1 million blockbuster drug, but you can make it so it's not a huge money loser," he said.
 So far, 120 research projects have submitted requests for financing and three have been selected to receive $4 million through next year. Glaxo Wellcome will work with Bristol University, SmithKline Beecham with the University of California and Roche of Switzerland with the University of Nebraska.
In addition to W.H.O. and the World Bank, the International Federation of Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Associations, the Rockefeller Foundation, the Global Forum for Health Research and Swiss and British government agencies are supporting the project.

HEADLINE: Benjamin Schwartz, 82, Dies; Expert on Mao's Revolution

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
Benjamin Schwartz, one of the first scholars to show that Mao Zedong developed his own brand of Communism beyond Soviet control and a professor emeritus of history and political science at Harvard University, died of cancer on Sunday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 82.
Although not as well known publicly as his mentor, John K. Fairbank, who helped build the field of Chinese studies in the United States through constant proselytizing, Dr. Schwartz in his books furnished several crucial ideas that still help form the foundation for American understanding of China. 
 Among them were his research on Mao, showing how the young Mao had masterminded the Chinese revolution by turning to the poor peasants instead of following Marx's reliance on urban workers.
Another insight was Dr. Schwartz's recognition that for 100 years the critical question for China has been "wealth and power," or how to catch up with the West economically and militarily.
In World War II, Dr. Schwartz was an officer in the cryptoanalysis branch of the Signal Corps, helping break Japanese codes.
Although he was known as a modest man who did not seek personal titles or pursue consulting contracts like many other Harvard professors, during the height of the Vietnam war in 1969, when Harvard students occupied university offices and brought the school to a standstill, he was improbably selected to a special committee to defuse the crisis.
"Ben was like the man with his finger in the dike and held the university together at a time when it was not clear it would hold," said Marshal Goldman, associate director of the Davis Center for Russian Studies at Harvard.
Benjamin Isadore Schwartz was born on Dec. 21, 1916, in East Boston and grew up in a poor family that was further set back by the Depression and later moved to Dorchester, a working-class section of Boston.
He graduated from Boston Latin, the city's premier high school for talented students, and was admitted to Harvard College in 1934 as a scholarship student, commuting daily from home. The experience of being poor, a day student and Jewish at Harvard in the 30's was difficult, friends said, and he found the other students and faculty snobby and elitist.
When he graduated magna cum laude in 1938 with a major in romance languages and literature, he expected to become a high school teacher or rabbi, and received a master's from the Harvard Graduate School of Education.
But the war intervened, and after the war, with his knowledge of Japanese, he returned to Harvard, where he encountered Professor Fairbank, always on the lookout for bright students to convert to the gospel of Chinese studies.
Mr. Schwartz fell for the pitch, like many others. He soon earned another master's, this time in regional studies, and a Ph.D. in history and Far Eastern languages. Harvard appointed him an instructor in history and government in 1950.
In 1951, his doctoral dissertation was published as a book, "Chinese Communism and the Rise of Mao," by the Harvard University Press and immediately established him as a pioneer in the fledgling study of Chinese Communism.
At a time when the United States was at war with the new government in China over Korea and there was a widespread belief that the Chinese Communists were merely an extension of Soviet power, Dr. Schwartz demonstrated that Mao had led the Communists to victory in China by defying Soviet plans and orders. Mao had discovered, after repeated failed uprisings in China's cities by other Communist leaders, that the real revolutionary force in China was the impoverished peasantry. Dr. Schwartz's book remains a key source today.
His second book, "In Search of Wealth and Power: Yen Fu and the West," was published by the Harvard University Press in 1964, adding to his stature as an authority on Chinese intellectual history.
Drawing on an encyclopedic knowledge of classical and modern Chinese literature and philosophy, Dr. Schwartz showed that the overriding goal of the country's leaders from the late 19th century on has been to resume China's rightful place in the world by catching up with the West, or in Chinese terms by a search for wealth and power. Yen Fu was a member of the traditional gentry of the late Qing dynasty who was the first to translate European works into Chinese, largely to seek out the secret of Western power.
That goal remains paramount today, as the search by Beijing for economic and military modernization leads to clashes with the United States over issues like opening China's market to American investment or the theft of nuclear secrets.
In his later years, Dr. Schwartz drifted further back into Chinese history. In 1985, he published "The World of Thought in Ancient China."
He was appointed to an endowed chair, becoming the Leroy B. Williams Professor of History and Political Science in 1975. Dr. Schwartz continued to work in his office every day from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., where he was available to students. And he ate lunch without fail in the cafeteria of the Fairbank Research Center where anyone could talk with him.
"He was a product of the Depression, and he felt it was his job as a professor to be there for his students," said Merle Goldman, a professor of history at Boston University.
Last year, the American Historical Association gave him its Award for Scholarly Distinction.
Surviving are his wife, Bernice; a son, Jonathan, of West Hartford, Conn.; a daughter, Sara-Ann Erichson of Montclair, N.J.; and four grandchildren.
One question his colleagues have is whether the tradition of lunch in the Fairbank cafeteria, always well attended by professors, students, and visiting Chinese scholars and officials, will continue. Dr. Merle Goldman, a professor of history at Boston University, said, "We just don't know what it's going to be like without him."
