HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Rising Oil Prices Help Push Shares Lower; Dow Drops 49.24

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks stumbled yesterday as oil prices neared three-year highs, rekindling fears on Wall Street that inflation could creep up despite the Federal Reserve's interest rate increase.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 49.24 points, to 10,883.09. 
 The Nasdaq composite index ended with a loss of 26.13 points, to 3,269.39. The 1.65 billion shares traded constituted the market's busiest trading session, breaking the record of 1.48 billion shares set on Tuesday, when it also set a revised closing high of 3,295.52.
The Standard and Poor's 500-stock index slipped 9.36 points, to 1,410.71, after setting a revised closing high of 1,420.07 on Tuesday.
Late in the Tuesday session, the Nasdaq market shut down for about 20 minutes, because of system problems. That affected the initial reports of closes for both the Nasdaq and S.& P. 500 indexes.
"There is probably some aftermath of worries as to what the Fed will do even though it said it will remain neutral," Peggy Farley, president of Ascent/Meredith Asset Management, said of yesterday's retreat. "There are probably some lingering worries that some statistics will lead the Fed to do something more."
Though the Federal Reserve said on Tuesday that the quarter-point increase in short-term interest rates would reduce the risk of inflation, the central bank also warned that the tight job market remained a concern.
One worry on Wall Street yesterday was the rising price of crude oil, analysts said.
"I don't think that the Fed action totally eliminated the risk of another hike in the next few months," said Ricky Harrington, technical analyst and senior vice president at Wachovia Securities in Charlotte, N.C. "Profit taking is certainly in order."
Also putting pressure on stocks was the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond, which fell 1 point in price, to 99 29/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.13 percent, from 6.06 percent on Tuesday.
In economic news, the Labor Department said that the Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in October. The growth, off slightly from the September pace, matched forecasts.
"I don't see the market heading south in any meaningful way," said Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer at New Amsterdam Partners. "Long term, we're still very bullish."
Declining stocks outpaced advancers on the New York Stock Exchange by a three-to-two ratio, on heavy trading of 960.1 million shares.
Oil stocks closed higher, lifted by rising crude prices, which approached three-year highs in New York after the world's leading producing nations vowed to maintain deep supply cuts until April. Exxon closed up 1 1/16 a share, to 80 1/4; Chevron closed up 3 9/16, to 96 9/16.
Financial-sector stocks, which are sensitive to moves in interest rates and were bolstered Tuesday by the Fed's decision, slipped yesterday as the bond market weakened. Citigroup fell 1 3/4, to 56 3/8; J. P. Morgan eased 2 3/4, to 139 3/4.
The Oracle Corporation jumped 6 5/8 a share, to 71, in heavy trading after the software company presented a bullish outlook to Wall Street analysts Tuesday.
Priceline.com, which lets Internet users name their own price for a variety of goods and services, including airline tickets, rose 8 5/16 a share, to 77. The company said it would take a one-time $1.1 billion charge to offer tickets from United Airlines, American Airlines and US Airways, three major carriers it had not previously offered.
And shares of the Microsoft Corporation slid 2 1/4, to 85 1/16, after its chairman, William H. Gates, said in a television interview he was willing to discuss "any sort of resolution" to the government's antitrust case against his company.

HEADLINE: Czechs Backtrack 10 Years, to the Time of Their Life

BYLINE: By ALISON SMALE 

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Nov. 17

 BODY:
This was a day for the has-beens, the have-nots, the still-haves and the never-have-hads to come together and remember the good times. And for people here, what times those were!
Ten years ago today Czechoslovakia was giddy with righteous resistance and rose up to overthrow Communism so swiftly and smoothly that the people called it the Velvet Revolution. 
 Proclaiming that "truth and love must prevail over lies and hatred," the playwright Vaclav Havel emerged from the oppression and obscurity of dissent to run the revolution from the stage of the Magic Lantern theater, and then, in a fairy-tale ending to a magical month, moved into Prague's Castle as president.
If the magic has since dissolved, its power could still be felt today, as Czechs and Slovaks -- now citizens of different nations -- savored anew their heady revolt.
"It was once in a lifetime," said Jan Bubenik, one of the leaders of the Prague students whose confrontation with Communist riot policemen on Nov. 17, 1989, began the uprising, bringing to Czechoslovakia the changes that had already swept Poland and Hungary and broke down the Berlin Wall. "Once in my life, I had a moment when I knew exactly what was good and what was evil. It will never come again, because now everything is sort of gray. But back then I really felt like the knight on his white charger."
Mr. Bubenik was speaking today at one of the many commemorations organized by students, the revolution's leaders and their foreign friends to mark the end of Communism. Former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, now a baroness, unveiled a statue of Winston Churchill. Former President George Bush, who celebrated the first anniversary of the Velvet Revolution in Prague, received an honorary doctorate at Charles University and lauded what he called the transformed world that has emerged from the cold war.
In the improbably grand surroundings of the vast Prague Castle, Mr. Havel joined in a reminiscence about the revolt and the circumstances that forged it with Mr. Bush, Lady Thatcher, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former Soviet president, Germany's former Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Lech Walesa of Poland, his fellow dissident and former president, and Danielle Mitterrand, the widow of Francois Mitterrand, the former French president. Then he awarded them his country's highest honor, the Order of the White Lion.
But there were simpler moments, too. At the Cafe Slavia, haunt of Czech men and women of words since the last century, Mr. Havel joined a handful of reporters who covered the revolution 10 years ago.
The revolution went so fast, he said, that he cannot define his favorite moment. Three events stood out, however: the resignation on Nov. 24, 1989, of the ruling Politburo; a protest the next day of some half a million people on Letna field, long the Communists' preserve and favorite parade ground; and then the announcement that the Communist Party had simply abandoned the leading role it had written into the Constitution for 41 years.
It was at the mass demonstration, Mr. Havel said, "that I felt in my mind that this really was the breaking point, because we had always had to consider the possibility of a confrontation -- and there I got the clear impression that there was not going to be one."
Indeed, there was none: the neo-Stalinists who had expelled half a million Communists from the party after the Soviet Union led an invasion in 1968 to crush the Prague Spring reforms of Alexander Dubcek gave up this time with barely a whimper. When the Politburo stepped down that Friday night, Nov. 24, the shouting was left to the tens of thousands who danced and drank beer on Wenceslas Square, and to Mr. Havel and Mr. Dubcek on stage at the Magic Lantern, toasting the Reds' departure with pink champagne.
The mood has soured in the decade since, the country has split, the economic surge that came with capitalism has petered out into stagnation. Czech unemployment, at 6 percent, is low but rising. Much remains unfinished and imperfect, and the pall cast by high hopes unrealized permeated even today's celebrations.
"The Communist regime got into our pores, and it's very hard to get rid of that," concluded Pavel Zacek, another leader of Prague's students in 1989.
Vaclav Maly, who introduced Mr. Havel and the others who electrified the crowds of November 1989, is now the Roman Catholic Bishop of Prague. He recalled the raw energy that came a decade ago from those masses, but reflected that the revolution was actually "too easy."
"People don't like to hear that," he said, still -- like Mr. Havel -- possessed of an almost boyish grin and engaging passion. "People don't want to change. They expect always a messiah, a savior. But the savior won't come."
Still, if things are not quite what many hoped they would be, very few Czechs -- even the 18 percent who now say they would vote Communist -- say they would turn the clock back to the days when they had to fill out dozens of forms simply to get a paltry amount of hard currency or to make a coveted trip next door to West Germany or Austria, and see their own lives ruined and their children denied study and other opportunities if they dared to dissent.
The revolution "is the best thing that could have happened to us," said Eva Hadkova, 29. "When I look at my parents, basically, their lives were almost wasted, much different than they could have had. But I have no problem, even though I know a lot of people are complaining. I can get a very good job, I can travel."
Vladimir Valenta, 45, a janitor, said he lived better before the revolution but still wouldn't turn back the clock. "We keep forgetting that things I now see on the street every day -- a good car, a decent piece of clothing -- we could see only perhaps once every half a year," he said. He said that standing on Wenceslas Square 10 years ago was a drunken high without alcohol, "better than a rock concert."
Now, in one of the most tangible signs of the change the revolution wrought, its makers are scattered in many different careers and fields, and around the world.
One who was absent today from Prague was Jiri Dienstbier, who shared jail terms with Mr. Havel and emerged from the revolution as his foreign minister. Now a lecturer in the United States and the United Nations' special rapporteur on human rights in the former Yugoslavia, Mr. Dienstbier acknowledged that many expectations were dashed in the past decade, but rejoiced that his people are now part of the world.
"When people started coming to me after 1989, asking me 'What can I do for you?' I always told them to take as many young people as possible to your universities, to give them a different perspective, because everything was closed here."
Even the dissidents had to learn, taking high office in their 50's, "things we should have learned at 25," Mr. Dienstbier said. "Even if a lot of things were spoiled in these 10 years, these young people will be a totally different generation. This is a fantastic basic change. If that was the only success of all we did, it made it worthwhile to do it."

HEADLINE: Inflation Still Tame but Resurging Commodity Costs Bear Watching

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The Consumer Price Index went up just enough in October to sustain concern about rising inflation without showing much evidence of a rise.
The price index, the nation's most popular inflation measure, rose just two-tenths of a percent last month, the Labor Department reported yesterday. Higher prices for apparel, airline fares, electric power and a few other items contributed to the increase, which was the smallest since June. But the prices of most of the goods and services that Americans buy held steady. 
 "Inflation has some moderate upward creep to it, but it is contained; there is no upward breakout yet," said Chris Varvares, a partner at Macroecomomic Advisers Inc. in St. Louis.
Inflation has been mild for most of this decade, but the booming economy, labor shortages, a weakening dollar and rising import prices all suggest to some forecasters that inflation might finally begin to rise more quickly. And they saw in the October report some evidence to support their concern.
"We have this consistent pattern of a steady acceleration in inflation, and I do not see any sign that it will cease," said John Makin, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute. He noted that when the index was measured over a 12-month period, it rose 2.6 percent in both September and October. That compared with a year-over-year rise of 2 percent or less in the first half of the year.
Rising oil prices made most of the difference. Remove energy and food, and the so-called core inflation rate -- the soundest measure of inflation in the view of many economists -- is up 2.1 percent over the previous 12 months. Core inflation has hovered at this year-over-year level for months. In October, it rose two-tenths of a percent.
The stock and bond markets, however, seemed to worry about future inflation or that the Federal Reserve, which raised interest rates Tuesday, might do so again in the not-too-distant future. The yield on long-term Treasury bonds rose to 6.13 percent yesterday from 6.06 percent Tuesday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 49.24 points, to 10,883.09. Investors often respond to rising inflation or rising interest rates, or the expectation of either, by shifting money from stocks to bonds.
The stock market would really respond, Mr. Makin said, if the year-over-year inflation rate broke above 3 percent. "Intuitively, people say, 'If I don't see a 3 in front of the decimal point, inflation is not a worry,' " he said. "If we have 3 percent inflation, we will see 7 percent long-term interest rates and that would mean the stock market is way overvalued."
Petroleum prices dipped in October, and that helped to hold down the inflation rate. But they have rebounded in recent days, suggesting that oil might be an inflationary factor in November. Moreover, the secondary effect of rising oil prices has not yet found its way into the index, said Patrick Jackman, a senior economist at the consumer price division of the Bureau of Labor Statistics at the Labor Department.
Oil, for example, is a raw material in products made with plastics, but few of those products have risen much in price. Prices for toys, often made with plastics, fell last month, and trucking rates have held fairly steady, although airline fares jumped 5.3 percent in October.
Fuel costs contributed to that jump, said Donald Ratajczak, director of the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University, but it was not the biggest factor. "Airlines enjoyed peak business travel in October and business fares are the least amenable to discounting," he said.
Elsewhere, prices reflected no particular trend. Apparel prices jumped six-tenths of a percent in October, reflecting temporary factors like the introduction of fall and winter clothes as well as changes in the way the bureau calculates clothing prices. Tickets to movies, plays, concerts and sports events jumped in October after falling in September. Cigarette prices, which jumped in September, fell in October. Telephone rates rose, but prices for other information processing fell, as did computer and software prices.
Still, inflation concerns persisted. New-car prices rose just one-tenth of a percent, but 2000 year models represented only 37 percent of the bureau's car price survey. As that percentage rises, so too will car prices, economists said. That is the implication of a rise last month in the prices that vehicle manufacturers charge dealers, the Labor Department said. The dealers may try to pass the increase on to consumers.
"My sense is that times are good enough so that dealers can discount car prices a little less," said Richard Berner, chief domestic economist for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
What really makes some forecasters brace is "shelter," the biggest component of the index. Shelter, which covers rent and a rental equivalent reflecting the cost of owning a home, rose just one-tenth of a percent in October and 2.2 percent over the last 12 months.
That is far less than the average rise in home prices. The purchase of a home is considered by the Labor Department to be an investment, not a daily living cost. But some economists argue that rising home prices must eventually have a spillover effect, pushing up rents and the daily cost of owning a home.
"The housing thing is the key to the future rate of inflation," Mr. Makin said.

HEADLINE: U.N. Hits Snag in Renewing 'Oil for Food' Program for Iraq

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 17

 BODY:
What the United States hoped would be a quick and painless renewal of the program under which Iraq sells limited amounts of oil to pay for goods to relieve civilian hardships turned today into complicated negotiations when Russia proposed changes favorable to Iraq.
The extension of the "oil for food" program for another six months requires Security Council action by the end of the week. American diplomats hoped that approval would be more or less automatic, so that the council could concentrate on the larger issue of agreeing on a new arms inspection system for Iraq. 
 Until Iraq meets disarmament obligations, by proving that its prohibited biological, chemical, nuclear and missile systems have been destroyed, international sanctions remain in place.
That larger agreement has no deadline, and the council is now in its sixth month of debating how to replace the United Nations Special Commission with another inspection system that all five permanent members can force Iraq to accept. The government of President Saddam Hussein has already rejected a draft version.
The five permanent council members -- Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States -- have been meeting daily to narrow differences, but an accord is still weeks away, if not longer, diplomats say.
"We aren't there yet," Peter Burleigh, the American representative working on the Iraq issue, told reporters today.
The Netherlands, which now holds a rotating council seat, and Britain are co-sponsors of the resolution being discussed. It proposes a suspension, not removal, of sanctions when Iraq demonstrates its compliance with disarmament requirements.
But the five permanent members are far apart on issues including how to decide when Iraq is in compliance, and for how long sanctions may be suspended before the situation is reviewed.
A Western diplomat who has followed the largely secret talks said the real challenge now was to convince Iraq that the Security Council could find a consensus that would hold.
"Otherwise Iraq will say: 'The council is divided; we are not interested,' " he said.
An Arab diplomat said the old inspection system could have led to a removal of sanctions. The Iraqis look at the new proposal, this diplomat added, and see only a suspension after meeting the same goals.
On the extension of the oil for food program, under which Iraq earned more than $7 billion in oil sales in the six-month period now ending, Russia is trying to introduce changes. They would relax air travel restrictions on Iraq, double the amount of money allowed for spending to upgrade the Iraqi oil industry and generally allow Baghdad more flexibility with available funds. American officials would like to keep all discussion about substantive changes out of the debate on the oil for food extension.
The Security Council heard a report today from Benon Sevan, who coordinates and directs the program at United Nations headquarters. Mr. Sevan again told the council of concerns about the number of contracts for Iraq purchases put on hold in the sanctions committee, where the United States frequently raises questions about items Iraq wants to buy abroad.
Secretary General Kofi Annan sent the council a report this week that was largely positive in assessing the progress of the program, which has now delivered 12 million tons of food to Iraq in three years and $729 million in medicines and medical equipment, as well as agricultural supplies and material needed to repair basic services.
But Mr. Annan was critical of the Iraqis for curtailing the freedom of the United Nations to monitor the distribution of imported civilian goods by not making Iraqi escorts available.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
A 1911 Fire As Good TV, Bad History

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
IF you watched Ric Burns's version of New York history last night on PBS, you heard horrible stories about sweatshops and saw awful pictures of garment workers burned at the Triangle shirtwaist factory in 1911. Then, as the music turned from somber to triumphant, you saw politicians and union leaders respond with "epoch making" reforms that protected workers across America.
Some of it was true. The fire was a horrific tragedy caused by unsafe conditions at one factory. But some economic historians disagree with Mr. Burns's depiction of the garment industry, and they point to evidence that the dozens of safety regulations inspired by the fire did little to protect workers. 
 As depicted by Mr. Burns, immigrants were brave souls who crossed an ocean only to become "hapless employees" unable to resist "nightmarish" exploitation in "brutal, dehumanizing" garment factories. The tyrannical bosses depicted might sound plausible in an isolated company town in West Virginia where there was no other place to work, but in New York a worker could walk across the street to a competing company or a whole new industry.
Turnover was high as workers left for better jobs -- a dynamic economy that somehow becomes a menace in the documentary. "The problem with the garment industry," says Mike Wallace, a professor of history at John Jay College, "is that it is thousands of small businessmen, many of them recently garment workers themselves." It was the "laissez-faire competitive market at its absolute worst," Dr. Wallace says in appalled tones. He explains that garment companies had to "bid against one another for contracts" (imagine that!), so they were forced to pay their workers "next to nothing."
His conclusion doesn't jibe with another terrible aspect of laissez-faire economics, which is that companies must bid against one another for workers. Nor does it jibe with data collected in 1908 by the United State Immigration Commission, which surveyed immigrants' pay in 21 industries and found that garment workers' pay was 8 percent above average. Their wage nearly equaled that of American-born workers, and was triple the typical wage in Italy or Eastern Europe.
A GARMENT factory in 1911 was pretty bad by today's standards, but not compared with the alternatives back then," said Price Fishback, a professor of economics at the University of Arizona, who has analyzed the history of workplace safety in two books. Long before the fire, he noted, manufacturers had financial incentives to be safe.
"Workers demanded a premium for taking risks, so if you made the factory safer you could get away with paying them less," Dr. Fishback said. "Also, you'd have less chance of getting hit with an expensive lawsuit."
To avoid expensive, unpredictable court battles, manufacturers joined unions in supporting the workers' compensation insurance system, which was passed by the New York State Legislature the year before the Triangle fire. "That was the political reform that had the most impact on safety," Dr. Fishback said, "because it increased the financial incentives for employers. Their insurance premiums would go up if there were accidents."
Dr. Fishback has detected little impact of factory safety laws like those passed after the Triangle fire, and other researchers agree. "The laws certainly were not the driving force behind the improvement in work safety and health in this century," said Mark Aldrich, an economist at Smith College and the author of "Safety First," a historical analysis published in 1997.
W. Kip Viscusi reaches similar conclusions about the modern regulations brought by the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration. "OSHA regulations reduce job fatalities by only 2 or 3 percent, often at enormous expense," said Dr. Viscusi, an economist at Harvard Law School. "The workers' comp system is much more effective because it reduces job fatalities by a third. But the most important factors are wealth and technology. We're richer, so we demand more safety, and it's now cheaper to provide safety because of technological innovations."
All those other factors, of course, do not make for compelling television. A fire provides better pictures. It's easier to understand the relative grimness of yesterday's factories if it's blamed on villains you can see, and the story comes to a far more satisfying ending if you imagine that a few politicians and reformers rode to the rescue. Melodrama is so much simpler than history.

HEADLINE: U.S. Thinks Iraq Is Rebuilding Ruined Military Installations

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The Pentagon's senior intelligence officer said today that Iraq had begun to rebuild military installations the United States and Britain destroyed last December and that he could not rule out the possibility that President Saddam Hussein had resumed building chemical or biological weapons.
Vice Adm. Thomas R. Wilson, the director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, said that American intelligence officials continue to monitor Iraq's program closely but that it was easy to hide weapons production inside legitimate commercial factories. 
 "I can't say authoritatively there is no work going on on," he said in an interview with reporters at the Pentagon today. "In fact, we assume that there is."
Admiral Wilson's assessment underscored the Clinton administration's quandary as the United Nations Security Council struggles to reach agreement on resuming international weapons inspections in Iraq more than 15 months after Mr. Hussein expelled inspectors, setting off a confrontation that culminated in air strikes last December.
In a rare interview by the top officer in the Pentagon's intelligence wing, Admiral Wilson also said China had embarked on a significant effort to modernize its military, which is the world's largest with some three million soldiers, though it is considered to be far behind the United States in technology and firepower.
Having seen American military might prevail in the Persian Gulf war in 1991 and during NATO's air war against Yugoslavia, China has begun actively seeking advanced aircraft, missiles and other weapons, he said.
"They have clearly made that an economic priority," he said.
Last week, American officials disclosed that the administration and the Pentagon had raised serious objections to Israel's decision to sell China a sophisticated, $250 million radar jet similar to American Awacs, fearing that the technology would increase China's ability to threaten Taiwan.
On Iraq, he said he knew of "no significant, precise evidence" proving Iraq's resumption of its weapons programs, which would be a violation of the cease-fire agreement that ended the gulf war.
Admiral Wilson, who visited the Persian Gulf last week, said the raids last December had set Mr. Hussein back militarily, while regular strikes by American and British jets patrolling the "no flight" zones over northern and southern Iraq since then had significantly damaged Iraqi air defenses.
But he said Mr. Hussein remained firmly in power.

HEADLINE: Year 2000 Computer Costs Estimated at $365a Person

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The government said today that the cost of repairing the Year 2000 computer problem would be $100 billion, or $365 for each man, woman and child in the United States.
For all that, the Commerce Department predicted that the effect of computer failures on the economy would be merely "something like a tangled shoelace for a world-class marathon runner." 
 In a new report, the government said the economy was sufficiently "stable, large and resilient" that failures -- even those overseas -- would not seriously affect the $9 trillion gross domestic product.
"Any glitches that pop up next year should not hurt our economic growth," Commerce Secretary William M. Daley said. "I am not going to lose any sleep."
The $100 billion figure for total repairs from 1995 through 2001 was generally in line with other estimates but is still an enormous amount.
It is roughly the same as the total spent last year by seven of the largest federal agencies and just more than the personal fortune of Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates.
Robert J. Shapiro, the under secretary of commerce, said some precautions -- such as companies adjusting inventories to hedge against possible supply problems -- could affect the "pattern and timing" of economic growth. Such moves could add to growth during the last three months of 1999 but would most likely slow it during the first months of 2000 to compensate.
Mr. Shapiro also said consumers who decided to stockpile food, water or other supplies could drive up prices in the last part of this year.
Another government report, being released on Thursday, predicted only a slight risk of "serious or widespread disruptions" in the nation's food supply. Consumer hoarding and weather-related problems could cause spot shortages, but food companies have made "remarkable progress" in getting their computerized systems ready, the report said.
President Clinton's top expert on the Year 2000 problem, John Koskinen, also cautioned today that "several hundred thousand" smaller companies had not performed any repairs, apparently intending to fix problems after they occur.
Mr. Koskinen warned that business owners would find long waits for technical support and new equipment early next year, and "some of them may lose their customers and go out of business."
"We are getting close to its being too late to start," Mr. Koskinen said.

U.S. Plans to Crack Down On I.R.S. Agent Misdeeds
Urged by Congress to get tough on abuse of taxpayers, a new team of Treasury agents plans a sharp increase in investigations of I.R.S. employees for misconduct. Indeed, the number of cases expected to be opened against I.R.S. employees will soon nearly equal the number of cases of suspected of tax crimes.
The I.R.S. goal has stirred worries even within the inspector general's own staff that investigators are being forced to search for far more misdeeds than may exist. Page A1. 

Scramble for Technology Workers
Thanks to the booming technology-based economy, companies' long-standing scramble for qualified technical workers has taken on an air of desperation. A severe shortage of engineers who design hardware and software and create Web pages has led companies and their recruiters to try all sorts of tricks. A1.

A coalition of consumer and community groups has called for a government ethics investigation into former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's decision to accept employment from Citigroup, the financial services conglomerate, contending the move presents an "undeniable appearance of impropriety." HEADLINE: Time Warner To End Gifts Of 'Soft Money'

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Time Warner announced today that it would no longer make unregulated donations to political parties, saying such "soft money" contributions distort the electoral process and sully the givers.
The company joins a handful of other corporations in swearing off contributions to the parties, but advocates of changes in campaign finance said it was too early to declare the unilateral actions a trend. 
 Time Warner, which owns Cable News Network, Warner Brothers and Time magazine, among other properties, has given roughly $1 million to the Republican and Democratic Parties in each of the last two elections.
Gerald M. Levin, the chairman at Time Warner, said much of the soft money had been used for misleading and negative advertising that cheapened the nation's political dialogue. Mr. Levin said the company would use the money instead to increase coverage of politics and to sponsor electronic town meetings to educate the voters better.
In a memorandum to employees, Mr. Levin and Richard D. Parsons, the president of Time Warner, said the company would halt its corporate giving to the parties but would continue to operate a political action committee using voluntary contributions from employees to make donations to individual candidates.
The memorandum referred to the company's "special responsibility" to provide full and fair coverage of politics, an acknowledgment that many in the newsgathering side of the company were uncomfortable with the political largess.
The situation is analogous at other major television companies that are owned by conglomerates with broad interests and big political budgets. General Electric, which owns NBC, and the Walt Disney Company, which owns ABC, are substantial contributors to parties and candidates. Viacom, the parent of CBS, gives virtually no money to the parties, but its political action committee contributes sizable sums to candidates.
Advocates of overhauling campaign finance applauded the Time Warner announcement, but other corporations, unions and wealthy individuals showed no sign of following the company's lead. Time Warner has not been among the biggest corporate soft-money givers -- it ranked 46th in 1997-98 with $471,000 and is 48th in the current cycle, with $155,000 so far this year. In 1997-98, Disney ranked 8th over all among corporate soft-money donors, General Electric 29th and Viacom 434th, said FEC Info, an independent group that tracks campaign expenditures.
"I think what they've done is courageous, and we hope it will be a good model for other companies around the country to follow," said Charles Kolb, president of the Committee for Economic Development, a group of business executives who favor the elimination of soft money.
Much of the soft money is used to pay for advertisements that are not supposed to support an individual candidate. Critics say the advertisements are merely a means of circumventing spending limits imposed on candidates but not on the parties.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
U.S. Investors Salivate Over Chinese Stocks In Pact's Wake

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
MAYBE it depends which side of the Pacific you're on.
In the days since China and the United States signed a deal that may lead to Chinese admission into the World Trade Organization, the Chinese stock market has made small gains, with indexes of mainland stocks up about 1 percent. Hong Kong stocks did better, with the leading index of such shares up 3.6 percent since Friday. 
 But most of the relatively small number of Chinese stocks traded on major American stock markets have risen sharply. In some cases they have gone absolutely berserk. Suddenly, any stock with China in its name seems to have willing buyers.
The biggest gains have gone to stocks that previously had been of little interest to American investors. By contrast, China Telecom (Hong Kong), which provides cellular telephone services in China and has been an institutional favorite in America, rose on Monday and Tuesday but fell $5.9375, to $86.5625, yesterday, and is up just 2 percent for the week.
But such languid performance is more than offset by other stocks that have skyrocketed. A list of nine stocks -- all traded on the New York Stock Exchange or Nasdaq and all with the word "China" in their names -- shows increases of at least 60 percent for six of the nine since Friday. Investors who put an equal amount of money into each of the stocks on Friday -- the last trading day before the W.T.O. agreement was announced -- would have more than quadrupled their money by yesterday's close.
The most amazing move came in the shares of China Prosperity International Holdings, a company that does property renovations in China -- but that has also been talking about doing something related to the Internet.
China Prosperity was once something of a hot stock, moving as high as $37 a share in Nasdaq trading in 1996 -- adjusted for a later reverse split. But it had fallen out of investors favor, and by Monday was trading at $1 a share.
Then on Tuesday, the stock leaped to $11.06, trading as high as $14, and volume rose to 521,100 shares, or more than had traded in the previous year. That however, was just the prelude. Yesterday, volume totaled 4.4 million shares, or more than the total volume in this country since the company went public in 1995. The price leaped as high as $80, then began to slide before ending at $32.0625.
There was no announcement from the company, but the same could not be said for another suddenly highflier. China Resources Development, a distributor of natural rubber, reported that its losses were growing. It added that it had no explanation for the stock's movement in Nasdaq small-cap trading.
That stock jumped $19, to $25 a share, in trading yesterday, on volume of 906,800 shares. That volume is nearly twice the total number of shares outstanding.
Another amazing performance was turned in by the Dransfield China Paper Corporation, which rarely trades on Nasdaq. During October, there were only two days when shares in the company, which distributes paper products and is building pulp mills in China, were traded. The price then was $1 a share. It fell to 43.75 cents on Monday, and then did not trade Tuesday.
But yesterday, with anything named China looking hot, 1.3 million shares were traded -- more than triple the total volume traded since the company was listed on Nasdaq in 1997 -- and the price rose as high as $29 before closing at $12.
China.com, a company based in Hong Kong that provides a portal for Chinese users of the Internet, leaped from $58 on Friday to a close of $105 yesterday, trading as high as $137. It had gone public, at $20 a share, in July.
Even China Tire, a company that makes car and truck tires, got in on the action. Since Friday, it is up 77 percent, to $10.625.
It is not easy to explain such moves based on expectations of what will happen if China is successful in entering the World Trade Organization, something that could yet be derailed by Congressional opposition. Changes in the Chinese economy will arrive over a period of years, and the opening of the economy to competition from foreign companies may damage some Chinese businesses even as others are helped.
But there seems to have been little in the way of such analysis regarding many of the stocks that were moving yesterday. Instead, Internet chat rooms were full of comments about how certain stocks were sure to keep moving because there were relatively few shares available for trading. Traders were chasing performance, and in the process they were creating it.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
The Ego Behind the Ego in a Trump Gamble

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
ROGER J. STONE has worked with Donald J. Trump for 19 years, a relationship longer than any of their marriages that is now reaching its blissful apotheosis with Mr. Stone as director of the Donald J. Trump Presidential Exploratory Committee.
Like his client, Mr. Stone is thin-skinned, with a shatter-proof ego. Adores power, and the myriad ways to grab it. Has a Sisyphean struggle with hair color. A history with the National Enquirer. 
 And an aversion to shaking hands with strangers. "For him it's a health issue, for me it's a suffer-fools-gladly thing," Mr. Stone said, during lunch at a Manhattan restaurant. "I used to watch Lee Atwater" -- once his partner -- "brown-nose people he didn't like or respect. I can't do that."
Inside the Beltway, news that the strategist behind Mr. Trump's latest gamble is Mr. Stone has been greeted with delighted groans, hisses and the occasional murmur of grudging respect.
This is, after all, the corporate and political fixer who, at 19, was an entry-level dirty trickster for Richard M. Nixon; whose 30th birthday party was given at the "21" Club by Roy Cohn; who consulted on campaigns for Ronald Reagan, George Bush and countless lesser Republicans; and who cites, among his shining moments, his successful $27 million strategy for the United States Sugar Corporation to defeat a penny-per-pound tax on sugar to help restore the Everglades.
"It was a superb program to tell the voters why not to vote for it," he fondly recalled. " 'How do you know the money will really go to the Everglades? These politicians in Tallahassee, you can't trust them.' "
Two questions about Mr. Stone.
First: Just how odd a duck is he? Answer: Very.
The balding spot apparent years ago has disappeared, and the dye job is obvious. Mr. Stone hates his natural mousy brown color. Clarification: yes, he always wears suspenders, but never red ones. "People with blond hair do not look good in red," he said. "And you shouldn't call them suspenders. It's more accurate to call them braces."
With his silver watch fob, spread-collar shirt and wide-striped double-breasted suit tailored to accentuate his bodybuilder's silhouette, Mr. Stone, a fan of Fanny Brice and Al Jolson, says he often feels like someone born in the wrong era. "I never owned a pair of blue jeans until I met my second wife," said Mr. Stone, 47.

THAT preternaturally youthful face?
He credits decades of following a regimen of Chinese herbs, breathing therapies, tai chi and acupuncture, in which he learned personality types correspond to a specific organ. Roger Stone is a kidney. He says that means he is aggressive.
For all his eccentricities, Mr. Stone is nothing if not resilient. In September 1996, soon after the lurid sex revelations about Dick Morris, the Democratic consultant, the National Enquirer wrote that Mr. Stone, then a volunteer spokesman for Senator Bob Dole, had placed ads and photographs seeking sexual partners for himself and his second wife, Nydia. Mr. Stone denied the stories, saying the ads had been placed by a former domestic helper who had stolen photographs and his checkbook. He bowed out of the Dole campaign.
Of that time, he says now, with a thin smile: "An awful lot of people left me for dead after that, but I'm still here."
Second question: just how ruthless is Mr. Stone?
Answer: The man who enjoys being known as the Prince of Darkness, really, really did not want it published that his three grandchildren -- by way of Nydia's past marriages -- call him, shucks, "Pop-pop."
A leading Republican consultant said, "Roger does have a sense of ethics, loath as he is to admit it."
That said, Mr. Stone is an exuberant negative campaigner, known for drawing journalists to seamy rumors. As a Nixon fan and a volunteer for the Committee to Re-Elect the President, he donated money to the presidential primary campaign of a Republican challenger, using the name of a left-wing group, and then mailed the receipt to a newspaper. In 1989, for local New Jersey Republicans, he designed a direct mail piece with government-style writing that said, "important tax information enclosed." It warned homeowners that their taxes had doubled, courtesy of the Democrats.
When it comes to political shrewdness, Mr. Stone was precocious. As a junior, then vice president of his northern Westchester high school, he manipulated the ouster of the president and his own succession. Running for re-election as a senior, "I left nothing to chance," he said. "I built alliances and put all my serious challengers on my ticket. Then I recruited the most unpopular guy in the school to run against me. You think that's mean? No, it's smart."
As for handling the maverick Mr. Trump, whose various business interests he has long represented, Mr. Stone is clearly having a grand, unbuttoned time of it. After Mr. Trump announced his tax-the-rich notion, "Every Wall Street economist trashed our plan," Mr. Stone said. "A conventional politician would pull his hair out, but we love it!" Attention, for better or worse, was paid.
He professes little interest in the mainstream candidates, although he keeps his four Washington Rolodexes spinning for his corporate clients. As long as Mr. Trump is in the race, Mr. Stone said, by way of understatement, "We're not going to bore anyone to death."

HEADLINE: Senator Hagel's Deceptive Bill

 BODY:
In the welter of unfinished business left behind by Congress this year, campaign finance legislation again stands out. Nevertheless, progress has been achieved. The House passed a reform measure in the summer, and 55 senators backed some form of "soft money" ban promoted by Senators John McCain and Russell Feingold. Less noticed but also significant, five more Republican senators now say some controls on soft money are needed. Congress can build on these gains next year.
A presidential election year is not usually productive legislatively, but cleaning up the election fund-raising system could prove an exception to that rule. A sign of the turning tide came yesterday with the announcement by Time Warner, one of the biggest corporate donors, that it would no longer make soft-money contributions to the political parties. With its action, Time Warner joins a growing number of companies that are in open rebellion against traditional fund-raising. Through groups like the Committee for Economic Development, that rebellion has spread despite heavy-handed warnings from Senator Mitch McConnell, a leading defender of soft money. 
 Meanwhile, Senator McCain has gained in the polls by supporting a campaign finance overhaul and has promised to bring up his bill again next year. This growing support for limits on special-interest money has produced a new danger, however. Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska, an articulate critic of current fund-raising practices, has proposed an alternative bill to control soft money. His bill has gained some adherents, but it is fatally flawed. The danger lies in this measure's serving as an excuse for not passing genuine improvements in the campaign finance system.
The objective of reformers, embodied by the McCain-Feingold bill, has been to outlaw soft money -- the unlimited contributions by corporations, unions and rich donors to political parties that circumvent the tight limits on donations to the candidates themselves. Mr. Hagel argues that an outright ban on soft money is extreme. He wants to cap such donations to parties at $60,000 a year, raise the ceilings on regular donations to individual candidates from $1,000 to $3,000, and allow an individual aggregate of $75,000 a year to parties for all races.
These ceilings are unacceptably high. They would not end the corrupt soft-money system so much as legitimize it. The $60,000 annual cap would actually be $120,000 for each two-year cycle, translating into $240,000 for a couple, along with $300,000 for each couple for direct donations to candidates. The caps would be a step backward, legalizing donations from corporations (outlawed in 1907) and from unions (outlawed in 1947). Another loophole in Mr. Hagel's bill would allow unlimited donations to state parties for use in federal elections.
In defending his bill, Mr. Hagel argues that the McCain-Feingold measure, with its complete soft-money ban, is dead in the Senate. He says he is only trying to find a middle ground. But this is no middle ground. It is a surrender to the corrupt status quo. The tipoff is that Mr. McConnell, the Senate Republicans' chief fund-raiser, has praised Mr. Hagel's bill and announced hearings on it for next year. Surely no more hearings are needed on this issue. Mr. McConnell is simply trying to use hearings as an excuse to forestall stronger legislation.
What is actually going on is that pressure is building on wavering Republicans to break the filibuster engineered by Mr. McConnell and Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, to thwart the majority support in the Senate for the McCain-Feingold bill. That pressure has led George Voinovich and Mike DeWine of Ohio, along with Spencer Abraham of Michigan and Craig Thomas of Wyoming, to back Mr. Hagel's bill, apparently hoping that their constituents will be fooled. Their anxiety is at least encouraging. Mr. Hagel can now perform a service by acknowledging the flaws in his own bill and bringing it closer to serious reform.

HEADLINE: Open Trade With Cuba

 BODY:

To the Editor:
If the United States can reach an agreement to open China's economy to foreign investors (front page, Nov. 16), surely it can reach an accord with Cuba to open its markets after 37 years of economic isolation. 
 The arguments for supporting a trade deal with Cuba and its bid to join the World Trade Organization are not very different from those asserted by the Clinton administration to support open trade and W.T.O. membership for China. As in the China deal, an agreement with Cuba would reduce tariffs on various industrial and agricultural goods and lift many barriers for American banks, insurance and telephone companies to operate there. Moreover, a deal with Cuba would lock in Cuba's commitment to economic reforms and thereby increase pressure for greater openness, more press freedom and enhanced rights for workers.
 
KLINT ALEXANDER
Louisville, Ky., Nov. 17, 1999
 
The writer is a former United States trade official. 
http://www.nytimes.com

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: CONGRESS AGREES WITH WHITE HOUSE ON SPENDING CUTS

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The White House and Republican leaders in Congress agreed on Wednesday to an across-the-board spending cut to the long-overdue federal budget, and then, after grappling all day over how to make that cut, shook hands on it this morning and made a deal.
The two sides agreed on an across-the-board budget cut of 0.38 percent, out of about $610 billion in spending for Federal agencies. Then they argued all day about how to perform that fiscal surgery, which would yield close to $1.3 billion this year. 
 Shortly before midnight on Wednesday they agreed to exclude military personnel from the cut and to give the White House the flexibility it sought on imposing the cut on the rest of the government, said Senator Pete V. Domenici the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Budget Committee.
Their daylong dispute was "like when you go to buy a house, and you've agreed on the price, and all that's left is a disagreement over the color of the trim on the tool shed," said Robert Stevenson, a senior aide to Senator Domenici.
Minutes before midnight, the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, Representative C. W. Bill Young, Republican of Florida, said he planned to file the final spending package on the floor of the House before dawn. The White House said at 1 a.m. today that it was still reviewing the bill's fine print.
The House will meet this morning to debate it. Congress is operating under a 24-hour continuing resolution, keeping the government running without a real budget until midnight. Under expedited rules of procedure that members jokingly call "martial law," the House is expected to pass the final package, containing the last five of the year's 13 spending bills, and send it to the Senate.
Then another battle is likely in the Senate. It involves Federal price controls for dairy farmers, an issue so crucial to the combatants that they are threatening to shut down the Senate, block any final budget bill and keep Congress in session well into December.
Senator Herb Kohl, a Wisconsin Democrat, has placed a formal hold on the final spending package in an effort to protect his state's 23,000 dairy farmers from legislation favoring Northeastern milk producers.
The budget cannot pass, and Congress cannot adjourn, until he lifts that hold, because the legislation he opposes is in the final spending package that will be filed in the House, voted on and most likely passed today before going to the Senate.
Jack Lew, the White House budget director, said the dairy dispute was so dire that it raises a real risk of a government shutdown."
This looming problem dismays many members of Congress. When the House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, began talking about it on the House floor Wednesday, members began to moo.
The day's war of words began when the House speaker, J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, said President Clinton had agreed in a telephone call from Turkey to an across-the-board cut of 0.38 percent in the budget, which is now 47 days overdue. That cut was a political do-or-die issue for the Republicans, but only part of the financial solution. The final piece was agreeing on how to impose it.
The senators, representatives and White House aides coming and going through the Senate's corridors for the negotiations looked exhausted after 10 nearly nonstop days of talks.
Republican leaders were pressing hard to finish without spending more money. "If I were king, I would have their heads all cut off," the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said on Wednesday.
The White House was seeking every last new dollar it could extract from Congress before shaking hands, including $100 million for a program for disabled workers.
The Republicans needed nearly $7 billion in savings to allow them to say that their spending bills would not dip into Social Security surpluses -- a political point they have made daily, since spring, but still have not formally fulfilled.
So the White House brought nearly $7 billion to the bargaining table today, enough to cover the Republicans demands without an across-the-board cut.
Up to $3.5 billion would come from a one-time transfer from the Federal Reserve's portfolio of government securities - -- strictly bookkeeping device, since the money belongs to the government to begin with.
The rest would come from delaying government paychecks for military personnel and many civilian employees for about 48 hours, until just after 12:01 a.m. next Oct. 1, the start of the next fiscal year. This would not save any money, but simply shift more than $3.2 billion in spending into next year's budget.
Both proposals remained in the final package, along with the across-the-board cut. Both sides agreed to exclude military personnel from the cut. Then came the stumbling block: how to impose the $1.3 billion cut.
The argument was over who would control the budget-cutting scalpel, what programs could be protected and which ones could take deep cuts.
Both sides described this as an "issue of flexibility." Two weeks ago, Mr. Clinton vetoed a 0.97 percent across-the-board cut that Congress passed, almost exclusively with Republican votes, calling it a "blind and mindless" exercise.
To make such a cut seem sensible to Democrats, the White House insisted on shielding some programs and cutting others more deeply.
Shortly before midnight, they won an agreement. Senator Domenici said that its terms allowed some programs within federal agencies to be protected from the cuts; other programs could be cut by up to 15 percent to make up the difference and achieve the savings.
That helps "make it not really across the board, but driven by policy," Mr. Lew said. "With a little more room to concentrate, it becomes a tool we can manage."
An across-the-board cut was a matter of principle for the party's conservatives in the House, who wore big buttons on their lapels today saying they had "stopped the raid on Social Security."
Just as important to two Democratic senators are demands for their home states.
Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia is threatening a filibuster to protect his state's coal miners from a Federal court ruling barring them from dumping in valley streams. His last-minute legislation that would stop the court ruling from taking effect for two years. The White House first supported Mr. Bryd's effort, then said it would veto any bill containing it. It appeared to be striking a noncommital stance on the issue on Wednesday.
Then there is Senator Kohl and the dairy dispute.
This year the House approved a measure that lets a system keeping the price of milk in New England artificially high to remain in place for another two years.
Mr. Kohl has placed a hold on every piece of legislation pending in the Senate, including the budget bill, to stop that measure from becoming law.
"Raw politics -- that's what originated it, and that's what keeps it going," Senator Kohl said in an interview Wednesday.
Authority for the cartel expired on Sept. 30, though a judge's order has kept the pricing mechanism in place temporarily. In September the House voted, 285 to 140, to extend the system. Then Mr. Hastert and Mr. Lott agreed this week to attach a two-year extension of the cartel to one of the final spending bills.
"The milk issue is all about economic self-interest," Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said last month. Now it will be decided in the closing hours of this Congress.

HEADLINE: Need for Computer Experts Is Making Recruiters Frantic

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The managers at Vivid Studios, a Web site consulting firm here, are accustomed to calls from employment recruiters trying to poach their technical staff. But the day a suitor telephoned looking for Nevil was a new low.
Vivid's receptionist assured the recruiter that it would be difficult to put Nevil on the line. And with good reason. Nevil is a black Labrador retriever. 
 Thanks to the booming technology-based economy, companies' long-standing scramble for qualified technical workers has taken on an air of desperation lately. A severe shortage of engineers who design hardware and software and create Web pages has led companies and their recruiters to try all sorts of tricks, like the Nevil-seeking entrepreneur who called each name listed on Vivid Studio's Web site.
Recruiters are known to send e-mail to all the engineers at a company, offering to beat their existing salaries. At dawn, recruiters scour Internet job-placement services for the most recently posted resumes before a competitor makes contact. At restaurants, they pull business cards from fishbowls in which engineers had placed them hoping to get a free lunch -- not a job offer.
"I was going to a funeral recently, and a friend said, 'Don't recruit,' " said Noelle Tardieu, a recruiter who works under contract for Silicon Valley companies. Weddings, however, are another matter. Ms. Tardieu says she reads the marriage announcements in the newspaper to find names and titles of prospective recruits.
So it follows that the heavily courted engineers and other technology-trained employees are cashing in. Salaries in specific high-demand areas, like Web site programming and development, have gone up 18 to 20 percent the last year, said Eric Campbell, vice president for human relations at Docent Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., which makes software for corporate training.
"We wind up six months after we hire an engineer having to fight off offers for that same engineer for more money," he said. "It's become a very predatory environment."
One big change in recent years is the extent to which stock options have become part of the package. Fifty percent of junior technical employees now have stock options, up from 35 percent three years ago.
To seal deals, recruiters offer candidates overseas airline tickets, increase vacation time to four or five weeks from the usual two weeks for starting employees or toss in 11th-hour signing bonuses that can range from $5,000 to $20,000. Other perquisites now seem commonplace: employees can redesign offices or cubicles, bring pets to work, work at home and dress casually -- even at interviews.
Longtime recruiters and compensation experts say the scramble for talent is the most intense they have ever experienced. "It's a free-agent market and the folks out there know it," said Mark Edwards, president of iQuantic, a compensation consulting firm in San Francisco. "I haven't ever seen companies be more flexible in how they attract and retain folks."
The fervent demand for technology employees often funnels down to the recruiters, where it comes out in a spigot of offers, cajoling, creativity, relationship building and, occasionally, ambulance chasing. Indeed, when the rare layoffs do occur at a company involved in a merger or experiencing a downturn, recruiters wait in the parking lot to scoop up the discards.
"I bag 'em and tag 'em," said Sandra C. Chroman, a recruiter in Silicon Valley, adding that recruiters fight over junior techs in the parking lot.
"I joke that I keep engineers bound and gagged in my trunk and just drive around the high-tech companies and drop them off on the lawn," she said.
If only it were that easy. Ms. Chroman said she had heard all the tricks of the trade and used a few of them herself. One tactic, she said, is to walk into high-technology companies, make friends with the receptionist through small talk, explain she wants to send everyone in the company a mailer and then walk out with a company phone list.
"Receptionists will give you people's home phone numbers," Ms. Chroman said. "It's amazing what some people will give you."
But lately Ms. Chroman, like many other recruiters, is looking outside Northern California for talent, notably at companies and universities in Canada and Mexico, where engineering candidates are not in as much demand as they are here. In addition, thanks to the North American Free Trade Agreement, their citizens are not required to obtain visas.
Another place often visited by recruiters is cyberspace. Comfortable with technology, engineers looking for better offers post their resumes on a growing number of Internet job services, like monster.com, where recruiters in turn look for the latest talent that may be willing to switch employers. "I check it every morning at 6," said Mara Flores, a contract recruiter for Fujitsu Software, who said she also used a program called a Web crawler to search the Internet for newly posted resumes from engineers.
But if demand for engineers has been tough on companies, it has been good for the recruiting business. Well over 1,000 recruiters operate in Silicon Valley, Ms. Tardieu estimated, a number that includes freelance recruiters, recruiters who work for agencies and contractors who sign on with specific companies. Ms. Flores said it was not uncommon for an aggressive recruiter, even with only a few years experience, to earn $100,000 to $200,000 a year.
The leeway given to recruiters by their client companies varies. Some companies conduct the financial discussions themselves; in other cases, they provide some flexibility, or recruiters insist upon it -- in working out signing bonuses, for instance.
And despite some seeming cutthroat tactics, the recruiters appear to treat one another cordially, even with a sense of brotherhood. There are few stories of back stabbing. Recruiters say they rarely hear of competitors disparaging one another or using dirty tricks to steal a candidate. More often, the battle simply comes down to who can best marry a willing candidate with a job opening and enticing benefit package.
The phenomenon is not confined to Silicon Valley, with at least 350,000 openings nationwide for programmers, systems analysts and computer scientists and engineers, according to a 1998 study by Virginia Tech and the Information Technology Association of America, a trade group. Today, the association reports, one of every 10 information technology jobs remains unfilled.
"We have the same trouble in Boston, New York, Dallas and Chicago," said Mr. Campbell of Docent.
At a recent job fair in Mountain View, in the heart of Silicon Valley, Hewlett-Packard said it had hundreds of jobs available in the Bay Area and thousands worldwide. The story echoed at booth after booth of prospective employers; easels and binders full of jobs, from administrative assistant to patent lawyer, but mostly engineers. A sign at the booth of Kaiser Electronics, a military contractor, sought to lure candidates with the promise of "Every Other Friday Off."
For the candidates, the experience can be both flattering and overwhelming. Samir A. Batla, 29, worked as an engineer at Ernst & Young in San Francisco until he decided four months ago that he wanted a new job. He posted his resume on monster.com and within days had heard from 11 recruiters.
Various sales pitches ensued, and the price tag escalated. Mr. Batla expected to earn $70,000 to $80,000, but he found his sticker price soon soared to $85,000 to $100,000. He said he was offered stock option packages that could have made him a millionaire if the company went public and its stock continued to climb.
The recruiters sought to sell him on intangibles, too. Some tried to sell him on the value of working at a smaller company, others at a larger, more established office. They talked to him about the culture of the prospective workplace, and this turned out to be an important hook for Mr. Batla, who said money was only one criterion. Another was attire.
"I decided I wouldn't work at any company if I had to dress up for the interview," Mr. Batla said. Ultimately, he settled on Vivid Studios, the Web design company. "To the interview, I wore blue jeans and a collared shirt -- what do you call those, polo shirts?" he said. The people interviewing him, he said, "were wearing shorts, T-shirts and sandals -- I felt overdressed." He took the job with the title of senior engineer.
Vivid Studios, onetime home of Nevil, the Labrador retriever, also knows what it is like to lose employees. The dog's owner, Dan Lederer, 40, quit Vivid recently to pursue a quieter life with his family in Plainfield, Mass., population 550.
Mr. Lederer, a Web site designer who said he was hounded by recruiters while working at Vivid, is now freelancing and says he seems to have found a recruiter-free zone in the Berkshires. "If you don't want to be called, it's nice to be out here," he said. Still, Mr. Lederer said he would not mind hearing from a recruiter who could offer him a job with money, benefits and one other perquisite: permission to work remotely from his home on 13 secluded acres.
"With the pay and the whole scenario working out, yeah, sure," he would entertain offers, he said. These days, it might not seem so much to demand; he and Nevil may be getting more offers than they can handle. 
http://www.nytimes.com

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Thursday about the recruiting frenzy for technical talent in Silicon Valley referred imprecisely to the immigration status of Canadian and Mexican workers. Visas are indeed required, though under the North American Free Trade Agreement, provisions are less restrictive for Canadians and Mexicans in some jobs than for other foreign workers.

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 3; The Arts/Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 1468 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Game Shows, Greedy and Otherwise

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES

 BODY:
"If I won a lot of money," said the contestant on "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire," a forthright housewife with double chins, "I'd like to lie in a bath of melted chocolate."
Her bath would be in England, where she was a contestant on the original version of the quiz show. No one has said anything quite so refreshing on the phenomenally successful ABC version, but then sweetness and sincerity are the marks of the game's American cousin. Despite astonishing similarities to the English original, the ABC "Millionaire" also displays a connection between wholesomeness and making money that is as bedrock American as Ben Franklin. 
 As in England, a contestant can get a phone friend or the strangers in the audience to help. If he hears a question he doesn't want to answer, he can pick up his money and walk away. Competition is so soothing and benign here, it seems positively virtuous.
It took just one generation of copies to unveil the darker side of this healthy competitive spirit, though. The Fox show "Greed" is the evil twin of "Millionaire." Although in many ways it is such a slavish imitation that it practically dares the "Millionaire" creators to sue, "Greed" offers a Darwinian vision of ruthless competition. "Millionaire" reflects Americans as we wish we were; "Greed" reveals what we fear (and perhaps believe) we must be to survive. Both are close enough to reality to hit a cultural nerve, yet exaggerated enough to be escapist fun.
"Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" has done more than reinvigorate the game show genre and ABC's fortunes. (It finishes its latest run on Wednesday, with its inevitable return date undecided.) Its impact even goes beyond the way "Final answer?" has become a catch phrase, understood and overused by almost everyone. What is most revealing is how the show's feel-good attitude has evoked a visceral response in an exceptional range of viewers, of all ages and classes.
An ABC promo shrewdly pinpoints at least part of that appeal: "They look like ordinary people; they could be your friends." The contestants do look as if they might be strolling around a mall in a white, suburban, middle-class neighborhood. They are dentists and teachers from towns with names like Cherry Hill and Falls Church. When asked what they would do with their winnings, they say they would pay off their parents' mortgages or send their children to college. And unlike Hollywood glamour-pusses, they are often in need of diets and orthodonture.
But the viewer's ability to identify with the person next door is not the deepest reason for the show's resonance. On an unconscious level, "Millionaire" creates an idealized vision of America as a society of tolerant, generous, good-willed people.
Almost all the contestants have been white men -- until Tuesday, when the show had two players, both of them women. "It's ladies night," the host, Regis Philbin, announced in anticipation on Monday, with evident relief. Even that homogeneous group of men, though, reflects a changing, inclusive America. With a matter-of-factness the sitcom "Ellen" could only have dreamed about a few years ago, one gay contestant brought a man introduced as "his partner" to root for him. When he returned for his second night on the show, he told Mr. Philbin how he had celebrated the night before: with dinner from McDonald's. It is hard to imagine a more Middle American value than that.
Another white man brought his African-American girlfriend; the camera went to her often, notably when he lost and she sweetly mouthed the words, "That's O.K."
Michael Davies, the show's executive producer, says that contestants are chosen on their ability to play the game, with no questions asked about their private lives and no attempt to balance the group by race or sex. (That must be true; surely there would have been a greater range if they had tried.) In the quiz show variation of "don't ask, don't tell," loved ones are introduced any way the contestants wish, with no one prodded to say "friend" instead of "partner," or vice versa. As Mr. Davies says, each player has a life story, and "we tell their stories." Those mini-narratives may seem like time fillers, but they give the show its "Our Town" aura.
Mr. Davies, English by birth, is in a good position to note the differences between the original show and the American adaptation. In England, people who want to become contestants are chosen at random in the first round of screening, rather than qualifying through a phone quiz as the Americans do. "In this country, lottery winners are not really respected because they never earned it," Mr. Davies says.
On the surface, the American and British shows are as similar as two Starbucks, with a mirror-image set, the same searchlights and clanging music, even the same phrases repeated by the host. "It's a good one," the English host says of a correct answer. (And we thought that was a Regis line.) But where the English host deliberately unsettles contestants, Mr. Philbin is a cheerleader. The shows' franchised sameness may reveal the global-village unity of the media age, but the differences in tone help explain the American appeal.
Part of America's diversity, of course, is the room it leaves for opposing points of view. "Do you feel the need for greed?" Chuck Woolery asks his "Greed" contestants, waving piles of cash under their noses, acting out the quiz show host as Mephistopheles. Here, if contestants choose to move ahead, climbing what is called "the Tower of Greed" toward a jackpot of $2.2 million, they must answer the question. And while a "Millionaire" contestant who reaches $32,000 will leave with nothing less, on "Greed" a wrong answer means losing everything -- except, that is, the $10,000 bonus a player can get for eliminating a competitor.
There is the essence of "Greed." The show has a team of players, but when a flashing light called "The Terminator" hits one of them, that person gets to challenge a teammate to face off on a single question. The loser leaves the game; the winner takes his money. Behind the facade of teamwork, contestants are waiting to stab each other. Turning a game show into a blood sport is not a surprise, coming from the network that has given the world "When Good Pets Go Bad." And though nothing like the phenomenon of "Millionaire," "Greed," now in its third week, has been a success for Fox.
As a spectator sport, "Greed" is a more dramatic game than "Millionaire." But it evokes uglier sentiments and brings in less conventional contestants. In a blood sport, after all, the audience needs villains as well as heroes. The less appealing players on "Greed" are not vile as in professional wrestling, but the principle is the same. Along with wholesome types like historians and librarians, its contestants have included an oversized nightclub bouncer.
The most memorable contestant has been an air traffic controller named Curtis, with a personality that veers between cocky and surly and hair that seems a cross between Edward Scissorhands and a porcupine. At the start of tonight's show (at 9) he and his two teammates return to decide whether to risk the million dollars they have won, taking a chance to double it.
Why are there such eccentrics on "Greed" and not "Millionaire"? Because on "Greed," a contestant's entertainment value counts. Bob Boden, an executive producer of the show (along with Dick Clark), explains that in an early selection round, potential contestants must pass a quiz as they do on "Millionaire." After that, they audition by playing a test game and are chosen not only on their skill but also on "looks, telegenic quality and personality," Mr. Boden says. "Our goal is to represent society with the greatest possible range."
These contestants are not model-gorgeous, either, but they are not so uniformly, wholesomely Middle American as the "Millionaire" players. And they are not so dominated by white men. (No one has a satisfactory explanation for that part of the "Millionaire" phenomenon, though the idea that men are quicker to punch in keypad answers is high on the list of desperate guesses.)
However contrived, "Greed" sends its own visceral message, similar to the chilling one Michael Douglas delivers in Oliver Stone's 1987 film, "Wall Street." As Gordon Gekko, the snaky financial genius, he proclaims, "Greed is good," justifying cutthroat competition as the foundation of American capitalism. That may seem like a pure 80's vision, but it may also be ready for a return in this healthy economy.
And game show viewers get to choose between two vicarious experiences: they can be as happily competitive as Ben Franklin or as savage as a Wall Street shark. One show offers an appealing picturesque fantasy; the other may be closer to the truth.

HEADLINE: Cooper Union Picks Physicist as First Black President

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art has appointed its first black president, a 53-year-old theoretical physicist and former research manager at AT&T Bell Laboratories.
George Campbell Jr., president and chief executive officer of a nonprofit corporation that, among other things, provides scholarships in engineering and other science-based disciplines for economically disadvantaged minority students, will become the school's 11th president in July, said Milton Glaser, the graphic artist who is vice chairman of Cooper Union's board. 
 "We're a unique school in the arts and sciences," said Mr. Glaser, who has been affiliated with the school since he graduated from it in 1950. "He seemed to be the perfect figure to reconcile art and technology, which we believe to be the top social issues of our time. He has an extraordinary interest in the arts and humanities."
Dr. Campbell's appointment to head the school comes at a time colleges and universities across the country are struggling to draw more minority students into engineering. Last year, 10 percent of students nationwide who received bachelor's degrees in engineering were African-American, Hispanic and American Indian, Dr. Campbell said.
Dr. Campbell has played an active role in tackling the problem in his work during the last 10 years at a nonprofit corporation, the National Action Council for Minorities in Engineering.
During the last two decades, the organization has provided scholarships for 7,000 students, 10 percent of all minority engineering graduates, a spokeswoman for the school said.
He is a member of the Congressional Commission on the Advancement of Women and Minorities in Science, Engineering and Technology and a member of the President's Information Technology Advisory Committee's socioeconomic and work force panel.
Dr. Campbell, a Harlem resident, said he looked forward to the challenge of working as the school's president. For the last five years, he has served on the advisory council for the school of engineering at Cooper Union. "I'm delighted," Dr. Campbell said. "I think it's a terrific opportunity. Cooper Union is a very prestigious institution. It has been very important to the city for a very long time."
Founded in 1859 by the industrialist Peter Cooper, the college was one of the first to prohibit racial discrimination in enrollment, according to Dr. Campbell. It has about 900 students, and it occupies three buildings on the edge of the East Village.
It is one of only a handful of private American colleges offering a free education to every student.
Dr. Campbell was selected from a pool of seven applicants after a four-month search, said Richard A. Bernhard, chairman of the trustees. Dr. Campbell replaces John Jay Iselin, who stepped down in April after 10 years.
Dr. Campbell received his bachelor's degree in physics from Drexel University and his doctorate in theoretical physics from Syracuse University. After his graduate work, in theoretical high-energy physics, he joined AT&T Bell Laboratories, one of the nation's premiere research institutions.
During his 12 years at Bell Labs, Dr. Campbell worked in various research and development positions. Besides Cooper Union, he works closely with several universities, serving on advisory boards and as a trustee.
He is an avid collector of African-American paintings and sculptures and African art. For six years, he was on the board of the Crossroads Theater Company. He is married to Mary Schmidt Campbell, dean of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. They have three children.

The Nov. 18 article also misstated the given name of Cooper Union's chairman. A reader pointed out yesterday that the chairman is Robert A. Bernhard, not Richard.
