HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 14.
 
Now Playing
 
* "AMERICAN BEAUTY," starring Kevin Spacey, Annette Bening, Chris Cooper, Wes Bentley and Thora Birch. Written by Alan Ball. Directed by Sam Mendes (R, 116 minutes). With heavenly finesse, Mr. Spacey plays a buttoned-down 42-year-old suburbanite who flips his lid for a teenage cheerleader. And he never gets it back on. The midlife crisis motif is familiar, but the stage director Sam Mendes brings terrific visual flair and dry humor to this barbecuing of the bourgeoisie. All the actors display coolly expert timing, especially Ms. Bening as the antihero's grasping wife. Although the story spreads itself thin among many characters, the film coalesces for a devastating finale (Janet Maslin). 

* "AMERICAN MOVIE," featuring Mark Borchardt and friends. Directed by Chris Smith (R, 104 minutes). An insightful, funny, not-to-be-missed documentary about a no-budget Wisconsin filmmaker who makes a horror film as if his life depended on it. And as Mr. Smith so affectingly reveals, Mr. Borchardt's hopes really do hang in the balance. This knowing and often hilarious look at try-anything indie filmmaking becomes a moving portrait of one man's uphill struggle and finds Mr. Borchardt often describing success and prosperity as his goals. Meanwhile his own life is eloquently presented as a very different, no less authentic kind of American Dream (Maslin).
 
* "ANYWHERE BUT HERE," starring Susan Sarandon and Natalie Portman. Directed by Wayne Wang (PG-13, 113 minutes). In a knowing film adaptation of Mona Simpson's widely praised, if not often wildly eventful, first novel, Ms. Sarandon is show-stopping as the 14-year-old heroine's mother and main nemesis. And Ms. Portman, who proves her mettle in a fully formed dramatic role, does a terrific job of holding her own in the film's battle of wills. Even when the material meanders, Mr. Wang supplies insightful, affectionate direction, just as he did for "The Joy Luck Club." A women's picture made with feeling and acted with great flair (Maslin).
 
* "BEING JOHN MALKOVICH," starring John Cusack, Catherine Keener, Cameron Diaz and (of course) John Malkovich. Written by Charlie Kaufman and directed by Spike Jonze (R, 112 minutes). Welcome to the fun house: in this exhilaratingly quirky first feature by a stellar video director, the reigning fears and obsessions of a technology-crazed, voyeuristic culture are given an even wilder workout than they got from "The Truman Show." Mr. Cusack plays a discouraged puppeteer who accidentally finds a way into Mr. Malkovich's mind. While the ordinary science-fiction plot might go downhill after revealing its gimmick, this one's inspired craziness goes on and on. Originality and cleverness abound (Maslin).
 
"THE BACHELOR," starring Chris O'Donnell and Renee Zellweger. Directed by Gary Sinyor (PG-13, 90 minutes). This crude, frantic yuppie farce stars Mr. O'Donnell as a selfish, marriage-shy bachelor who botches his proposal to his sweetheart (Ms. Zellweger) days before his grandfather dies and leaves him $100 million on the condition he marry before his 30th birthday. That gives him 27 hours either to win back his true love or find another wife. After running through his ex-girlfriends, he finds himself besieged by a horde of prospective brides chasing him through the streets of San Francisco. Based on a 1925 Buster Keaton classic, the movie lands a few satiric thrusts at the money-mad workaholic 90's (Stephen Holden).
 
"THE BONE COLLECTOR," starring Denzel Washington and Angelina Jolie. Directed by Phillip Noyce (R, 118 minutes). One of the year's most gruesome movies, the ingenious but preposterous whodunit stars Mr. Washington as a quadriplegic forensic detective tracking down a serial killer who plays cat and mouse with him by leaving elaborate clues at the crime scenes. Ms. Jolie is the police officer (and former model) whom he instructs by cell phone on how to gather evidence. Crammed with the usual manipulative jolts, this urban creepshow at least succeeds in sustaining an atmosphere of menace, and Mr. Washington's and Ms. Jolie's star chemistry smolders without the two exchanging so much as a kiss (Holden).
 
* "BOYS DON'T CRY," starring Hillary Swank and Chloe Sevigny. Directed by Kimberley Pierce (R, 114 minutes). This stunning debut feature tells the strange and resonant story of Brandon Teena, who despite being born Teena Brandon went on to create a charismatic identity as a young man. Brandon's ultimately wrenching tale may sound tabloid-ready, but on screen it turns into Theodore Dreiser's idea of American tragedy. The film makes it hauntingly real and even tenderly romantic, with the astonishing acting needed to make it work. One of the year's best (Maslin).
 
"BRINGING OUT THE DEAD," starring Nicolas Cage and Patricia Arquette. Written by Paul Schrader from a novel by Joe Connelly. Directed by Martin Scorsese (R, 115 minutes). An intense, volatile film full of sorrow and wild, mordant humor. This time it took prop garbage on the streets of Hell's Kitchen to create a sufficiently hellish ambience for another nighttime tour of Manhattan. But Mr. Scorsese has mellowed significantly since his "Taxi Driver" days, and his uneven but impassioned, visually inventive new film is more contemplative than it looks. Mr. Cage gives a fine, soulful performance as a New York ambulance driver haunted by ghosts. Ving Rhames is a major scene-stealer as one of his partners (Maslin).
 
* "DOGMA," starring Matt Damon, Ben Affleck, Linda Fiorentino, Chris Rock and Salma Hayek. Directed by Kevin Smith (R, 130 minutes). Mr. Smith's idea of angels in America is the notion of two cool dudes who take a hair-splitting, legalese approach to Roman Catholic doctrine and think it would be amusing to nullify all existence. And nothing in this wildly brazen, unexpectedly devout comedy is any less outrageous than that. Mr. Smith again shows off a rare gift for fusing his comic-book sensibility with serious debates and big, big laughs, even if some parts of his film (Ms. Fiorentino's performance, Mr. Rock's and semi-repartee from the ubiquitous Jay and Silent Bob) work better than others (an excrement monster). Making a gutsy leap into matters of faith, Mr. Smith miraculously emerges with his humor intact and his wings unsinged (Maslin).
 
* "FELICIA'S JOURNEY," starring Elaine Cassidy and Bob Hoskins. Directed by Atom Egoyan (PG-13, 116 minutes). In the brilliantly realized surreal thriller, adapted from William Trevor's popular novel, Felicia (Ms. Cassidy), a pregnant Irish girl searching for her boyfriend in the English midlands, is befriended by Joseph Hildritch (Mr. Hoskins), a catering manager who also happens to be a serial killer. Mr. Egoyan, Canada's most gifted filmmaker, elevates this cat-and-mouse game into a film that transcends genre by entering the characters' consciousness and implying a world of half-discernible connections in which the weather, the landscape and the chance encounters of strangers suggest the sense of a grand design (Holden).
 
"HOUSE ON HAUNTED HILL," starring Geoffrey Rush, Taye Diggs and Peter Gallagher. Directed by William Malone (R, 115 minutes). If the ever vigilant Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, is truly determined to snuff out inflation aborning, then he can do no better than to take sharpened pencil in hand, make his way to the nearest theater showing this film and strike fearlessly until its feeble pulse beats no more. This is a sorry reincarnation of the 1950's William Castle horror film in which an eccentric millionaire played by Vincent Price offered five strangers $10,000 each to spend the night in a spooky old mansion. In the new version the ante for survival has been raised to $1 million apiece. Even allowing for inflation in the 40 years since the original opened, the reward in 1999 should come to only $57,113.47, according to the Federal Reserve Bank in Minneapolis. But some things have not become devalued over the years: words like junk, for example. "Hill" was pronounced junk in these pages in 1959. And it is still junk (Lawrence Van Gelder).
 
* "THE INSIDER," starring Al Pacino, Russell Crowe and Christopher Plummer. Directed by Michael Mann (R, 155 minutes). Mr. Mann directs this taut thriller about the tobacco industry whistle-blower Jeffrey Wigand with pulse-quickening panache. And he illustrates why, in the corporate climate of the 90's, truth-telling is a riskier business than it was circa "All the President's Men." While Mr. Pacino delivers galvanizing moral outrage as a producer for "60 Minutes," and Mr. Plummer wickedly mimics Mike Wallace, Mr. Crowe movingly captures the complexity of Mr. Wigand's situation. Shaky docudrama ethics cloud the film's take on "60 Minutes." But this is an inordinately well-played thriller, with Mr. Mann's stylistic brio at its best (Maslin).
 
"THE MESSENGER: THE STORY OF JOAN OF ARC," starring Milla Jovovich, John Malkovich, Tcheky Karyo and Faye Dunaway. Directed by Luc Besson (R, 130 minutes). The Hundred Years' War feels twice that long in this shrill, frenetic account of Joan of Arc. It's a film whose main revelation is that the Middle Ages may have been a lot more lurid than previously reported. Mr. Besson directs plenty of grisly, hand-held battle scenes and absurd scenes of royal scheming, while Ms. Jovovich talks. Like this. And doesn't seem faintly plausible as France's teenage martyr. Here's a case where "Don't shoot 'The Messenger' " would have been sound advice (Maslin).
 
"MUSIC OF THE HEART," starring Meryl Streep, Aidan Quinn, Angela Bassett and Gloria Estefan. Directed by Wes Craven (PG, 110 minutes). Not many of us enjoy being lectured by dressed-down Hollywood stars in gritty classroom situations. But the true story of Roberta Guaspari, a music teacher in East Harlem and a single mother surviving a nasty divorce, has been given a blunt, no-nonsense tone that works. Ms. Streep gives a down-to-earth performance that is sheer award bait. The story is inspirational enough to take Ms. Guaspari from no job prospects to watching her proud students play alongside Itzhak Perlman, Isaac Stern and other violin stars. Not a bad reason for Mr. Craven to have sidelined the claws and hatchets for a while (Maslin).
 
* "PRINCESS MONONOKE," with the voices of Billy Crudup, Claire Danes, Billy Bob Thornton and Minnie Driver. Directed by Hayao Miyazaki (PG-13, 133 minutes). A landmark feat of Japanese animation from the acknowledged master of the genre. This complicated, exotically beautiful epic features gods and demons locked in battle for the future of the forest, and its visions are breathtakingly rendered. But it is the film's stirring use of nature, myth and Japanese history that makes it so special. Worth seeing just for its Forest Spirit, which takes animal form by day and roams the night as a diaphanous, Godzilla-like divinity. The image of plants and flowers springing to life beneath his hooves is ravishingly presented. Despite a superb blend of hand-drawn cels and fluid, computer-generated animation, the film's look is gratifyingly understated (Maslin).
 
* "THE STRAIGHT STORY," starring Richard Farnsworth and Sissy Spacek. Directed by David Lynch (G, 110 minutes). As the least likely filmmaker on the planet to pull off a G-rated miracle, Mr. Lynch rises to the challenge with exhilarating vigor. It may not sound like much, but this account of an old man making a long trip on a riding lawn mower turns out to be a slow-moving, folksy-looking, deeply spiritual film with the power to hold audiences in thrall. And as Oscar may well note next spring, it would not have been possible without Mr. Farnsworth's terse, no-nonsense honesty at its heart. Mr. Lynch's famously unwholesome imagination crosses a new frontier to explore simple virtues and natural beauty. The result: a supremely improbable triumph (Maslin).
 
Film Series

HEADLINE: Fed Was Anticipating a Rate Increase, October Minutes Say

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers anticipated six weeks ago that they might need to raise interest rates this week to slow the economy but decided then there was no immediate need to do so, according to the minutes of their Oct. 5 meeting, which were released today.
Members of the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee thought a faster-than-expected economic revival abroad plus rising cost pressures at home had set the stage for higher inflation. But they concluded that conditions had not yet hit a danger level, the minutes said. 
 "Members saw little risk of a surge in inflation over coming months, though some pickup from the current subdued level of core price inflation was a distinct possibility," the minutes said.
Policy makers saw little risk in postponing a rate increase but "they believed that the committee probably would need to move to a less accommodative policy stance in the relatively near future, possibly at the November meeting."
Several factors troubled the policy makers as they looked ahead, including the possibility that gains in productivity might not continue to generate the increased output needed to offset higher wages and prices.
"A further pickup in productivity was by no means assured, and a number of other favorable developments in supply and prices that had acted to restrain inflation in recent years had already begun to dissipate or reverse," the October minutes said, citing increased energy and health-care costs and rising import costs as the dollar weakened.
The minutes are traditionally released after the next meeting of the open market committee. At its meeting on Tuesday, the Fed raised two key short-term interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, a move foreshadowed by the committee's unanimous decision in October to adopt a stance toward tighter policy.
The Fed minutes said the economy had "substantial momentum" that should carry through the end of the year before slowing. But they cautioned that a faster-than-expected revival in foreign economies and rising United States exports might offset part of the anticipated slowing in domestic demand.
The policy makers were clearly uncertain in October about inflation prospects, with several of them commenting on the "surprisingly benign" behavior of prices for so long.
In any event, they feared that even if the pace of economic expansion moderated it would occur with labor markets so tight and consumer spending so strong that there was still a risk of higher inflation.

HEADLINE: No Easy Labeling

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
When it comes to some prominent economic and social issues, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops can make all but the most liberal Democrats look pale.
Last April, for example, the bishops issued a statement calling for an end to capital punishment, not least because it "is often applied unfairly and in racially biased ways." In September, they joined other religious groups in a document that called access to housing "a sacred right" and urged the government to do more to help the poor find permanent shelter. 
 But in recent annual meetings, in considering internal church issues, the bishops have often taken conservative positions, underlining their gradual shift toward the right in the 1990's, a result of two decades of appointments by Pope John Paul II. On Wednesday, for example, the bishops voted to adopt a statement of new standards for Catholic universities that would require theologians to be certified by a bishop to show they were teaching "authentic Catholic doctrine."
And in 1998, on abortion, which the bishops see as a human rights issue, they pledged themselves to challenge politicians, particularly Catholic politicians, who support abortion rights to undergo "a change of heart."
The apparent difference in directions, some prelates and authorities on the church say, can be attributed to a more conservative stance by the bishops on the internal church issues, and those have come to dominate meetings of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops.
In the 1980's, by contrast, the bishops' conferences were preoccupied by debate on sweeping pastoral statements about wealth and poverty in America and the nation's role in preserving world peace.
"In the 80's, we were dealing with a lot of big, spectacular issues," said Bishop Robert N. Lynch of St. Petersburg, Fla., in a news conference after the bishops' meeting ended today. In the 90's, he said, "it seems to be a lot of internal issues."
And on those issues, the bishops have felt pressure from the Vatican to follow its direction. Three years ago, for example, Rome sent back to the bishops for revision an earlier version of the higher education document, which is titled, "Ex Corde Ecclesiae," a Latin phrase meaning "From the Heart of the Church." The Vatican asked for a more legalistic approach to the relationship between the church and the university classroom.
"They're getting all kinds of instructions from the Vatican," said the Rev. Thomas J. Reese, editor of the Jesuit magazine America. "And they're fairly deferential to the Vatican."
Earlier this year, church authorities in Rome ordered an American priest and nun to end their longtime ministry to gay and lesbian Catholics and their families. Despite hopes expressed by some of the ministry's supporters, the bishops made no move to question the decision.
The shift toward the right is even more apparent because the conference lacks a consensus-building figure, who could unite conservatives and moderates among the bishops, as it had in Cardinal Joseph Bernardin, the Chicago archbishop who died in 1996.
And among those the pope has elevated to church leadership is very likely the man the Vatican will choose as successor to Cardinal John O'Connor, who as archbishop of New York occupies the nation's most prominent and influential see.
Cardinal O'Connor did not attend the bishops' meeting this week. But his presence was felt in two letters he sent, both of which were read aloud. One expressed his support for the document on higher education.
The other bade an apparent farewell to his fellow prelates. In that one, he said it would be "the height of presumption" for him to expect that Pope John Paul II would allow him to remain in office much beyond his 80th birthday, next Jan. 15. Who might succeed him has been a matter of growing, if often private, speculation, including at the bishops' meeting.
But as a body at least, the bishops will probably continue to defy easy labeling.
Father Reese said that looking beyond their opposition to abortion and their support of state aid to parochial schools the prelates still stood "to the left" on many issues. As examples, he cited the bishops' support for the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, which was defeated recently in the Senate, and their concern for the rights and well-being of undocumented workers.
The conference's president, Bishop Joseph A. Fiorenza, head of the Diocese of Galveston-Houston, said the bishops were not "pulling back in any way" from addressing issues outside the church. "I think you will see us addressing more things like assisted suicide, capital punishment, sanctions against Iraq and Cuba," Bishop Fiorenza said. "We will respond to those issues out of what we believe, out of our faith."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
New Apartment Tower in Upper 90's

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Work is to begin in January on a 12-story rental building on the southeast corner of 97th Street and Lexington Avenue that will be the first of three new residential buildings that its developers plan for the immediate area.
The initial $32 million project, Carnegie Terrace, will have studio to two-bedroom apartments, with 513 to 1,050 square feet on average, in a brick structure that will rise to 6 stories along 97th Street and to 12 stories on Lexington Avenue. Eighty percent of the apartments are to be rented at market rates; the remaining 20 percent are to be leased to tenants with incomes of $14,950 to $26,700 a year, depending on family size. The building will also have 5,677 square feet of ground-floor retail space and a 150-car garage. 
 Carnegie Terrace, to be completed by May of 2001, is part of a larger plan by Navigator Realty to erect apartment buildings on two other sites it owns on Lexington Avenue between 96th and 98th Streets, both now vacant or used for parking. The plan envisions at least 385 additional apartments in two residential buildings, as well as 27,000 more square feet of stores.
"Essentially, what we are doing is building a new neighborhood," said Kinne S. Yon, who with her brother, Cornelius E. Sigety, are principals of Navigator Realty.
The plan for the three buildings in East Harlem, several residential brokers said, underscores the continued northward migration of market-rate housing into the high 90's on the Upper East Side.
Brian G. Edwards, director of leasing at the Halstead Property Company, a Manhattan brokerage, said that in the last decade's construction boom, a string of high-rise residential buildings was built along Third Avenue north of 86th Street, culminating with a 522-unit mixed-income rental that opened in 1992 on the north side of 96th Street. He said that when that building, called the Monterey, was successfully leased, it showed that "people were willing to cross the perceived traditional boundary of the Upper East Side to the north side of 96th Street."
In the current development wave, he said, the activity is spilling southeast to First Avenue, where several rental buildings are rising. They include the Chesapeake, with 208 units, at 94th Street and First Avenue, and Century Tower, with 128 apartments, at 90th Street and First Avenue. With Carnegie Terrace, he said, the activity will move northwest to Lexington Avenue.
The Sigety family, which owns and operates the Florence Nightingale Health Center at Third Avenue and 97th Street, has owned the development sites between 96th and 98th Streets since the 1970's. A decade earlier, Charles Sigety, the family patriarch, who is now retired, began buying properties in the neighborhood to redevelop into nursing homes. While the elder Mr. Sigety built a pair of nursing homes, both operated under the Florence Nightingale name, on two of the properties in the mid-60's and 70's, only the one on 97th Street, constructed in 1975, remains.
In 1987, Charles Sigety, according to his son Cornelius, removed the older nursing home, on 96th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues, from the state-subsidized system and sold the building to the Related Companies, a Manhattan developer, who razed it to make way for the Monterey. Over the years, state health officials repeatedly found that the home was not meeting quality health care standards, according to the State Health Department.
With the favorable response to the Monterey, Cornelius Sigety said he and his four siblings, who took over control of the three development sites from their father, decided to build housing on them, but by the early 1990's, the housing market had flattened. It also took three years to get the sites rezoned, which he said was necessary to make the projects economically feasible. The zoning change permitted larger and taller buildings, up to 16 stories from 7, to be constructed on the sites.
Though the rezoning was granted in 1997 by the City Council and approved by Community Board 11, it drew opposition from residents and members of local housing organizations, including tenants of Charles Sigety, who over the years accused him of trying to drive them out so that he could demolish the buildings and develop the land. The older Mr. Sigety is not involved with the housing projects and is no longer part of the operation of the existing nursing home, Cornelius Sigety said.
David E. Givens, chairman of Community Board 11, said he voted against the plan because "I would rather see more moderate-income housing built, which would be more beneficial to local residents." He said his hope was that neighborhood residents would qualify for the low- and moderate-income units in Carnegie Terrace and that the other buildings would also include such units.
Henry M. Calderon, a board member who is president of the East Harlem Chamber of Commerce, takes a different view. "Having market-rate housing," he said, "will send a strong signal to the investment community that East Harlem is not just a low-income neighborhood."
For Carnegie Terrace, a so-called 80-20 project, Navigator Realty received $32.6 million in bond financing from the New York State Housing Finance Agency and is working to secure a letter of credit from the Dime Savings Bank to protect bondholders.
Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, the brokerage that is the leasing agent for Carnegie Terrace, said Carnegie Terrace, designed by the Manhattan firm of Schuman Lichtenstein Claman Efron, will have mostly studio and one-bedroom apartments. Amenities planned at the building, which is one block from a subway stop, include a roof terrace, health club and doorman.
Though monthly rents have not yet been set, she said they would be competitive to those in comparable area buildings, which average $40 a square foot annually. That means that if leased today, the apartments would have monthly rents of about $1,800 for a studio and $3,500 for a two-bedroom unit, she said. Monthly rents for the low- and moderate-income units will be $326 to $541.
Cornelius Sigety said he would start construction on the second building, on the west side of Lexington Avenue between 96th and 97th Streets, after the first was leased.

HEADLINE: Deal to Revamp Organ Allocation Is at Risk

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
A bitter fight over whether, and how, to restructure the nation's system for distributing donated human organs has erupted in Congress, and a deal struck last week that would have cleared the way for the Clinton administration's long-planned overhaul was on the verge of falling apart today.
Under the agreement reached last week between Donna E. Shalala, secretary of health and human services, and a bipartisan group of Congressional appropriators, new federal rules governing organ allocation would take effect by late December or early January. The agreement was attached to a spending bill that is to be considered soon by Congress. 
 But in a last-minute move late Wednesday, Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, and J. Dennis Hastert, the speaker of the House, inserted a provision that would counteract last week's deal into a package that includes two popular bills, one that would help disabled people get back to work and another that would extend certain tax credits. That provision would delay the effective date of the rules by three months, giving Congress enough time to return from its winter break and take action to overturn them.
The tax credit and work incentives measure passed the House tonight. So now there are two major pieces of legislation working their way through the House and Senate, each with minor amendments governing organ allocation that are diametrically opposed.
Because the differing provisions cannot be stripped out of the bills, it is possible that both could be approved; in that case, Senate staff members on both sides of the issue said, the bill signed last would take precedence. But no one today was quite certain how it would turn out.
"It's a mess," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, who supports the Republican leadership and is pressing to delay the federal rules.
Mr. Torricelli is not the only member crossing party lines. As chairman of the Senate subcommittee that governs health spending, Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, worked with Dr. Shalala to reach last week's agreement. Today, a very angry Mr. Specter predicted that the matter might wind up in court, and he threatened to filibuster the tax credit legislation to block the actions of his fellow Republicans.
At the same time, the action of the Republican leaders placed the Clinton administration in a ticklish position. The administration strongly supports both the tax credit and workplace bills, and Mr. Clinton is not likely to veto them to keep the organ allocation deal intact.
"Right now, we have a very serious problem," said Dan Mendelson, associate director for health at the Office of Management and Budget.
The dispute stems from a bitter political and economic feud over which patients should have priority in receiving human organs, the nation's scarcest medical resources. An estimated 62,000 Americans are waiting for a heart, lung, liver, kidney or pancreas, and last year alone, 4,000 people died waiting. But waiting times vary greatly from region to region, and in February 1998, Dr. Shalala declared the current system unfair and said she intended to overhaul it.
Dr. Shalala's proposal, twice delayed by Congress, would force organs to be shared across bigger regions, with the sickest patients getting first priority, and would also greatly increase the secretary's authority over the private network that contracts with the government to distribute donated organs. The network, the United Network for Organ Sharing, has opposed the plan.
The proposal has also touched off a fight between large and small transplant centers, with small centers insisting that Dr. Shalala's rule would put them out of business by steering organs to big-city hospitals. This accounts for why the issue does not divide along party lines; members of Congress who represent states that have big transplant centers tend to support the administration, while those who represent states with smaller centers want the current system to remain intact.
"The stakes are extremely high," Senator Torricelli said. He added: "Hospitals will close, donations of organs will be altered. This is an issue that deeply divides the Congress, and it is something that should be debated and voted upon in the Congress."

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Gap Appears to Be Stabilizing

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
The trade deficit appears to be stabilizing as foreign economic growth picks up and the voracious American demand for imported goods and services slows, Commerce Department figures showed yesterday.
While the gap by which imports outpace exports widened in September, to $24.4 billion, the third biggest on record, analysts said it would have narrowed for the second consecutive month had it not been for the surging price of imported oil and an off month for exports of aircraft, which tend to occur in bunches. 
 "We've really seen some improvement" since the deficit peaked at $24.9 billion in July, said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International and a former trade official in Washington. He added that while the jump in oil prices would tend to mask this trend in coming months, the United States was well positioned to supply high-technology products to developing and newly industrialized countries that are increasingly able to afford them.
On the other hand, the deficit with China in September inched up to $6.9 billion from $6.87 billion, the biggest gap ever with any country. This provides ammunition to those in Congress who oppose the agreement reached Monday under which China is to lower barriers to American exports in return for support of its application for membership in the World Trade Organization.
Supporters, including Mr. Hormats, counter that such large imbalances show how important it is that Chinese markets be opened and that China be admitted to the world trade group, which sets the rules for international trade.
In September, the amount of what the United States bought from China was 6.3 times what it sold to China, up from 5.9 times in September 1998. Exports to China edged up just $100 million, to $1.3 billion.
The trade deficit with Japan climbed to $6.6 billion in September from $6.4 billion, with American purchases 2.5 times its sales compared with 2.1 times in the month a year earlier. Exports were virtually unchanged at $4.6 billion.
Marcus Noland, senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said the deficit with Japan, whose economy is still weak, would most likely expand in coming months until higher prices slow Japanese exports.
But he called trade adjustment elsewhere in Asia on track. "Those economies are pulling out of their recessions," Mr. Noland said, referring particularly to Hong Kong, Korea, Singapore and Taiwan.
Over all, American exports amounted to $81.7 billion in September, $700 million less than the record set in August. The biggest factor was a $900 million decline in capital goods, which the Commerce Department said consisted primarily of civilian aircraft. By contrast, agricultural sales, which have been depressed, rebounded to the highest level in almost two years, and consumer goods also sold better in world markets.
Imports edged up to a record $106.1 billion, $700 million more than in August, despite a $400 million decline in foreign motor vehicles and parts. This is in sharp contrast to the first nine months of the year, when automotive imports surged 22.5 percent, compared with figures in the period a year earlier.
Swamping this was a huge rise in the nation's bill for imported oil, a $6.8 billion jump reflecting higher volume as well as higher prices.
The nation's deficit with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries jumped to a record $3 billion in September from $2.7 billion in August.
Despite the recent stabilization, the American trade deficit so far this year totals $191.6 billion, or 58 percent more than the deficit in the period a year earlier. It is on a path to reach $255 billion. While this is already a record number of dollars, the deficit in the past has represented a larger share of the American economy, a more accurate measure of its importance. In 1987, the last time the trade deficit set a record before this summer, it accounted for 3.3 percent of gross domestic product; it now represents 2.9 percent.
Yesterday's report also showed that the deficit with Western Europe shrank to $3.5 billion from $4.4 billion, while that with Canada fell to $2.9 billion from $3.3 billion. The deficit with Mexico was unchanged at $2.2 billion. Unlike the aggregate figures, comparisons with individual countries are not adjusted for recurring seasonal variations.

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
Reggae Beat Keeps St. Lawrence Winning

BYLINE: By RON DICKER 

 BODY:
They developed their swagger in Brooklyn and their ball-handling skills on the island of Jamaica and other points south. Traveling a well-worn trail, they have now transferred their talents and aspirations to New York and points north.
The five Caribbean members of St. Lawrence University's soccer team have divined strengths from each leg of a journey that has taken them to snowy Canton, N.Y., just minutes from the Canadian border. In the process, they have transformed their sport into a big player on campus. 
 Although the Saints still play in the shadow of the school's Division I hockey team, they are casting their own shadow on Division III soccer. St. Lawrence, which has a 39-game unbeaten streak, advanced last weekend into the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament with victories over Norwich University of Vermont and Plattsburgh State. St. Lawrence next faces Messiah College of Pennsylvania tomorrow.
In the regular season, the Saints were a perfect 17-0, having trailed in just two games, and they are bursting with Caribbean flair. They blare their theme song, "Destiny," by the Jamaican reggae artist Buju Banton, before each match. They're hoping that destiny will help them bring St. Lawrence its first national soccer championship. Last season, the Saints lost to Williams on penalty kicks in the N.C.A.A. quarterfinals.
"We don't want to be like the Atlanta Braves, doing well in the regular season and folding in the playoffs," forward Howard Beckford, a product of Canarsie High in Brooklyn and Jamaica, said this week.
This year, the Saints feel they are better-equipped to deal with postseason pressure. A big reason is their largest contingent of island-born Brooklyn players yet. Not to mention midfielder Danny Annan, a four-year starter who played at Port Richmond High on Staten Island after immigrating from Ghana in west Africa.
"The biggest thing they bring is not really from Brooklyn," Coach Bob Durocher said. "It's their technical ability. The kids are very good on the ball. You can tell they were playing all the time. They were probably playing a lot of soccer on the streets. There's a lot of spontaneity, a lot of offensive ability."
Durocher's Caribbean recruiting pipeline opened when he was approached at practice in 1991 by a visiting economics professor named Gladstone Hutchinson. A former star at Oneonta State and a native of Jamaica, Hutchinson had connections to Jamaicans and other immigrants who were outstanding soccer players and academically minded.
Most came from Brooklyn high schools and played on a club team called the Rovers. The Rovers' coaches, Donovan Dixon and Errol Phillips, screened the players, and other prospects would emerge through an annual scouting combine at St. John's.
The migration to St. Lawrence began with a St. Francis College transfer named Chris Rose, a Jamaican, who was the leader of a Saints team that went 5-8-3 in 1992. Then Andre White, a star on Jamaica's junior team, enrolled the next season and St. Lawrence finished 8-4-3, its first winning record in eight seasons.
Durocher was so encouraged that he added one Brooklyn player a year for a few years before recruiting them in bunches. Now, St. Lawrence has qualified for the postseason four straight years.
The current crop, according to Nick Hillary (Samuel Tilden High), a senior fullback, comes from poor single-parent families that moved to New York so the children would have better educational opportunities. Hillary, the second oldest of 13 children, calls his mother, Dorrette, "my right hand."
Hillary, 24, who served as a tank gunner in the cleanup operation after the Gulf War, hopes to pursue a teaching career. He is the Saints' emotional leader and enforcer. He said he has urged the team to focus on the playoffs and push the unbeaten streak into the background. "We need to play every minute like it's our last," he said.
Beckford, a junior forward, turned down Division I-A offers to play for St. Lawrence, which has no sports scholarships, although athletes can earn most or all of the $30,000 tuition through need-based and academic scholarships. Beckford said Durocher was the selling point. "He wasn't wondering whether I had 4.4 speed," said Beckford, who plans to attend law school. "He was concentrating on my academics."
Jamal Ballantyne, a sophomore forward from Brooklyn Friends and originally from the island of St. Vincent, is St. Lawrence's fastest player and has 6 goals and 6 assists. A high school teammate, the sophomore midfielder Allan Maragh, from Jamaica, is also a full-time starter. Another Jamaican, Andre Webster, a sophomore forward out of Brooklyn's South Shore High, was slowed all season by abdominal and knee injuries and has been left off the tournament roster.
The team's leading scorer with 10 goals and 5 assists is Ryan Carruth, a junior striker from Boulder, Colo. Carruth knew he would be in for a different experience at St. Lawrence when his first stop on a recruiting visit four years ago was to Andre White's house. Dreadlocks flowing down to his shoulders, White strummed a guitar to a reggae record while the two chatted about school.
Now Carruth and many of the other American-born Saints are regulars at the house shared by the current Jamaican players, especially when they are cooking curry chicken and dumplings. "They bring a creative style of soccer," Carruth said. "And as people they bring a certain charisma that adds to the chemistry."

HEADLINE: 1968 Redux: New Issues Are Hot, Value Stocks Are Not

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
It's beginning to feel a lot like 1968.
Back then, the economy was barreling along, nearing the end of what was to be the longest period without a recession in American history. Individual Americans had more of their money in stocks than ever before, and the best-performing stocks were the ones that appeared to offer the worst values -- at least to those old-fashioned investors who worried about things like earnings. 
 In Washington, the government was bragging about its budget wizardry. The fiscal year that began in mid-1968 produced the first budget surplus in more than a decade.
The 1961-69 expansion will be replaced as the longest period of growth if the United States gets through the winter without a recession. Gimmicks and all, the federal budget is again in surplus. Households have more of their wealth in stocks than ever, and investors who pay attention to earnings are missing out on the best-performing stocks.
Over the last 18 months, an investor who carefully went through the stock market and chose a portfolio that was balanced among sectors and focused on the 10 percent of stocks with the lowest ratios of prices to earnings -- in other words, a value investor -- would have lost money.
But somebody who took the opposite strategy, buying only the stocks that were losing money or had the highest ratios of prices to earnings -- in other words, the kind of companies that seem overpriced to begin with -- would have a portfolio that rose 34 percent.
Those calculations come from Gina Moore, a research analyst at Aronson & Partners, a Philadelphia-based money management firm. She ran the numbers back to 1962, and reports that the only other time that value stocks trailed by so much was in the 18 months that ended in June 1968.
"It's mind-boggling," said Theodore Aronson, the firm's founder. "People are so underestimating risks." Mr. Aronson, a value investor, is not having a good year.
There are differences between now and 1968. Then inflation was rising, and the Vietnam quagmire was worsening. In the stock market, the expensive stocks that were flying high were generally smaller technology stocks with no profits but lots of hype. There are some such stocks now, most notably among Internet issues, but the most expensive stocks also include many of the big technology companies, whose financial success is clear.
But the similarities may be more significant. In 1968, the stock market had been rising, with only minor interruptions, for two decades, and the last recession, in 1961, was a distant memory. Many hot initial public offerings doubled the first day they traded. American households had a record 23.7 percent of their assets in stocks -- a figure not exceeded until 1998, when it hit 24.3 percent. (In 1978, after a brutal bear market, the figure was down to 8.5 percent.)
The lesson is that long bull markets and prolonged expansions breed complacency. In 1968, there was talk that central bankers could "fine tune" the economy to prevent recessions indefinitely. Now there is a "new paradigm" in which technological progress assures inflation-less growth.
Those who profited in 1968 were destined to suffer later, as the leading stocks of that market crumbled. The laggards of that era held up better, but virtually every stock was devastated in the 1973-74 bear market.
There is nothing visible now to stop the ascendancy of this year's market stars, and cautious voices have repeatedly been shown to be wrong as stocks they called overvalued proceeded to double and more. Just like 1968.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN TURKEY: THE LOANS;
U.S. Is Reconsidering Money for Russia

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The Clinton administration is quietly reassessing whether to slow two major loan programs to Moscow as the war in Chechnya accelerates and the two leading candidates for the Republican presidential nomination call for a cutoff of aid to Russia.
In public, White House officials have said that they continue to favor modest economic support for the Yeltsin government, and that termination of the aid runs the risk of further destabilizing Russia before two major elections there. Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, reiterated that position on Monday when he told reporters that despite the Russian military offensive in Chechnya, it would not "make sense for us to affect" a forthcoming loan from the International Monetary Fund, "assuming the economic and transparency criteria are met." 
 But within the administration, divisions on the question are growing; advocates of both views say there is a movement to go slow on two major loans -- one from the International Monetary Fund and another from the Export-Import Bank of the United States.
"There has been a debate brewing in our government over engagement versus disengagement for a year now," one senior administration official said today. "But in recent weeks it has gotten much more intense, and there are some strong voices for disengagement."
The first issue is whether the United States should allow the International Monetary Fund to release a long-delayed payment of $640 million to keep Russia from defaulting on past monetary fund loans. The money, part of a $4.5 billion program, would actually never enter Russia; it would simply be transferred from one I.M.F. account to another.
But its delivery would take economic pressure off Russia's central bank, which officials in several departments of the administration fear could send a political message that Moscow will not have to pay a price for its continued military action in Chechnya.
Administration officials say that they are making the decision on the merits, and ignoring the political impact on Vice President Al Gore, who played a major role in the development of the administration's economic support program for Russia.
But Mr. Gore's staff appears increasingly worried about his vulnerability on the issues, especially because Gov. George W. Bush Jr. of Texas, the Republican front-runner, has said he will call for a complete cutoff of the aid to Russia in a foreign policy speech he is expected to deliver on Friday. And Senator John McCain of Arizona, Mr. Bush's leading challenger for the nomination, has already opposed the loan while the war in Chechnya continues.
An even bigger issue is the Export-Import Bank loan, a half a billion dollars for the export of American-made oil equipment to Russia. Unlike the monetary fund loan, this money would come directly from an agency of the United States government. Again, it would not go directly to Moscow but rather to American companies supplying Russian oil companies with equipment.
Nonetheless, it would constitute the first resumption of direct American aid to Moscow in more than a year, and officials say the semi-independent Export-Import Bank has come under pressure from the administration to put the loan on "administrative hold," perhaps for a year or more.
In both instances the administration is making the case that, at the moment, the loans should be slowed for economic reasons that have nothing to do with Chechnya.
That enables it to avoid the question of whether they should seek to cut off the money as an act of political protest over the Chechnya military campaign, as they did to Indonesia during the violence in East Timor earlier this year.
In the case of the monetary fund loan, lengthy negotiations with Russia have yet to resolve some issues of "transparency" -- public explanations of how Russia is spending money and regulating its banks. The fund is insisting, for example, that Russia commit to a public audit of Sberbank, a major bank owned by the government, and make a series of amendments to its bankruptcy laws, among other demands.
"At this time Russia has not met the economic criteria," said one senior administration official deeply involved in the issue.
But asked whether Russia's behavior in Chechnya would be considered in coming weeks, the official added, "These things are always complex and there is a desire to maintain flexibility."
There are two Export-Import Bank loans pending, both of which have received preliminary approval from the bank's board of directors and were referred to Congress for a 30-day review period, now complete. The board is now free to approve the loans whenever it feels ready. But that moment still seems weeks or months away, and could be longer.
One of the deals involves $203 million in financing for the sale of equipment and services by ABB Lummus Global Inc., a Bloomfield, N. J., company, to update the Ryazan Oil Refinery near Moscow. The second is $292 million in financing for exports by Halliburton Co., of Dallas, to rehabilitate the Samotlar oil field.
The loans were controversial before the Chechnya fighting because the Russian company that will benefit, Tyumen Oil Co., is a player in a complex takeover effort that involved the bankruptcy of another oil company. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, 10 percent controlled by the United States government, is a major creditor of the bankrupt company.
The takeover dispute has already reached the Russian courts; there have been charges that the bankruptcy was manipulated by Russian oligarchs. The conflict has persuaded some administration officials not to aid Tyumen.

HEADLINE: Bill Expands Health Benefits for Disabled People Who Work

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Congress and the Clinton administration said today that they had agreed on a bill expanding Medicaid and Medicare so that people with disabilities could return to work without losing their health insurance benefits.
Supporters said the legislation was the most important step by the federal government to help disabled people since passage of the Americans With Disabilities Act in 1990. It was also the most significant health legislation to emerge from Congress this year, the supporters said. 
 The House of Representatives approved the compromise legislation tonight by a vote of 418 to 2, and the Senate is expected to approve it within a few days.
Under existing law, when disabled people go to work, they often lose Medicaid and Medicare. Without such coverage, they often cannot obtain the health care or medical equipment they need.
"The president is thrilled," said Chris Jennings, the health policy coordinator at the White House. "He sees this as one of the most important initiatives emerging from this year's budget negotiations."
Republicans saw the bill as a way to help people who want to work and pay taxes, rather than depend on federal aid.
Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware and chairman of the Finance Committee, said: "No one should have to choose health care over employment. This bill will make that choice unnecessary."
Advances in medicine have allowed many people with disabilities to work. And with the unemployment rate at a 29-year low, many employers are eager to hire them. Often the jobs carry no health benefits and disabled people are unable to find or afford insurance from private companies.
Eight million disabled people of working age receive more than $50 billion a year in cash benefits from Social Security and Supplemental Security Income. Fewer than 1 percent return to work. The number of people receiving disability benefits has risen in the last decade.
The bill sailed through the House in October on a vote of 412 to 9, after a similar measure was approved by the Senate in June, 99 to 0. But the bill has been imperiled at every stage by one dispute after another, most recently by disagreements over how to pay the cost, about $800 million over five years.
The bill includes an unrelated provision that would delay federal rules to create a national system for allocating kidneys, livers and other human organs donated for transplant.
The whole package was bundled with legislation to extend expiring tax breaks, including credits for research conducted by technology and pharmaceutical companies. The package was separate from the appropriations package that Congress was also considering today.
White House officials said Mr. Clinton opposed delay of the organ distribution system and hoped to delete it, but he was not threatening to veto the underlying bill.
Under another section of the bill, states could provide Medicaid to workers who are not actually disabled, but have physical or mental impairments that are "reasonably expected" to become severe disabilities in the absence of treatment.
This could be a boon to people who have been infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, but have yet to develop symptoms of the disease. Medicaid would help them get protease inhibitors and other powerful drugs so they could fight off AIDS and continue working.
The same section of the bill could help people with Parkinson's disease, multiple sclerosis and other chronic or degenerative conditions. States could also provide Medicaid to workers with potentially severe physical or mental impairments that could be traced to birth defects.
Representative Rick A. Lazio, Republican of New York Republican and chief sponsor of the House bill, said: "The bill sends a message to people with disabilities. If you go to work, you won't be punished, and you don't have to impoverish yourself just because you want to become a taxpayer."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and one of his aides, Connie Garner, found ways to rescue the bill when it appeared that it might sink under objections from conservative Republicans.
The legislation would help disabled people in these ways:
*People who lose eligibility for Social Security disability benefits because they return to work could keep their Medicare coverage for eight and a half years. That is four and a half years more than they get under current law.
*People with disabilities could buy Medicaid coverage even if they took jobs and earned money that would otherwise disqualify them. They could be required to pay premiums to cover some of the costs.
*States could allow disabled workers to buy Medicaid coverage, even if the workers lost eligibility for cash benefits because of improvements in their medical conditions.
The bill would establish a way of providing employment and training to people with disabilities. The government would issue a voucher, or ticket to work, that could be used by a disabled person to buy such services from either a state agency or a private business.
The cost of initiative would be offset by an assortment of cutbacks and minor changes in other programs, including the school lunch program, loans to college students and fees for lawyers who represent Social Security beneficiaries.

HEADLINE: School Board's Approval of $300,000 for a Film Angers East Orange

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 18

 BODY:
Residents here expressed concern and some anger today over revelations that the school board in this financially strapped city approved spending $300,000 to help finance a film conceived by the district's superintendent as an educational tool.
While some people expressed concern about spending public education funds on a movie set in an economically depressed area and sprinkled with four-letter words and possibly objectionable sexual references, others criticized it as a misuse of resources in a district where many basic needs are unmet. They blamed the superintendent, John Howard Jr., whom some critics have termed autocratic and ineffectual in guiding the 12,000-student district. 
 The existence of the film script and the appropriation were first disclosed today in The Star-Ledger of Newark.
Chief among the critics of the appropriation for the film was the East Orange mayor, Robert L. Bowser, who questioned "the purpose of the content and the subject matter" of the film, adding, "Simply put, this filmmaking project is just inappropriate, particularly in light of the fact that I believe the funds could have been put to better use to address pressing issues facing our children concerning the mastery of the basics." The district has a $139 million annual budget.
Mr. Howard declined to comment on the dispute and said through a spokesman that he would speak about it "at the appropriate time."
Repeated attempts to reach members of the city's school board, who approved the $300,000 expenditure, and to determine what exactly it was to be used for, were unsuccessful.
The Rev. Dwight Gill, pastor of New Hope Baptist Church here and a frequent critic of the school system and of Mr. Howard, said that he and others would call for the superintendent's resignation over the incident. Although he conceded that he had not read the film script, he said it was an example of the "self-centered, egotistical style" of the superintendent.
"All of this seems to be about Dr. Howard's dreams rather than the school district's needs," Mr. Gill said. "The schools are in terrible physical condition, the test scores are not improving and the administration is top-heavy."
The title page of the script for the movie, "Dragonfly," reads, "Story by Dr. John Howard. Written by the East Orange Film Cooperative." A reading of the script shows it to be an uplifting amalgam of "West Side Story," the television show "Fame" and the recent film "The Substitute." It is set in a fictional East High School in a four-square-mile city identical in size to East Orange, where Haitian-American gangs and gangs of native-born American blacks are at each other's throats, in a rivalry not entirely unlike the real-life tensions in East Orange.
The plot pits a cynical white teacher who plays to and exploits the students' worst impulses and tenuous social situations against a benevolent black teacher who tries to lift them above their circumstances and bring out their talents for dance, music or computers. The script's earnest tone is punctuated by a dialogue that sometimes uses expletives as it seeks to mimic the slang and speech of the high school setting.
As with most disputes in East Orange, the current one owes some of its vehemence to longstanding political rivalries in the city of 78,000. Mr. Howard and the majority of the school board date to the administration of the former mayor, Cardell Cooper, now a top official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Mr. Bowser is a longtime political opponent of Mr. Cooper and, since winning the mayor's office two years ago, he has been quick to highlight problems in the city that he believes are the legacy of the previous administration.

LENGTH: 1652 words

HEADLINE: New Digital Cameras Poised To Jolt Worldof Filmmaking

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 18

 BODY:
A digital video camera was perched like a bazooka on the shoulder of the director Mike Figgis as he carved a path through the oblivious pedestrians on Sunset Strip, following the actor Stellan Skarsgard into a swanky glass-faced office. At the same moment, not far away, three other digital cameras were following other actors as they made their way down the sidewalk, chatted on cell phones or bickered at curbside, the real world swirling all around them.
Whatever this film in progress might add up to artistically, Mr. Figgis, the British director best known for the Oscar-winning "Leaving Las Vegas," is at the very least extraordinarily ambitious, some might say audacious, about exploiting the digital technologies that are beginning to seep into the Hollywood mainstream. 
 For years digital moviemaking has been a grass-roots movement among aspiring filmmakers who resented the dominance of the Hollywood aesthetic. Mr. Figgis's film, "Time Code 2000," brings the new technology inside the walls of the major studios -- in this case those of Sony Pictures, which, not coincidentally, is owned by a company that also manufactures digital equipment. Once inside the walls, many believe, digital moviemaking will have a major impact on the way movies are made and how people view them.
"Time Code 2000" is being shot in real time; that is, as one continuous take, without editing, that lasts a predetermined 93 minutes. The four cameras dance across a half dozen sets and down city streets with a breathtaking seamlessness, following the film's characters in and out of meetings, assignations and confrontations.
Mr. Figgis thought of doing the film just a few months ago, and he said the digital technology would require only four to six weeks of postproduction work instead of the typical several months, time spent mostly fussing with the sound mix. The film potentially could be available for theatrical release before the end of the year. When it appears in theaters, he said, the images from all four cameras will be shown simultaneously, either in horizontal strips with four images shown from left to right or stacked two-atop-two, allowing audience members to edit the film in their own heads as they switch attention from one image to another and try to follow the plot.
Despite many predictions that digital technology will transform the industry, its potential influence is still far from certain. For one thing, many filmmakers are extremely resistant to using digital video because of the flat, bland image that videotape often produces, particularly in comparison to the richer images recorded by film.
The cost of converting to digital projection systems is also formidable -- $100,000 per projector multiplied by the more than 34,000 screens in the United States alone -- and theater owners and studios have very different ideas about who should pay the tab. Meanwhile, even the adventurous Mr. Figgis must transfer his digital tape to old-fashioned film so it can be projected by the machines now in place.
Nevertheless, digital proponents remain exultant. "It's a revolution," said Rodger Raderman, chairman of iFilm, a San Francisco-based company that distributes digital films on the Internet. "And I believe it's coming faster than most people think."
Documentary filmmakers, in particular, have been at the forefront, driven by economic necessity and a lack of interest from the entertainment industry in financing their projects.
Such respected directors as Penelope Spheeris and Spike Jonze have done work in digital video, and earlier this month New Line Cinema announced that it had signed a deal with Spike Lee to make "Bamboozled," a movie entirely on digital video.
When digital filmmaking's full potential is reached, a growing number of people in the industry believe, it might even threaten a studio power structure that has held firm since the advent of sound and has absorbed such technological challenges as television and VCR's.
"It is beyond imagination what this is going to do to filmmaking," said Mr. Figgis, whose roots are in music, theater and experimental film. "What has been an exclusive medium of high finance, banking and financial exclusivity is now going to become something that is within the reach of everyone."
The theory is that even the most modestly financed filmmaker could afford to shoot a movie and transmit it to theaters digitally at little expense.
This revolution, if that's what it is, is being driven by the convergence of several technologies: relatively inexpensive digital video cameras, only now becoming widely available; digital projectors that eliminate the need for film; and the growing ability of the Internet and other information pipelines to transmit digital sounds and images to multiplexes, living rooms and computer screens without reliance on a studio's expensive production and distribution services.
It may even become possible to distribute and market those films effectively on the Internet if the example of this summer's "Blair Witch Project," a cheaply made horror film that became a huge hit after a shrewd marketing campaign that exploited the World Wide Web, is a guidepost to the future.
"The whole economics of the business are basically turned upside down by digital technology," said Bruce Apar, editor in chief of Video Business, a magazine published by Variety. "It will change the movie industry, absolutely."
Emerging technologies may push change even further. Some will allow filmmakers to bypass not only film, but also digital tape, making it possible to shoot onto digital sticks, which resemble credit cards, and computer disks, both of which break down images into binary code. The images can be downloaded to a computer and transmitted the same way that any other computer file is transmitted. They can be edited on the computer screen, extraordinary effects can be added, and the resulting movie can be sent by modem or satellite to any place in the world. Then theater owners can download the movies and project them onto a screen with the new generation of digital projectors.
The financial savings can be considerable even with available digital equipment. Digital cameras cost a small fraction of what film cameras cost, and prices are plummeting. New software allows anyone to edit film on a home computer. There are no costs for developing film, no need for reels of celluloid. Instead of paying hundreds of thousands of dollars to make copies of a movie, producers could make as many copies as necessary at the click of a mouse.
Mr. Figgis illustrated, picking up a small, hand-held camera that was resting on a nearby chair. "See this? It's a new, state-of-the-art digital camera. Costs about $3,000," he said. "I'd be using it on this movie except the tapes are only an hour long and I need two hours."
"Time Code 2000" is being made on a budget "in the low millions," Mr. Figgis said, about 5 percent of the $60 million that is spent on the average major studio production. Most of his budget is going to pay the union wages of those working on the film and for the handful of sets he is using.
"If I were some young filmmaker in Ohio or someplace," Mr. Figgis said, "and I could use friends and shoot on found locations instead of on sets, this movie, this very same movie, could be made for about $100,000."
Mr. Figgis's film looks little like the slick, visually sumptuous films that Hollywood studios regularly produce. It is rapid, jerky and definitely ragged around the edges, but Mr. Figgis believes that moviegoers who accepted "Blair Witch," which had many of the same qualities, will accept his film, too.
The emergence of the new technology is most visible on the proliferation of Internet sites devoted to digital films (even the major studios have begun to get involved in this) and in the growth of the microcinema movement, in which digital filmmakers exhibit their work in cities around the country.
The attraction to filmmakers is only partly economic. It is also artistic. Digital video makes filmmakers more mobile, better able to shoot scenes without cocooning themselves in studios or at on-site locations, and freer to move through the bustle of real city streets, even interacting with real people. For most of the century filmmakers have been restricted to shots of no longer than 10 minutes, a length limited by the size of film magazines. (A 20-minute magazine has recently become available.) Digital cameras, however, can shoot and shoot and shoot.
Studio executives, who acknowledge that the technology will change their business, are not so sure that it will make them as irrelevant as some filmmakers might hope. Studios, they argue, will still be the marketplace where creative ferment produces the best stories. And it will still be the studios -- and the surrounding world of agents and producers -- that will retain control of the copyrighted characters (think "Batman") and the top-name actors who will be needed to make a movie, even a digital movie, rise above the expected glut.
By the time production on "Time Code 2000" ends on Friday, Mr. Figgis will have shot the film more than seven times. Then he will choose the version he considers best.
If his project feels a bit like a stunt, Mr. Figgis does not disagree, though he prefers the term "performance art." His movie is intended, in part, to draw attention to the possibilities created by digital technology.
"My hope is to have the film released, at least in a couple of theaters, before the end of the year," he said. Columbia Pictures has not decided whether it will release the film late this year or early next year. What is telling, though, is that it is possible to release a film so quickly.
"I think," Mr. Figgis said, "it would be nice to have this look at the cinema of the next century come out in the last week of this century."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Pursuit of Stock Wealth Brings a World of Swindlers
Along with the greatest bull market in American history comes a world of low-priced stocks and high-priced dreams, of grimy offices and sham companies, of swindlers who bilk Americans out of roughly $2 billion a year, securities regulators say. The problem is so severe that regulators and prosecutors have made it one of their chief goals to crack down on what they used to dismiss as "penny-stock fraud." 
 It was in this world that Albert Alain Chalem and Maier Lehmann lived -- and died. The men, who were promoting stocks over the Internet together, were both shot in the head on Oct. 25 and left to die on the marble floor in the $1.1 million home in Colts Neck, N.J., where Mr. Chalem lived. Page A1.
 
Investigators are examining whether there is a link between the deaths of the two stock promoters and an account one of them may have had at Harbor Securities, a small stock trading firm that closed this week. B6.
 
Digital Technology Seeps Into Films
Mike Figgis, the director of "Leaving Las Vegas," is seeking to exploit the digital technologies that are beginning to seep into the Hollywood mainstream. His latest film, "Time Code 2000," is being shot in real time with four digital cameras as one continuous take. When it appears in theaters, he said, the images from all four cameras will be shown simultaneously, either in horizontal strips with four images shown left to right or stacked two atop two, allowing audience members to edit the film in their heads as they try to follow the plot. Once inside the walls of major studios, many think, digital movie making will have a great effect on how movies are made and how people view them. A1.
 
Boeing Agrees to Settle Bias Case
Boeing has agreed to pay at least $4.5 million to women and minority employees who the Government says are paid less than their white male counterparts, according to people involved in the settlement, the largest ever under a Labor Department affirmative action compliance program. C2.
 
S.& P. 500 and Nasdaq Hit Records
Stocks rallied, led by computer-related companies, after Hewlett-Packard sold shares in its measurement instruments unit. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 14.23 points, or 1 percent, to 1,424.94, a record. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 77.72 points, or 2.38 percent, to 3,347.11, also a record. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 152.61 points, or 1.4 percent, to 11,035.70. C8.
 
4 Nations Back Caspian Pipeline
Four nations in the Caspian Sea region -- Georgia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Turkey -- took a step toward embracing one of President Clinton's cherished foreign policy projects, a pipeline that would assure Western control over the region's potentially vast oil and natural gas reserves. A1.
 
Shares of Hewlett Increase 21%
Shares of Hewlett-Packard jumped nearly 21 percent, one day after the company posted stronger-than-expected quarterly earnings, set an aggressive sales goal for next year and began spinning off Agilent Technologies. Hewlett-Packard closed at $94.3125, up $16.3125. Shares in Agilent, the test business, were up $12.75, at $42.75, in their first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. C8.
 
Trade Deficit Is Seen Stabilizing
The nation's trade deficit appears to be stabilizing as foreign economic growth picks up and the American demand for imports slows, Commerce Department figures showed. While the gap widened in September, to $24.4 billion, analysts said it would have narrowed had it not been for surging oil prices and an off month for aircraft delivery. C2.
 
28 Regal Hotels Are Sold in U.S.
Millennium & Copthorne, a London real estate company, has agreed to buy the 28 Regal hotels in the United States for about $253 million plus the assumption of $387 million in debt from Regal Hotels International of Hong Kong. The hotels include the Regal U.N. Plaza in Manhattan, the Regal Biltmore in Los Angeles, the Regal Bostonian in Boston and the Regal McCormick Ranch in Scottsdale, Ariz. C5.
