HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN TURKEY: THE OVERVIEW;
YELTSIN AND WEST CLASH AT SUMMIT OVER CHECHEN WAR

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Nov. 18

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin and the West squared off over Chechnya today, as the Russian leader told a European summit meeting that the West had no right to criticize Russia for its campaign against "bandits and murderers."
But President Clinton insisted that the West was only trying to do for Chechnya's civilians what it would have done for Mr. Yeltsin himself when he was on the barricades: defend their rights against the abusive authorities. Excerpts from their speeches, Page A21. 
 Seldom since the end of the cold war has Russia appeared so isolated on the world stage as one by one, Western leaders at the meeting of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe declared that Russia's indiscriminate bombardment of Chechnya was needlessly killing and wounding its own citizens.
Mr. Yeltsin, looking unusually hale and combative, mocked the idea that the plight of civilians justified Western meddling in Russian affairs. He branded the calls for peace talks as hopelessly naive.
But unlike the sharp human rights debates of Soviet times, the criticism of Moscow today was more in sorrow than in anger, as Western officials lectured Russia that its treatment of civilians in Chechnya fell below civilized norms.
In surprisingly personal remarks, Mr. Clinton sought to justify the West's intercession over Chechnya by recalling how Mr. Yeltsin clambered onto a tank to prevent an assault on his government headquarters by hard-line Communists during the final days of the Soviet Union.
"President Yeltsin, one of the most thrilling experiences of my life as a citizen of the world, before I become president, was when you stood up on that tank in Moscow when they tried to take the freedom of the Russian people away," Mr. Clinton said. "If they had put you in jail instead of electing you president, I would have hoped that every leader of every country around this table would have stood up for you, and not said, 'Well, that is an internal Russian affair that we cannot be a part of.' "
Mr. Yeltsin listened attentively to Mr. Clinton and later gave him a bear hug. Still, there was no sign that the Russian had been persuaded.
While Mr. Clinton and other leaders argued that moral considerations sometimes justified intervention in another nation's affairs -- military action in the case of Kosovo and public criticism in case of Chechnya -- Mr. Yeltsin ridiculed the notion as "humanitarian interference."
"You have no right to criticize Russia for Chechnya," Mr. Yeltsin said at the 54-nation meeting. "There will be no negotiations with bandits and murderers."
Behind the public fireworks, the Russians also pressed privately to deflect the West's criticism of their Chechnya policy.
Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov gave American officials a diplomatic paper that hinted Russia would drop some of its objections to American policy toward Iraq if Washington offered a private assurance that the issue of Chechnya would not be brought before the United Nations Security Council.
A small measure of agreement was reached when Russia agreed to allow a representative of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to visit Chechnya. That was less than the mediation role that some Western governments had sought for the organization.
But Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said, "I think we got a good foot in the door."
With parliamentary elections only a month away in Russia, domestic politics appeared to be a significant factor in the fiery tone of Mr. Yeltsin's speech. The president and other Russian politicians have discovered that a hard-nosed policy toward Chechnya and open defiance of the West is very popular with Russians.
Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the leader of the liberal Yabloko party, is one of the few major Russian politicians who have even broached the idea of negotiating with the Chechens, and for that he has branded a virtual traitor by some capitalist reformers.
Even though the fighting has resulted in more than 200,000 refugees, many of them ethnic Russians, many Russians seem to think this is an acceptable price to hunt down the Islamic militants who invaded Dagestan last summer and who are generally blamed for a spate of terror bombings in Moscow and other cities that have killed nearly 300 people. The Chechen guerrilla leaders accused of the attacks deny the charge.
The antipathy many Russians harbor toward people from the Caucasus has further tempered their sympathy for the Chechen refugees. Sergei Shoigu, Russia's minister for emergency situations, has also sought to defuse the talk of a humanitarian crisis in Chechnya by asserting that the main fighting would be over by Feb. 1, and that the 200,000 refugees could then return.
Then there is the determination of the Russian military to avenge its defeat in the 1994-96 Chechen war, and not only to subdue Chechnya, but to also send a message to the region that Russia is still a power to be reckoned with.
The Russian annoyance with the West has been further fanned by a host of other disputes, including the Clinton administration's interest in pressing ahead with an antimissile defense and its position on oil pipelines in former Soviet areas.
Today, for instance, Mr. Clinton watched approvingly as Turkey, Azerbaijan and Georgia signed an agreement to build a pipeline that would channel oil from the Caspian Sea to international markets without passing through Russian or Iranian territory, dealing another blow to Russian influence in the region.
The dispute over Chechnya delayed the signing of a new Charter on European Security, which was to have been concluded today.
In criticizing the Russian policy, Western officials sought to make clear that they agreed that they were not challenging the Kremlin's right to use military force to put an end to terrorism and to prevent the nation from fracturing.
The problem, they said, lay in the way Russia was pursuing that goal -- indiscriminate rocket attacks and bombings that have taken a heavy civilian toll and have fostered a new generation of embittered and revenge-minded Chechens.
"We are all determined to fight terrorism," said Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general. "But the force we use to fight it should always be proportional, and focused on the actual terrorists. We cannot and must not fight them by using their own methods, by inflicting indiscriminate violence and terror on innocent civilians."
Gerhard Schroder, the German chancellor, added, "War is no way to eliminate terrorism."
As much as such comments irritated the Russians, they fell short of what some Western critics, like former United States national security adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski, have urged: the cutoff or Western credits and assistance.
But in Washington, some officials now say the administration has begun to reassess its modest economic support for the Yeltsin government, and is considering going slow on two large loans, one of them from the International Monetary Fund.
During the first Chechen war, Mr. Clinton and other Western leaders were slow to criticize Russia. Mr. Clinton, in fact, even likened Mr. Yeltsin then to Abraham Lincoln during the Civil War, while Vice President Al Gore initially insisted that Chechnya was an internal Russian affair, echoing Moscow's current position.
In part, today's comments by Western officials appeared intended to persuade their own publics that they are not ignoring the matter.
Mr. Clinton's comments were among the most persuasive, a number of people who gathered here for the meeting said. White House officials said Mr. Clinton rewrote the remarks as the meeting began to mention Mr. Yeltsin on the tank.
As filtered through the Russia media, however, Mr. Clinton's argument may have become lost or distorted. The state-owned ORT television network presented Mr. Clinton's comments as an indication that he was impressed by Mr. Yeltsin's moral character and had been won over by the strength of the Russian president's address.
President Eduard Shevardnadze of Georgia sized up the problem before the meeting. "It is not easy to influence Russia," he said.

HEADLINE: Mistrustful of U.S., Egyptians Are Bitter About Crash Inquiry

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Nov. 18

 BODY:
As the inquiry into the crash of EgyptAir Flight 990 moves into a delicate new phase, Egyptian and American officials face high stakes in trying to find conclusive and satisfactory answers to questions about what brought the plane crashing into the ocean late last month.
For the Egyptian government, the results of the investigation could affect both national pride and the fortunes of the country's tourism industry, one of its economic lifelines. In a sign of how volatile the issue of the inquiry has become, conspiracy theories are now circulating wildly in Egypt, troubling both American and Egyptian officials. 
 Some have blamed Israel's intelligence service for the crash; others have suggested that the American investigators are covering for the plane's manufacturer. And as unlikely as the theories might seem, they have been embraced here more easily than the very different hypothesis put forward by American investigators: that the aircraft and all 217 people aboard might have been brought down by a suicidal Egyptian pilot.
The response by the Egyptian public and government to that suggestion has been so bitter that some say it is unclear whether the Egyptian government will ever cooperate fully with the kind of exhaustive criminal inquiry that is the next step favored by many American investigators.
"Even if they are persuaded that there is reason to suspect this pilot, I wonder whether Egypt will feel comfortable allowing an F.B.I. team to come to Egypt and begin asking questions at will," said a Western diplomat here.
Already, an Egyptian challenge to the working American theory has delayed any decision to shift responsibility for the case to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. American and Egyptian officials in Washington are reviewing the evidence that has been gathered by accident investigators from the National Transportation Board in hope of reaching a joint decision on how to go forward.
Egyptian experts are expected to help interpret voice recordings from the cockpit, while diplomats from the United States and Egypt will try hard to present a picture of partnership. Only with the permission of the Egyptian government could American investigators begin any kind of criminal inquiry here into the background of Gamil al-Batouti, 59, the reserve pilot who the Americans think might have been responsible for the crash on Oct. 31.
But the Egyptian government is likely to listen closely to the anger being voiced by ordinary Egyptians, who say the pilot sabotage hypothesis is little more than the product of an overactive American imagination.
"The Americans are trying to harm Egypt's reputation by any means," said Mohammed Sami, 62, a retired executive of the Egyptian railway authority. "They just want to take every small thing and turn it into a very big complicated thing that backfires against Egypt."
The United States and Egypt are close allies, and both have good reason for wanting to defuse any dispute or tension. Egypt receives more than $2 billion a year in assistance from the United States, making it the second-largest recipient of American aid, behind Israel. The United States relies heavily on Egypt as a mediator in peace talks and as a potential staging area for troops in the event of renewed conflict in the region.
In Washington, the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, insisted at a briefing today that the United States and Egypt had been "working very, very closely together at all levels in the investigation."
"Our long and close friendship will not be harmed because we have confidence that the Egyptian government, like the United States government, wants to get to the bottom of this," Mr. Rubin said.
But in Turkey today, Egypt's foreign minister, Amr Moussa, amplified his government's reluctance to accept the American theory that the plane had been brought down by pilot sabotage. So far, the foreign minister said, it is too early to label the crash anything but a technical failure.
"You can't jump to conclusions from someone quoting the Koran and say that this was more than an accident," Mr. Moussa said.
Mr. Moussa's reference was to a phrase, translated as "I put my trust in God," that Mr. Batouti, then sitting at the controls of the aircraft, was heard to have uttered at the start of events that led to the crash. The American investigators at least initially thought Mr. Batouti's use of the phrase was an indication that he might have been preparing for death.
But Egyptian officials have scoffed at that notion, saying that if anything, Mr. Batouti's language might be a sign that he had encountered some kind of emergency in the cabin. In a new response to the American theory, EgyptAir today dispatched a team of medical and technical experts to the United States, and officials said they would seek to address what Mr. Batouti's former colleagues have called the unfounded accusations against him.
Since the crash, Egypt has allowed the United States to assume primary responsibility for the investigation into the cause. But under international agreements, it could reassert its authority over the investigation at any time, experts here say.
There has been no indication that Egypt might take such a step. But in an implicit warning, Al Akhbar, the semi-official Egyptian daily, complained in an editorial today that the publicity given in the United States to the theory of pilot sabotage "indicates that there is an intention to rule out any American responsibility for this tragic accident."
On Wednesday, Louis B. Freeh, director of the F.B.I., said that if Egypt did assert primacy in the case, the United States would carry out its own investigation, but he acknowledged that such an inquiry could not extend to Egypt without permission from the Egyptian authorities.
Along with its stated aversion to a rush to judgment, the Egyptian government has solid practical reasons for at least wishing that the American inquiry would shift away from a finding of pilot misconduct.
Any conclusion that an EgyptAir pilot was responsible for the crash could subject the state-run airline to heavy liability claims. And an adverse ruling would almost certainly rebound against Egypt's tourism industry, which has only now recovered from the setback caused by the 1997 killings of 58 foreign tourists during an attack in Luxor.
At the same time, the suspicion and bitterness with which many Egyptians have responded to the American theory reflect a view that runs deep here: that the United States and other Western powers, for all their declarations of partnership, do not have Egypt's best interests at heart.
Those sentiments could be heard today in conversations around the capital, as Egyptians spoke with near unanimity in rejecting the American version of events.
"They're looking for a scapegoat," said Issam Abdel Moneim, 58, an accountant.
"They want to escape responsibility," said Amr Abdel Kalik, 21, a student.
"They are not neutral," said Manal Ali, 30, a secretary.

HEADLINE: Chechnya and the West

 BODY:
President Boris Yeltsin of Russia growled this week at Western leaders meeting in Turkey that they had no right to criticize his nation's war against "bandits and murderers" in Chechnya. On this point, the Russian president is simply wrong. Mr. Yeltsin and his allies in Moscow need to listen to warnings by those leaders who tried during the European security conference in Istanbul to explain that using bombs and tanks would not work, militarily or diplomatically, to oust Chechen terrorists.
President Jacques Chirac of France, for example, said this war to combat terrorism was "a tragic error" that was taking too many innocent lives in the breakaway republic. President Clinton, who had compared the earlier Chechen war, from 1994 to '96, to the United States' Civil War, this time tried another tack. 
 Mr. Clinton reminded Mr. Yeltsin about the beneficial side of meddling by outsiders. He noted that the West had rallied to Mr. Yeltsin in August 1991 as hard-liners tried to take over the government and the Yeltsin forces were in the streets of Moscow. "If they had put you in jail instead of electing you president," Mr. Clinton told the Russian leader, "I would have hoped that every leader of every country around this table would have stood up for you and not said, 'Well, that is an internal Russian affair that we cannot be a part of.' "
Whether it was the tougher words of the Europeans, the more understanding tone of Mr. Clinton or other unrevealed factors in the Istanbul meeting, the Russians did agree to allow the chairman of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to visit Chechnya and help seek a political resolution to the conflict. That, at least, is good news. It means that the leaders meeting in Turkey will have both a political and humanitarian role in the region. But Chechnya is still a raw battlefield that Russian leaders are using to rally political support at home even as criticism mounts abroad.
While Russia's need to pursue terrorism is understandable, Mr. Yeltsin and his government should take note of Gov. George W. Bush and those in the Clinton administration who want to take a harsher line against Russia. Mr. Bush has suggested cutting off aid until Russia stops killing Chechen civilians. Such threats, aimed more at the American voters than at the international arena, sound better on the campaign trail than they would as policy. Aid to Russia is in America's own interest -- not only to provide help in dismantling Russia's nuclear weapons but also to foster economic and civic stability in an emerging democracy.
The Russians, however, must realize that good will in the West and especially in America is in their interest as well. The stream of refugees from Chechnya and the bombings in downtown Grozny are images the American people care about. In the long run, these cruelties add to American doubts, not simply about Chechnya but about the willingness of Russia's leaders to move away from the brutal methods of the past.

HEADLINE: A New Front in the PCB War

 BODY:
New York's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, who has been suing big corporations right and left recently, has now charged General Electric with impeding navigation along a stretch of the Hudson River and thus preventing the river from reaching its full potential as a commercial and recreational waterway. The suit represents a novel attempt to speed a resolution of the 25-year controversy over PCB contamination in the Hudson. If successful, the suit may also establish a precedent for claims against other companies whose activities can be shown to have restricted economic development along New York's waterways.
But the furor surrounding Mr. Spitzer's announcement inflates its immediate importance. The real battle is still the struggle between the company and the federal Environmental Protection Agency, which will decide late next year whether to require G.E. to undertake an expensive dredging operation to rid several contaminated "hot spots" in the river of PCB's. G.E. has never denied responsibility for the chemicals, which were discharged from two now-defunct plants north of Albany years ago. The E.P.A. regards PCB's -- polychlorinated biphenyls -- as a health risk to wildlife and to people who regularly eat fish caught in the upper Hudson. PCB's are also among the biggest remaining obstacles to the ecological recovery of the river. 
 Mr. Spitzer's suit does not address environmental or health risks. Instead it argues that the costs associated with removing and storing toxic sediments are so high that the state has been unable to dredge the Champlain Canal, an important navigable waterway that stretches from Lake Champlain to Waterford, about 30 miles south of the old G.E. plants. As a result, Mr. Spitzer asserts, economic activity has suffered. His suit seeks to force G.E. to pay the extra costs of dredging the PCB's, a sum that could be at least $10 million. At his news conference, Mr. Spitzer openly invited other communities up and down the Hudson to bring similar actions if his strategy turns out to be successful. His hope is to achieve what one of his associates called a "critical mass" of lawsuits that will force G.E. to undertake widespread dredging, whatever the outcome of the E.P.A. investigation.
G.E., which called the suit absurd, was not alone in questioning Mr. Spitzer's approach. There was much confusion over whether the canal actually needed dredging, with the New York State Canal Corporation saying no and several local officials saying yes. The Canal Corporation, a division of the state Thruway Authority, controls 524 miles of canals. It would presumably have to put up part of the money if a judge rules in favor of dredging the canal.
Meanwhile, John Cahill, Gov. George Pataki's environmental chief, warned that the depositions and other requirements associated with the suit would siphon valuable resources from the environmental agency's study and from a state investigation. The Pataki camp, unduly sensitive to any challenge to the governor's claim to be the state's top environmentalist, is clearly annoyed by Mr. Spitzer's intervention. Compared with the E.P.A.'s investigation of health and ecological damage along the entire river, Mr. Spitzer's suit seems too narrow to get the job done. But the war to rid the Hudson of PCB's is an important one, and Mr. Spitzer has every right to join it.

HEADLINE: Congress on Record Course for 'Pork,' With Alaska in a Class of Its Own

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
It was a throw-away line on NBC's "West Wing," biting in its indictment of an inventive, sometimes outlandish bid by Congress to spend taxpayer money. There, amid a list of appropriations requests recited by a fictional White House aide, was a gem: $2 million to monitor Alaskan skies for volcanic ash.
"There are volcanos in Alaska?" a "West Wing" aide asked, smirking. 
 Cue laughter and eye-rolling.
But in the chandelier-studded offices of Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, who as chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee controls billions of dollars, the joke was not funny. That is because the item was not a made-up bit of drama, something writers of the series knew when they used it. It was a genuine Stevens request and a sparkling example of the senator's mastery at steering copious amounts of money to his home state.
In fact, Mr. Stevens has gotten so good at sending taxpayers' money Alaska's way that he is threatening to outdo even the legendary Senator Robert C. Byrd in that department, a man whose name adorns many a highway and building in his home state, West Virginia.
"They laughed hysterically about that: $2 million to track volcanic ash in Alaska," said Connie Godwin, Senator Stevens' press secretary. "They would be lucky about the $2 million if they were on that KLM plane 10 years ago that dropped thousands of feet because of the ash it sucked in."
Bolstered by a fat economy and a budget surplus, this year promises to set new records in Congress when it comes to funneling taxpayer money to projects like counting walruses and fixing Y.M.C.A. swimming pools. Detractors call it pork, but those who benefit call it filet mignon.
"This is the greatest pork barbecue of all time, and unfortunately, at this barbecue, it's the taxpayers who are getting cooked," said Jim Campi, a spokesman for Citizens Against Government Waste, an organization dedicated to eliminating pork, or the billions of dollars routed to projects back home that are not requested by the White House or reviewed by a Congressional committee. The organizations will be busy tallying all the special projects in all the final spending bills over the weeks to come, but right now, Congress is primed to surpass last year's numbers easily, Mr. Campi said.
So far, the pork estimate in 7 of the 13 spending bills for the 2000 fiscal year is $14.65 billion, Mr. Campi said, while the record for pet projects, set in 1997, was a total of $14.5 billion. And this under a Republican regime devoted to less government.
For Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who is seeking the presidential nomination and has made pork-busting a mission, this increase in pet projects ranks among his greatest disappointments. He calls it an evil linked to special-interest groups. "I can't judge the projects on their merits," Mr. McCain said. "I can judge the fact that the entire legislative process has been turned on its head."
In the tussle for pet-project money, known as earmarks, few lawmakers hold greater sway than the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, the panel that divides billions of dollars to keep the military churning, farmers afloat, research institutions financed and highways built.
For Mr. Stevens, the 76-year-old veteran of three decades in the Senate, what is remarkable is not so much that he carves out millions of dollars for projects in his state, with the help of the other two members of the Alaskan delegation, Senator Frank H. Murkowski and Representative Don Young, who are also Republicans. It is that he manages to do so despite the fact that his home state has about the same number of people as Milwaukee, 614,000.
In some places in rural Alaska, townspeople are so appreciative that they call the dollars "Stevens money."
"He has been able to master the art of putting his state first in line, even though it was the last to join the union," said Marshall Wittmann, director of Congressional relations for the conservative research group, the Heritage Foundation. "This was the art of Byrd: take an underpopulated rural state and just pour in millions upon millions of federal money."
Mr. Wittmann added, "The joke was that the federal government was going to move to Martinsburg, West Virginia, and now there is a danger it will move to Anchorage."
Last year, Alaska received more money through earmarks per person -- $273 -- than any other state, according to Citizens Against Government Waste. Hawaii came in second, at $155. The national average was $19. Mississippi led in earmarked money in 1998, thanks to the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott.
This coming year could be a tossup between the two states, considering the $375 million that Mr. Lott wrangled to begin building a $1.5 billion Navy ship that the Pentagon never requested.
Senator McCain said Mr. Stevens was gung-ho about pet projects "because he feels that Alaska has never been given the equal consideration that other states have been given."
As for Alaska, it will find itself with a bevy of new projects in the new year, with some already signed into law, and others waiting in the wings pending Senate approval.
There is, for example, $900,000 for an airport on St. George's Island, a speck of a place off Alaska's coast. There is $2.5 million to train Russian and other foreign workers in oil field management in Alaska, $7.9 million to build the Alaska Maritime National Wildlife Refuge and visitor center in Homer, $2.2 million for a senior citizens center in Anchorage and $15 million for the University of Alaska to study the aurora borealis, a perennial pet project of Mr. Stevens.
Military bases in Alaska also benefit. There is $9.5 million to fix a highway at the Elmendorf Air Force Base, $12 million to refurbish the barracks at Fort Richardson and another $13 million to build a parking ramp for a C-130 there.
Sea life, too, would be well tended. There is $100,000 to conduct a census of Pacific walruses, $4 million to help stranded sea lions and $5 million to monitor fish.
Protecting fish and its fishermen ranks high on the list, with millions of dollars earmarked for projects related to salmon, including $900,000 to the Bering Sea Fisherman's Association, which is so well cared for that it does not even have to demand money for its struggling fishermen.
"Senator Stevens, God bless him," said Jude Henzler, the executive director of the association, based in Anchorage. "He's been a godsend to the fisherman in general. You can't lard it on too thick."
One amazing feat of Senator Stevens' is a request for $22 million in emergency financing over a three-year period for four tiny towns in southeast Alaska that were hard hit by restrictions on tree cutting.
But in the spirit of "one person's pork being another's prime cut," as Mr. Wittmann, of the Heritage Foundation, put it, the money has gone, and will go, a long way to helping these communities stay alive. And this, Mr. Stevens' press secretary said, is the unspoken value of pork, which the senator believes is categorized much too broadly.
"If it wasn't for Senator Stevens, we'd be in a lot of trouble for sure," said Stan Filler, the mayor of Sitka, a southeastern Alaska town of 8,000 people that suffered from the timber industry's decline. Sitka would receive $4 million over three years to set up new businesses and repair roads and buildings. "For a lot of years, we didn't get anything, flat nothing," Mr. Filler said. "It wasn't like we were even here."

HEADLINE: On Budget, Everything in Moderation

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
For all of the partisanship and intense wrangling of the past 10 days, the budget agreement between President Clinton and the Republican-run Congress ended up being most remarkable for its moderation.
Despite the temptations posed by an era of federal surpluses, the package approved by the House tonight contains no expansive new spending programs, such as President Clinton's proposal for a new Medicare prescription drug benefit. Nor does it include the $792 billion tax cut over 10 years that the Republicans tried to push through, only to be stopped by Mr. Clinton's veto. 
 In fact, the struggle over spending for the 2000 fiscal year showed that both an impeached president and House Republicans, reduced to a razor-thin majority, proved remarkably resilient. The outcome came about because each side, in effect, fought the other to a draw. As a result, both sides could take credit today for a spending agreement that will take another step toward paying down the national debt.
And the most far-reaching effect of this year's budget struggle may well be a consensus that has emerged through two years of political combat that Social Security payroll taxes should no longer be used to pay for other government programs.
President Clinton first used the "save Social Security first" refrain in 1998 to stop Republican tax cuts. But this year, with the size of the surpluses growing almost monthly, Mr. Clinton softened his stance to allow for new spending. He said that 63 percent of the total budget surplus over 15 years should be used for Social Security with the rest going to other programs.
That was when the Republicans decided to trump Mr. Clinton and call for the entire Social Security reserve to be protected. Many Republicans said this week that their pledge had created a powerful new political weapon to contain federal spending in a time of surplus.
"The big thing was when it was obvious that we stopped the raid on Social Security, we set a parameter that was impenetrable," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader.
Indeed, the idea of leaving Social Security revenue untouched has now become so widely embraced that some version of it is recited by presidential candidates across the political spectrum, from Gov. George W. Bush of Texas to former Senator Bill Bradley.
Senator Tom Daschle, a South Dakota Democrat, said, "I think it's going to be very difficult for either party to go back at any time in the future and acknowledge that they are using the Social Security trust funds."
This idea could come back to haunt the Republicans as much as the Democrats -- constraining tax cutting as well as spending. "We checkmated each other," said a senior Democratic staff member. "We said 'save the surplus to stop tax cuts.' They used it to stop spending programs. So it came out as a draw."
The Republican focus on Social Security, which has long been an issue that Democrats wielded against Republicans -- was part of a fundamental shift in tactics by the brash conservatives who swept to control of Congress in 1994 on a pledge to reduce the scope of government. It came in fits and starts across the year.
The Republicans began the year pledging fiscal restraint but then blew past the spending limits set in the 1997 balanced budget law by more than $30 billion. They approved a $792 billion tax cut but failed to generate much public enthusiasm for it. So instead of fighting after Mr. Clinton vetoed the tax cut, Republican leaders made a pragmatic decision to adjust to the limits of divided government and to the mood of an electorate that is no longer dominated by the angry and economically pressed voters who swept them into office.
They borrowed, and sightly retooled, historical Democratic campaign themes. They promoted education spending. They put more money into the military and certain health programs than even Mr. Clinton had asked for. They struck compromise after compromise with the president, thus moving more in line with a time when their preferred presidential candidate is running as a "compassionate conservative."
"We've kept the bulls-eye off our forehead, unlike the last four years," said Representative John A. Boehner, an Ohio Republican.
And oddly enough, after years of cacophony, the Republicans found a unifying theme in Social Security.
Almost daily, Republicans pledge to keep the money brought in from the Social Security payroll tax from being used to pay for other government programs -- even though Democrats wield studies from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office that the Republican spending bills are full of gimmicks and actually risk eating into the Social Security reserve by $17 billion.
The theme helped Republican leaders rally the party's moderates, who want to pay down the national debt, and its conservatives, who believe that the refrain has created a powerful new political firewall that will prevent both parties from increasing the size of government now that deficits are no longer forcing reductions in spending. Of the projected $3 trillion surplus across the next decade, $2 trillion of the money would be in Social Security revenue.
"It's a moment that's dripping with irony," said Marshall Wittmann, director of Congressional relations for the conservative research group the Heritage Foundation. "We've reached the fourth year of the Republican revolution and they are laying their political future on defending the cornerstone of the welfare state."
He added, "If you ask Republicans what time it is, they say 'save Social Security.' If you ask what the weather is they say, 'save Social Security.' It's a kind of unity they haven't had since they took over."
Whether Republicans can really benefit politically from the Social Security issue in next year's elections is another question. Among the public at large, polls show voters still trust Democrats far more than Republicans when it comes to issues relating to the retirement fund.
Irritated by Republican commercials accusing Democrats of wanting to raid Social Security, House Democrats today continued to showcase all the accounting gimmicks the Republicans used to hide the true levels of spending they approved.
Still each side could point to victories. Mr. Clinton received money to pay for his signature programs to hire 100,000 more teachers and 50,000 more community police officers. He secured money to pay the country's back dues to the United Nations and finance the Wye River Mideast peace accord. And the White House fought off provisions on mining and oil drilling that it had opposed as threats to the environment.
Republicans got a foothold for their efforts to loosen federal restrictions on how education money can be used. They put in place language to limit federal financing of groups that promote abortion rights overseas. They prevailed in increasing military spending even more than Mr. Clinton wanted. And they won a largely symbolic across-the-board spending cut.
"If this were a football game, the score would be pretty close to a tie," said Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican. "This is a deal where no one got a scalp, but everyone came back from the hunt with something to brag about."

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE;
EUROPEAN RATES ARE UNCHANGED

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The European Central Bank left its interest rates unchanged, two days after the United States Federal Reserve nudged up a key rate. The European Central Bank, which sets monetary policy for the 11 nations that use the euro, had raised its interest rates two weeks ago and indicated at the time that no further rise was planned soon. The decision to keep interest rates steady came at a regular meeting of the central bank's governing council. The bank governors issued no statement. The European Central Bank left its main lending rate at 3 percent for loans to banks. It raised that rate from 2.5 percent on Nov. 4.

HEADLINE: FINAL BUDGET BILL IS PASSED BY HOUSE IN BIPARTISAN VOTE

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
United by a desire to proclaim victory and leave town, Republicans and Democrats in the House joined tonight to pass the final budget bill, seven weeks after the fiscal year began.
Congress then passed a resolution that will continue government operations for two more weeks while the Senate finished its work. 
 The House voted 296 to 135 for a package of five spending bills containing $385 billion, sending the measure to the Senate. There, an avalanche of oratory from three Senate Democrats seeking benefits for their states blocked the bill's path and briefly threatened a government shutdown, a threat that evaporated when the Senate extended the budget deadline until Dec. 2.
Moments after the House passed a new budget resolution, the Senate did the same. A short time later, the White House chief of staff, John D. Podesta, carrying the resolution, left for Athens so President Clinton could sign it.
After the earlier House vote on the omnibus spending bill, in which 170 Republicans were joined by 125 Democrats and one independent supporting the bill, both parties claimed victory in nearly identical language.
After seven months of haggling over 13 spending bills, and after 10 days of negotiations between the White House and the Republican leaders in Congress, both sides said the result represented the essence of compromise.
Mr. Clinton called it "a hard-won victory for the American people."
And the speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert, said Congress had "basically turned the corner on how this town does business" by limiting spending in a booming economy, allowing the government to pay down part of its $3.6 trillion debt.
The Republicans won a $17 billion spending increase for the Pentagon, along with more money for politically popular health research and education. They said they kept their promise to refrain from using excess contributions to Social Security to pay for the spending bills.
The Democrats and the White House were able to assert that they had won the money for hiring more primary school teachers and police officers, underwriting Middle East peace agreements and finally paying $351 million of the $926 million withheld by Congress in dues the United States owes the United Nations.
Both sides agreed to provide $12.8 billion over five years to teaching hospitals, nursing homes and other health care providers who were suffering financially from cuts in Medicare imposed by Congress in 1997.
The 84 Republicans voting no were protesting spending increases won by the White House for programs like foreign aid and environmental projects.
The 51 Democrats who voted no, a quarter of their party in the House, split with the president over the compromises the White House made in its final negotiations with the Republicans. Some rebelled over restrictions Republicans sought on aid to international family planning groups in exchange for freeing up the back dues owed the United Nations.
Mr. Clinton agreed to a ban on using such aid to promote abortions to free $351 million of the money that the United States owes the United Nations. He can waive the restrictions, but then $12.5 million in federal grants to women's health groups would be shifted to a children's fund.
Angry at this trade-off, 19 House Democrats who are women demanded that the White House make amends. Steve Ricchetti, a deputy White House chief of staff, told them today that the administration would ask Congress next year for more than $500 million in grants for the groups.
Other Democrats protested what they called bookkeeping tricks that allowed Republicans to say they had protected Social Security surpluses. The Congressional Budget Office says the bills dip into at least $17 billion of the retirement reserves.
The final deal, agreed to early this morning, included some of this sort of sleight of hand, such as delaying the last payday of next September for Pentagon personnel and some civilian government employees so it falls in the next fiscal year. That saves no money, but eliminates expenditures in the 2000 fiscal year.
But the Senate was not ready to pass the bill, with three Democratic senators threatening to hold it hostage.
Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, threatened to hold back the continuing resolution over a law, stripped from the final spending package, that would have required satellite television companies to carry local stations in rural regions. When the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, promised him the Senate would take up such a measure by April, he relented.
Then Senator Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin, rose. He had threatened to block any bill, including a resolution and the final budget package, over language in the spending bills that he said favored dairy farmers in the East and hurt his state's milk producers.
"One of the options we have is to vote against a continuing resolution, which would in effect shut down the government at midnight, which is something I have considered," Mr. Kohl said. "It's not a step that I'm going to take."
The maneuvering was necessary because Congress was operating under a resolution that kept the agencies covered by the spending bills running for 24 hours without a real budget. But the passage of a resolution keeping the agencies going until Dec. 2 alleviated that problem.
The Senate will soon take up the final budget package, which includes these five separate bills:
*One bill includes $315 billion measure for the Departments of Health and Human Services, Labor and Education. Of that sum, $229 billion is for mandatory programs that Congress must finance, like Medicare and Medicaid. The rest, $86 billion, is medical research, special education and job training.
*A measure for the Commerce, Justice and State Departments totals $39 million.
*Two $15 billion bills were included in the package, one for the Interior Department, one for foreign aid.
*A $429 million bill for the District of Columbia included a $576 million emergency measure for the flood victims of Hurricane Floyd.
But the budget battle is not over.
Tonight, Robert Byrd of West Virginia, dean of Senate Democrats, took the floor with amendment, seeking to protect his state's coal miners from a court ruling ordering them to stop dumping waste from mountaintop mines into valley streams.
He wanted to attach his amendment, which the White House has opposed, to any legislation he could.
"We're being impeded and we're being wronged by the White House," Mr. Byrd said. "This is the time to head off the dragon. Beat it back! Take up the sword that I offer! Take this sword!"
While Mr. Podesta was flying to Athens with the resolution, Mr. Byrd's amendment passed on a vote of 56 to 33. That vote attached his amendment to a completely different resolution.
The Senate intended to send it to a legislative graveyard.
Mr. Lott, in an effort to grind down opponents to the budget bill, said the Senate would take it up again at 1 a.m. on Saturday.

HEADLINE: Ex-Official Is Charged With Assault

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU 

 BODY:
A former New York City health official was charged yesterday in United States District Court in Brooklyn with assaulting and intimidating Trans World Airlines crew members last year after detonating stink bombs on a flight taking off in New York and one departing from Paris.
The former official, Victor E. Botnick, 45, set off a stink bomb on T.W.A. Flight 925 during takeoff from Charles De Gaulle Airport on Aug. 1, 1998, according to court papers. The searing fumes made crew members and passengers teary-eyed, forcing the plane to return to the gate. 
 Eight days later, court papers said, Mr. Botnick set off another stink bomb as T.W.A. Flight 924 took off from Kennedy International Airport. This time, two crew members checked beneath Mr. Botnick's seat and found glass shards and a wet area reeking of burning rubber, according to the papers.
The court papers said that Mr. Botnick, a frequent flier on T.W.A., became angry after the airline inadvertently canceled his family's reservations on a flight to Israel to celebrate his son's bar mitzvah in December 1997.
Mr. Botnick, a Yonkers resident, was released yesterday on $150,000 bond. Federal Magistrate Roanne L. Mann instructed Mr. Botnick to stay away from airports and airplanes unless he received specific approval from the court.
Mr. Botnick, who was accompanied by his wife, Lee, glared at reporters as he left the courtroom and said "no comment" to questions. When a reporter tried to follow him, he turned around and said "Did you understand? No comment."
In the 1980's, Mr. Botnick served as a special assistant and confidant to Mayor Edward I. Koch. He resigned as the head of the municipal hospital system in 1986 after admitting that he had falsely claimed to be a college graduate.
Gina L. Mendola, Mr. Botnick's lawyer, said the charges against him were "trumped up" to support a separate federal investigation in New Jersey. "There is not a great deal of evidence against my client," she said in court. She declined to comment further.
Cynthia M. Monaco, the assistant United States attorney who is handling the case against Mr. Botnick in Brooklyn, confirmed that he was being investigated by the United States attorney's office in New Jersey on a separate matter, but denied that there was any connection. Michael Drewniak, a spokesman for the United States attorney's office in New Jersey, said there were no charges against Mr. Botnick at this time, but declined to comment further.
Magistrate Mann has allowed Mr. Botnick, who is unemployed, to drive or take the train to New Jersey to meet with federal investigators, as well as to Connecticut, Washington and Maryland to consult with lawyers and look for jobs. Mr. Botnick turned in his passport to court officials.
At yesterday's hearing, Ms. Monaco requested that Mr. Botnick undergo a psychiatric evaluation. The court denied the request after Mr. Botnick's lawyer objected, but ordered him to continue psychiatric counseling with his own doctor. Mr. Botnick, who never removed his red-and-black ski jacket, nodded as he stood quietly with his hands clasped in front.

HEADLINE: Bronx School Will Expand But Phase Out Poorer Area

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
After months of heated debate, a Bronx school board overwhelmingly approved a plan last night to expand Middle School 141 in the affluent neighborhood of Riverdale but narrow the school's attendance zone to phase out students from the nearby, poorer Marble Hill neighborhood.
Under the zoning change, which the school board approved in a 7-to-2 vote, children from Marble Hill will attend a new middle school, M.S. 368, to be built closer to their neighborhood. The plan has come under attack, partly because the school is to be built on a site where environmental studies have found contaminated soil. The planned site is adjacent to an elementary school where tests showed elevated lead levels earlier this month, escalating the controversy. 
 Some Marble Hill parents have complained that the plan is an elitist scheme to keep poor and minority children out of the school in Riverdale, a mostly white community. But proponents say that M.S. 141 will become more racially diverse under the plan, which will convert it into a rigorous academy for grades 6 through 12.
At a time when the city school system is struggling to retain middle-class students, the conflict in Riverdale underscores how difficult such efforts can be. While opponents say the plan smacks of racial and economic prejudice, supporters say it is the last hope of maintaining at least some diversity in the Riverdale schools.
They point out that the plan would simply be reinstituting the attendance zone that M.S. 141 had before 1992, when a previous board voted to expand its zone and bus students into Riverdale from Marble Hill. The school has lost more than half its white population since then, they say.
The student body at M.S. 141 is now about 16 percent white. But G. Oliver Koppell, the school board president, predicts the number will grow to 30 percent to 40 percent once M.S. 141 is converted to a combination middle school and high school with a more challenging curriculum.
The protest has mostly focused on the rezoning issue, but in recent weeks, opponents have focused more on whether the site for the planned school for Marble Hill students is environmentally safe. At a public hearing on Tuesday and at last night's meeting, many parents voiced concern about the recent elevated lead levels at P.S. 37, which is next to the site for the planned school, M.S. 368, on Tibbett Avenue in Kingsbridge.
The opponents have also raised questions about an ambulance garage that the city is building near the site, and in particular about a 2,000-gallon diesel tank that will be on the garage property. In addition to at least a dozen parents, Dr. John Rosen, a pediatrics professor at Montefiore Medical Center who specializes in environmental medicine, urged the school board to conduct further tests on the site.
"I would consider this an absolute necessity from an environmental safety and public health standpoint," he said.
But Bernard Orlan, director of environmental health and safety for the Board of Education's Division of School Facilities, said yesterday that any soil with unacceptably high levels of chemicals would be removed before construction. He said the nearby diesel tank would not pose a threat because it would be closely monitored.
"Based on all the results so far, it appears there are some areas of the site that need to be cleaned up," Mr. Orlan said. "But we haven't seen anything that would be fatal to the project."
Residents of Riverdale and Marble Hill have been fighting about the plan since it was proposed in 1997 as a way to ease overcrowding and bring back quality neighborhood schooling in District 10. The district is the city's largest, with more than 40,000 students.
The previous board, which was mostly black and Hispanic, rejected the plan last winter. That prompted Riverdale residents to flock to the polls during the May school board elections and vote in a seven-member slate that campaigned on the promise of pushing through the plan. The slate was led by Mr. Koppell, a longtime resident of Riverdale and a former State Attorney General. Only two members of the previous board remained in office, and both -- Charles Williams, who is black, and Myrna Calderon, who is Hispanic -- voted against the plan last night.
Chancellor Rudy Crew signed off on the plan last month, on the condition that all students currently enrolled at the Riverdale school have the option of staying there.
Dr. Crew dedicated $14 million to expand M.S. 141 and $15 million to help build M.S. 368, which is to open in 2001. The Board of Education had already set aside $30 million for the M.S. 368 project.

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Papers Show Struggle to Keep Pace as U.S.S.R. Unraveled

BYLINE: By JAMES RISEN 

DATELINE: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 18

 BODY:
Declassified government documents show that analysts at the Central Intelligence Agency were deeply pessimistic about the chances of success for President Mikhail Gorbachev's efforts to reform the Soviet Union's Communist system even in the final days of the cold war.
C.I.A. experts in the late 1980's and early 1990's came to believe that Mr. Gorbachev was genuinely interested in reform, yet the agency remained concerned that political instability could lead to a return to hard-line Communist rule or anarchy. 
 A decade after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the C.I.A. released 24 intelligence estimates today that show how the agency sought -- sometimes far too cautiously -- to keep up with the incredible pace of events between 1988 and 1991. The declassified reports provide insight into an enduring debate over whether the C.I.A. really "missed" the collapse of the Soviet Union, as critics charge.
The reports were declassified by the agency in conjunction with a conference being held here on the role that American intelligence played in the final days of the cold war.
Clearly, the rapid change in eastern Europe and in the Soviet Union caught the C.I.A. off guard and forced the agency to focus much more on political developments within the Soviet Union than ever before. In 1988, for example, the chief of Soviet analysis at the C.I.A. told Congress that the agency had "never really looked at the Soviet Union as a political entity in which there were factors building which could lead to at least the initiation of political transformation that we seem to see."
Late in 1988, the C.I.A. suggested that Soviet weaknesses gave the West a wedge to achieve "marginal bargaining advantages" in arms control talks, but not to expect true reform.
By April 1989, however, the C.I.A. wrote an analysis that included an unusually large section devoted to dissenting views. The C.I.A. was divided over how significant Mr. Gorbachev's reforms were. Still the report concluded that the Soviet Union would remain an adversary.
C.I.A. analysts worried that Mr. Gorbachev's hold on power was fragile, and were concerned because Moscow still had an enormous military even though its economy was cratering. In September 1989, for example, even as the C.I.A. had become convinced that Mr. Gorbachev was sincere, it still told President Bush that Mr. Gorbachev's chances of remaining in power were "doubtful at best."
By November 1990, even after eastern Europe had gone through a peaceful liberation, a C.I.A. report outlined "nightmare scenarios" that could lead to civil war or chaos in the Soviet Union. The paper stated that "the old Communist order is in its death throes," and that the crisis of perestroika was threatening to "tear the country apart."
That estimate seemed to overstate the extent to which a poor economy was leading to unrest and a breakdown of political authority, a new C.I.A. history noted this week.
In April 1991, the C.I.A. found that "anti-Communist forces are breaking down the Soviet empire and its system of governance," and it laid conditions in which die-hards might move to reassert control "with or without Gorbachev."
Then in July 1991, the agency reported that "the U.S.S.R. is in the midst of a revolution that probably will sweep the Communist Party from power and reshape the country within the five-year time frame of this estimate." The C.I.A. was far too cautious. The next month, the Soviet Union went out of business.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 24, 1999, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about Central Intelligence Agency documents from the end of the cold war misstated the month when the Soviet Union formally dissolved. It was December 1991, not August.

HEADLINE: Minimum Wages, City by City;
As More Local Laws Pass, More Businesses Complain

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
What bothers Henry A. Berber most about the new "living wage" ordinance in Los Angeles is the picketing at his restaurant, La Luz del Dia, during a busy lunch hour. "The way they are dressed," he said, "they give the impression they are my regular customers, very dissatisfied. It hurts me personally."
The pickets are in fact community advocates who pushed for passage of the local law, which increases minimum wages at companies doing business with the city. Because Mr. Berber leases his site in a subsidized tourist zone, the ordinance requires him to pay $8.76 an hour, not the $5.75 that is standard pay for kitchen help here. The reasoning is that all his workers should benefit from the public largess that makes the quaint Olvera Street where his Mexican restaurant is situated so profitable. Mr. Berber has raised his bottom wage, but only to $6.75 an hour, without health insurance -- and the pickets are trying to get him to go the extra distance. 
 "I am moving in the direction of conforming," he said, leaning for emphasis across a huge, cluttered desk that almost filled his small, low-ceilinged office. But to pay the full wage now, he said, would put his restaurant in the red.
Here and elsewhere, a small but increasing number of employers who do business with government are suddenly finding themselves required by local ordinances to grant big raises and benefits to their low-wage workers. Forty cities and counties in 17 states, particularly those with large constituencies of low-wage workers, have enacted such wage laws since the movement began five years ago.
As one follows another, lately at the rate of a new ordinance a month, the movement has begun to broaden from a simple emphasis on higher wages into a wide range of requirements involving health insurance, vacations, sick pay, job security and incentives to unionize.
"You have to look at the living wage movement in the context of the utter failure of federal labor law, now so stacked against workers," said Madeline Janis-Aparicio, director of the Los Angeles Living Wage Coalition. She cited what she said was Washington's failure to raise the national minimum wage to keep pace with the needs of the working poor or to strengthen labor's bargaining power. The coalition, an amalgam of community groups, churches and unions that organized the picketing at Mr. Berber's restaurant, is out to redress the balance.
As the ordinances spread, business opposition and complaints about higher costs and patchwork regulation are on the rise. But the vast majority of affected companies, though often ducking full compliance, have generally lived with the law rather than give up profitable contracts, subsidies and leases on choice city-owned properties like Olvera Street, three studies have found. The early evidence suggests that relatively little of the extra cost has been passed on to the cities or to consumers. Companies are absorbing the higher wages or finding ways to offset them.
"The cost increases for companies in Los Angeles were only 1 to 1.5 percent of their total expenses," said Robert Pollin, an economist at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst who led one of the studies.
The "living wage" movement is an increasingly popular tool for improving the lot of janitors, cleaning people, restaurant and health care workers, security guards, school bus drivers, parking attendants and others who earn less than $8 an hour. That group represents 25.7 percent of the work force, or 28.5 million people.
Yet only a fraction of these workers -- no more than 44,000, according to an analysis by Mr. Pollin, Mark Brenner and Stephanie Luce -- are covered so far by wage ordinances, the largest group being the 9,000 or so in Los Angeles. But more than 50 other cities and counties are considering such bills. One alone, in San Francisco, would nearly double the number of workers covered nationwide if the proposal now before the Board of Supervisors passes.
The ordinances cover the companies that tap the public till through a tax abatement, for example, or a service contract to clean schools or through leases at a city airport; the companies can be cut off if they fail to raise wages. Here in Los Angeles, United Airlines and Delta Air Lines have accepted the ordinance as lessees at the international airport, imposing the new wage -- $8.76 without health insurance, or $7.51 in pay and $1.25 for health insurance -- on the contractors and subcontractors who supply baggage handlers, security screeners, wheelchair attendants and the like. The airlines' own employees generally earn more in wages and benefits than the law requires.
"United resisted the ordinance for a while and could have tied us up in court for a long time," said Isaac Nuru, lead organizer at the airport for the Living Wage Coalition. "But it did the moral thing; it did not want a bad press."
The ordinances have their limits. They are hard to enforce even when city officials audit corporate payrolls, as they do in Los Angeles and one or two other cities. Further, though companies like United and Delta comply with the ordinance at the city-owned airport here, workers employed by contractors at the airlines' other sites in the city are not covered. And companies do not have to comply with the ordinances in most cities until existing contracts and leases are renewed or revised, though some companies do so anyway.
Host Marriott Services did. It runs bars and restaurants at the airport here and has applied for a revision of its lease to expand. Even before submitting the application, the company increased the pay of 700 airport workers to the levels specified in the ordinance, which took effect last January at the airport. And in a bit of horse trading, Ms. Janis-Aparicio's coalition has endorsed Host Marriott's request.
"You monitor every lease that comes up for renewal or revision," she said, "and you go to the company and say, 'We want to work with you.' "
Still, much of American business, once indifferent to a movement that seemed to apply to so few workers, is now fighting the effort more vigorously -- denouncing the laws as an excessive cost for business and a distortion of wages, which should be set in the marketplace, not by government.
"When you raise the wage so much, a lot of the people you are trying to help will lose their jobs," said Thomas R. Larmore, a lawyer in Santa Monica. He heads a Chamber of Commerce committee formed recently to prevent passage of a wage proposal in Santa Monica that would be the first in the country to go beyond companies that benefit directly from city business. The ordinance would apply to an entire commercial district, a two-mile stretch of Pacific coast developed with public funds as a tourist mecca.
Within this zone, which extends three blocks inland from a promenade overlooking the ocean, no company with more than 50 employees would be allowed to pay its workers less than $10.69 an hour. Other provisions, borrowed from the Los Angeles ordinance, include paid vacations, a health insurance requirement and a provision to protect workers against retaliation.
The zone flourishes, the argument goes, because the city spent hundreds of millions of dollars to develop it as a tourist and entertainment center, and limited the number of hotel rooms, to help keep room rates high, often above $300 a night. Low-wage employees, advocates say, should share more of this public bounty, or at least earn a high enough wage to live in Santa Monica. Most commute from poor Los Angeles neighborhoods.
Mr. Larmore says such reasoning is spurious. "It is totally backward to say that business is subsidized by the city," he said. "It is business that is lifting the city," he added, by providing a huge flow of tax revenue that allows the city to provide many services.
A majority on Santa Monica's seven-member City Council, which recently approved a ban on automated teller fees for nonbank customers that has been temporarily set aside by a local court, favors the ordinance. But rather than act now, the council is likely to wait while the wage issue is fought out in next year's election campaign. The Chamber of Commerce is raising money to support candidates who will oppose it.
Wage ordinances have become a goal of such national groups as the Independent Areas Foundation and the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now that seek to bring community groups together in social action campaigns. And with increasing frequency, the ordinances are becoming big issues in local politics.
In San Francisco's Dec. 13 runoff election for mayor, the issue divides Willie Brown, the incumbent, who has been lukewarm about a wage law, and his challenger, Tom Ammiano, president of the Board of Supervisors and chief sponsor of the proposal. It specifies a wage of $11 an hour, surpassing the current national leader, San Jose, where an ordinance requires $9.50 with health insurance and $10.75 without. By comparison, the national minimum wage is $5.15 an hour; adjusted for inflation, that is nearly $3 less than it was in 1968.
"If the bill is watered down too much, say to $9 an hour," Mr. Ammiano said, "and nonprofit organizations are exempted and there is not enough funding for enforcement, then I would advocate taking the proposal to a referendum."
The first such ordinance was enacted in Baltimore, in December 1994, largely through the efforts of a community organization called Build. Last November, Build got thousands of residents in poor neighborhoods to the polls. Most voted for the re-election of Gov. Parris N. Glendening of Maryland, who is increasingly using the city's ordinance as a model for contracts that the state makes with private companies.
Here in Los Angeles, Mayor Richard J. Riordan tried to block the measure, but his veto was overridden by the City Council. "I believe employers should be aware that employees who earn under $10 an hour cannot lead an independent life," he said. "But I do not believe that government should dictate wages. We have seen this fail in Socialist and Communist countries. It will do irreparable harm."
Mayor Riordan said, however, that he agreed with supporters of the wage ordinance that income inequality had increased in part because of the decline in union bargaining power. Several ordinances try to reverse that trend through an "opt out" loophole that lets companies partly off the hook if they agree to let their workers organize.
Half of Mr. Berber's 28 employees, for example, have signed a petition seeking union recognition. If he granted recognition voluntarily, the opt out clause would allow him to negotiate a labor agreement that permits pay and benefit levels below the city's mandated wage, at least temporarily. But he would be locked into a union -- a central goal of Ms. Janis-Aparicio's coalition.
"Whenever you rely on legislation solely, the gains can be lost," she said, noting that the Los Angeles City Council's current pro-labor bent could disappear in a future election. "So we need to build union agreements that have community support and will last."
While running a refugee center here, Ms. Janis-Aparicio, 39, was recruited into her present line of work in 1993 by Miguel Contreras, now the powerful executive secretary-treasurer of the Los Angeles County Federation of Labor.
Mr. Contreras, who had worked with Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers, was mindful of the public support -- the consumer grape boycott -- that had brought such success to the farm workers. So he asked Ms. Janis-Aparicio to set up a nonprofit organization that could foster similar community support for labor. She founded the Los Angeles Alliance for a New Economy, which operates with a $1 million annual budget and 18 salaried staff members. The wage issue soon became the central cause.
"This question of job inequities in the public sector, if we address it as a union, people say we are self-serving," Mr. Contreras said. "But if it has the cloak of religious leaders and community activists, then it becomes a community issue."
 
New York Law Covers 1,400
New York was one of the first cities to adopt a "living wage" ordinance. Overriding a veto by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the City Council enacted a law on Sept. 11, 1996, that was narrow in scope and has never been expanded.
About 1,400 people are covered. They are employees of companies that have contracted with the city to supply security guards, food service employees, cleaning workers and temporaries. A "trend toward paying low wages" appears to be "most egregious" in these four areas, the ordinance declares.
But rather than fix a uniform minimum, the ordinance requires the city comptroller to determine the prevailing wage for each class of workers. The wages today for most of these workers fall between $7.50 and $12 an hour.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2147 words

HEADLINE: Minimum Wages, City by City;
As More Local Laws Pass, More Businesses Complain

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
What bothers Henry A. Berber most about the new "living wage" ordinance in Los Angeles is the picketing at his restaurant, La Luz del Dia, during a busy lunch hour. "The way they are dressed," he said, "they give the impression they are my regular customers, very dissatisfied. It hurts me personally."
The pickets are in fact community advocates who pushed for passage of the local law, which increases minimum wages at companies doing business with the city. Because Mr. Berber leases his site in a subsidized tourist zone, the ordinance requires him to pay $8.76 an hour, not the $5.75 that is standard pay for kitchen help here. The reasoning is that all his workers should benefit from the public largess that makes the quaint Olvera Street where his Mexican restaurant is situated so profitable. Mr. Berber has raised his bottom wage, but only to $6.75 an hour, without health insurance -- and the pickets are trying to get him to go the extra distance. 
 "I am moving in the direction of conforming," he said, leaning for emphasis across a huge, cluttered desk that almost filled his small, low-ceilinged office. But to pay the full wage now, he said, would put his restaurant in the red.
Here and elsewhere, a small but increasing number of employers who do business with government are suddenly finding themselves required by local ordinances to grant big raises and benefits to their low-wage workers. Forty cities and counties in 17 states, particularly those with large constituencies of low-wage workers, have enacted such wage laws since the movement began five years ago.
As one follows another, lately at the rate of a new ordinance a month, the movement has begun to broaden from a simple emphasis on higher wages into a wide range of requirements involving health insurance, vacations, sick pay, job security and incentives to unionize.
"You have to look at the living wage movement in the context of the utter failure of federal labor law, now so stacked against workers," said Madeline Janis-Aparicio, director of the Los Angeles Living Wage Coalition. She cited what she said was Washington's failure to raise the national minimum wage to keep pace with the needs of the working poor or to strengthen labor's bargaining power. The coalition, an amalgam of community groups, churches and unions that organized the picketing at Mr. Berber's restaurant, is out to redress the balance.
As the ordinances spread, business opposition and complaints about higher costs and patchwork regulation are on the rise. SECTION: Section B; Page 11; Column 5; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 770 words

HEADLINE: THINK TANK;
A Saintly Jew Whose Spirituality Rejected Jews

BYLINE: By Paul Lewis 

 BODY:
As a brilliant but radical philosophy student in Paris in the late 1920's, she was nicknamed the Red Virgin and the Categorical Imperative in Skirts.
But today Simone Weil is remembered mainly as a French Jew who used her stunningly original intelligence to denigrate the Jews on the eve of World War II and espouse a mystical Christianity of her own invention. 
 Last week French and American scholars gathered at Columbia University for a conference to discuss her writings and her odd combination of beliefs.
Why is there such interest in this young Frenchwoman with such repugnant views on Jews? A woman who joined General de Gaulle's Free French in London before dying in 1943 at the age of 34 from tuberculosis aggravated by self-imposed starvation? (She was trying to share the hardships of the occupation.) Even her admirers speak of her as a kind of mad virtuoso.
T. S. Eliot called her genius "akin to that of the saints," while Albert Camus spoke of her "madness for truth." At the conference, Sylvere Lotringer, a professor of French literature at Columbia, called Weil "one of the great minds of the 1930's and 40's, pushing her ideas to the limit without pity for anyone, in a kind of delirium."
As a young teacher, Weil worked on behalf of the unemployed and dreamed of restoring dignity to manual labor. She joined the Republican forces in the Spanish Civil War, compared Hitler to Julius Caesar and encouraged de Gaulle to unify the French resistance by creating a National Council of the Resistance. Later, she advised de Gaulle to ban political parties in France once the war ended because their lust for power encouraged totalitarianism.
Weil wanted to found an elite nursing group to tend wounded soldiers at the front. Only months before her death, she begged to be parachuted into occupied France on a secret mission -- "preferably a dangerous one."
Not surprisingly, however, the conference was dominated by Weil's hostility toward Judaism. She died before the horrors of the Holocaust became known, but in general she saw the Israelites of the Old Testament as cruel imperialists and their God as vengeful and violent. The lives of the patriarchs were "sullied with atrocities," she said, while the prohibition against idolatry encouraged "the chosen people" to self-worship.
"I am paralyzed by the thought that I am accused of descending from people who could not find anything better to give humanity than Jehovah," Weil wrote. Christianity, she believed, sprang from the spirituality and grace of ancient Greece but had been subverted by imperial Rome, which turned it into a centralized, dominering religion in its own image. She was never baptized, nor did she join any Christian church.
As a paraphrase of Weil's view, Jeffrey Mehlman of Boston University said: "Rome, the incarnation of imperial statism, ripped Christianity from the spiritual fabric that sustained it and reinterpreted it spuriously as the heir of the this-worldly religion of Israel and its God of vengeance."
Some scholars at the conference felt Weil viewed Hellenic civilization through rosy spectacles. She explained away the destruction of Troy, for example, by saying the Greeks never gloried in it as the Romans did in their anihilation of Carthage.
For Page duBois, a classicist from the University of California at San Diego, Weil's sense of the purity of ancient Greece was based on "selective reading" that omitted "the sex and drinking."
Still, there was no agreement on Weil's attitude toward fellow Jews or the effect of her thinking on contemporary anti-Semitism. Michael Stanislawski, a professor of Jewish history at Columbia, called her an anti-Semite whose views were an "unpardonable perfidy" to some.
Sylvie Courtine-Denamy, a French philosopher, pointed out that under the collaborationist Vichy regime of Marshal Petain, Weil proposed limiting Jewish entry into the French civil service and sought to encourage Jewish assimilation and mixed marriages.
But Mr. Lotringer defended Weil, arguing that assimilation was a way of shielding France's Jews from persecution by eliminating them as a separate minority.
The mystical nature of her Christianity led her to welcome suffering -- which she called "affliction" -- believing it brought the soul closer to God. This, several speakers suggested, may have diminished her sympathy for Jewish suffering in occupied France.
Her attitude toward Judaism seems rooted in a conviction that the ancient Israelites were aggressive and cruel. This caused her to battle oppression -- except, it seems, against her own people.

HEADLINE: Low Wages Are Relative

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Serfs of the Service Economy" (Op-Ed, Nov. 16): 
 Bruce Raynor overlooks that many low-paid service positions in the United States pay significantly more than unskilled work in underdeveloped nations. I am a lawyer and some of my clients are immigrants from impoverished countries, where they often were agricultural workers. While none perceive that a $7 per hour job here is a godsend, most see the many opportunities here for their children and them, and many feel quite privileged simply to be in the United States.
Low-paid service jobs can be deemed "exploitation" in relation to professional jobs, and working conditions should be improved, but it must be remembered that the economic situation in much of the rest of the world is far beneath that found here.
WILLIAM J. VOLONTE
Hoboken, N.J., Nov. 17, 1999
