HEADLINE: Is This the End of the Story for Books?

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
First the scroll, then the codex and the Gutenberg Bible. And now the electronic book? Almost nothing causes more anxiety in the publishing world than the idea that books as we know them might one day be replaced by electronic or e-books. Will paper books, with their distinctive smell and touch, the special, almost trancelike intimacy they can engender between writer and reader, vanish forever? And if so, what will the experience of reading be like in the 21st century?
Books will still be around, many scholars say, but we may read in a different way. Only a handful of e-books -- portable devices with screens designed just for reading -- are available today. Among those already on the market are the SoftBook, which sells for around $300 and a commitment of $19.99 a month to buy material for it, and NuvoMedia's Rocket eBook, advertised at $199. Within six months, Microsoft plans to begin shipping the Reader, a new program designed to make the text on a computer screen look as it does in real books. Unlike the current crop of e-books, Microsoft's Reader is not a separate device; it is software designed for use on someone's home or laptop computer. The Reader will be available as a free-standing program for use with Windows. By giving the program away or selling it at low cost, Microsoft says, it will stimulate the manufacture of more e-book devices that the company hopes will eventually all use the Reader. 
 But is the act of reading something that needs improving? Analysts say that existing e-books are selling poorly because consumers are satisfied with the old-fashioned reading experience. "People aren't interested," said Tom Rhinelander, who analyzes the electronic book market for Forrester Research Inc., a Cambridge, Mass., concern that studies computer use. "The market went nowhere in a year. The fundamental reason is that people who read books don't have a problem with books today."
 "The main issue is that if it's not broken, don't replace it," Mr. Rhinelander said.
Regular books have clearer typefaces than computers, and they are lighter. And e-books have batteries that make them hot. "If you're a consumer, how would you consume this?" Mr. Rhinelander asked. "You would buy a $300 device and download it and relearn how to read. If you're a book lover, you're not putting them in a bookcase and giving them to friends."
Even the architect of Microsoft's new Reader program, Bill Hill, admits: "People do not like to read on the screen." He added, "It's horrible."
Consider that some studies have shown that the average person reads no more than three to five paragraphs of text on a computer screen before pressing the print button.
At its best, reading results in a change of consciousness, a total immersion. Indeed, researchers have documented that during periods of total absorption in reading, there are changes in respiration and heartbeat. Computers, with their heft and weight, their lighted screens and distracting icons, interfere with that experience.
But a new generation of readers weaned on computers, habituated to receiving information in short takes, may not find it difficult to acclimatize to e-books.
Robert Darnton, a professor of history at Princeton University who has championed electronic publishing for scholarly dissertations, said, "I think it's only a matter of time before we can have mechanical devices that will make possible a satisfactory but new experience of reading."
But he conceded: "One thing that seems to be missing is paper, the feel of a book when you hold it, its grain, its texture, its elasticity, its whiteness. The sensation of paper is bound up in the experience of reading. We have a long-term kinetic memory of paper. How will we substitute a new medium for it or improve on it?"
Mr. Hill said he drew on histories of reading and studies of its psychology and physiology in developing Microsoft's Reader. "The book today is at the apex of millions of years of evolution," Mr. Hill said. "It goes back beyond the printed word and tablets of stone."
Initially, people read on tablets or scrolls without punctuation or spacing between the words. Reading was a communal experience, with texts mostly being read aloud. In the third or fourth century A.D. came the codex, pages bound at the inner margins, which made reading easier because the reader could thumb through the text. The codex formed the prototype for the modern book. Two pages, side by side, also made it easier for the eye to flow across the text, as did adding page numbers. As with nearly every new development in reading, the appearance of the codex brought about social change and facilitated the spread of Christianity, which was a religion of the Book.
In the Middle Ages, punctuation and word separation came into use. Possibly some time in the early Middle Ages, reading became a private experience rather than the communal one of reading aloud.
Gutenberg's printing press and the advent of movable type in the 15th century paved the way for the Reformation, which was a reaffirmation of Christianity as a religion of the Book, with a Protestant translation of the Bible required in every church in England.
After the Reformation, the Enlightenment spread through Europe by means of the printed word, books and pamphlets, resulting in "a secularized world in which print culture is fundamental," said Mr. Darnton of Princeton.
Of primary importance in the history of the book is the evolution of typefaces. Books are usually printed in serif type. In this face, each letter has at least one serif or tiny dash attached to it, giving the eye a kind of horizontal line to follow across the page. Many computer texts are printed in sans-serif, blocklike letters that are harder to read. The text in paper books also has kerning, a term for printing certain letters closer together, and ligatures, the blending of two letters into one, both of which ease the eye's path across the page.
Most new technologies begin by trying to duplicate previous technologies, said Anthony Grafton, a professor of history at Princeton. "Early photographers did what the landscape painters were already doing. Later, they did things no painter had thought of. The camera could both duplicate ways of dealing with nature and create new ones."
That is in a sense what companies like Microsoft are trying to do: recreate the experience of reading a printed book.
Mr. Hill said the main feature of the Microsoft Reader was its new display technology ClearType, which is designed to make a computer screen look like a page in a book, with letters having the same clarity and resolution as they do on paper. The Reader software will have a built-in dictionary, and it will enable the consumer to download hundreds of books into one portable device. As with other programs, the consumer will be able to write in the margins of the e-book and save his place, and instead of the text scrolling down the screen, a new page will appear with the click of a button. Microsoft, SoftBook and Rocket eBook have also joined to establish a universal format for all e-books, called the Open eBook standard.
Still, Microsoft's program works best for reading from a standard LCD screen, the kind found on many laptop computers -- a substantively different act from reading a paper book. And that's a real drawback, according to its competitors. "In the end you're holding onto this big, hot piece of hardware with a short battery life," said Martin Eberhard, co-founder and chief executive officer of Nuvomedia, which makes the Rocket eBook. Of course, with the Rocket eBook and other reading devices, you're still holding a pricey electronic device with a screen.
Mr. Grafton of Princeton says the history of the book shows that one form doesn't necessarily replace another. Most computers still use scrolling, just as medieval texts did, for instance.
With e-books, people may learn to read in a whole new way, Mr. Grafton said. Instead of reading being a linear experience as the reader's eye moves across the printed page, reading may become "circular," with the reader following text from link to link on a computer screen with the click of a mouse.
E-books may also become simply an alternate form of reading. "Many forms of reading exist in any complex society," Mr. Grafton said. "I read my American Express bill differently from the way I read the text I'm teaching."
"Reading," he added, "is a complicated, multiple process."

HEADLINE: Gore Campaign Responds to Money Crunch

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER with KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Fund-raising for Vice President Al Gore's presidential campaign is lagging, forcing Mr. Gore to add new money-raising events and slash spending, campaign officials said today.
Mr. Gore expected to have completed all of his major fund-raising events for the primary campaign by the middle of November, but instead he has added at least three more fund-raisers to meet the campaign's $4 million target for the October-December period. 
 The first of these was held on Thursday night in McLean, Va., at the home of Terry McAuliffe, President Clinton's chief fund-raiser, and brought in about $200,000. Events planned for New York and Nashville in December are expected to raise more than $1 million.
Aides to Mr. Gore said that the campaign was in strong financial shape, but the hurriedly scheduled fund-raisers and a campaignwide effort to cut costs belied their assertion.
The money crunch has also led Mr. Gore to schedule more official events in his role as vice president, using his office to make policy announcements that are not overtly related to the campaign and thus can be paid for with taxpayer money.
Mr. Gore, campaigning in New Hampshire today, said his plan was "not to use the official events to campaign," but "to promote the administration's ideas."
Asked if he thought this was appropriate, Mr. Gore said: "Sure. To use official events to promote the administration's agenda? I don't know why it wouldn't be."
In an effort to conserve scarce dollars at the presidential campaign, Mr. Gore closed fund-raising offices in Washington and California today, with all efforts now concentrated in Nashville and New York. The overall fund-raising staff has been reduced to 6 people, from a peak of 40 this summer and early fall, a senior Gore adviser said.
The vice president's political traveling party has been cut to just two aides, from six or seven: Michael Feldman, a political adviser, and Chris Lehane, the press secretary.
Salaries at Gore headquarters in Nashville have been capped at $95,000 a year, down from the $180,000 a year that some advisers were making before the severity of the financial crunch became clear.
Mr. Gore's public appearances and private fund-raising events have been simplified, eliminating studio-type lighting for town meetings with voters as well as elaborate menus for money-raising dinners.
Mr. Lehane said that all major fund-raising efforts would be completed by the end of the year, yielding more than $40 million. The overall figure includes an estimated $13 million in federal matching funds and $4 million to cover the legal and accounting costs of meeting federal campaign finance regulations.
The Gore campaign applied for $9.2 million in federal matching funds in early October and expects the request to be approved by the Federal Election Commission as early as Monday, Mr. Lehane said. A second filing, for about $4.5 million, will be submitted in early January, he said.
The campaign expects to raise nearly $3 million in the early months of next year, chiefly through direct-mail appeals and donations solicited over the Internet. Mr. Gore has already raised more than $500,000 over the Internet; the campaign of Mr. Gore's Democratic rival, former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, announced this week that he had raised more than $1 million through his Web site.
Mr. Gore's advisers became alarmed at the end of September when the profligate spending became apparent, leaving his campaign with less money in the bank than Mr. Bradley's even though Mr. Gore had raised $5 million more than Mr. Bradley. On Oct. 1, Mr. Gore reported $10.3 million cash on hand; Mr. Bradley had $10.7 million.
Campaigns have to report figures on donations and spending only every three months, so a current comparison is not available.
But the decision to schedule three additional big-dollar events is a clear sign that the vice president has had trouble meeting his fund-raising targets and that spending continues to be a problem.
When Mr. Gore moved his campaign headquarters to Nashville from Washington last month, he said he was doing so to be closer to his Tennessee roots and to the voters. But he also hoped to sharply reduce the costs of running his campaign out of Washington, including $60,000 a month in rent. The new headquarters, in a former suite of medical offices in Nashville, rents for roughly a third of that.
A December dinner in Nashville is the last planned major fund-raising event, with a goal of roughly $1 million, a senior Gore adviser said. "We're not calling it the Super Bowl, and we don't rule out doing additional events later on, but this is the major push," the adviser said.
There are no current plans to again call on President Clinton's fund-raising prowess to assist the vice president, the adviser said. Mr. Clinton appeared at three Gore events in August and September that yielded more than $600,000.
Mr. Gore, confident that he will prevail in his primary battle with Mr. Bradley, is already looking ahead to the spring post-primary period when his campaign treasury will be emptied by travel and television advertising costs.
He is scouring the federal government for program and policy announcements that he can make in his role as vice president that will give him opportunities then to generate news coverage that he will not have to pay for, Mr. Lehane said.

HEADLINE: Mr. Bush's Foreign Policy

 BODY:
After a bumpy foreign policy debut on the campaign trail, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas faced the obvious task of showing that he understands international issues even though he lacks direct experience with them. In a speech yesterday at the Reagan library in California, the Republican presidential candidate placed himself solidly in his party's internationalist mainstream with warnings about isolationism and protectionism. His simplistic approach to arms control was the major flaw in a generally balanced overview of the foreign policies he would pursue if elected president.
On China, Russia and other nations in Asia and Europe, Mr. Bush outlined moderate Republican positions that would be consistent with the management of American foreign policy over the course of recent decades. And after his wobbly performance on foreign policy issues in recent months, he seemed determined to let no freelance remarks blotch a speech drafted by a number of senior advisers to his father, former President Bush, and to former President Reagan. Mr. Bush followed the text word for word. 
 He called for dealing with China "without ill will -- but without illusions." Avoiding naming the Clinton administration, he rightly criticized President Clinton's rush several years ago to embrace China as a strategic partner. Mr. Bush described China realistically as an emerging world power that has interests in common with America, but may also threaten America's interests in the future. His harsh criticism of Chinese human rights policy was justified. His intention to work with China on economic and political issues, while remaining wary of China's increasing military power, was sensible.
The broad outline of Mr. Bush's analysis of Russia was thoughtful. He understands that Russia remains a great power because of its nuclear arsenal, its natural resources and its sheer size. He wisely suggested that the United States reach out to a younger generation of Russians committed to democracy and reform, including political leaders outside Moscow. On nuclear proliferation, Mr. Bush promoted more funding for dismantling nuclear weapons in the former Soviet Union, and his general concerns about the issue were well put. But his downgrading of ratification of the Start 2 treaty as a priority was a mistake, particularly if there is no effort to move to the next round of arms cuts.
Mr. Bush's other prescriptions for controlling the spread of nuclear weapons were more dubious. His rejection of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty only compounded the error made by Senate Republicans in rejecting the treaty last month. His reliance on missile defense systems underestimated the difficulties involved in developing a reliable shield. It also underemphasized the crucial matter of trying to work with Moscow to amend the antiballistic-missile treaty.
One speech cannot eliminate questions about Mr. Bush's familiarity with national security affairs. Nor did it provide a blueprint of what he would do if elected. But it was a serious effort to which the other candidates will no doubt be responding.

HEADLINE: Army Increases Incentives for Some Who Enlist

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Trying hard to fill its ranks in an era of prosperity and relative peace, the United States Army is offering bigger enlistment bonuses and shorter hitches for some recruits.
The inducements vary widely, and the Army's Web site encourages prospective soldiers to contact recruiters for more details. But even a cursory visit to the site is apt to be startling for middle-aged veterans who recall a somewhat less hospitable Army. 
 Sign-up bonuses up to $20,000 await some enlistees qualified for the specialities most in demand, like intelligence posts. Moreover, for the first time qualified recruits will not have to choose between a sign-up bonus and money for college. Some who qualify for the $20,000 bonus may also be eligible for up to $50,000 in college aid later.
Enlistees who score high enough on their military-aptitude tests can sign up for two years, instead of the traditional three, and receive up to $26,500 for college or vocational training.
The new bonuses are not a surprise in view of the military's difficulties in finding and keeping people. There has been no draft since 1973, and with a booming civilian economy there has been little incentive for many young people to join up.
For the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30, the Army fell short of its recruiting goal for the second straight year, recruiting about 7,000 fewer men and women than the 74,500 it said it needed. For the current fiscal year, the Army needs to recruit about 80,000 people to stay at its Congressionally mandated level.
The Air Force and Navy have also had trouble keeping up their strengths, although less than the Army. But their Web sites make it clear that they, too, recognize the need to project themselves as friendly and full of opportunities. (The Marine Corps, the smallest of the services, continues its spartan approach: "The few, the proud.")
The Army bonus offers include $4,000 for enlistees who sign up for three or more years and report for active duty no later than Dec. 27. Recruits with some college training can get $4,000 to $8,000. Enlistees who choose airborne training will get a $3,000 bonus, which can be combined with some other bonuses.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Shares Battered After Warning About Profit

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Shares of Caterpillar Inc. plummeted 12 percent today after the company warned that fourth-quarter earnings would not meet expectations.
The profit warning was the third in the last year at Caterpillar, which said yesterday that it was suffering from weaker-than-expected sales of its heavy equipment in North America. 
 Shares of Caterpillar, the world's largest maker of construction and earth-moving equipment, fell $6.75, to $49.1875, on the New York Stock Exchange. The drop also weighed down the Dow Jones industrial average, which lost 31.81 points, to 11,003.89.
Caterpillar had warned earlier this year that it was having trouble in Asia and Latin America, as well as experiencing weakness in the demand for its mining equipment. But yesterday, company executives said that softening construction business in North America and increased price competition had forced the company to trim expectations.
"Demand for our type of products" has not risen to the level the company thought it would, said Marsha Hausser, a spokeswoman for Caterpillar, which is based in Peoria, Ill. "North America has been down, and the industry is softening."
The company released few details about its fourth-quarter problems, saying only that its executives had been too optimistic and that some revenue that was anticipated from a federal highway construction bill had not materialized.
In a statement early in the day, Caterpillar said it expected fourth-quarter revenue and profit to be slightly ahead of the third quarter, in which the company reported earnings of 61 cents a share on revenue of $4.7 billion.
Analysts had been projecting profit of 97 cents a share, according to a survey by First Call/Thomson Financial. Wall Street analysts reacted to today's news by drastically revising their fourth-quarter estimates, though few made sharp cuts in their forecasts for next year.
"There are three factors," said Tobias Levkovich, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "The marketplace is not as strong, a lot of equipment has already been replaced and interest rates are higher."
Among those who made revisions today, the consensus was that Caterpillar would earn 66 cents a share in the fourth quarter, according to Charles Hill, director of research at First Call, down from 83 cents a share in the fourth quarter of 1998.
Analysts said there were indications that the construction and housing boom that had been a main driver of the nation's economic engine might have peaked, and that many construction companies might have already reached full capacity.
Although construction activity remains robust, several analysts said that some of the world's leading construction and heavy equipment makers, such as Ingersoll-Rand, Komatsu of Japan and Deere & Company, had stepped up their manufacturing activity and introduced new products and vehicles.
"There are so many manufacturers making machines; everyone's adding capacity," said David A. Bluestein, an analyst at PaineWebber. "We have a market that is still reasonably strong, but the outlook is mixed."
Despite the warnings, Caterpillar said it was witnessing a rebound in sales in Asia, and strong growth in its truck engines and financial products divisions. The company said revenue and profit next year were expected to be slightly ahead of this year; if analyst estimates are correct, profit this year could be $2.62 a share, down 36 percent from $4.11 a year ago.
After record revenue of $20.9 billion in 1998, Caterpillar has been trying to reduce costs and hoping for a turnaround in the global economy. What was unexpected, analysts said, was that North America -- which accounts for more than 55 percent of the company's revenue -- would sour for Caterpillar in the midst of a strong economy.
Last March, the company warned of an earnings slowdown, noting that profits should improve in the second half of the year. But third-quarter profits fell 34 percent, and if the revised forecasts are accurate, they mean a drop of 20 percent from near- record profits of a year ago.

HEADLINE: Trade Pacts Must Safeguard Workers, Union Chief Says

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Raising the stakes in labor's dispute with President Clinton over trade, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, John J. Sweeney, called on the administration today to scuttle a worldwide round of trade-liberalization talks unless negotiators first take steps toward protecting workers' rights.
Mr. Sweeney, already angry about last week's trade agreement with China, said American labor unions want Mr. Clinton to persuade trade ministers gathering in Seattle on Nov. 30 to allow trade sanctions against countries that violate basic labor standards, like the ban on child labor. 
 The labor movements in the United States and in other industrialized countries are taking a much more aggressive approach toward the Seattle trade talks than toward previous rounds of negotiations, insisting that workers' rights be included in any new trade agreements. In past rounds of trade talks, corporations and developing nations prevailed with their arguments that worker rights have no place in trade accords.
In what was billed as a major address to the National Press Club here, Mr. Sweeney rejected accusations that labor's attacks on the World Trade Organization and the China deal stemmed from protectionism and isolationism.
"The debate isn't about free trade or protection, engagement or isolation," he said. "The real debate is not over whether to be part of the global economy, but over what are the rules for that economy and who makes them -- not whether to engage China, but what are the terms of that engagement, and whose values are to be represented."
Union leaders view the Seattle trade meeting as a landmark opportunity to establish for the first time a worldwide system of enforceable labor rights. Labor officials say these rights would enable workers, and not just corporations, to enjoy the fruits of expanded trade.
Mr. Sweeney said it was time to ensure that any future trade agreements take into account not just corporate concerns, but also the concerns of workers, environmentalists and human rights advocates.
Mr. Sweeney said he was pleased that President Clinton had backed labor's call to have the trade organization ministers set up a committee that would draft rules on core labor standards. But with developing countries vowing to block such a move, union leaders fear that Mr. Clinton will drop his commitment to labor rights, rather than block the planned round of worldwide trade talks from moving forward.
"Until the W.T.O. addresses these important issues, there will be no support for a major new round of trade negotiations," Mr. Sweeney said.
Some labor leaders are warning that if President Clinton leaves the Seattle talks without winning an international pledge to create a system of worker rights, he will further antagonize union members who are already fuming about his deal to let China join the W.T.O. Union leaders are angry that the administration agreed to China's membership in the trade organization without having gotten China to agree to allow independent trade unions and to free imprisoned labor leaders.
Gene Sperling, the president's economic adviser, said: "There's no question that Bill Clinton is the single head of state fighting hardest for and leading the effort for a working group on labor. We will continue to make an all-out effort to achieve that goal."
The anger at the administration, union leaders say, might not only soften labor's support for Vice President Al Gore in his campaign for the presidency but cause a diversion of union money and manpower from Mr. Gore's race to a fight against the China trade accord and the W.T.O.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is working with environmental, consumer and human rights groups to sponsor a large rally in Seattle to protest what they see as the trade organization's pro-corporate tilt and its frequent overruling of countries' environmental and consumer protection laws.
The trade organization's meeting, scheduled to run from Nov. 30 to Dec. 2 and bring together ministers from 135 countries, aims to set ground rules for a multiyear round of trade talks that would liberalize trade in agriculture, financial services, Internet services and other areas.
As an example of how labor values might be included in trade rules, Mr. Sweeney argued that W.T.O. rules should allow China's trading partners to seek sanctions against China for using forced labor and barring trade unions.
"This is a country where anyone attempting to organize a union is immediately arrested and imprisoned -- no exceptions," Mr. Sweeney said of China.
Developing countries are seeking to block the trade organization from creating enforceable core labor standards and even from taking the preliminary step of setting up a working group on labor rights. Such core labor standards, union officials say, would include a ban on child labor and on forced labor, and a right to form trade unions and engage in collective bargaining.
Third world countries fear that allowing their trading partners to seek sanctions for violations of such labor standards would pave the way to banning their exports.
"These countries say that we'll just slap restrictions on their exports and make them poorer," said Jeffrey Schott, senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics.
Thomas Donohue, the president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, expressed alarm at Mr. Sweeney's call on Mr. Clinton to block the new trade round unless worker protections are included. Mr. Donohue has backed creating a working group on labor.
Insisting that the new trade agreements will increase American exports and jobs, Mr. Donohue said, "I think John Sweeney and other labor leaders are smart enough to recognize that to scuttle this trade round and the China-W.T.O. deal would not be in the interests of this country, its workers, its economy or its national security. This is a watershed opportunity to bring China into the international trading system and to get it to adhere to the international law."
Mr. Sweeney's speech made clear that he would rely on an alliance with environmental, consumer and human rights groups to pressure the W.T.O. "We will continue to organize in the Congress against any trade accords that do not include workers' rights and environmental protections," he said.

HEADLINE: Journal;
Who Doesn't Want to Be a Millionaire

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
When historians look back at America as it rang in the momentous year of 2000, what will they find? Y2K panic? An outbreak of millennial spirituality? "Prosperity with a purpose"?
Guess again. What they are going to see instead is a country drunk on a TV quiz show called "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire." As the countdown to the new millennium intensifies, it is impossible to exaggerate the appeal of ABC's nightly national Vesuvius of greenbacks. Even in the few days since its success landed it on the front page of The New York Times, the show's numbers have continued to soar. "The Virgin Mary, Arnold Schwarzenegger, leprechauns -- nothing could stop Regis Philbin and his mind-numbing multiple choice show," wrote Lisa de Moraes in The Washington Post, chronicling the also-ran ratings for such other network sweeps stunts as the heavily promoted spectacular "Mary, Mother of Jesus." 
 Not only is the "Millionaire" viewership huge, but in an era of "niche" audiences, when every fractionalized demographic in the nation is pandered to by its own cable channel, "Millionaire" is gathering Americans from all walks of life around the electronic hearth in the way "I Love Lucy" once did. Low-attention-span kids and surly teenagers watch. Parents watch. The elderly watch. Who could imagine a happier ending to our long siege of White House sexual revelations and workplace massacres? At last, a G-rated cultural value that unites the entire American family -- greed!
All brought to us by the wonderful world of the Disney Company, which has finally found a dirt-cheap entertainment formula that pleases Wall Street without offending any major faith. If you can find a link on the ABC Web page that doesn't lead to a "Millionaire" promotion, jokes the veteran Hollywood agent Bernie Brillstein, "the site it takes you to has Walt Disney turning over in his grave."
"We've come to a tough moment at the end of the millennium," says Rosalyn Weinman, an NBC executive who holds a doctorate in sociology. "All the stuff our parents told us didn't come true. No one cares if you're good. People only care if you're good-looking and rich." Not that NBC won't try to get its share in a gold rush: the network is shamelessly scrambling to bring back "Twenty-One," its own notorious contribution to the 1950's quiz-show scandals. How will the new "Twenty-One" be different from the old? I asked Fred Silverman, who is readying the retread in L.A. "The first thing," he replied, "is that it is not going to be fixed." The second: "more accessible" questions.
Back in the 50's it was the young Congressional investigator Richard Goodwin, on his way to the Kennedy White House, who led the contestant Charles Van Doren, the star fraud of "Twenty-One," into a Washington hearing room to confess to a disillusioned nation. At my urging this week, Mr. Goodwin caught an episode of "Millionaire" and, once he had, sounded almost nostalgic for Mr. Van Doren, who, though fed questions in advance, was at least a bona fide egghead. Mr. Goodwin thought "Millionaire" was "a joke" and has no use for its dumbed-down questions. "In the 50's," he said, "we cited these contestants as examples of how we were intellectually ahead of the Russians. The shows were designed to create heroes, people to admire and look up to for their learning and knowledge. Now they're trying to make audiences feel better about themselves."
The return of the quiz-show craze in the late 90's, Mr. Goodwin added, suggests a parallel between now and the 50's, another prosperous "time of dullness" with "really intense public apathy and little ferment over public issues." And certainly "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" gains intellectual heft when compared with the current political culture's debate over Al Gore's wardrobe. Yet affluent as the 50's were, they are nothing next to our current boom, which rivals the late-19th-century Gilded Age in terms of its creation of fabulous wealth.
Mark Twain called the Gilded Age a time of "money-lust." This week terms like "voyeurism" and "vicarious orgasms" and "ecstasy" kept popping up when I canvassed people about the late 1990's appeal of "Millionaire." In this sense, the new quiz shows were a phenomenon waiting to happen; they're the giddiest manifestations yet of a culture that offers a pornography of wealth almost everywhere you look.
"So what's it like to be worth $400 million when you're 27 years old?" asked Fortune in its cover story on "The Young and the Loaded," one recent example culled from the avalanche of media celebrations of dot-com zillionaires. (Answer: darned good.) The new Esquire features a first-person confession by an anonymous, freshly minted millionaire exulting in his financial virility in the same terms that men's magazines once celebrated sexual prowess. To up the ante on the debut night of "Millionaire" this month, ABC led into it with "Annie," the musical about the Depression-era orphan who finds happiness in the loving arms of the eponymous Daddy Warbucks. "The richest night of television!" is how the network promoted the double bill. Further gilding the already gilded lily are the relentless commercials on "Millionaire" for E*Trade, which not only invites viewers to play the market but to enter a sweepstakes that will award a million to the entrant who correctly guesses the Dow Jones average at year's end.
If this country is so rich, why are so many coveting prosperity they already have? The answer is that most people don't have it, and the gap between the haves and the have-nots -- and between the haves and the middle class -- is growing. While nearly half the country invests in stocks, 90 percent of the shares are held by the wealthiest 10 percent of the households, according to studies cited by The Wall Street Journal; meanwhile, stock options have pushed the ratio of executive pay to factory-worker pay from 42 to 1 in 1980 to 419 to 1 in 1998. Nelson Aldrich Jr., the author of the memoir "Old Money," says the distribution of wealth among Americans now looks like "the pyramid on the dollar bill -- with the top sliced off and floating up by the transparent eyeball."
Americans aren't angry about these discrepancies. Politicians aren't vocal about them, with the fringe exception of Pat Buchanan -- and Donald Trump, who last week announced a confiscatory tax plan for the super-rich. Instead of getting riled, have-not and have-not-so-much Americans are looking for their own financial scores, especially quick scores. Las Vegas is our fastest-growing city. Day trading and Internet betting are in the stratosphere. According to this year's report by the federal commission on the subject, the national explosion in state lotteries and casinos has led Americans to spend far more on gambling per year than they do on groceries. For children addicted to acquisitiveness but not old enough to put cash on the table, there are chips, in the form of Pokemon cards.
In the corporate offices of television, where executives have to worry about when today's hits will fade, there seems to be unanimity about how the quiz-show fad could burn itself out. "If the economy tanks," says Dr. Weinman of NBC, "the whole thing falls apart. Then you have envy and jealousy." She is seconded by the psychologist Dr. Joyce Brothers, who in 1955 won a total of $134,000 on "The $64,000 Question," until now the only quiz show to top TV ratings for a season, and its offshoot, "The $64,000 Challenge." Reminiscing this week, Dr. Brothers told of how she spent that long-ago windfall -- a Park Avenue medical practice for her husband, dishwashers for the rest of her family -- and also of how warmly the public responded to her winnings. She feels that the same approval accrues to 1999's quiz-show victors, at least for now. But in an economic downturn, she fears, there might be a backlash against overnight millionaires who got "something for nothing" and "did no real work."
At the height of the quiz show scandals in the 50's, John Steinbeck wrote a letter to Adlai Stevenson that The New Republic published under the headline "Have We Gone Soft?" Steinbeck wrote, "If I wanted to destroy a nation, I would give it too much and I would have it on its knees, miserable, greedy and sick. . . ." But you'll find no such jeremiads here -- or almost anywhere. Everyone loves Regis, the show is way more fun than Stone and Jane, and only a millennial-eve party pooper could imagine that the biggest bubble in the nation's history will ever burst.

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
The Downside of a Social Security Promise

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
When President Clinton vowed in last year's State of the Union address to "save Social Security first," he in effect vowed to scuttle any attempt by Congress to use the surplus dollars in the Social Security trust fund for government programs or for tax cuts. He pledged to use the surplus money instead to pay down the federal debt.
At the time, many liberals cheered because the vow seemed a deft way to fight off a Republican plan to pass a huge tax cut for rich families. But the president's position, by locking away trillions of tax dollars, also blocks any plans liberals might have for using surplus money for traditional causes, like investing in urban schools or training disadvantaged workers. 
 Burgeoning Social Security surpluses must be used one way or another. Mr. Clinton argues that his choice -- buying back Treasury bonds from the public, thereby reducing federal debt -- is sound economic policy. He's right. But his plan is not the only sound economic use of the surplus.
Proponents of Mr. Clinton's plan point out that the policy boosts saving and private investment. When government buys back its bonds, it turns dollars over to bondholders. They, in turn, lend those dollars to companies that want to expand productive capacity. That helps the economy to grow, driving up the wages of future workers. The payoff of this plan is that high-wage workers will not feel much pain when it comes time to turn over taxes that are needed to support the elderly.
But there are other ways to boost saving and investment. Government spending on, say, early childhood education is also an act of saving and investment. Money is taken from taxpayers -- reducing their consumption -- and used to train smart workers for the future. The act of reducing consumption today in order to expand output tomorrow fits the definition of investment. So does building airports and paying for basic research.
So which is better: raising private investment by paying down the federal debt, or raising public investment by spending on schools? At that level of generality, there is no answer. Economists attack the question one project at a time -- with grunt work that tediously estimates benefits and costs.
Consider a public project to create after-school mentoring and tutoring programs for young students. According to recent research, such programs can produce large, long-lasting benefits for disadvantaged children -- cutting drug use and school absences by 45 percent or more. Those benefits can exceed the typical benefit that comes from throwing more money into private capital markets by buying back bonds.
The liberals who signed onto Mr. Clinton's Social Security vow sacrificed a lot. They agreed to keep hands off $2 trillion that is expected to flow into the trust fund over the next 10 years but not flow right back out to retirees. That decision could eliminate projects that have made up the core of the liberal agenda for more than 60 years.

HEADLINE: MAN IN THE NEWS: Richard A. Posner;
Wide-Ranging Legal Thinker

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
As a federal appeals court judge, Richard A. Posner has an exalted job, but one held by a few hundred others. But to a wide swath of intellectuals, he is one of the most fascinating thinkers in the nation, especially about contemporary American social issues.
While most sitting federal judges rarely engage in public comment about subjects outside their courtrooms, Judge Posner has produced more than 30 books on a breathtakingly broad variety of subjects, including sexuality, aging, the economics of AIDS and literary criticism. Most recently, he produced a crisp legal and intellectual analysis of the investigation and impeachment of President Clinton in which he did not shrink from concluding that the president had committed perjury and obstruction of justice. 
 But Judge Posner's principal field, if one must be selected from the wide span of his work, is the intersection of law and economics. Before he joined the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, where he is now the chief judge, he was a law professor at the University of Chicago. On the campus where the Chicago School of economic thought revered the free market, he played a leading role in establishing a field of legal thought on the same foundation. It holds that most legal issues can be subjected to rational quantitative reasoning, often in the form of cost-benefit analysis.
Critics of the Chicago School argue that by elevating the value of increasing economic efficiency, the thinking is inevitably without compassion and often cruel.
Within the field of law and economics, Judge Posner has devoted an enormous amount of time to writing and thinking about antitrust law, the very area in which he has taken on a major role as mediator of any settlement talks in the Microsoft case.
While at the University of Chicago, Judge Posner produced a treatise on antitrust law in 1976 in which he projected the general libertarian skepticism over the way antitrust laws were enforced. In the book, he argues for a narrow view of antitrust law in which the best candidates for regulation are hard-core examples of price-fixing by corporate coalitions or cartels and mergers that would obviously stifle competition.
The Microsoft situation, in which a single company comes to dominate an industry, does not neatly fit into either of those categories. But as a judge and a thinker, Judge Posner has shown himself to be brazenly unpredictable on occasion.
"Richard Posner is one of the most important antitrust scholars of the past half-century," said Professor William Kovacic of the George Washington University Law School, himself a leading antitrust scholar.
Professor Kovacic said that although Judge Posner's overall approach to economic issues suggests he would be sympathetic to Microsoft, that might not be the case.
"It's a fascinating choice," he said. "Because if Richard Posner tells the government it will lose on appeal or Microsoft that it will lose on appeal, that judgment will come with an enormous amount of credibility." Judge Posner, he said, will be able to dissect the issues and probabilities of the way things may turn out, "like no other person in this country. His views will come with a towering reputation and a tremendous knowledge of the history in this area."
Before he was named to the federal bench in 1981 by President Ronald Reagan, Mr. Posner augmented his professional life by helping to found Lexecon Inc., a consulting firm that tried to put into practice the Chicago School theories. A large portion of Lexecon's early business when he was still a partner was advising companies as to whether their competitive practices would run afoul of antitrust laws.
As a judge, he has ruled on a few antitrust cases, with no obvious pattern in his decisions.
In 1996, writing for a unanimous appeals panel, Judge Posner ruled that it was a violation of the antitrust laws for an oil refiner to set a cap on the price of its product that retailers could charge. He wrote that he was obliged to rule that way in State Oil Company v. Kahn because of a well-established principle of antitrust law, but his opinion included a long argument as to why the principle was outdated and should be scrapped.
The next year, the Supreme Court reversed the ruling, adopting Judge Posner's criticism of the precedent.
In 1986, the Hospital Corporation of America sought to appeal a ruling from the Federal Trade Commission, which had disallowed a merger. Judge Posner upheld the commission, in a decision that Professor Kovacic said demonstrated that he was not a reflexive opponent of antitrust enforcement decisions.
In 1995, Judge Posner wrote a ruling that his critics said demonstrated his commitment to emphasizing economic efficiency. He ruled that thousands of hemophiliacs who contracted H.I.V. from a blood-clotting medicine could not join a lawsuit against the drug companies because such an action could "hurl the industry into bankruptcy."
Last month, Judge Posner wrote the dissenting opinion as the Seventh Circuit, by a 5-to-4 vote, upheld the constitutionality of laws in Illinois and Wisconsin that criminalize a late-term abortion procedure that opponents call "partial birth" abortion. Judge Posner's minority opinion said the laws were questionable because they were designed only to dramatize the ugliness of abortion, not to reduce the number of them.
Richard Allen Posner was born in New York City on Jan. 11, 1939, the child of Max and Blanche Posner.
Judge Posner is the father of two grown sons, one a law professor and one an investment banker. He and his wife, Charlene, also have three grandchildren. In addition to family pictures in his chamber, Judge Posner keeps a photograph of Justice William J. Brennan Jr. prominently displayed. Judge Posner was a clerk for Justice Brennan after he completed his studies at Harvard Law School, where he graduated first in his class in 1962 and served as president of the law review. His undergraduate degree is from Yale, where he was an English major.
It was his background in literature, he has said, that drew him to write an account of President Clinton's impeachment. In explaining why he wrote "An Affair of State: The Investigation, Impeachment and Trial of President Clinton," he described both President and Hillary Clinton as having produced a drama worthy of Shakespeare.
The circuit court he administers covers Illinois, Indiana and Wisconsin. In addition to his judicial duties and relentless writing, he still carries a one-third teaching load at the University of Chicago Law School.
At 60, he likes to forsake the elevator every few days, he recently told a visitor, and climb the stairs to his office on the 27th floor of the Everett M. Dirksen Federal Building in Chicago. This summer, when the power was shut off in the building, he trekked up to his office where he was one of the few people at work.

HEADLINE: Colombia Tries, Yet Cocaine Thrives

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MAGUARE, Colombia

 BODY:
Under American pressure, for most of this decade the Colombian government has been sending planes to spray herbicides on the fields of coca that flourish in areas like this. With a new, more cooperative government in power in Bogota, last year was a banner year for that joint effort, with a record 135,000 acres fumigated.
But 1998 also turned out to be a record year for cocaine production in Colombia. By official estimate, acreage devoted to the cultivation of coca, the plant that provides the raw material for cocaine, surged more than 25 percent and is now three times larger than in 1994. Colombia has passed Peru and Bolivia to become both the largest grower and processor of coca in the world. 
 All told, at least 180,000 acres are now given over to coca cultivation, according to a survey made public by Colombia's Anti-Narcotics Police in September. An additional 14,000 acres are used for growing heroin poppies, another illicit crop that is booming despite the American-financed spraying campaign. Such crops were grown in only 10 of Colombia's 33 provinces five years ago, but are now cultivated in 21, the survey estimated.
The reasons for this surge, which is continuing, are many. American officials say the success of air interdiction efforts in Peru and Bolivia has forced traffickers to shift cultivation here.
The surge has also coincided with an intensification of Colombia's decades-old war against leftist guerrillas, with each fueling the other. The rebels earn money by selling protection to the growers, who are then free to cultivate still more crops without fear of interdiction.
Colombia acknowledges that more than three-quarters of all coca cultivation is concentrated here in the province of Caqueta and neighboring Putumayo, both strongholds of the country's largest rebel force, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. The group operates at will across much of southern Colombia.
At the same time, American and Colombian officials have gradually come to realize that simple economic logic has propelled the explosion of coca production as much as the ebb and flow of the civil war.
Since the collapse of the Cali and Medellin cartels -- the two groups that dominated the cocaine trade until their leaders were arrested or killed in the mid-1990's -- trafficking groups too small to be regarded as cartels have proliferated. In striving to build supply networks of their own, they have provided credit to peasant farmers.
"You've got a much more decentralized situation with a lot more actors, well over 100, and that has increased demand," said Bruce Bagley, a University of Miami professor who is a leading academic expert on the drug trade.
"They don't have the capital or the equipment to fly coca in from Peru or Bolivia."
Colombian trafficking groups have also been experimenting with more potent varieties of coca, Col. Jose Leonardo Gallego, chief of the Anti-Narcotics Police, said in an interview while flying over this rebel-dominated region.
With the help of agronomists hired for the purpose, they have imported a type of coca native to Peru and grafted it onto the weaker species traditionally grown here to create a powerful hybrid.
"Now you have a variety that can be harvested six to eight times a year," Dr. Bagley said. "So along with the expanded area under cultivation, you get much greater productivity per plant and a higher alkaloid content, which means much less cost in refining and a bigger bang for your buck."
Furthermore, while the United States and Colombia may agree on the extent of the coca problem, they often diverge on solutions. The Colombian government has long had doubts about spraying campaigns and prefers to focus on crop substitution, but because the United States insists on spraying -- and is willing to pick up the costs -- that approach has been emphasized.
"To me, fumigation makes no sense," said Armando Borrero, a former national security adviser to the Colombian government, expressing a view often heard in official circles in Bogota. "It only forces the migration of cultivation."
In recent years, this area of rolling hills and fertile forest has been not only a prime region for growing coca but also a laboratory for efforts to check its spread. Three years ago, coca growers fought pitched battles with the police just south of here in an attempt to disrupt such efforts.
Nowadays, though, farmers here seem more willing to shift away from coca. The National Plan for Alternative Development, a government agency that seeks to wean peasants from coca to legitimate crops like coffee and sugar cane, operates a pilot rubber-producing program here that has attracted dozens of peasant families.
"It is a relief not to have the law after me anymore," said Nidia Perdomo, who grew coca for eight years before stopping in 1998. "You can grow as much rubber as you want, and you don't have any conflict with the police or the guerrillas."
The farmers' interest in abandoning coca may stem partly from a growing resentment of the guerrillas, who have been increasingly unwilling to pay the market price for coca paste as they have extended their control. At local markets, the guerrillas have imposed a ceiling of about $410 a pound for paste; elsewhere, traffickers offer up to $570.
When asked if it was the spraying campaign that made them stop growing coca, Ms. Perdomo, 41, and her brother Miller, 49, said no. "The problem with coca is that the profits do not go to those who grow it," she said. "The intermediaries make all the money while you are barely surviving."
Peasants eking out a living from small coca operations, however, often end up prime targets of the government's fumigation campaign. In addition, the spraying appears at times to undermine alternative crop programs based on rubber, palm and fruit trees.
Legitimate farmers commonly complain of being pushed into poverty after planes mistakenly spray herbicides on fields in which no coca is growing, or because pilots deliberately dump their chemicals.
"When you spray indiscriminately, as they often do around here, you kill off the rubber trees as well as the coca plants," said Jesus Bastidas, president of the Caqueta Rubber-Growing and Reforestation Association.
Juan Carlos Claros Pinzon, the crop substitution agency's director for Caqueta province, said: "Spraying works fine with large-scale commercial cultivation, but when it is aimed at the smaller producers, it creates a social problem and only makes our work more difficult. When we show our project to a person who has been left with absolutely nothing, he says, 'That will be fine in a year, but I am hungry today.' "
Many peasants then simply choose to become "raspachines," or day laborer hired to tend and harvest coca on large plantations. Those jobs typically pay $7.50 a day plus meals, twice the going wage for a worker on a legitimate farm.
Using the slang term for those who run the drug trade, Wenceslao Villa, operations director for the alternative development agency founded in 1996, described the problem this way: "You fumigate, and the narcos follow behind, offering support and financing" to the peasants.
A lack of money has hurt the alternative crop strategy favored by the Colombian government. Mr. Claros learned that firsthand when he recently visited rebel leaders in San Vicente del Caguan, capital of the demilitarized zone that the Colombian government handed over to the rebel group last November. The hope was to get peace talks started, but the zone is now the focal point of the guerrillas' drug operations.
"One guerrilla commander asked me how much money I can spend in a year," Mr. Claros recalled. "I answered that I have a budget of $4 million and he nearly laughed in my face. To them that is nothing -- what they pay in one weekend at two or three peasant markets to buy coca paste."
The proposal for American aid to Colombia now before Congress contains a sizable increase meant for alternative development programs like the one here. But for the foreseeable future, the American focus is likely to be on aerial spraying, much to the dismay of Colombian officials who believe the program inadvertently helps the enemy.
"The day after, it looks like you dropped napalm, but four months later it is all flowering again," Mr. Villa said. "You've actually done them a favor by cleaning up the lot."

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1128 words

HEADLINE: Far From New York, Prayers for a Victim but No Curses for the City

BYLINE: By C. J. CHIVERS 

DATELINE: ATHENS, Tex., Nov. 19

 BODY:
The members of the First Baptist Church here have been saying nearly continuous prayers for Nicole Barrett since Wednesday, taking turns in hourlong shifts in front of a wooden cross in a room attached to the church's gymnasium, where they sit or kneel and ask God to grant her a speedy recovery. They have been at it since word first spread through East Texas that their former neighbor had been seriously injured in Manhattan by a man who had fractured her skull with a brick.
Ms. Barrett, 27, a native of Athens, was attacked on Tuesday afternoon while she was walking near the intersection of 42nd Street and Madison Avenue. It was the latest in a string of frightening assaults on people in New York's public spaces. She was placed on the First Baptist Church prayer list within a day, and has been the topic of countless conversations here ever since. 
 But the Rev. Kyle L. Henderson, the church's senior pastor, said that while the attack on Ms. Barrett -- especially its brutality and unfathomable randomness -- has been a subject of intense talk, a key element is missing from the discussion: blame for New York City, where the young woman had gone to try her prospects but where she is now suffering from a severe brain trauma she received while merely walking down the street.
With her parents at her side, Ms. Barrett is at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, where hospital officials said yesterday that her condition was improving.
"There's been an improvement in her level of wakefulness," said Lorinda Klein, a hospital spokeswoman. "They've seen movement in all four extremities. She's opened her eyes and closed them again. She is moving her arms and her legs; this is a good sign."
Ms. Barrett's brother Scott told a Fox Five News reporter last night that the attack would probably not dampen his sister's enthusiasm for New York. "She liked the city so much it wouldn't surprise us if she came back," he said.
In Athens, Mr. Henderson said, residents were horrified by what has befallen Ms. Barrett. But few people in this city of 12,000 think that the assault is a reflection on New York, which he said seemed no more dangerous than many other places in America. "I don't think that New York really has the reputation here in the South of the way it used to be talked about," he said. "It's not a place where people say the social fabric is breaking down. This week it happened in New York. Next week it could be Oklahoma City. It could be Fort Worth."
Mr. Henderson's words, echoed in two dozen interviews in this city 70 miles southeast of Dallas where Texas prairie gives way to Southern forest, appear to represent a palpable swing in public perception of the city and the dangers it holds.
In 1990, when Brian Watkins, a high school tennis champion visiting from Utah, was stabbed and killed by muggers on a Midtown subway platform, there was a public uproar, leading to calls for more policing in a city that much of America thought was out of control.
Mr. Watkins died after trying to defend his mother, who had been kicked in the head. New York, it seemed, was a metaphor for urban lawlessness.
The assault on Ms. Barrett, however, has been met with a quiet reaction among the people who knew the victim or her family. People here pray for her recovery. Otherwise, the mood is restrained -- a product, residents say, of their awareness that school and workplace shootings have been taking place in cities large and small, and their sense that New York has become increasingly safe in recent years.
"There's a whole lot of meanness in the world, not in New York in particular," said E. Herbert Gatlin Jr., a former mayor of Athens and now director of the city's Economic Development Corporation. "In fact, when you look at the number of people in Dallas that get shot, beat, hit and killed, I think Dallas might be meaner than New York."
Athens is a quintessential small Southern city, where pecan shells litter the sidewalks and handshakes are firm. The city's center is a courthouse ringed by one- and two-story shops. Its past is rich in cotton farming and brick manufacturing -- two products of the area's dark, clay-streaked soil. Its present includes a belt of strip malls that could be found anywhere in America, and two large employers -- Champion Homes Inc., which makes mobile homes, and Maxxim Medical, a surgical supplies manufacturer.
Crime is not unknown here. Recent federal statistics show that the local police record 1 or 2 murders a year, and as many as 9 rapes and 33 car thefts. But residents say the overall incidence of crime is low, and they feel safe.
And though they shudder at its details, most Athens residents seem to see no larger significance to the assault on Ms. Barrett than that described by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has portrayed it as a random act of violence that should not sully the reputation of New York City.
In fact, some Athens residents who have recently visited New York said the attack had given them pause to reflect on how much the city seemed to have improved from the days when it was legendary for its drug wars and drive-by shootings. This was true of former Mayor Gatlin, who said he was startled by the city's gritty and menacing feel 15 years ago, when he traveled to Manhattan to secure a municipal bond, and surprised "at how clean and well-lighted" it was during a recent trip.
It was also true for Sandra S. Abadie, youth coordinator at the First United Methodist Church, who made her first trip to Manhattan on Nov. 4.
"We saw the opera, we saw the plays, we rode on the subways and I never felt unsafe," she said. "The time I had was so fantastic, it just changed my whole impression of what I had heard about New York."
Those in Athens who had a bad impression of New York said it stemmed from a general preference for rural areas, rather than a belief that New York was a magnet for crime. "I don't like large cities in particular," said Daniel W. Rogers, family minister at the Eastern Hills Church of Christ. "Well, I guess I like Dallas -- in my rear-view mirror."
Even among the people who know Ms. Barrett, the appeal of New York was untarnished. Cheryl McMillan, whose daughter Misty was a close friend of Ms. Barrett's when they grew up, stood outside Athens High School on Thursday night and dabbed a tear. She was deeply troubled by the thought of Ms. Barrett lying injured in a hospital bed, but that thought did not change her sense of the city, a place where talent finds opportunity and cultural life thrives, she said.
"My youngest daughter is fixing to go to N.Y.U.," she said. "She's an honors student all the way, in theater and literature, and she wants to try it.
"She's fixing to go, and I won't stop her."

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
CROSSING: A Memoir, by Deirdre McCloskey. (University of Chicago, $25.) An economist and historian of considerable distinction who decided at 52 to become a woman focuses more on the emotional evolution of the crossover than its surgical side (though that was grueling enough).
 
HOMESICKNESS, by Murray Bail. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, paper, $14.) An Australian novel that cogitates on the dubious pleasures of mass tourism as a group of 13 follows a senseless itinerary through surreal and baffling museums.
 
LIVES OF THE POETS, by Michael Schmidt. (Knopf, $35.) This big book (940 pages plus bibliography and index) is a history of English poetry from the 14th century to the present, by a British publisher and editor who has read about everything and does not fear to evaluate.
 
LOSING NELSON, by Barry Unsworth. (Doubleday, $23.95.) A provocative, absorbing novel whose mad hero hides from his own life by his elaborate identification with Admiral Nelson, a folly he understands well enough to labor at the same time to destroy it.
 
MY MOVIE BUSINESS: A Memoir, by John Irving. (Random House, $19.95.) A measured and genial personal history of seeing Irving's novels made (or not made) into movies; the rancor with which book people are often said to regard film people is nowhere, or hardly anywhere, apparent.
 
PASSAGE TO JUNEAU: A Sea and Its Meanings, by Jonathan Raban. (Pantheon, $26.50.) This hydrophilic traveler describes a physical and intellectual journey with a 35-foot ketch, some books and a deep alertness to what the sea has been up to for the Indians and their successors.
 
RIGHTEOUS VICTIMS: A History of the Zionist-Arab Conflict, 1881-1999, by Benny Morris. (Knopf, $40.) A clinical and credible work by an Israeli historian whose narrative begins with the arrival of the first Zionists and identifies the reciprocal misunderstandings and economies of truth that have plagued both sides ever since.
 
SILENT STARS, by Jeanine Basinger. (Knopf, $35.) A film historian argues that many of the stars of the silents wielded talent and cultural scope that have been forgotten as the films themselves were forgotten, lost or just unseen.
 
SOMEWHERE IN FRANCE, by John Rolfe Gardiner. (Knopf, $24.) A thoughtful, well-built novel whose hero, an American doctor in World War I, becomes estranged from his family and ensorcelled by a French nurse and healer.
 
THE TINY ONE, by Eliza Minot. (Knopf, $22.) Ostensibly an elegy for a mother, this persuasive novel inspects the questing, swerving quality of the life and mind of an 8-year-old girl from her own perspective and those of others.

HEADLINE: Paranoid Enemies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his review of Christopher Andrew and Vasili Mitrokhin's book, "The Sword and the Shield" (Oct. 31), Joseph E. Persico observes, "Paranoia seems to have been a communicable disease in the Kremlin." This is purportedly manifest in the Russian leaders' "absolute conviction that the United States intended a nuclear first strike against the Soviet Union." 
 But consider the background: (1) The United States had already dropped the bomb on the Japanese. (2) The United States later maintained thousands of nuclear weapons permanently targeted at the Soviet Union. (3) The United States in 1954 offered two atomic weapons to France for use at Dienbienphu, an offer that was rejected by the French in order to protect their own troops.
(4) The United States openly threatened nuclear war over Cuba in 1962. (5) The United States consistently refused to adopt a "no first-strike" policy in its official nuclear stance.
Given these and other such precedents, Soviet "paranoia" seems a reasonable inference rather than a mere fantasy.
Incidentally, throughout the cold war American military doctrine was founded on the supposed axiom that a Soviet invasion of Western Europe was imminent. (Remember all those zealous Sovietologists who made a career out of counting Warsaw Pact tanks?) Given what was also well known about both the inefficiency of the Soviet economy and the low morale of Warsaw Pact troops, it is the American stance that truly qualifies as paranoid in its irrationality.
 
G. H. Bell-Villada
Williamstown, Mass.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Hong Kong Is Hoping Disney Magic Rubs Off

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
EVER since it was handed back to China in July 1997, this former British colony has worried obsessively about what it was going to become. Now, it has an answer: Hong Kong will be the next outpost in the Disney empire.
This month, the Walt Disney Company announced plans to build a theme park here, its third outside the United States and second in Asia, after Tokyo Disneyland. While it would be cynical to say that this metropolis of 6.8 million will be defined by Mickey Mouse, it is hard to overstate the impact that officials here believe a Disneyland will have on Hong Kong's image and its tourism industry. 
 "We kind of faded out of the spotlight after 1997, and everybody wrote us off," said Mike Rowse, Hong Kong's tourism commissioner. "This project tells the world that we are alive and kicking."
As the man who negotiated the $3.6 billion deal to bring Disney to Hong Kong, Mr. Rowse is understandably keen to prove its worth. He contends that Hong Kong Disneyland, which is to open in 2005, will pump $19 billion into the economy over four decades, much of it through a revived tourist trade.
Mr. Rowse said that the theme park would attract 1.4 million additional visitors to Hong Kong in its first year, and 2.9 million more annually by the time it is fully developed in 2020. If these projections are accurate -- and the 17.5 million people a year who visit Tokyo Disneyland suggest they might be -- the park would reverse a steady erosion in tourist arrivals since the handover.
Last year, Hong Kong drew 9.5 million visitors, an 8 percent decline from 1997. Much of that can be attributed to the regional economic crisis. But even before that, Hong Kong was becoming less popular. In 1996, nearly 12 million people visited Hong Kong. Many were eager for a last look at a British colonial outpost. Once the Union Jack came down, the crowds went elsewhere.
Officials here note that the number of arrivals has rebounded 11 percent so far this year. But nobody disputes that Hong Kong needed a jolt -- something to remind tourists that it is still probably the most cosmopolitan city in Asia.
Disney executives said Hong Kong's international character was a key reason they chose it over Shanghai and other mainland cities that were lobbying to be the site of the first Chinese Disneyland.
"It's just an incredibly exciting city," said Judson C. Green, chairman of Disney's theme-park division. "It always has been, irrespective of the financial crisis."
Mr. Green said Disney was also attracted by Hong Kong's infrastructure. With a spectacular year-old airport and a gleaming network of roads, railways, tunnels and bridges, Hong Kong is one of Asia's easiest cities to get to and get around in. The site for the proposed Disneyland is in a quiet bay on Lantau Island, conveniently midway between central Hong Kong and the airport and not far from a high-speed train that connects the two.
Like other Magic Kingdoms, the park will have shops, restaurants and theaters -- some with an Asian flavor. It will also have three or four hotels, with a total of 2,100 rooms. Although the hotels could compete with those in Kowloon or central Hong Kong, few hoteliers seem worried.
"It will be a boon for all the hotels, because it will put Hong Kong back on the map," said Robert Hutchinson, former group director of marketing at Shangri-La Hotels and Resorts, a leading Asian chain.
Mr. Hutchinson said that business people traveling to Hong Kong would have an incentive to bring their families; they could stay in the city for a week, then tack on an extra couple of days at a Disney hotel.
To be successful, Hong Kong's Disneyland will also have to attract millions of visitors from mainland China. Officials here said that they planned to work with Beijing to streamline the visa procedures. With opening day five years away, officials are confident of reaching an accommodation.
Even as Disneyland is poised to draw more Chinese visitors to Hong Kong, some people here fret that it will rob the city of its Chinese character. Disney's goal in Hong Kong -- as in Paris and Tokyo -- is to create an idealized version of America that pays little heed to the folkways of the host country.
"At the end of the day, what makes a city great is its ethnic identity," said David Tang, the founder of Shanghai Tang, a boutique that sells pricey clothing with a retro-Mao flavor, mostly to tourists. "This is a Chinese city. We have to cultivate these Chinese elements."
But Mr. Tang is a lonely dissenter. After years of worrying about its future -- fears that were compounded by the Asian crisis -- Hong Kong seems willing to bear the cultural baggage of Disney so long as it brings the crowds back. Besides, people here are used to foreign powers with global ambitions.
