HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Hockey Arena Raises Hopes of a Livelier Trenton

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
CITY officials are hoping that the 8,000-seat minor-league hockey arena opened in Trenton last month will move the state capital another step forward in its revitalization effort.
Called Sovereign Bank Arena, the $50 million project rose over the last year and a half on 20 acres on the west side of Route 129. It is part of the revival of a 45-acre industrial district that was once home to the John A. Roebling & Sons and American Steel & Wire companies, manufacturers of cables for bridges, elevators and trolleys. 
 The project follows the opening in 1994 of a minor league baseball stadium about a mile to the southeast on the Delaware River waterfront. Trenton's mayor, Douglas Palmer, says the stadium has helped the city mute its image as a government center that shuts down by 6 p.m. and become, like other former industrial cities such as Newark and Baltimore, livelier municipalities. The arena project "extends that role," said Mayor Palmer.
Since 1994 other municipalities have followed Trenton's lead in building or planning minor league ball parks. Stadiums have opened in Frankford Township in Sussex County, Newark, Atlantic City and Bridgewater in Somerset County. Others are planned in Lakewood, Camden and North Wildwood.
One other minor-league hockey arena, in Atlantic City, is under way on the boardwalk, where the former convention center is being converted to a special events complex that will include a hockey arena.
Leisure industry professionals said there are several reasons why the growth of hockey arenas will not be as quick as the growth of baseball stadiums. Among them are that arenas are more expensive to build than ball parks and obtaining a hockey franchise is more difficult than obtaining one for a minor league baseball team.
Stoking the growth of sports complexes since 1985 is "a push toward affordable, family-oriented entertainment," said Robert Canton, national director of the sports, convention and leisure division at the Tampa, Fla., office of PricewaterhouseCoopers.
In the last 15 years, 90 minor-league baseball stadiums have been or are being built in the country, according to the office of Minor League Baseball in St. Petersburg, Fla., which governs minor league teams nationwide. That interest, Mr. Canton said, has spilled over to hockey arenas in the last five years.
Officials involved with stadium and arena projects said they not only were a way to compete for entertainment dollars, but also promoted economic development.
While Mr. Canton said such developments -- which, for the most part, are largely publicly financed -- can "generate a new level of interest" in municipalities, he cautioned against viewing them "as the sole catalyst to transforming blighted areas." Mr. Canton said that to increase the chances for success such projects should "be part of an overall plan to attract investment."
In Atlantic City, the ballpark and arena projects are considered a way "to bring family entertainment to the oceanside resort and establish it as more than just a gaming town," said James Kennedy, executive director of the state's Casino Reinvestment Authority. The authority, created under a 1984 state law to channel revenue from the casinos into urban renewal, and the city financed both projects.
THE $14.5 million, 6,000-seat stadium opened in 1998 as home of the Atlantic City Surf, an independent franchise in the Atlantic League. The site, 25 city-owned acres on Albany Avenue at the edge of an old municipal airport, is seven blocks from the Tropicana and the Hilton, the nearest casinos.
The stadium "will not have too much of an economic ripple effect," Mr. Kennedy said. He noted, however, that "it gives the city prestige and another amenity," adding that the long-term plan was to turn the land adjacent to the stadium into a recreation and park area, where an ice-skating rink is planned.
Mr. Kennedy said the hockey arena -- as part of the $76 million renovation of the city's landmark former boardwalk convention center into an entertainment complex -- was expected to have greater impact on economic development than the baseball stadium.
In addition to being home to the Atlantic City Admirals, an East Coast Hockey League team that is moving from Hampton Roads, Va., the 1,200-seat complex will also be the site of concerts and other sporting events, as well as the annual Miss America Pageant. The complex, scheduled for completion by 2001, will complement the $268 million convention center, which opened in 1997 in the city along with an adjoining 500-room Sheraton Hotel.
Trenton and Mercer County leaders say the baseball stadium and hockey arena are two anchors in an overall plan they describe as linking together a triangle of economic development. The third anchor is a $50 million, 199-room hotel and conference center, the city's first in decades. Construction of the full-service hotel, to be managed by Marriott, is to start next month.
"We expect all three to feed off one another," Mayor Palmer said, noting that while there had been some traffic and parking impacts they were outweighed by the benefits.
The $23 million 6,150-seat baseball stadium is home to the Trenton Thunder, an affiliate of the Boston Red Sox. Attendance has averaged 440,000 a year, out of a possible 461,000, said Joseph Caruso, one of the owners of the team.
The stadium, part of a larger riverfront revival project that ultimately will include other recreational amenities like a fishing pier and an amphitheater, also has spurred the conversion of a nearby vacant factory to a restaurant/nightclub.
AND 18 months ago the Advance Group, of Bedminster, bought three adjacent half-empty office buildings with a total of 230,000 square feet, renovated them and brought them to full occupancy on a site Advance called Riverview at Trenton. The company is now negotiating for a 100,000-square-foot structure, the last building on the site,. and plans to start construction of a 750-car parking structure next year. It also plans to build a 400,000-square-foot, two-building retail and office complex as well as a second 750-car garage on the site.
"The stadium is not a panacea" said Stephen J. Kukan, senior vice president of business development at Advance. "But it shows the germ is in place for a serious revitalization effort, which bodes well for the growth of the city and, in turn, our investment."
The Sovereign Bank Arena, home to the Trenton Titans, part of the East Coast Hockey League, will also be the site of some 165 events, including concerts and other events, for which the seating will be expanded to 10,000.
The arena is considered the second phase of the redevelopment of the former Roebling complex, where the Berman Development Company L.L.C. of Trenton has built 181,000 square feet of office and retail space and is planning to build 50,000 more square feet of offices. A city-sponsored housing project -- 75 rental units for the elderly -- is also in place and work continues on the conversion of the former Roebling machine shop to a museum and science center.
Berman sold the land for the arena to the county and built it at a cost of $50 million, which includes the company's development fee. An additional $10 million was spent on street and parking improvements.
Ronald Berman, the company's chief executive and part owner of the hockey team, said 5,150 season tickets had been sold for its maiden hockey season this year,, indicating the arena so far has not competed with the ball park. There are also some early signs of an economic ripple effect, he said, pointing to an increase in business for area restaurants.
Agreeing with that assessment is Roland Pott, one of the developers and owners of the Urban Word Cafe, which opened last April on South Broad Street, across from the arena. In the early months business "was tough because there was little walk-by traffic," Mr. Pott said, adding that since the arena opened "sales have jumped."
He said it would also help his future development plans. The cafe and an adjacent bookstore occupy one of four buildings along South Broad Street with a total of 20,000 square feet that Mr. Pott said he and his partners had acquired. He said the other three buildings would be occupied by a nightclub, office space and artist studios.
Mayor Palmer said the challenge now was "to connect the transportation dots among the redevelopment areas and with the support of the hotel develop a market for overnight stays." While it's still too early to say what the arena and the stadium projects will really do, he said that they had accelerated the timetable to get to that goal.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Island's Second Hotel in a Decade to Open in a Month

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY

 BODY:
BARRING any unforeseen hitches, the 130-room, five-story Wingate Inn under construction here on Stewart Avenue is scheduled to open next month.
It will be only the second hotel to open on Long Island in more than a decade, following a 104-room Extended StayAmerica in Bethpage that accepted its first guests on June 30. 
 One other hotel is now under construction on Long Island, a 134-room facility in Melville that will also be part of the Extended Stay America chain. Another hotel is expected to start construction this winter, two others have all approvals and several more are in various stages of the planning process. In addition, older hotels are being upgraded and expanded.
Is there too much hotel construction? "Not for the demand," said Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, a Commack-based business group, adding that room rates had "risen nicely."
Over a six-year period ended Sept. 30, occupancy rates on Long Island have risen from 63.6 to 76.8 percent and average room rates have risen from $75.21 to $111.44 a night, according to Smith Travel Research of Hendersonville, Tenn., an independent research agency that tracks hotels of 20 or more rooms.
"However," Dr. Kamer cautioned, "if the economy softens and business travel abates, that might be a different story."
The Garden City Wingate is representative of a new generation of hotels aimed especially at business travelers that dispenses with amenities such as the swimming pool and restaurant-bar of more traditional lodgings in return for lower rates.
The emphasis at the Wingate is on accommodating the business client, with an around-the-clock business center that will offer free facsimile transmissions anywhere in the United States and a computer, printer and copier. Rooms will have free high-speed Internet T-1 lines and two-line phones with a speaker, data port, voice mail and conference-call capabilities. The hotel will also have a meeting room with seating for 90 and a conference room for 12 people.
The "rack rates," an industry term for room rates without discounts, will be $139 a night until April 1 when they rise to $149 a night. But that is still far below those of a full-service hotel. At the nearby luxurious Garden City Hotel, rates range from $250 to $375 a night.
The Wingate will also have 12 suites, able to accommodate four to six people. Rates range from $179 to $209 a night; prices include breakfast.
"First and foremost, travelers want affordable accommodations," said Albert L. Salvatico, the developer of the $13.5 million Wingate, which will be managed by Hospitality Management of Garden City whose partners are Alan Fairbairn and Mr. Salvatico's brother, Louis L.
Albert Salvatico, who is an insurance executive, said he became a hotel developer "because I travel a lot so I know what travelers want and I also saw a good opportunity."
"As people see the hotels doing as well as they're doing and occupancies being so high, new people want to come into the marketplace with more hotel rooms because they see it as a place where they can make a profit," said Michael Hollander, president of the Long Island Convention & Visitors Bureau and Sports Commission in Hauppauge.
Robert Lipper, president of Island-Metro Publications in Farmingdale, which publishes tourist and economic guides and tracks the hotel industry, estimated that 25 proposals for hotels were on the table, ranging from "someone saying we'd like to put a hotel up to people who are filing applications."
He estimated, however, that no more than 10 of the 25 were "serious proposals." Of those, he said, perhaps 6 would be built adding only about 1,000 new rooms to the region's current supply of about 15,000 rooms in all types of facilities including bed-and-breakfast inns.
Extended Stay America, a rapidly growing chain that owns and operates 352 hotels in 38 states, expects to open its Melville hotel early next year. It is seeking approvals from the Town of Brookhaven to build yet another with 104 rooms in Medford.
UNTIL Extended Stay America's entry into the Long Island market, the concept of providing rooms with kitchenettes for travelers who expect to stay a week or longer was available only at the 160-room Marriott Residence Inn in Plainview.
Now this type of accommodation is becoming the fastest growing segment of the Long Island industry. Another chain, Homewood Suites, is entering the market with a 138-room hotel to be built in Ronkonkomaa on Veterans Memorial Highway by a joint venture of Pitcairn-Parr of Ronkonkoma and Linchris Hotel Partners of Hanover, Mass. The hotel is expected to start construction this winter and to open a year later.
Demand for extended stay hotels, said Dr. Kamer of the Long Island Association, is a reflection of the growth of high technology companies on Long Island. "You have business travelers from other parts of the country and from around the world who come here for extended periods of time and don't want to rent an apartment," she said.
The average stay at an Extended StayAmerica hotel is three to four weeks, said Michael Wilson, vice president of marketing for the publicly traded company, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. At the Bethpage hotel, room rates for a 300-square-foot room with a fully equipped kitchenette are $469 a week and $94 a night and the hotel began achieving full occupancy within 30 days of opening, Mr. Wilson said.
The Homewood Suites hotel will be more upscale, with two-room suites and a full kitchen. The four-story building will have a traditional colonial-style design with a peaked roof and a brick exterior. Amenities will include an indoor pool, a business center, and a small convenience store for guests. Breakfast will be included in the rates, which have not yet been determined.
"Currently, there are no extended stay facilities in Suffolk County, and there is a need because of the way the economy has moved," said William A. Mullaney, senior vice president of Linchris Hotel Partners, which also owns the Hampton Inn in Commack.
Homewood Suites and Hampton Inns are both brand names of the Promus Hotel Corporation of Memphis.
Among hotels still needing approvals is a project by the J. D. Carlisle Development Corporation of Manhattan. The developer, which is about to start construction on a 268,000-square-foot shopping center on Carleton Avenue in Central Islip, has submitted plans to the Town of Islip for a $26 million, 225-room hotel that it proposes to build on the east side of Carleton Avenue, near the federal and state courts complex.
"We feel pretty sanguine about the project because we have several major chains, both extended-stay and full-service hotels, coming to us with offers," said Jules Demchick, Carlisle's president.
Some major investments are also being made by operators of existing hotels. The 35-year-old, 120-room Holiday Inn in Plainview, for example, is in the midst of being converted from a motel to a hotel. Rooms that had outside entrances are to be entered from interior corridors. When completed in the spring of 2000, the $7 million renovation will include a new lobby and a two-story addition with two meeting rooms on the ground level and six hotel rooms on its second floor. The restaurant and ballroom and the outdoor pool are also being refurbished.
THE 209-room Sheraton Long Island in Smithtown is also undergoing a $7 million renovation. "We have a very strong base of business, and to be competitive you have to invest money into your hotel," said Gary D. Tucker, the Sheraton's general manager. He said that there is still a strong demand for full-service hotels, which the Sheraton represents. Occupancy there is in the 80 percent range, he noted.
But industry observers are expressing some caution, saying that the demand for hotel rooms, which had been climbing over the last six years, is leveling off and that the market could be hurt if too many new rooms come on line, especially if the economy softens.
"If you have too many rooms, occupancy goes down, rates fall, and hotels get into trouble financially because they can't meet their debt service," said Mr. Lipper of Island-Metro Publications.
William A. Mullaney Jr., general manager of the Hampton Inn in Commack as well as president of the Long Island Hotel and Motel Association, noted, however, that hotel development on Long Island would always be limited because of the scarcity of land and the difficult approval process.
For example, a hotel was a permitted use for the 2.25-acre site occupied by the Garden City Wingate. Still, it took one year to get variances and three years to bring the project to completion, Albert Salvatico said.
John Tsunis, a Hauppauge lawyer and a hotel developer, said it took him two years to get approvals for two hotels he intends to build -- one with 139 rooms in Hauppauge, the other with 168 rooms in Farmingville.
Financing is beginning to become harder to get, Mr. Lipper noted. "One of the first things to get cut if the economy changes is travel and entertainment," he said. "The banks are becoming more cautious because so many got burned the last time around."

HEADLINE: A LA CARTE;
A Sophisticated Meal, Easy on the Wallet

BYLINE: By RICHARD JAY SCHOLEM 

 BODY:
IF appetizers are the apple of your eye, do I have a restaurant for you. It's called the California Cafe, but on weeknights, from 4 to 7, the bar and lounge area becomes appetizer heaven. That's when the price of every starter, including soups, salads and light entrees, is cut in half. Diners who enjoy the creativity, diversity, economy pr ordering two or three appetizers rather than conventional entree-centered meals will be delighted with the choices and fun available at this sleek Roosevelt Field Shopping Mall spot in Garden City (516-294-8686). Add a glass of any house wine for $3, and on Monday nights any bottle for half its regular price, and you have a varied and sophisticated feast for a virtual pittance.
A recent 12-dish spread for 4, complete with a bottle and two glasses of wine, cost $73. It was eaten off a paper-covered white tablecloth at a comfortable banquette of the warm, woody bar and lounge. (There is seating at the handsome mirror-backed bar or a number of tiny, uncovered cafe tables as well.) The California Cafe is anything but a typical shopping-center eatery. It is a handsome, even luxurious place that serves innovative West Coast dishes, often with Asian twists and turns, prepared by Daniel O'Connor, a talented chef. On weekends valet parking is available. 
 The 17 appetizers and light entrees on the menu in the bar and lounge are identical in size, quality and configuration to those in the dining room. The chef's warm, porous focaccia and crusty onion rolls tasted even better when dipped in the extra virgin olive oil available on every table; mibbling them made the task of choosing which and how many appetizers an agreeable one.
Dinner-sized plates, holding everything from dainty, fire-roasted Maine lobster to a huge sirloin burger (both $5.48) began arriving in short order along with a $23 bottle of Parducci pinot noir that was now $11.50. Although it's difficult to pick one dish over another when confronted with a virtual smorgasbord, some observations are possible. Definitely order soups ($1.75 cup, $2.25 bowl), though California-style salads ($2.75 to $3.48) are a close second choice. So-called light entrees ($4.98 to $5.98) are gigantic; diet-conscious eaters should target the Asian-influenced listings. The fried calamari ($3.48) was the single most outstanding dish we tried.
Both the soup of the day, a husky, warming puree of tomato-based vegetables, dense with navy beans, and the menu's portobello mushroom bisque were simply superb. The latter was creamy and rich but not so much so that it obscured the mushrooms' woodsy flavor. Aside from the absence of hearts in the hearts of romaine (just outer leaves), all the salads -- , a classic Caesar, a simple sprightly mix of baby, organic greens and especially the country concoction -- were first rate. The culinary counterpoint of goat cheese and dried cranberries in the country salad and the crusty spiced pecans in it and the romaine were noteworthy.
That thick, medium-rare sirloin burger on a warm bun, with nubbins of melting Gorgonzola cheese, sauteed mushrooms and caramelized onions came with thin, addictive french fries lightly coated with a pesto of garlic, olive oil and parsley. An even larger light entree is the towering Oriental chicken salad ($5.98). Crowned with carrot hay and daikon sprouts and ringed by wispy cucumber rounds and crisp fried won tons, this colossus of Napa cabbage, onions, red peppers, enoki mushrooms, fried rice sticks, roasted almonds, carrots and grilled chicken strips, dressed in soy vinaigrette, is, as Mr. O'Connor says, "out of control."
The diners at our table were out of control when we devoured that tender, crisp, lighter than air, world-class calamari, with its pulpy, lively plum tomato and caper remoulade sauces. Aside from the Oriental chicken, the Asian contingent consisted of grilled chicken and smoked shiitake spring rolls ($3.48) presented with crunchy citrus jicama and hoisin barbecue sauce and a Thai beef and rock shrimp wrap ($4.98), soft, marinated meat and substantial shrimp in a mango sesame vinaigrette. The cold Maine lobster, a tiny taste of tail and claw meat strikingly turned out with a fan of cucumbers, asparagus, mango, watercress and dressed in a lemony vanilla bean vinaigrette, was overwhelmed by that citrus dressing.
 
Openings
When Mino Fazio was the chef at the now closed Da Mino in Port Washington, Nick Di Pacquale was one of his admirers. Now the two of them are partners at La Toscana, a new 100-seat storefront restaurant at 284 Glen Street in Glen Cove (516-759-1913) that opened last month where Il Vilero had been. Mr. Fazio, who is from Bari, Italy, said that his dinner entrees are priced from $17 (veal with shrimp) to $24 (veal chop).
 The Sea Port Restaurant, at 415 Main Street in Port Washington (516-883-3030), is the new name of Da Mino, an Italian eating place that was on this site. Paul Ram, the new chef who previously worked at Da Vinci and the Frog and the Peach, is now cooking more seafood than Da Mino offered. Steaks, chops and Italian dishes are also available.

HEADLINE: In Denver, Nostalgia in a New $50 Million Enclave

BYLINE: By MINDY SINK

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
FOR more than a century, the Elitch Gardens Amusement Park here was a place where families gathered for summer entertainment, picnics or just a stroll. Now, as houses replace roller coasters on the old site, the developers' hope is that those traditions will continue.
"There is a great phrase that the best cities have one foot in nostalgia, and one foot in prophecy," said Jonathan F. P. Rose, a developer based in Katonah, N.Y., who has joined a Denver developer and restaurateur, Chuck Perry, to form the Perry/Affordable Housing Development Corporation. "Some part of them reaches back to their past and the other to their future, and we really tried to do that here." 
 Mr. Perry and Mr. Rose bought the old amusement park site last year, four years after it had closed, and are building a $50 million mixed-use project there called Highlands' Garden Village. It is scheduled for completion in 2002.
The property, about three miles northwest of downtown Denver, is the first of three large mixed-use developments to go into construction here. The others are to be at the former Stapleton Airport and the old Lowry Air Force base.
So far, three homes are occupied and two dozen are under construction at Highlands' Garden Village. Later, stores and offices are to be built within walking distance of the homes. In the center of the site are two remnants of the amusement park's glory days -- the historic theater and the carousel house, which are to be restored. To date, 25 of the 31 detached houses in the first phase have been sold, with prices ranging from $200,000 to more than $300,000. The architect is Wolff-Lyon of nearby Boulder.
Following a master plan created by Calthorpe Associates of Berkeley, Calif., Highlands' Garden Village is designed to make the new homes and buildings blend in with the older, existing neighborhood around the site of the old amusement park, where family-owned shops and restaurants are within walking distance of the homes -- an element that Mr. Rose and Mr. Perry are now trying to emulate.
Most of the development's 51 houses will face existing homes outside the perimeter of the site. Like them, they will have a traditional look, with front porches and garages in the rear, reached from alleys between the houses. Some will have attached carriage houses with separate entrances above the garage, which may be used as rental apartments.
In later phases of the project, there will be a three-story housing complex with 63 apartments for the elderly; an 8-building, 90-unit apartment complex; 37 row houses and 90,000 square feet of commercial space. There will also be large areas of open space for community gardens and parks, a day-care center and possibly 23 live/work areas that are expected to be for artists.
In addition, the plan calls for a 34-unit co-housing complex -- where families live in their own homes, but are clustered together and share maintenance chores, child-care and meal preparation. The co-housing units are to have one to four bedrooms, and be priced from $140,000 to $250,000.
THE Elitch Gardens Amusement Park opened in 1890 on a broad hill that was considered remote from the bustling downtown at the time. It offered the public everything from botanical gardens to wild animals and thrill rides to big-name entertainers.
"When Elitch's left in 1994, it left a hole in the neighborhood," said Mr. Perry, whose home and restaurant are nearby. "There was a lot of uncertainty and concern about what would happen. This was not considered a 'hot' neighborhood then. It has always been primarily working-class."
Part of the development process involved meeting with community groups and residents who had endured long summers listening to the shrieks of riders on the Twister, the roller coaster at the park.
"I think the developers kept the good elements -- the theater, the gardens, the parks -- and it's no loss at all losing the amusement park," said Mary Riffle, who has lived across the street for 30 years. The developers plan three acres of parks and gardens.
The centerpiece of the project is actually a leftover from the park -- the historic octagonal two-story theater that was not only America's longest surviving summer stock showcase, but also where the first movies were shown in Denver and where stars such as Grace Kelly and Sarah Bernhardt appeared.
Currently, Perry/AHDC is trying to find a nonprofit organization that will renovate and run the theater with cultural events such as films, music festivals or plays.
"There is such a love and almost mysticism attached to this theater," Mr. Rose said. "What could we replace it with that could be any better? A shopping center? There's nothing we could do that would be better than this. These buildings come with such a heritage of goodwill that we can build upon."
Another remnant from the old park that has been incorporated into the design is the old carousel house, which will now serve as a gazebo near the restored "diagonal park" and the day care center. The carousel itself -- along with most of the rides from Elitch's -- was moved in 1995 when the owners relocated closer to downtown Denver in the Platte River Valley.
And there are other, less obvious, vestiges of days gone by. Elitch's was known as much for its gardens as for the Tilt-a-Whirl. Mr. Rose proudly points out that the honeylocust trees next to one of the completed houses had been moved within the park. Tulip bulbs were saved and will be replanted throughout the development in gardens and along walkways.
Although the novelty of the site's history makes it intriguing, it is actually the smallest of similar projects being developed in east Denver. One is at the former Stapleton Airport site on 4,700 acres, which is expected to have a mix of 12,000 residences and 17 million square feet of office and retail space. The other is at the old Lowry Air Force base on 1,866 acres, which is expected to have 4,000 homes and apartments and 2 million square feet of office and retail space.
All three of the developments hope to include schools and grocery stores, and there is a plan for a church at the former Stapleton Airport.
Mr. Rose considers these projects the recycling of previously developed land. "We're not reducing the supply of farmland, we're not destroying a forest, we're working where there's existing land," he said. "We're also working on existing infrastructure. A huge amount of environmental impact comes from the creation of new roads and new water and sewer systems."
Mr. Rose is a son of the late Frederick P. Rose, who was chairman of Rose Associates, a major owner-developer of housing in New York City. He left the family business in 1989 and now divides his time between his home office in Katonah and the Rocky Mountain region.
"At the time I started my business here, which is affordable housing, it was very difficult to do development work on the East Coast because of the recession," he said. "I had done some work in Santa Fe, and I love the Rocky Mountains, physically, the environment, the taste of the air."
Mr. Rose and Mr. Perry did their first project together in 1993, when they redeveloped the Denver Dry Goods building in the 16th Street Mall downtown.
The once-crumbling 104-year-old former department store now has 51 loft residences mixed with office space and a large retail space on the ground floor. The Denver Urban Renewal Authority extended partial financing both to that project and to Highlands' Garden Village.

HEADLINE: In Good Times, Cosmetic Surgery

BYLINE: By JOAN SWIRSKY 

 BODY:
WHAT price beauty? For Iris Grosso, 54, a divorced office manager from Great Neck, it was $20,500, which covered the cost of the face lift she had in August and the tummy tuck and liposuction she had in September on her thighs, stomach and knees. That doesn't include the cost of removing the bags under her eyes and the brow lift she had in 1993, or the nose job she had at 16.
She said her mother paid for her first operations and left her some money after she died that she used for her recent surgery. "I talked to my mother at the graveside," she explained, "and I knew she'd be happy I was doing this." 
 "I hated my parakeet nose and everybody saying 'Polly want a cracker?' to me," Ms. Grosso said, "and I always hated the bags under my eyes that I think I was born with. When I got older, I hated my turkey chin and jowls. Now I feel like a million dollars, and when people see me, they go bananas. They say, 'I can't believe you're going to be a grandma.' "
Ms. Grosso's willingness to spend tens of thousands of dollars on improving her looks is common on Long Island. With a high average income and a booming economy, Long Islanders are spending millions on cosmetic surgery, even though medical insurance covers the costly procedures only for patients who are disfigured by illness or injury.
The exact number of procedures performed on Long Island is not known, but a spokeswoman for the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons said the leading procedures in New York State were liposuction (16,647), eyelid surgery (11,315) and rhinoplasty (12,722). Only 5,687 breast augmentation procedures were performed, as opposed to 20,026 in California.
"It's an across-the-board phenomenon," said Dr. Frederick N. Lukash, 52, a plastic surgeon from Manhasset, referring to the teenagers, young adults and baby-boomers, male and female, who seek cosmetic surgery.
"People used to watch 'Father Knows Best,' but now they watch 'Baywatch,' where no one is dressed and they see all those perfect bodies, and they want them," Dr. Lukash said. "It's a youth-oriented society."
Cosmetic surgery patients are also less shy about telling the world than they used to be. "Plastic surgery, like psychiatry, used to be a private matter," Dr. Lukash said, "but today everything is an open book."
Edythe Guthy, a 33-year-old hairdresser from Levittown, is thrilled with her new figure. After losing 100 pounds and giving birth to two children, she found that her breasts had "no roundness and they were very unattractive." She paid for her breast augmentation with a loan from a finance company, although her fiance at the time told her "he loved me for what I am, with or without the surgery."
She said she opted for the surgery "to give me more self-confidence, which it did." Her fiance, who became her husband, "loves them," she said.
Dr. Robert Gotkin, 45, a plastic surgeon from Greenvale, confirmed that "breast enlargement is among the most popular choices, and this procedure and liposuction have replaced the nose job as the graduation presents du jour in the teenage set." About 25 percent of people having liposuction are men, he added.
Many of his patients seek cosmetic surgery "to stay viable in the workplace," Dr. Gotkin said. Other patients include widows and divorced people "who want to look better in order to meet someone new."
Mollie Seltzer, 55, a Manorhaven resident who works for a lighting company, nursed her second husband through four years of cancer treatment before he died two years ago. "We were married for 22 years," she said, "and when I looked in the mirror, I could see the toll all the stress had taken on my face. I looked haggard, 10 years older from all the crying." She decided to have a face lift, a brow lift, a rejuvenation for her eyes, and laser surgery around her mouth for the "lipstick bleed lines" common in former smokers.
"The thought of having general anesthesia was so scary that I almost canceled the night before," she said, "but I wasn't scared enough to not do it." The results were "worth it," she added. "Everyone said I looked beautiful, and when the U.P.S. driver at work told me I looked wonderful, I told him I had gone away on a two-week cruise.'
Ms. Seltzer recently read that "a woman over 35 has a better chance of being kidnapped by a terrorist than of meeting her soul mate, and it's true," she said. "Now, men notice me more than they did before, even younger men, and it makes me feel very good. But I did this for me, and I'll be doing it again when I'm 65. I tell my friends, 'Just go and do it.' "
Dr. Lukash said: "The root of everything we do comes down to self-esteem." He cited as poor candidates for surgery the woman who wants breast augmentation because her boyfriend likes big breasts, or the teenager whose parents both had rhinoplasty and want the same surgery for their child. "I say to these patients, 'The only reason for you to have this surgery is because you want it.' "
Dr. Gotkin added: "Sometimes a patient is depressed, and they want surgery for all the wrong reasons: they were rejected, or their spouse is having an affair." Other patients may have body dysmorphic disorder, he explained, in which they are disproportionately fixated on some aspect of their appearance. "In this case, they often need counseling or psychiatric help."
Prices vary from region to region, but on Long Island the cost of rhinoplasty is generally $7,500; a face lift, $10,000; breast augmentation, $5,000; breast reduction, $10,000, and liposuction about $3,000 per anatomical site. None of these figures, however, include anesthesia and use of the operating and recovery rooms, which will add at least $1,000 to the total bill.
The American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons reports that more than two million plastic surgery procedures were performed nationwide in 1998. Of these, just over half were for reconstruction or repair after trauma, tumor removal and lacerations, the kind of work many plastic surgeons view as the core of their practice.
But it's the cosmetic surgery that pays for their Mercedes-Benzes. The business is so lucrative that it now includes a sizable but uncounted number of cosmetic procedures performed by dermatologists, ophthalmologists, dentists and other doctors who have gone outside their specialties to supplement their incomes with high-ticket procedures.
"Many of these specialists gravitate towards cosmetic surgery because their incomes have taken such a hit from managed care," Dr. Gotkin said. "They try to bolster diminishing incomes with elective, out-of-pocket procedures that are free of the encumbrances of the insurance industry. But most don't have the background or training to perform these procedures safely, nor the ability to deal with potential complications."
Age will eventually take its toll, of course, on even the finest face lift. But many people opt for truly temporary cosmetic procedures that won't last much longer than a hair-coloring job. And cosmetic surgeons report a rise in demand for these quick fixes as the millennium approaches.
Dr. Stephen Greenberg, a Great Neck surgeon, offers a package that includes a "power peel" to smooth and polish the skin, collagen injections to get rid of deep facial lines, and botox injections to decrease crow's feet around the eyes and lines in the forehead. The effects can last several months, he said. Prices vary by procedure but run into the hundreds of dollars.
Dr. Deborah S. Sarnoff, a cosmetic surgeon from Greenvale, said her "21st-century look-good, feel-great package" will remove age spots, unwanted hair on the chin and upper lip, and broken blood vessels in the face. She includes a facial, makeup application and skin-care regimen to maintain the new you."
"People are more interested in looking great for this once-in-a-lifetime experience," she said, "than they are in any potential Y2K problems."

HEADLINE: HOME REPAIR;
Carpentry, Asian Style: Using Japanese Handaws

BYLINE: By EDWARD R. LIPINSKI

 BODY:
MOST Japanese tools, planes, hammers and chisels are similar in appearance and design to their Western counterparts. Japanese handsaws, however, are different from handsaws designed and manufactured by European and American toolmakers because they cut on the pull stroke, not the push stroke.
Experts are not sure how this came about -- other Asian countries, like China and Korea -- have push-cut saws like ours. Some historians believe the Japanese handsaw was developed to cut the soft, straight-grained cedar and cypress woods that are the primary building materials of Japanese carpenters. Other authorities think the saw was designed to fit the needs of Japanese woodworkers, who work primarily from a seated position holding the work with their bare feet. 
 Japanese saws look different; they have long handles fixed in line with the blade. Since they cut on the pull stroke, not the push stroke, the blade is not under tension so there is no tendency for it to bind and bend as it cuts. Consequently blades on Japanese saws are harder and thinner and have more teeth per inch than Western saws. This means that the blades will cut faster and with less effort than a push saw, and because they are easier to control it is possible to make more accurate cuts.
Traditionally, Japanese saws were made entirely by hand. The saw maker forged a laminated blade blank, then cut and tempered the teeth. The blades were then fitted with a wooden handle wrapped with rattan. Today most saw blades are made from factory-rolled steel with the teeth cut by a power grinder fitted with a diamond wheel. While the wooden handle is still popular, many manufacturers are turning to more contemporary materials, like nylon, to fashion handles.
There are three types of Japanese saw: the dozuki, the ryoba and the azebiki. Each saw is designed for a specific use. In Japanese the word dozuki means shoulder or tenon, and the dozuki saw is used in cabinet making to cut dovetails and tenons. The dozuki has a thin blade with a single row of teeth. Some dozuki saws have a stiffening spine (usually made of brass) to keep the blade stiff and straight.
The ryoba is the traditional carpenter's general-purpose saw. It has a long straight blade with teeth on both sides -- crosscut teeth on one side and rip teeth on the other. This makes the ryoba an economical tool to buy because you get two cutting tools for the price of one. A ryoba blade is flexible, so you can work in tight quarters bending the handle away from the blade to keep from scraping your knuckles on the work.
Some ryobas, and a few dozukis, have blades that curve along the leading edge. The teeth, sometimes called "woodpecker" teeth, along this rounded edge allow you to make a plunge or pocket cut in the middle of the work without drilling a pilot hole first.
The azebiki has a short curved blade with teeth on both sides. The blade design makes it easy to make pocket cuts -- cuts in the middle of a panel -- and to cut in very tight spaces. This saw can also be pulled along a straight lie to make precise cuts.
Cutting with a Japanese saw takes a little bit of practice. Novices usually adopt a stance more natural to the western sawyer and grip the saw with one hand. However, greater control and accuracy can be gained by gripping the handle with two hands. Most western saws are positioned at a 45-degree angle for cutting, but Japanese saws cut better if they are held closer to the work at a shallow 10- to 20-degree angle. This puts more teeth in contact with the work so the cutting is faster and more accurate. It is also easier to operate the saw if the work is positioned below waist level.
In general, position your body directly in front of the cut and pull the saw toward you. It is easier and more accurate to start the cut by holding the saw with one hand while using the other to guide the blade; the fingers should be near the center of the blade not near the teeth. As the saw cuts into the wood, move the guide hand to grip the handle. Do not apply any downward pressure; instead let the teeth bite into the wood as you pull the saw.
Japanese saws can cost from $20 to $50, although it is possible to pay as much as $250 for a fine, handcrafted model. Admittedly most neighborhood hardware stores and even the average home center do not carry them. Instead, you will have to buy them through a mail order supplier.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
The March of Progress

BYLINE: By JEFFREY RUBIN; Jeffrey Rubin is a professor of economics at Rutgers University.

 BODY:
SOMETIMES I wonder if all the attention to facts, figures and the future -- test scores, college placement statistics and so on -- ignores the importance of the day-to-day experiences high schools provide our children. In the language of the economist, there may be as much to the consumption benefits of school as there is to the investment aspect of school.
I bring this up because every year for the last eight, my wife and I have spent a good part of our weekends following our two sons and about 200 of their schoolmates as they performed with the high school marching band. For us, long night and weekend music practices, half-time shows at football games and spirited band competitions are as much a sign of autumn as cleaning leaves from the gutter or moving the summer clothes to the cedar closet. 
 We are band parents, a very odd species, more common in New Jersey than one would suspect. The members of this species spend a great deal of time watching the band perfect its show. On occasion they do venture out of the stadiums, dressed in school colors, if only to help sell decals or pester friends and relatives to buy candy. More likely, they can be found riding long distances on school buses jammed with teenagers trying to change from street clothes to band uniforms, or hidden away in high school sewing rooms stitching yet another uniform for the color guard. We are grown-up groupies.
We've been lucky; our two trumpets have enjoyed success on the football fields of New Jersey without ever have to strap on a helmet or get knocked unconscious trying to tackle a running back. (No one's child actually plays an instrument. Instead, we refer to our children as being a trumpet or tuba or clarinet. They and their instrument become one.)
On a Saturday earlier this month, we completed another season, culminating just as the seven before had. Under the artificially illuminated night sky, in the cold and wind of Giants Stadium, our band, the Piscataway High School Superchiefs, was one of nine in the Group V Open event. Bands, and their entourages of parents and siblings, aunts and uncles, came from five states to vie for the title.
The crowd oohed and aahed, applauded and rang cowbells or shook milk containers loaded with coins to spur on their band. Images of each band and its formations filled the giant screen high above the stadium.
Between performances, the screen offered a recorded message from Meryl Streep and Gloria Estefan. They recited the virtues of music education and pleaded with us to get involved in local school decisions to ensure a vibrant and expansive music program. Talk about preaching to the choir. I suspect that many in the crowd are frequent participants in school budget debates. We like to think that the pride our town takes in its marching band plays a role in our reasonably good record of passing budgets with enough money to maintain a strong music program.
As the final band completed its performance, Saturday night had turned into Sunday morning, and the cold wind blew pods from the nearby marsh grass across the field. The clock was nearing 1:30 a.m. The announcer turned his attention to the Group V results, reporting each band's score, from lowest to highest. It came down to just two bands; the Superchiefs and their perennial rivals from Pennsylvania.
Finishing second was a great accomplishment for our kids, but it is hard on the band parents. Year after year, a lot of people, young and old, learn some valuable lessons during band season; some are just a little harder to take than others.
After a cooling-off period that lasted as long as it took to drive from exit 16W to exit 10 on the turnpike, plus a few minutes of grumbling about the judges, our attention returned to the students and their teachers. And at 3 a.m., when the nine buses returned to the high school, the band parents were there to cheer this year's band. Mixed with the disappointment and sadness was the opportunity for parent and child to embrace and then walk away, knowing all the hours and all the work were worth it.
So, as the media and the policy analysts and the parents of New Jersey's children struggle to understand all the data available to evaluate school quality, my suggestion is that everyone take a closer look at the extracurricular opportunities a school district offers. Based on my experience, there is no better place to start than with the high school's marching band.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Welfare Reform Is a Success, So Voters Are Led to Believe

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
Only a group of Democrats would give up a perfectly good Sunday evening at home, with the Broncos and the Seahawks still playing football, for crying out loud, to go hear about the problems of the poor.
Yet there they were, members of the Princeton Community Democratic Organization, sitting in the Princeton Borough Hall and hearing not just the statistics but the very names and stories of the men and women and kids who have not yet been pushed or pulled out of welfare -- the verb is politically significant -- by Work First New Jersey, the state's welfare reform plan. 
 Everyone has heard about the great success of welfare reform, which combines a stick -- a five-year limit on the dole -- with numerous carrots, including help with child care, medical care, housing and transportation. A preliminary study of the system by Mathematica Policy Research has found that about 35 percent of 1,400 welfare families had left the rolls and found jobs that paid an average of $1,600 a month, nearly double the $800 average for those in the study who remained on welfare.
Good news for the success stories, certainly, although $1,600 a month is hardly easy street. But the 50 so men and women who met last Sunday were worried about the failures, the 27 percent in Mathematica's survey who were neither working nor receiving benefits, or the 12 percent who reported no means of support. Who were they, the organizers wanted to know on Sunday night, and who are they here in Mercer County, the capital county?
"The average age of the homeless in Mercer County is seven," said Sheldon Sturges, the president of the Princeton Democrats. The county's only homeless shelter, the Sleep-E-Hollow Motel on Route One in Lawrence, was flooded by Tropical Storm Floyd, and the homeless are now being sent to Pennsylvania, "like our garbage," Mr. Sturges added. "Twenty-sixe thousand people in Mercer County are living in povery, and 9,500 of them are children," he said.
Mr. Sturges added: "It's true that the welfare rolls are falling. But it's also true that the bottom 12 percent are falling off the face of the earth."
The Democrats maintained that the state government, which is run by Republicans, lacks the will to attack the problem of what welfare officials call "the hard to serve." And they were upset to read on a federal Web site that New Jersey still had $233 million funds from Federal Temporary Assistance to Needy Families, or TANF, going unspent. Why wasn't some of that money going to the bottom 12 perecent? The news media elsewhere have picked up on similar unspent balances in other states and have asked the same questions.
In the case of New Jersey, that matter of the $233 million surplus is at least easy to answer. "That must be an old report, because it isn't true," said Jacqueline Tencza, the spokeswoman for the Department of Human Services. "Through September 30th, which is the end of the federal fiscal year, we have spent or allocated all of the federal welfare dollars for New Jersey."
Some of the money -- like $100 million for a three-year child care assistance program -- only gets spent over time, Ms. Tencza said.
But that still leaves the harder question of what to do with former welfare recipients who have exhausted their eligibility and have either not been able or willing to pull themselves and their children into the working world.
"These are very vulnerable people," Sally Osmer, director of the Crisis Ministry of Princeton and Trenton, told the gathering. "They are not people who want to see themselves in this situation. They may not have engaged in the best planning, but they are still in crisis."
Connie Mercer, director of HomeFront, another social agency, listed the people she knew who were at the end of the rope: Chris, a single man, a graduate of Lawrence High School and a diagnosed paranoid schizophrenic; Darren, HIV-positive and "a heavy drug addict." Sharon, who lost her benefits because she could not name the man who fathered her child several years ago.
"Just because the welfare rolls are lower, and my God, the rolls are lower! -- doesn't mean that welfare reform is a success," Ms. Mercer said.
The state is increasing the money it will spend on helping the hard to serve find employment and to stay off welfare, but ultimately, the question of helping those who can't or won't help themselves will become a political question, and therefore a political question for the chairman of the Senior Citizens, Veterans' Affairs and Human Services Committee, State Senator C. Louis Bassano of Union Township.
"Contrary to what some people believe, we are our brother's keeper," Mr. Bassano said. "We are a generous country, and when there is a disaster someplace we are the first ones there, trying to help, and I think people in America feel the same way about people who need help." But there is no blank check.
"For the people who need help and can't help themselves, the public wants society to provide the help," Mr. Bassano went on. "But the ones who can help themselves and won't help themselves, those are the ones people are willing to walk away from. And that reflects my feelings exactly."

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Tropical Treats, at the Corner Store

BYLINE: By MARCIA BIEDERMAN 

 BODY:
BEHIND the counter of a bodega at West 169th Street and Audubon Avenue in Washington Heights, Antonio Araujo rings up purchases, hands over packs of cigarettes and occasionally dispenses a single, unwrapped cookie or candy to a customer wanting a reminder of home.
A dozen transparent plastic containers are stacked at Mr. Araujo's elbow, each holding 24 confections, like bread pudding, coconut balls and a caramel fudge called dulce de leche, sold in individual pieces for between 40 and 99 cents. On a patron's request, the clerk pries open a container and provides patrons with paper squares to pull one out. 
 "We sell loads of them," said Mr. Araujo, who, like the store's other employees and most of its customers, was born in the Dominican Republic. There, and in other parts of Latin America, the same sweets are sold this way.
In New York's Latino food stores, these confections are common. At least two or three containers stand on the counters at many bodegas, most of which are now owned by Dominicans, according to Alfred P. Placeres, president of the New York State Federation of Hispanic Chambers of Commerce. Like the rugelach or macadamia nut cookies heaped in glass jars in other food shops in the city, these items suggest home cooking. There are also custardlike desserts sold in plastic cups.
Many of these tropical treats are produced by a handful of small Latino-owned bakeries in the city. Business is conducted in Spanish, and there is little contact with the English-speaking mainstream. Started with little capital and unable to obtain loans, some of these stores are struggling. The bakeries' finances are tied to those of the bodegas, which, Mr. Placeres said, have been squeezed by rent increases in recent years.
On the other hand, the sweets have plenty of potential customers. There are 750,000 Dominicans already in the city and 20,000 more arriving annually, according to the Dominican Studies Institute at the City University of New York.
"The market is there," said Rafael Reynoso, president of the Gollo Bakery, speaking in Spanish. Mr. Reynoso showed a visitor around his small bakery on Suydam Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, as workers scooped mounds of peanut confection onto trays. With two walk-in ovens, Gollo, unlike some even smaller competitors, makes bread and crackers as well as sweets.
Mr. Reynoso, 58, founded the company months after his 1991 arrival in the United States. His initial investment was $5,000, the proceeds from the liquidation of a cheese factory he had owned for 30 years in the Dominican Republic, he said.
In addition to himself and a son, Elizardo, Mr. Reynoso has six employees. Monthly sales are about $15,000 during the winter, which is the busiest season because customers often avoid candy in the summer in favor of ices, soda or ice cream.
Like many other small food companies, Gollo has no trucks of its own. So Mr. Reynoso uses 8 to 10 independent route salesmen to sell and deliver his wares. Each deals regularly with at least 20 bodegas a day.
Why is the food unpackaged? "Latinos won't buy anything wrapped," Mr. Reynoso said. He overstates the case a bit. At the Bravo supermarket around the corner from Mr. Reynoso's bakery, coconut cookies from New Jersey are sold in clamshell containers.
Raymond Cornil, manager of the Bravo store, said he knew Gollo's products and would consider buying them if they were packaged. "Loose things," Mr. Cornil said, "are for small businesses."
Mr. Reynoso would like to buy more ovens and mixers to increase production. But he has payments to make on the ones he bought from local equipment vendors, with whom he negotiated through translators because he and his son speak little English.
"I have many complications," Mr. Reynoso said.
Rachel Bakery and Candy, in the Bronx, is smaller than Gollo, said Meiling Martinez, who founded it six years ago with her husband, Raul. At first, she said, they operated it illegally in their home kitchen, working around the clock with other family members. "We couldn't sleep" because of the noise, she recalled.
Now with two employees, the company produces candies and other stove top products -- but no baked goods -- in a cramped industrial space on West 238th Street in Kingsbridge. Among its products is meringue candy, made of egg whites and sugar, just like the topping on meringue pies.
Mrs. Martinez laughed as she remembered her first failed attempts to produce candy in bulk with the family-sized recipes she had brought from the Dominican Republic. Initially, she said, the independent route salesmen refused to handle her goods, so she and her husband had to distribute them on their own. But when the salesmen saw the items popping up in bodegas, they began asking the company for orders.
Now, Rachel Bakery distributes its goods through Syn-Chriss Importer Wholesale, of the Inwood section of Manhattan. Syn-Chriss, with $3 million in annual sales, provides about 50 route salesmen with a range of tropical products for Latino consumers, said its president, Ramon Castillo.
Both Mrs. Martinez and Mr. Castillo said the route salesmen, or ruteros, have the most profitable link in the chain. Also, "They don't work the hours we do," Mrs. Martinez said. But still, said Mr. Castillo, himself a former rutero, "You have to be likable."
Despite her hard work and ownership of a business -- facts that many Americans would link with bright prospects -- Mrs. Martinez might be considered part of the "hidden unemployed" by some scholars. Many of New York's poor ethnic groups often start up businesses not out of entrepreneurial zeal but out of a lack of alternatives, said Silvio Torres-Saillant, director of the City University of New York's Dominican Studies Institute. "There isn't a job for them, so they conjure one up," he said, but the work often fails to provide decent hours and pay.
Mrs. Martinez, who immigrated 30 years ago and speaks English, sees no signs of the economic boom from her view in the Bronx. "People don't have money," she said. Her company was started with a $6,000 loan from her brother, but she has found no loans since.
Asked if she dreamed of expanding her company, she replied, "Sometimes it's not good to have dreams."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Trade Pact With China: Hold the Applause

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
FOR more than 100 years, American business has been bewitched by the size and potential of China. The experience, of course, has been a rocky one. But the dreams live on.
Investors are not immune, either.
In the glow of the trade liberalization agreement that the United States struck with China last week -- a necessary condition for China's entry into the World Trade Organization -- many Chinese stocks have surged on major American exchanges. 
 The trade deal is good news, but the market's reaction may be premature and, some experts say, overdone.
Over the past 21 months, Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, has traveled to China eight times. Last week, he took some time to put the trade agreement into perspective. Following are excerpts from the conversation:
 
Q. The United States is China's biggest single trading partner, but this country exports only about $15 billion of goods and services there each year. If this deal is approved by Congress, should people expect that number to skyrocket?
 
A. Even if exports doubled, which they will not, it is not a watershed event. It's pretty clear that a year from now we will not be celebrating the end of the U.S. trade deficit as we know it. This agreement is generally a constructive development, but not one of instant gratification for investors around the world.
Possibly the most important conclusion I would take from this is that it is really a watershed event for Chinese economic reform. And it offers a real chance that we will be able to participate in what is likely to be the greatest economic development story of the 21st century.
 
Q. Aside from trade, is it likely that foreign direct investment in China will rise as a result of the agreement?
 
A. I think foreign direct investment will go up a lot. So far this year, it has slumped compared to 1998: through October, about $32 billion in direct investment, compared with $46 billion a year earlier. To a large extent, that is a byproduct of the Asian crisis, which has acted as a disincentive.
 
Q. What sorts of companies are likely to benefit most rapidly from trade liberalization?
 
A. The telecom area will be a real opportunity immediately. Anything with a technology content to it has demand for it. Given the lack of infrastructure, the wireless opportunities are truly extraordinary. I go to China a lot, and almost everyone in Beijing or Shanghai has a cell phone.
Opportunities in financial services may not emerge quite so promptly, but it is hard to say.
 
Q. To what extent is the publicity surrounding this deal masking the difficulties companies will face in trying to break into China?
 
A. There will clearly be sentiment in some quarters to avoid giving too much away to foreigners. But the Chinese leadership has demonstrated they are pretty determined to play by the rules.
Still, the culture of bureaucratic corruption, which is something I have heard about but not seen, is not something that gets broken overnight. And there is no mistaking the depth and breadth of the bureaucratic culture in a managed economy. There is nothing foolproof here.
 
Q. In order for China to gain acceptance into the W.T.O., Congress, European nations and Canada must approve. Will they?
 
A. Seven months ago, when the deal fell through, the political forces were struck against a deal.
But now there is an increased likelihood of Congressional approval. And I think the Europeans will definitely follow suit. The economics are just too compelling not to do this. It is basically a win-win proposition to have greater access to the world's most populous economy.
 
Q. Will this give W.T.O. members a boost at the next round of trade liberalization talks that will start in Seattle later this month?
 
A. I think it is really important for the Seattle talks, because it will have a significant impact on the tone of the discussions. As a successor to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, W.T.O. has been in search of an identity. Managing the accession of China will be very important to it.
 
Q. Will trade liberalization have an immediate impact on China's economic growth?
 
A. Throughout most of the 1990's, the Chinese economy, which is about $1 trillion in size, has been growing at about 10 percent a year. This year it will grow around 7 percent, and it could expand at an 8 or 8.5 percent rate in 2000.
Admission into the W.T.O. won't hurt growth, but it won't help much either over the next year or so. Over time, say the next three to five years, you will begin to see some meaningful growth, probably driven by foreign direct investment, but also by Chinese consumers, who have been on the sidelines.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM/MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS;
Furniture Store of Older Era Swept Up in Urban Renewal

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Nearly 30 years ago, as part of federal urban renewal, the city took possession of the block of 125th Street that is home to Nat Krohn's store, Corvett Furniture Corporation. Mr. Krohn was allowed to stay on as a tenant, and he did, paying rent to the city.
But now the chickens of urban renewal are coming home to roost in a coop that looks very much like Corvett Furniture. Harlem is being redeveloped on a grand scale, and most of the bedraggled block between Lexington and Third Avenues where the store sits is being swept up in the change. 
 The city's Economic Development Corporation is selling the land to the Blumenfeld Development Corporation, which has agreed to develop a retail complex there. So, at the end of December, Mr. Krohn must vacate the premises after 47 years.
All the furniture in his store is on sale, half price. He is more than half angry.
"I was even thinking of going to get Al Sharpton, and I hate the guy," he said.
The city says that it has agreed to pay Mr. Krohn $169,000 in relocation benefits, although he says he has nowhere to relocate to. Mr. Krohn first learned of the city's plans more than a year ago, said Carol Abrams, a spokeswoman for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
It would be hard to argue that more development in East Harlem, whose rebirth has lagged behind that of central and western Harlem, is a bad thing. The company has said that it plans to bring a shopping center with a 10-screen multiplex to the block, where, other than a fast food restaurant on the corner, Mr. Krohn's is the only commercial business.
As Corvett Furniture prepares to pack up, Seaman's Furniture is preparing to move in down the street. It has signed a lease with Gateway Ventures, which is developing an $8.6 million project at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 125th Street.
Mr. Krohn's store is the old-fashioned kind, with couches and television sets and bedroom sets spread over four unfancified floors. There are pictures of him and his wife with the horses they own and train. And there is a group of employees who call themselves the "gray-haired club," most of whose members have several decades of service at the store.
"There was a relationship between the customers and the store," said Jose Ruiz, who has worked at Corvett for 35 years. "But there was some kind of more deep feeling: friendship." AMY WALDMAN

HEADLINE: Bumpers Cave In to the Bump and Grind

BYLINE: By CHERYL JENSEN 

 BODY:
WHEN the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety rammed a 1999 Mazda Protege into a pole in Virginia early this year, the impact reached California.
At Mazda's North American headquarters in Irvine, officials scrambled to clean up a public-relations mess. The '99 Protege suffered $4,609 in damages in four 5 m.p.h. crashes -- the worst showing, by far, of nine vehicles tested. It was also a turnabout; a '97 Protege had suffered just $1,930 in testing damage. 
 The problem stemmed from a redesign. To trim about two pounds, part of a broader effort to reduce weight and improve mileage, Mazda had eliminated an aluminum bar and energy-absorbing foam. After the test results became public, Mazda decided to return to the previous design for 2000-model Proteges.
 Bumper tests like these can leave consumers scratching their heads. How can a series of 5 m.p.h. impacts cause nearly $5,000 in damage? Don't federal rules protect consumers' wallets from such big whacks?
Not really, consumer advocates say. Indeed, there has been a decades-long debate over whether consumers are served or shortchanged by the rules governing bumpers.
In 1977, the government required that the bumpers of all new cars meet a 5 m.p.h. standard. That meant there could be no damage to safety-related items (headlights and turn signals) or to exterior surfaces (the body or sheet metal). It did allow damage to bumpers and attaching hardware. The standard was later strengthened to prohibit substantial harm to the bumper, allowing only minor damage.
Then, during the energy crisis, automakers complained that the heavier bumpers reduced fuel economy. In 1983, the government relaxed its rules.
Cars must now meet this standard: A 2.5 m.p.h. crash cannot damage safety-related parts or body panels. There can, however, be damage to the bumper. Lots of damage.
"You could destroy the bumper," said Brian O'Neill, president of the insurance institute, a lobbying and research group that is largely financed by the insurance industry. The institute tests the bumpers of about 25 vehicles a year.
Why should consumers care? After all, the insurance companies are the ones writing the big checks.
"Consumers don't realize how much difference a good bumper makes in terms of what they pay every six months or so to their favorite institution, the auto insurance companies," said Kim Hazelbaker, senior vice president of the Highway Loss Data Institute. That organization, which is also financed by auto insurers, provides information to help the companies set rates. "Premiums are influenced by how frequently collisions occur and how much money it takes to repair the damage," Mr. Hazelbaker said.
Since nearly half of collision claims are for $1,000 or less, they have a big effect on insurance premiums. And minor damage almost always involves bumpers.
"These are low-speed collisions that all too often are generating high repair bills," Mr. O'Neill said.
Not only do flimsy bumpers mean that consumers pay higher premiums, but the deductible comes directly out of the consumer's pocket. The most common collision deductible is $500, Mr. Hazelbaker said.
The financial penalty can be even larger for the millions of people driving supposedly rough, tough light trucks, particularly sport utilities. The current bumper standard -- weak as it is -- applies only to cars. There is no standard for light trucks.
"These people think they are in an invincible Goliath when in fact their invincible Goliath has an Achilles' heel," said Clarence Ditlow, director of the Center for Auto Safety.
Although the damage suffered by the Protege was high, it has been worse for trucks, including minivans.
The midsize sport utility vehicles tested by the insurance institute suffered damage from $2,918 ('99 Mercedes ML320) to $6,282 ('99 Mitsubishi Montero Sport). Four of the six had repair bills of more than $5,000. Among pickups, the '98 Dodge Dakota had $3,863 in bumper damage; the '98 Toyota Tacoma had $4,361.
If the automakers are failing to design better bumpers, can they be compelled to do so? The United States Department of Transportation could impose stricter standards, but hasn't. That leaves groups like the insurance institute, which uses the carrot and stick of publicity.
"We are trying to embarrass the automakers that have bad bumpers and praise the automakers that have good bumpers," Mr. O'Neill said. He said he had seen some improvement.
This may save money for the insurance companies, but Mr. O'Neill says there is also a clear benefit to consumers. "If you ask a consumer would you like a car with a bumper that sustains expensive damage or one that sustains no damage, I think the answer is clear," he said.
The problem, consumer groups say, is that many automakers have either forgotten, or no longer care about, the original purpose of bumpers: to take the hard knocks of daily driving and protect the rest of the vehicle.
Bumpers first appeared on automobiles in 1906. (The Wescott touring car was the first vehicle with standard front and rear bumpers, in 1919.) Today, designers strive to blur the lines between where the bumper ends and the car begins, but Mr. O'Neill argues that bumpers should again be distinct and utilitarian.
In his view, a bumper should be set away from the expensive sheet metal and lights. It should jut out, making it hard for an impact to reach the body. It should absorb the energy of a minor collision.
"A bumper should bump," Mr. O'Neill said.
He cites the 1981 Ford Escort as a standard that manufacturers should emulate: its bumpers sustained no damage in any of the four tests. Like the bumpers of many past cars, the Escort's were mounted to shock absorbers. And they stuck out.
"Unfortunately, it was not one of the prettiest cars on the road," said David Champion, auto testing director at Consumer Reports magazine.
Style and substance do not have to be incompatible. The chic Volkswagen New Beetle had damage totaling only $134 from all four low-speed crashes at the insurance institute.
"The Beetle is the only car the institute has tested that begins to compare with the 1981 Ford Escort," Mr. O'Neill said.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Mania of Momentum And the Cost of Trading

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
PHOOEY on the Fed.
Not about to let Tuesday's interest rate increase stop their runaway train, stock traders rode the major indexes back into record territory last week. The Standard & Poor's 500 closed near its high, up 15.68 percent for 1999, while the Nasdaq composite reached yet another record, up 53.65 percent for the year. 
 But if rising interest rates don't seem to faze stock investors, rising volatility should. While stock prices have been rocketing, price swings in shares are now approaching levels seen only during two famous crisis periods: the Russian debt collapse of last summer and the crash of 1987.
High volatility makes it harder for investors to get in and out of trades at reasonable prices and therefore raises trading costs. Although increasing volatility permeates all aspects of the market, price movements among the largest companies are most disturbing because they are the ones that investors believe are the safest and most liquid.
According to Salomon Smith Barney, price swings among the 100 largest stocks in the Russell 1000 index are now averaging 42 percent, annualized, close to the 44 percent during the Russian crisis and the 46.5 percent endured in 1987. "Everyone looks to these companies as being the most liquid," said Keith L. Miller, director of United States quantitative research at Salomon Smith Barney, "but they're experiencing greater volatility."
Behind these swings are high prices -- which leave much room to fall -- and investor concentration in a handful of growth stocks. But the mania for stocks that are rising -- known as momentum investing -- contributes mightily to volatility, too. Online investors made the technique notorious, but now even pension fund managers have succumbed to its lures.
Mr. Miller likens the role of momentum investing in today's volatility to the effect that portfolio insurance had on the market in 1987. That strategy, which increased exposure to the S. & P. 500 as the price rose and lessened it as the price fell, failed because the market could not absorb the selling when everyone wanted out.
Today, instead of zeroing in on an index, many investors focus on a small group of individual stocks. These heavily influence the entire market's volatility, which causes investors to underestimate the risk in their portfolios, Mr. Miller said.
That view is echoed in a recent report from Sanford C. Bernstein, which says that the volatility of the stocks owned by the typical online investor -- a k a momentum players -- is double that of the broad market. These traders turn over their portfolios at six to seven times the rate of the market.
Never mind that excessive trading almost guarantees subpar investment performance. Brad M. Barber and Terrance Odean, professors at the Graduate School of Management at the University of California at Davis, studied 78,000 households trading stocks through a large discount broker between 1991 and 1996. Those trading the most earned annual returns of 11.4 percent, compared with 18.5 percent among infrequent traders. Frequent traders also lagged behind the market's return -- 17.9 percent.
So, frequent traders do poorly in their own accounts and raise other investors' costs by increasing volatility. Does anybody else see something wrong with this picture?
