HEADLINE: URBAN TACTICS;
Is There a Butler In the House?

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY 

 BODY:
HEN Mary Ellen Keating became engaged, she decided on a do-it-yourself wedding and immediately descended into six months of detail hell. How many New Yorkers, after all, have the time to fret over seating charts and apple tarts, twice-baked crab and Aunt Rose's taxi? So when Ms. Keating turned 40 two years ago, she did what any self-respecting New Yorker with more money than time would do: She hired a consultant.
"I wasn't going to go through that again," said Ms. Keating, a senior vice president at Barnes & Noble. "So I turned to Tinker Boe." Ms. Boe runs a consulting and catering business called Mood Food, which specializes in concept parties tailored to each client's personality. 
 At Ms. Keating's party, guests were led through rooms decorated and filled with foods and wines "to match my character traits," Ms. Keating said. "Everyone was given a brochure to guide them through the rooms. One was bubbly, one sweet, one bold, one subtle, and so on. It was Tinker's idea, not mine. But it was fabulous."
Party planning has always been big business in New York, but lately it has gotten a lot bigger. Ten years ago, most clients were Park Avenue matrons vying to outdo one another's dinner parties, free-spending corporations celebrating themselves and their money, and big-name charities holding black-tie affairs at Midtown hotels.
All of that continues. But business is also booming at the smaller, less opulent end of the party spectrum. Increasingly, harried New Yorkers with unexpectedly large amounts of cash to burn are hiring consultants to help them wine, dine and impress colleagues, friends and family in the comfort of their own living rooms.
"With this economy, people can't help but spend money on entertaining their friends," said Dennis Wilson, an owner of Wilson & Kreulen, a firm that specializes in flowers, lighting and decor.
Most party consultants began as cooks, caterers, wedding planners, decorators or disc jockeys. During the last decade, many restaurants have got involved, not only with catering, but also with planning entire events at the homes of favorite customers. Florent Morellet, who owns the popular bistro Florent in Lower Manhattan, began planning Christmas parties a few years back for customers in the surrounding meat market district. Now he designs full-scale Victorian Christmas celebrations, replete with roast fowl, glowing candles and evergreen garlands.
There has been a marked movement toward home entertaining in New York in recent years, party planners say. And since "no one has the time to be perfect," as Mr. Wilson of Wilson & Kreulen put it, "they pay someone to make things perfect for them.
"Maybe in the Midwest or something, there's time to hand-press the napkins and make fancy little boxes to put them in," he added. "But in New York, everyone is too busy to be Martha Stewart. Even Martha Stewart is too busy to be Martha Stewart."
Harriette Rose Katz, the owner of Gourmet Advisory Services, says new kinds of clients have begun to seek her services in recent years. "We still have a lot of Park Avenue people who hire us for their big parties," she said, "but we have also started consulting on many small ones for people of more modest means."
Among her new clients are young professionals who want to have a proper party but never quite learned how. "They hire me to teach them how to entertain," she said. "They want lessons in etiquette, wine, food and timing. And I'm an expert in timing. I love timing."
Another growing group of clients are single young men, successful at business but clueless when it comes to entertaining. "They're not in the frat house anymore, and they know it," said Ms. Boe of Mood Food. "A keg of beer and a bag of chips just won't cut it anymore when you work on Wall Street. But what do they know about crab puffs and pate?"
This being New York, the ability to entertain at home, and to do it well, has become a mark of status. "People want to show off their houses, but they need help learning how to entertain," said John Sullivan, owner of a firm called the Butler Did It, which handles everything from providing waiters for an intimate home-cooked dinner to masterminding a cocktail party for hundreds.
"People get nervous about doing everything correctly, so they call one number and we make it all happen," Mr. Sullivan said. "It's so painless for them, because they don't have to think about all the little details, like putting tissue in the bathroom and buying scented candles and turning the air-conditioning way up."
A good planner will provide one-stop shopping, a tried-and-true list of resources covering everything: caterers, decor, lighting, sound, entertainment, invitations, glasses, ice, menu planning, flowers, photography, coat check, bartenders, waiters, valets and cleanup crews.
"If you try doing all that on your own," Mr. Wilson said, "you're just taking a stab at the Yellow Pages. And, he said, a good consultant will always be on top of the very latest party trends and food fashions, which seem to change almost from lunchtime to dinner. "A few years ago, many people had never tried foie gras or sweetbreads or goat cheese," he said. "Now there's a foie gras shortage. People are always looking for the next big thing."
What might that be? "Turkish food and design," Mr. Wilson said. "That, and Latino music. Everyone wants the Ricky Martin thing now. So suddenly, you're going to be at parties with Turkish food and Latino music. It's never been paired before, and it doesn't make much sense; you know, falafel with salsa music, or maybe falafel with salsa on it. That's the party of the future."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
North Korea Opens a Door, but Not Necessarily Its Mind-Set

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
In the two months since it agreed to freeze its long-range missile tests in exchange for the United States lifting economic sanctions, North Korea has been swamped with inquiries from foreign companies, investors and trade groups seeking to do business there.
With a population of 24 million, a low-cost, well-trained work force and close proximity to two important Asian economies, South Korea and Japan, North Korea has its attractions as a site for foreign investment. 
 Though the inquiries have led to several highly publicized trade missions to North Korea, few, if any, foreign firms are expected to actually set up shop there any time soon, because of one obstacle that has not changed: the hermetic country's Stalinist political climate.
Government officials, consultants and people who have done business with North Korea said that unless the reclusive regime of Kim Jong Il simplifies the investment process and makes its dealings more open and businesslike, substantial new foreign investment and trade are unlikely.
"A lot of investors will come to Pyongyang on a trade mission and take one look at the way North Korea operates, and they will never come back," said Anthony Michell, president of Euro-Asian Business Consultancy Ltd., which advises companies with an eye on northeast Asia.
Mr. Michell said that North Korea might be an attractive place to manufacture goods for export to the United States, now that such trade will be legal, but that foreign companies will have to endure a long, convoluted and frustrating negotiation process to get established.
"The biggest turnoff is dealing with an old-style Communist system in which people don't understand the ways of the world," said Michael Breen, a public relations consultant who has advised companies seeking a foothold in North Korea.
"It's a very bureaucratic place, and party politics rule," Mr. Breen said. "It's easy to be misunderstood, and most people who are friendly and supportive of the regime eventually run afoul and get thrown out."
He recalled the case of a Belgian entrepreneur who set up a diamond-cutting business in North Korea that employed several hundred people. The business thrived for a while, and the government often showed off the factory to foreign trade delegations. Then the entrepreneur was forced to leave the country without explanation. "North Korea doesn't see you as an individual, but as part of the agenda of your country," Mr. Breen said. "Something happens at a high level with your country's government that they don't like, and the North Koreans take it out on you."
Still, investors remain interested. A few pioneers, mainly South Korean conglomerates like Hyundai, Samsung and Daewoo, have already made major investments in tourism and manufacturing in North Korea. And the American Chamber of Commerce in Seoul plans to take a delegation of 10 United States business executives -- chosen from more than 90 applicants -- on a trade mission to North Korea as early as next month.
OBVIOUSLY, nobody who does business in North Korea is going to make a lot of money right out of the starting blocks," said Jeff Jones, president of the chamber. "It's a beginning, and everybody knows that it will be slow and difficult. But over time we believe that North Korea will learn how to deal with U.S. businesses."
Members of the delegation will be seeking assurances from North Korea on remittances, ownership rights and security issues, the chamber said, and will want to see if distribution and transportation facilities, regulatory systems and labor will be adequate.
Mr. Jones said the initial business activities in North Korea are likely to be in areas like infrastructure development, finance, agriculture and telecommunications. For example, Motorola, the mobile telephone company, will join the delegation. Much of North Korea has not been wired for basic telephone service, and it may be faster and more economical for the country to install a national cellular system instead.
The Clinton administration agreed to relax sanctions under the Trading with the Enemy Act, dating from the Korean War in the 1950's, after North Korea pledged to stop development of a long-range missile that threatened to upset the balance of power in Asia. The country's erratic behavior has long scared off investors; in the last year it has provoked a naval skirmish with the south over fishing rights and held a tourist captive on charges of being rude.
"What's most important to attract investors is the improvement of North-South relations and a reduction of military tensions between the two," said Myoung Gyon Chu, an official at South Korea's Unification Ministry.
If large-scale foreign investment comes to North Korea, most analysts expect it to be on the coattails of the South Korean companies already making headway there. The biggest investor by far is Hyundai Group. A year ago, in the biggest inter-Korean joint venture since the country was partitioned in 1945, Hyundai began running sightseeing cruise tours of Diamond Mountain, a scenic attraction on North Korea's east coast.
Since 1996, the Daewoo Group has operated a 1,300-employee joint venture in the north to manufacture shirts, jackets and bags for sale in Europe, Latin America and Japan, including items under the Pierre Cardin label. It exports about $25 million of apparel a year.
Ki Hwan Moon, general manager of Daewoo, said it took $5 million and four years of negotiations with North Korea to get the company up and running. "We decided to do it because there was a new market opportunity, the production costs were lower and the workers speak the same language," he said. "Part of the investment is to promote good will and improve relations between the two countries."
BUT even major South Korean companies like Hyundai, which has long been a champion of investing in North Korea, sometimes find it difficult to deal with Pyongyang. Hyundai reached an agreement on Oct. 1 to build a new industrial complex to make a variety of consumer products, but a follow-up delegation twice had to postpone a visit to the country because of a difference over where to build it: the company favors Haeju, a western port city less than 100 miles from Seoul, while the government prefers Sinuiju, far to the north near the Chinese border. The delegation finally began its trip last Monday.
Other companies are closely watching Hyundai's experience in North Korea. Ghil Joon Choi, director of North Korean business projects for Samsung Group, said that he expects similar delays in obtaining approval to build a large consumer electronics factory and set up a fish-importing business there. "There has been no real progress since our last trip to North Korea," around the time of the June naval skirmish, he said.
Asked why foreign companies should consider North Korea worth the frustrations and risks, Mr. Jones, the chamber president, argued that economic integration would help stabilize the country, whose 24 million people will one day offer a lucrative market opportunity, just as South Korea did a generation ago.
"If it doesn't work out, then I guess we will lose a few bucks, but given how hard-working and bright the Koreans are, I suppose it will work," he said.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Steven E. Folker;
Fifth Third Quality Growth Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
EVERY summer, Steven E. Folker treks up to his cabin in the northern Wisconsin woods near Chequamegon Bay to cast his line for smallmouth bass and lake trout. The rest of the year, he seeks bigger fish -- large-capitalization, high-quality growth companies that will end up in the portfolio of the fund he manages, Fifth Third Quality Growth.
"We want companies that historically have been able to consistently grow their earnings at above-average rates," Mr. Folker said from his office at the headquarters of Fifth Third Bancorp in Cincinnati, overlooking the coal and oil barges that dot the Ohio River. "More important, we want companies with strong earnings growth in the next three to five years." 
 He has reeled in some winners. The fund, with $774.8 million in assets, returned 26.8 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Nov. 12, compared with 21.1 percent for its peer group of large blend funds and 26.1 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher.
Mr. Folker, 44, looks for leading American companies in growth industries -- generally companies with market capitalizations of more than $10 billion, although he does hold a few midcap companies with market caps of between $5 billion and $10 billion. His goal is annual earnings growth of more than 15 percent.
He also keeps a sharp eye on price. Typically, he aims to pay a price-to-earnings multiple that is less than twice the company's comparable growth rate: for example, a P/E of 35, or so, for a company whose earnings are growing 25 percent a year. But he is willing to pay a bit more for faster growers. "If a company's fundamentals and growth prospects are really strong," he said, "we'll be a little flexible on its valuation."
Mr. Folker said he and the seven analysts working on the fund spend most of their energy on bottom-up, fundamental research. "Mostly, we tear companies apart fundamentally to see whether they have the growth prospects that we're looking for."
To choose the roughly 50 stocks in the fund, he looks for solid balance sheets. And he likes to see plenty of cash being produced -- "enough to generate free cash flow," he said, "or to generate enough cash to fund the company's future growth without diluting earnings."
He also wants relatively modest amounts of debt, generally a ratio of debt to total capitalization of no more than 25 percent.
Mr. Folker likes a high return on equity, too, typically seeking 18 percent or more. "We like to see high and stable profit margins," he added, "ideally improving margins."
Mr. Folker and the analysts devote much time to visiting companies and talking to management. "We want to confirm the growth prospects and understand the company's long-term strategy for achieving above-average growth," he said. When management is focused on increasing shareholder value, he is doubly pleased, especially if the executives' compensation is linked to performance.
He steers clear of companies whose earnings growth is dependent upon the vagaries of the world's economy. So he is unlikely to hold steel, automobile or commodity chemical companies.
MR. FOLKER recently added to his position in Schering-Plough, the pharmaceutical giant that produces Claritin, the allergy medication, and Intron A, used for cancer and hepatitis patients. The company has no debt and generates enough cash flow to finance significant amounts of research and development, Mr. Folker added. Its return on equity is 51 percent. Moreover, "we think there will be ongoing consolidation in the pharmaceutical industry," he said, "and this company is a leading acquisition target."
The fund originally bought Schering-Plough shares in 1996, at an average cost of $25. Mr. Folker forecasts 16 percent annual earnings growth for the company over the next three to five years. The stock now trades at $55.4375, or 39.6 times his 1999 earnings forecast of $1.40 a share.
Mr. Folker also likes Marsh & McClellan, the insurance broker that owns Putnam Investments, a money manager, and the Mercer Consulting Group. He expects earnings at Putnam to grow 15 to 20 percent a year because of its "strong reputation and heavy equity orientation." Mercer should grow even faster, he said -- about 20 to 25 percent a year, "because it's well positioned in attractive growth markets, particularly the pension and retirement area, health care and compensation."
Marsh & McClellan's ratio of debt to total capital is 39 percent, he added, very solid for its industry. Its return on equity is 23 percent, and net profit margins -- more than 10 percent over the past three to five years -- should expand as its high-margin money management and consulting businesses grow.
The fund started buying shares in April 1998 at an average cost of $59. On Friday, the stock closed at $79, or 22.6 times his 1999 earnings estimate of $3.50 a share.
He added to his position in another favorite, Texas Instruments, in September. "The company is the world leader in digital signal processors, which is the core product in the telecommunications industry," he said.
Texas Instruments' shift away from commodity products like dynamic random access memory chips, or DRAM's, to proprietary, value-added products, like D.S.P.'s, will ratchet up its growth to about 25 percent a year from just 3 percent over the past five years, Mr. Folker said. Its ratio of debt to total capital is just 12 percent, he said, and its return on equity is 19 percent.
He first bought shares in November 1998, at $32. The stock closed on Friday at $98.375, or 57.9 times his 1999 earnings estimate of $1.70 a share.

HEADLINE: C.E.O ROUND TABLE;
Online Pioneers: The Buzz Never Stops

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
SPEED. Sleep. Greed. Recruiting. Role models like Thomas Edison and Ayn Rand. Losing money, yet turning away capital. New-found wealth and an ensuing change in lifestyle -- or not.
Those were some of the topics on the table when four chief executives from dot.com companies -- Candice Carpenter of iVillage, a women's Web site; Fernando J. Espuelas of StarMedia Network, a Spanish- and Portuguese-language service; Kevin O'Connor of DoubleClick, an on-line advertising network, and Stephan J. Paternot of Theglobe.com, a shopping, news and business information site -- gathered late one afternoon early this month at The New York Times for a wide-ranging discussion about managing in the Internet age. 
 These pioneers from Silicon Alley, an area in the Flatiron district of Manhattan that is populated by many fledgling Internet companies, were joined in the two-hour discussion by Saul Hansell, Patrick J. Lyons and Judith H. Dobrzynski of The Times.
As founders of young companies, each executive had experienced the adrenaline highs and the growing pains that accompany the transformation of an idea into a business and then into a publicly traded company. They don't worry about nonexistent earnings in a topsy-turvy environment where not producing a profit is, for the moment, a virtue. For them, the bigger pressure is to build organizations -- fast -- before opportunities slip away.
Following are excerpts from the conversation. JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI

Q. What's the difference between running the kind of company you run and running a big company?
 
CARPENTER Speed. Leading in conditions in which speed is a very big factor. It puts a lot of additional pressure on all the systems. And you have a lot of very young people, and you're teaching them to be managers at a very accelerated pace without a lot of formal programs.
 
PATERNOT Tying into that is just the idea of keeping your entrepreneurial spirit. Things are shifting fast enough that you need to be able to jump into any new idea, shift your company into it and move at light speed.
 
ESPUELAS I would say the absence of a road map. Not that any business is particularly easy, but when there's nothing that you can follow except your instincts and the little bit of data you're able to gather in this context of a lot of speed, I think there's a lot of intuition that goes into these kinds of very fast-moving environments.
 
O'CONNOR In large corporations, you need to spend a lot of time quantifying what the market's going to look like and how you're going to go about it and what the expenses are going to be.
And here it's very much speed, it's intuition, it's trying to figure out, "Is this a big market or a small market?" If it's a big market, you go after it. You spend a tremendous amount of money and you go after it quickly.
 
Q. What's the first thing that's sacrificed in the name of speed?
 
O'CONNOR Facts.
 
CARPENTER Sleep. We're trying to really come up with graded solutions to burnout caused by exhaustion. We have people who have been at this for four years in our company and we have to figure out a way to get them to learn how to completely refresh themselves in short increments of time.
I've stood at the elevator with people going on vacation and actually taken the laptop and the cell phone out of their hands and said, "Great, now you can actually have a vacation." The only way to truly regenerate yourself enough to be truly creative and inventive again is to be unwired at times in the year and to be in the other part of the world.
 
Q. Do any of you have programs for dealing with burnout?
 
PATERNOT Sometimes it's frequent rotation of some of your stars. You'll often find that in your company you have a few stars, and if you leave them in the same position too long they'll burn out. And, quite frankly, you don't want to lose them.
 
CARPENTER We're starting a sabbatical program. It's for people who've been there three years who would love to be there 20. We're giving them a month to go and just do whatever they want. Sleep probably will be at the top of most people's list.
 
ESPUELAS Are you going to take it yourself?
 
CARPENTER Yeah, I am. I have to, otherwise no one else will take it.
 
O'CONNOR We have a very strong policy that people can move to wherever they want to move. Any job in the company's open. So we try to force rotation, because doing the same thing, day in and day out, tends to cause burnout.
 
Consciously Reaching Out
 
Q. Tell us a little bit more about how you're managing growth so far.
 
ESPUELAS I travel all the time. And I try to talk to as many people as possible. We do monthly all-hands meetings and we actually Web-cast them simultaneously and have people call in and try to have an ongoing dialogue. And now we're doing things which I never thought we'd ever do. We're going to create an employee newsletter. We're doing a lot of things that I used to scoff at when I worked at other companies.
What I've also found is that things I said two years ago are now on a plaque, and that people are still acting the same way: "But Fernando said that." Yeah, but that was two years ago.
 
Q. Is communication a common problem?
 
PATERNOT Absolutely. We've seen ourselves have to increase the rate of communication dramatically. When we started four or five years ago, it was a group of 20 to 25 people. My partner Todd Krizelman, co-chief executive and I could just make decisions very quickly, hoping everybody can keep up. But eventually it starts to hurt you more when you get to 200, and people in departments don't understand what's going on. And we've had to deal with a lot of organizational changes over the last year, but everybody understands why we're doing stuff.
 
O'CONNOR We start off with a week of training. It's a week of indoctrination for every employee -- whether you answer the telephone in the German office or you're a vice president, it doesn't matter. You sit, you learn what we do, why we do it, what's the core culture of the company, so everybody's got a good, firm foundation.
 
Q. How do managers who have worked at large companies fare in your kinds of companies?
 
O'CONNOR On average, they've fared pretty well. You've got to pre-screen them very carefully. You tend to get people who expect to have two assistants. But our first test is, we make them take a pay cut. If they won't take a massive pay cut, you've pretty much got them pegged.
 
Q. Do they have options, though, on the other end?
 
O'CONNOR Absolutely.
 
CARPENTER The structure that I've seen be the most successful is a solid infrastructure of senior managers from big companies, very seasoned, very good at creating structure. That gives you room to promote people with less management experience, and have someone to go to when wisdom and time around the track is the issue.
 
Mountains of Resumes
 
Q. How hard is it to find employees? Are strangers handing you resumes as soon as they find out who you are?
 
O'CONNOR I probably get 10 resumes myself a day. We probably get, as a company, 100 resumes a day. There's a lot of talent that wants to get in, that absolutely wants to get into the dot-com company. To get great, smart people is always tough. But it's relatively easy for a dot-com company.
 
ESPUELAS We have two realities. One is in the U.S., which mirrors that. But in Latin America, it's totally different: There's no such thing as us. There's a lot of big companies that are owned by families, so the best you can hope for is to work for so and so, as opposed to being one of the owners of the company. So in Latin America we're able to really tap into really great people who don't have an equivalent to go to.
 
PATERNOT Even though we get a hundred resumes a day, we're at a point where we're trying to find the perfect person to fit this type of software development. It's easier for us to find people in marketing and sales, because New York has a lot more of these people and they're easy to train.
But finding the right technical person, whether it's for infrastructure or for software, we still find it tough. These people can command huge salaries from the banks. And finding a seasoned database manager, for instance, can mean that you have to pay huge cash, because some of these people want the options and they want the cash, and they're not going to leave their cushy job at Goldman Sachs unless you throw it all at them. The fact is, if you're a well-known dot-com company, it helps immensely over the unknown dot-com companies and over a lot of the other companies.
 
How to Set Priorities
 
Q. Do you find that your thinking about the way you run your company changes over time?
 
ESPUELAS For the last two years, I've been thinking about, well, what happens in 10 years and what happens in 20 years? Which is kind of a ridiculous thing to think about on the Internet.
 
O'CONNOR Most start-ups go through the struggle of going from an entrepreneurial environment to professionalization. Making that transition from a total entrepreneurial world with no rules to where you've got to have systems; you've got to have order.
 
PATERNOT You have to learn to delegate. Todd and I were completely attached to the product, had to test everything ourselves. We were the chief Q. A. quality assurance guys. Eventually, you have to stop that. As much as I still use the product now, when I have to use it, I want to be able to rely on 50 people who think about this more than I do and who know it better than I do.
 
O'CONNOR On the flip side, I still spend half my time with new products -- because that is the entrepreneurial side and new products are the key to rejuvenating the company, growing the company. We set out to create a big company.
 
Q. Did you, from the beginning, do something differently than other start-ups might have done, because you were planning for growth?
 
O'CONNOR Definitely. I was fortunate because I started my first company right out of college. So I went through the "how you could have done things differently and better." We tried to avoid all the mistakes. I was building the human infrastructure, getting the people who could build their own business and leverage. When I look at DoubleClick, we're actually a collection of about 50 companies: People who were running their own thing, whether it's their own country, and there were 22 countries, or we have a bunch of business units with people running their own businesses. The thing we most tend to look for in people is intelligence and -- I call it -- athleticism: people who love to compete, don't like to lose.
 
ESPUELAS I don't think anybody stumbles onto a big company. You have to visualize where you're going. You don't know the path necessarily, but there's a goal. There's something I always think about and try to get people to think about. I'm not a martial-arts guy, but when you break a board with your hand, what they teach you is that if you were able to project the energy, not on the surface of the board, but behind the board, you will break it. And you can break three boards, then four boards. But if you aim it for the surface, you will break your hand. And that's a little bit of what you dream about. You have to make choices accordingly.
When we were looking for venture funding, and we were out of our money and we got offered by not-so-great V.C.'s venture capital firms who wanted not-so-great terms, we knew we'd never go there. So we held out. And we got good funding.
 
CARPENTER I can think of a number of examples where we turned down advertisers, we turned down money, because to do otherwise would create a precedent which would limit us later. And as a very tiny company, it's very scary to do or have to do it. And once you do it, it inspires everybody.
 
Of Churchill, and Branson
 
Q. Other chief executives want to be Jack Welch of General Electric. Is there any model you think about?
 
ESPUELAS I spent a lot of time learning how Winston Churchill ran the Second World War. I bring that up as a metaphor -- not having information, not having clarity, the stakes being very high. Of course, the stakes he had to deal with were somewhat higher than what we have to do. But that was part of the encouragement -- to think that something so important could be managed, and all the mistakes that were made and the chaos of the moment. And the other thing, which he said, which I love as a philosophy, is: You don't have to get it right all the time. You just have to get it right 51 percent of the time, and that will carry you through. And that's a very, very liberating philosophy.
 
CARPENTER I admire two people. Steve Ross, who turned a funeral parlor into one of the great media empires in the world Time Warner . He did it by empowering people tremendously. And he was a bit of a cowboy, but that's the only way you get from a funeral parlor to one of the largest media companies in the world. When you were in the room with him, you would want to just get up and run and help him to fulfill this vision.
And then in the dot-com world, I personally admire Tim Koogle chief executive of Yahoo so much. I think Yahoo has an elegance in the way they do things. They never sacrifice. They're the only portal that never charged money for carriage. And they did it because they only want to have the very best content. They want to invite the best people in. Everything they've done has been for long-term greatness.
There's all these fancy dot-com buildings down in Silicon Valley. And you go to Yahoo and it's so very understated. We send our architects out there to visit it because, we said, this is the model. And the employees love it because they really thought about how the employees could have a great day there.
 
PATERNOT Todd and I have the same idol: Richard Branson founder of the Virgin Group -- just his philosophy of wanting to be a successful businessman and having fun while doing it. And he's one of those guys that's really built up one of the best-recognized brands in the world. And after reading his book, "Losing My Virginity," you can see how he's had a lot of similar experiences to what Todd and I had. Seeing how he started from some inexperienced young guy and turned it into some major media empire. And seeing how this man embodies the brand, Virgin, is extremely inspiring.
Todd and I have always had a philosophy since we started, that we're only doing this as long as we have fun. The day that you're just doing it for the money, that's the day we get out.
 
O'CONNOR Mine's more historical. Edison was a horrible C.E.O. but a hell of an innovator. He pretty much innovated the 21st century. And then Ayn Rand.
 
CARPENTER Yeah. Champion of capitalism.
 
O'CONNOR Her philosophy of capitalism and the individual is just how we pretty much run the company.
 I think Koogle is great. I think Steve Case chairman of America Online is amazing. How many times did people write Case off? And he's always come back. Gates Bill Gates of Microsoft is an incredible entrepreneur that everyone really respects -- an entrepreneur who was successful in transitioning from an entrepreneur to building a phenomenal company.
 
Q. Can you imagine out a couple of years? If you have a 10,000-person organization, is it going to be like every other 10,000-person organization?
 
CARPENTER No.
 
O'CONNOR There's nothing wrong with big companies. We all want to become one. And we all want to create a company that stands the test of time. Look at the great companies: General Electric -- what they do is something to be idolized. Disney -- they keep innovating. I.B.M. -- we all want to be like that. But we all want to stay away from the bureaucracy.
 
ESPUELAS I'm sure that some Internet companies will become stodgy old media companies in the next five years. The challenge is: How do you maintain that freshness and how do you organize yourself and how do you develop a culture that it doesn't matter whether you're 500 or 5,000 or 50,000 people? At Microsoft, they have 30,000, 40,000 employees. They move fast. They have that drive. That's cultural.
 
The Price of Profits
 
Q. How long do you think you can exist without producing profit?
 
O'CONNOR It's clear what the market's telling us. They want to give us a lot of money, so we take it and we invest. Why? We look back, and what was the biggest mistake that we made? We should have invested even more money. We should have lost more money. Why? Because this is the biggest thing that's ever hit. Market share is everything.
But it depends on what stage the company is in. People are going to start expecting profits from us in the next one to two years.
 
PATERNOT The reason we all lost money and all went crazy for this is because we realized how big it could be. And it's worth losing the money for the sake of becoming that much bigger down the long road. And I think that investors traditionally, by default, will say "yes, we'd prefer a profitable company," but not if they know it's at the expense of getting that company to be way bigger a little bit further down the road.
 
ESPUELAS Things have changed. In '96 when we started our company, nobody knew if anybody could make a profit on the Net. And now we look and we see that there are certain models, in our case the advertising model, and the e-commerce models, that actually can be profitable.
The biggest risk is that we under-invest, as Kevin said, because this won't come again. And if we don't own that waterfront before everyone else, somebody else will. We don't want to be in a situation next year having to buy someone for a billion bucks that we could have invested $25 million to build or buy them when they're little.
We have invested over the last two years much more in building our brand than the advertising revenue available in the whole of Latin America. Now we're either very stupid or clever and I'd like to think that we're clever, because it means that we are now capturing more than our fair share of that revenue opportunity.

Q. How much longer will it be before people begin to say "wait a minute"?
 
CARPENTER Off the Internet, media companies take five to seven years to become profitable. Everybody knows that in the media business.AOL took eight years, because they were early. Let's say Yahoo took four and a half. So that kind of defines it.
Part of what's interesting is that many of the investors came out of technology. They don't have models of the dynamics of a media company. They're applying a different model and then wondering, "Gee, this doesn't look like anything I've seen," but it's not like the world has never seen it before. You can look at media models and see exactly where we all are on the curve, because it's a business where you do spend a lot up front to build brand, to build advertising-revenue generation capability, and then your revenue starts scaling past it.
 
O'CONNOR It is starting to happen. The scary thing that's happened is what's coming out public today are companies that have no revenue.
 
Q. How do you pay your employees?
 
ESPUELAS We pay good salaries, but fair salaries within the norm for that kind of job in other industries. And then we try to get people to really think about the stock being their major compensation.

Q. Does everybody have stock?
 
ESPUELAS Yeah, after I believe it's six months -- after your first review -- everyone gets stock options.
 
PATERNOT Same policy exactly.
 
Q. At a couple of your companies, the stock price today is a quarter of where it once was. Does that linger as a question in the hallways?
 
PATERNOT You've got to have open communication with your people. You've got to tell them not to look at your day-to-day stock price, but at the same time they deserve to have an explanation and understanding of where things are going in the long run. Give them enough vision so that it's their decision: "Well, I don't care what the stock's at today, I think that we had a great internal story, and a year from now I think things could be way better; I'm going to stick around."
 
CARPENTER At the time of the I.P.O., we pulled out the stock charts of five companies and we said, "Well, here's what you're in for." The pattern was so ridiculously consistent.
 
Risk vs. Executive Reward
 
Q. Many big-company chief executives think you're overpaid. The whole world thinks they're overpaid. Are you overpaid and are they overpaid?
 
O'CONNOR Am I working a million times, or whatever it may be, smarter than someone else? No. Am I overpaid? No. It is what it is.
 
ESPUELAS We win when the stockholder wins and not otherwise, which is a perfect alignment of value.
 
PATERNOT If those traditional media types all want to complain about it, they can always start their own Internet companies and take a chance, and I think they'll realize what the risk-reward ratio is.
 
CARPENTER It is a little bit like the lottery, because the person brought in to run eBay hit the lottery. She, Meg Whitman, is great, but she would be the first to say she got really lucky. The risk of walking away from what's known and guaranteed and starting over in one room that you're sharing with eight people, in retrospect, looks like no big deal. But when you do it, you're taking a big risk. Our culture happens to reward that behavior, which is one reason it's a great country.
My old media colleagues say, you know, "damn, this is really annoying that you guys went and did this," but there's something in you that allows you to go take that risk. It wasn't guaranteed. In the end, it could have been worth absolutely zero.
 
Q. Do you worry that the Internet economy isn't a fair economy, that you have to be lucky to get rich in it?
 
O'CONNOR No, I think the market's very discriminating, and customers are very discriminating.

PATERNOT In many senses, it's this wealth creation -- even though sometimes I don't like the fact that a lot of people are jumping into this industry to make a buck -- that is driving every single business out there to want to give it a chance. No one disputes that the Internet, in some way -- business to business, business to consumer -- is improving the lives of consumers.
 
Wealth, but No Time
 
Q. What do you tell people who want to be entrepreneurs about your lives and the impact that sudden wealth has had on your lifestyle?
 
O'CONNOR I tell everyone just to pursue what you love. If you pursue what you love, you're either going to put in the effort, and you become the best at it, and then you're going to create a successful company, and lots of money, and do well and have fun, or you're going to die poor and happy because you pursued what you love.
 
ESPUELAS I was just meeting with entrepreneurs talking about this in Argentina and saying: Forget the money. You probably won't go public. You probably won't be able to raise money. You're probably going to die as a company, so you have to focus on the fundamentals. What is it that you're going to do that's going to change the world? And if you pick something that changes the world really well and you do it very well, then you'll make money off of that.
 
CARPENTER You have to have leisure time to change your lifestyle, and no one has leisure time yet, so I don't see people rushing out and capitalizing on the money to change the way they live. Everyone's too busy building a franchise right now.
Obviously, this is going to create huge shifts in wealth. And I think it's going to open up charitable giving in a wave that we haven't seen for 50 years that's going to change this country dramatically.
I did go out and buy a few Versace gowns. It was really therapeutic. And I've just bought a little fur jacket, and all of that's really fun, but at the end of the day, that all takes time, and I basically have to go back to work and keep building.
 
Q. Do you have time to follow politics? What do you want from Washington?
 
O'CONNOR I think the Internet is changing the world like no other system -- in such a short period of time -- that it's causing industries to become entrenched in wanting to limit the Internet. People want to stick their hands on the Internet through regulations, so I think we're all finding ourselves spending a lot more time educating governments and senators and Congress people to make sure that they understand.
 
PATERNOT A coalition has been formed -- Netcoalition.com -- that is specifically for the purpose of having someone there, including the C.E.O.'s of those member companies, going to Washington and speaking with senators, just educating them, so that eventually, when they do make a policy decision they haven't made it completely out of thin air.
 
CARPENTER We're involved in politics on the consumer side. We have each of the presidential candidates coming in to do a town meeting in which the questions are not created by the people of iVillage but are filtered up through the membership. It's just having this fabulous rejuvenating impact on democracy that we haven't even seen the beginning of yet.
 
O'CONNOR Platform for libertarianism worldwide, you're going to see it worldwide. That's my theory.
 
To Change the World
 
Q. Is there a difference in culture between now and the 1980's? Are we just a "greed-is-good.com" culture or is anything different motivating people now?
 
ESPUELAS At least in the first couple of waves of the Internet, you'll find a lot of people who think they're actors in a play to change the world, which is very different than money for money's sake.
We're not investing in glamour and luxury; we're investing in our product and our people and basic business stuff. So I think the culture is very different.
 
PATERNOT If you look at the movie "Wall Street" as the quintessential example of that, nothing really new was being created. We're in positions here where I think the reason there is wealth is because we're doing something completely different than playing with money. We are literally shaping, in some way, the way people are going to live and the way businesses are going to run.
 
CARPENTER I was talking to someone about this whole thing, about why this thing grabs hold of you. And then you feel like you don't have it; it has you.
For some reason, some number of people have been tapped on the shoulder, like 'you're going to be part of this thing that is going to be born.' There is nothing that's going to stop this particular transformation.
It is great sometimes. Other times, it's just so consuming that you wish you could just dial down and have 60 percent of the experience. But that's not available. You're either in, tapped, put to work, on the road crew, or probably you're not in. There is no kind of convenient, "this really works for my life." And I think that's probably when any big transformation happens -- it just sort of puts people to work in the service of itself.
 
Q. Kevin is burning to say something.
 
O'CONNOR It's something I probably shouldn't say, because it's contrarian. I think that without question there's a real temptation for some really bad things to happen. And you start to see signals of it.
We had the highest turnover in our Silicon Valley office. I'll talk to an employee who's leaving the company and saying: "Love the company, love the compensation, love DoubleClick, love everything, but I'm going to go and really throw my hat in the ring with a hot new start-up over here. The guy next door made $20 million. I've got to make my $20 million or I'm a failure."
So you start to see greed. Money creates greed, and greed creates corruption. And you're going to see more and more of this. You're going to see bad companies. Wherever there's an incredible, immense amount of money, there's going to be bad people.
 
CARPENTER As long as the pie keeps rapidly expanding, everybody's going to be really good friends and get along really well. When it starts really getting to be a battle for market share, it'll be a different story.
 
No Fun in the Fishbowl
Q. What do you all really hate about being a chief executive?

ESPUELAS Having to be "on" all the time. Everyone you meet sees you through that optic. So much so that now, unless it's a business context, I never say what I do. I always work for "a Latin American company."
 
PATERNOT That's exactly what I do as well. A nameless company.
 The biggest change I saw to the negative is going from a private company to a public one. All of a sudden you have to be that much more careful with the random people that you meet, because sometimes you'll start off in a perfectly casual conversation and before you know it, you realize that person's just wanting to know where your stock's going next week. That can get annoying.
It's constantly feeling like sometimes you're being taken advantage of by people who do know who you are, and you just want to be anonymous. You don't want to necessarily be a public profile 24 hours a day.
 
Q. Is there anything else you dislike?
 
CARPENTER Travel. Today, being a C.E.O. means an enormous amount of travel. Often, you go somewhere and you talk for an hour and it's critical. You have to do it, but you think, "God, this whole thing took me 12 hours and it was an hour of something that actually happened." We can be more and more productive on planes with computers, but travel takes a huge personal toll.
 
ESPUELAS I arrived this morning in Miami at 5 from Buenos Aires, had a press conference at 8:30, gave a speech at 9:30 and got on a plane at 11 to come to New York .
Something I don't think is at all a positive is that the C.E.O. figure has become a bit of a starlet. Literally, there's probably 30 people or more in our company who could have done that speech today, and done it much better than I, since I was half dazed anyway. But people want to meet you, and that makes a difference. Sometimes it is a bit overwhelming.
 
O'CONNOR To me, it's just family. You just don't get to see them. Wife can understand, but two kids, two young kids, they have a tough time.
 
Q. Will you still be the chief executive of DoubleClick when you're 60?
 
O'CONNOR The board willing. Hopefully, I'll drop dead behind my desk of old age and the board doesn't shoot me. So far they like me, though.
 
Q. You envision that kind of career?
 
O'CONNOR Yeah, if the board thinks I'm the best person for the job, then, yeah, I'd love to keep it.
 
Q. How about the rest of the panel?
 
ESPUELAS Sixty's a long way away. I love what I do. I can't imagine doing anything else, but I've also seen people who've been at the same job for 20 years, and it's not pretty. I'd like to also think that I'm imminently replaceable, that within the 700 people we have in our team are at least 100 that could have my job.
I like to think that anybody can replace me and that that should be everyone's desire at our company, that they should want my job and that they should work for it and get it.

PUB-DATE: November 21, 1999

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 899 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Stock Option Bonanzas Vs. Stagnant Paychecks

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THIS is a story in search of an ending. The unemployment rate has fallen as steadily as a barometer announcing a storm. Employers struggle to find workers. The Federal Reserve raises interest rates in anticipation of inflationary pressures from higher labor costs. But those costs don't show up in the standard statistics. Yet they must be out there, so the search is on.
The Fed itself is a prominent sleuth, and its latest lead is stock options. This popular form of pay for the higher end of the work force is not recorded in the government's tallies of an employer's labor costs, now dominated by wages and benefits. If they were added, then, voila, labor costs would suddenly accelerate, and the story would have a familiar ending: tight labor markets do indeed force up corporate labor costs, and then inflation. 
 "Our calculations suggest that in recent years, stock options have been a not-insignificant part of actual overall compensation growth," four economists at the Federal Reserve concluded in a recent study.
Maybe. The Labor Department is skeptical of the Fed's study, which is based on an analysis of the practices of 125 companies, plus some heroic projections about the rest of America's public companies. Still, the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics is sleuthing in the same direction, preparing a survey "to find out if options are as prevalent as some people say they are," said John Ruser, a bureau economist.
All this focus on options as the proper ending reflects a reluctance to embrace an alternative story line: that labor costs are not really rising. Even in these flush times, most workers are accepting modest raises because they are beaten down by global competition, job insecurity, temps, weak unions and corporate migration to lower-wage regions. If this alternative story line is true, and a rising economy will not lift pay by enough for enough workers, the only hope for jacking up incomes may be government intervention, an idea out of favor among both Democrats and Republicans.
The market alone must set labor compensation, most politicians and mainstream economists insist; even the minimum wage should not be restored by Congress to its old buying power. And if the market raises income through stock options, so be it.
But America changes. Workers earning less than $10 an hour make up almost two-fifths of the work force, and they rarely get stock options. More than in the past, they are left out of a rising economy, a blow to equality. Only 6.7 percent of the lower-occupation workers in the Fed study got stock options, compared with 32.8 percent at the upper end.
These lucky ones present a different problem. Their options make them rich, or they feel rich, but only as long as stock prices stay up. When a falling market shrinks their wealth, they pull back on spending faster than they might have if their pay had been in cash, and they had saved some of the cash. Their quick retreat multiplies the blow to the economy from falling stock prices. They also rush to exercise options and sell stock, exacerbating the market decline.
The government has two measures of labor costs. The most popular, the Employment Cost Index, calculates what companies pay out in wages, salaries and benefits. It does not capture stock options or tips or bonuses paid to recruit people or keep them -- all growing categories. The second measure, much broader but rarely publicized, is compensation per hour, which includes the tips and bonuses, and even stock options when they are exercised -- but not the value of unexercised option grants.
Rough estimates put the value of those option grants at $60 billion to more than $100 billion last year. Options, therefore, "ought to be considered as compensation on issue date," the Fed study said.
If they were, then the rise in the Employment Cost Index -- currently recorded as 3.1 to 3.5 percent a year since 1996 -- may turn out to have been understated by three-tenths of a percentage point each year, according to the study. "There is an understatement," said Ken Matheny, an economist at Macroeconomic Advisers, "but given the sketchy data available, it is hard to know how much cost is really involved."
SAY a company with a $10 stock grants options to employees, giving them the right over several years to buy the stock from the company at that price. If the market price rises to $15, an employee can exercise the options and sell the newly purchased stock at a $5-a-share profit. Whether the company satisfies the options by issuing new shares or by buying existing ones in the market at $15 apiece, a cost is incurred.
It won't show up as a cost on the books, because American accounting practices grant special treatment for stock options. And perhaps the cost is not so much: perhaps the company bought some shares for $10 when the options were granted and set them aside against the day they would be exercised. Or maybe the options will expire unexercised because the stock price has dropped below $10 in a falling market, and won't wind up costing the company a thing.
Options, in sum, are not the inexorable labor cost that a weekly payroll represents. So the search must continue for a better ending. Perhaps a boom economy just doesn't lift enough boats any more, and that is the simple and unfortunate reason that labor costs are not rising all that much. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

COMPANY: FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM FEDERAL RESERVE BANK OF NEW YORK (66%); FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM (59%); FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM (59%); BUREAU OF LABOR STATISTICS (54%); BUREAU OF LABOR STATISTICS (54%);

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
MoreFired Workers Are Suing for Stock Options

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
WHEN Charles E. Knox was terminated from his job in middle management at Microsoft in 1995, he sued the company, accusing it of breaching his employment contract. He asked for not only the usual lost salary, but also the worth of his options. A court awarded him $650,000 but denied him the value of any options.
But last year, a Washington state appeals court agreed with Mr. Knox's larger claim, ruling that he was entitled to more than just the salary he had left behind. It said Mr. Knox, who had spent more than 10 years at Microsoft, could also claim the value of the stock options he lost when he left. His lawyers contend that those options are worth tens of millions of dollars, an estimate Microsoft disputes. 
 Mr. Knox is not alone among fired American workers. Employment lawyers say a growing number of workers who feel that they have been discriminated against or wrongfully fired are seeking redress not just for lost wages but also for the value of lost stock options. The stakes in employment-related lawsuits are rising rapidly.
These claims pose a particular risk for technology companies. Many of them grant their employees stock options in lieu of large paychecks and have seen the value of their shares soar.
"There's no doubt that the value of options in such cases is rising," said Frank D. Tinari, an economics professor at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J. Professor Tinari is often called into employment cases to put a price tag on damages. He estimates that about one-tenth of the 120 employment lawsuits where he has provided analysis in the last two and a half years have involved claims for stock options.
Options typically grant the right to buy stock at a fixed price for a fixed period of time, no matter how high (or low) the shares go. A portion of them usually vest, or become effective, in each of several years after they are granted.
Mr. Knox said he was forced to exercise options, then had to sell 25,000 of those shares to pay his exercise costs and related expenses. He said he also had to give up 17,000 options that had not yet vested. Had he been able to keep all of his options, he said, he would now have 360,000, thanks to subsequent stock splits.
Jerry R. McNaul, a Seattle lawyer who is representing Mr. Knox, said an economist recently valued the lost options at $25 million to $70 million, with the larger number reflecting their possible value if they were held until their latest expiration date, 2003.
"Stock options were a major incentive for coming to Microsoft," Mr. Knox said. "They far outshadowed salary and other benefits."
The Microsoft case is scheduled for a hearing in January. In court papers, Microsoft said Mr. Knox was working under a contract that permitted his dismissal at any time. A Microsoft spokesman said the company also contests Mr. Knox's valuation of his options. "There is a universally recognized method for valuing stock options, and based on that, we think that the value of his options is significantly less than what he is claiming," said the spokesman, Dan Leach.
Mr. McNaul has represented about a dozen former Microsoft employees who have tried to recover the value of lost options. Most of those cases, he said, were settled out of court, with provisions requiring that the outcomes be kept confidential. But, he said, in each case, "the principal damage claim was the loss of stock options."
Such a claim was also made by Nina Bronk Kellner, a former manager involved in business development and strategy at America Online. Last December, Ms. Bronk Kellner filed a claim with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, accusing AOL of wrongful termination and discriminating against her both because of her pregnancy and her gender. Ms. Bronk Kellner joined AOL in 1995, when, she said, the company was an underdog in the race to attract online subscribers. She said she had enough faith in the company's prospects to accept a salary that was low by industry standards, but which was accompanied by an attractive options package.
Ms. Bronk Kellner said that she was forced to exercise her options when she lost her job in June 1998 and that she also had to give up options that had not vested.
She said that since she lost her job, AOL's stock price has quintupled. Debra S. Katz, a Washington lawyer representing Ms. Bronk Kellner, says her client's lost options are now worth $34 million.
As Ms. Bronk Kellner put it, "I took a huge bet with this company, whose stock could just as easily have gone down. I feel like I lost a lot of money."
Nicholas J. Graham, a spokesman for America Online, said the company had no comment on the claim's specifics. But, he added, "We are confident that we are fully justified in our employment decisions."
Lawyers say companies and employees often appear willing to settle out of court rather than to try a case in a developing area of law -- and the courts are still trying to decide how to compensate employees for lost options. "These are clearly high-risk cases," said Lewis M. Steel, a Manhattan employment discrimination lawyer.
Walter Lucas, a lawyer specializing in wrongful-discharge law in West Orange, N.J., said that while companies are generally willing to grant former employees roughly three-quarters of the value of options that might have vested during the year they were fired, they rarely offer compensation for options that would vest later. The law is unclear on whether employees can recover options that have yet to vest, he said.
It is not even clear how these options should be valued. The formula commonly used by investors and compensation experts is more reliable for companies whose shares have long histories than for companies that have only recently gone public.
"I think these types of cases are going to create a cottage industry of experts for projecting what these options will be worth," Ms. Katz said.
Still, the employment lawyers said the courts have generally supported the right of wrongfully fired employees to recover the value of lost, vested stock options. Ms. Katz said the courts have also decided that, because options represent pay already received, claims for them should not be subject to the limits that the federal Civil Rights Act puts on compensatory damages in employment discrimination suits. These limits range from $50,000 to $300,000, depending on the size of the company.
Last month, employees seeking to recover the value of options scored a victory when a New Jersey state superior court decided to compensate a fired employee even for options he would have received in future years. The court, in Morristown, awarded Alfred Jablonski, a former lawyer for American Home Products, about $1.6 million both for lost earnings and stock options. Mr. Jablonski contended that he had been wrongfully dismissed when he turned 65.
 PROFESSOR TINARI was called into the American Home Products case by Mr. Jablonski's lawyers to determine how much he was entitled to collect. He calculated that Mr. Jablonski deserved not just $765,000 in lost salary and bonuses, but also more than $1 million in lost options, including options he would have received had he worked until he was 70.
The New Jersey court did not say how much of the award was for Mr. Jablonski's options only. Lowell Weiner, a spokesman for the company, refused to comment on the specifics of Mr. Jablonski's options. But he said that the company believes that the discrimination claim is without merit and that it is appealing the decision.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Why the Market Is Neutral On Research Spending

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT 

 BODY:
STUDENTS of the stock market have long worried that it does a poor job of valuing the long-term benefits of corporate research and development.
All things being equal, a company that invests heavily in R. & D. should be more profitable over the long run than one that doesn't. Yet such companies are sometimes shunned by short-term traders seeking a quick buck; they buy companies that reduce their R. & D. budgets in favor of reporting higher earnings immediately. 
 While undervaluing research is worrisome at any time, it is particularly serious in today's technology-driven economy. In the computer software sector, for example, the average R. & D. outlay amounts to 17 percent of a company's total sales and two times its earnings. A failure to value R. & D. correctly can lead to a major mispricing of a company's stock.
But perhaps that isn't happening. According to a new study by Louis K. C. Chan, Josef Lakonishok and Theodore Sougiannis, professors at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, there seems to be no evidence that the market penalizes companies that invest in R. & D.
For each year from 1975 to 1995, the researchers divided stocks into two groups. The first group consisted of companies that reported R. & D. expenditures that year; the second was composed of those companies that did not. The professors then tracked the subsequent three-year performance of each group.
Through mid-1998, on average, the three-year annualized return of the companies spending money on R. & D. was 19.65 percent, statistically indistinguishable from the 19.50 percent return for the others.
So the professors think that investors, over all, neither overvalue nor undervalue research spending. Of course, some investors may be shunning companies that invest in research because of the stocks' higher price-to-earnings ratios. But the effect is evidently balanced by other investors who look below the surface and see the potential value of companies' research.
Although the professors give the stock market a passing grade on this subject, they found one subset of companies whose R. & D. expenditures seemed to be systematically undervalued: those companies that trade at low price-to-book multiples -- and are therefore often considered value stocks.
In this subset, the professors found that companies that invested heavily in R. & D. outperformed those that didn't by nearly 8 percentage points, annualized, through mid-1998. That is an impressive amount, given that value stocks in general have historically outperformed the market anyway.
EVIDENTLY, the stock market fails to recognize that when the management of such companies spends big amounts on research, it is a bullish signal. After all, such managers are often under intense pressure to reduce their spending on research, thus increasing short-term earnings and helping to raise the stock price. To invest in R. & D. under those conditions speaks of extreme confidence on management's part.
The professors have a hypothesis about why the market does such a poor job valuing such stocks: "R. & D.-intensive firms who are past losers become 'orphaned' stocks with no natural underlying investor clientele," the study said.
Growth investors, for example, tend to shun such market laggards. And because those stocks still look expensive according to the conventional valuation criteria, value-oriented investors aren't likely to buy them, either.
Such stocks fall through the cracks -- the ideal condition for market mispricing.
In short, R. & D. spending alone doesn't tell investors much about a stock's prospects. But examining that spending in conjunction with a stock's price-to-book multiple can yield a powerful indicator of future performance.

Chan, Josef Lakonishok and Theodore Sougiannis)

HEADLINE: The World;
One Giant Step For Mr. Jiang's China

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
ONLY a few weeks ago, after the uninspired 50th anniversary extravaganza for the People's Republic that equated President Jiang Zemin with Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping, Mr. Jiang became a victim of Beijing's merciless joke circuit. In stories told in quiet tea houses and at raucous dinner parties -- the nearest thing here to Jay Leno's monologues as an index of political fortunes -- Mr. Jiang was portrayed as lacking the vision and stature that this foundering country needs.
One of the most repeated jokes imagined the president's thoughts during the anniversary parade. He looks to the north, the story goes, and sees millions of unemployed workers. He looks to the south and sees millions of prostitutes. He looks to the east and sees the vast smuggling of goods and he looks to the west and sees ethnic rebellions. He looks to the sky and sees NATO bombs falling, then he looks down and finds himself surrounded by Falun Gong demonstrators intent on continuing their spiritual movement. 
 Mr. Jiang walks to the Mao mausoleum to ask the Great Helmsman's advice. After hearing all the woes, Mao rises up from his crypt and says, "You'd better lie down here, I'll take charge."
They weren't telling that one any more last week, after Mr. Jiang and his fellow party chiefs signed a trade deal with America that seemed breathtaking in its implications and anything but lacking in vision. After months of speculation that conservative, protectionist forces were gaining the upper hand, China made sweeping commitments to slash barriers to trade and foreign investment and to accept international rules governing these activities.
Some Chinese experts even compared the agreement, which Americans demanded in return for supporting the country's entry into the World Trade Organization, to Deng Xiaoping's momentous "opening and reform" of the late 1970's, when he cast aside Mao's screwball economics and introduced market incentives.
China's signature Monday showed that Mr. Jiang, and most if not all of the other six Communist Party leaders who make major decisions here, are convinced that radical change is the only hope if China is to attain long-term prosperity and greatness. Since these seven men, who serve on the all-powerful politburo standing committee, are also politicians, they are most likely making this risky leap in the belief that it is the only way to save the party's monopoly on power.
"It's a sort of pact with the devil," said Andrew J. Nathan, a political scientist at Columbia University. "You compromise on some aspects of social and economic control, and hope you can keep political control."
Some of the risks are obvious. Wringing out the state sector and creating competitive companies, as China hopes to do as a member of the World Trade Organization, should eventually bring about a richer, more efficient country. But the lower agricultural tariffs China agreed to last week will mean a "blood bath" for farmers, as a Western economist said here, forcing more migrants into cities where they will compete with laid-off factory workers for jobs. In urban areas, freer trade and investment will cause temporary dislocations as leaner, technologically advanced foreign companies wipe out bloated domestic ones.
EVEN without foreign competition, angry workers and farmers have protested often enough to put the Government on edge. Leaders and citizens alike know that, at this point in Communist rule, political obedience depends on the party's ability to deliver greater wealth.
For the party, there is also a deeper long-term risk. From President Clinton to eternally hopeful liberals inside China, some openly voiced the thesis last week that an influx of foreign companies, and the enforced discipline of global trade rules, will promote the rule of law and prod along political change.
Many experts think, too, that a growing middle class that owns homes and businesses and pays taxes will demand a greater voice in government, and form interest groups outside party control. In the last two decades, the Mao era's grip over personal decisions like how and where to live and work has greatly weakened.
Fair and predictable enforcement of rules, in business and throughout society, will certainly improve daily life and aid China's development. But this is already a prime goal of the Communist Party leaders, who know that widespread corruption and arbitrary decisions are corroding the last remnants of popular faith. In the battle against corrupt provincial and local officials and in their efforts to build a trimmer, better-educated bureaucracy, the leaders hope to gain efficiency and also bolster the party's rule.
"The Chinese leaders clearly don't embrace the theory that political change is inevitable," said Mr. Nathan. "They intend to keep a monopoly on political power while still opening the economy. They no longer insist on compete control over everything because they realize they don't need it."
The global corporations speak in evangelical terms about their ultimate impact on society, but they are in China for one reason -- to make money. Their greatest need is clear rules, predictability and social stability. It may well be, as American diplomats argue, that, as society becomes more sophisticated and diverse, a political opening will be vital to preserving stability. But it may also be that political change, when it happens, will not come smoothly or peacefully.
In the meantime, the rest of the world might do well to assume that Mr. Jiang and his comrades know more about how to survive as Communist Party leaders.
When all is said and done, common sense suggests that the expanding flow of information -- now aided by the Internet, a true devil with which the Communists feel they must consort -- will create deep and unsettling consequences. Monday's pact should accelerate this subversive exchange of facts and ideas.
But despite the mythical patience of the Chinese, politicians here have to worry a lot more about tomorrow than about the next year, or the next decade. With his bold promise last week to embrace the modern world, Mr. Jiang has given the Chinese people hopes and dreams that may sustain them for a while. If all the contradictions come crashing together one day, well, he is gambling that may be on someone else's watch.
