HEADLINE: Word for Word/Survivalist Magazines;
The End Is Nigh: Better Get Some Videos

BYLINE: By DAVID WALLIS 

 BODY:
BEFORE scurrying to their fortified bunkers and underground bomb shelters, America's millennial-minded survivalists have so much to do. Is there still time to top off the water tanks? Stockpile antibiotics? Clean the rifles? Replenish the pantry with plenty of Tang and rations?
For big-time Y2K worriers, there's help, of course: self-reliance publications dedicated to smoothing the way to apocalypse now. 
 Among the leading camouflage-and-khaki Martha Stewarts are the editors and writers of periodicals like American Survival Guide (which boasts an unaudited readership of 60,000) and Backwoods Home Magazine ("practical ideas for self-reliant living"). Both offer tips on what to do when the ball drops and all hell breaks loose -- not to mention a chance to win a one-year supply of dehydrated foodstuffs! Here is a sampling from the genre.
 DAVID WALLIS
 An ad in American Survival Guide peddling hand-cranked flour mills and freeze-dried vittles sets the general tone:
 At the stroke of midnight on 12/ 31/99, millions of computers, including those that run the global economy of money, food and energy, are in danger of crashing! Everything, including the infrastructure for power and food supplies, may very well grind to a halt. You need to be prepared with enough food and supplies for as much as a year! . . . Remember, we ship in 72 hours!! Don't wait! Every day means lost time!
 Under the headline "Millennium Hoarding Creates Scarcity," Alger International offers a $20 gold coin for $ 599:
Many people fear the impending collapse of worldwide markets in the new millennium. Fortunately, this massive gold coin is respected around the world and experts think it will hold its value regardless of international currency crashes. . . . This price is valid for phone orders only within the next 48 hours. This could be your last chance!
 In Delta Force, a sort of L.L. Bean catalog for the militia set, an ad for a video, "Surviving the Year 2000," gets creative with New York history:
In July of 1997 New York City went dark. The blackout lasted from 5 to 25 hours. During that time, over 2,000 stores were looted and hundreds more burned to the ground. At least 3,700 people were arrested. Now, imagine if the blackout lasted 5 to 25 days, even weeks. It is not a pleasant thought.
But just suppose the city does descend into complete and utter mayhem. You'll need "Urban Combat," the video:
Jungles of glass and steel, cities are the most dangerous of all terrains to fight a war -- and the most likely. Here's the info that prepares police, military units and civilians to meet -- and beat -- the threat of urban combat. The book is loaded with illustrations showing the best tactical moves, accompanied by clear, concise directions. Topics include offensive operations, combat support, how to clear buildings, demolitions and much, much more.
As you plan your escape to rural safety, you'll want to look like you're going to the Hamptons rather than going postal, says an article in the "Special Doom and Gloom Issue" of Backwoods Home:
This retreat can be called a summer home, vacation home, hunting cabin or whatever. Calling it a survival retreat immediately brands you as a nut-case radical. Just quietly go about your business, not making waves or attracting attention, and secure your hideaway.
How about an urban outhouse? Jackie Clays, a writer for Backwoods Home, thinks it a wise move:
Yep, even if you live in the city, discreetly dig a hole and build a garden shed over it. Umhmm, I know it's not legal in many localities, but in an emergency you can use it and keep your home much more sanitary and sweet-smelling.
Hungry? You might feel a bit nostalgic as you leaf through "Depression-era gardening," an article by Alice Brantley Yeager in Backwoods Home:
The Depression forced people to save and make the best of what they had. . . . I take the optimistic view that Americans can survive almost anything if we get in touch with the soil and use common sense about other things. . . . To those folks who are apparently married to their computers and not inclined to have rapport with a garden, I can only say that I have yet to see a computer serve a fresh tasty garden salad or some stir-fried veggies.
Self-reliance is even more of a snap when you can rely on the government, writes Kenn Abaygo in "Urban Survival in Extreme Situations," in American Survival Guide:
Begin life on the lam as a bum. Society and its government will care for you in nearly every way by giving you shelter from the storm, food and water, medical attention, clothing and encouragement. They ask for nothing in return and seldom ask your name; almost never do they ask for identification either. They just want to give you a hand and they feel good doing just that.
In the course of reporting, Mr. Abaygo picked up the knack of gourmet foraging:
Some of the best dumpsters in Central Park are behind Tavern on the Green, the famous restaurant. I lifted a lid on one of them, and, lo and behold, it was half full of steaks, seafood, pasta, chicken, pork, salad fixins, vegetables and other goodies. Some of it was still warm, too. Yum.
When the going gets tough, the tough go hunting -- even in Central Park:
Squirrels are tame . . . as are pigeons. Many will come right into your hand for a speck of food, and none are expecting to be trapped, snared or hunted. . . . A squirrel pole snare for those furry critters and a noose stick for birds are two excellent devices for taking game in the park.
Of course, the apocalypse has no dental plan. Good thing there are do it yourself tooth extraction videotapes starring Dr. Dennis Knobeloch, advertised in American Survival Guide:
A preparedness-oriented dentist has set out to help those in the uncertain future by showing them how to take out painful teeth. . . . By mounting a special video camera on a headband, this dentist has recorded the actual removal of teeth from people with severe toothaches. Front teeth, back teeth, top teeth and bottom teeth. Everything is shown in up-close detail. Definitely not for the squeamish but very definitely for the well prepared.
And while you may be a loner, that doesn't mean you have to be lonely. Both Backwoods Home and American Survival Guide publish personal ads for the Y2K-prepared:
Granny with an attitude (a positive one) . . . pro-gun, pro-Constitution, into 4X4s, rural living, camping, fishing . . . would like to hear from any who are trying to survive/thrive/ protect themselves and their families for coming hard times.
Lutheran male, 34 . . . certified security specialist, certified survival instructor, bodyguard . . . Willing to trade skills, provide additional security in exchange for a place of refuge (preferably in WY, CO, NM, TX or OK) for the coming possible turmoil. No racists or Democrats need reply.
SWM, 25, incarcerated survivalist, pro-freedom, pro-gun, seeks white female, 18-30 . . . would like to relocate. Release date is 2000.

LENGTH: 1213 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Triumphant, The Left Asks What Else It Is

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN

 BODY:
AS leaders of the center-left parties that govern much of the Western world gather in resplendent Renaissance palaces in Florence this weekend to ponder the course of the fuzzy but resonant political idea some of them call the "third way," sharp differences are evident as to what social democracy in the post-cold-war world should be.
Leaders from Bill Clinton to Gerhard Schroder like to declare themselves newfound allies in championing market-friendly governments that still look out for the less fortunate. Out with tax-and-spend, state-heavy irresponsibility -- in with the new culture of fiscal conservatism and opportunity. But this surface accord masks fundamental questions about a "third way" ideology that is part marketing tool, part pragmatism and part the innovative fruit of the left's past failures. 
 The divisions in Europe are particularly profound. Britain, like Bill Clinton's America, is a transformed society, steered to a new entrepreneurial culture first by Margaret Thatcher and now through the pro-market centrism of Tony Blair; France is loudly proclaiming its loyalty to socialism while quietly installing a market-oriented culture; and Germany is struggling to begin reforms that would end what Chancellor Schroder has dismissively called "the nanny state."
Among the center-left, Britain does what it says, France does what it says it will not do and Germany says a lot without proving able to do much. But there is a central dilemma: the left, once unified in Europe around the idea of class struggle, has not yet figured out exactly whom it represents these days and, as a result, what its priorities should be. Is its most important constituency still workers and state employees, or young founders of Internet companies with progressive ideas?
This has been a heady decade for Democrats and Social Democrats. Seldom has so much power accumulated so fast in one political family. Deprived of their old Communist enemy and disoriented by the global economy's erosion of such traditional conservative values as the nation, right-wing political forces have reeled. In their place, leaders like Mr. Blair, Mr. Schroder and Lionel Jospin of France have stepped forward with a new message in which the Clintonian echoes have often been unmistakable.
It is true that the Clinton years have brought America many results of which Europeans can only dream: a budget surplus, the creation of close to 19 million new jobs, sustained growth, virtually full employment and welfare rolls at a 30-year low. But at the meeting in Florence convened to ponder 21st-century "progressive governance," Mr. Clinton will find his ideas challenged by Europeans still struggling to galvanize their economies.
At a fundamental level, globalization has challenged the left by changing the workplace in which socialism evolved. With less than 20 percent of workers in western Europe in factories, the working class has become less relevant. In a way, this has opened new opportunities for the pursuit of equality conceived as something beyond the old vision of class conflict or social leveling, and more as equality of opportunity.
But equality, in the words of Ronald Dworkin, a legal scholar at New York University, "is now thought to be electoral poison in the United States and basically has gone off the screen." America is growing more unequal. And, even in Europe, at least outside France, the idea of "sufficiency" has gained ground as a more important value than "equality": society should provide a bare minimum of social protection and equality of starting positions, but no more than that.
The pressure to move in this ideological direction has come partly from the global economy. Countries including Germany and France have seen their state-heavy economic systems challenged by new demands for competition. Unemployment rates have stayed stubbornly in the 10 percent range, and employers point to comprehensive welfare systems that add heavy social insurance charges to wage costs. Why get a job if benefits plus occasional work off the books provide a better income?
In the grand tradition of Franco-American sparring, the French -- on the surface, at least -- are clearly most resistant to the notion of a third way. The platform of Mr. Jospin's party for the last meeting of the Socialist International said capitalism was "unjust and often irrational." When Mr. Jospin deploys his mantra -- "We reject the market society" -- he leaves little doubt that he is referring to the United States of the super Dow.
Such oratory still has a ring to it. But it is something of a smokescreen, deployed to mask the radical market-oriented changes that Mr. Jospin's socialists have quietly encouraged in recent years: sweeping privatization, encouragement of stock options, support for a nascent share-holding culture inspired by the success of such former state monopolies as France Telecom. It is not for nothing that the Bourse has soared: investors understand that left-leaning theory may be the best buttress for a right-leaning reality.
The opposite has been true in Germany, where the culture is more literal and conservative. Mr. Schroder, for example, emphasizes a centrist stance to the point of calling his political platform "The New Middle." But German society has been slow to change, lagging behind France in flexibility and growth, far exceeding France in wage costs. "Germany is still an example of socialism at work," said Norbert Walter, chief economist for Deutsche Bank.
Yet the policy paper on a reinvented left that Mr. Schroder co-signed with Mr. Blair this summer amounted to a remarkably fulsome endorsement of Mr. Clinton's favorite themes. "Too often rights were elevated above responsibilities" by former governments of the left, the two leaders said, adding that the responsibility of the individual "cannot be off-loaded on the state."
Fine words, but Germany and Britain remain far apart in reality. They differ on whether a rampant market should be embraced or reined in; and what, if anything, to do about regulating the Internet-driven zone where human activity seems to lie beyond the control of individual nations.
"We have different words for different traditions, but the fact is we have all reached a new place," said Sidney Blumenthal, an adviser to President Clinton. "We are in the new economy, whether we like it or not. What is the alternative? Close your economy? Reflate? Nobody among these center-left leaders is doing that because everybody knows it leads straight to disaster." True, but the cultural gulfs remain striking. The French, for example, remain far more adamant about insuring what Mr. Jospin calls "the precedence of the political over the economic."
A great Florentine political thinker also believed in that precedence. His name was Machiavelli and he wrote: "Above all, a prince strives to gain from all his acts notoriety as a strong man of superior ability." On that, at least, the still ascendant center-left might agree. For if Mr. Clinton, Mr. Blair, Mr. Jospin and Mr. Schroder have one thing in common, it is an intensely pragmatic nose for power that is stronger than any surviving Socialist, Social Democratic or Democratic principle in this post-ideological age.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: After the Baby Boom;
For the Jobless Rate, The Forecast Is Hazy

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT is hard to walk into a store these days without confronting a help-wanted sign. Software whizzes and hamburger flippers alike can take their pick of jobs, and increasingly can expect not only a fatter paycheck but some kind of sign-on bonus.
This is a good time to be working, by most measures the best in a generation. At 4.1 percent, the unemployment rate last month was the lowest since January 1970. Joblessness has been below 4.5 percent for a year, and below 5 percent for nearly two-and-a-half years. 
 The big questions now about unemployment are how low it can go -- and whether the improvement can be sustained over the long run as the economy and the population change.
Alan Greenspan, for one, seems to think the unemployment rate should not go much lower. The Federal Reserve chairman raised interest rates last week by a quarter of a percentage point, the third time he has done so this year, in large part because of concern that the economy is literally running out of workers to fill all the jobs being created.
The Fed's fear is that as companies have a harder time finding the workers needed to expand or to replace employees who have left for better jobs, they will bid up wages, and then raise prices to maintain their profit margins, setting off an inflationary spiral that could derail the long economic expansion.
For years, analysts believed that inflation danger signals would start flashing red if unemployment dropped below about 6 percent and the economy continued growing at a robust pace. The experience of the past few years suggests that this so-called "natural" unemployment rate is substantially lower, and that the concept is not precise enough to be used by the Federal Reserve to determine when to hit the economic brakes.
Still, no one knows for sure whether the current jobless rate is too low for the economy's overall good or whether there is room for it to drop further. The answer hinges on the economy's ability to generate increases in the growth rate of productivity -- the amount each worker can produce in an hour.
From the early 1970's until this middle of this decade, productivity appeared to be growing at about 1 percent a year, a lackluster performance that had economists puzzled. But in the last few years, productivity growth has been surging. If the productivity improvement sticks, the result would be more job creation and downward pressure on unemployment rates with less risk of inflation -- what some analysts call the "new economy."
The problem now is that growth and unemployment are straining against the limits of what even the new economy would permit.
"You can have an overheated new economy just like you can have an overheated old economy," said Richard Herd, an economist at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the research group for the world's industrialized countries.
In the long run, one of the biggest influences on the labor market is sure to be the immense demographic shift the United States is undergoing. Population growth is slowing, and as the baby boom generation ages, the nation is getting much older.
One implication is clear: the working age population will be smaller, suggesting at first blush that very low unemployment might be the wave of the future. But predicting the effect of the demographic shifts on issues like unemployment is a hazardous business.
For one thing, slower population growth does not necessarily mean that there will be fewer workers competing for each job. If population growth slows without an offsetting increase in productivity, economic growth could be expected to decline as well, and so would job creation.
Moreover, the economy's cyclical ups and downs have proven more powerful so far in determining unemployment than the size of the labor pool. In Japan, for example, the working age population is beginning to shrink, yet the unemployment rate has been going up as the economy suffers through a long downturn. And while there is no obvious reason why the long economic expansion in the United States should end anytime soon, the business cycle is by no means dead.
UNEMPLOYMENT and the size of the labor pool could also be tremendously influenced by any rise or fall in immigration, or by changes in the age at which workers choose to retire. A long trend toward earlier retirement now seems to be giving way to a willingness or need on the part of many older people to keep working at least part time.
"Simply knowing ahead of time the ratio of workers to non-workers takes you a little way toward answering questions like the implications for unemployment," said Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution. "But it doesn't take you terribly far, because that could be determined by other policy choices or some kind of economic shock."

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Have a Heart, or Several

 BODY:
What next, a patent on the human heart? No, but a production line for kits so surgeons can build hearts, maybe. William Haseltine, the highflying chief executive of Human Genome Sciences, raised that possibility last week. His company, which aims to develop medical applications for human genes, has already helped produce a drug, now in testing, meant to generate new vessels when injected into the heart. In other words, a bypass without surgery.
Mr. Haseltine has far greater ambitions over the longer run. "I'm part of a 25-year plan to reconstruct a heart," which could then be implanted, he said in a speech to the Committee for Economic Development in New York. He was referring to a group of business people and scholars led by Michael V. Sefton of the University of Toronto. 
 Mr. Haseltine is already deep in a debate over the extent to which gene sequencing research should be freely available or patented by companies like his. No patents on complete organs are likely, he said after his speech, adding, "It won't be like you have a central hospital in Iowa pumping out human hearts."

HEADLINE: The World: Battle Line;
Russia Pines for a New Savior: Victory

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
JUST for a moment, imagine the corked-up fury of life in a failed superpower, a place where the government seems impotent and scandal-scarred; where the army is demoralized by defeat and incompetence; where the economy seems to rock between inflation and depression. Then imagine that Islamic terrorists from magnifying-glass specks on the map are blowing up your citizens, seemingly with impunity. If you lived there, it might feel good to hit back, too.
That is one way to view, though not to condone, Russia's brutish efforts to subdue its runaway province of Chechnya, a blunt-edged assault that is messily wiping out civilians and soldiers alike, drawing world protest -- and, by Russian estimation, working quite well, thank you. 
 Americans cannot truly imagine Russians' frustration at their imperial disintegration and economic collapse. But perhaps they can get a whiff of the emotional release Chechnya evokes among Russians by recalling how good it felt, after two decades of Vietnam, Watergate, Iran and Lebanon, to finally regain their military prowess -- striking back first at Libyan terrorism in 1986 and then, far more dramatically, against Saddam Hussein in Kuwait in 1991.
Think back to that time: The notion that the United States was back, a force not to be messed with, was almost palpable. American approval was tinged with jingoism; "Vietnam syndrome" was declared dead. Now, after President Boris N. Yeltsin's defiant speech to a gathering of Europe's and America's leaders in Istanbul last week and the Russian military's vow to ignore the world's carping about its tactics in Chechnya, it seems conceivable that post-Soviet Russia has reached a similar turning point in its brief history.
Similar, but not identical. Unlike America, the Bear isn't back. And Russia these days is truly reeling, socially and economically, as America never did. In all probability, it is decades away from reclaiming the world stage. Still, a powerful backlash is beginning to coil, a Slavic jingoism born in desperation, fed by resentment of Western might and exploited by even the most liberal Russian politicians.
THIS is the context in which the Kremlin, eyeing the presidential election next June, is casting the war as a Russian wake-up call -- a "don't tread on me" warning to domestic bandits and foreign critics alike, from a people whose faces are black with heel marks.
"Those early signs of being Westernized, they were all superficial," Leonid A. Sedov, an analyst with Moscow's Public Opinion Foundation, said in an interview. "What's happening is that Russia is taking her own special course, and it's very dangerous."
All these themes, and more, are braided in Chechnya. The military was mortified there in 1996 after the Kremlin yanked it out before it could be decimated by urban guerrillas in the streets of Grozny, Chechnya's capital.
The current war offers generals the chance to wipe that slate clean and regain a measure of influence in Mr. Yeltsin's weakened government.
Military policy makers are bristling over America's attempts to fill the power vacuum along the old Soviet Union's shrunken borders. NATO's three-month bombing campaign against Yugoslavia last spring was, in retrospect, a fault line in relations between the two countries. Chechnya provides a chance to reassert Russian military strength in its own backyard, and to show that Moscow will not surrender its old spheres of influence so easily.
Foreign-policy strategists here have abandoned the gauzy notion of a decade ago that Moscow and Washington would together make the world safe for democracy; now they see the West mostly as a rival, if not a threat. Nowhere was that clearer than last week in Istanbul where, as Western leaders condemned Chechnya misdeeds in one hall, President Clinton watched in another as several former Soviet states signed a deal for a new oil pipeline that would circumvent Russian pipelines and their tariffs.
To Russian foreign-policy makers, subduing Chechnya keeps Russia in the pipeline game, since a stable Chechnya is central to building new routes nearby or enlarging pipelines already in the area. And it allows the Kremlin to return the thumb in the eye that it clearly believes has been delivered by America and its allies on issues from pipelines to economic reform.
To the political elite, Chechnya is as much electoral as military strategy. Given a chance to wave Russia's tricolor instead of lamenting its decline, virtually every politician in the nation has closed ranks behind the Kremlin and against its foreign human-rights critics.
Just how little daylight separates them is clear from one remarkable scene: A leading Western-oriented member of parliament, Grigory Yavlinsky, suggested a negotiated Chechen peace earlier this month. And immediately, the man who is perhaps closer to Washington than any politician in Russia, the Kremlin adviser Anatoly Chubais, called it the act of a traitor.
Mr. Chubais, who hopes to elect his own faction to parliament, would not be saying such things if voters did not enthusiastically agree. For whatever the elites now believe, it is the nationalistic backlash among ordinary Russians that is driving them and events in Chechnya.
FOR those Russians, the distinction between human-rights violations and the extermination of terrorists is not so much artificial as nonexistent. True, ordinary Russians opposed the last assault on Chechnya, in 1994, as a cruel waste of lives and money. But now it is an issue of self-defense: Chechen bandits invaded the province of Dagestan last summer, seeking to extend their reach, and Russians widely believe that it was Chechen terrorists who blew up apartment houses and barracks across Russia, killing hundreds of innocents. No one in Russia expects such a war to be played by Hoyle's rules.
For Americans, the irony is that they may have done a lot to set the mood for Russia's current attitude toward Chechnya. Conflict there may have been unavoidable; Islamic militants effectively gave the Kremlin and its armies a choice of fighting or losing both territory and Russia's honor. But both the rules of the battle and the mentality of its leaders have been molded by NATO's relentless bombing of Yugoslavia last spring -- opening an East-West rift that American diplomats then predicted would soon be papered over, but that has only yawned wider in the intervening months.
In Russia, the Kosovo war is remembered as a conflict NATO launched in utter disregard of Moscow's emotional pleas and warnings of disaster. This time around, Moscow has returned the cold shoulder, ignoring Western pleas to mediate and even to closely observe the conflict.
Now, in Russian eyes, Moscow's day-and-night bombardment of Chechen targets mirrors NATO's round-the-clock raids, save the smart bombs and accurate missiles that minimized civilian Yugoslav deaths.
Then, Russia denounced as war crimes the civilian deaths that did occur, from errant NATO missiles or bombs that hit refugee sites. Now those same horrors have become justification for ignoring complaints about Chechen civilian casualties. More than 200,000 Chechens have fled their homes, and Chechen officials say more than 4,000 civilians have been killed.
It is not that Russia is insensitive to those complaints, or at least to their effect on domestic politics. In fact, the Kremlin has tightly manipulated news coverage here, calling the war an "anti-terrorist action," restricting live coverage and playing down stories of civilian suffering. But while Mr. Sedov's own polls show some softening of public backing for the conflict in recent weeks, Russians' thirst for a victory to celebrate seems apparent: whereas half the population supported giving Chechnya independence four years ago, 8 in 10 now support the Kremlin's battle plans.
More revealing, perhaps, is the response to the question of whether Russia must reinstate itself as a "great empire;" 85 percent said yes, and 7 percent no.
"It reminds me of the feelings of an old man who still imagines that he's a young vigorous man again," Mr. Sedov said.

Chart: "Politics, Petroleum and Pride"
Russia's battering of the autonomous republic of Chechnya echoes in many ways in the Russian psyche, reflecting frustrations at the Soviet breakup and fears that Russia itself could disintegrate.
 
FEARS OF A PRECEDENT
With 21 other ethnically-based semi-autonomous republics left over from the Soviet era within the Russian Federation, authorities in Moscow do not want to appear to be opening the door to demands for independence.
 
LOST OIL AND INFLUENCE
The Caspian Sea is one of world's hottest zones for oil and gas exploration, and many of the promising fields lie in territory that once was part of the Soviet Union but became independent a decade ago. Now, though, the newly independent republics of Azerbaijan and Georgia are planning, with Turkey, to build a pipeline that would completely avoid Russia and instead pump oil toward Western markets via a Turkish port on the Mediterranean. The oil deal is a central element in efforts by these republics to build closer relations with the Kremlin's old rival, the United States.
 
CHRONOLOGY OF CONFLICT
 
1990
NOV. 23 -- Chechen independence movement, led by Jakar Dudayev, calls for sovereignty.
 
1991
OCT. 27 -- Without recgognition from Moscow, Dudayev is elected president of Chechnya.
 
1992, 1993
A two-year period of mutual non-recognition ensues. Opposition to Dudayev grows in Chechnya.
 
1994
DEC. 11 -- After several small skirmishes, Russian troops launch a full-scale invasion, taking control of the capital Grozny.
 
1996
APRIL -- After more than a year of brutal combat, Dudayev is killed in a Russian bombing raid.
 
AUG. 6 -- Hundreds of Chechen rebels seize Grozny after a two-week battle. Russia begins withdrawing demoralized troops.
 
1997
JAN. 28 -- Chechens elect Aslan Maskhadov as their new president.
MAY 12 -- Yeltsin and Maskhadov sign peace treaty.
 
1999
AUG.-NOV. -- Relations are still strained and formal recognition still elusive. Conflict escalates again after a summer of terrorist bombings in and around Moscow. (pg. 5)

HEADLINE: BRIEFS;
Heading for a Record Low, Unemployment Rate Drops

BYLINE: By LISA SUHAY 

 BODY:
The state's unemployment rate dropped for the fourth straight month, a decline that some say is likely to continue and result in the state's lowest jobless rate in history.
"What we are seeing here is the largest peacetime expansion of jobs since we've been keeping records," said Carl Van Horn, director of the John J. Heldrich Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers University. 
 According to the state Department of Labor, the unemployment rate dropped another O.1 percent in October, bringing it to 4.5 percent. The report, made public last Wednesday, stated that nearly half of the non-government jobs created last month were in the construction industry.
Payroll employment in the state increased last month by 3,200 jobs, for a record 3,880,400, according to the report. New construction jobs accounted for the biggest increase, with 1,400 jobs added to payrolls. Construction employment rose to 138,900, the highest in nine years.
Other strong growth categories included social services, finance and insurance, health care and retail trade. LISA SUHAY

HEADLINE: The Battle Over A.T.M. Fees

 BODY:
Customers are expressing outrage at the surcharges banks impose on them for using automated teller machines owned by banks other than their own. The cities of Santa Monica and San Francisco recently banned these surcharges. The New York City Council is planning to do the same. But before customers get too riled up about paying fees for the privilege of reclaiming their own money, they need to recognize that businesses do, after all, have a right to charge for their services. More important, efforts to ban the surcharges are apt to backfire and cause bank customers more harm than good.
Consider depositors at, say, Chase Manhattan Bank in New York City. Most of them pay no fee if they withdraw money from one of Chase's machines. But if they withdraw money from their Chase accounts by using one of Citibank's machines, they pay two fees. 
 The first goes to Chase, which keeps some of the fee and passes the rest on to the computer network that processes the transfer and to Citibank. The second fee goes directly to Citibank as additional compensation for providing its machines to noncustomers. It is this second fee that particularly angers many consumers and leads to complaints that the banks are charging the noncustomers twice.
But those consumers forget that before A.T.M.'s depositors sometimes had to pay fees to get a bank to cash a check drawn on another bank. But often they could not get cash at all from banks other than their own. Now they can, but for a fee.
Over the past three years, as surcharges have taken hold, banks and other institutions, such as merchants, have installed A.T.M.'s in airports, gas stations and nearly everywhere else. Surcharges make it profitable for merchants to own A.T.M.'s, and the competition from these merchant-owned A.T.M.'s keeps the banks from imposing excessive charges for use of their own machines. If Citibank tried to charge noncustomers excessive fees, nearby merchants would profit by installing their own A.T.M.'s and luring users by setting lower surcharges.
Critics of surcharges argue that they drive depositors from small banks to large banks so that they can take advantage of machines spread all across town that are free, of course, only to the large bank's depositors. There is, however, no evidence that this has happened. In fact, it is the bans on surcharges that most threaten to harm small banks. After Santa Monica passed its ban, two large banks, Bank of America and Wells Fargo, shut their machines to noncustomers. That, more than modest surcharges, threatens to make customers flock to big banks.
Banning surcharges will have three economic reverberations, none good. Some banks will close down machines in underpopulated regions because, in the absence of surcharges, they will generate too little revenue. Other banks will block depositors from other institutions from using their machines.
But the most common reaction may well be that banks sell their A.T.M.'s to nonfinancial owners, such as individual hotels and restaurants, which remain eligible under most state and local surcharge bans to keep imposing fees. The rationale is that the exemption for nonfinancial owners preserves their incentive to install machines. But the odd result is that bans designed to protect depositors may wind up preserving surcharges even as they make finding A.T.M.'s more difficult.
The banks are challenging local bans on surcharges in the courts. However, neither legislation nor litigation should cloud the central goal of consumer protection. The best policy for consumers is to steer clear of local regulations that will help concentrate business in a few big banks and make it harder for many citizens to obtain cash.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Silent Majorities;
Polling's 'Dirty Secret': No Response

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON is such a devoted student of public opinion polls that his aides say he can recite, from memory, the American people's double-digit tastes on a wide array of issues. Besides using survey data to help shape some of the most important decisions of his presidency, Mr. Clinton has also consulted polls before deciding whether his family should go to the beach or the mountains on their summer vacations.
Most infamously, Dick Morris, his former political adviser, testified that Mr. Clinton asked him to conduct a secret, overnight poll to determine whether Americans were prepared to hear the truth about his affair with a 21-year-old intern inside the White House. Mr. Morris said that after taking the survey, he told the President: "You can't tell them about it. They'll kill you. They're just not ready for it." 
 "Well, we just have to win, then," Mr. Clinton replied. It was Mr. Morris's poll that helped persuade the president to deceive his family, his aides and the public for months.
"So the few hundred people who answered Morris's poll determined a critical presidential decision," wrote Arianna Huffington, the conservative columnist who has crusaded for years against politicians' devotion to polls by urging people to refuse to respond to pollsters' questions. Ms. Huffington described the White House sex scandal as "the first political crisis to be so entirely driven and shaped by polls," asserting that it was the president's consistently high approval ratings that spared him from removal from office by the Senate in February.
This vigilant reliance on poll numbers by the president and most politicians raises an important public policy question: Who actually talks to pollsters and who does not?
The answer, it turns out, is troubling news for the polling industry and the people who rely on the numbers: Far fewer people agree to participate in surveys than just 10 years ago, a fact that some critics call the industry's "dirty little secret," because most polling firms refuse to divulge their surveys' refusal rates.
THE trend is especially important in the current presidential campaign, with a newly front-loaded primary calendar that makes polls more crucial to candidates' fortunes than ever. Already, some candidates have cited their own discouraging poll numbers and the subsequent lack of financial support as reason enough to drop out of the race, months before the first primary ballot is cast.
Thanks to the ever-rising number of opinion polls and telemarketing phone calls -- and no doubt to the increasing disengagement of people from politics article, page 16 -- more and more people simply refuse to be questioned. Lately the trend has raised alarms among pollsters and social scientists, who are starting to question the validity of many surveys conducted for politicians and the media.
And doubts about polls can only increase with the rise of Internet polling (which Mr. Morris, among others, is trying to promote). Internet polling raises obvious questions of methodology, in part because respondents are self-selected and come only from the population subset of computer users.
In traditional polling, falling response rates, as they are called in the trade, are a "terrible, terrible problem," says the pollster Everett Ladd, director of the Roper Center. Even gauging it is a challenge, given the reluctance of polling firms and media organizations to routinely disclose response rates.
Pollsters say response rates have fallen as low as 20 percent in some recent polls, which means that as many as 8 out of 10 people initially asked to participate in a poll refused to be interviewed. Ten years ago, polling response rates were typically at least 50 percent.
ONE media pollster attributes the growing number of refusals to the public's weariness with aggressive telemarketers.
"Everybody is always trying to sell you something on the phone," said the pollster, who insisted on anonymity. "Most refusals come within the first 30 seconds, when people are not certain it is a legitimate poll. They usually assume it is just another attempt to sell them something."
In response to the problem, an International Conference on Survey Non-Response was convened last month in Portland, Oregon. It was attended by 500 pollsters, marketing professionals and academics, who spent several days grappling with the issue.
"If you have money to spend, you can still get quite high response rates," said Robert M. Groves, a professor at the University of Michigan who chaired the conference in Portland. But the national polls conducted for large media outlets with limited budgets often cut too many corners to produce results in just a few days, experts argue.
M OST of the political polls taken by news organizations, including The New York Times/CBS News poll, struggle to persuade people to participate. (The Times doesn't publish its response rates, which vary but generally match the long-term trend. It has provided them on request to journalists from other news organizations.)
Some scholars are concerned that the public's diverse demographics aren't being reflected in poll results.
"The data are pretty clear that you miss people who live alone, especially younger people who are more likely to be out in the evenings," Mr. Groves said. "You tend to over-sample people with young children because they are home. You also tend to over-interview the elderly population because they are at home and are often willing to be polled. You get the unemployed. It's an odd distribution."
The poll with the highest response rate is the monthly unemployment survey conducted by the government. The survey result is a key economic indicator -- last week it prompted the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates -- so it better be reliable. And scholars generally agree that it is, largely because the survey's response rate is between 94 and 96 percent. The survey's pollsters interview 40,000 people across the country over a 10-day period. Studies show that people are much more willing to respond to a poll conducted by the government than by the media or a private firm.
Ms. Huffington and other conservative commentators have asserted that Mr. Clinton's enduring high approval ratings result from a political bias in polls conducted for the national media. In 1996, these critics complained that the polls often overstated Mr. Clinton's lead over the Republican nominee, Bob Dole.
But the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press studied this question and found little evidence of political bias in national political polls. The study also considered the criticism that quick media polls often miss some people.
The center took two surveys -- one that contacted 1,000 adults by phone in a five-day survey, and a more elaborate one over eight weeks, which included advance letters announcing that a poll-taker would be calling and offers of a small monetary gift in return for participation.
Perhaps not surprisingly, 79 percent of the people contacted in the more rigorous survey agreed to be interviewed, while only 65 percent agreed to participate in the five-day telephone survey.
"But as it turned out," the center reported, 'the standard and rigorous surveys produced strikingly similar results."
Thus the Pew Center findings suggest that the non-response issue could be addressed with polls that adhere to rigorous standards and controls.
Increasingly, academics, social scientists and even politicians are becoming more vocal about their distaste for politicians who vote according to polls rather than their consciences.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York recently decried politicians' addiction to poll results, suggesting that it had caused Congress to adopt popular causes, like the line-item veto, that were later found by the Supreme Court to be unconstitutional. "We've lost our sense of ideas that we stand by, principles that are important to us," Mr. Moynihan said in an interview with Peter Jennings, the ABC News anchor, which was published in the periodical Civilization. "We've got very near to becoming careless with the Constitution."
Mr. Jennings asked, "Do you think that, in some respect, polls have contributed, as I think I detect on occasion, to a lack of confidence in politicians in their own deliberative thinking process?"
"Yeah," Mr. Moynihan replied, "I think you wouldn't be mistaken, as a citizen, to ask: Are we really necessary?"

LENGTH: 971 words

HEADLINE: Electoral Setbacks Force German Chancellor to Retreat From Lure of the Free Market

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: FLORENCE, Italy, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Having spoken out vigorously this summer in favor of the free market, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany arrived at a conference here today on the future of Social Democracy saying a leading German company should be protected against a hostile takeover bid from a British concern.
The apparent contradiction between the chancellor's avowed embrace of a freewheeling entrepreneurial culture and his patriotic defense of the mobile phone group Mannesmann suggested yet another zigzag in his attempt to reform his Social Democratic Party and adapt Germany to the pressures of the global economy. Trying to strike a balance between the market and traditional values of social justice is a major difficulty facing center-left leaders who are meeting here to try to define a political course some have called the "third way." 
 President Clinton, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain are among the leaders attending the two-day conference on "progressive governance," where Mr. Clinton will lay out the themes of fiscal discipline, government activism, individual responsibility and broadened opportunity that he believes have buttressed American economic success in recent years.
That success -- while seemingly incontrovertible in numbers like the 19 million jobs created during the Clinton years -- is by no means universally recognized in Europe. On a recent tour of the continent, Sidney Blumenthal, an adviser to Mr. Clinton, was struck by the image of the United States in the minds of the European left:
"Top-hatted plutocrats crushing the masses, a place from a Brecht play where crime is so rife you can barely stick your head outside without being shot," he said. "An anti-American imagination is at work that obscures American reality."
In part, of course, such descriptions merely reflect European distaste for American triumphalism. The French now often refer to the United States as a "hyperpower," and the Greeks have dubbed Mr. Clinton a "planetarchis," or planetary ruler.
But the disappearance of the communism against which the moderate left long defined itself and the emergence of a global economy that has transformed the workplace have created pressures and divergences within the family of the moderate left that go far deeper than trans-Atlantic misunderstanding.
Nowhere is the pressure on Social Democracy greater than in Germany, home of "consensus capitalism" and the "social market" model that propelled the postwar miracle. This model, while still enjoying wide support, has proved generally ill-adapted to the speed and competitive demands of a global economy driven by information technology.
Mr. Schroder came to power just over a year ago beneath the electoral slogan "the New Middle," and this summer he co-signed a long paper on the third way that said the European left had too often favored state intervention and excessive economic regulation.
"The weaknesses of markets have been overstated and their strengths underestimated," Mr. Schroder and Mr. Blair wrote then. "We want a society which celebrates successful entrepreneurs."
Since then, however, Mr. Schroder has suffered a series of electoral setbacks, and he has been roundly criticized both by the labor unions that remain a cornerstone of German Social Democracy and the governing Socialists in France.
As a result, in another of the zig-zags that have characterized his government, he has begun to retreat from his embrace of Mr. Blair's New Labor. His unusual intervention today in the British company Vodafone's $123.6 billion hostile bid for Mannesmann illustrates this retreat vividly.
In an interview published in Le Monde today, Mr. Schroder said that "those who mount such operations in Germany underestimate the virtues of co-determination" -- a reference to the German model of having worker representation in the boardroom.
While there is no evidence that Vodafone would undo this model in Mannesmann's operations, there is ample evidence of German unions' and the popular press's uniting in outcry against the British bid.
"Hostile takeover bids destroy the culture of a company," Mr. Schroder said. "They harm the target, and, over the medium term, they also hurt the predator." He added that he was not, as a general rule, against foreign companies taking "stakes" in German companies, but called for "extreme prudence."
German companies have been very active in buying foreign companies in recent years. The automaker BMW bought Rover Britain, and Daimler-Benz bought Chrysler. Other prominent acquisitions include Deutsche Bank's purchase of Banker's Trust and Bertelsmann's acquisition of Random House.
But is is clear that ahead of a Social Democratic Party congress in Berlin next month, Mr. Schroder has become deeply concerned with retaining the support of the left wing of his party. He has taken to scoffing privately at his old political slogan. "The New Middle," he now says, "drives Porsches."
In his latest lurch to the left, Mr. Schroder is certain to find support from French Socialists, who have rejected the third way as a doctrine and are fiercely critical of Mr. Clinton's America. "The United States is too unjust a society for us to admire it, and places too much trust in the market," said Alain Bergounioux, a leading Socialist.
Mr. Jospin and Mr. Blair have taken radically different views on the future of the center-left, with Mr. Jospin emphasizing that Socialism was "born and developed to oppose the capitalism of industrial society" even as he has adopted a pragmatic approach to government.
"Mr. Clinton is no Social Democrat, and cannot judge European socialism," Mr. Bergounioux said. "At best, perhaps Hillary is a Social Democrat, because she tried and failed to borrow some ideas from our welfare state."

HEADLINE: CHOKING ON GROWTH: A special report.;
In Atlanta, Suburban Comforts Thwart Plans to Limit Sprawl

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 20

 BODY:
The builders of Georgia's epic new mall, a vast savanna of shopping on 100 acres, chose a precarious moment in Atlanta's history to open their doors a few months ago.
All summer, the city had been trapped under a hood of smog. Highway information signs begged commuters to eat at their desks. Traffic was so heavy that a single accident caused nine hours of delays one morning. 
 Normally conservative politicians and business leaders had been driven to create an extraordinarily powerful superagency to slow the region's growth machine. Its chairman, a real estate developer, took to quoting Gandhi on greed.
And right in the middle of Atlanta's summer of excess, the Mall of Georgia opened 35 miles northeast of downtown in Gwinnett County. It called itself a new kind of mall, an open-air village for strollers complete with a nature park, but as the largest mall in the state, it quickly became an enormous emblem of sprawl.
The town square out front could not hide the surrounding blacktop with spaces for 8,600 cars, because cars are the only way to get to the Mall of Georgia. There is no public transportation in Gwinnett County, and none will be available for years.
Atlanta, like so many other cities, continues to build malls, office parks and subdivisions, even though the consequences have been made clear on the region's highways and in its air. The national call for smarter, more urban growth has been heeded by the region's leaders, but the packed parking lots around the Mall of Georgia suggest a deep disconnect between the way most Americans live and one of the first official efforts to control their appetite for suburban comforts.
The leadership of the 10-county metropolis that includes Atlanta has known for years that the region's smashing economic success was producing so much congestion that its future was threatened. This year it acted, creating one of the most powerful tools in the country for containing growth, the Georgia Regional Transportation Authority, empowered to veto highways, order new rail lines and deny development like subdivisions and malls.
But sprawl is the result of millions of small, individual decisions -- from the building of a giant mall to the decision to shop there -- that have barely changed, despite the public's expressed disgust.
Given years of population growth that was overtly encouraged by government, those decisions have accumulated to make Atlanta the epicenter of the nation's struggle with road congestion, air pollution and overdevelopment. No city has scrambled faster to develop long-range plans that might reduce the effects of growth, but in no city in America do residents continue to spend more time in their cars. That is a direct result of the Atlanta area's low population density, the lowest of the nation's largest metro areas, and its continuing consumption of forest land at the rate of 50 acres a day. The Atlanta region has about 1,370 people per square mile, compared with about 5,400 in the Los Angeles area.
If the region still has any hopes for continued economic growth -- and Atlanta is loathe to turn off the population spigot, which added more people here in the 1990's than to any other metropolitan region -- its residents will have to change their way of life, and they may have started too late.
 
With Car the King, A Lack of Sidewalks
Counties like Gwinnett and Douglas still prefer the tax revenue of a new mall to rejecting a developer's request; three regional malls that rival the Mall of Georgia are being built and another is planned.
Despite a renewed interest in developing vacant sections of downtown and midtown, home buyers still prefer the big lots and low prices of suburban cities like Cumming and Alpharetta to a smaller, more expensive city home. And most commuters, particularly those who work at suburban office parks, still find a single-occupant car more convenient than a train or bus.
For all the prosperous professionals who have moved into the core city of Atlanta to escape traffic, the growth of the suburbs was 100 times greater than that of the city last year. The city, in fact, has grown little while the region around it has swelled. With 427,500 people, Atlanta today accounts for 13.3 percent of the metropolitan area's 3.2 million residents, while it made up 22.4 percent in 1980.
The automobile is so essential here that most neighborhoods lack sidewalks, and the design of the cities has made it difficult for people to find ways to reduce driving. Though a growing number have joined car pools that allow them to use designated faster lanes, vehicle emissions have hit a historic high. Of more concern, the region's residents now drive an average of 35 miles a day, more than anywhere in the country.
Neighborhoods continue to reject public transit lines, in part because they fear that they will bring other races into their midst, or because they dread the foot traffic and development that public transit is designed to concentrate. Counties that do try to restrain growth often face furious opposition in a region with a strong libertarian streak, as longtime landowners insist on the right to sell to the highest-paying developer.
"We're talking about changing human nature here, and especially the independent streak that so many Southerners have," said Lucy Smethurst, director of the region's Clean Air Campaign, a consortium of businesses, government agencies and environmental groups trying to break long-standing regional habits. "We're trying to slow down the Queen Mary, and we've just now seen the rocks in the water ahead."
It is a measure of Atlanta's ambivalence about how to deal with its roaring growth that even the Mall of Georgia, which one environmentalist decried as "the very embodiment of sprawl," is being offered by its supporters as a solution to the problem.
F. Wayne Hill, the chairman of the Gwinnett County Board of Commissioners, who pushed the mall through the approval process, said it would keep Gwinnett residents from driving to a mall across the county.
"It's not sprawl -- it's actually keeping our people from driving even further," Mr. Hill said. "Do you want everyone on the roads, driving downtown to shop? Gwinnett needs its own malls because people are choosing to live here, which they can still do because this is a free country."
All that freedom, however, lies at the root of Atlanta's crisis. The region's population has grown 70 percent since 1980, spilling into once-rural counties, largely because there was always more farmland to clear for another subdivision, unimpeded by natural barriers. Gwinnett County's population more than tripled, to 523,900 residents.
Until recently, there were few regulatory barriers to growth. The competition for development and the accompanying tax revenue led counties to build hundreds of miles of roads without fear of interference by the state. (The Mall of Georgia will generate nearly $5 million a year in property taxes and $6 million in sales taxes.)
That way of thinking began to change in June 1996, when the Environmental Protection Agency threatened to ban federal money for highway construction in 13 regional counties because of high ozone and smog levels. Last year, when the ban took effect, businesses acted, fearing that government regulations combined with Atlanta's congestion, pollution and worsening image would begin to hurt profits.
One business leader very publicly called the federal action a "train wreck" for the region. Companies began to organize to reduce air pollution, which this year produced 69 smog-alert days, a local record.
"I think the business community realized that we couldn't afford to be paralyzed by the situation, the way other cities are," said the chairman of the Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce, John A. Williams, a real estate developer. "To ensure that Atlanta continued to grow and be prosperous, it became evident that the single most important issue was improving the quality of life. So we had to work with the political and environmental communities to come up with a solution."
Businesses, in fact, have done far more than residents to reduce congestion.
In the last year, ridership on the region's subway increased only 1.4 percent. But BellSouth, the huge regional telecommunications company with headquarters here, announced that it would consolidate 75 offices, with 13,000 employees, into three regional centers, each situated at a subway station.
The Coca-Cola Company plans to bring 2,500 employees from the suburbs to its headquarters downtown. And several real-estate developers are beginning to concentrate on what is called new urbanism projects, in which housing is built around offices and shops, encouraging residents to walk to work.
The hope is to find a way to continue the region's growth -- the lifeblood of corporate profits -- while concentrating it in a way that is less harmful.
"It's what it means to be a good citizen," said BellSouth's chief executive, F. Duane Ackerman. "The congestion and air quality situation has really risen to a crescendo here in Atlanta, and anything that affects the quality of life could affect the growth of the area."
Most important, however, business leaders joined forces with environmental groups to support Gov. Roy E. Barnes's plan for a Georgia Regional Transportation Authority, known as Greta.
The authority, quickly approved by the State Legislature in March, is intended to provide the firm control over growth and transportation planning that local governments, competing with one another, have failed to muster.
The agency will have the power to build (or veto) roads and transit systems. In theory, it could build and operate a rail line through any of several counties that have opposed mass transit. It can also have an effective veto over large subdivisions, office parks and malls by refusing permits to tie into the road system.
The authority's chairman, Joel Cowan, made it clear in a recent interview that new projects like the Mall of Georgia would not be approved unless they had mass transit connections, or at least the population density to justify them.
"We're going to have to reorder the culture in which decisions to build these projects are made," said Mr. Cowan, a developer and advocate of better planning. "A mall like that will be a huge traffic generator, and there's nothing we can do about it now. But in the future, we will need to see a great deal more density before a plan like that is approved, and a corridor for transit. We have to ensure that these projects don't create new trips."
In other words, a mall might be approved if it is integrated with housing and office buildings. This idea of "manufactured density," for which Mr. Cowan is a leading apostle, is fairly radical for Atlanta and the Southeast, which grew up around the historical planning orthodoxy of strictly separating housing and commercial areas. But a consensus is clearly growing among the region's leaders that houses, offices and shops must begin sharing the same space, much as they do in older, Northeast cities.
"That's the way Atlanta is going to have to grow, in true live-work-walk communities, with enough density to support transit," said Mr. Williams, who has bet much of his company on the concept. "It's going to be a lifestyle change, but given the alternative, I think people will take to it."
That consensus, however, is at a fairly elite level, and it is unclear whether it will trickle down to the warring camps of property owners and new residents. A stark example of their conflicting interests occurred recently in Cherokee County, a largely undeveloped area 25 miles north of downtown where the population has grown more than 50 percent since 1990.
Last year, at the urging of newcomers who moved in and then wanted to slow the growth around them, the county commission passed an innovative plan to concentrate development in 13 town centers, leaving most of the county pastoral. Longtime landowners, however, fought the plan bitterly because it meant they might not be able to sell to developers; some zoning meetings erupted in fistfights. In July, the commission dropped the plan.
"I haven't given up," said Emily Lemcke, the chairwoman of the Cherokee commissioners and a leading proponent of careful growth. "I still hope that we can educate people and get them to understand that the whole region is going to have to change. But for now, there are still too many people who don't want to be told how to live their lives or what to do with their land."
That seems quite likely. In September, Greta delayed a new beltway in the far northern suburbs, long the favorite of state highway builders, in favor of more carpool lanes and an expanded transit system. Governor Barnes has also ordered counties to set aside 20 percent of their undeveloped land for parks and green space.
Mr. Cowan, the chairman of the agency, said he planned to interpret its mandate broadly, and would make the decisions that are too tough for local politicians to swallow. Asked, for instance, about the recent refusal by neighborhoods east of downtown in DeKalb County to accept a new rail line, he noted that the agency had the power to build a line over local opposition.
 
Efforts to Revive Dormant Downtown
There are other signs, too, that the region is beginning to look inward for its future. Several major projects are under way to awaken Atlanta's dormant downtown, which until recently had not had the nightlife to attract nearby residential development. In September, Turner Broadcasting opened its new basketball and hockey stadium, Philips Arena, next to its expanding CNN Center, having reversed a decision to build in the suburbs. Two developers plan to build a walker-friendly mini-city of homes, offices and shops on the site of the Atlantic Steel plant, a 144-acre wasteland on the northern edge of downtown.
Neighborhoods near the center of the city have become popular among young couples who have rejected the commuter's life, making houses in such areas far more costly than similar dwellings in the suburbs.
"We're too young to be spending our entire lives in the car," said Kate Folse, an employee-benefits manager who recently moved with her husband, Brian, from suburban Duluth, in Gwinnett County, to the Virginia Highlands area, Atlanta's brick-restaurant and coffee shop district. "It was hard convincing my husband, but when we did the math, we realized we were spending 20 hours a week commuting, and we had no control of our time. Now we love walking everywhere."
The Folses, however, are vastly outnumbered by their suburban counterparts. From April of last year to this year, the 10-county Atlanta region grew by 94,300 people, the second-largest annual population increase in its history. But the city of Atlanta grew by only 900 people.
Those trends show no sign of changing. Last month, local officials proposed a 25-year plan, intended to reduce ozone emissions, that still forecasts the region growing by a million more people by 2025, most of whom will live in suburban areas and continue to drive. Even with all the proposed spending, the average time that Atlantans spend in the car is projected to increase to 90 minutes a day, from 80 minutes now.
Some transportation experts say that as long as a region's economy is growing and creating jobs, there is nothing the city can do about traffic congestion.
"The people who are complaining about congestion really need to get a life," said David T. Hartgen, the head of transportation studies at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, who has studied Atlanta's traffic patterns. "This is a democratic, free society with a lot of wealth, which translates to private mobility. Short of extremely draconian measures which no one wants to take, there's almost nothing that will materially affect traffic congestion."

HEADLINE: U.S. Readies a Major Land-Protection Initiative

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: CORTEZ, Colo., Nov. 20

 BODY:
As one of its last major public land initiatives, the Clinton administration is preparing to designate as national monuments up to a dozen open areas in the West that federal officials say need protection from future commercial development and recreational overuse.
Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, who came to Colorado this weekend to build support for the action, said the administration had decided to act because, in many cases, Congress had failed to act on proposed legislation that would accomplish the same thing. Delays, he said, had prompted President Clinton to consider invoking the Antiquities Act of 1906, which gives the president the authority to act by executive order in the case of any lands that have scientific, historic or archaeological significance. 
 Since the law was passed, every president except Richard M. Nixon, Ronald Reagan and George Bush has designated at least one national monument. There are now more than 100.
Mr. Babbitt said the administration was more than willing to allow Congress to take the lead. But conceding that opposition in some cases might be strong, he said the president was willing to act.
"I certainly hope this is not our last major initiative, but it is a major undertaking," Mr. Babbitt said in an interview on Friday before hiking through part of the 73,000 acres he wants added to the Colorado National Monument, near Grand Junction. Today he toured Indian ruins here that he wants declared monuments.
"The needs are growing year by year," he said, referring to commercial and recreation pressures. "Congress hasn't responded at all. So rather than leave it all to the 11th hour, the president is ready to consider these on a case-by-case basis."
Besides the two Colorado sites, the other proposed monuments are the Arizona strip, on the north rim of the Grand Canyon; Perry Mesa, near Flagstaff, Ariz.; La Cienega, near Tucson; the Missouri Breaks, along 140 miles of the Missouri River in Montana; Steens Mountain, in southeast Oregon; Soda Mountain, in southern Oregon; the Santa Rosa Mountains, near Palm Springs, Calif.; the Carrizo Plain, in California's central valley; the Otay Mountains, east of San Diego; and thousands of islands and rocks off the California coast.
Having toured them all within the last year, Mr. Babbitt said he had found growing public support for granting monument status, which would provide greater protections through the National Park Service or the Bureau of Land Management. All the lands under consideration are managed by the land bureau, but monument status would add access restrictions and ensure that they cannot be developed or sold.
Preservation groups and environmentalists are applauding the initiative. "It sends a very important signal that these special places deserve more protection than they're getting," said Richard Moe, president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation. "This tells the world that they are very significant sites."
But many opponents view it as little more than a political tactic by Mr. Clinton, a way for him to seal his legacy as an environmentalist and cement environmental groups' support for Vice President Al Gore in his quest for the presidency.
In addition, lawmakers from Western states, like Senators Robert F. Bennett of Utah and Wayne Allard of Colorado, object to federal intervention within their borders without sufficient local input. And commercial interests say the initiative is yet another effort by the administration to ignore the economic consequences of environmental policy.
"This certainly smacks of another antimining advocacy effort," said John Grasser, a spokesman for the National Mining Association. "You have to go where the minerals are, and if they continue to withdraw lands where the mines are, it means going elsewhere to develop, which means out of the country and the loss of millions of jobs."
Myra B. Hyde, director of environmental issues for the National Cattlemen's Beef Association, whose members own herds that graze on open lands, said: "Once you take lands out of production, it affects whole communities."
Lawyers for the Interior Department said that some of the lands in question have mineral resources but that none have active mines. They also said grazing rights would probably not be affected.
Representative James V. Hansen of Utah, who is chairman of a House national parks and public lands subcommittee, sponsored legislation two years ago that would require approval of Congress as well as the governor and state legislature to designate a national monument that exceeds 5,000 acres. It passed the House, but a companion Senate bill is still under consideration.
When the most recent national monument -- Grand Staircase-Escalante, a 1.9 million-acre tract in southern Utah -- was designated by Mr. Clinton in 1996, Mr. Hansen called the designation "the biggest land grab in the nation." And in a letter last month to Mr. Babbitt expressing concern over monument designations in their state, three Colorado lawmakers -- Senator Allard, Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell and Representative Scott McInnis -- described it as a "heavy-handed federal action."
Mr. Allard said in an interview this week that Mr. Babbitt had yet to respond to the letter. He criticized administration officials for "storming in and storming out without doing the proper legwork" on the issue.
Mr. McInnis, who attended a public forum led by Mr. Babbitt at the Colorado National Monument on Friday, predicted that Congress would expand the monument, which is in his district, within the administration's timetable. With regard to the other lands, he added: "Executive order is not the way to go. The Antiquities Act was never intended to bypass Congress."
Allen Freemyer, staff director of Mr. Hansen's subcommittee, said that even without Mr. Hansen's bill, the administration already had "hundreds of tools" to manage public lands without drawing on a 93-year-old measure that was passed before agencies like the park service were created to manage and protect federal lands. "This is a big photo-op declaration, which really isn't necessary," he said of Mr. Babbitt's initiative. "They're just doing what Al Gore likes to do best, the champion of the environment warning that if we don't make these places monuments, the bulldozers are waiting."
To administration officials and environmental groups, that prospect is not much of an exaggeration. As the expanding national economy of the 1990's has created more business opportunities and disposable income, they contend, open lands have become more vulnerable to commercial development, recreational use and encroaching sprawl.
At the forum, Mr. Babbitt said that whether it is Congress or Mr. Clinton who makes the designations, monument status would assure that "the next seven generations" have the same opportunity to enjoy the lands that visitors have now.
