HEADLINE: A Metropolis Made Great By Greed;
New York Has a Credo, But 'You First' Isn't It

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Most cities have a burnished story of creation, some hoary tale of heroism and principle that swells the chests of their citizens as they strut down historic streets past Starbucks and The Gap. Take Philadelphia; founded on the premise of religious tolerance, its very name evokes fraternal love.
Then there is New York. Crass, uncouth, grubby New York. 
 As the recent PBS documentary "New York" demonstrates, this city was founded largely on the premise of making a buck. While Providence, R.I., proudly remembers the meeting between Roger Williams and the Narragansett Indians that led to its becoming a haven of tolerance, New York recalls how Peter Minuit bought Manhattan island from local Indians for a Dutch song.
Legend has it that Minuit paid $24 in beads and trinkets. Historians say the price was closer to $600. Either way, it was "the operative moment of New York as a real-estate deal, and that hasn't changed," said Peter Quinn, a historian and writer. "Donald Trump would have tried to pay $22."
Children do not re-enact the Minuit moment in school plays, perhaps because it is hard to imagine celebrating a development deal that enshrined capitalism -- some would say "greed" -- as the primary force in the city's growth and identity.
"It's not something that Americans and even New Yorkers are entirely comfortable with," said James Sanders, an architect and author who wrote the documentary with Ric Burns. "It's not really democracy and Mom and apple pie. It's something to be skeptical about, capitalism and greed. It is a funny connection."
But the connection between New York and the pursuit of wealth is as complex as it is odd. Some of the historians featured in the documentary suggest a cause-and-effect link between capitalism and several significant social advances, including the establishment of housing, health and zoning codes. Others say the documentary overstates that connection, and that many factors -- not just the quest for profit -- made New York a pioneer in social reform.
So New York was established as a money-making venture. So it took settlers a few years to erect a church. So what? Boston was founded by English Puritans, but Quakers who thought that meant religious freedom were sometimes hanged for their misinterpretation. And historians generally agree with the documentary's point that New York's commercial roots contributed to a kind of no-nonsense tolerance that continues to this day.
"At some level, everyone is equalized in the sense of: 'What can you do for me? I don't want to be your friend; let's just do business,' " Mr. Sanders said. But that rather cold demeanor can be interpreted another way, he said: "I don't need to be your friend. I don't care what color you are, what your religion is or what your politics are. But if you put up the cash, we'll do some business."
Carol Berkin, a history professor at Baruch College, agreed that New York's crass beginnings oddly worked to its advantage. "If you have the wrong ideology," she said, "it's better to have no ideology at all. Maybe you don't want to write an epic poem about a place where you can make a buck. But given the alternative, it made it more tolerant."
Of course, history is more complicated in real time than when it is poked and analyzed generations later. Beware grand abstractions and theoretical concepts, advised Mike Wallace, the co-author of a Pulitzer Prize-winning history of New York called "Gotham" (Oxford University Press, 1998) and one of the documentary's prominent figures. "Events on the ground are never so clear and simple."
And so it is with New York. For example, it is true that soon after establishing the village of New Amsterdam -- later called New York -- in the early 17th century, the Dutch founders accepted people from many cultures. And it is true that the community's leader, Peter Stuyvesant, was overruled by superiors in Holland when he proposed banishing Jews from the colony; think of the higher goal of profit, they suggested.
But those days were not all handshakes over piles of guilders. "If you are talking about the Dutch being willing to accept a variety of cultures," Mr. Wallace said, "the Dutch were also perfectly prepared to enslave zillions of people if that were the way to make money."
The British ousted the Dutch in the late 17th century, and American colonists ousted the British after the Revolutionary War. But while the flags overhead changed, the businesses on the ground continued to grow: banking, shipping and manufacturing.
One event was overtaken by the next. Alexander Hamilton struck a deal that solidified New York as the country's financial center. A grid of intersecting streets was built. The Erie Canal was completed, simplifying the movement of goods between the Great Plains and the rest of the world.
By the 1830's, the city saw fit to create a financial district on Wall Street to which people commuted. "It is the first time in human history that a district is devoted to the single purpose of commerce," Mr. Sanders said. "Nobody lives there. And that's a new way of life."
Fortunes were made in bull markets, lost in bear markets, and forgotten by the next bull market. The affluent built town houses and mansions in the ever-expanding uptown, while the poor blacks and Irish immigrants congregated in the Five Points, a foul-smelling sinkhole of a district -- near today's Foley Square -- with unpaved roads, run-down buildings and occasional epidemics.
The documentary's chapter on this period is aptly called "Sunshine and Shadow."
Mr. Quinn, among others, sees the natural tension between these extreme forms of economic life in New York as setting the stage for the social reforms to come. "That's where you have greed and the resistance to greed playing out," he said. "New York was the most economically advanced state in America. That's why you had the labor movement and the social-reform movement existing here, but not existing in other places in the United States."
For example, he said, the political machine known as Tammany Hall converted the anger of poor Irish and German immigrants into votes that allowed it to control and corrupt city government. ("I seen my opportunities and I took 'em," a Tammany leader, George Washington Plunkitt, once said.) In exchange, Tammany's operatives provided jobs and fought anti-Catholic movements. Later, to secure the support of the new wave of Jewish and Italian immigrants, it backed significant social legislation to improve the conditions of working people.
But Mr. Wallace argues that an alternative vision for New York dates back to the early 19th century, when some people contended that the rich came perilously close to resembling the aristocracy that existed under British rule. And the city has always been a haven for radicals and rebels, from Tom Paine to Cuban revolutionaries. That environment, he suggests, played an important role in creating a sense of entitlement.
"It is based on the notion that people are entitled, by virtue of their citizenship, to certain rights," Mr. Wallace said. "They are entitled to decent housing, public health, free education."
A concept emerges from the streets of New York that is somewhat foreign to the rest of the world, historians say. Simply put: With profit there must come social justice.
But reform was often more theory than practice: The arguments of an economic reformer named Henry George failed to persuade the city to elect him mayor in 1886. The city had millionaires by the score, and conditions in tenements that Kenneth T. Jackson, a professor of history at Columbia University, says in the documentary were "as bad as anything ever seen."
Then, as the documentary suggests, seminal moments in the arc of New York fostered institutionalized change. Jacob Riis's stirring photographs of life in Five Points in the late 1880's shamed city elders into developing housing codes for tenements. A fire at the Triangle Shirtwaist factory in 1911 killed 146 women in 15 minutes; the tragedy led to broader powers for the Fire Department to ensure factory safety and bolstered the drive to unionize factory workers.
More than before, the city began to blaze trails in social reform. "New York becomes an example of a liberal democracy," said Mr. Jackson, the editor of The Encyclopedia of New York (Yale University Press, 1995). "It learns that you can't let capitalism run completely amok. You have to take care of the people who get trampled along the way."
Or, as Mr. Sanders put it: "New York is one of the first to realize that capitalism wasn't enough".
The first five parts of the documentary ended last week by focusing on the Great Depression, which historians say taught New York yet again about the dangers of unfettered greed. The sixth and final episode will not be shown until early next year. But Mr. Sanders and others said the last 70 years would continue to reflect a city striving to strike the proper balance between capitalism and the public good.
Several pointed to the demolition of the majestic Pennsylvania Station in 1963 as an example of the city failing to find that balance, of paying the price for wanting everything bigger and better. But in the continuing evolution of its municipal conscience, the city soon created the Landmarks Preservation Commission that led the successful fight, years later, to save Grand Central Terminal from the wrecking ball.
In a sense, the historian John Steele Gordon said, "Penn Station died for our sins."
And so the paradox of New York continues. In Manhattan, the rich rent F. A. O. Schwarz overnight for pajama parties for their children, and the ex-wife of a billionaire, Ronald Perelman, says in divorce court that she spends $3,175 a month on clothing for their 4-year-old daughter. And in Queens, immigrants -- from Guatemala, Eastern Europe, Pakistan -- cram together in illegally subdivided houses. Some subsist by selling flowers on the street, batteries on the subway.
Daniel Czitrom, a historian featured in the documentary, grew up in the Bronx and drove a taxi in the city before earning his doctorate and landing a teaching job at Mount Holyoke College in Massachusetts. A specialist in the city's history, he remembers the service cutbacks during the recession of the 1970's, and marvels at the public improvements during the bull market of today.
"But you still have this super-exploitation of workers in these cockroachlike industries," he said. "And you have people paying a quarter-million for one-bedroom apartments in Manhattan.
"It just blows my mind."

HEADLINE: Democracy in Pakistan: Can a General Be Trusted?

BYLINE: By BARRY BEARAK 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 18

 BODY:
This country's elite has been notorious for corruption, with some elected officials the most voracious at the trough. So it is tempting for Pakistanis to cheer on Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who took power in a coup five weeks ago. His new government has ordered the arrest of dozens of prominent wealthy people who supposedly finagled multimillion-dollar bank loans they had no intention to repay.
A war on the wicked rich is the central reform mandated by the general, who has taken the title of chief executive. He says he is ending "sham" governance and will "pave the way for true democracy" in this country of 150 million people. 
 Military despots have intermittently run impoverished Pakistan for 25 of its 52 years, and each time that democracy was shoved aside a sincere-sounding general explained his assumption of power in roughly the same way. Will this time be any different?
It is far too early to tell, but most Pakistanis are eager to give General Musharraf the benefit of the doubt, agreeing with him that their wobbly and troubled democracy needed to be demolished so it could be rebuilt on a surer foundation.
Others, however, merely hear an all-too-familiar melody sung by yet another crooner with epaulets. "Military rule always begins with the same empty promises," said. I. A. Rehman, director of the Human Rights Commission of Pakistan.
In 1958, Field Marshal M. Ayub Khan announced that "our ultimate aim is to restore democracy but of the type that people can understand." In 1969, Gen. A. M. Yahya Khan vowed "that I have no ambition other than the creation of conditions conducive to the establishment of a constitutional government." In 1977, Gen. Zia-ul-Haq said, "The survival of this country lies in democracy and democracy alone."
General Musharraf may indeed be no better with his promises, but at least for now some very able people believe otherwise. They are risking their reputations to join his new government.
In the last month, the general has been making important hires, naming a seven-member National Security Council, a cabinet and provincial governors. The list has more than its fair share of generals, active and retired, but the majority of the appointees are civilians. While most come from the same well-connected families that have always run the country, many are well regarded as independent thinkers with a bent toward reform.
Shaukat Aziz, a Pakistani living in New York, was a highly paid vice president at Citibank. Soon after the coup, he was urged to visit Islamabad by General Musharraf, a man he had never met. The military wanted advice about an economy that is $32 billion in debt and on the brink of bankruptcy.
The general offered the banker the post of finance minister. "I was impressed by the chief executive and his team, their sense of purpose and eagerness to set things right," said Mr. Aziz, a perfectly coifed executive with just the right amount of gray around his temples and a neatly folded handkerchief in the breast pocket of his blue blazer.
"Pakistan has this small window of opportunity here, this chance to fix things with integrity and transparency," he said. "The army wants to do away with the culture of corruption that exists in Pakistan. And I'm totally convinced they mean business, that they really care about improving the lot of the people."
Omar Asghar Khan, an environmentalist who has been working in opposition to the illegal harvesting of timber, was offered a cabinet post to oversee rural development and labor issues.
"These people are talking about the devolution of powers, trying to get average citizens into government," said Mr. Khan, the Cambridge-educated son of an air marshal. "They don't have a time frame for a return to democracy, but I don't blame them for that. The sheer survival of the state is at stake. Things shouldn't be rushed."
Abdul Sattar, an amiable, if pedantic, retired diplomat, was at a conference in Washington when the coup occurred on Oct. 12. He too had never met General Musharraf, but the two hit it off after Mr. Sattar was asked in for consultation.
Both men share a burning distrust of India, Pakistan's neighbor and fellow nuclear power. Indeed, Mr. Sattar, who has twice been ambassador to New Delhi, said the 13 years he spent on Indian-Pakistan relations was a "desert that produced nothing positive."
He accepted the job of foreign minister. "Democracy here was just musical chairs, and what we need are fundamental reforms," Mr. Sattar said.
General Musharraf, once a commando, insists that his government is "entirely civilian." However, he also says the army is needed to monitor everything that goes on. "Only the military, which is all over Pakistan, can act as eyes and ears," he said in an interview.
The United States has been relatively tepid in criticizing the military takeover, but the Commonwealth -- a group of 54 nations, many of them former British colonies -- has suspended Pakistan, demanding "restoration of civilian democratic rule without delay."
For the most part, such condemnations draw sneers in Pakistan's capital, where people are wont to claim that the ousted prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, was nothing but a power-hungry conniver, stuffing his already fat pockets while systematically enfeebling the judiciary and the legislature through political foul play.
In General Musharraf's view, the army too had become a victim of this institutional meddling, with the prime minister sowing dissension in the ranks, especially after a humbling military setback in a near all-out war with the Indians in June and July.
An alternative chain of events is offered by the party hierarchy of Mr. Sharif's Pakistan Muslim League. In this account, senior officers were plotting against the general, whispering warnings to the prime minister about a Musharraf-led coup.
This goes to the heart of the question of the hour in Islamabad. On Oct. 12, Mr. Sharif fired General Musharraf. Was the prime minister trying to thwart a coming coup? Or was the coup, as the general enjoys describing it, an utterly spontaneous and tellingly loyal response by his officers to the news of his dismissal?
The events of that evening are now part of Pakistani lore. General Musharraf, unaware that he had been fired, was seated aboard a commercial jet, heading to Karachi from Sri Lanka. The air traffic control tower, supposedly under orders from Mr. Sharif, denied the plane permission to land. The runway had been blocked. Fuel was running perilously low.
As the story goes, only the quick reflexes of the general's subordinates saved the day. The army took control of the tower. The plane and all 198 on board, including 60 schoolchildren, were saved. The coup began. Mr. Sharif was quickly placed in custody. He has since been accused of treason, hijacking and conspiracy to commit murder -- all capital crimes.
And that brings up the second question on people's minds, endlessly debated over tea. Mr. Sharif will soon stand trial. Most people assume a verdict of guilty.
So will they or won't they? people wonder. Are they going to hang him?

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Pataki Upstages a Rival Over Cleanup of Hudson

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 20

 BODY:
On Friday, Nov. 12, aides to Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer let reporters know that New York State was about to sue General Electric over the dumping of toxic waste in the Hudson River, a move long demanded by environmentalists. The news conference would be on Monday.
Later that day, an aide to Gov. George E. Pataki called reporters to say that the governor would be making his own announcement about G.E. on Saturday, two days before Mr. Spitzer. 
 The timing was curious. The Pataki administration rarely makes news on a Saturday, an inconvenient day for state officials and reporters alike, and there was no hurry about the governor's announcement, an order that G.E. clean up PCB-contaminated soil at a defunct factory, which had been in the works for months.
It was the latest evidence that for the Republican governor and his aides, the sudden prominence of the Democratic attorney general on environmental issues has become a sore spot. When asked, administration officials did not deny that their Saturday announcement was intended to take a little wind out of the attorney general's sails and keep Mr. Pataki's name in the news.
The governor's office dismisses the suggestion that there is any competition to be the state's leading defender of air and water, fish and fowl. "The governor has a long and distinguished record on environmental protection," said Michael McKeon, his press secretary. "He is very secure in his record."
But there is no denying that the dynamic has changed. For four years, Mr. Pataki was, without question, New York's most prominent conservationist. There were always legislators and advocates who took some positions before he did, or criticized his record, but there were serious limits on what they could accomplish without his cooperation.
Then Mr. Spitzer took office this year, taking control of the state's power to prosecute and litigate. His actions have gained heavy coverage from the news media and rave reviews from environmentalists and editorial writers.
He sued 17 power plants in other states over air pollution that blows across state lines, making New York the first state to try that tactic. He was the first in the state to sue G.E. over the dumping of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, into the river. Specifically, he charged that for years, the contamination has kept the state from dredging a shipping channel, the Champlain Canal.
The danger to Mr. Pataki is not only that he might have to share the stage with Mr. Spitzer, but also that the administration's responses to the situation will seem petty or political. Recently, when the governor announced a major clean-air project, environmentalists who had criticized him were barred from the news conference.
After Mr. Spitzer announced his suit against G.E., administration officials, in some cases, seemed to be reaching for arguments against it. In particular, they insisted that there was no need to dredge the canal because boats could use it with no trouble.
That was news to people who live and work along the 35-mile-long canal, which links Lake Champlain to the Hudson River. "I see boats get stuck in the mud all the time," said Joanne Fuller, tourism promotion administrator for Washington County, who has lived beside the waterway for 19 years, as silt deposits have made it shallower. "Some tour boat companies have given up coming through here. It has hurt the economy of the entire region."
Officials in the village of Fort Edward say the landing there has become inaccessible to most boats, hurting local business. John C. Tobin, a lawyer for a group of barge, tugboat and tanker operators, said: "It's a huge problem. You can't get boats through, and if you try, you can get hung up on the mud."
Even the Thruway Authority, which operates the canal, conceded that getting boats through sometimes meant removing cargo, or using dams to raise the water level.
The funny thing is, environmentalists are happier now with Mr. Pataki than ever before. He recently ordered New York's power plants to meet the toughest air emissions standards in the nation. He made New York the second state, after California, to adopt new emission controls for new cars and trucks. And this month he ordered the strictest rules in the country for cleaning up a gasoline additive that has polluted ground water.
"It looks like there's some competition going on, and that's fine, because they're both doing some good things," said Cara Lee, environmental director of Scenic Hudson, a conservation group. "But whether or not there's competition, I don't understand the administration's reaction. They have been a little touchy."

HEADLINE: SPOTLIGHT;
An Imperiled Muse Weaves Her Spell

BYLINE: By MARGARETT LOKE 

 BODY:
Outside museums and galleries and fine-art publications, black-and-white photographs from the past don't often take center stage. An exception to that observation is "Shooting the Past," a two-part Mobil Masterpiece Theatre drama being shown tonight and next Sunday night at 9 on PBS. Its extraordinary main character is a vast picture library housed in a splendid 19th-century mansion on the edge of London and tended by a small and intensely devoted staff.
As the drama begins, the staff is jolted out of its cocoon by the arrival of Christopher Anderson, an American businessman who is the building's new owner. Mr. Anderson, played by Liam Cunningham, plans to keep the collection's few valuable pictures, dispose of the rest and in four days' time begin turning the mansion into a business school. 
 Marilyn Truman (Lindsay Duncan) is the library's manager, a strong-willed upper-class woman who extracts from Mr. Anderson a week's delay in the renovation to find a buyer for the collection. Joining her in a quixotic attempt to persuade Mr. Anderson to keep the collection intact is her deputy, an eccentric by the name of Oswald Bates (Timothy Spall) who has no need for a computer since he knows which picture is in which box in which room.
That these are not ordinary pictures is obvious. Early on, while Mr. Anderson matter-of-factly informs Ms. Truman of the "economics of the situation" -- that the cost of storing the pictures would be prohibitively expensive -- the protagonist makes its appearance. The screen is filled with one hauntingly beautiful image after another. And as the drama unfolds, more of the library's treasures from the past -- of adults and children at play, of faces and street scenes -- take star turns.
In real life the photographs are from the Hulton Getty Picture Collection, and Stephen Poliakoff, the British dramatist who wrote and directed ' the drama, made them an integral part of his script.
Mr. Poliakoff said in a recent telephone interview that he became interested in the subject in the early 1990's, when Celia Barnett, a friend and an art director for films, found herself frantically searching for a home for a picture collection that EMI studios, which was then her employer in London, wanted to dispose of quickly. Many of the pictures showed details of England in the 1940's, 50's and 60's that would be invaluable to researchers. The collection eventually went to Lucasfilm, which has a large research library at its base in California.
The paradox, Mr. Poliakoff said, is that the BBC, which commissioned "Shooting the Past," was "whacked with a big charge" for the use of pictures it once owned. In 1957, the BBC had bought the original Hulton picture library from its owner, Edward Hulton, a British publisher. Inspired by the archive at his magazine Picture Post, which ceased publication in 1957, Mr. Hulton had acquired a number of choice photo collections.
In 1987, the BBC sold its Radio Times Hulton Picture Library for about 2.5 million. The current owner is Seattle-based Getty Images Inc., one of the world's largest providers of archived photographs. The Hulton Getty commercial picture library itself, with more than 12 million images, is in two converted warehouses in West London.
After writing the script for "Shooting the Past," Mr. Poliakoff discovered other endangered collections. While hunting for a film location, he came across the Mansell Collection in a Georgian house in London. He found the staff "living in a dusty eccentric world" not unlike that in his script. The Mansell's holdings -- half a million rare and important photographs, drawings, paintings, lithographs and engravings -- were was sold to Time Inc.
So potent did Mr. Poliakoff find black-and-white photographs in the picture collections he came across that he has Ms. Truman tell Mr. Anderson two absorbing picture stories in her role as a latter-day Scheherazade. Based partly on photographs in the Hulton Getty, the images she uses to bewitch him are a seamless, computer-manipulated blend of the real and the fictional, and look for all the world as though they were drawn from a real collection.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK;
New York Joblessness Dips Slightly in October

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
New York's unemployment rate was slightly better in October than in September, but joblessness in the state is still worse than the national average, according to State Labor Department analysts.
The state's unemployment rate was 5.2 percent last month, down a tenth of a percentage point from September. The jobless rate in October 1998 was 5.4 percent. 
 By contrast, the national unemployment rate last month was 4.1 percent, also down a tenth of a percentage point from September, and down four-tenths of a percentage point from October 1998.
Labor Department analysts said on Friday that they counted 6,993,800 private-sector jobs in October, an all-time record. The job total grew by 16,000 from September, the 26th consecutive month with an increase.
Joblessness in New York City in October was at 6.9 percent, down from 7.2 percent in September and 8.0 percent in October 1998.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK;
Woodstock '99 Proves Profitable for Rome

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
Sales tax numbers show that Woodstock '99 was a big boost to the local economy. From June to August, the City of Rome took in about $560,000 more than it did during the same period in 1998, a 36.5 percent jump, City Treasurer John Nash said, attributing the increase to the summer music festival at the former Griffiss Air Force Base. 
 "We've never had a jump like this in any one quarter," Mr. Nash said. He said he had anticipated a $300,000 windfall in the 1999 budget because of Woodstock, but the added increase was a bonus. The extra money will go into the general fund surplus to stabilize taxes, he said.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL BRIEFING;
Turning Marriage Into a Political Issue

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
State Representative Mark Anderson of Arizona, a conservative Republican, hears a different legislative drum.
Ever since he was elected to the Arizona House in 1994 from Mesa, a city just east of Phoenix, he has made marriage issues a big priority, his pitch being that a state whose couples are happily married is a happy state and, more important, a strong state. His proposals have not enjoyed a lot of success -- Arizona still has its share of divorces and broken homes -- but he keeps pushing. 
 First, he tried to get the State Legislature to finance a $2 million program to teach single women on welfare the advantages of getting a husband. His bill would have enabled women "interested in pursuing a career track in home management" to learn "positive thinking and attitude adjustment techniques" and would have helped them understand the "economic and personal benefits of marriage."
Next, when a constituent, a divorced single parent, asked him to push the Legislature to provide child care for single parents who are in college, he suggested that her best course of action would be to "revisit the issue of your marriage failure, perhaps take some classes in parenting" and then find a new husband.
Now he has a new proposal.
He wants the state to put up $17 million to finance an array of public school and adult education classes that promote the idea of getting married and staying married. Some of the money would be used to develop a "healthy marriage" handbook and courses in marriage and communication skills, some would be used to underwrite attendance at such courses by poor people and to provide tax breaks for employers who offer marriage courses, and some would be used to underwrite a "marriage is a healthy lifestyle" advertising campaign.
Representative Anderson's goal: to reduce Arizona's divorce rate, now ranked 10th worst in the nation, by 5 percent by 2002.
State educators do not like the proposal. They say they already have trouble enough finding money and time to teach the three R's, let alone taking on a how-to marriage course.
But Mr. Anderson, who has never been divorced, refuses to back off. He argues that relationship skills that work in a marriage will also work in just about any other setting, including the workplace, and he notes that other states, including Florida, Oklahoma and Utah, are beginning to debate the kind of special education programs he is proposing.
"I'd rather have people graduating from school that can communicate and be a good marriage partner and be a good parent than somebody who can add," he declared last week.

HEADLINE: Better Perks Resonate in Boom Times

BYLINE: By MICHELLE LEDER

 BODY:
HIS name may not be familiar to anyone but his own employees, but chances are you've heard about what Al Galdi has done: given new BMW's to any employee who has worked at his company for at least a year.
 During the last six months, Mr. Galdi has handed out BMW keys to 34 of his 45 employees. The cars, which are leased, cost him about $9,000 a year each, including insurance. Needless to say, turnover at Arcnet, an architectural engineering firm in Holmdel, N.J., has been virtually nil since Mr. Galdi began offering the perk in June. Employees who leave have to give back the cars. 
 They also lose out on other goodies, like $100 gift certificates on their birthdays, health club memberships and a cash bonus equal to 25 percent of their annual salary on the fifth anniversary of their employment.
 About once a month, Mr. Galdi says, he asks his employees if they would rather have cash. The answer is always no.
 "They seem to really like the programs," he said, "because it helps with their quality of life."
 You could probably count on one hand, and perhaps even one finger, the number of employers in the New York metro area who are handing out keys to BMW's. But with the economy booming and unemployment at record lows, many employers are trying to come up with new and interesting perquisites.
 "It's not so much about rewarding, but retaining," said Michael A. Keane, managing consultant at Watson Worldwide, a consulting firm in Morristown, N.J. "When it comes to employees, it's basically a seller's market, and many companies are having to make extraordinary efforts."
 A recent survey by the outplacement firm Lee Hecht Harrison found that the top two perks on employees' wish lists were health club memberships (58 percent) and flextime (57 percent). That's not what most employers are providing: A.T.M.'s on premises (25 percent) and travel services (15 percent), according to a survey of more than 1,000 employers conducted by Hewitt Associates, a compensation consulting firm.
 "Employers need to ask themselves how they can make themselves different from everyone else," said Ray Baumruk, who helped conduct the study for Hewitt.
 Perks vary widely from company to company and within particular industries. High-tech firms tend to have the most innovative offerings, like on-site massages, concierge services, even quiet rooms where workers can nap. Blue-chip companies, particularly those on suburban campuses, tend to focus more heavily on time-saving perks like on-site dry-cleaning and film drop-off.
 For example, the 500 employees at Xerox's corporate headquarters at Stamford, Conn., are able to work out at an on-site fitness center, order meals from the company cafeteria for dinner and drop off dry-cleaning when they get to work in the morning; it's usually ready to be picked up the next day. On-site massage therapy -- a perk offered at other Xerox locations, but not in Stamford -- is in the works, said Christa Carone, a spokeswoman.
 One difference from several years ago is that the perks are for a larger pool of workers. At Arcnet, even the receptionist qualified for a BMW. Last month, Ikea, the Swedish furniture retailer that has stores in Hicksville, N.Y., and Elizabeth, N.J., pledged cash bonuses amounting to a day's worth of sales, $80 million worldwide, to its employees, from the snack bar staff and stock clerks to the president. Each employee will end up with $2,435 when checks are distributed this month, said Marty Marston, a spokeswoman for Ikea North America. Retailing tends to be among the lowest-paying type of employment, so the one-time bonus could equal a month's pay for some.
 But even companies that can't afford to provide a car or a day's sales have plenty of options. Many perks being offered today cost the employer virtually nothing, but still create plenty of good will. Men's Wearhouse, a large California retailer that operates about 20 stores in the New York metro area, has signed up 120 local employers, including Citibank and New York University, for its V.I.P. program, which gives a company's employees 10 percent off on Men's Wearhouse purchases.
 Transitchek, a program that allows employees of enrolled companies to set aside up to $65 a month before taxes for public transportation commuting costs, also provides savings on corporate taxes. Each month 7,000 to 8,000 employers in the New York area participate in the program, said George Serventi, Transitchek director.
 "A lot of these things are in the interest of the employers who are doing them," said Helen Darling, a consultant at Watson Worldwide's Stamford office.
 Even costly perks often pay off in the end. Lipton Child Care Centers, a Washington company that operates backup child care centers in Manhattan, White Plains and Jersey City, says that employers still save money because parents don't need to miss work when their regular child care provider isn't available. The service has attracted employers like the National Hockey League, the National Basketball Association, Philip Morris, Pepsico and Texaco, as well as newer, smaller companies like Knight Securities of Jersey City.
 Stephanie Bernstein, director of human resources for Knight, a Nasdaq market maker, said she and several other parents were able to sell Knight's chief executive on the idea of backup care, even though Knight, like many other brokerage firms, mostly employs single men.
 "There were a couple of people here, myself included, who would get into a situation and be jammed," Ms. Bernstein said. Now, for an annual fee of $50, she and other Knight parents have access to the Lipton center in the lobby at Newport Center.
 At Dialogic Corporation, a Parsippany technology company recently bought by Intel, the company's 1,000 employees have access to a corporate concierge, who is able to arrange things like dinner reservations, family vacations and oil changes for cars. Dialogic pays LesConcierges of San Francisco for the service, but employees have to pay for individual requests. Other Dialogic perks include an on-site fitness center, a free coffee and juice bar, and heavily discounted soda.
 "This is all aimed at making it comfortable for people to be here longer than 40 hours a week," said Ken Cardinal, Dialogic's director of compensation and benefits. Though Mr. Cardinal said the company hadn't tried to figure out whether the concierge service and other perks were paying off for the company, he said that turnover had been lower than expected.
 Still, at most companies, benefits are limited to items like health and life insurance and a retirement plan. Mr. Keane, the consultant at Watson Worldwide, estimated that only 15 to 20 percent of all companies offer what he described as nontraditional perks. That could grow if the economy continued to prosper.
 "A lot of companies are being pretty cautious, because once you add it, it becomes hard to take it away," said Alan M. Johnson, managing director at Johnson Associates, a Wall Street compensation consulting firm.
 Many consultants and even the companies that provide the perks wonder what will happen to the programs when the economy takes a turn for the worse. Employees who have grown used to the perks may be unwilling to give them up.
 "We all know it's going to be difficult to take these things away," Mr. Cardinal said. Given the choice of layoffs or reducing perks, most employers would probably reduce the perks, consultants say.
 But not Mr. Galdi. When business slowed down a few months ago, he said he had to lay off several employees. But he has no plans to stop handing out BMW's or cut back on any of the other benefits Arcnet employees receive.
 "I'm in the service business," Mr. Galdi said, "and having employees that are happy and hard-working is good business for me."
 
 Like a Front Desk at the Office
 SO what exactly does a corporate concierge do? Just about anything, as long as it's legal.
 "I never know what each day will bring," said Pam Wildrick, a corporate concierge at Dialogic Corporation, a technology company that was recently acquired by Intel Corporation. "People come in and they drop their problems on my desk."
 In the year and a half since Ms. Wildrick began working at Dialogic's Parsippany headquarters, she's done everything from picking up gifts for spouses who have forgotten a birthday or anniversary to locating a clock that ticks backward to finding a guide to take an engineer through dense jungle in Costa Rica. In a typical month, she fields 230 to 250 requests from Dialogic's 1,000 employees.
 Though Ms. Wildrick works in Parsippany, she's actually an employee of Les Concierges, a 13-year-old San Francisco company that provides concierge services to companies. (In the past, she had worked for several nonprofit groups in Morris County, including a stint as president of the Junior League and director of communications and special events for the Arts Council of the Morristown Area.)
 Though the concierge concept is popular in California, particularly in the Silicon Valley, corporate concierges are still relatively new in the New York area.
 "There's a lot of potential in the New York area," said Phil Wexler, Les Concierges' executive vice president. The company recently reached an agreement with Goldman Sachs to begin providing concierge services to its employees early next year.
 Ken Cardinal, Dialogic's director of compensation and benefits, said the service was popular. One part of Ms. Wildrick's job involves arranging for oil changes and other routine maintenance on employees' personal cars while they are working, saving the employees valuable time on the weekends.
 So is there anything Ms. Wildrick won't do?
 Yes. She won't hire strippers, though she has been asked to.
 Though that's not illegal, Ms. Wildrick said she just didn't feel comfortable arranging that kind of entertainment for Dialogic employees, even if it took place off-site.
 "That one just crosses the line," Ms. Wildrick said.
 MICHELLE LEDER

HEADLINE: Better Perks Resonate in Boom Times

BYLINE: By MICHELLE LEDER

 BODY:
HIS name may not be familiar to anyone but his own employees, but chances are you've heard about what Al Galdi has done: given new BMW's to any employee who has worked at his company for at least a year.
 During the last six months, Mr. Galdi has handed out BMW keys to 34 of his 45 employees. The cars, which are leased, cost him about $9,000 a year each, including insurance. Needless to say, turnover at Arcnet, an architectural engineering firm in Holmdel, N.J., has been virtually nil since Mr. Galdi began offering the perk in June. Employees who leave have to give back the cars. 
 They also lose out on other goodies, like $100 gift certificates on their birthdays, health club memberships and a cash bonus equal to 25 percent of their annual salary on the fifth anniversary of their employment.
 About once a month, Mr. Galdi says, he asks his employees if they would rather have cash. The answer is always no.
 "They seem to really like the programs," he said, "because it helps with their quality of life."
 You could probably count on one hand, and perhaps even one finger, the number of employers in the New York metro area who are handing out keys to BMW's. But with the economy booming and unemployment at record lows, many employers are trying to come up with new and interesting perquisites.
 "It's not so much about rewarding, but retaining," said Michael A. Keane, managing consultant at Watson Worldwide, a consulting firm in Morristown, N.J. "When it comes to employees, it's basically a seller's market, and many companies are having to make extraordinary efforts."
 A recent survey by the outplacement firm Lee Hecht Harrison found that the top two perks on employees' wish lists were health club memberships (58 percent) and flextime (57 percent). That's not what most employers are providing: A.T.M.'s on premises (25 percent) and travel services (15 percent), according to a survey of more than 1,000 employers conducted by Hewitt Associates, a compensation consulting firm.
 "Employers need to ask themselves how they can make themselves different from everyone else," said Ray Baumruk, who helped conduct the study for Hewitt.
 Perks vary widely from company to company and within particular industries. High-tech firms tend to have the most innovative offerings, like on-site massages, concierge services, even quiet rooms where workers can nap. Blue-chip companies, particularly those on suburban campuses, tend to focus more heavily on time-saving perks like on-site dry-cleaning and film drop-off.
 For example, the 500 employees at Xerox's corporate headquarters at Stamford, Conn., are able to work out at an on-site fitness center, order meals from the company cafeteria for dinner and drop off dry-cleaning when they get to work in the morning; it's usually ready to be picked up the next day. On-site massage therapy -- a perk offered at other Xerox locations, but not in Stamford -- is in the works, said Christa Carone, a spokeswoman.
 One difference from several years ago is that the perks are for a larger pool of workers. At Arcnet, even the receptionist qualified for a BMW. Last month, Ikea, the Swedish furniture retailer that has stores in Hicksville, N.Y., and Elizabeth, N.J., pledged cash bonuses amounting to a day's worth of sales, $80 million worldwide, to its employees, from the snack bar staff and stock clerks to the president. Each employee will end up with $2,435 when checks are distributed this month, said Marty Marston, a spokeswoman for Ikea North America. Retailing tends to be among the lowest-paying type of employment, so the one-time bonus could equal a month's pay for some.
 But even companies that can't afford to provide a car or a day's sales have plenty of options. Many perks being offered today cost the employer virtually nothing, but still create plenty of good will. Men's Wearhouse, a large California retailer that operates about 20 stores in the New York metro area, has signed up 120 local employers, including Citibank and New York University, for its V.I.P. program, which gives a company's employees 10 percent off on Men's Wearhouse purchases.
 Transitchek, a program that allows employees of enrolled companies to set aside up to $65 a month before taxes for public transportation commuting costs, also provides savings on corporate taxes. Each month 7,000 to 8,000 employers in the New York area participate in the program, said George Serventi, Transitchek director.
 "A lot of these things are in the interest of the employers who are doing them," said Helen Darling, a consultant at Watson Worldwide's Stamford office.
 Even costly perks often pay off in the end. Lipton Child Care Centers, a Washington company that operates backup child care centers in Manhattan, White Plains and Jersey City, says that employers still save money because parents don't need to miss work when their regular child care provider isn't available. The service has attracted employers like the National Hockey League, the National Basketball Association, Philip Morris, Pepsico and Texaco, as well as newer, smaller companies like Knight Securities of Jersey City.
 Stephanie Bernstein, director of human resources for Knight, a Nasdaq market maker, said she and several other parents were able to sell Knight's chief executive on the idea of backup care, even though Knight, like many other brokerage firms, mostly employs single men.
 "There were a couple of people here, myself included, who would get into a situation and be jammed," Ms. Bernstein said. Now, for an annual fee of $50, she and other Knight parents have access to the Lipton center in the lobby at Newport Center.
 At Dialogic Corporation, a Parsippany technology company recently bought by Intel, the company's 1,000 employees have access to a corporate concierge, who is able to arrange things like dinner reservations, family vacations and oil changes for cars. Dialogic pays LesConcierges of San Francisco for the service, but employees have to pay for individual requests. Other Dialogic perks include an on-site fitness center, a free coffee and juice bar, and heavily discounted soda.
 "This is all aimed at making it comfortable for people to be here longer than 40 hours a week," said Ken Cardinal, Dialogic's director of compensation and benefits. Though Mr. Cardinal said the company hadn't tried to figure out whether the concierge service and other perks were paying off for the company, he said that turnover had been lower than expected.
 Still, at most companies, benefits are limited to items like health and life insurance and a retirement plan. Mr. Keane, the consultant at Watson Worldwide, estimated that only 15 to 20 percent of all companies offer what he described as nontraditional perks. That could grow if the economy continued to prosper.
 "A lot of companies are being pretty cautious, because once you add it, it becomes hard to take it away," said Alan M. Johnson, managing director at Johnson Associates, a Wall Street compensation consulting firm.
 Many consultants and even the companies that provide the perks wonder what will happen to the programs when the economy takes a turn for the worse. Employees who have grown used to the perks may be unwilling to give them up.
 "We all know it's going to be difficult to take these things away," Mr. Cardinal said. Given the choice of layoffs or reducing perks, most employers would probably reduce the perks, consultants say.
 But not Mr. Galdi. When business slowed down a few months ago, he said he had to lay off several employees. But he has no plans to stop handing out BMW's or cut back on any of the other benefits Arcnet employees receive.
 "I'm in the service business," Mr. Galdi said, "and having employees that are happy and hard-working is good business for me."
 
Like a Front Desk at the Office
 SO what exactly does a corporate concierge do? Just about anything, as long as it's legal.
 "I never know what each day will bring," said Pam Wildrick, a corporate concierge at Dialogic Corporation, a technology company recently acquired by Intel Corporation. "People come in and they drop their problems on my desk."
 In the year and a half since Ms. Wildrick began working at Dialogic's Parsippany headquarters, she's done everything from picking up gifts for spouses who have forgotten a birthday or anniversary to locating a clock that ticks backward to finding a guide to take an engineer through dense jungle in Costa Rica. In a typical month, she fields 230 to 250 requests from Dialogic's 1,000 employees.
 Though Ms. Wildrick works in Parsippany, she's actually an employee of Les Concierges, a 13-year-old San Francisco company that provides concierge services to companies. (In the past, she had worked for several nonprofit groups in Morris County, including a stint as president of the Junior League and director of communications and special events for the Arts Council of the Morristown Area.)
 Though the concierge concept is popular in California, particularly in the Silicon Valley, corporate concierges are still relatively new in the New York area.
 "There's a lot of potential in the New York area," said Phil Wexler, Les Concierges' executive vice president. The company recently reached an agreement with Goldman Sachs to begin providing concierge services to its employees early next year.
 Ken Cardinal, Dialogic's director of compensation and benefits, said the service was popular. One part of Ms. Wildrick's job involves arranging for oil changes and other routine maintenance on employees' personal cars while they are working, saving the employees valuable time on the weekends.
 So is there anything Ms. Wildrick won't do?
 Yes. She won't hire strippers, though she has been asked to.
 Though that's not illegal, Ms. Wildrick said she just didn't feel comfortable arranging that kind of entertainment for Dialogic employees, even if it took place off-site.
 "That one just crosses the line," Ms. Wildrick said.
 MICHELLE LEDER

HEADLINE: U.S. Deal on Caspian Oil Still Faces Problems With Bottom Line

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
For both financial and political reasons, the agreement to build a pipeline to carry Caspian Sea oil across Turkey, which the Clinton administration views as a strategic victory, is far from being a reality, oil executives and administration officials say.
For years, oil companies have looked at various pipeline routes to get the Caucasus region's vast oil reserves to market. And they have signed similar deals before, though this one looks more solid. 
 For the oil companies, the chosen route must be profitable. But for the Clinton administration, the prime concern has been strategic: guaranteeing that any pipeline would skirt Russia or Iran and deny them a choke-hold over a new energy supply for the West. The administration would also like to use the oil deal to bring several former Soviet republics into a Western-looking bloc, and to enhance the regional power of Turkey, a crucial NATO ally.
But whether the route agreed to this week -- which is strategically advantageous to the United States but costly for the oil companies -- can be made profitable quickly is still a big question. So too is the political fallout with Russia, the loser in the deal.
The major oil company involved in the pipeline project, BP Amoco, said it would seek help from Washington to line up enough oil shipments from producers in the region to make the pipeline commercially viable.
The company, said Michael Townshend, its director of international affairs, has set a deadline of next October for raising financing and commitments to use the pipeline. A new batch of oil from the Caspian will be ready by 2004, and the oil companies will need to decide by October where they are going to build a pipeline to carry it.
"It's not impossible, but it's a stretch," he said.
"The only way this is going to work is to make the pipeline as affordable as possible for shippers to put their oil down it," he added. "We're asking the United States government to attract as much oil as possible and to attract as much financing as possible."
If that money is not in place in time, BP Amoco can try to get the oil out by a different route, by expanding the capacity of an existing pipeline from Baku, Azerbaijan, to Supsa, Georgia, near the Black Sea, Mr. Townshend said. From there the oil would be taken by tanker through the Bosporus, a route less to the liking of Washington and the oil companies.
It is also possible that BP Amoco will delay the next phase of oil production in the Caspian Sea if the structure of the pipeline deal is not settled.
The Clinton administration has not pledged any money for the project beyond $500 million in loan guarantees from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation and the Export-Import Bank, officials said.
The oil companies had first hoped Washington would allow a shorter route through Iran, with an outlet at the Persian Gulf. But this was blocked by Washington's refusal to lift economic sanctions against Iran.
Beyond strategic considerations, the route through the narrow Bosporus also raises some environmental problems, and as they became more evident, the oil companies leaned more toward the more expensive route through Turkey.
As the oil companies wavered, Turkey tried to make the route to its port of Ceyhan more appealing by announcing it would pay for cost overruns on the estimated $1.4 billion the pipeline is expected to cost the oil companies.
When the deal was announced at a European summit meeting in Istanbul this week, it was, for Turkey, the most substantive part of President Clinton's five-day visit there. The other countries to sign the deal were Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan.
That victory for the Clinton administration may have unseen costs, however. Administration officials acknowledged that Russia has always viewed the pipeline route through Turkey as an implicit threat. While the Russian reaction appeared muted this week, even the prospect of a pipeline deal had led Moscow officials to speculate publicly that Washington was trying to foment chaos on its southern borders.
Alan Makovsky, an analyst at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, said Russia perceived Washington's efforts in the Caspian Sea as the equivalent of NATO expansion on Russia's southern flank.
Russia came to live with NATO's embrace of its former satellites -- Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary -- but how it would react to the pipeline that is designed to deprive Moscow of precious income and prestige was an open question.
"They clearly see this as threatening," said a senior administration official. "They see this as the next phase of U.S.-Russian competition. They don't seem to understand that they would be better off with a stable southern flank."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Y2K Plus 5

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka

 BODY:
In a few days the World Trade Organization will hold a summit in Seattle. Some 150,000 protesters are going to take to the streets to denounce the W.T.O. and globalization as unalloyed evils. The protesters might want to talk to the workers of Sri Lanka first, because what you find here, in this island state located off the southern tip of India, is a rather nuanced view of globalization -- an awareness that it is as much a vehicle for developing countries to escape poverty as it is a vehicle for them to be exploited.
Let's start with Sri Lanka's biggest concern about globalization. At the Ministry of Industrial Development here is a sign that says: "The Year 2005 is only 60 months away. What are you doing to get ready?" The developed nations of the world are terrified about a year 2000 bug that could make all their computers stop. But for poor developing countries, it's 2005 that matters -- the year when their sewing machines could stop. 
 Most Americans don't know that a global Multi-Fiber Agreement sets quotas on exactly how many clothes every developing country can sell in U.S. and E.U. markets. The quotas are the lifeblood of countries like Bangladesh, China, Vietnam, India, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. By 2005 all the quotas will be phased out, which is going to trigger a Darwinian free-for-all to sell clothes to the U.S. and Europe.
Sri Lankan textile workers and manufacturers are now gearing up for Y-2005. Their biggest concern? China. "What we worry about with China is the profit motive -- they have state-owned factories that don't need to make a profit, but just keep people employed," said Mahesh Hirdaramani, a Sri Lankan textile maker. "It means they can sell at any price. And once there are no quotas anymore to protect our market share, China could undersell us everywhere."
To deal with the China threat, Sri Lankan textile companies are trying to move up the quality ladder. "We can't be the low-end producers anymore," says Mahesh Amalean, another manufacturer. "Bangladesh and China will run circles around us. So we are focusing on better quality, so retailers will want to stick with us. And we are working to make ourselves more valuable to the retailers by actually designing clothes ourselves. In the past, the retailers designed the garment and we had to show them we could make it. Now we have to design more things ourselves, get the fabrics, and then show the retailers that they can get the whole package from us. We have to become more than just tailors to survive."
I visited Mr. Amalean's factory, which makes underwear for Victoria's Secret. Located in the small tropical village of Pannala, the factory is completely computerized and will soon be linked by Internet to the Victoria's Secret chain to handle e-commerce. About 1,400 employees, mostly women 18 and older, work in this modern, air-conditioned factory on pneumatic sewing machines. The workday is eight hours and is intense. Each woman has to stitch so many garments per minute. Wages are about $80 to $100 a month, the average here, and there is a waiting list for jobs. In terms of working conditions, this factory is world class, and it's not alone here.
"The only way we can survive against China and Bangladesh after 2005 is if we build long-term relationships with the big global brand retailers," explains Mr. Amalean, "and those brand retailers are now demanding not only better prices and quality, but better conditions for workers." And they are demanding that not because they suddenly became socially conscious, but because American consumers are demanding it, thanks to recent anti-sweatshop campaigns.
In other words, working conditions have improved here not because Sri Lanka has put up walls against globalization, but because in today's global economy Sri Lanka must tie itself to Western retailers to survive. And the more it does that, the more its factory standards have to meet the values of Western consumers.
There are still plenty of sweatshops in this region, and the Seattle protesters should go after them -- by targeting the specific retailers who use them, but not by targeting globalization. That is stupid, not only because globalization is inevitable, but also because if managed properly, it can be an effective tool to lift labor standards around the world. The Seattle protesters need to understand that. The people of Sri Lanka already do.

HEADLINE: American Movie Classic

BYLINE: By Sarah Kerr; Sarah Kerr writes about culture and politics for The Times, The New York Review of Books and other publications.

 BODY:

CONVERSATIONS
 WITH WILDER
 By Cameron Crowe.
 Karen Lerner, editorial consultant.
 Illustrated. 373 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $35. 
 Imagine a book written a few years into the future, chronicling the changing tastes of the 20th century. Now imagine a chapter devoted to the topsy-turvy career of Billy Wilder. It would make for a gripping, and rather emblematic, tale. Born in Vienna, Wilder leaves for Hollywood in the mid-1930's and quickly crash-courses himself into a basic command of American pop English. With a partner he begins to churn out scripts, and in order to rescue these scripts from mismanagement he starts directing them himself. A string of brilliant and unforgettable films follows, each astoundingly different in plot and flavor from the one before. To name just a few: "Double Indemnity" (wicked noir, 1944); "Sunset Boulevard" (creepy, eerily beautiful classic of Hollywood decadence, 1950); "Sabrina" (sunny fairy tale, 1954); "Some Like It Hot" (mob-caper, cross-dressing romp, 1959); and "The Apartment" (sublimely subtle look at work, sex and the unseemly intersection thereof, 1960).
Audiences adore Wilder's work, and Oscars accumulate, but throughout his career there are critics, professional and otherwise, who remain on the fence. Reviewing Wilder's rat-a-tat-tat satire of the cold war, "One Two Three" (1961), Pauline Kael harshly concludes that he is a clever, lively director whose work lacks feeling or passion or grace or beauty. And for years this is the running rap on Wilder: that he is detached, at times clinically so; that the ease with which he moves between genres makes his oeuvre less personal than that of auteurs like Ford and Hitchcock and Hawks; that he is a crowd pleaser first and an artist second.
But over the past decade Wilder's stock has seemed to rise and rise. There have been remakes aplenty: Andrew Lloyd Webber's "Sunset Boulevard" extravaganza on Broadway, Sydney Pollack's new version of "Sabrina," an updating of "The Apartment" rumored to be in the works. America's enduring crush on two actress-icons particularly associated with Wilder's work, Audrey Hepburn and Marilyn Monroe, has ensured that Wilder still enjoys that most coveted of trophies, high name recognition among younger audiences. Spike Lee and Ang Lee and Steven Spielberg, among others, have praised Wilder and quoted his films in their own, and a few years back a panel of best-director nominees could agree on only one man whose example taught them all: Billy Wilder. At the age of 93, Wilder has entered the pantheon. He is the contemporary idea of what a classic should be.
Cameron Crowe's sweetly reverential, beautifully illustrated book of interviews with Wilder makes it easy to see why. Crowe is a very talented writer-director in his own right (his latest film is "Jerry Maguire," source of the two endlessly repeated lines of dialogue, "You complete me" and "Show me the money!" -- but he should be forgiven), as well as a skilled former journalist who knows how to capture personality in print. The Wilder he brings to us is dapper, impatient, proud of his triumphs and freshly mortified by his goofs, a spontaneous comedic genius in private conversation, an art collector with idiosyncratic but exquisite taste, a sports addict in frequent contact with his bookie, a man subject to the unceasing physical stress of old age who nevertheless shuns the elevator because it might get stuck. There is some decent if not mind-blowing gossip here (surprise: Marilyn Monroe was hard to work with) and lively opinions dished out with the appealing, uncensored honesty of the elderly (Wilder loathed "Titanic," while, admirers might be taken aback to learn, his favorite movie of the 90's is "Forrest Gump").
But mostly "Conversations With Wilder" is devoted to fascinating and detailed discussions of the work, with Crowe gamely playing the humble novice, asking how Wilder did this and that, and Wilder dispensing wise little jewels that add up to an inspired manual on how to write and direct a film. On the art of the voice-over, which Wilder used to such famous, daring effect in "Sunset Boulevard," with its opening shot of William Holden floating dead in a pool -- and talking to the audience -- his advice is always to add to what the viewer is seeing. Wilder the writer likes a well-plotted three-act structure, with one final surprise for a strong ending. Crucial plot points should be introduced quickly, even hidden inside a joke so that the audience doesn't know what it swallowed. Music is good, but never for its own sake. He prefers contemporary, realistic lighting to glamorous chiaroscuro, and he finds most close-ups gratuitous -- though to stroke an actor's ego, he was not above setting up an unloaded camera as a kind of placebo, and pretending to shoot one. "If it does not follow the story," Wilder asks with his charming vestigial European syntax, "why?"
What emerges in this conversation tends to confirm Pauline Kael's suspicion that Wilder didn't always pour his heart into the human story in his films. But pour out his heart he clearly did: there is beauty in his caressing of details, and integrity in his decision to be a quiet, unfussy director, not a show-off like Welles or Hitchcock. He picked up an important lesson early on, he says, from a paragon sophisticate, the German director Ernst Lubitsch: if you say two and two, the audience does not have to be told it's four.
Crowe clearly worships Wilder, and his tender familiarity is the strength of this book. Indeed, his more technical questions reveal such intense personal study that it suddenly hit me how closely "Jerry Maguire" was filmed after the style of Wilder. The sendup of cheery corporate culture recalls "The Apartment." You may recall, too, that Tom Cruise's character, a vain and ambitious sports agent, is saved from perdition by a football player (Cuba Gooding Jr.) so loving and upbeat he is almost monstrous. Trade Cruise for Holden and Gooding's benign monster for Gloria Swanson's hell-bound Norma Desmond, and what do you have? "Sunset Boulevard," with a happy twist: had Wilder written and directed the film, Jerry Maguire might have ended up a corpse, dangling from a stadium skybox.
In his adoration, Crowe sometimes claims too much. Wilder was undoubtedly undervalued for most of his career, but Crowe's advocacy does not prevent this reader, at least, from thinking that these days Wilder's reputation is just a tiny bit on the high side. "The Apartment" is a delight -- groundbreakingly frank, and brilliantly executed -- but for all its internal perfections it is hardly the greatest American comedy, as Crowe seems to want to suggest. For all his freshness, Wilder did sometimes descend into formula; his three-time pairing of Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau is partly to blame for one maddeningly durable genre, the grumpy-buddy comedy. And if Wilder is rarely flat-out cold, he can, by his own mischievous admission, be calculating: "Some pictures play wonderfully to a room of eight people," he tells Crowe. "I don't go for that. I go for the masses. I go for the end effect."
Wilder's principled opposition to all forms of phoniness may strike a special chord in these world-weary times, but there is always room -- more than that, there is a need -- for the other kind of artist, who chases after unattainable ideals. Still, his particular genius shines throughout this book. After mistrusting Crowe at first, and firmly dismissing the idea of a book-length project, he grows enthusiastic enough to fuss over the tape recorder and make sure it is capturing his every word. When Crowe becomes too earnest, pressing him to admit that his work is all about the theme of masks and disguises, Wilder grabs the rudder and changes course. And when the interviews drag on for over a year, and Crowe is obviously neglecting his own work, Wilder begins to fear the book will meander (it does, a little). "Let it go," he counsels with a detachment that is healthy, affectionate, anything but cold. Such is his commitment to strong, economical storytelling that he even pitches his own death as a possible finale. Now that is devotion to the craft! Further proof, too, that there is indeed such a thing as inspired irony, and cynicism with a higher purpose.
Its -- his -- name is Billy Wilder.

LENGTH: 1438 words

HEADLINE: The Worst of Times

BYLINE: By Josef Joffe; Josef Joffe is the editorial page editor and a columnist at Sddeutsche Zeitung in Munich, on leave this year as the Payne Lecturer at Stanford's Institute for International Studies.

 BODY:

Reflections on a Ravaged Century
 By Robert Conquest.
 317 pp. New York:
 W. W. Norton & Company. $26.95. 
 How will we remember the 20th century? First and foremost, it was the century of the Three T's: total war, totalitarianism and terror. When did it begin? Make that not 1900, but 1861. With 600,000 dead, more than fell in all of America's other conflicts, the Civil War was really the first war of the 20th century -- a guerre l'outrance, sparing neither cities nor civilians. Save for the airplane, the machinery of mayhem that would grind up Europe in the two world wars was already in place between Harpers Ferry and Appomattox: breech-loading rifles and machine guns, ironclads and submarines, railroads and telegraphs, scorched-earth tactics and bombarded cities.
When did the century end? The monster of total war was chained early -- on
V-J Day. But the other two T's -- totalitarianism and terror -- endured. Having outlived Fascism and Nazism, Soviet Communism would fall only with the Berlin Wall in 1989. And genocide, along with its contemporary variant, ethnic cleansing, continues to thrive, most recently in Rwanda and Kosovo. So whatever wondrous things this century has brought -- the Internet, the microwave, Prozac -- it will stand out as the age of annihilation in the name of tribe, nation, race or class. Consider these gruesome numbers. Regular war has killed 30 million, but this figure pales when compared to the 170 million civilians massacred by states and regimes like the Soviet, German or Chinese ones.
What drove this most murderous of centuries? It wasn't just industrialization and technology as exemplified by the Nazi death factories; deliberate starvation in the ways of Stalin and Mao was even more "productive." Which is why the historian Robert Conquest has justly focused on ideas, on the "ideological frenzy" that gripped so much of the century. In the 18th and 19th centuries, enemies were defeated; in the 20th, they were exterminated in Auschwitz or the killing fields of Cambodia.
"Reflections on a Ravaged Century" is a collection of essays addressing one big question: where did this century go wrong? Conquest, who has written more than a dozen books on the Soviet Union, is a traditional conservative. He quotes with approval the great conservative thinker Michael Oakeshott: ideologues regard government as an "instrument of passion"; for them, "the art of politics is to inflame and direct desire." Woe unto the world when they grab power, for the "conjunction of dreaming and ruling generates tyranny." A liberal polity in the Anglo-American way is the very opposite; its mission is to "restrain, to deflate, to pacify and to reconcile; not to stoke the fires of desire, but to damp them down."
Our century has been the era of ideologues and their apologists. The book's most poignant passages quote from a recent interview with the Marxist historian Eric Hobsbawm. Had he known back in 1934 that "millions of people are dying in the Soviet experiment," would he have renounced Communism? "Probably not," replied Hobsbawn. And why not? Because "the chance of a new world being born in great suffering would still have been worth backing." So it would have been worth the sacrifice of 15 million, 20 million? "Yes."
This is the quintessential answer of the 20th century, stunning in its cruelty and breathtaking in its navete. The most potent message of Communism and Nazism was of course an idealistic one: final victory over "the enemy," hence liberation from all conflicts, followed by economic plenty with equality and justice for all. Yet there is no such thing as a free society without "contradictions," to recall the Marxian vernacular. The dream of salvation will always end in the nightmare of a faceless, atomized mass cowed and controlled by a behemoth state. Evil means will not produce lofty ends but poison them. This elementary insight of both conservatism and liberalism is the leitmotif of Conquest's essays.
Though wrapping themselves in the emancipatory banner of the Enlightenment, the Communists were no better than the Nazis. Conquest asks us to listen to Ilya Ehrenburg, Stalin's poet laureate, when writing about the kulaks, the smallholders doomed to extinction because they resisted collectivization: "Not one of them was guilty of anything; but they belonged to a class that was guilty of everything." Substitute "Jew" for "kulak," and "race" for "class," and you can hear Heinrich Himmler.
The point is that terror was intrinsic to both totalitarianisms, though many in the West still deny the twinship of Stalinism and Hitlerism. But why fight these old battles again? The ogres have been slain, and democracy is on a roll. For Conquest, the fight is a matter of honor as well as pedagogy. So-called right-wing intellectuals like Conquest (a former British soldier, diplomat and journalist) at Stanford's Hoover Institution, or like Richard Pipes at Harvard did not have an easy time in the academy during the 1970's and 80's, when "anti-Communist" became an epithet and moral judgments about the "evil empire" became, well, "judgmental."
Now, a decade after the empire's demise, and with ever widening access to party and state archives, it turns out that those "cold warriors" were right, while many of their opponents look like unregenerate apologists. Yes, Stalin did want control over Europe and was not just reacting to "American imperialism." The repression was every bit as vicious as Solzhenitsyn had described it in "The Gulag Archipelago." "Really-existing socialism," to recall the jargon, was indeed the "private ownership of the state," as Khristian Rakovsky, a Bolshevik critical of his comrades, already complained in the 1920's.
At 82, Conquest might have been forgiven for striking a triumphalist note. But he has not done so. Drawing on a vast wealth of detail, writing with an almost literary flair that is disappearing from the American academy, Conquest has stressed a moral that bears endless repetition. Though the two totalitarianisms are dead, and the liberal polity (where the state is subservient to the individual) seems to have won, the underlying battle will continue to the very end of humanity.
It is the contest between two conceptions of politics that have vied for the minds of men since the pre-Socratics. One is what Oakeshott calls the "myth of rationalist politics" or the "assimilation of politics to engineering." It is based on the frightful idea that some of us (like Lenin's "vanguard") know what is best for the rest. The task of the leaders, as the Hungarian party chief Janos Kadar pontificated in 1957, "is not to put into effect the wishes and will of the masses. The task of the leaders is to accomplish the interests of the masses."
The mildest version is the paternalistic, "caring" state, say Sweden. It relies not on the K.G.B. and the gulag, but on an ever expanding budget and a bureaucratic class that taxes, disburses and regulates in the name of the collective good. Yet as goodness spreads, so does state power, while autonomy shrinks. The worst version, which has splattered this "ravaged century" with the blood of millions, is Jacobinism, with (in Matthew Arnold's words) its "fierceness and its addiction to an abstract system." If you don't fit, you die.
The other conception is liberal democracy, where the wishes and the will of the masses do matter, where conflict is legitimate, where the state's power is limited, where politics is not an exercise in Procrustean bed building -- off with his feet, or worse. There is no final purpose to history, no perfection, no utopia, and therefore no need for a "New Man" forged in the crucible of the re-education camp.
That fight between top-down expansionist and bottom-up limited government puts Plato, Rousseau and the Red Guards in one corner, Locke, Jefferson and Burke in the other. Who shall decide what is good, just and true? Man or the state, the individual or the collective? Is rational thought possible, or is it just a construct that masks the interests of gender, race or class?
Conquest's answers are as plain as they are spirited. Transcending history, this book is a resolutely intelligent contribution to the culture wars that will stretch into the next century. History is learning about (and perhaps from) the disasters of yesteryear, from ideas that became mindtraps rather than pathways to enlightenment. As the bloodiest of all centuries draws to a close, read these essays, not to weep but to learn how to make the word -- and the world -- safe for liberal democracy.
