SECTION: Section 7; Page 14; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 621 words

HEADLINE: The Mind's Eye

BYLINE: By Henry Kisor; Henry Kisor, the book review editor of The Chicago Sun-Times, is the author of "What's That Pig Outdoors? A Memoir of Deafness" and other books.

 BODY:

TWILIGHT
 Losing Sight, Gaining Insight.
 By Henry Grunwald.
 130 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $20. 
 Gifted writers -- Helen Keller is their lodestar -- long have illuminated the dark and silent corners of their blindness or deafness. Rather than submit to their loss, they confront it by studying causes and contemplating consequences. With "Twilight," a slim but splendid memoir, Henry Grunwald, former editor in chief of Time Inc. publications, once United States ambassador to his native Austria and author of the acclaimed "One Man's America: A Journalist's Search for the Heart of His Country," joins their ranks.
Pouring water one day in 1992, Grunwald missed the glass. Age-related macular degeneration, the doctor said. In each eye tiny, fragile blood vessels were growing wild and breaking, scarring the macula, an area a quarter of an inch wide at the center of the retina, the eye's projection screen. There is no cure, and palliatives work only temporarily.
Grunwald whisks the reader through a brief history of the eye, beginning with its evolution from light-sensitive spots on the skin of primitive organisms. In the seventh century B.C., Assyrian eyewash employed the gall of a disemboweled yellow frog mixed in curd. Closer to our time, eye disease helped wreck Napoleon's Egyptian campaign and spurred research in Europe. Not until 1885 was macular degeneration identified, and not until 1970 was it understood. It is not complete sightlessness -- it makes the sufferer see everything through an ever thickening haze. Grunwald could still recognize shapes and colors, but reading had become "the visual equivalent of struggling for breath." Good days and bad alternate: "A paragraph read was a triumph; a sentence undeciphered was a blow." Soon he could no longer read, disastrous for a word-driven person.
Audio books help. He hires readers to record magazines and newspapers on tape. He dictates his own words. But "my books are still more than furniture, but less than the living things they used to be."
Grunwald is candid. Near blindness makes him "restless and moody," he admits, and affects his relations with friends and family. And it foreshadows the dreaded event that eventually overtakes most of us: the moment when the child becomes caregiver to the parent.
But he copes. At New York's Lighthouse for the Blind, his fellow "macular degenerates" help him learn to live with the disease. He crosses busy streets next to women with baby carriages, a sight that thwarts the most aggressive traffic.
He compensates. Always a good listener, as every journalist should be, he learns to hear more attentively than ever before. And he contemplates, dredging his memory for indelible sights, "constructing in my mind a kaleidoscope of the past": a rich world of history, myth and art. Recalling Turner's misty canvases of Venice reminds Grunwald how he sees Venice -- and everything else -- through a veil today. Yet, if properly lighted, "many portraits, like the ones by Titian or Memling, seem to burst out of a fog and seize me with sudden power." (Like any true artist, Grunwald sees not only with eyes but also imagination.) He appreciates unexpected moments of humor, too. In a Chinese restaurant the imposing matre d' with whom Grunwald tries to shake hands turns out to be a large statue of a monkey.
To call writing this book a feat of courage would be to patronize its author; after all, what else could he have done? Henry Grunwald simply weds a graceful, economic prose to a lucid vision of his changed world -- exactly what we would expect from such a distinguished journalist -- and produces a lovely book. In losing his sight, he has reached for light.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
The Hours That Make A Student an M.D.

BYLINE: By ABIGAIL ZUGER, M. D. 

 BODY:
THE young doctor was reminiscing about his first year out of medical school. "I was chronically in a terribly nervous state," he wrote. "Nearly every case disclosed to me more and more plainly the depth of my ignorance, my utter unpreparedness and incompetence."
He could have been any intern who started working at any teaching hospital in the country last July ("It was mortifying to discover that I lacked the knowledge which every nurse possesses.") He could have been me 18 years ago, or any other doctor at almost any time in history. The emotions an obscure Russian named Vikenty Veressayev detailed in his little-known 1916 classic, "Memoirs of a Physician," are a given in medicine: the panic, self-doubt, profound exhaustion and occasional exhilaration of that first year out. 
 For centuries book-smart youngsters with new diplomas have slunk out of medical school knowing, if they have any sense at all, that they are impostors. A few years later they discover they have turned into doctors. And, for all the tinkering with those years by generations of medical educators, the alchemy of the transformation remains almost as mysterious as ever.
How many hours does it actually take to make a doctor? This is still one of the big mysteries of the process. Is medical care better delivered by a fatigued young doctor who has been at your bedside 36 hours -- or by a succession of fresh young strangers who work shorter shifts, and have heard about you through the medical equivalent of the game of telephone?
This century has seen a dramatic evolution in medical training from long working hours to shorter ones. Up through World War II, interns and residents in the United States were indentured servants in hospitals, available 24 hours a day. Most received little compensation (except for room and board) along with a free-form education that was shaped by whatever sick patients and senior physicians happened by.
Now their dual roles of worker and student are more precisely defined. As workers, interns and residents get days off and a living wage. As students, they attend lectures and conferences that encompass social and economic aspects of medicine long ignored in medical training. And as indentured servants -- for they continue to work many extra hours for the health care system -- they at least have the satisfaction of knowing that their day-to-day welfare is of more concern to their employers than it used to be.
In the days when interns worked every night or every other night, the pace of the work was slow enough that they could actually get some sleep. Technology put an end to that: in the 1970's and 1980's 36-hour stretches without a nap became commonplace, and workweeks could stretch to 100 hours or more.
"Working a double?" a nurse once asked me when she noticed one morning that I was in the same place (and in the same clothes) she had seen me the evening before. I pointed out that I was actually working a quintuple, as I would every third night for most of my three years of residency.
A terrible accident changed that routine in New York. The death of a young woman, Libby Zion, was traced directly to these long, unsupervised hours, and in July 1989 the state Hospital Code was amended to restrict the average workweek to no more than 80 hours and mandate that a senior physician be available to supervise at all times.
New York remains the only state where these stipulations are law, but they are rapidly becoming the standard elsewhere. All internal medicine training programs are now held to similar standards, and failure to comply may result in a loss of accreditation.
Other medical specialties are following suit. So are other countries: New Zealand long ago limited its residents to a 72-hour workweek, and the European Union is now hashing out the practicalities of a 48-hour week for the 270,000 trainees in its member countries.
Several studies have now found that the mistakes doctors make from fatigue do diminish with shorter work hours, but they are replaced by errors that result when a patient's care is transferred from one doctor to another at the end of shorter shifts. No study has yet addressed the broader question: Will shorter workdays keep interns and residents from developing the important instincts those awful long nights hammered in -- a sense of the pace of illness and recovery, of what is likely to happen to a patient and when?
THESE details are, of course, the easy part of a medical education. I must grudgingly admit that the grisly old days of training -- may they never return -- helped teach us one of the harder lessons too.
Interns and residents are a spectacularly healthy lot of young people. Most are far too young to have encountered illness or death among friends or relatives; fewer still have ever been ill themselves. Yet somehow they all must learn to bridge a huge gap of imagination and develop some real feeling for the subjective experience, as well as the objective appearance, of disease.
Some educators say studying literature and the humanities can teach this kind of empathy. Others doubt it can be taught at all. One famous professor simply suggested that all interns be required to use a bedpan in front of a silent group of white-coated strangers, and see how it feels for themselves.
But here is an alternate route to empathy: stay awake every third night for three years, tired, aching, nauseated and terrified that despite the very best intentions in the world you are about to make a terrible mistake.
With any luck at all you will get a vague idea of how it must feel to be truly sick, powerless and frightened -- and with any luck the lesson will stick even after it is all over.

HEADLINE: Media Talk;
Judge Dismisses Bias Lawsuit Against CNN

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEISER 

 BODY:
Four years ago, CNN hired a veteran journalist, Art Browne, as a senior editor in its New York office. What made the move somewhat unusual for CNN was that Mr. Browne was 59 at the time, had been unemployed for four years and suffered from a neurological condition called essential tremor disorder, which caused his voice, hands and head to shake.
Sixteen months later, Mr. Browne, after being told that his work had been unsatisfactory, was fired. He sued CNN last year, contending that he was dismissed because of his age and his disability. 
 But last Tuesday, a federal judge in Manhattan dismissed the suit before trial, saying that Mr. Browne had failed to prove discrimination and that CNN should receive credit for hiring him in the first place.
"It would do disservice," wrote Judge John S. Martin Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan, "to the goals that our antidiscrimination laws are designed to foster if we did not give substantial weight to the fact that CNN hired Browne with full knowledge of his age and disability."
Given the lack of evidence of discrimination, the judge added, were he to allow the suit to proceed, "other companies would, in the future, be reluctant to follow CNN's example and hire someone like Browne."
Maureen S. Binetti, a lawyer for Mr. Browne, said he had no comment, but she criticized the decision, saying, "It's dead wrong."
"The judge ignored critical evidence that we believe mandated the denial of" CNN's motion to dismiss the case, she said, "and it's a shame."
"This person was in this business for four decades," she said, "and I find it incomprehensible that as matter of law, a judge would find that he could not do that particular relatively low-level job when he had tremendous jobs in the business in the past."
CNN described the job Mr. Browne took in October 1995 as one with important responsibilities. Mr. Browne had had a long career in television and radio, working as national editor of ABC News in New York from 1977 to 1981 and later in television news operations in New Haven, Chicago and Washington. CNN hired him as senior futures editor, a job that involved planning beyond the day's news for events throughout the Northeast, CNN said in court papers.
 But his superiors became dissatisfied with his performance, giving him warnings, and in one case, removing him from coverage of the explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800 after he was found to be "an impediment to coverage," Judge Martin noted in his opinion.
To bolster his discrimination case, Mr. Browne said in legal papers that CNN had replaced him with a 26-year-old "who had fewer years on this planet than plaintiff had doing television news," that almost all of CNN's employees in New York were under 40 and that his superior made derogatory comments about his disability.
But in rejecting various arguments by Mr. Browne that he was a victim of discrimination, Judge Martin said "poor work performance is a legitimate, nondiscriminatory reason to discharge an employee."
A CNN spokesman, David J. Bittler, would say only, "We feel the decision speaks for itself." BENJAMIN WEISER

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Class-Action Suit Based On Microsoft Antitrust Case
Lawyers say they will file a class-action suit today against Microsoft on behalf of millions of Californians in the first of what could become a flood of lawsuits springing from the antitrust case against the company.
The suit will accuse Microsoft of using its monopoly in operating systems software to overcharge buyers of Windows 95 and Windows 98. The complaint does not estimate the financial effect to Windows users, but the lawyers bringing the case are seeking a triple-damages award if the suit leads to an eventual finding of financial harm. Page A1.
 
Tracking Stock for Excite@Home
The board of Excite@Home has agreed to create a division between its cable and content businesses by establishing a separate tracking stock for the media assets, including the Excite Web portal. C2. 

Bias Suit Against CNN Dismissed
A federal judge in Manhattan has dismissed a discrimination suit against CNN before trial. Art Browne, a senior editor in the network's New York office, contended he was fired after 16 months on the job because of his age -- he was 59 when he was hired -- and because of a disability that caused his voice, hands and head to shake. CNN said his work had been unsatisfactory. C17.
 
Telecom Italia to Keep Mobile Unit
Olivetti and Tecnost, the unit through which Olivetti bought Telecom Italia, said that they had abandoned plans to strip Italy's largest telecommunications company of its profitable mobile phone unit. C2.
 
PepsiCo to Raise Concentrate Price
Following a trend set by Coca-Cola, PepsiCo plans to raise the price it charges its bottlers for concentrate by 7 percent next year. The increase means both soft-drink giants are committed to a key shift in strategy that rejects the volume-at-any-cost model in favor of improved profit margins with less volume. C2.
 
Agreement and Snags for Digital TV
Solving a problem that has been an impediment to digital television, the cable television and consumer electronics industries say they have agreed on a way to connect digital cable boxes to digital TV sets. But the two sides are still sniping at each other over details. C17.
 
Incompletes on Year 2000 Grades
The federal government is going to get a respectable report card when the House subcommittee tracking Year 2000 preparations issues what it calls its final grades today. But the subcommittee has decided not to issue grades for more than 40 vital government programs because many programs dependent on the states and private organizations are not completely ready for the transition. C10.
 
Credibility Code Meets Resistance
The Internet's growing lack of credibility among consumers is beginning to draw more attention. Two organizations -- one grass roots, the other representing industry -- have announced their intentions to bring some balance to a debate that has been lopsided toward unfettered growth at any cost. But it seems that the Internet economy is far more willing to risk consumer rejection than to voluntarily adopt a code of conduct or to reveal too much about how it conducts business. Digital Commerce. C5.
 
Software Tool Seeks Low Prices
Web users who like to comparison shop no longer have to click to another site to find better prices. Several companies have developed a new breed of agents -- software tools that work with Web browser software, offering shoppers better deals on whatever goods they happen to be viewing on a Web page. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C16.

HEADLINE: Hear, Hear, Please! 'Question Time' in Japan

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 21

 BODY:
The prime minister is at the lectern, struggling to field a series of increasingly challenging questions from the leader of the opposition. Jeers are rising in crescendo from the Parliament floor, and the few spectators allowed in are on the edge of their seats, fairly straining for a view.
The scene, known as question time, has been adopted straight from British politics. On the surface, just two weeks into its existence, it still may seem like a jolting innovation to some in the often soporific world of the Japanese Parliament. 
 Of course that was the idea -- arrived at jointly by the government and the opposition -- from the start: that the Parliament of the nation where consensus is so highly valued that trenchant comment had become an endangered species needed some serious reinvigoration. And what better way, it was thought, than a dose of old-fashioned, British style confrontational debate?
From technology to popular culture, Japan is well known for its facility for borrowing from other countries. Its Parliament was modeled on those of Europe, and foreign models inspired most of this country's modern institutions.
What is less widely known abroad is how assiduously Japan reshapes whatever it borrows, molding everything from Chinese food to American words to fit within the nation's rather narrow comfort zones. And as it is already turning out, question time is no different.
So there was Yukio Hatoyama, the leader of the opposition Democratic Party, standing tall and tugging at his shirt cuffs for dramatic effect demanding an explanation from Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi about why policemen have not been arrested in a provincial corruption case.
Was this the most compelling question to begin the second edition of the new, weekly 40-minute debate? Perhaps not, but it was an improvement over Mr. Hatoyama's first try, a week earlier, when the nation's eyes were bracketed on him as he began the new spectacle by asking Mr. Obuchi what he had eaten for breakfast that morning.
Blunt confrontation, it seems, does not come any more easily to Japanese politicians than it does to ordinary Japanese, whose national language is a maze of well-practiced protocols and polite indirection. But to be fair, Mr. Hatoyama eventually warmed to his subject in the 26 minutes accorded him.
Why did Mr. Obuchi temporarily suspend unpopular tax payments for a national nursing care system just as elections are nearing, Mr. Hatoyama asked. And how was it that the conservative governing party, the Liberal Democrats, had gone into coalition recently with a party widely seen as the creature of the country's largest Buddhist organization?
"This is happening because you share a desire to be ruling parties, not because you have agreed on any policies beforehand," Mr. Hatoyama said. "And you should be ashamed of that." Turning up the heat further, the opposition leader handed Mr. Obuchi a three-year-old pamphlet from the prime minister's own party that denounced the Buddhist-affiliated party as unconstitutional.
Leaning heavily on his lectern, Mr. Obuchi replied weakly: "Around that time that was the mainstream view of the party. But after that we have had some twists and turns."
If that exchange furnished a touch of drama, for those taking part it almost certainly involved little surprise. In the incestuous world of Japanese politics -- again, as in the society at large -- few things are avoided so carefully as surprise.
While politicians' staff members in the United States are responsible for trying to prepare their bosses for every possible question in advance, in Japan the opposition has courteously submitted its questions to the governing party two days in advance of question time.
Much the same thing happened to a foreign journalist when he arrived for an appointment with a government minister here recently. A staff member handed him a list of questions that he suggested be used in the interview. He agreed only hesitantly to answer some others.
What is the purpose of holding a debate at all, one might ask? Still, the new system might be seen as an improvement over the traditional parliamentary debates here in which bureaucrats prepared the questions for both opposition and governing parties, and then sat and answered them solemnly in testimony.
Question time here is meant to remove some of the immense power from a bureaucracy discredited by 10 years of economic drift. And it is intended to give elected politicians more of an air of involvement in running the country instead of just counting money and votes.
Although formally democratic, Japan has been a virtual one-party state for decades, with Mr. Obuchi's Liberal Democratic Party making few concessions until its monopoly on power was broken in 1993.
Nowadays, few voters feel strong party affiliation. And many of the country's political leaders look longingly toward the West, where stable two-party systems are common and political identities run deeper.
"The old one-party system has collapsed, and the new party system hasn't yet emerged," said Gerald Curtis, a professor of political science at Columbia University who specializes in Japan. "In the meantime, what can differentiate one party from another in a society that isn't rent by deep cleavages, whether class or primordial issues like ethnicity?
"Just by copying the British in organizational terms doesn't mean that you can copy them in terms of free speech and wit and the skills of parliamentary debate, and that is what question time is all about. What we are left with is personalities."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Clinton, a Renaissance Guy, Paints the Globe Bright

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: FLORENCE, Italy, Nov. 21

 BODY:
It was a long wait, particularly long because the bathrooms were placed off limits for security reasons, long enough even for the Champagne and the caviar canapes to run out, but when President Clinton arrived he quickly wowed a glittering audience with visions of a juster world.
The setting was New York University's Florentine retreat, Villa La Pietra, complete with Donatellos. So it was perhaps inevitable that the president should turn to the fruitful ferment of the Renaissance to illustrate his conviction that a similar era of enriching inventiveness is now being driven by the Internet and a global economy. 
It is late in the presidency, a time when history books come to mind. And it was clear throughout a two-day conference on "Progressive Governance" that began on Saturday night at the Villa La Pietra that he sees an important part of his legacy in the reinvention of center-left politics he has called the Third Way.
The central themes of Clintonian Third-Wayism have become familiar: fiscal discipline in the place of tax-and-spend profligacy; investment in education and new technologies; opportunity for all and responsibility from all.
The vindicating American statistics were liberally showered on Europeans still struggling to generate some growth: lowest unemployment in 30 years, lowest poverty rate in 20, first back-to-back budget surpluses for 40.
"We have, in addition, a much greater opportunity to spread the benefits of this renaissance more broadly than it could have been spread 500 years ago," Mr. Clinton said, adding that achieving this "requires us to go beyond the competing models of Industrial Age politics."
Lionel Jospin, the French prime minister who still has a penchant for the socialist ideas that grew out of the Industrial Age, among them the notion that socialism must be critical of capitalism, was not impressed.
Back resolutely turned, he declined even to look at Mr. Clinton, keeping his chair pointed in the other direction, toward the somewhat bemused visage of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, who prefers to call his updated social democracy the New Middle.
Whatever you call the reinvented left, the French do not seem to like it much. Such newfangled gatherings as this Florentine get-together tend to be seen by French Socialists as an insidious trans-Atlantic attempt to take over their preferred global forum, the Socialist International, where Mr. Clinton's Democratic Party does not tread.
Roberto Benigni, the Oscar-winning director of "Life is Beautiful," had no such qualms. Celebrities, of course, are part of the new left's vote-winning package, not least in Hollywood, so Mr. Benigni was there to hear about social democracy's new politics of empowerment and opportunity.
To the evident astonishment of Mr. Blair, he leapt into Mr. Clinton's arms, showering the president with kisses. A slightly red-faced Mr. Clinton then introduced the British prime minister, who shook the Italian actor's hand. Life is indeed beautiful when the Third Way leads to Florence.
 
A Reticent First Lady
So beautiful that John Sexton, the dean of the New York University School of Law, could not resist calling the dinner "a quintessentially global moment," before announcing that the "New York University Global Law School Leadership Award" would be presented to Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Mrs. Clinton rose, walked toward the podium, accepted a small plaque, smiled for the cameras -- and said nothing. A few words from the first lady had been anticipated, and in this land of graciousness, her silence did not go unremarked.
"She thought it would be presumptuous to say anything in front of so many world leaders, and also for her to be the only first lady to speak," said Sidney Blumenthal, an adviser to the president. But some present suggested that the fracas over her recent meeting in Israel with Mrs. Arafat had inclined Mrs. Clinton to see wisdom in silence.
Among the other first ladies present was Cherie Blair, whose unexpected pregnancy at the age of 45 has inspired the German popular press to urge the Chancellor -- childless despite four marriages -- to follow the Blairs' example. Doris Schroder, who has opted not to move to Berlin from Hanover, was conspicuous by her absence.
At a meeting much concerned with the aging populations of Europe and the United States -- Mr. Clinton pointed out that during the next 30 years the number of people over 65 in America would double -- the Blairs were complimented by the European Union Commission president, Romano Prodi, for their "heroic efforts" to bolster the active population.
But while agreeing that many challenges like aging populations are shared ones, Europeans and Americans opted to differ over their models of society, with Mr. Prodi saying that Europe must reform but also defend "its social model" and what he called the greater justice and equity of the European welfare state.
 
Globalism Is Kicked Around
There is an optimistic view of globalization among center-left leaders and there is a pessimistic one. The optimists, and they include Mr. Clinton and Mr. Blair, say that if the opportunities created by a global economy are well managed, they will benefit mankind and eventually advance equality.
"If you give people access to technology, a lot of smart people figure out how to make a lot of money," Mr. Clinton said, adding that this would be just as true in Africa as it has been in the United States.
The pessimistic school, or at least the cautious one, was led here by Mr. Jospin, with some support from Massimo D'Alema, prime minister of Italy, and the Brazilian president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, whose country suffered a battering from global financial panic too recently to feel confident.
"There are still huge divides within nations and among nations, and we have to meet this challenge of inequality," Mr. Jospin said today, arguing that modern global capitalism engendered more inequality than the capitalism of the early part of this century. "We have to accept a networked world, but not a world dominated by networks, because then it would be dominated by private interests."
It was Mr. Clinton's turn to look skeptical. Private interests, of course, are what make America tick.
The president and Mr. Blair argued passionately that so long as workers' rights, the environment, and ideals of inclusiveness are not forgotten while an open, global economy is promoted, the fruits of wealth will one day be spread wide.
So long, the president insisted, as fiscal conservatism prevails. "Part of the liberal left program is now to balance the budget," Mr. Clinton said. "We are now the parties of fiscal discipline, because that brings interest rates down, creates jobs, lowers interest rates on mortgages and car loans, and so helps ordinary people."
The post-cold-war world of the left really has changed: fiscal tight-fistedness, the argument now goes, actually helps the poor. Turning to Mr. Cardoso, the president added, "If we all run a surplus, that makes it that much cheaper for Enrique to get money in Brazil."
Simple, really. If only everyone on the center-left understood. But, to judge by the meeting here, not everyone gets Clintonomics.

HEADLINE: Colombia Extradites Drug Suspect to U.S.

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
A Colombian accused of running a major heroin smuggling ring was bundled aboard an American government plane in Colombia today and flown to the United States. It is the first time in nearly a decade that Colombia has turned over one of its own citizens to stand trial in this country.
The Clinton administration hailed the extradition of the 30-year-old suspect, Jaime Orlando Lara, the first of 42 drug suspects being held in Colombian jails awaiting transfer to the United States. 
 But it almost certainly means new turmoil for Colombia, the source of most of the cocaine sold on American streets and a fast-growing exporter of heroin to the United States as well.
Colombian drug cartels appear to be beginning a new wave of terrorist attacks in protest over the resumption of extraditions of drug trafficking suspects to the United States.
Two weeks ago, a car bomb killed eight people and wounded scores of others in a fashionable shopping district of Bogota, the capital. The police there said it was a final warning against the extradition of Mr. Lara and the others. Similar violence by the drug traffickers led the Colombian government to halt extraditions in 1991; the last one before today's occurred in 1990.
President Andres Pastrana, who has won praise from the Clinton administration as well as large American aid commitments for his willingness to crack down on the drug trade since he took office last year, defiantly signed Mr. Lara's extradition order only hours after the deadly bombing.
"President Pastrana must be commended for his courage and dedication," said Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the White House director of drug control policy. "Actions such as today's extradition to confront the traffickers will send a powerful and helpful signal."
Terry Parham, the chief spokesman for the Drug Enforcement Administration, said that Mr. Lara was "a big deal as far as being a major trafficker" but that "the bigger deal is the resumption of the extradition process" by Colombia. "This is very positive for law enforcement," he said.
Mr. Pastrana has formally authorized the extradition of two other suspects wanted in the United States on drug trafficking charges: a Cuban, Bravilo Gonzalez, and a Venezuelan, Fernando Jose Flores.
Prosecutors hope that Mr. Flores will prove to be a valuable witness against the leadership of the now-defunct Cali cocaine cartel.
Mr. Lara, who was flown initially from Bogota to Fort Lauderdale on the way to New York, is wanted by federal prosecutors in Manhattan on charges that he conspired to smuggle large amounts of heroin into the United States and distribute it here.
Law enforcement officials have charged that at one point his family-run smuggling ring exported 25 pounds of heroin a week into the United States through distribution points in New York, Houston and Miami, usually by hiding it in commercial airliners, sometimes in passengers' luggage. Mr. Lara's two sisters were arrested in the United States earlier this year.
Colombian police spokesmen were quoted in Bogota as saying Mr. Lara was in handcuffs this morning when he was placed aboard a twin-engine Cessna plane owned by the United States Drug Enforcement Administration. The spokesmen said the heavily guarded suspect, dressed in jeans and sneakers, had not said a word as he walked the 60 feet across the tarmac to the plane.
Acting on an American request, the Colombian police captured Mr. Lara in Bogota last December.
American law enforcement officials say he fled the United States in July after his sisters were arrested by the Drug Enforcement Administration. Immigration records, the officials say, show that he left Colombia 29 times between August 1991 and July of last year.
The Clinton administration is piecing together a major economic and military aid package for Colombia intended to support Mr. Pastrana's government as it struggles with a thriving drug trade, a leftist guerrilla insurgency, right-wing paramilitary forces fighting the guerrillas and an economic crisis.
But the aid package, worth as much as $1.5 billion over the next three years, is inducing reservations even among some in the administration, who fear that the United States is being drawn too deeply into a civil conflict that has left tens of thousands of Colombians dead in the last four decades.
But administration officials say they are desperate to find a way to stem the flood of Colombia cocaine -- as well as heroin that is transshipped through Colombia -- into the United States. The Central Intelligence Agency estimated last year that Colombia might have produced as much as 188 tons of cocaine from its own crop, up from 88 tons in 1995.

HEADLINE: Thanksgiving Message

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Following is President Clinton's Thanksgiving Day proclamation:
Thanksgiving 1999
 
By the President of the United States of America
Well over three and a half centuries ago, strengthened by faith and bound by a common desire for liberty, a small band of Pilgrims sought out a place in the New World where they could worship according to their own beliefs. Surviving their first harsh winter in Massachusetts and grateful to a merciful God for a sustaining harvest, the men and women of Plymouth Colony set aside three days as a time to give thanks for the bounty of their fields, the fruits of their labor, the chance to live in peace with their Native American neighbors and the blessings of a land where they could live and worship freely. 
 We have come far on our American journey since that early Thanksgiving. In the intervening years, we have lived through times of war and peace, years of poverty and plenty, and seasons of social and political upheaval that have shaped and forever changed our national character and experience. As we gather around our Thanksgiving tables again this year, it is a fitting time to reflect on how the events of our rich history have affected those we care about and those who came before us. As we acknowledge the past, we do so knowing that the individual blessings for which we give thanks may have changed, but our gratitude to God and our commitment to our fellow Americans remain constant.
Today we count among our national blessings a time of unprecedented prosperity, with an expanding economy, record low rates of poverty and unemployment among our people, and the limitless opportunities to improve the quality of life that new technologies present to us. We can give thanks today that for the first time in history, more than half the world's people live under governments of their own choosing. And we remain grateful for the peace and freedom America continues to enjoy thanks to the courage and patriotism of our men and women in uniform.
But the spirit of Thanksgiving requires more than just an acknowledgment of our blessings; it calls upon us to reach out and share those blessings with others. We must strive to fulfill the promise of the extraordinary era in which we live and enter the new century with a commitment to widen the circle of opportunity, break down the prejudices that alienate us from one another and build an America of understanding and inclusion, strong in our diversity, responsible in our freedom and generous in sharing our bounty with those in need.
NOW, THEREFORE, I, WILLIAM J. CLINTON, President of the United States of America, by virtue of the authority vested in me by the Constitution and laws of the United States, do hereby proclaim Thursday, November 25, 1999, as a National Day of Thanksgiving. I encourage all the people of the United States to assemble in their homes, places of worship or community centers to share the spirit of fellowship and prayer and to reinforce the ties of family and community; to express heartfelt thanks to God for the many blessings He has bestowed upon us; and to reach out in true gratitude and friendship to our brothers and sisters in the larger family of humankind.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand this twentieth day of November, in the year of our Lord nineteen hundred and ninety-nine, and of the Independence of the United States of America the two hundred and twenty-fourth.
 WILLIAM J. CLINTON

HEADLINE: Protesting War School for Foreigners

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 21

 BODY:
In a small classroom inside a pink building on this historic Army post, Maj. Pablo Friedrich is learning the art of war.
A bearish marine from Colombia, he will spend nine weeks here studying tactical manuals translated into Spanish from the books used by American officers. Then he will return home as deputy commander of a marine battalion in Cartagena, rejoining Colombia's civil war against guerrillas and drug traffickers. 
 Whether he returns as a more professional soldier infused with American military values or as one trained to wage a more efficient war of repression is the question at the heart of a roiling national debate over this training center, the Army's School of the Americas.
Over the weekend, thousands of protesters led by a Roman Catholic priest gathered at Fort Benning's main gate just outside Columbus for the annual protest to demand the closing of the school, the nation's main training center for Latin American military and police officers for more than 50 years.
Today, a funereal procession of 3,100 protesters marched onto the post, led by several dozen dressed in black robes and white masks and carrying wooden coffins they said represented those killed by graduates of the school. In a peaceful, carefully choreographed confrontation, the Army stopped them after nearly a mile, put them on buses and drove them off the post. Sixty-fiveprotesters were detained and given citations barring them from Fort Benning for three years.
"You don't teach democracy anywhere by training the military," said Joe Morton, 63, a professor at Goucher College near Baltimore, moments before he boarded a bus at the post. "Students who come here are going to go back to their countries and shoot people like us."
Last week, Secretary of the Army Louis Caldera announced plans to make significant changes to the school's curriculum in hopes of muting growing opposition, especially in Congress, which nearly voted to close the school this fall. But the plans failed to win over the most fervent opponents. "We are not here to transform this school," the Rev. Roy L. Bourgeois, the priest who has organized the opposition, told protesters on Saturday. "We are here -- and we need to make this clear -- to close this school."
A visit to the school and the protests suggest that this has become a debate about how the United States will work with Central and South American militaries after the tumultuous, sometimes violent engagement of the past, when Washington overlooked abuses in the name of fighting leftist insurgencies.
"This place has become an abstraction to the people out there," the school's commandant, Col. Glenn R. Weidner, said on Friday, as the first protesters assembled at the gate.
Mr. Caldera and other officials have strongly defended the school and its mission, which they say is to promote modern, professional militaries that respect democracy and human rights. Mr. Caldera said the changes would enhance that, training Latin American officers to cope with today's problems, including drug trafficking and disasters.
"These are legitimate security interests that they have," Mr. Caldera said in an interview.
He said the school's critics were "willfully ignorant," slurring the reputation of the Army with accusations that the school has encouraged violence against civilians.
"We don't teach American soldiers to violate human rights," Mr. Caldera said, "and we don't teach soldiers of any foreign countries to violate human rights."
The debate has become so polarizing, the oratory so extreme, that it overshadows the teaching that goes on inside the old headquarters of the Army's Infantry School.
Founded in Panama in 1946 and relocated here in 1984, the school still offers purely military courses in skills like basic combat and flying helicopters. But since the end of the cold war, its focus has shifted. Its catalog now includes courses on computers, medical care and more mundane matters of organizing a professional military. Students today spend more time in the classroom than on Fort Benning's firing ranges.
Major Friedrich, whose father was a German U-boat sailor who immigrated to Colombia after World War II, arrived with four captains from his country and another from Mexico for a course on how to plan a defense against a hypothetical invasion. Consulting Army manuals and scrawling with markers on maps and charts tacked to the wall, they plotted each step of the "battle" with occasional nudging from their Army instructor, Maj. Jaime F. Llinet.
Major Friedrich said the course was valuable, exposing him to the latest in American war tactics. "We believe it is the most advanced doctrine in the world," he said.
In its history, the school has trained 61,000 students from 23 countries. Today, only students from Cuba, Nicaragua and Haiti are ineligible. The State Department pays students' expenses and screens applicants for accusations of abuses. The school trains about 800 students a year in courses that last from two weeks to 12 months.
In noncombat classes, up to a third of the students are civilians, like Maria Gonzalez Vila, a lawyer with Uruguay's defense ministry. She just completed a five-week course called Resource Management. Under Mr. Caldera's plan, the school would increase slots for civilians.
In recent years, the Army has also added training on human rights. The busiest lecturer on the staff of 288 is the erudite Army lawyer who teaches international humanitarian law, Maj. Antonio Raimondo.
Even those who come for as little as two weeks receive eight hours of lessons on human rights. The officers who attend the yearlong "Command and General Staff Course" sit through 40 hours. And there is an annual "Human Rights Week," which in February will include a study of the American massacre at My Lai during the Vietnam War and a tour of Andersonville, the Confederate prison camp, whose commander was the only officer hanged for war crimes after the Civil War.
Colonel Weidner said the graduates who went on to commit abuses were the exceptions. By the opponents' own count, he said, only 300 to 500 of the school's 61,000 students have been linked to atrocities, in some cases years after they attended short courses. Those few, he added, are the ones who did not learn the lessons taught here. "We feel betrayed by them," he said.
Critics view the emphasis on human rights, like the proposed changes, as an obfuscation. The school's core is and will be military training, they say, perpetuating the militaries' disproportionate role in Latin American democracies.
"I've heard the reform line before," said Heather A. Dean, a protest organizer. "And while they have made some reforms, the bread and butter is still combat training."
The protests at Fort Benning began 10 years ago with only a handful of opponents, led by Father Bourgeois, a Navy veteran who has been deeply involved in Latin American causes since serving as a missionary in Bolivia in the 1970's. Since then the protests have grown, even as the crimes committed by the school's graduates recede into the past. "It's not for them to say when it is time to forgive," Father Bourgeois said of the Army's insistence that the school has moved on from its cold-war role.
Last year, more than 5,000 people attended the November protest. This year, the Columbus police estimated that there were 8,000, the largest gathering of people in the city since it played host to women's softball in the 1996 Olympics. The protest has become such an event that the city's tourism bureau this year helped arrange hotel accommodations.
To the school's instructors, the placards depicting blood and graves and invariably referring to the "School of the Assassins" have become uncomfortably personal attacks. Several singled out remarks by a leading Congressional critic, Representative Joe Moakley, Democrat of Massachusetts, who last week dismissed the planned changes as "putting perfume on a toxic dump."
"If this is a trash dump, then I'm the trash," said Major Llinet, the instructor. A 19-year veteran, he pointed defiantly, defensively to a patch on his shoulder that he earned for serving in the Persian Gulf war.
"I am not an assassin," he added. "I'm a good old Army guy."
Major Llinet, who was a military trainer in Venezuela, said he agreed with some of the protesters' underlying concerns. He spoke of "social injustice" in Latin America, particularly the economic disparities that leave the poor mired in hardship and the elite, often including the militaries, in control. But he said the school's training served a valuable purpose by promoting regional stability, encouraging democracy and minimizing the possibility of American military intervention, the very thing the protesters oppose most.
"Maybe we don't have to send American forces to Latin America because of the students who came here," Major Llinet said. "If we close the school, maybe we're going to have to go back to the interventionist policies of Teddy Roosevelt, because when there is a security threat in Latin America, you know we're going to be there."

HEADLINE: Microsoft Faces A Class Action On 'Monopoly'

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Lawyers say they will file a class-action suit against Microsoft today on behalf of millions of Californians, in the first of what could become a flood of major lawsuits springing from the Justice Department's antitrust action against the company.
The suit, to be filed by three longtime class-action lawyers, will accuse Microsoft of using its monopoly in operating systems software to overcharge buyers of Windows 95 and Windows 98. The complaint does not estimate the financial impact to Windows users, but the lawyers are seeking triple damages if the suit leads to an eventual finding of financial harm. 
 The suit marks the beginning of what legal experts say could be a wave of private litigation against Microsoft. The prospect could put additional pressure on the company to settle the antitrust case and thereby lessen its financial risks by avoiding a final ruling with its findings of law.
The big software maker's vulnerability to private suits increased sharply earlier this month when Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson issued his findings of fact in the government's antitrust case against Microsoft. Judge Jackson concluded that Microsoft is a monopoly whose anticompetitive acts have stifled innovation and harmed consumers.
Unlike conclusions of law, a judge's findings of fact in a federal antitrust case are not generally considered admissible as evidence in private suits. But Judge Jackson's findings agreed so strongly with the case presented by the Justice Department and 19 states that antitrust experts say his final verdict, expected early next year, will almost surely find that Microsoft is a monopoly that violated the law.
Typically, only a final ruling can be used as evidence in other cases. But a judge's fact findings and final ruling are ordinarily issued at the same time. Judge Jackson took the unusual step of separating his findings of fact from his findings of law, which gave his fact findings greater importance.
Still, legal experts say Microsoft will surely challenge any attempt by class-action lawyers to build a case on the findings of fact alone.
The bigger financial threat to Microsoft may come not from corporate suits, in fact, but from class actions on behalf of the millions of users of the company's industry-standard Windows operating system. Such consumer suits, legal experts say, have the potential to cost Microsoft hundreds of millions of dollars, perhaps even billions, in damage claims.
"This is the start of the race to get to the courthouse," observed Stephen Axinn, a partner in Axinn, Veltrop & Harkrider who is an antitrust litigator. "It could be like the tobacco litigation, in the sense that you have lots of plaintiffs' lawyers in different states sharing information."
Reducing the financial risk from such litigation, according to legal experts, should be a powerful incentive for Microsoft to seek an out-of-court settlement in the government case. The chances of a settlement appeared to increase last Friday when Judge Jackson appointed Richard A. Posner, a federal appeals court judge and leading antitrust scholar, as mediator in settlement talks between Microsoft and the Justice Department and the states.
"The prospect of a flood of private follow-on cases -- with their triple damages in private antitrust cases -- are lawsuits with potentials that Microsoft simply cannot ignore," said Herbert Hovenkamp, a professor at the University of Iowa law school.
Yet, publicly at least, Microsoft insists that its risk from private antitrust suits is exaggerated. "That litigation is something we're prepared to defend and defend aggressively, if necessary," said Tom Burt, a Microsoft lawyer.
In consumer class actions, legal experts say, Microsoft has defenses that will lessen its potential liability and present formidable obstacles for plaintiffs. For example, most computer users do not purchase Windows directly from retail software stores in shrink-wrapped boxes. Generally, the operating system is already loaded on computers when they are purchased. An estimated 90 percent of Windows 98 users got it preloaded on new machines.
The legal significance is that a 1977 Supreme Court ruling -- the Illinois Brick Company v. the State of Illinois -- declared that indirect purchasers of goods could not recover damages in class-action antitrust cases.
Since 1977, however, 18 states including California and New York have passed laws allowing indirect purchasers to qualify for triple damages in antitrust class actions.
And while Judge Jackson's findings do provide a road map for plaintiffs' lawyers, there remains a lot to prove in court. Judge Jackson, for example, found that Microsoft has a monopoly, but he did not say precisely when it achieved monopoly status. He found consumers were harmed by Microsoft, but the class-action lawyers must put a figure on how much users were overcharged.
"The econometrics on damages will be very complex," Mr. Axinn said. "There's no question that Microsoft has some good cards to play on defense."
Still, Judge Jackson provided class-action lawyers with some tantalizing details. In asserting that consumers may have paid more for Windows than they would have in a competitive market, he cited a Microsoft study suggesting possible prices of $49 and $89 for the retail upgrade to Windows 98. Microsoft chose to charge $89, which the study identified as the "revenue maximizing" price.
"That portion of the judge's findings was an invitation to a class-action lawsuit," said Robert Litan, a former senior official in the Justice Department's antitrust division who is now at the Brookings Institution.
Microsoft replies that the November 1997 study was garden-variety pricing analysis. Trying to estimate an optimal, or revenue maximizing, price is something that every consumer product company routinely does for each of its offerings.
The judge's discussion of the Microsoft pricing study, according to Terry Gross of Gross & Belsky in San Francisco, is "a clear marker." But, he said, it is mainly the overall drift of Judge Jackson's findings that provides a solid starting point for the class-action suit he and his colleagues are filing.
"Throughout the judge's findings," Mr. Gross said, "he makes it clear that all Windows users were harmed by paying too high a price for Windows."
The class action, which the lawyers plan to file in California Superior Court in San Francisco today, does not specify the number of members in the class of both individual and corporate users of Windows. But Mr. Gross estimated that number in California as "at least 10 million," and he said the suit covers Windows users since the introduction of Windows 95. The complaint does not estimate the financial damage to Windows users in California.
Earlier this month, a small New York advertising company that purchased Windows, Seastrom Associates Ltd., sued Microsoft and sought class-action status to represent thousands of similar corporate customers in New York State.
But to take on Microsoft in a class action, legal experts say, will require experience, skill and resources. They note that the three lawyers behind the California suit -- Mr. Gross, Daniel J. Mogin of San Diego, and Francis O. Scarpulla of San Francisco -- are state class-action lawyers who have worked for two decades on antitrust cases involving products ranging from snack foods to tires.
"There is a tremendous amount of work that needs to be done," Mr. Mogin said. "We have to quantify and prove actual damages that consumers suffered."
The lawyers say they will continue their litigation even if the federal case is settled out of court. Judge Jackson's findings of fact alone, they insist, ease the way for suits like theirs.
"A settlement in the government's case wouldn't make our case go away," Mr. Gross said. "We still have these findings that Microsoft is a monopoly that abused its power by overcharging consumers."

LENGTH: 2336 words

HEADLINE: Neighbors Give Central Park a Wealthy Glow

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

 BODY:
By passing the hat among its neighbors, who happen to be America's most densely packed bunch of rich people, Central Park has harvested the largest haul of private dollars ever raised for a public park.
As is obvious to the 20 million people who enter the park every year, this bumper crop of philanthropy, $233 million so far, has done a world of good. The graffiti-smeared ruin that was an international embarrassment two decades ago has been reborn as a meticulously restored greensward where bronze-preservation specialists each year polish and wax all 50 of the park's statues. 
 What is far less obvious is how this happened.
To exploit the giving habits of New York's elite, the park reinvented itself as an elite cultural charity. It has become a player in the most exclusive social ritual in town, shrewdly capitalizing on unwritten rules about how the rich must give to one another's pet causes or face social ostracism.
Less obvious still is the profound effect that Central Park has had on other urban parks not encircled by multimillionaires. Park advocates across New York admit they resent Central Park's phenomenal success, but nevertheless copy its management and fund-raising methods.
"There is something healthy even in envy," said Elizabeth Barlow Rogers, who created the Central Park Conservancy 20 years ago and ran it for 16 years.
The conservancy has become the dominant model, in New York and across the country, for groups trying to revive crumbling urban parks, said Chris Walker, director of community and economic development for the Urban Institute in Washington.
"It is almost impossible to discuss park restoration in the United States without discussing Central Park," he said.
People who live near some of New York City's most troubled parks are imitating the conservancy. Around Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem, neighbors are raising money from local businesses, hospitals and developers. They have recruited volunteers to clean up the park and plant flowers. A gardener trained in Central Park will soon begin working in their park, his salary paid by a private grant.
Those who live near Marcus Garvey say they are painfully aware of the demographic chasm that separates them from the people who live around Central Park. Their October fund-raising dinner raised $7,000. The Central Park Conservancy's Halloween ball raised $805,000.
"We do not have much money, but we are getting organized as a pressure group," said Helen Murray, a retired nurse who lives in a brownstone next to the park. "Central Park is a model that gives us a very high standard to work for."
Neither imitation nor envy, though, can conjure up the fuel that powers Central Park: private money donated in huge chunks. The rebirth of the park, as much as anything, is a story about why the wealthy give in New York.
As major park donors themselves explain, the rich tend to give to what they know and to what gives them personal satisfaction. It is no accident that many of the park's largest benefactors can monitor the fruit of their giving from their apartment windows.
Eighty percent of the nearly quarter-billion dollars that has been donated to the park in the last two decades has come from about 20 percent of the conservancy's donors, according to conservancy officials, who said that hundreds of the largest donors live within a block of the park.
"The park is visible, you can touch it, you can partake of it, you can brag about it, you can see the difference your money makes," said Michael R. Bloomberg, founder of Bloomberg Financial Markets. He is a member of the conservancy's board and a major donor, and lives half a block from the park.
Richard Gilder, a stockbroker who grew up playing in Central Park and now lives beside it on Fifth Avenue, has given the park $17 million, which is believed to be the largest gift from any individual to any municipal park.
"It is a natural for people who live near the park," Mr. Gilder said. "It is upbeat. There are so few things you can give money to that aren't in desperate shape."
Social considerations also figure strongly for donors. Although the conservancy is a relative arriviste among the city's charities, it has staked out a status niche that puts it roughly on a par with the Museum of Modern Art or Carnegie Hall, which is to say only slightly less chic than the Metropolitan Museum of Art, several philanthropists said.
The rich say they give to elite charities to advance their social standing, make business contacts and get invitations to charity benefits, according to research done by Francie Ostrower, an associate professor of sociology at Harvard who interviewed 88 New York philanthropists in the 1990's.
The Central Park Conservancy has used its social cachet to leverage donations, said Timothy M. Thompkins, director of Partnership for Parks, which raises money for city parks other than Central Park.
"There is a bit of a herd mentality," he said.
About 1,200 members of that herd gather each spring for Central Park's premier social and fund-raising event: a luncheon in the Conservatory Garden sponsored by the conservancy's women's committee.
"It is really the envy of the world," said Phyllis Cerf Wagner, a founding member of the women's committee, which itself has raised $30 million. "Last year we raised $2 million."
Part of the reason for the luncheon's success is its timing.
"It is in May," Mrs. Wagner said. "Everyone has new spring clothes. They have new hats."
Another reason is Mrs. Wagner herself. As the widow of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner and of Bennett Cerf, the co-founder of Random House, she has friends among the political, publishing and philanthropic elite.
"You don't say no to Phyllis Wagner and end up with that many teeth to talk about it," Mr. Gilder said fondly.
Mrs. Wagner invented the park's adopt-a-bench program, which has led to the endowment of 600 park benches, at $5,000 for a standard bench and $25,000 for a rustic handmade model. Four hundred trees also have been endowed, at $1,000 for a sapling and $25,000 for a "historic tree."
"Pretty soon we will be down to blades of grass," Mrs. Wagner said.
Things were different in the late 1970's, when Central Park was "a disaster zone," in the words of Gordon Davis, then commissioner of parks. The city's fiscal crisis had cut spending on parks by nearly two-thirds, and Central Park had lost about half its work force. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan called Commissioner Davis, told him that the park was a "national disgrace" and threatened a federal takeover.
Casting about for a way to rescue the park, Mr. Davis concluded that the only way to revive it was to find one person to run it. He settled on Elizabeth Barlow Rogers, who had written a book on Frederick Law Olmsted, the principal designer of Central Park.
"When I named Betsy administrator of Central Park, she had no money and no power," Mr. Davis said.
She did, however, have a simple and, as it turned out, profoundly powerful idea. She decided the park should be a cultural institution, rather like the Metropolitan Museum. "The trees and the monuments and the gardens are our collection," she said.
It was an easy sell. The park was bordered by many thousands of the country's richest people, many of whom had strong emotional and financial reasons for resuscitating it. Dr. Ostrower's research found that New York's philanthropic elite gave most of its money to colleges and arts institutions. "With striking frequency, these gifts went to precisely the kinds of educational and cultural organizations that are used by, and have prestige among, the elites," Dr. Ostrower wrote in "Why the Wealthy Give: The Culture of Elite Philanthropy" (Princeton University Press, 1995).
A stumbling block for the conservancy, though, was getting to corporate executives. The park needed a rainmaker, someone whose calls would always be returned. Such a man, William S. Beinecke, happened to live in a penthouse apartment on 79th Street between Madison and Fifth Avenues, with a splendid view of the park.
Mr. Beinecke, who had just retired as chairman and chief executive at Sperry & Hutchinson Company, remembers he was "shocked" by the park's appearance and agreed to be the conservancy's first board chairman.
His C.E.O. credentials worked like a passkey, Mr. Beinecke recalled, and he had no trouble gaining access to top executives at corporations like Morgan Stanley and American Express. He found that the closer executives lived to Central Park, the more closely they listened.
"I didn't make a pitch for money," said Mr. Beinecke, who merely recruited members for the conservancy's board. But board members were later urged to give to the park and to pressure their peers to do likewise.
The philanthropic money machine shifted into high gear in the mid-1980's when the conservancy recruited Henry R. Kravis, the billionaire leveraged-buyout specialist. He was the principal mover as the conservancy raked in $65 million during the 1980's.
Requests for money from Mr. Kravis, who has given tens of millions of dollars to New York charities, could not be ignored, several donors said.
"If he helps your charity, then you must help his," said Howard J. Rubenstein, a multimillionaire who heads a public relations firm, serves on the conservancy board and lives on Fifth Avenue. "In the upper echelons of millionaire's row, it is almost like a trade."
The conservancy's Halloween ball was held this year in a vast tent in Central Park and attended by 615 masked and costumed revelers. Among them was Ian Smith, the new chairman of the conservancy board and chief executive of Marsh & McClennan Companies.
Before dinner, as guests watched young actors sheathed in black fabrics perform as creatures of the night, Mr. Smith explained that "a lot of the people who care about Central Park have unlimited ambition for it. They would like to see everything perfect."
The morning after the party that raised $805,000, Elizabeth Cook, the executive director of the Park Council, a 90-year-old nonprofit that is critical of the city's reliance on private money for the parks, said that she was impressed that the conservancy had raised so much money but was concerned that all of it went to just one park.
"I wish that the wealthy who give so generously to Central Park would give equally to the rest of the park system," said Ms. Cook, who did not attend the party. "We are concerned that this is creating a two-tiered park system in New York City; one rich, one not. The city's growing dependence on private money makes it very difficult for communities that don't have strong leadership to compete and raise private funds for their parks."
Ms. Cook also complained about the citywide implications of the management contract that the conservancy signed last year with the city. The contract guarantees that the city will provide $1 million a year for Central Park, if the conservancy raises $5 million. If it raises more, the city must match half, up to a maximum city contribution of $2 million a year.
"It gives Central Park protection against city budget cuts; as long as the conservancy meets its fund-raising obligations under the contract, it is protected from reductions in city support," she said. "Other parks are not similarly protected."
City parks officials heatedly dismiss Ms. Cook's criticism, saying the city can cancel the contract whenever it wants. They also say Central Park is a model of professional management that other parks can imitate.
"A rising tide lifts all boats," said Henry J. Stern, the parks commissioner. "If one park in New York City is world class, it creates pressure for other parks to improve their standards."
Other New York parks are improving in part because of the Central Park model, but they are limited by the fact that they are not surrounded by so many rich people. The Prospect Park Alliance in Brooklyn raises about $2 million a year from private donors. Still, it lags far behind the Central Park Conservancy, which raises about $15 million a year.
"There is resentment," said a parks department official at Prospect Park who did not want to be identified by name. "It is mostly about the rich people in Manhattan and how they can afford to make their park beautiful, and why won't the city put in the money to make our park nice, too."
The city's record of support this decade for parks other than Central Park is mixed.
It has cut the number of park employees by more than half, from 4,507 in 1990 to 2,190 this year. Central Park has been relatively insulated from the city cuts because the conservancy pays about 80 percent of the park's employees.
Across the city, though, the impact of these cuts has been largely mitigated by the assignment of nearly 5,000 workfare employees to work in parks. There is widespread agreement that the parks are cleaner and in better repair than they have been in decades.
As for Central Park itself, a few restive members on the board of the conservancy believe that since the park is almost completely refurbished, the conservancy should take its act on the road.
"We should have a loftier goal for ourselves," said Mr. Gilder, who has been lobbying the conservancy board to shift some of its expertise and fund-raising ability to Morningside Park in Harlem.
The idea of spreading the wealth, however, is not yet popular among most conservancy donors, who as a rule do not give to charities that support other city parks.
Besides, with Central Park having been elevated to such a rarefied standard, donors are worried about the soaring cost of maintenance. Next year, the cost of the nearly complete restoration work at the North Meadow will by itself add $450,000 to the conservancy's annual budget.
"How are we going to meet our ongoing costs?" asked Karen Putnam, the conservancy's president. "We are not to the point where we can put our feet on the desk and take on another park. We have our hands full."
