HEADLINE: A Homeless Man Challenges New York City Crackdowns

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Even before New York's police commissioner pledged last week to arrest homeless people who persist in sleeping on sidewalks, a homeless Army veteran who has improvised a bed on the city's streets for a decade was quietly trying to stop him through the courts.
In some ways the veteran, Augustine Betancourt, 33, is an unlikely legal adversary. But nobody knows better that the announced police tactic is not new. Nobody more clearly illustrates its mixed results. 
 Almost three years ago, on the cold night of Feb. 27, 1997, Mr. Betancourt tucked himself into cardboard and fell asleep on a bench in a small park across the street from the Criminal Courts building in Lower Manhattan. About 1:30 a.m., he was awakened by two police officers. And for the first time in his life, he was arrested.
"Direct order from Giuliani," an officer told Mr. Betancourt before taking him to jail, according to court affidavits. "You're not supposed to be sleeping here."
Mr. Betancourt, a slight, soft-spoken man who has shunned most social interaction since his honorable discharge in 1987, was strip-searched, held for 27 hours and handed a summons. The ticket, on an obscure sanitation code violation -- one of several ordinances typically used by the police to arrest or ticket the homeless -- turned out to be invalid.
But in Betancourt v. Giuliani, a little-noticed 1997 federal class-action lawsuit now nearing a conclusion, Mr. Betancourt and the lawyer he found in a soup kitchen's legal clinic have mounted a small but significant challenge to police crackdowns on the homeless.
The lawsuit contends that he and all 25 others in the park area the same night were falsely arrested in a police sweep for violating a sanitation ordinance that was impermissibly vague, and only a pretext for punishing the homeless. It asks that the police be barred from using the ordinance as a tool for making targets of the homeless.
The city argues that the arrests were legitimate and necessary to reclaim the area near the Criminal Courts building from debris left by homeless people who had rejected earlier offers of shelter.
Mr. Betancourt is still homeless. But now he sleeps in an alley not far from the park, hidden in a cardboard box. And since he was dropped from the welfare rolls three years ago for failing to appear for a work assignment, he will not qualify for a shelter bed if Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani succeeds in his other effort to tackle homelessness: enforcing state regulations that make work and all other welfare rules conditions of shelter.
"The years I spent out in the street, people watch me collect cans or kids laugh when they see me at night getting into a cardboard box, I've never felt insulted or less than human," Mr. Betancourt, who won a merit award as a soldier, said in a deposition. "But incarcerated, I felt deprived of humanity."
Even if it was a mistake to arrest Mr. Betancourt under a sanitation statute that makes it unlawful to leave "any box, barrel, bale of merchandise or other movable property" in a public place -- the district attorney declined to prosecute the case -- the city contends that he still could have been legitimately arrested for other reasons.
A 1996 police manual for carrying out such sweeps, "Quality of Life Enforcement Options: A Police Reference Guide," lists 35 offenses that can prompt an arrest, including camping in the park without a permit and being present after the official 1 a.m. closing time.
Last week, after a Midtown office worker was left in critical condition by a random attack that may have been committed by a homeless man, Mayor Giuliani promised to renew such crackdowns. He dismissed any civil liberties opposition to his plan as romanticism that did the homeless no favors.
"Streets do not exist in civilized societies for the purpose of people sleeping there," the mayor said. "Bedrooms are for sleeping."
Police Commissioner Howard Safir seconded his remarks, declaring that if homeless people sleeping on the sidewalks refuse help from the police and then "don't obey, we're going to arrest them."
For city lawyers defending against the Betancourt suit, the remarks came at an awkward moment. Mr. Betancourt's lawyer Doug Lasdon, who directs the nonprofit Urban Justice Center, with lawyers at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison who are donating their time, have argued that the Giuliani administration has transformed administrative ordinances into anti-vagrancy laws in a bid to outlaw homelessness.
The city has responded in legal papers that there is no police policy aimed at the homeless. In September 1997, the city successfully opposed the plaintiffs' demand for a preliminary injunction that would have temporarily barred such enforcement of the sanitation ordinance, arguing in part that Mr. Betancourt and his fellows had not established that they were at risk of being arrested again.
Last week, the plaintiffs asked the court to bar the city immediately from such enforcement of the ordinance. Judge John S. Martin of Federal District Court in Manhattan could rule early next year.
Police depositions in the case open a rare window on the broad discretion an ordinance can afford. One officer testified that a person sitting on a park bench with a coat around the shoulders would be in violation of the section, but would not be in violation if the coat were zipped.
Another testified that a person sitting beside a newspaper that was "touching their body" would not violate the code, but the person could be arrested if the same newspaper was "one inch away."
Throughout the city's history, officials have periodically enforced vagrancy laws that blurred the line between poverty and criminality. In "Gotham: A History of New York City to 1898" (Oxford University Press, 1999), Mike Wallace and Edwin G. Burrows describe how early in the 19th century, vagrancy laws were used for street roundups "at the behest of merchants and shopkeepers determined to improve New York's business climate by scouring away peddlers, scavengers, beggars and potential criminals."
In the 1870's and again in the 1890's, an increase in street begging and pauperism that historians attribute to economic dislocations led reformers to discontinue or tighten municipal poor relief, and to step up enforcement of vagrancy statutes, arresting and locking up "tramps" and sending them to workhouses.
A series of high court rulings from the 1950's through the 1970's invalidated the old vagrancy laws. In a recent case, in 1995, the United States District court in Manhattan ruled that people arrested or ejected from Pennsylvania Station by the Amtrak police for "hanging out" there had been deprived of their constitutional rights.
Like people in cities around the country, many New Yorkers went from compassion to exasperation about the homeless in the 1980's. Despite the city's uniquely far-reaching right to shelter, established by advocates through court rulings in 1981, there seemed to be disheveled figures huddling on every Manhattan sidewalk grate in 1987, when Mr. Betancourt returned to New York after three years in the Army.
He soon stopped contact with his elderly immigrant parents, who were unaware, he said, of the deep depression and anxiety attacks that had overwhelmed him in adolescence. His jobs as kitchen helper or stock clerk grew scarcer after the stock market crash, and in 1988 he lost his room in a cheap hotel.
Turning to the city's shelter system, he was placed in the Franklin Armory in the Bronx, where about 600 men, many mentally ill or addicted to drugs, slept on a drill floor. He found the street less frightening. Someone helped him obtain public assistance in 1992, about $100 every two weeks. But he was one of thousands dropped from the rolls when the city instituted a strict workfare requirement in August 1996.
In a sense, Mr. Betancourt did become more self-reliant, though not as city welfare officials had envisioned: he dug himself deeper into a solitary groove of life bound by the schedules of soup kitchens and shower programs, coping with his constant anxiety by killing time in libraries and bookstores, paring down his needs to what would fit in a small book bag, and hunting nightly for cardboard to make his bed.
"It's the people that you don't see that are actually most vulnerable to these anti-homeless laws and ordinances, because they're most reluctant to seek help," Mr. Betancourt, who does not smoke or drink, said in a recent interview, unobtrusive in his plain black baseball cap, white T-shirt, checked shirt and khakis.
The mayor's first round of sweeps in 1996 were welcomed by many New Yorkers. But though they broke up major encampments of homeless people and offered services, their limitations quickly became apparent. In monthly spread sheets laid out by location, internal reports by the Department of Homeless Services reflect that homeless people routed from one place showed up somewhere else, or ebbed back to the old spot over time.
Issued summonses, many homeless people failed to show up in court, resulting in bench warrants later used to arrest them. Many spent time in jail on Rikers Island, where mental health unit beds cost $91,000 a year, compared with $20,000 for a city shelter bed and $12,000 for the supervised apartments that have been the greatest success for the mentally ill homeless, but remain in short supply. Annual admissions at the jail reached an all-time high of 133,300 in 1997, up from 106,000 in 1993. Admissions are now about 127,000 a year.
The Franklin Avenue shelter that frightened away Mr. Betancourt in 1988 was cut to 200 beds through lawsuits brought by advocates for the homeless. More than 70 percent of the shelter system is now run by private nonprofit agencies.
But through shelter regulations Mr. Giuliani himself sought from the state, the legal right to shelter underpinning this improved system is now under challenge as never before.
On a recent Friday night, no one was sleeping in the park where Mr. Betancourt was arrested. But about 11 p.m., homeless people began slipping out from the chilly shadows of the surrounding streets one by one, until more than a dozen stood in the dim light of a street lamp as a small yellow truck pulled up.
Soon a small caravan of volunteers from a New Jersey group called Bridges was distributing hot soup, toiletries and blankets to the men. Mr. Betancourt withdrew to his cardboard box, set in the shadows between lofts and sweatshops. When he was most fearful of being arrested again, he said, he never slept in the same place twice. He sought out recessed crannies in the financial district and moved on before the rumble of garbage trucks at dawn.
"My motivation in this lawsuit doesn't have anything to do with money or some kind of vendetta against the city,' he said. "My motivation is to avoid any further disruption and living like a fugitive."

HEADLINE: Town With Fabled Past Facing Uncertain Future

BYLINE: By EMILY YELLIN 

DATELINE: PRINCEVILLE, N.C.

 BODY:
When a group of newly freed slaves here wanted to form a community of their own just after the Civil War, they had to take whatever land they could get. In 1865, that was a snake-infested, mosquito-ridden swamp in a flood plain along the southern side of the Tar River in eastern North Carolina. It was land that the white people in nearby Tarboro, on the northern side of the river, did not want.
Twenty years later, those former slaves had built a town so viable that they petitioned the state to recognize it as a legal entity. In 1885, Princeville became the first town in the United States to be chartered and governed solely by blacks. 
 Now the more than 2,000 residents of Princeville, many of whom are direct descendants of its founders, face a dilemma more extreme than any other this town has ever faced.
Their storied community was washed away in September by the worst flooding in North Carolina's history, and they must choose whether to return and rebuild or abandon forever the place where their ancestors first experienced full United States citizenship. The impending decision has those who would accept a federal buyout of the town at odds with the many who believe that doing so would betray the cherished legacy of their forebears.
"The challenge we are facing in Princeville," said Representative Eva Clayton, the Democrat whose district includes the town, "is how to keep its legacy and make it viable in the future."
A handful of places similarly devastated by floods in recent years have accepted government buyouts of all or part of their towns. Grand Forks, N.D., was one, along with Valmeyer, Ill., and Kinston, N.C. Federal Emergency Management Agency officials have already received word from at least 45 city or county governments affected by the floods in eastern North Carolina that they intend to apply for federal buyouts.
In all, officials estimate, the flooding caused $1.2 billion worth of structural damage across the state. Of the 6,000 buildings that the federal agency estimates were damaged beyond repair statewide, about 600 are in Princeville.
Last Friday, Princeville officials reported that only 92 people had signed up for the buyout so far. The town has given its residents, about 40 of whom are white, a Dec. 16 deadline to submit applications. After that, city leaders will decide whether there is enough interest to apply for the buyout. The town government must make a formal application before any individual applications are considered. If the town decides against a buyout, no residents will be eligible.
For Glennie Matthewson II, 55, a lawyer and former Princeville mayor, leaving is not an option. His great-grandmother was a slave and one of the first residents of Princeville.
"When our ancestors built this town, they were seen as uppity blacks, with the audacity to talk about incorporating their own town," Mr. Matthewson said. "That is a hell of a legacy. The deeper the roots the harder the fight, and the more resistance you're going to get to taking the town from us."
The mayor of Princeville, Delia Perkins, 57, lost her home in the flood, but she, too, remains firm about returning. She works full time as a teacher's assistant in the Edgecombe County School system and receives $250 a month to serve as mayor.
"If I had my druthers," she said, "I would have said from Day 1 that we will rebuild, no doubt about it." But she added that she thought the town government must consider all its options.
Some question the wisdom of rebuilding. Marcia Wheeler, 43, a mother of two, says she has no plans to return -- ever. "I wouldn't want to go through this again," she said.
Under the buyout, the Federal Emergency Management Agency would buy property for what appraisers estimate was the market value the day before the flood. The buildings would be removed and the open space deeded back to the town, but it could never be built on again.
If the town decides to rebuild, money from a federal buyout will not be available and the town will seek money from other government agencies and private sources. The mayor estimates the cost of rebuilding to be at least $80 million. Central to the effort would be reconstruction of a dike that controls the Tar River. That cost is estimated at $300,000 and would be paid for by the United States Army Corps of Engineers.
The levee was built in 1965, a century after the area was settled. It was designed to protect the town against the kind of flood estimated to happen only every 300 years. That levee afforded enough protection to negate the flood-plain status of the town in official terms. And it is what allows the town even to consider the option of returning to the same site.
Todd Davison, Southeastern mitigation director of the emergency management agency, noted that the United States Geological Survey had issued a report this month saying the recent flood was well in excess of a 500-year event.
"That is a biblical kind of flood," Mr. Davison said. "The risk is so remote that we don't regulate against it, just as we don't protect against meteors."
The Tar River began its rampage in Princeville on Sept. 16, as a result of the 20 inches of rain dumped on the state by Hurricane Floyd. When it spilled over the dike, it had reached 48.5 feet above sea level. Early the next morning the town was evacuated. The river crested at 53 feet above sea level, and the town remained under about 14 feet of water for several weeks.
When residents were allowed to return, they were shocked to see houses that had floated off their foundations and landed on top of cars. Precious family photographs, keepsakes and heirlooms were lost. Many houses had been condemned. More than 200 coffins dislodged from the town cemetery were found floating around the town. None of the original slaves' graves were disturbed -- perhaps because they had been dug deeper than more recent graves.
And even today, two months after the deluge, the damage is strikingly evident in the deserted town. Mud-caked clothes hang from trees. The water has gone and most of the facades of houses are still intact, but their insides have been stripped bare to remove destroyed furniture and rotted drywall.
That is the case at Linda Whitest's home on Walston Street in the heart of Princeville. Her year-old house was destroyed by flood waters. Across the street, her grandmother's house, where Ms. Whitest, 49, grew up, was destroyed. Next door to her grandmother's house, her mother's house was also ruined. The homes are all situated on land handed down from Ms. Whitest's great-grandfather, Frank Walston, a son of slaves and the man for whom the street was named.
"A month ago I said there is no way I'm going back, I was so devastated," Ms. Whitest said. "But then I thought about it, and I said, why should I give up what my ancestors had worked so hard to leave us? It would be like Princeville never existed, like it had just been erased away."
Mr. Matthewson said moving the town even a few blocks away was unacceptable to most residents.
"My ancestors' energies and efforts and resources went into that specific property in Princeville," he said. "Those are the streets I played in, the trees I climbed. You take the town and move it anywhere else, then you've severed me from my actual roots."
Soon after the flooding, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and the Rev. Al Sharpton both visited the town, as did President Clinton.
"If this was Valley Forge," Mr. Sharpton said, "imagine what America would be doing. We preach black pride. Here's an example of a city that has faced a major disaster. I think it's incumbent upon black America to use its economic and political resources to try to restore that city."
Along with other flood victims, the displaced residents of Princeville are living either with friends and relatives or in the temporary trailer park set up by the emergency management agency in nearby Rocky Mount. The trailer park, just around the corner from a women's prison, is officially named New Life Fountain Park. Residents call it FEMA City.
Lee Black, 35, a construction worker, has been living at the temporary site since it was opened two months ago. He said he planned to return to the Princeville property passed down to him by his ancestors.
"My people took that swampland and made a town out of it," Mr. Black said. "It would make us look real bad to let it go now."

HEADLINE: Israel's Leader Highly Praises Hillary Clinton

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel offered an unprompted defense of Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday, telling a group of American Jewish leaders in New York that her recent trip to the Middle East had been "highly successful" and had advanced the peace process.
Mrs. Clinton had been criticized by some Jewish groups in the United States for her handling of the trip, particularly for sitting silently during a visit to the West Bank while Suha Arafat, the wife of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, accused Israel of using toxic gas in the region. 
 Mr. Barak's comments came as he answered questions after a speech at the Helmsley Park Lane Hotel to an audience at the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, the largest umbrella organization of American Jewish groups. Mr. Barak volunteered that he had read "a lot of criticism" about Mrs. Clinton in the aftermath of her visit to the West Bank. He wanted to make clear, he said, that her trip to the Middle East was "a highly successful, highly moving visit."
"I believe the first lady's visit to Israel contributed to the peace process in spite of this incident," he said, and added, "May I tell you frankly as prime minister of Israel that myself and all my successors will always wish to have two such friends as the Clintons in the White House."
Mrs. Clinton, who has sometimes had disputes with American Jewish voters over her views, was roundly criticized by some Jewish groups in America for not immediately denouncing Mrs. Arafat's remarks about poison gas. The first lady did so later, but her delayed reaction prompted criticism, and a Republican Jewish group is planning to begin running a television advertisement this week criticizing Mrs. Clinton over the visit.
While Mr. Barak's statement of support yesterday was not surprising -- he has close ties to the Clintons and has shared campaign consultants, including James Carville, with them -- it came at an important period for Mrs. Clinton in her expected race for United States Senate against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the prospective Republican candidate, who has enjoyed popularity among Jewish voters.
Howard Wolfson, the spokesman for Mrs. Clinton's exploratory Senate campaign committee, said yesterday that he was gratified by Mr. Barak's statement. "We appreciate the prime minister's comments," he said. "It speaks volumes about the first lady's commitment to a safe and secure Israel."
Bruce Teitelbaum, the director of the mayor's Senate exploratory committee, declined last night to comment on Mr. Barak's remarks.
Mr. Barak is popular among New York Jews, and his speech, the second to Jewish leaders this weekend, was warmly received. As expected, he extensively discussed the peace process, reiterating his commitment to moving forward with negotiating a "final status" agreement with Israel's neighbors.
"Everything must be put on the table," he said. "Settlements, borders, refugees, the nature of the Palestinian entity, economic relations, security relations, everything."
But he said such an agreement could not be founded on documents alone, but "should be based on the military might of the Israeli Defense Force, our strategic capability, a unique alliance with the United States and a growing economy."
Apparently in an effort to broaden the dialogue with American Jews beyond the peace process, Mr. Barak dwelt at length on the need to strengthen Israel's economy, and on the country's socioeconomic stresses. Recent statistics revealed record unemployment in Israel, and a gap between the rich and poor second only to that in the United States in the developed world.
Noting that Israel had just been through a deep recession, Mr. Barak said that it needed to develop its high-technology sector to increase jobs. The country, he said, had to pursue both deregulation and privatization to allow economic growth and had to deal with "very urgent" social needs.
Mr. Barak also paid a visit to Cardinal John O'Connor at his residence yesterday afternoon, traveling eight blocks down Fifth Avenue in a security-laden motorcade that attracted several hundred onlookers.
The two met for about 45 minutes at the prime minister's request, according to a spokesman for the archdiocese, who declined to discuss their conversation. An Israeli official said the cardinal expressed support for the peace process, and that the two discussed the pope's planned visit to the Middle East next spring. The official said that a dispute in Nazareth, where the Israeli government recently gave permission to Muslim leaders to build a mosque next to the city's main Roman Catholic shrine, did not come up explicitly, but that the two did discuss ways to "minimize tensions."
The Prime Minister met with Gov. George E. Pataki as well, following on a meeting he had with Mayor Giuliani on his last trip to New York.
Mr. Pataki said they discussed the peace process and economic ties between New York and Israel. But if Mr. Barak began the day by defending Hillary Clinton, Mr. Pataki ended it by attacking her. "Someone who has never lived here, never worked here, looking to represent us -- it's very difficult," he said. "I feel very optimistic about the mayor's prospects."

HEADLINE: A Labor Shortage?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Apparently the Federal Reserve has raised interest rates out of concern "that the nation is literally running out of workers and that, as it does so, wages and then prices will inevitably be pushed higher, endangering an economic expansion" (Business Day, Nov. 17). 
 I don't get it: There are millions of qualified people all over the world who would be glad to immigrate to the United States and relieve the labor shortage. Rather than recklessly jeopardizing the economy's momentum and healthy business climate by raising interest rates, why not encourage the Clinton administration and Congress to take a positive approach and direct the Immigration and Naturalization Service to drastically raise its immigration quotas instead? That would help both the United States and ambitious potential immigrants who happen to live in countries with high unemployment.
 
PAUL FEEHAN
Columbus, Ohio, Nov. 17, 1999

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices surged 3.6 percent, to $27 a barrel, the highest since the Persian Gulf war, after reports that Iraq halted oil shipments and rejected a United Nations plan to extend an export agreement for two weeks.
Iraq, which normally exports about 3 percent of the world's oil, is seeking an end to economic sanctions, including United Nations control over its oil exports. The United Nations plan to extend the program temporarily came after Russia and the United States were unable to agree on terms of a new six-month plan. 
 "Thirty-dollar oil looks real if this suspension continues," said Nauman Barakat, vice president for global energy trading at ABN Amro Inc. in New York. He added that Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, probably is not "going to agree to the extension of the present oil-for-food sales without any changes, so my assumption is that the suspension is going to be here for a while."
Crude oil for January delivery rose 93 cents, to $27.07 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the highest price since January 1991.
Baghdad has halted exports from its pipeline through Turkey and is expected to complete tanker loadings at its own port tomorrow, after refusing over the weekend to sign the two-week extension, according to the United Nations.
Iraqi oil exports were put under an international embargo after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990. The United Nations, since late 1996, has allowed Iraq to export limited amounts of oil to buy food and medical supplies, and to pay war reparations.
Amer Mohammed Rasheed, Iraq's oil minister, said the extension "is absolutely meaningless, since nothing can be done in a period of two weeks, hence Iraq will not deal with this resolution," the official Iraqi News Agency reported.
The current six-month round of the United Nations-sponsored program was to have expired last Saturday, but was extended Friday for two weeks to allow the Security Council more time to discuss its renewal and longer-term policy regarding sanctions and weapons inspections.
Oil prices rallied this year after members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and several other producers cut world supply by about 7 percent from February 1998 levels in a bid to eliminate a glut and raise prices.
An extended halt in Iraqi exports would also come amid rising demand for winter fuel in the Northern hemisphere and with inventories of crude oil in the United States near their lowest level in two years.

HEADLINE: Stari Trg Journal;
A Battered Kosovo Village the West Forgot to Help

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: STARI TRG, Kosovo

 BODY:
Bairam Bala stood on the concrete foundations of what was once his house, surrounded by ragged edges of shelled and collapsed walls, near the burned and rusted remnants of his belongings gathered neatly in a pile, for some Westerner, who will never come, to inventory and make good his losses.
Myftar Haxha has his own wretched pile of post-tragedy trash, and so does Behram Mernica. They walk forlornly around the twisted remains of washing machines and ovens, television sets and tool kits, lamps and bedsprings, as Kosovo's winter closes in. 
They've lost everything, they say, and that is indisputable. Their ultimately victorious fight with the Serbs here in this utterly devastated little village began in the summer and autumn of 1998 when the Serbs began to attack the Kosovo Liberation Army in earnest.
This Albanian village -- the name means "old market" -- overlooks part of the Trepca mines, one of the few economically important sites in Kosovo. So it became strategic territory, and it was badly shelled.
What survived the fighting in 1998 was obliterated last April, after another Serbian offensive prompted a 78-day bombing war from NATO on behalf of Kosovo's ethnic Albanians. These men and their families fled to the surrounding hills -- only a few left Kosovo -- and returned in July to this blasted landscape, where their fathers had lived before them.
President Clinton is to visit Kosovo on Nov. 23 to celebrate Thanksgiving with American soldiers at their huge, fortified base at Camp Bondsteel. But having won the war to save people like those in Stari Trg, the West is moving slowly to consolidate the peace and to help them rebuild their lives.
"We lost everything and we have nowhere else to go," said Mr. Haxha, rubbing his long stubble on a face that looks 70, not 58. "Look down there," he said pointing at a shattered wall marked by smoke. "This was my land and my house. I had a good house. I had 100,000 marks invested here," some $55,500 at today's exchange rate.
There were 30 houses here; all of them are destroyed. Only five families live here now, Mr. Bala said. The rest, for the moment, are scattered in other villages, or they are imprisoned or dead. Of the approximately 250 people who lived here two years ago, at least 12 have been killed, Mr. Bala said, and 2 were arrested by the Serbian forces and have not returned.
In July, aid workers from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees came by and provided a few nice tents, about 13 feet square, to keep off the rain, and people moved in. But the tents cannot be heated.
And now it is too cold, and there has been no other visitor to provide the single warm room that the world has promised them, let alone a winterized tent, so they have gone to squat in an office building across the way. Now the Serbs don't frighten them so much, Mr. Bala said, as the thought of eviction.
"I'd be happier here in a better tent than in the office," Mr. Bala said. "I'm afraid every day they will throw us out. It is an official place. It's not for family living -- it's all concrete."
He, like the others, says he will rebuild here, nowhere else, and would have liked to have started by now. "If those foreign organizations had helped us we could have rebuilt this year," he said. "We thought they would help with timber and roof tiles. But now they say they will help us in the spring."
No one offered them much after July, Mr. Haxha said.
"They said everyone would have one warm room for the winter, and we don't have one," Mr. Haxha said. He has six children, two here and four in Germany. "They can't send me money because there is no bank," he said. "I'm waiting for them to come. But Germany wants to throw them out." Now that the war is over, Berlin and other European capitals are eager to send the ethnic Albanian refugees home.
In Pristina, senior United Nations refugee officials were upset to hear that no one had revisited Stari Trg, and promised to do so. They were relieved that the families had found their own shelter, however uncomfortable, and said that no one would turn them out.
The officials pointed to the progress they had made in providing emergency shelter for so many thousands, and all the obstacles they had overcome, from clogged borders and production delays to late financing from governments. Some 80 percent of the United Nations refugee agency's 16,000 emergency kits, mostly roof-quality plastic sheeting and stoves, has been delivered, they said, though other organizations were slower.
"This will be a hard winter," said the refugee agency's director here, Dennis McNamara, but he promised that no one in Kosovo would freeze to death. But many thousands, like the people of Stari Trg, will have to fend for themselves.
Here, Mr. Bala displays his pile of rusted rubbish. "Everything I had I put here," he said, showing the broken plates, melted pipes, charred alarm clock and the tool box, with his ruined tools, which he used when he worked as an electrician at the mine.
"I heard we should write down what we lost," Mr. Bala said forlornly, idly picking up the rusted runner of what had been a child's sled. "But I thought it's better for someone to see it." He paused, then said: "Of course, all the wooden furniture is lost. And I think they stole the television -- I couldn't find any parts of it."
He paused again. "But no one came to see. They gave us a paper in July to write down damage, but nothing happened."
He sobbed once, briefly, then recovered. "I couldn't even save the spoons."
Mr. Bala, who has four children, then gestured to some nearby ruins. "From this house, only one woman survived," he said. "Her husband, son and daughter were killed. So we should be happy we are alive."
Xheme Maksuti, nearly 70, was killed in the shelling. His son Ilaz, 35, and his daughter, Saba, 22, were shot to death by the Serbs as they tried to run away, Mr. Bala said. Only Naile Maksuti, 64, survived, he said, but he does not know where she is.
Workers from a local charity, the Mother Teresa Society, bring the people of Stari Trg packets of food from time to time, with beans, pasta and other proteins, originally donated by Western and United Nations agencies. And they have promised to provide a stove for the office.
Mr. Haxha walked in a tight circle, rubbing the moisture from his stubble. "How many promises did they make us before we returned?" he asked bitterly. "If they piled them all up it would make us four-story houses."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: A Virtual Oasis For Morocco Stocks;
Trading Going on Here? Shocking!

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: CASABLANCA, Morocco

 BODY:
The trading floor of the Casablanca Stock Exchange, with just 30 traders working in little computer cubicles, is as quiet as a church. And it is about to get even quieter.
Early next year, the trading floor is shutting down, exchange officials say, thrusting Casablanca's small, young, but technologically hip stock market into the growing ranks of virtual exchanges around the world.
As in London, Paris, Brussels, Toronto, Sao Paulo, Brazil, and a rising number of other places, brokers here will be trading directly from their own offices in a kind of miniature Nasdaq. 
 "We'll be cruising on the electronic highway," said Zouheir Bensaid, the immediate past president of the exchange and now a senior executive at one of the country's biggest financial companies, Group BMCE.
The conversion will add efficiency to domestic trading and make it technically possible for brokers anywhere to trade directly in the Moroccan market. It is an impressive step, and one that several other Middle East stock markets are expected to emulate in the coming year.
After long, sleepy histories, this region's stock exchanges have caught the attention of government officials as vital tools for selling state-owned companies and attracting foreign investors as they move from centrally planned economies to free enterprise.
And like the exchange here, in a mirror-paneled office block in downtown Casablanca, many are being revitalized with advanced systems and are attracting platoons of young Arab financial whizzes with M.B.A.'s and job experience in New York, London and Paris.
Casablanca's shift to decentralized, computerized operation comes as the New York Stock Exchange, one of the remaining great halls of hubbub and clanging bells, is debating a move toward greater automation. And it comes as the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, with its shouting and hand-waving traders, has introduced the same French-designed system the Moroccans are using.
But even if the countries in this region are in the technological vanguard, financial experts say, they will have to overcome significant impediments before they can expect the kind of foreign investment that has poured into the emerging markets of Asia, Latin America and Central Europe.
One problem for Morocco and neighbors like Tunisia, Lebanon and Jordan is size. Their markets are minuscule. There are 55 companies traded on the Casablanca exchange, with daily volume of about $6 million; in New York and London, many individual trades surpass that figure. Tunisia has about 40 listings; Lebanon has nearly a dozen. Jordan has more than 150 companies listed, but its daily trading volume is only about $3 million. Although the Cairo Stock Exchange lists more than 1,000 companies, daily volume there is only about $31 million.
Angus Blair, head of equity research on the Middle East and North Africa at the London office of ABN Amro, the Dutch investment bank and securities firm, said it was difficult for big international investors even to consider putting money into a market as small as Casablanca's. Mutual fund and pension fund managers routinely put $500,000 to $5 million in a single emerging-market stock. A daily volume of $6 million would not give them much room to maneuver. "You need to have high daily volumes so you can get in and out of a stock easily," Mr. Blair said. "The last thing you want is for it to be difficult to sell while the price is moving against you."
Another problem in Morocco is that share prices are higher than in the rest of the region -- more than twice the level, for example, of those in Egypt. That is because, in an attempt to husband foreign exchange, the government officially prohibits Moroccans from investing abroad. Having no place else to go, the insurance companies and the roughly 100 mutual funds that have sprung up here in the last few years compete for the few stocks traded here, pushing prices up.
Morocco, like some of its neighbors, has signed an agreement with the European Union that will eliminate tariffs and, experts say, probably lead to a loosening of foreign exchange and investing restrictions. But, they say, the changes will take years.
After soaring for several years, the market here has gone into a long slump, starting toward the end of summer last year. Foreign investors, who held about 6 percent of the market's shares, began taking their gains, financial experts say, to offset losses in Asia and the former Soviet Union. Local investors were scared and began withdrawing their money. From September to the end of December, the market lost 12 percent, but it still closed the year with a gain of 20 percent. This year, with the economy depressed by one of the country's periodic droughts, the market has been mainly flat.
But Rachid Ouali Alami, chairman of the Casablanca Stock Exchange, and many of his colleagues see better days ahead. In the coming year, he said, the Government is expected to offer, for the first time, a large number of shares in Royal Air Maroc, the national airline, as well as in the national telephone company. And one banker said work was under way on at least a dozen initial public offerings of private companies. One sign of confidence: Two new brokerage firms have just taken seats on the Casablanca exchange.
The big job for the financial community is to persuade more of Morocco's privately owned businesses to go public, enabling the exchange to grow. But, the financial experts say, that is not going to be easy. Karim El Fekkak, director general of ABN Amro in Casablanca, estimates that there are more than 500 companies with more than $1 million in capital that would be candidates for the exchange. But, like most businesses in Morocco, they are family owned and so far have shown little interest in sharing ownership.
One thing that makes them reluctant, said Eric Stoclet, head of Citibank in Casablanca, is that the family-owned companies "don't want to open their books." In Tunis the government has given tax breaks to companies that go public, and there has been talk of that here. But here, as in many emerging markets, financial experts say, the privately held businesses are believed to be enjoying substantial tax breaks already, and these would be hard for the government to top.
As free trade with the European Union develops, Mr. Fekkak said, competition from European imports is likely to push some private companies into the market in search of financing to expand and create economies of scale.
Like others in the region, the government here has been criticized for dragging out the process of selling off state-owned companies, which began in 1993. After decades of foreign domination before independence in the 1950's and 1960's, all the governments fear being accused of permitting foreigners to gain control of important segments of the economy. That is one reason governments in the region have put only minority shares of many companies on the market.
But in late summer the government here scored a big success. It auctioned off a license for a mobile phone company for $1.1 billion, about three times what was expected. And the winning bidders, a consortium of Europeans and Moroccans, said they expected to invest $800 million in equipment. The government, in effect, gave up a piece of paper -- the license -- in return for lots of money and, almost certainly, a huge improvement in telephone service in Morocco.
Eventually, the mobile phone company is expected to be traded on the stock exchange. (Such a company is a star of the Egyptian market.) But one of many government regulations that frustrate Morocco's young, aggressive financiers prohibits any company -- no matter how strong and stable it seems -- from selling shares until it has done business in the country for at least three years.
In another drag on the stock market, the government this summer introduced a capital gains tax of 10 percent, in response to pressures from real estate brokers who said investment money that once flowed to them was going into the stock market because of the tax advantages. Foreign investors were exempt, but the tax was an unsettling reminder of how terms of business can change overnight in Morocco and other emerging markets. Early next year, the United States Commerce Department plans to hold a conference in the United Arab Emirates to encourage Middle East governments to work on consistency in government administration and judicial procedures.
"On paper, the procedures here are clear," said Mr. Bensaid, who studied at Cornell University and received a degree in business at the University of Nevada. "But in practice, things are not that clear. Once you get involved in a problem in the courts, it can go on for 10 years."
Tension with Algeria over Western Sahara, which in 1975 Morocco claimed as an extension of its territory and where it still has troops, remains a lingering uncertainty. But for Morocco's financiers, the political picture brightened this summer with the ascension to power of King Mohammed VI after the death of his father, Hassan II, who had reigned for 38 years. Mohammed VI, 36, has permitted the return from exile of political opponents of his father and says he wants to reduce poverty and illiteracy. Illiteracy is more than 40 percent, among the highest levels in the Middle East.
The young people giving the Casablanca Stock Exchange its spark say that government officials, while cordial, have little training or experience in finance. By contrast, the financiers felt an instant rapport with the new king, they say, because of his youth and his professed interest in bringing change to Morocco. He is clearly different from the ministers and other men of his father's generation who have been running the government.
"Our king," Mr. Bensaid said, "is going to force those people to let us do our work."

HEADLINE: A Grateful Clinton Offers Encouragement to Bulgaria

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 22

 BODY:
President Clinton thanked Bulgaria today for supporting the NATO campaign against Slobodan Milosevic in nearby Yugoslavia and urged the struggling nation to stay the course of economic reform.
More than 10,000 people packed the central square under the glittering Cathedral of St. Alexander Nevsky -- the same spot where mass rallies 10 years earlier led to the overthrow of the Communist government -- and celebrated the visit with music and fireworks. 
 "I am very proud to be the first American president to visit Bulgaria -- a free Bulgaria," Mr. Clinton told the crowd in a 45-minute speech at dusk. "I am proud to stand in this place where voices were silenced for too long."
He arrived late on Sunday, a week into his European tour, which will end with a trip to Kosovo on Tuesday. The visit here was intended to reward Bulgaria for letting NATO planes use its air space in the Kosovo campaign last spring, to offer some encouragement, and to send a message to the Serbs only 30 miles away.
"I am told that during the recent war you could actually hear some of the bombs falling in Serbia from this square," Mr. Clinton said. "Tonight, I hope the people of Serbia can hear our voices when we say if you choose as Bulgaria has chosen, you will regain the rightful place in Europe Mr. Milosevic has stolen from you, and America will support you too."
The crowd of people -- most of whom were taught at an early age of the evils of America's imperialist ways -- roared with approval and shouted Mr. Clinton's name.
"It used to be dangerous to talk to foreigners," said Kiril Manov, 70, a retired lawyer who was bundled up against the chilly evening air. "We used to learn about the evils of America. Never did we think an American president would stand here."
During his visit today, Mr. Clinton laid a wreath at a soldiers' memorial, spoke with a small group of college students over a lunch of tabbouleh and skewered chicken, and slipped out to a jazz club with President Petar Stoyanov.
During his visit to Kosovo, his first trip there, Mr. Clinton is to meet military commanders, opposition leaders and American troops, and is expected to urge the Albanians of Kosovo to set aside revenge as they rebuild after the war.
"I think it's very important that Kosovo, in effect, not become the mirror image of Serbia," he told the Bulgarians.
During his speech, the president held out the possibility of NATO membership for Bulgaria in the coming years and thanked the nation for allowing the alliance's jets to streak over Sofia during the air campaign in Kosovo. "You stood with NATO," he said. "I know it was very hard for you to do."
But most of all, Mr. Clinton's visit was intended to leave a measure of hope to a country still struggling with the difficult transition from dictatorship to democracy.
"I ask you to remember what you left behind," he said. "A police state with no room for disappointment, because there was no hope for improvement. When nobody felt left behind because no one was allowed to get ahead. When there were no dreams and some Bulgarians were even robbed of their very identities, forced to change their names."
The border with Serbia lies just 30 miles to the east of Sofia, the Bulgaria capital, so close that a handful of NATO bombs that veered off course actually landed here. The sanctions against Yugoslavia, a onetime trading partner, have had a crippling effect on Bulgaria's economy, which already suffered from a steep drop in living standards and high inflation that followed the Soviet era, a period when Bulgaria was one of the most Stalinist of the East Bloc countries.
American support is considered important to the people here, where jobs are difficult to come by, salaries are low, and gray concrete-block architecture stands as a reminder of a Communist system that left little room for initiative. Mr. Clinton arrived without bringing any big offers of aid, but he talked of a continued partnership with Bulgaria.
"Most of the people living here are desperate with the economic situation," said Ognyan Minchev, the director of the Institute for Regional and International Studies in Sofia. "This visit is a sign of hope."
That is how Snezhana Popova saw it. She stood in the back of the crowd with two tiny flags in her hand, one from the United States and one from Bulgaria. Mr. Clinton's visit, she said, just had to help make things better.
"It's very difficult to get a well-paying job here," she said.
The remark that most encouraged her came midway through Mr. Clinton's speech when he talked of plans to encourage more United States companies to do business in Bulgaria.
Bulgaria is making a push for entry into the European Union, which Mr. Clinton said ought to happen one day. In closed meetings with President Stoyanov and Prime Minister Ivan Kostov, he discussed Bulgaria's effort to reduce and modernize its Soviet-era military, among other issues.
As he encouraged Bulgarians to continue their reform efforts, the president reminded them that democracy has been a long road for the United States. He said it has taken America more than two centuries "to overcome slavery and civil war, depressions and world wars, discrimination against women and ethnic and religious minorities."
Bulgaria was allied with the Germans in both world wars, but it came to the aid of its Jews when the Nazis sought to send them to concentration camps. Today, the country has a legacy of religious and ethnic tolerance that Mr. Clinton praised.
"We must help all of southeastern Europe choose freedom and tolerance and community," he said. "We must give all the people in this region a unifying magnet that is stronger than the pull of old hatreds that has threatened to tear them apart over and over again."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Technology Issues Continue to Help Nasdaq Index Climb

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Technology stocks continued their rapid ascent yesterday, carrying the Nasdaq composite index to its 14th record in the last 17 sessions. Gains in Internet stocks and big companies like Microsoft and Intel helped to fuel the advance.
Despite the gains in Nasdaq stocks, the other main stock gauges were mixed. 
 "It is a surprise to a lot of us to continue to see the market act the way it is acting," said Ned Collins, head stock trader at Daiwa Securities America. "It continues to beat all expectations."
At the close, the Nasdaq composite index was up 23.31 points, to 3,392.56. Since the start of the month, the index has gained more than 14 percent.
Big gains in several old-line blue chips, including Coca-Cola, AT&T and I.B.M., helped to push the Dow Jones industrial average up 85.63 points, to 11,089.52.
But the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 1.06 points, to 1,420.94. And the Russell 2000 index of small companies dipped half a point, to 460.77.
Microsoft, a component of all three main market gauges, was the biggest positive influence in yesterday's session, traders said. The stock jumped 4 3/16, to 90 3/16, after Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who is presiding over the government's antitrust case against the company, named a mediator last week to try to help reach an out-of-court settlement.
"The news from Microsoft is probably the most positive corporate news out there," said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company in Boston.
Trading was brisk yesterday, but is likely to slow as the Thanksgiving holiday nears. The stock market will be closed on Thursday and will be open for a half-day on Friday.
More than 873 million shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange. On the Nasdaq market, 1.2 billion shares changed hands.
Coca-Cola was among the best-performing Dow stocks. The company jumped 4 7/8 a share, to 65 3/8, after a Merrill Lynch analyst issued a positive report on the company's prospects next year and raised his rating on Coke shares.
AT&T was also a big winner, rising 5 7/16, to 52. And I.B.M. gained 4 1/16, to 108.
Among Internet stocks, Exodus Communications jumped 17 3/16 a share, to 118 3/16, after the company, which manages Internet sites for other companies, announced a two-for-one stock split effective Dec. 14. It is the third time the company has split its shares this year.
Electronic Arts rose 14 9/16, to 106 9/16, after the video-game publisher said it had signed a deal to provide all content to America Online's games site.
A rise in long-term interest rates, prompted by a jump in spot oil prices, did not help financial service stocks.
Shares of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter fell 1 9/16, to 122 13/16. Citigroup dropped 1, to 55 1/2. And Chase Manhattan fell 1 1/8 a share, to 81 7/8.
The rise in oil prices, though, did little to help big oil company stocks. The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, an S.& P. component, fell 5/8 a share, to 62 3/4. Mobil declined 1 1/16, to 103 7/8. And BP Amoco lost 1, to 59 7/16.
"The immediate effect of a sharply spiking oil price is negative for the majors," Mr. Hogan said, "because they hedge their positions for a long ways into the future. Also, these companies are much more diversified than they used to be. So it doesn't go hand in glove that a spike in oil prices is good for the majors."

Treasury Yields Jump
 By Bloomberg News
 Treasury bond yields rose yesterday to their highest level this month, as surging oil prices and a drop in the dollar raised concern about quickening inflation.
Bond prices fell for the fourth time in five sessions, as investors became increasingly concerned that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates again in coming months to curb inflation. It raised rates last week, the third time in five months, and said that risks to sustainable growth persist.
"With the resurgence in world growth and higher oil prices, we have higher rates to look forward to," said Christopher Sullivan, chief investment officer of the United Nations Federal Credit Union.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 12/32, to 99 5/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.19 percent from 6.16 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: In New Jersey, Judges Make Their Case For a Raise

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Nov. 22

 BODY:
State judges need a raise, the chief justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court told a special legislative panel today.
Appearing at a hearing of the Public Officers Salary Review Commission at the governor's office here, Chief Justice Deborah T. Poritz said that judges' low pay, relative to their counterparts in other states and to arbitrators in private practice, had damaged morale and threatened the state's ability to keep strong judges. 
 "I wanted to emphasize, on my part, that judges in the state have had only one salary increase in 10 years, and they work under enormous pressure, with one of the highest workloads of any state," she said. "I think I can say to you, without hesitation, that morale is very low."
The salary commission was created in March by a joint resolution of the State Senate and Assembly to review the salaries of judges in the Office of Administrative Law, which now start at $81,900, up through the salary of the chief justice herself, who makes $138,000 a year, $5,750 more than her associates on the State Supreme Court. Superior Court trial judges, the most common variety of state judge, make $115,000 a year. Trial judges received a 15 percent raise in 1996, their first increase since 1986.
Judge Barbara A. Harned, director and chief judge in the Office of Administrative Law, asked the commission to peg her judges' salaries to those of Superior Court trial judges to ensure that the administrative judges' pay does not continue to fall behind that of their trial court counterparts.
Workers' compensation judges, by formula, make 90 percent of what trial judges make. Nonetheless, Judge Paul Kapalko, director and chief judge of the Division of Workers' Compensation, also appeared before the commission asking for a raise. Judge Kapalko said first-year associates at some law firms earn more than the judges they face.
No members of the general public attended the hearing, and no one spoke against raises. The salary commission is also charged with reviewing the pay of state legislators, who make $35,000 a year; cabinet members and county prosecutors, who each make $115,000, and the governor, whose salary is set at $130,000, although Gov. Christine Todd Whitman accepts only $85,000.
It will be up to legislators and the governor to act on the commission's recommendations, although increases will not apply to them in their current terms. The commission chairman, James A. DiEleuterio Jr., a former state treasurer who is now president of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, said there was no schedule for completing the review. A hearing on legislative salaries is scheduled for Monday.
Asked after the hearing for his impression, Mr. DiEleuterio said, "Certainly, if you take a look at the statistical information, it looks as if the judges in New Jersey are underpaid compared with other states."
Trial court judges in New Jersey have the seventh-highest salary in the nation, behind judges in New York ($136,700), Illinois, Alabama, Delaware, Virginia and Florida. But New Jersey drops to 28th, just behind Utah, when the figure is adjusted for cost of living. Inflation has also eroded judges' real wages, said Chief Justice Poritz. In 1970, for instance, trial judges made $37,000 a year, translating to $158,776 in 1999 dollars, according to figures submitted to the commission.
Chief Justice Poritz said raises for judges had lagged behind raises for many other state employees. She said that while judges' salaries rose 15 percent, some state salaries went up 98 percent, including automatic increases for seniority and merit-based pay raises.
Commission members said that paying enough to attract and keep outstanding people was difficult in all branches of government, particularly for elected lawmakers reluctant to anger taxpaying voters.
"It's a political problem," said a commission member, Samuel F. Crane, who was state treasurer under Gov. Jim Florio. "If this were a $20 billion corporation," Mr. Crane said, using figures for the state budget and the treasurer's salary, "could you find a chief financial officer who would work for $115,000?"

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
In Trash Fight, Aiming Pebbles at Goliath

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

DATELINE: ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 22

 BODY:
What to make of this mayor who started the garbage war against New York City?
J. Christian Bollwage (the J stands for James and the surname is pronounced BOWL-wage) has quite publicly battled the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on its real-estate-management practices and its jet-noise proclivities. Before that, Mr. Bollwage, as a fifth-ward Democratic councilman in 1992, picked off then-Mayor Thomas G. Dunn, who had held City Hall firmly in his grasp for 28 years. 
 And today he was wholly unrepentant here in the fastness of his rebel base at City Hall. "It's a David and Goliath situation," said the mayor, leaning forward intently in his studded red-leather chair and transfixing a visitor with his abrupt blue eyes. "The largest city in the country is imposing its will on this small municipality. Well, like David, we have a few pebbles in our basket. And we're going to throw them."
Mayor Bollwage brought the undersized but enthusiastic might of Elizabeth to bear against an armada of New York City sanitation trucks, under orders to schlep an estimated 1,200 tons of garbage daily from Staten Island to waste-transfer stations in this city of 110,000.
In response, the 44-year-old Mayor has commanded his police skirmishers to issue summonses to New York trash vehicles intruding on this ordinarily hospitable 10.6-square-mile blue-collar enclave. Such harassment "is a fight to make trash moving economically not feasible for New York City," he said.
An adjunct professor at Kean College who has a fondness for military metaphors, the mayor likens the tussle to a war, in which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is "Rommel, the Desert Fox," Mr. Bollwage said, adding, "Elizabeth isn't Patton, we don't have the force to crush our opponent, but I liken us to George Washington, who husbanded resources and carefully chose his shots."
On Friday, George Washington suffered a setback when a Superior Court judge in Union County denied Elizabeth's bid for a temporary restraining order preventing transfer stations from receiving Staten Island waste. The judge set a hearing for Jan. 31. "We don't see this as a defeat," Mr. Bollwage said. "Now we have a chance to make our case."
Mayor Bollwage's, um, trashy little war began in September when New York City let it be known that all of Staten Island's residential garbage would be sent to private waste stations in Elizabeth before being shipped to out-of-state landfills.
Mr. Bollwage charged that noisy New York sanitation trucks would disrupt the tranquillity of Elizabeth, polluting its air, damaging its streets and their 100-year-old sewers and menacing an elementary school.
Beyond this is the image-insult problem, since "New York is trying to say that we are still a town that can be dumped on," the mayor contended. "But we've changed over the last few years," he added, proffering statistics showing a decline in unemployment to 7 percent from 14 percent in 1993, and a 30 percent crime reduction over the last three years.
Not to take this personally or anything, but exactly what's so leper-colony about the garbage of New York? "Unlike New Jersey's solid waste, New York's trash has a high content of unrecycled cans and bottles," Mayor Bollwage said. "It's filled with dangerous things like unrecycled batteries."
BUT doesn't messy, trash-rich New York have any right not to be overwhelmed by waste? "In 1987, New Jersey began creating a network of transfer stations and incinerators and made recycling a priority," the mayor said. New York City's "only solution," he said, "was to impose their problem on others."
The two-term mayor's stand against alien garbage has defanged even some of his harshest detractors. "At this time the people of Elizabeth are behind him," said third-ward Councilman Bob Jaspan, a frequent mayoral critic. That said, Mr. Jaspan contended that "part of the mayor's stance is for publicity," adding, "It would have been much better if the mayor of Elizabeth and the mayor of New York had called each other on the phone instead of having press conferences." Mayor Bollwage countered that "no one in New York has ever called us, and therefore the only dealings we have with New York City are through the press."
Such dealings make his day. In his own words, There is "no better job than being mayor of the town you grew up in." He was born on Bellevue Street, one of five children of Frank and Jeanne, a letter carrier and a homemaker. He graduated from St. Mary's High School in 1972, and worked his way through Kean College in Union over nine years, winning a subsequent master's degree in public administration. The mayor and his wife, Nancy, are expecting their first child in May.
The triumph of the Bollwage years, according to the mayor, is the newly opened $360 million Jersey Gardens Outlet Mall in Elizabeth. But Mr. Jaspan said he was worried that thanks to the mayor's borrowing and debt restructuring, Elizabeth was "up to our limit and over our head in borrowing capacity."
The mayor countered by pointing with pride to the fact that last month Moody's Investors Service upgraded Elizabeth's bonds from Baa to A. Could that rating improve if, trashwise, Elizabeth were a New York-free zone? "David took his time in facing Goliath," the Mayor answered. "Only time will tell whether Goliath will win."

HEADLINE: Survey Finds Race-Relations Gap In Armed Services, Despite Gains

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Despite a decades-long effort to promote equal opportunity and good race relations in the armed forces, the Pentagon has found that wide gaps remain between how whites and minority uniformed personnel perceive how they are treated.
In a survey of more than 40,000 members of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines and Coast Guard, the Pentagon also found that a large proportion had experienced what they considered to be a racially offensive encounter, often from a superior, in the 12 months before the survey was taken. 
 The survey, the largest and most detailed effort to discern racial attitudes ever undertaken by any institution, military or civilian, generally painted an encouraging picture of race relations, indicating that large numbers of military personnel felt comfortable living and working around people of another race and formed close friendships across racial lines.
Even so, the survey found that when military personnel filed complaints about particularly bothersome incidents, 51 percent said nothing was done.
And the survey found that 34 percent of white, 47 percent of Hispanic and 48 percent of black personnel said that some of these incidents caused them to lose trust or have negative feelings about their colleagues, a finding that could be particularly troubling to a military that strives to promote cohesiveness and teamwork.
The survey's findings were a bit of a disappointment to current and former Pentagon officials. The military, especially the Army, has prided itself on doing more than perhaps any institution in the country to foster a good racial climate and promote equal opportunities.
The Defense Department's efforts have drawn acclaim from some academics and politicians, including President Clinton, who has praised efforts in the area of race relations and affirmative action.
"This tells us that even the military, which we still believe is ahead of the rest of society, still has some racial tensions," said Edwin Dorn, former under secretary of defense for personnel and readiness, who commissioned the survey and has been briefed on its findings. "The results of this survey are not nearly as wonderful as we might have liked. It gives a good sense of the kinds of things that need to be worked on."
Many of the survey's findings indicate that the military has created a much more tolerant racial climate than most other institutions in American society, and that in many ways racial attitudes in the armed forces are more tolerant than they are in the civilian world.
For example, 82 percent of white members of the armed forces who responded said they had a close personal friend who is black. In a comprehensive poll of Americans taken in 1997 by the Gallup Organization, only 59 percent of whites reported having a close black friend.
At the same time, however, the survey also found that members of minorities, especially African-Americans, tended to hold a more pessimistic view than whites of race relations in the military.
Minority service personnel also are much more likely to say they have received a poor evaluation because of their race or ethnicity, compared with whites, and are more likely to believe that the armed forces have paid "too little" attention to discrimination based on race or ethnicity, according to the survey.
Particularly telling was the fact that 17 percent of whites who responded felt the military did not pay enough attention to the problem of race discrimination. In contrast, 38 percent of Hispanic personnel and 62 percent of black personnel said they felt that way.
Pentagon officials cautioned that further study of the survey's findings was required before any solid conclusions or policy recommendations were proposed.
"This gave us initial answers," said William E. Leftwich 3rd, deputy assistant secretary of defense for equal opportunity. "I have to say these initial answers are not enough."
To conduct the study, the Defense Manpower Data Center, a Defense Department agency, sent out a 16-page form to 76,754 soldiers, sailors and aviators from September 1996 to February 1997.
The confidential forms were mailed to enlisted personnel and officers up to the rank of captain in the Navy and Coast Guard and its equivalent rank, colonel, in the Army, Air Force and Marines. About 53 percent of the questionnaires were returned in usable form, a relatively high percentage for surveys returned by mail.
The exercise was mandated by legislation pushed by Ronald V. Dellums, a former Democratic representative from Berkeley, Calif., who was chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. The survey is the first of a series of comprehensive studies on race relations in the military. Pentagon researchers say they will be conducting another next year.
Even as the survey suggested that the military must still grapple with racial issues, another report by the Pentagon indicated that the armed forces had a mixed record when it came to promoting minorities.
The report, "Career Progression of Minority and Women Officers," indicated that in 1997 minorities made up 15.3 percent of all officers, and women 14.1 percent, up from 7 percent and 5.9 percent, respectively, in 1977.
But the report said that while the promotion rates for white men and white women were about the same, African-American men and women were being promoted at a much lower rate.
Pentagon officials attribute the discrepancy in the promotion rates to factors that were not necessarily related to race. For example, members of minorities and women tended to be more heavily clustered in administrative and support units in the military. These areas tend not to provide the faster track for promotion that combat units do. Also, Pentagon officials acknowledge that the military does not do a good job of mentoring women and minority personnel who show potential to become officers or move up the officer ranks.
