HEADLINE: Republican Governors, Wanting One of Their Own, Decided Early on Bush

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: CARLSBAD, Calif., Nov. 20

 BODY:
More than one Republican governor looked at making a presidential run this year, and there was a touch of envy directed at the one who ultimately did. When Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin decided against a campaign, he observed that his Texas counterpart had a more famous name and more money, was better-looking and came from a much bigger state.
"Other than those few little things," Mr. Thompson said, "I'd have been the front-runner." 
 As Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah puts it now, "It became pretty clear pretty early that the one among us on whom fate seemed to be settling was George W. Bush."
Even before Mr. Bush emerged, the nation's Republican governors, eager for a greater say in the affairs of the national party in 2000 and privately irritated with what they regarded as Congressional Republicans' bungling of public sentiment, had largely concluded that the time had come to nominate one of their own for president.
Now Mr. Bush has assembled a remarkably unified team from the ranks of the Republican governors -- the chief executives of 31 states, and of 8 of the 9 most populous -- with whom he frequently consults for both campaign advice and policy ideas. Many of them endorsed him long before he officially jumped into the race in June, and led fund-raising drives that helped him amass more campaign money than any other presidential candidate in history.
The Republican governors are united behind Mr. Bush not so much by any firm ideological ties as by the concerns that all governors share and by a common hope among the Republicans that, as Gov. John Engler of Michigan put it, "a Republican president in Washington would be enormously helpful" in reducing the power of the federal government and granting more to the states.
Indeed, the governors' own ideologies range from the moderate stances of Northeasterners like George E. Pataki of New York and Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey to the staunchly conservative views of some Westerners and Southerners like Mike Foster of Louisiana.
But any such differences are clearly being shelved, at least for now, and a visitor to the recent meeting of the Republican Governors' Association in this Southern California community might well have confused the event with a Bush-for-President strategy session. It was here that the governors gathered not only to discuss campaign themes but also to vote their support for Mr. Bush, the first such endorsement with a primary battle still under way in the organization's 36-year history.
The governors hold regular conference calls with Mr. Bush, and he often refers to them as some of his closest friends in politics or singles them out for praise in campaign speeches. One of them, of course -- Jeb Bush of Florida -- is his younger brother.
That the governors could wind up playing so large a role says a great deal about their popularity among the public. While a recent New York Times/CBS News poll found that just 37 percent of respondents approved of the way the Republican-controlled Congress was handling its job, many Republican governors boast approval ratings that are nearly twice as high. The governors are reaping the benefits of a strong national economy, which has allowed them to cut taxes and increase spending on popular programs at the same time. They also seem to fare better than their Congressional counterparts because the public does not associate them with the drive to impeach President Clinton.
In interviews at the meeting here, many governors said Mr. Bush had brought a fresh political attitude to the party.
"He basically adopts the strategy that you concede no issue, you concede no voter, you concede no region," said Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania. "Every voter's an opportunity. For too long, there's been a notion that maybe we can win nationally if we can put together the least common denominator: 'Let's figure out how we can get just enough to win.' And George's approach, my approach, the approach of a lot of governors, is, 'Hey, how do we put our arms around this whole thing and get as many votes as we possibly can?' "
Governor Engler, a vigorous Bush backer, said that as early as last year he and his colleagues were holding informal talks about advancing a governor as the party's next candidate for the White House.
"Certainly there was discussion among the governors about the advisability of leading with our strength in the next presidential election," he said, in the kind of comment that reflects continuing tensions between Republicans in the governors' offices and Republicans in Congress.
And Mr. Bush, for all the reasons that Governor Thompson well knew, quickly emerged as the informal consensus choice.
"We didn't all go out and do our secret handshake and do a vote," Governor Engler said. "That didn't happen. But there was just a clear sense that George W. Bush would be a very good president and a feeling, 'Hey, let's go out and do it.' "
Their shared outlook and familiarity with the man they have now endorsed only enhance the prospect of payoffs for the governors: cabinet posts, perhaps, should he win election, or maybe a spot on the national ticket as his running mate.
Nearly all the governors say it is far too early to speculate on the makeup of a ticket, and Mr. Bush, should he gain the nomination, might well get advice to pick a running mate with Congressional experience.
But at least a few of the governors are willing to promote the idea of a vice-presidential nominee from among their own ranks.
" 'Outside of Washington' works," said Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut. "A governor would be perfect," he added, before suggesting his colleague from Pennsylvania: "Tommy Ridge would be great."
And Ms. Whitman, who has been mentioned as a possible vice-presidential candidate, said a Congressional career was not so vital a prerequisite as it used to be for a running mate of a governor seeking the presidency: "balance" of that kind is simply no longer deemed so crucial.
"Frankly, I don't think the public is particularly enamored of D.C. experience these days," she said. "I think it is very important to have had executive experience."
As a rule, the governors promote themselves as more moderate and more pragmatic than many Congressional Republicans. Frank Keating of Oklahoma, departing chairman of the Republican Governors' Association, calls the states "hothouses of experimentation" in which the governors are leading a "solution revolution."
Thad Beyle, a political scientist at the University of North Carolina, echoes the thought, noting for instance that it was the states that took the lead in promoting the vast welfare overhaul ultimately adopted by Congress.
"They feel they had to virtually go out and get welfare reform done," Mr. Beyle said of the Republican governors. "They do not want another U.S. senator or a national figure from the Republican Party to be the leader in 2000. They want someone who has felt the fire of being in the governor's chair."
The concerted effort on Mr. Bush's part was led by several governors, including Mr. Engler, Paul Cellucci of Massachusetts and Marc Racicot of Montana, who, beginning early this year, called colleagues around the country urging them to endorse him, even as he was saying he would not make up his mind about running until after the Texas legislative session ended in May.
Gov. Bob Taft of Ohio remembers getting a call from Mr. Engler but replying that he would hold off since an Ohioan, Representative John R. Kasich, was in the race. "Then the day after John dropped out" in July, "Marc Racicot was on the phone," Mr. Taft recalled. "And it was, 'O.K., can you do it now?' "
An earlier Bush boomlet occurred in February at a meeting of the National Governors' Association, where several other governors announced for Mr. Bush. "It was the only spontaneous thing I've seen happen in R.G.A./N.G.A. politics in five years," Governor Rowland said with a laugh.
Others who had held off on shelving their national ambitions eventually saw the light.
"I watched George Bush come out of the blocks so fast," Mr. Thompson said. "And as he did, I thought, 'I better get on that horse.' " Mr. Thompson, who calls Mr. Bush a "wonderful candidate," endorsed him this summer.
Another factor in Mr. Bush's favor was that many of the governors had long links with the Bush family, dating from his father's run for the White House starting in 1979. Mr. Ridge, for instance, led that Bush campaign's effort in Erie County, Pa., and as vice president, George Bush returned the favor with campaign help during Mr. Ridge's successful run for Congress in 1982.
For his part, Governor Bush has done nothing to dampen speculation that he might just tap a fellow governor to run with him if he wins the nomination. He has even registered BushEngler, BushPataki, BushRidge and BushWhitman as names for Web sites, though his campaign says that it has reserved many other such names and that no preferences should be read into the move.
Indeed, though naturally parrying questions about a vice-presidential selection, Mr. Bush certainly does nothing to rule anybody out. During a two-day fund-raising tour of Pennsylvania in June, when he and Governor Ridge took a break to go for a run along the Susquehanna River, he jokingly referred to Mr. Ridge as his "jogging mate."
And in Iowa in August, he ran into Governor Thompson, who was helping to promote his successful bid to win a straw poll there.
"It's Tommy T.!" said Mr. Bush, throwing his arms around the man who had wanted to run for the presidency himself but declined in the face of the Bush juggernaut. "Tommy T.," Mr. Bush said, "he's the best. I know how lucky I am to have him with me."

HEADLINE: Tiffany's Owns the Building Once Again

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Fifteen years after Tiffany & Company sold its flagship store on Fifth Avenue, the jewelry maker has repurchased the property, which was the setting for Truman Capote's novel "Breakfast at Tiffany's."
The luxury jeweler, whose robin's-egg-blue gift boxes are an international status symbol, paid $94 million for the 10-story building at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 57th Street. Just as there are few bargains in Tiffany's bejeweled showcases, the building did not come cheap: Tiffany paid $29 million more than it got for the building in 1984. 
 "That location became known as the Tiffany corner," said Scott Latham, managing director with CB Richard Ellis, a real estate brokerage. "It's a good defensive move. Their lease comes up for renewal soon, and I think they were going to get clobbered. Of course, $94 million is a major league commitment to lock up that location."
It was business as usual yesterday beneath the soaring first-floor ceiling of Tiffany's.
"The building serves as a tangible symbol of our retailing and merchandise initiatives throughout the world," Michael J. Kowalski, president of Tiffany, said in a statement last night. "In financial terms, the tradeoff between the cost of leasing and the cost of ownership is not expected to have any effect upon earnings."
Whatever its symbolic value for Tiffany, the property was something of a loser for the Japanese company, Daiichi Real Estate Company, that sold it. Daiichi bought the building for $94.35 million at the height of the real estate boom in the 1980's. But when the recession hit in 1991, property values dropped by 50 percent or more, leaving Japanese buyers like Daiichi with grossly overpriced investments. The once eager buyers have been sellers ever since.
"The Japanese banks and insurance companies are trying to clean up their balance sheets," said Jack Rodman, the director of Asian-Pacific operations for Ernst & Young. "None of these investments was a home run."
In a sign of the times last year, Ernst & Young changed the name of its annual report "Asian Investment in United States Real Estate" to "United States Investment in Asian Real Estate."
From 1987 to 1989, the Japanese went on a $7.4 billion shopping spree in New York, buying trophy properties like Rockefeller Center. That spawned a xenophobic reaction from critics who decried the sell-off of American landmarks. But New York trophies lost their luster when the recession hit Japan and New York real estate almost simultaneously.
"For the most part, it was not a profitable shopping trip," said Richard Baxter, a senior managing director at Insignia/ESG Capital Advisers. "The Germans are now the largest buyers of real estate, but unlike the 1980's, everything trading today has some economic justification."
Mitsubishi Estates walked away from its billion-dollar investment in Rockefeller Center when rents failed to cover the mortgage payments. Mitsubishi, however, still owns a couple of adjoining skyscrapers on the Avenue of the Americas.
Shuwa Investments recently sold the 41-story ITT Building, at 1330 Avenue of the Americas and 53rd Street, for almost $200 million to a German investment fund. Last year, Shuwa sold a building at 551 Madison Avenue. Japanese owners also sold the Essex House on Central Park South and the Four Seasons hotel.
Sumitomo Realty, which paid $488.6 million 11 years ago for the Tishman Building, at 666 Fifth Avenue, accepted bids last week for the 39-story skyscraper that were expected to exceed the original purchase price.
For Daiichi, the art deco Tiffany building qualified as a trophy more because of its tenant than its architecture. The famed jeweler had first moved there in 1940, from its original landmark palace on Fifth Avenue at 37th Street. The building is the largest column-free retail store on Fifth Avenue and the corner of 57th Street soon became synonymous with luxury. After an expensive management buyout of Tiffany & Company from Avon Products, Avon sold the land and the building in 1984 to an investment group from Texas for $66.5 million. Tiffany then leased the space. With a real estate market in a frenzy, the investors sold the property a year later to Daiichi for a fast $27.85 million profit. Despite the jump, the Japanese landlord never got a rent increase.
According to real estate executives, Daiichi, which was represented by Kennedy-Wilson International in the Tiffany sale, will also sell its building at 1 East 57th Street, home to the Warner Brothers Studio Store.

HEADLINE: Denouncing U.N., Iraq Cuts Oil Sales Used to Buy Food

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Iraq today unexpectedly began to cut off the oil it is allowed to export in exchange for food and other basic supplies, after the Security Council extended the program for only two weeks.
Fred Eckhard, the United Nations spokesman, said independent experts reported this morning that Iraq had cut the flow of oil to the Turkish port of Ceyhan and was preparing to stop shipments from the Iraqi port of Mina al Bakr on Tuesday. Those ports are Iraq's main export points. 
 The Iraqis said the cuts were ordered to protest the Security Council's failure last week to extend the program for six months, as in the past. After Russia tried to improve the terms of the oil-for-food program for Iraq, the council chose to extend the program for only two weeks.
The United Nations permits Iraq to export controlled amounts of oil in exchange for basic supplies, to mitigate the effects of long-term sanctions ordered against the government of President Saddam Hussein. The sanctions were imposed because of the government's failure to demonstrate that it had eliminated production of weapons of mass destruction.
Iraq exported more than $7 billion worth of oil over the last six months, an amount that equals about 5 percent of the oil sold worldwide.
After the Iraqi cutbacks, crude oil prices rose in the New York market by almost a dollar, to more than $27 a barrel, a nine-year high.
Iraq's rationale for cutting its exports was not immediately evident to diplomats here.
In the past, Iraq has repeatedly generated crises to pressure its adversaries, and some diplomats thought that President Hussein would use any cutoff of food to claim that the economic sanctions were causing ordinary people to suffer. The initial speculation was that the cutoff of oil exports was temporary.
If Iraq fails to carry out the program, "it will be thumbing its nose at the international community again," said James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman.
"Every time that Iraq shows its contempt for the world, and its contempt for the world's concern about the people of Iraq, it only makes it harder for Iraq's positions to be taken seriously in the Security Council," he said.
The Security Council debate has focused on reaching an agreement among the five permanent members -- Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States, each of which can veto an agreement -- to send disarmament inspectors back into Iraq after a year's absence.
The efforts have been focused on finding a formula that Russia, Iraq's main ally on the council, would not reject.
Some diplomats say the Iraqis may have been stunned by reports that the Russians might be willing to drop their strong advocacy for Iraq. Reports last week suggested that Moscow had informally offered the United States a deal to soften Russian opposition to a Western resolution on Iraq, in return for American restraint in criticizing Moscow's war in Chechnya.
The Russians deny that such an offer was made.
France, which at times has argued on Iraq's side, is now considered part of the consensus behind a tougher resolution demanding that Iraq accept and cooperate with arms inspectors. In return, Baghdad would get a suspension of sanctions -- but not a total removal of sanctions, and only for renewable periods.
The French say they are concerned that Iraq, with a record of secret prohibited arms programs, is not being monitored. France is now expected to back the new inspection system being discussed.
Iraq has said repeatedly that it will not accept any inspection system that does not remove sanctions first. The government, which has long chafed under the close monitoring and tight financial controls of the oil-for-food program, may be trying to hold the program hostage at a critical moment to win concessions on both plans.
Diplomats and officials here say Iraq may be concerned that the oil plan and inspections may be dealt with as a package in the council, leaving little room for them to maneuver. The Russians have consistently rejected this linkage, but they made it more likely by putting off a normal extension last week after their delegation failed to change the terms in Iraq's favor.
The Security Council's permanent members are sharply divided on several parts of the arms-inspection plan. These include how long to wait before Iraq would qualify for a suspension of sanctions after demonstrating cooperation; how long the suspensions would run before being reviewed, and how independent a new inspection commission would be.
The danger for the United Nations is that by shutting down oil flows and continuing to oppose a new disarmament plan, Iraq might effectively free itself of foreign supervision.
That would raise the question of military action to enforce Security Council resolutions. The United States has been silent about such a possibility, in contrast to last year's bellicose policy, which led to the bombing of Iraq in December and the effective end of the old United Nations arms control system there.
United Nations officials were taking a wait-and-see attitude and were leaving the administrator of the program and his staff in place in Iraq, and civilian goods ordered earlier were continuing to flow to the country, said Mr. Eckhard, the United Nations spokesman.
"There are an awful lot of supplies in the pipeline, so our work doesn't need to stop just because the oil stopped flowing," he said. "Our hope is that this can eventually be worked out and they will continue the oil-for-food program."
The program -- which Baghdad has never liked because of the controls and monitoring of sales and purchases that came with it -- is intended to relieve the hardships of ordinary citizens.
Sanctions were imposed on Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait in August 1990. By late 1991, it was becoming apparent to the Security Council that the disarming of Iraq by the United Nations Special Commission would take considerably longer than expected and that the sanctions were beginning to take a toll on Iraqi civilians. The council offered President Hussein the first oil-for-food program, which was rejected by Iraq. Four years later, a second plan was presented to the Iraqis, who finally accepted it in 1996 after months of stalling, and goods began to arrive in 1997.
The current plan, as amended, allowed Iraq to export $5.26 billion worth of oil every six months. That amount has increased, in part because of the recent climb in oil prices.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 24, 1999, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about Iraq's move to cut off the oil it is allowed to export in exchange for food and other basic supplies misstated the reason United Nations sanctions were imposed on Iraq. They were imposed, in 1990, because of Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait. The reason was not the Iraqi government's failure to demonstrate that it has eliminated production of weapons of mass destruction; that is a reason they have not been lifted.

HEADLINE: LIFE'S WORK;
Sleeping With the Competition

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN; This column about the intersection of jobs and personal lives appears every other week. Lisa Belkin's e-mail address is Belkin@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I realized I would never marry my college boyfriend the day that he was chosen for a summer internship at The Washington Post and I wasn't. He did nothing so boorish as gloat; in fact, he barely dared to celebrate. But I ended things anyway. Perhaps I'm revealing more about my ego than is wise in a national publication, but I knew even then that I was too competitive to go through life with someone who did the same work as I.
A look at any workplace shows that the economy might cease to function if everyone felt this way. 
 "Where else do you meet people?" asked Fran Rodgers, chief executive of WFD, a consulting company in Boston that specializes in personnel issues. (Not coincidentally, her husband is second-in-command at WFD.) People spend more of their time at work, she says, and women are doing jobs once done mostly by men. The result? Corporate courtship.
One of Ms. Rodgers's clients found that 30 percent of employees who went through its training program married somebody else in the program. Add to that the spate of entrepreneurial start-ups begun by couples, and you have a good chunk of the population sharing work while sharing life -- navigating the territory that I ran away from all those years ago.
Talk to them and they start with the advantages. "We're both creating the marriage, and we're both creating the business," said Jeff Multz, who met his wife, Susan, when she was a client of his computer consulting company, Emerging Market Technologies, in Atlanta. She is now the company's president, and he, as vice president for sales and marketing, reports to her.
That sense of partnership is a common refrain. "We speak the same language," said Linda Safran, a medieval art historian who heads the department of Greek and Latin at the Catholic University of America in Washington. Her husband, Adam Cohen, is also a medieval art historian, and last year he took over her courses for three months when she was ordered to bed during a complicated pregnancy.
Even so, these work-love mergers can take some negotiating. When Susan Multz joined her husband's company, she remembers that every week "I was grabbing my keys and quitting." Why? Because, her husband answers drily, "I was the president and she wasn't." Instead of calling a marriage counselor, they brought in a management consultant who suggested that Susan take on the day-to-day operations of the company -- and the title of president.
The Cohen-Safran partnership is under a strain that would challenge even the savviest consultant. There are only half a dozen slots for medieval art professors in the Washington area, and all are filled, one by Professor Safran. As a result, Dr. Cohen can't find a job. Moving isn't an option; how many universities would have two openings for their esoteric specialty? So Dr. Cohen stays home, writes manuscripts, cares for 1-year-old Josiah and wonders if he should abandon his field.
He says he does not resent his wife as she leaves each day to do the work he is also trained to do.
"I'm angry all the time," he said, forcing a laugh, "but never at Linda."
I don't think I could be as selfless as all that. I'd be more like a dear friend of mine, a screenwriter out in California, whose husband just landed his dream job as a staff writer for a hit TV show. Unfortunately, it is also her dream job, and she is not taking it well.
"Sure, I'm happy for him," she said morosely. "But then I have to go back to my little office to write my pathetic little scripts." She finds herself reminding people, loudly and often, that at age 35 she is much, much younger than her 40-year-old husband. In other words, he had a head start.
My own 40-year-old husband and I have a different sort of buffering distance between us. Bruce is a physician who also runs a genetic research lab, and he writes in a language I can only pretend to understand. Yes, sometimes I miss the easy shorthand of couples who do the same things, but I'm pleased to trade that for the complete absence of competition. I am freed to be the best writer in the house, just as he is the best doctor.
That he will never scoop me on a story is hardly the reason that I married this remarkable man. But it sure is a relief to know that he won't.

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 1; Workplace 

LENGTH: 964 words

HEADLINE: When to Hold, When to Fold (a k a Retire)

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Seven days a week, for 9 or 10 hours each day, Merritt W. Huntington is on the job, negotiating deals and supervising a small staff. But he is no striving young investment banker or 20-something consultant on the make. He is a 73-year-old orchid grower.
Why does he keep at it? "It's a passion, I guess," said Mr. Huntington, owner of Kensington Orchids in Kensington, Md., the biggest orchid producers in the mid-Atlantic states. But something else prompts him to shake off his periodic reveries about living a life of ease: the belief that hard work will prolong his life. 
 Retirement is not for him.
"I saw too many people my age who lived another six months or two years and then they were gone," he said. So he is staying put, helped by his wife, Helen, 71, the company's bookkeeper.
Again and again, you hear the stories: People who keep working live longer. Sociologists say it is a little more complicated than that. To some extent, they say, old people who are healthy keep working simply because they enjoy working.
Still, they add, it is beyond dispute that active use of both one's mental and physical capacities promotes longevity. Inactivity can be hazardous to health. And you're more likely to use your mind and your muscle in an office or a factory than in a hammock. "Job conditions offering a challenge and the opportunity to do self-directed, substantively complex work increase intellectual flexibility," a study at the National Institute of Mental Health concluded. The effect, in fact, is "significantly greater" for older workers than younger ones.
It helps if people like what they are doing. Take Jean Sharp, who will turn 80 on Sunday and who sews seams in hosiery and leotards at Alsace Textile in Reading, Pa. She sees her work as a vital social connection as well as a source of money to pay off her mortgage, which has three years to go. She said she could not imagine what it would be like to retire.
"It's like family," said Mrs. Sharp, a widow whose son died at the age of 48. "We girls get along good. I think that's what keeps me going."
Mrs. Sharp is especially pleased that she is allowed to set her own hours, which average about 30 a week. "When I get there, I get there," she said, "and when I feel like leaving, I leave."
Such control over working conditions enhances job satisfaction and thus promotes health, social scientists say. It is probably for that reason, they add, that a study of British civil servants in the early 1990's found that those in higher-status positions with more control over their daily routines were healthier than those in low-status jobs.
"The higher you are, the better your health and the longer you live, even controlling for initial health-risk factors," said Dr. Richard M. Suzman, an associate director of the National Institute on Aging in Bethesda, Md.
Russell S. Bickel, 88, puts in more than 40 hours a week as a stockbroker for Prudential Securities in Wyomissing, Pa. Work for him these days is a comfortable routine in a business he has been part of since he dropped out of high school in 1928 and that gives structure to his life.
He has thought on occasion about retirement but decided he would be doing much the same thing at home -- "fooling around with investments" -- and that as long as he felt good and had enough customers, most of them with long-term horizons, he would just stay on.
But he says old people should either love their jobs or leave them.
"I can imagine myself in certain types of monotonous or repetitious jobs that I would be itching to get out of," he said. "I'd have my hand on the doorknob."
To be sure, the vast majority of Americans retire as soon as they can. The proportion of American men still working at 65 plummeted to 30.5 percent in 1985 from 71.7 percent in 1950, though it has since edged up to 33.7 percent.
Even those who are still toiling away recognize that at some point they will have to throw in the towel.
"I've told my bride that if she sees me slipping my marbles to not let me come to the office anymore," Mr. Bickel said. "I don't want to be the judge of that."
Moreover, there is the cause and effect question: Do people stay healthy because they keep working, or do they keep working because they are staying healthy?
"There's real problems of causation here," said Joseph F. Quinn, a dean and economics professor at Boston College with long experience in the field. "It's really important not to generalize about what's good or not good for your health."
Conclusive proof that work benefits health is very hard to find, because it is mostly people who are already in good health who choose to keep on working.
Statistical analysis has not solved the riddle, either. Specialists note, for example, that women who have never been in the labor force outlive men by the same margin as those who have worked for decades.
If older workers need a role model, it might well be Mary W. Walker, 85, a trust department administrator at First Union Bank in Philadelphia.
Ms. Walker was forced to retire at the age of 70, before Congress passed a law restricting such involuntary departures. But she didn't miss a beat; she linked up with a "temporary" employment agency and was assigned the very same job. Since then, the bank has gone through three mergers and today, a new temp agency, Manpower Inc., cuts her checks. But she is still there, doing what she always did.
In spring and summer, she loves to cap her day by walking seven miles from the First Union office in downtown Philadelphia to her home in the Germantown section. Because of an injury in a fall, she may have to forgo those strolls next year, but she will keep the job.
"I love office work," Ms. Walker said. "My doctor told me, 'Keep on working.' "

HEADLINE: Failures of Peace in Kosovo

 BODY:
President Clinton went to Kosovo yesterday primarily to pay a pre-Thanksgiving call on American troops and encourage ethnic reconciliation. His pleas for forgiveness toward the Serbs drew a predictably chilly reception. But his visit will be valuable if it draws broader attention to the serious problems bedeviling international rebuilding efforts in Kosovo. Last spring NATO used its military power to uphold humanitarian principle and allow hundreds of thousands of brutally uprooted ethnic Albanians to return to their homes. That precious victory must not now be allowed to degenerate into an unstable, unworkable peace.
More than five months after the withdrawal of Serbian forces, Kosovo still lacks basic water, electricity and sanitation services. With police scarce and courts nonexistent, criminals control the streets while non-ethnic-Albanian residents, whether Serbs, Gypsies or Bosnian Muslims, are being burned out of their homes. European donors have been slow in following through on their pledges of financial help and many countries have lagged in providing volunteers for the short-staffed international police. Officials from the United Nations and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe spend too much time and money building up their rival bureaucratic empires and not enough helping Kosovars create their own institutions. 
 Through the hard work of local inhabitants, Kosovo's private economy is starting to revive. But the international organizations have not been much help. They have failed to rebuild the power plants and waterworks sabotaged by the departing Serbs or the roads and bridges bombed by NATO. They have not moved fast enough to put the old Serb-run state companies into private local hands.
The U.N. and the O.S.C.E. seem intent on erecting bureaucratic structures for long-term international administration rather than encouraging eventual self-government. Able to offer much higher salaries than local employers, they have drawn educated Kosovars to their payrolls at the expense of schools, law offices and other professions. They have poured disproportionate resources into building competing official broadcast networks, siphoning money and talent that should be going to strengthen independent media.
NATO must also take responsibility for its failure to protect Serbs and Gypsies and preserve the possibility of a multi-ethnic Kosovo. Instead, most Serbs have either fled to Serbia or regrouped in the northernmost part of Kosovo. There French NATO commanders have wrongly tolerated a kind of unofficial partition, marked off by road barricades, that has left one of the province's most valuable economic resources, a lead and zinc mining and smelting complex, under Serbian control.
The peace in Kosovo is hardly lost, and Mr. Clinton was right to urge local civilians to be patient. Bernard Kouchner, the chief U.N. administrator, has shown an admirable willingness to listen to critics and occasionally change direction. But unless there is a significant reining in of the international bureaucracy and greater efforts to involve the Kosovars more directly in the economy and administration, the outlook is disheartening.

HEADLINE: Earthquake Helped to Lower October Durable Goods Orders

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Supply disruptions for computer and electronics makers after an earthquake in Taiwan led to a drop in orders for durable goods in October, government figures showed today. Demand for most other items increased.
Orders fell 1.3 percent last month after declining 1.9 percent in September, the Commerce Department said. A 15.3 percent drop in orders for electronics more than offset gains for military aircraft and heavy machinery. 
 "The outlook for U.S. manufacturing is really quite good," said Kenneth Mayland, chief economist at KeyCorp in Cleveland. "Strong domestic demand, a lean inventory situation, and recovering foreign economies will cause durable goods orders to rebound strongly." Analysts had expected orders to rise four-tenths of 1 percent.
Excluding the electronics category -- which includes semiconductors, communications equipment and household appliances -- orders rose 2 percent. Compared with figures in the month a year earlier, October's durables orders were 6.1 percent higher.
The drop in electronic equipment orders was the largest since a 16.6 percent decline in July 1997. The most recent drop was partly attributable to disruptions in the computer parts industry after a September earthquake in Taiwan, which "might have resulted in some firms putting off orders, if there was an interruption in some components deliveries to U.S. manufacturers," said Henry Willmore, an economist at Barclays Capital Group in New York.
The earthquake closed plants where computer chips, circuit boards and other parts for personal computers are made. That may have hindered production of chips at the Intel Corporation and Advanced Micro Devices and curtailed orders.
About two million chip orders for Intel were canceled after the earthquake, Dan Niles, an analyst at BancBoston Robertson Stephens, said in September.
Orders for transportation equipment rose 3.4 percent in October after falling 4.7 percent the month before. The increase was probably a result of a rise in orders for military aircraft, as orders for civilian aircraft fell 3.1 percent.
Excluding transportation, durable goods orders fell 2.6 percent -- the biggest drop since October 1998 -- after a 1.1 percent slip in September.
Orders for personal and business computers and other industrial machinery rose 2.8 percent in October after falling four-tenths of 1 percent in September.
The drop in demand for civilian aircraft came after an 18.4 percent decrease in September. The Boeing Company, the world's largest aircraft maker, reported only 3 orders in October, down from 20 in September, according to the company's Internet site. Boeing's orders numbers do not follow the government's statistics in lock step.
Manufacturing has recovered after suffering a drop in export demand caused by economic troubles in Asia and Latin America last year, analysts said. That should spur the economy to its longest-running expansion early next year, they added.
While domestic demand is staying strong, it is slowing from earlier this year. In the third quarter, personal spending rose at a 4.3 percent annual rate, down from 5.1 percent in the previous three months. As a result, order growth could start to slow.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1209 words

HEADLINE: In a Nonstop Economy, Truckers Keep Rolling

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: FRANKLIN, Ohio

 BODY:
Terry Wheat cherishes his new International Eagle 18-wheeler loaded with Budweiser beer, soon to be loaded with whatever the dispatcher assigns him next. "My truck is built strictly for comfort," he said. "My seats swivel and kick back." Behind the seats is his sleeper, with double decker beds, a television, a VCR, a refrigerator and his Nintendo games.
This is Mr. Wheat's cocoon, his home 341 days a year. Breaking off from the herd of hog-nosed gorillas thundering along Interstate 75 here, he said he drove 10 hours a day, seven days a week, for eight weeks straight. Then he gets four days off, a total of 24 days a year. He spends those days at home in Franklinton, La., with his wife and 6-year-old son. 
 "The reason I'm out here is my kid," said Mr. Wheat, who is 36 and earns 33 cents a mile driving more than 120,000 miles a year, or around $40,000. "He's got more than I ever had."
Mr. Wheat is proud of the work. "Anything that goes in a store, we carry," he said. And he likes the solitude. "You get your whole life in perspective," he said.
These are busy, good-money times for the nation's nearly 600,000 drivers of large trucks, those weighing more than 10,000 pounds. High employment, easy credit and free-spending consumers may be prosperity's engines, but these men -- nearly all are men -- are its mules. Truckers lug 81 percent of the value of all the nation's freight, and 60 percent of the tonnage.
Trucking is more hectic than ever, in part because the economy of the 1990's has assigned trucks a new function. They have become warehouses on wheels. Stores and factories, many tied to the Internet, have found they can cut costs by shrinking the warehouses where they store the materials they use in production or the goods they sell later to consumers. Instead, they rely on trucks to deliver the goods the moment they need them.
Propelled by this "just in time" method of inventory control, trucking company revenue is up more than 60 percent in this decade, to more than $400 billion, according to the American Trucking Associations, and the number of big trucks has risen 18 percent, to 1.7 million.
In April, the Department of Transportation toughened its fines for rule violations, like driving too long and ducking safety measures. And for the first time in 60 years, said Julie Cirillo, acting director of the Office of Motor Carrier Safety at the department, the Clinton administration is preparing new rules governing the hours that drivers work and sleep. "Twenty to 25 percent of the drivers," she said, "are not responsible."
The drivers here represent a subset of the American culture most akin to those who work the seas. They play havoc with the cycles of the sun and the moon. Required by law to rest for 8 hours after driving for 10, they can start driving on Monday at 8 a.m., stop at 6 p.m. and start on Tuesday at 2 a.m.
On a run early in November, Don Maxwell, 58, and his son Wayne, 34, both of Bremen, Ohio, order their main meal of the day, the popular Plaza Special for $7.40. It includes coffee, two slices of white toast and a plate stacked with three scrambled eggs, two round slabs of ham and a mound of hash brown potatoes.
The Maxwells, unlike most other drivers, are a team. They own a 445-horsepower, 1994 bunk-bedded Kenworth tractor that they bought used a year and a half ago for $56,000, about half what it would cost new. Taking alternating five-hour driving and sleeping turns, they can work 24 hours straight, with time out for showers and meals at truck stops.
Married, they get home to Bremen most Saturdays at noon and set off again just before midnight on Sundays. Currently, they haul groceries to Aldi discount food stores in Ohio, Kentucky and the Carolinas.
"We average about $1 a mile, loaded or empty," Mr. Maxwell said, three times the earnings of most other truckers, who do not own their tractors and earn nothing when moving empty.
But the Maxwells share the complaint of most other drivers. Starting out 23 years ago, the elder Mr. Maxwell said, "You didn't have to work as hard -- you run now." Company dispatchers get on the phone to them.
"Everything is 'on time,' 'on time,' " he said.
As yet, little real evidence shows whether tight scheduling endangers the highways. The fatality rate in accidents involving trucks last year was 2.33 for every 100 million miles, a record low. Alcohol is rarely a factor. Still, the absolute number of fatalities involving trucks has rarely dropped below 5,000 in two decades.
And some drivers here say they routinely break rules. They fudge their log books. Like passenger car drivers, they routinely speed. Unlike most passenger car drivers, they have citizen band radios to warn one another of lurking "smokies."
A 28-year-old Indianan, who would not give his name, said, "I can't drive totally legal and make good money. If I drove legally, do you know how much freight would still be sitting in a warehouse?"
In this driver-short, fast-moving economy, truckers who have a gripe with their dispatchers can quit and be driving another truck within a week, and many do.
"The average trucking company has a turnover rate of 100 percent annually," said Bob Costello, an economist at the American Trucking Associations.
Help-wanted advertisements for truck drivers filled an entire page of The Cincinnati Enquirer's classified ads on a recent Sunday. Company recruiters linger at truck stops. Typically, to induce drivers to switch, companies keep a tractor just three years, down from five a few years ago, so they can offer recruits something new.
Some truckers fashion a way of life that allows them to thrive through booms and busts. Torvey McAllister Jr. of Cadiz, Ky., 65, was hauling Toyota Corollas to the Budget Car Rental office at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago for H & H Transport of Murray, Ky.
Approaching his 1993 Peterbilt cab, his blue-eyed, pointy-eared, driving companion with savage incisors peers from the driver's seat. The companion is a usually docile, playful, year-old female timberwolf who is a terror to the thieves and prostitutes who cruise around ill-tended truck stops.
"I guess you can be a truckaholic," Mr. McAllister said. "I've hauled everything but furniture and gasoline. I sleep every night. I don't have to wear glasses. I've got a clean record. No accidents, knock on wood. I've had the same wife since January the sixth, 1959," the year he started trucking.
He said he felt little of many other drivers' pressure to hurry. "Nobody pushes anybody," he said. "I don't run illegal."
Drivers like Mr. McAllister exploit their freedom on the road in many ways, like changing course to reach a customer or stopping when they get the urge to stop.
More of that freedom is at risk today. To keep trucks running on time, many companies are fitting dashboards with satellite-linked computers that can tell when the truck is running or idle, or where it is within a block or two.
Cosmo A. Lippolis, a 60-year-old trucker from Baltimore who is hauling Serta mattresses from Indiana to Orlando, Fla., said the computer saved log-keeping paperwork and made it faster to get help after a breakdown or an accident.
Still, he said, "they're watching now."

SECTION: Section C; Page 11; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Hold Steady As Inflation Concerns Grow

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Reacting to investor fears that the economy will continue to race and that the Federal Reserve will be forced to respond by raising short-term interest rates again, bond prices fell slightly yesterday, leaving yields at their highest level in a month.
The price of the 30-year Treasury slipped 1/32, to 99 4/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, was unchanged at 6.19 percent. 
 In addition, the Government sold $15 billion of new two-year notes yesterday, and the dollar weakened against the Japanese yen, making dollar-denominated invesments like government securities less attractive to some foreign investors.
Kim Rupert, an economist for Standard & Poor's MMM, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, said that "as expected, the auction results didn't offer much inspiration for Treasuries.
"There is not a lot to look forward to tomorrow, but at least it's a shortened session," she added yesterday.
The bond market will close at 2 p.m. today in advance of the Thanksgiving holiday.
"You have an investment community fixated on equities," said Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at the J. W. Genesis Financial Corporation in Boca Raton, Fla. "Other investors, however, are mandated to buy fixed-income products. Trading is thin, with not a whole lot of conviction either way."
The two-year notes were awarded at 5.946 percent as expected, with the bid-to-cover ratio of 2.46 to 1 a little less than last month's ratio but better than average. "Today's two-year note was not auctioned in the most favorable environments and produced rather lackluster results," Ms. Rupert said.
The decline in the dollar also meant that imports were more expensive, and that will likely put upward pressure on consumer prices. Inflation fears are also being fueled by higher oil prices, and that is a negative for bonds.
Prices were briefly buoyed in the morning by a government report that showed an unexpected drop in orders for durable goods last month. But some analysts see the drop as evidence that companies are merely postponing purchases until the new year.
"This market is nervous," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Asset Management. "Indeed, another round of Fed tightening during the first quarter of next year has already been priced into the Treasury market, judging from the spread between the two-year note and the Federal funds rate, and this will likely remain a fixture of the yield curve until evidence suggesting the economy is slowing to a noninflationary pace begins to accumulate."
Even though the "economy is in a full-tilt boogie," Mr. Pugliese said, the Fed will need time to reassess its options and nothing is expected to happen until the first quarter.
The drop in durable good orders yesterday was a result of an outsized 15.3 percent decline in new orders for electronic equipment, which was attributed in part to an earthquake in Taiwan that closed plants that make computer chips. Many market participants think that some of this decline was also related to concerns about the Year 2000 computer problem, which would imply that orders would most likely be replenished in the future.
"In any event," Mr. Fine said, "new orders for durable goods at the current time are considerably stronger than at the same point last year, which bodes well for future production and implies that rising interest rates have not yet suppressed demand in this interest-sensitive sector of the economy."
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of two-year notes:
